title: Where to Eat in North Texas
description: If youre headed to Cowboys Stadium for the Super Bowl, Sam Sifton, The Timess restaurant critic, suggests a few places to eat.

title: For Fans With Texas-Size Appetites
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  The faithful have started to arrive in this drab, featureless city a little closer to Fort Worth than to Dallas. They have come sweat-panted and reverent to stand along Collins Street to photograph Cowboys Stadium, to walk the sidewalk surrounding its $1.2 billion form.

title: On Eating in Dallas
description: The sports desk sent me south last week to eat my way through the Dallas-Fort Worth metroplex in advance of Sundays Super Bowl between the Green Bay Packers and the Pittsburgh Steelers. I wrote an article about it for the Tuesday paper. And there is a multimedia feature that goes along with that piece.

title: Envoy to China to Resign, Weighing 12 G.O.P. Bid
description: WASHINGTON  The United States ambassador to China, Jon M. Huntsman Jr., delivered a letter of resignation on Monday to President Obama and intends to leave his position on April 30, a White House official said, clearing the way for him to explore a potential 2012 Republican presidential bid.

title: Sotomayor Reflects on First Years on Court
description: CHICAGO  Justice Sonia Sotomayor, speaking at a law school here on Monday, said she had taken heat at her Supreme Court confirmation hearings two summers ago in part because she was the first Hispanic nominee.

title: The Moment for Al Jazeera
description: Media reporter Brian Stelter examines the demand for Al Jazeera English during the Egypt protests.

title: Cairos Ornate (or Odd) Portals to the Past
description: The museums that Jason Larkin included in his Past Perfect portfolio look as if they belong in a museum.

title: Egypts Economy Is Near Paralysis
description: ALEXANDRIA, Egypt  Egypts economy approached paralysis on Monday as foreign commerce, tourism and banking all but halted, placing acute pressure on President Hosni Mubarak to find a way out of the weeklong chaos.

title: Same Names, but Different Pedigrees
description: The fifth round of the English F.A. Cup offers a romantic if mind-boggling matchup between two teams called the Red Devils: mighty Manchester United and minor league Crawley Town.

title: N.F.L. and Union Set Negotiating Meetings
description: DALLAS  Negotiating teams for the N.F.L. and the players union will hold a formal negotiating session here Saturday, and they have also agreed to a series of meetings over the next few weeks, the sides announced in a joint statement Monday.

title: Race to the Top of What? Obama On Education
description: On the morning after the State of the Union speech was delivered, John Hockenberry, co-host of the NPR program The Takeaway, read aloud President Obamas declaration that we want to prepare 100,000 new teachers in the fields of science, technology, engineering and math. Hockenberry commented: You scientists, engineers and techies know who you are; but what about the rest of us?

title: Figures of an Infant Jesus, Dressed for a Feast Day
description: Norma Castro laid the familiar figure on the counter before her, next to a basket of poblano peppers. Then, ignoring the twangy bachata music that blared from a nearby market stall, she furrowed her brow, delicately plucked it up and admired it.

title: Al Jazeeras Egypt Coverage Is Deep, but Hard to Find
Al Jazeera English Finds an Audience
description: White House officials have turned to Al Jazeera English among other television channels to monitor the mounting protests in Egypt. But most Americans lack the same ability to tune in to the broadcaster, which is based in Qatar, because cable and satellite companies in the United States have largely refused its requests to be carried.

title: Napolitano Accuses Critics of Politicizing Border Issues
description: Sharpening a confrontation with Republicans over Southwest border enforcement, Homeland Security Secretary Janet Napolitano said on Monday that crime and illegal crossings had dropped sharply along the border, and she accused lawmakers who say violence is out of control there of trying to score political points.

title: Super Bowl Marketers Try to Score Points, Too
description: MOST marketers that typically advertise in the Super Bowl sell brands with broad appeal and long histories, the better to resonate with the mass audiences that watch the game each year.

title: Obamas Bid to End Oil Subsidies Revives Debate
description: WASHINGTON  When he releases his new budget in two weeks, President Obama will propose doing away with roughly $4 billion a year in subsidies and tax breaks for oil companies, in his third effort to eliminate federal support for an industry that remains hugely profitable.

title: Treasurys Warrior at the Negotiating Table
description: WASHINGTON  When David N. Miller joined the Treasury Department during the height of the financial crisis, the governments bailout programs were not expected to break even, let alone turn a profit.

title: Bushs Daughter, in a Break, Endorses Gay Marriage
description: The Bush dynasty is no stranger to generational conflict: father and son differed over deposing Saddam Hussein, raising taxes and the role of the United Nations.

title: Retiring Nicely After Betraying Publics Trust
description: Guy J. Velella, a former state senator from the Bronx who died last week, was bidden farewell at a funeral service on Monday. His legacy, however, lives on. Among other things, Mr. Velella will be remembered for having turned a career of public service into one of public shame by taking bribes and going to jail for his corruption.

title: Bank Overdraft Rules
description: To the Editor:

title: Greece Tries to Shut a Back Door to Europe
description: ORESTIADA, Greece  On a chilly night recently, a half-dozen young men huddled in the shadows of the tiny train station here, stamping their feet to stay warm, waiting, though they had no money, to board a train for Athens.

title: Attracting Global Talent
description: To the Editor:

title: Grand Jury Meets on Blizzard Slowdown
description: The grand jury testimony of Daniel J. Halloran III, the city councilman at the center of charges that a union slowdown left some neighborhoods snowbound after the Dec. 26 blizzard, was cut short on Monday as he and federal prosecutors argued a related matter before a judge.

title: Bloggingheads: Late-Term Abortions
description: Amanda Marcotte, left, of Pandagon and Mollie Ziegler Hemingway of GetReligion.org debate abortion and the Kermit Gosnell case.

title: Report Lists Perils for Envoys After U.S. Leaves Iraq
description: WASHINGTON  The United States will not be able to protect its diplomats in Iraq adequately if it sticks to the plan to withdraw its last 50,000 troops by December, potentially hindering American efforts to reach out to the Iraqi people, according to a new report by the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.

title: BMW Robbery Victim Is Called Trusting
description: His family calls him Olakunle, a name that means the wealth that fills the house in the Yoruba language of Nigeria, where Akeem Ajimotokan grew up adored as the youngest of four boys.

title: Museums and Society
description: To the Editor:

title: Preparing for the Feast of Candelaria
description: Las Gemelas, a shop inside Moore Street Market in Brooklyn, sells clothing for Baby Jesus dolls for Candlemas.

title: U.S. Pushes, but Reactors Are Lagging
description: WASHINGTON  In his State of the Union address, President Obama proposed giving the nuclear construction business a type of help it has never had, a role in a quota for clean energy. But recent setbacks in a hoped-for nuclear renaissance raise questions about how much of a role nuclear power can play.

title: Hearst Agrees to Buy 100 Magazines From Lagardre
description: Hearst Corporation, the American magazine giant that publishes Cosmopolitan, Esquire and Good Housekeeping, said Monday that it had agreed to acquire more than 100 magazines from the French publisher Lagardre in a deal that would make Hearst the second-largest domestic magazine company and greatly expand its international footprint.

title: Haiti Agrees to Issue Passport for Aristide, Lawyer Says
description: WASHINGTON  The Haitian government has agreed to issue a diplomatic passport to former President Jean-Bertrand Aristide, his lawyer said Monday, potentially dropping a major hurdle that has prevented Mr. Aristide from returning home after seven years in exile.

title: U.S. Charges Fraud Scheme by 2 Fake Guggenheims and One Fake Countess
description: Of all the frauds charged in Manhattan federal court in recent years, few have offered as bizarre a cast of characters as those described in a complaint unsealed by prosecutors on Monday.

title: G.O.P. Governors Take Aim at Teacher Tenure
description: Seizing on a national anxiety over poor student performance, many governors are taking aim at a bedrock tradition of public schools: teacher tenure.

title: Exhilarated by the Hope in Cairo
description: CAIRO

title: 10 Questions for Gene Sperling
description: Gene Sperling recently returned to the job of director of the National Economic Council, which he held during the Clinton administration. He sat down with John Harwood of the New York Times and CNBC to discuss the economic and budget outlook and what effect the turmoil in Egypt might have. Here is an edited and condensed transcript of their conversation.

title: State Prisons and Medicaid to Face Cuts in Cuomo Budget
description: ALBANY  Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo will seek to cut more than 3,000 prison beds, roll back scheduled spending increases on Medicaid and education by billions of dollars and make steep reductions to state operations, a move likely to lead to the loss of thousands of state jobs, according to people briefed on the budget he will unveil on Tuesday.

title: Imam Stirs Confusion Regarding Islam Center
description: Two weeks after the developer of a controversial Islamic center and mosque planned near ground zero distanced himself from the imam who co-founded the project, the imam has raised confusion over who is in charge by suggesting that he would move the center to a less contentious space if an opportunity arose.

title: More on Egypt and the U.S.
description: Mark Blumenthal of the Huffington Post links toward a different survey of Egyptian public opinion, this one by the pew Global Attitudes Project, which tells a completely different story. In contrast to the BBC study that we linked to this morning, which found relatively favorable attitudes toward the United States, the Pew poll finds that just 17 percent of Egyptians have a favorable view of the U.S. against 82 percent unfavorable. It also shows, again in contrast to the BBC study, that views of the United States declined somewhat between 2009 and 2010.

title: U.S. Official With Egypt Ties to Meet With Mubarak
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration has sent a diplomatic troubleshooter with close ties to Egypt on a mission to Cairo to meet with President Hosni Mubarak and other senior officials, as the administration struggles to gauge Mr. Mubaraks intentions amid the fast-moving events there.

title: Tuesdays Forecast: Horrific
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo.  Government budgets around the nation, already busted by the bad economy, now have a new nemesis: Mother Nature.

title: When Microcredit Wont Do
description: If you asked poverty experts to name the single most significant new concept in the field in the last few decades, chances are they would say microcredit. Microcredit is the lending of very small amounts of money to very poor people to help them invest in things that have the potential to bring income later on  a loan of $50 to buy a sewing machine to make clothes, for instance, or piglets to raise and sell. It reaches nearly 100 million clients in more than 100 countries.

title: Lottery Numbers
U.S. Scrambles to Size Up ElBaradei
description: WASHINGTON  When President Obama unexpectedly won the Nobel Peace Prize in 2009, one predecessor was quick to applaud his selection for the award.

title: Apps Alter Reading on the Web
description: The DVR rocked the world of television by letting viewers skip commercials and build their own home viewing schedules. Now a handful of Web services and applications are starting to do much the same thing to online publishers.

title: John Barry Dies at 77; Composed for Bond Films
description: John Barry, whose bold, jazzy scores for From Russia With Love, Goldfinger and nine other James Bond films put a musical stamp on one of the most successful film franchises of all time, and who won five Academy Awards as a composer for Born Free, Dances With Wolves and other films, died on Sunday in New York. He was 77.

title: Sam Houston, We Have a Problem
description: Everything about Austin, a town of just 3,500 people on the banks of the crystalline Colorado River, was new. The very idea of being a part of the United States was still settling in: after all, in 1861 the American flag had been flying over the Lone Star state for just 15 years. Now it looked set to leave yet again.

title: Smithsonian Official Defends Disputed Videos Exhibit
description: WASHINGTON  A video that outraged some Roman Catholics and some members of Congress was suitable for inclusion in an exhibit at the National Portrait Gallery, a member of board that reviewed a decision to pull it from the show said Monday. But museum officials insufficient explanation of the work led to its hasty withdrawal, he said.

title: State TV in Egypt Offers Murky Window Into Power Shift
description: CAIRO  As hundreds of Egyptian protesters filled Tahrir Square on Monday, many calling for their president to go into exile, one of the two state-owned television stations had its cameras focused elsewhere, capturing the steady flow of traffic on a Cairo bridge.

title: $10 Million in Pay for Bank of America Chief
description: It was a tough year for Bank of America, what with the foreclosure mess and a sagging stock price. Its chief executive, Brian T. Moynihan, nonetheless received $10 million in his first year on the job.

title: Pakistani Nuclear Arms Pose Challenge to U.S. Policy
description: WASHINGTON  New American intelligence assessments have concluded that Pakistan has steadily expanded its nuclear arsenal since President Obama came to office, and that it is building the capability to surge ahead in the production of nuclear-weapons material, putting it on a path to overtake Britain as the worlds fifth largest nuclear weapons power.

title: Senate Passes Cuomos Property-Tax Cap
description: ALBANY  Gov. Andrew M. Cuomos proposal to limit local property taxes won overwhelming approval from the State Senate on Monday, escalating the pressure on Democratic legislators in the Assembly who have expressed reservations about the bill.

title: Debt Limit Follies
description: At a recent gathering of House Republicans, lawmakers made it clear that they intend to hold an increase in the nations debt limit hostage to major spending cuts.

title: An End to Bush-Era Politics
description: Every White House since the days of President Jimmy Carter has had a political affairs office to assess the effects of policy on voters and make sure that presidents are aware of the nations political temperature. The office has grown in power alarmingly with each presidency, but the most recent Bush administration became so consumed with Republican politics that it crossed a legal red line, according to a new federal investigative report.

title: Theft From PTA Is Suspected
description: The Police Department said on Monday that it was investigating whether the former treasurer of the PTA at Public School 29 in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, stole roughly $5,500 from the groups account.

title: Tuesday: Celebrity Guest Solver Mollie Katzen
description: TUESDAYS PUZZLE  So, I was sitting here wondering how to introduce todays guest, when it occurred to me that what I needed was a really good segue. See if this works.

title: Love Hurts, and for Some Couples, Thats the Point
description: Gruesome Playground Injuries  a blood-spattered twig of a play from the up-and-coming dramatist Rajiv Joseph  recalls that time in the 1960s when Hollywood was in thrall to what publicists liked to call a different kind of love story. Incarnated by a twitchy new breed of beauties that included Warren Beatty, Natalie Wood, Tuesday Weld and Anthony Perkins, a battalion of sensitive, damaged Romeos and Juliets took over American screens, writhing in romances that were more about pain than about pleasure, or perhaps the confusion of the two.

title: Property Tax Ploy
description: Late Friday, Gov. Andrew Cuomo of New York sent a radical bill to cap property taxes to the State Senate. It would devastate school districts in the state. The bill, which exempts New York City, was passed by the Senate on Monday.

title: Difference Between No. 2 UConn And Third-Ranked Duke? 36 Points
description: STORRS, Conn.  For more than two seasons, the Connecticut womens basketball team won every time it took the floor, peerless in history. Although its streak ended in December, the second-ranked Huskies are still the sports measuring stick.

title: Mr. Pullmans Compass
description: The austerity cuts in Britain  part of the governments overly harsh deficit-reduction plan  have provoked many outcries, but few quite as eloquent as a speech given recently in Oxfordshire by Philip Pullman, author of the highly regarded trilogy His Dark Materials. The subject was the Oxford county councils plan to stop financing 20 of its 43 libraries  because of cuts in national financing  and hope that they would be run instead by volunteers.

title: Walsh Eager to Finish Job, if Knicks Let Him
description: From his elevated perch in the final row of Section 16, Donnie Walshs view is clean, unobstructed and thoroughly enjoyable.

title: Allying Ourselves With the Next Egypt
description: Washington

title: Reach for the Skies
description: IN his State of the Union speech last week, President Obama talked about why things like high-speed rail and faster Internet connections were critical to American prosperity. But he left out the fastest, safest mode of transportation available: aviation.

title: With Anthony Main Attraction, Nets Steal a Win
description: NEWARK  For Carmelo Anthony, this was hello and goodbye, what could have been and what may still be, all rolled into one speculative Monday night.

title: G.M. Says Lawsuit Isnt Affecting Mets
description: The official purpose of a conference call arranged by the Mets on Monday was to announce the new two-year contract for the knuckleballer R.A. Dickey. But General Manager Sandy Alderson was on the call, too, so Dickey became something of an afterthought  a pitcher pulled after a couple of comments  as Alderson answered questions for the first time about the financial uncertainty in which the team finds itself.

title: The Quest for Dignity
description: I wonder if sometime around 50 years ago a great mental tide began to sweep across the world. Before the tide, people saw themselves in certain fixed places in the social order. They accepted opinions from trusted authorities.

title: In the SEC, Winning on the Road Is Not Easy
description: When I started thinking about writing this article, I was very confident about what it would be about. The headline would be Winning on the Road in the SEC, and the content would describe the great feeling you get when you beat a rival on ESPNs College Gameday.

title: Dickey Is Happy for Some Security in New Deal
description: The knuckleballer R.A. Dickey was the best thing that happened to the Mets in 2011, emerging from a career on the fringe to go 11-9 with a 2.84 earned run average. He hustled in the field and on the bases, hit a robust .255 and impressed just about everyone around the team with his curiosity (a locker full of books), vocabulary and simple willingness to answer any and all questions.

title: Photo Replay: Jan. 31
description: Li Na was celebrated in China, while the Winter Asian Games were full of action in Kazakhstan.

title: In Switch, Brooklyn College Will Hire Adjunct on Mideast
description: Brooklyn College on Monday reversed an earlier decision not to hire an adjunct professor to teach a seminar on Middle East politics, a decision that the professor and others called politically motivated.

title: Red-Light Cameras Lower Traffic Deaths, Agency Claims
description: In a study released on Tuesday, the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety, found that red-light cameras could save lives.

title: Apple Moves to Tighten Control of App Store
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Apple is further tightening its control of the App Store.

title: Somalia: Infighting Leaves 15 Dead
description: At least 15 people were killed Monday and another 30 wounded after government forces clashed with each other in Mogadishu, witnesses said. The shooting started when a government soldier tried to enter a hospital with a gun and was repelled by government security guards. A fierce firefight erupted, which killed soldiers and civilians in a nearby market.

title: Hadron Collider to Keep Running
description: Saying that new discoveries might be now within reach, CERN, the European Organization for Nuclear Research, said Monday that they would run the Large Hadron Collider in 2012 instead of shutting down for repairs, as had originally been planned.

title: Raising Money, to Help Other People Raise Money
description: A lack of ready cash is stalling the growth of small businesses across the United States, All Things D says. But On Deck Capital, the latest venture capital darling, aims to solve this problem.

title: South Africa: Mandela Responds to Treatment for Respiratory Infection
description: Military doctors treating former president Nelson Mandela, 92, for an acute respiratory infection said Monday that he continued to respond to medication and had a peaceful night, according to a statement from President Jacob Zumas office. Mr. Mandela went home Friday after spending two nights in the hospital.

description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

Ernest McCulloch, Crucial Figure in Stem Cell Research, Dies at 84

title: Margaret Price Dies at 69, Soprano With Rich Voice
description: Margaret Price, the Welsh soprano who brought a voice of pure, floating richness to lieder and the operas of Mozart and Verdi, died on Friday in Wales. She was 69.

title: Obama Urges Faster Shift of Power in Egypt
description: CAIRO  President Hosni Mubarak declared Tuesday night that he would step down in September as modern Egypts longest-serving leader, but that did not go far enough for the hundreds of thousands who poured into Tahrir Square in a sprawling protest that cut across entrenched lines of piety, class and ideology.

title: BP to Pay First Dividend Since Gulf of Mexico Spill
description: LONDON  BP said Tuesday that it planned to sell half of its refining capacity in the United States while expanding in faster-growing economies, and that it would resume paying a dividend for the first time since the rig explosion in the Gulf of Mexico last year.

title: Q. and A. With Larry Fitzgerald
description: Arizona Cardinals wide receiver Larry Fitzgerald is considered among the best players in the game. A two-time first-team All-Pro, Fitzgerald has recently dedicated his efforts to the American Cancer Society. Cecil Lammey and Matt Waldman had the opportunity to interview Fitzgerald just before his fifth Pro Bowl appearance. Lammey is a senior staff writer for Footballguys.com and the N.F.L. Insider for the Front Range Sports Network. Waldman is a staff writer for Footballguys.com and the author of The Rookie Scouting Portfolio, an online publication devoted to play-by-play film analysis of N.F.L. prospects at quarterback, running back, wide receiver and tight end.

title: Deutsche Bank Expects Net Income of $826 Million
description: Deutsche Bank released its preliminary results for the fourth quarter late on Monday, saying it was set to report 7.4 billion euros in net revenue for the period compared with 5.5 billion euros in the period a year earlier.

title: Korean Military Talks Set; Leaders Might Meet Later
description: SEOUL, South Korea  South Korea announced on Tuesday that it would hold military talks with North Korea next week, the first inter-Korean dialogue since a deadly artillery exchange in November, and President Lee Myung-bak said for the first time that a summit meeting with Kim Jong-il, the North Korean leader, was a possibility.

title: What Is Your Racial and Ethnic Identity?
description: Multiracial and multiethnic  or mixed race  people are a rapidly growing demographic in the United States. And more and more people, especially young people, are embracing and expressing their multifaceted racial and ethnic backgrounds. How about you?

description: Martha C. Merrill, the dean of admission at Connecticut College, is one of a handful of admissions insiders who have written occasionally for The Choices Tip Sheet column. Today, she is joined by Elaine Solinga, the colleges director of financial aid.  Jacques Steinberg

title: War Photographer Remembered at Paris Show
description: Among war photographers, the name Henri Huet once ranked alongside Robert Capa. He is remembered, by those who knew him, as among the bravest, the most soul stirring, the most tragic of his class of shooters. Now a new generation of Parisians and tourists have a chance to view his haunting work at Henri Huet: Vietnam, running Feb. 9 through April 3 at La Maison Europenne de la Photographie (5/7 rue de Fourcy; 33-1-44-78-75-00; www.mep-fr.org) in Pariss Fourth Arrondissement.

title: Egypt Poses P.R. Challenge for New White House Team
description: Days of mounting unrest in Egypt have turned into a delicate public relations challenge for the White House as a number of new players in the West Wing try to craft messages for President Obama that will resonate well overseas and at home.

title: Jets Alosi Steps Forward and Resigns
description: Sal Alosi, the Jets strength and conditioning coach, closed a chapter on a controversy by resigning Monday. In December, Alosi tripped a Dolphins punt gunner after organizing a sidewall wall of inactive players.

title: The TV Watch: Skins, Sex and Foreign Affairs
description: On Mondays episode of MTV could show minors in the kind of flagrante delicto that is usually reserved for mature audiences. Yet most adult Americans still cant watch Al Jazeera English on television  even now, when the world is transfixed by images of Egypt in revolt.

description: There was no chicken in the first blog post or the original concept of Southfork Kitchen. Not on the menu, not in the soup, not anywhere in the restaurant. (There was no menu and no restaurant at that point, but play along.)

description: Four in five Internet users have searched the Web for health care information, most often checking on specific diseases and treatments, a Pew Internet Project survey reported on Tuesday.

description: Valeant Pharmaceuticals said on Tuesday that it would acquire PharmaSwiss, the maker of generic drugs, for 350 million euros ($481 million).

description: Unrest in Egypt is causing jitters in global markets as investors worry about the wider political implications for the region. Still, analysts see few immediate reasons for economic concern.

title: Updates on Day 8 of Protests in Egypt
description: On Tuesday, The Lede continues to provide updates on street protests in Egypt. For a summary of the latest events, see the main news article by my colleagues on the ground. A stream of Twitter updates from bloggers and journalists were following is in the right column of this blog. Updates below mix alerts on breaking news with reports from other Web sites and video, photographs and eyewitness accounts posted on social networks. Readers can share information in the comment thread below or send photographs or video from Egypt to pix@nyt.com.

description: The Food and Drug Administration has declined to approve yet another prescription diet pill, vanquishing nearly any prospect that a new obesity medicine will be available to overweight Americans this year.

description: In researching Mondays article about opposition to smart meters, I found myself once again facing a dilemma built into environmental reporting: how to evaluate whether claims of health effects caused by some environmental contaminant  chemicals, noise, radiation, whatever  are potentially valid? I turned, as usual, to the peer-reviewed science.

description: Barbara Bush, one of President George W. Bushs twin daughters, recorded this video endorsing gay marriage. Read the full story by my colleague Michael Barbaro.

description: By all accounts, the F.B.I.s concern was clear: Just make sure hes really dead.

title: A Superstitious Harvey

But all the attention hasnt made Harvey Weinstein, whose company is the American distributor of the film, complacent. In fact, quite the opposite: hes become superstitious.

title: Helmut Langs Got a Brand New Bag
description: I always carry my iPhone, keys, credit card and some gloss, says Nicole Colovos, the co-designer for Helmut Lang. She and her husband, Michael, are gearing up for the first collection of bags to hit the stores since they took over the label in 2006. We developed all new hardware and looked at bones and bird claws for inspiration and used hints of military finishes, Michael says. Available this month, the bags come in tough washed creta leather and smooth napa and have a whole lot of zippers. Styles range from duffels and messengers to clutches and pouchettes  just the right complement to their edgy-yet-polished motorcycle-jacket-and-skinny-leather-pants aesthetic. The Syn, a spiraling half-clutch/half-shoulder bag made from Perch skin, blends Michaels past as a commercial fisherman (straps have fisherman knots and braids) and Nicoles penchant for utilitarian dressing. We wanted to create something sculptural, in an interesting fabrication, yet keep it functional, Nicole says. We couldnt ask for more. Except maybe a shoe collection. Hint, hint.

title: O.K., Youre a Library, State Tells Chocolate Shop
description: Byron Bennett can legally call his East Village shop the Chocolate Library.

description: If self-hurt and demotivational books ever become a publishing trend, you can bet that Sue Sylvester, the deliciously nasty cheerleading coach on the Fox musical comedy Glee, will have a best seller. In the meantime, Jane Lynch, who has won a Golden Globe and an Emmy Award for her portrayal of that character, hopes to take a more inspirational tone in a book of her own.

title: Debtonista
description: Indebted slaves to fashion.(Debt + Fashionista)

title: 2012 Hopefuls Stake Out Positions on Egypt
description: Some potential Republican rivals to President Obama in the 2012 race are cautiously staking out positions on the unrest in Egypt, which is likely to figure prominently in discussions of foreign policy in the coming months.Mitt Romney, the former governor of Massachusetts, said on Good Morning America on Tuesday that the president of Egypt, Hosni Mubarak, should leave office, and he urged Mr. Obama and his administration to signal more support for the protesters aims.

title: Storm Stops Travelers as It Moves Across U.S.
description: A paralyzing 2,000-mile swath of winter at its snowy, icy, messy worst pushed eastward across the United States on Tuesday, disrupting the rhythms of everyday life and punctuating this seasons recurring lesson that humankind has no dominion over nature.

title: Ever-Larger Protests Flood Cairo Streets
description: Hundreds of thousands of people in Tahrir Square on Tuesday demanded the ouster of President Hosni Mubarak, despite government efforts to block access to Cairo.

title: Overkill Report: Lipton, the Angry Iced Tea
description: Eminem to Appear in Iced Tea AdIced tea sure has gotten angrier in the years since Don Meredith hawked Lipton. Eminem (or Mr. Marshall Mathers, as he is known around here) will appear in a Lipton Brisk commercial. He will appear in claymation form, meaning a duet with Gumby cannot be far behind. Our goal here at the Fifth Down is to question Eminems musical integrity in the hope that he responds by insulting us in a future rap. Theres no word yet whether rapper Ice T will endorse any candy-coated chocolate products in response to Eminems commercial.

title: The Oscar Curse (or, Why It Stinks to Be a Successful Woman)
description: So much for having it all.

title: Tuesday Reading: Less Expensive Concierge Care
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: Third Time Wont Be the Charm
description: LOS ANGELES Surely this will shock  shock!  everyone in Hollywood, but it seems even bad publicity is good publicity. Ricky Gervais, whose acerbic performance as the host of the Golden Globes overshadowed the awards themselves (quick: what won best comedy?), was asked to host the show again.

title: The Most (and Least) Expensive Vehicles to Insure
description: From our colleagues at Bucks:

title: Democrats Pick Charlotte for 2012 Convention
description: The Democratic Party announced Tuesday that Charlotte, N.C., will be the site of its 2012 national convention, with the city winning out over St. Louis, Minneapolis and Cleveland as the place to formally kick off President Obamas re-election bid.

title: S.&P. Proposes New Method for Rating Banks
description: Standard & Poors, one of the largest credit rating agencies, could soon overhaul its method for rating banks located across the world, according to a proposal that the company circulated recently.

title: Rocco Landesman Weighs in, Again, on Arts Organizations
description: Last week, Rocco Landesman, the chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts, prompted an outcry when he publicly suggested that perhaps the supply of arts organizations exceeded the demand for them. On Monday, Mr. Landesman weighed in on the debate his comments has generated.

title: Dish Network Poised to Land DBSD for $1 Billion
description: After a drawn-out court battle, Dish Network is set to acquire the satellite operator DBSD North America for about $1 billion as it emerges from bankruptcy. Dish Network will also make a loan of $87.5 million available to DBSD.

title: In the Rough, a Pair of Ferraris Seek Auction Records
description: As Rob Sass noted in his recap of last months Scottsdale, Ariz., vintage-car auctions, a faded paint job or a loose muffler might add to, not detract from, a vehicles allure. Cars in original but well-preserved condition fetched high premiums at the five major Scottsdale auctions, a trend that most likely will continue.

title: For Top College Recruits, a Day No Longer Set in Stone
description: National signing day has transformed into a ritualistic process as much a part of college football as Notre Dame players slapping the Play Like a Champion Today plaque or the Ohio State marching bands performing the Script Ohio.

title: Excuses, Excuses and Style Points for Alibis
description: The meat defense does not seem to be working.

title: What Were Reading
description: An aggregation of links by the reporters and editors of Diners Journal.

title: Repeat Offenses
description: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style. (Some frequently asked questions are here.)

description: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style. (Some frequently asked questions are here.)

title: Sales of Larger Vehicles Bring Automakers an Upbeat Start for 2011
description: DETROIT  New-vehicle sales rose 17 percent in January, automakers said Tuesday, led by pickup trucks and other big profitable vehicles even as gasoline prices increased.

title: Leading Off: The Calm Before the Media Storm
description: 6:19 p.m. | Updated Peter King has issued a clarification on SI.com that Roger Goodell was referring to N.F.L. players, not only Steelers players, when saying that Ben Roethlisberger had no support from other players during interviews regarding his personal conduct suspension. From King:

title: New Service Lets Voices From Egypt Be Heard
description: With the unruly sounds of protests in the background, the Egyptian man declared there were 50,000 demonstrators in the streets of Cairo.

title: An Audio Guide to the Footsteps of Heroes
description: It might not quite feel like the Hollywood Walk of Fame  even aside from the lack of palm trees  but the downtown corridor between Battery Park and City Hall is a well-beaten path where heroes and celebrities have paraded to the cheers and confetti of the citys residents.

title: The Un-COLA Era
description: Im still having fun with the Atlanta Feds sticky-price CPI data. These data go back to the late 1960s, and offer an interesting contrast between then and now.

title: Filling In the Blanks on Himalayan Glaciers
description: Last year, the United Nations Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change ended up with a bit of mud on its face when it had to retract an alarming claim in its landmark 2007 assessment: that the probability of Himalayan glaciers disappearing by the year 2035 and perhaps sooner is very high. Climate skeptics pilloried the panel for including what proved to be an unsubstantiated and, glaciologists said, unlikely figure. Rajendra K. Pachauri, the head of the panel, called the inclusion of the statistic a regrettable error.

title: Measure for Measure and Alls Well That Ends Well Are Headed for Central Park
description: 8:46 a.m. | Updated

title: Space Zombies, Prepare to Meet Your Mower
description: Is there a place in mass entertainment for dismemberment, dementia, wails of anguish and the infernal corruption of children? Is there a place for a vision of future humanity in the grip of an eldritch religion that sees salvation in alien mutation? Is there a place for titillation in the form of gore, for human (and once-human) offal as an acceptable form of set decoration?

title: Back to Iowa, Leaving a City in His Bones
description: Leaving New York is easy. Feeling New York leave you is the hard part.

title: Baghdad Bureau Chief Answers Readers Questions on Iraq
description: BAGHDAD  Thanks to everyone who wrote, especially Jimmy from Dallas who asked if those of us working here realize you are read. We do, even if Iraq has receded so far from the center of public attention in the United States  as I noted about President Obamas State of the Union address  that it can sometimes feel as if it has been forgotten, overshadowed by economic troubles at home, the renewed focus on Afghanistan and all the turmoil elsewhere in the world.

title: Report From Tahrir
description: Especially at first, the people at Tahrir were overwhelmingly young men. But now the crowd is democratizing, and today there are lots of women and indeed lots of families making a party out of it. At right, a photo of the youngest protester I saw.

title: Historic Black Enclave in Queens Gains Landmark Status
description: The predominantly African-American neighborhood of Addisleigh Park, an enclave of brick and stucco houses in southeast Queens and the former home of luminaries like Jackie Robinson, W.E.B. Du Bois and Ella Fitzgerald, is now a historic district, New York Citys 102nd.

title: Following in the Footsteps of a Suburban Fisher
description: Roland Kays, curator of mammals at the New York State Museum and author of Mammals of North America, writes from Albany, where he is comparing the behavior of fishers in urban and wild settings.

title: Court Counselor Sentenced to Four Years for Sex Assaults
description: A juvenile-justice counselor who almost got a no-jail plea deal last year in the sexual assaults of three young girls under his care was sentenced Tuesday to four years in prison, the maximum allowed, after a jury convicted him on sexual assault charges last month.

title: Pyrrhic Recoveries
description: John Dizard hails the Estonian recovery, even while saying that its not a useful role model for other countries. But Im puzzled by his dismissal of my assertion that it will be many years before Estonia and its neighbors make up the lost ground.

title: In Mexico, Massacres and Claims of Progress
description: ACAPULCO, Mexico  Only a week into the new year, 15 human heads sat outside a gleaming shopping center on the other side of the lush hills that frame this seaside resorts big tourist hotels. Within hours, several bodies turned up in a taxi and elsewhere, bringing the number of victims to 33 in a single weekend, scattered around a side of town few visitors see.

title: EMI Taken Over by Citigroup, Making a Sale More Likely
description: Updated at 8:02 p.m. | Citigroup on Tuesday seized control of EMI from Terra Firma, ending the private equity firms disastrous ownership of the famous music company and most likely accelerating the search for new owners.

title: Bloomberg on the Icelandic Miracle
description: Iceland Proves Ireland Did `Wrong Things Sacrificing Taxpayers:

title: The Rangers at the Top of the Stretch
description: Fifty-two games down, 30 to go, the All-Star break behind us and the final third of the regular season looming ahead. This is the time when the hockey gets serious and you start checking the standings  the right time to look at how the Rangers are doing, man by man. Their official N.H.L. record is 29-20-3, which really means theyre 29-23, but thats still a quite-good .558 winning percentage. Coach John Tortorellas team just might be going places, especially now that theyre starting to get their injured forwards back (Ryan Callahan and Vinny Prospal are the first, with Brandon Dubinsky and Eric Christensen soon to follow). Tortorellas emphasis on conditioning has paid off in strong third-period performances (the Rangers lead the league in comeback wins with seven, two more than anyone else), and he has mellowed somewhat from the volcanic-tempered coach of the previous season.

title: Natural Gas: Its Not Easy Being Green
description: Natural gas has long enjoyed a clean-and-green reputation  at least in comparison with coal, its brethren fossil fuel and most immediate substitute in the electricity-generation game. And of course, T. Boone Pickens and others would like to see natural gas replace oil as the chief source for the nations transportation fuels.

title: Sharks Cavanaugh Remembered for his Life, Not his Illness
description: The hockey world has paused a few times over the past weeks to remember former San Jose Sharks player Tom Cavanaugh.

title: Discovery Names New General Manager for TLC
description: Bolstered by Kate Gosselin and Sarah Palin, TLC has been one of the most talked-about cable channels in recent years and one of the flagship channels for its parent company, Discovery Communications.

title: Agency Investigates 400,000 Nissan and Infiniti S.U.V.s for Suspension Failures
description: The National Highway Traffic Safety is investigating structural failures involving the front suspension on 400,000 Nissan Pathfinders and their sibling, the Infinti QX4.

title: Ethics Committee Names Special Counsel to Aid in Ensign Investigation
description: The Senate Ethics Committee announced Tuesday that it has named a special counsel to help determine whether to bring formal charges against Senator John Ensign, the Nevada Republican who has been accused of using his political influence to help cover up an affair he had with the wife of a former top aide.

title: Citigroup Takes Over EMI
description: Citigroup has taken over EMI, the British music label of the Beatles and Radiohead, under a restructuring of its debt, EMI announced on Tuesday.

title: Walking Down Memory Lane
description: In healthy adults, the hippocampus  a part of the brain important to the formation of memories  begins to atrophy when were about 55 or 60. Now a team of psychologists has published an intriguing report suggesting that the hippocampus can be modestly expanded, and memory improved, in older adults by means of a low-tech, low-cost intervention with very few unpleasant side effects: regular walking.

title: Mohamed ElBaradei Memoir Rushed to Publication
description: As Mohamed ElBaradei has emerged to become the face of the opposition in Cairo, the world has scrambled to figure him out.

title: Explaining Egypt
description: [May 8, 3:50 p.m. | Updated | Researchers report in the journal Science that rising temperatures have hurt corn and wheat harvests in some countries, but not others (including the United States). They also fond that gains in other crops related to climate shifts and rising carbon dioxide levels have largely offset the overall impact of climate change so far. In a news report in Science, John Reilly, an economist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology specializing in climate, cast doubt on the findings.]

title: With Cuts, Cuomo Offers Shrunken Budget
description: ALBANY  Declaring New York State functionally bankrupt, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo proposed a $132.9 billion budget on Tuesday that would reduce year-to-year spending for the first time in more than a decade, slash projected spending on education and health care, and slice the budget for state agencies by more than half a billion dollars in the next fiscal year.

title: Free Time for Parents
description: For months after my son was born I kept a running time tally in my head of time I no longer had to myself. Television I wasnt watching. Books I wasnt reading. Conversations I wasnt having. Sleep I wasnt getting.

title: Victoria Clark Joins Sister Act on Broadway
description: Victoria Clark (The Light in the Piazza) will play Mother Superior in the coming Broadway production of Sister Act, the shows producers announced on Tuesday. The musical, based on the 1992 Whoopi Goldberg film, has a score by Alan Menken, lyrics by Glenn Slater, and a book by Cheri and Bill Steinkellner. It will be directed by Jerry Zaks. The show is to begin previews on March 24 at the Broadway Theater, with opening night scheduled for April 20. As previously announced, the Olivier Award nominee Patina Miller will reprise her role as Deloris Van Cartier, the undercover nun with a disco past. She originated the role when the West End production of Sister Act opened at the London Palladium in June 2009.

title: 'The Whipping Man'
description: A scene from the Manhattan Theater Club's production of Matthew Lopez's play. (Video courtesy of MTC)

title: Iraq: Department of Clarification
description: BAGHDAD  The United States military in Iraq issued a statement on Tuesday that was bound to draw attention. Iraq agrees to purchase 18 F-16 multirole fighter aircraft, the headline went.

title: His Sport Dismissed, Venezuelan Is Now Star
description: SAN DIEGO  Hugo Chvez, the president of Venezuela, is no friend of golf. He has called it a bourgeois sport played primarily by lazy, rich people in carts. He has closed six of the countrys courses and said the government should appropriate private urban land for public housing. Do you mean to tell me this is a peoples sport? he said in 2009. It is not.

title: Checkmate for Gambit
description: This is the last post on the Gambit blog. Articles on chess will continue to appear in the Crosswords, Games & Cartoons section of The New York Times Web site.

title: Do Health Savings Accounts Make for Savvy Patients?
description: A recently released survey from the Employee Benefit Research Institute, a nonprofit group, examined the link between health savings accounts and other health reimbursement arrangements and cost-conscious behaviors among the people who use them.

title: All in a Days Work: Developing Soft Skills for Job Success
description: Overview | What skills do students need to excel and succeed in the professional world? In this lesson, students distinguish between hard and soft skills that are needed in the workplace and engage in activities that help them practice those skills. They then create a handbook of rules for the workplace for peers.

title: Critics Picks Video: Solaris
description: In this weeks Critics Picks, A. O. Scott looks back at Andrei Tarkovskys rumination on memory and loss, Solaris. The film explores the boundaries between consciousness and reality within a science-fiction narrative. Mr. Scott appreciates how Solaris uses outer space to explore humanity and look at how every individual human beings emotions  love, grief, alienation, nostalgia  are as vast as the universe itself, he says. Have you seen Solaris? Please share your thoughts.

title: New President for Struggling Gap Inc. Unit
description: The head of Gap North America is leaving the company, one of a number of changes that Gap announced for its flagship brand after years of declining sales at the division.

title: Whether Large or Small, Theyre Big Dogs on Campus
description: Dr. Evil had his cat, Mr. Bigglesworth; President Obama has Bo; even Jabba the Hut had an interstellar critter named Salacious Crumb. And at the seats of power in some of New York Citys private schools, theres sometimes something fluffy curled around the chair legs.

title: Mercedes-Benz C63 AMG Resumes M3 Hunt
description: Daimler AG announced a lightly restyled and revised version of its Mercedes-Benz C63 AMG sedan on Tuesday. This should be welcome news for performance-minded followers of the German brand, who may have experienced some agita following its recent return to a 4-cylinder C-Class.

title: Q&A: Multigenerational March Vacation in Europe
description: Q.

title: Comparative Peripheral Suffering
description: A correspondent asks a good question: why do I have kind words for Icelands performance, when its GDP decline was not much less than Estonias?

title: Jimmy Bradley, Being Treated for Oral Cancer, Shelves Plan for Food Hall
description: Jimmy Bradley, the chef and an owner of the Red Cat and the Harrison, two restaurants in Manhattan, said he is recovering from oral cancer, and will not be moving forward with plans to open J & S Food Hall in the Nolitan Hotel.

title: Awaiting Health Laws Prognosis
description: With a court decision on Monday declaring the health care law unconstitutional and Republicans intent on repealing at least parts of it, thousands of Americans with major illnesses are facing the renewed prospect of losing their health insurance coverage.

title: Channels Join Fight To Broadcast Al Jazeera In Egypt
description: The signal for the Arabic-language Al Jazeera channel was being disrupted in unprecedented ways during its coverage of the protests in Egypt, the Qatar-based broadcaster said Tuesday.

title: Paper Cuts Joins ArtsBeat
description: The Book Reviews Paper Cuts blog has joined ArtsBeat.

title: G-Zero
description: Term used to denote the absence of a politically and economically dominant country or bloc.

title: Packers at the Podiums; Grilled on Hair, Nicknames, Weather
description: The NFL Network covered the Packers portion Super Bowl Media Day live this morning, allowing fans to experience the thrill of being a reporter: milling around and asking repetitive questions of bored athletes.

title: In a Warm Room, the Globe Feels Hotter
description: As any climate scientist will attest, proof of global warming is found not in the warmth or cold of any given day or even a particular year, but in long-term trends in temperature averaged across the entire planet.

title: Health Insurance Kicks In for Congress
description: Government-subsidized health insurance  one of many perks of serving in Congress  kicked in on Tuesday for new members.

title: Diplomatic Scramble as Ally Is Pushed to the Exit
description: WASHINGTON  Last Sunday at 2 p.m., a blue-and-white Air Force jet left Andrews Air Force Base bound for Cairo. On board was Frank G. Wisner, an adroit ex-diplomat whom President Obama had asked hours before to undertake a supremely delicate mission: nudging President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt out of power.

title: Guiding the Leap From Employee to Entrepreneur
description: Last week I wrote about Terri Maxwell, founder of Succeed on Purpose, a business incubator that specializes in transforming former employees, often layoff victims, into entrepreneurs. These would-be business owners face many common challenges because of the attitudes and habits theyve developed while collecting a paycheck. Dismantling those employee mindsets is a priority for Ms. Maxwell.

title: Pictures of the Day: Egypt and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Egypt, Pakistan and Greece.

title: BP Heads to Arbitration Over Rosneft Venture
description: A group of wealthy Russian businessmen won a British court order on Tuesday blocking BPs proposed joint venture with Russias state-run Rosneft to explore for oil in the Arctic and sending the dispute to arbitration.

title: Focusing on the Stress of Prostate Cancer
description: Helping men cope with the stress of prostate cancer surgery before the operation may speed up both their physical and psychological recovery, new research suggests.

title: Al Jazeera Finds New Paths In U.S.
description: New ways to watch Al Jazeera English in the United States keep popping up  but not on cable or satellite systems.

title: Charting Lil B
description: Lil B is a member of the Bay Area rap group The Pack and a social network-obsessed solo artist who posts a dizzying array of songs, mixtapes and videos online. The artist Andrew Kuo charts one of his recent concerts at the Highline Ballroom in New York, where he performed some of his spacey ambient-rap music with off-the-cuff thoughts on religion, fashion and the Internet. Check out some of Lil Bs latest music here.

title: Sanofi Plans to Raise Genzyme Bid
description: Sanofi-Aventis plans to raise its takeover bid for Genzyme by several dollars a share, in an effort to clinch a deal for the biopharmaceutical company, people briefed on the matter told DealBook on Tuesday.

title: Bloomberg Is Criticized for Arizona Gun Show Scrutiny
description: 3:22 p.m. | Updated  PHOENIX  Arizonas attorney general, Tom Horne, was not amused by the undercover investigation that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg of New York City recently conducted at a Phoenix gun show, in which undercover detectives found two gun sellers apparently violating federal law.

title: The Fat Radish
description: THERE are two ways to look at the Fat Radish, which opened spare and loftlike on lower Orchard Street a few months ago.

title: Reviewing the Fat Radish
Minor League All-Star Game Has All the Scoring, None of the Glitz
description: HERSHEY, Pa.  Bobby Butler, a first-year pro with the Binghamton Senators, was named the most valuable player in the American Hockey League All-Star Classic, which was held Monday night before a sellout crowd of 10,376.

title: A Big Day for Red Shirt Nation
description: The news that Liverpool had agreed on the fee to buy striker Andy Carroll from Newcastle on Monday night sent so many visitors to the clubs Web site that it crashed. But that might have been the only thing that went wrong at Anfield on Monday.

title: Google Takes Street View Into Art Museums
description: Now that Google has conquered a majority of the earths major streets with its Google Street View project, the company is starting to move inside. Its creating the Google Art Project, a virtual equivalent of 17 major art museums, including the Metropolitan Museum of Art and Museum of Modern Art in New York, the Tate Britain and National Gallery in London, and the Van Gogh Museum in Amsterdam, among many others.

title: School Workers Penalized for Sitting Out Snow Day
description: Update, 11:15 p.m. | The policy described below actually applies to tens of thousands of city workers, not just Education Department employees. Read the final version of the story from the print edition of the paper.

title: Hollywood Foreign Press: Nice Try, Ricky
description: LOS ANGELES Theres no such thing as bad publicity, as they say, and theres no end to a he-said, they-said argument, especially when it generates more publicity. The Hollywood Foreign Press Association has responded to comments that Ricky Gervais made in Heat magazine, that the organization invited him back as a Golden Globes host even after his controversial barbed performance.

title: Who Am I? Tuesday Edition
description: All week, the Fifth Down blog will post Who Am I? quizzes to test your knowledge of Packers and Steelers of the past. Peeking at Pro Football Reference just ruins the fun for everyone, so dont do it!

title: Risk of Inflation Puts Europe in a Tough Spot
description: Inflation in the euro zone is rising even before the European Central Bank has had a chance to end the European debt crisis. Consumer prices rose at an annual rate of 2.4 percent in January, according to European Union statistics released Monday, significantly above the central banks target of about 2 percent.

title: Ready for the Next Argentine Invasion?
description: TORRONTS has been touted as the hottest thing to arrive from Argentina since the tango. Or at least since malbec. Its a grape, and a white wine, and some say it will be as popular in the United States as pinot grigio.

title: For the Nets, a Brooklyn Stars Cant See
description: Newark

title: The Kennedys Finds a Home on Reelz
description: 4:12 p.m. | Updated

title: Tea Party Shadows Health Care Ruling
description: Among the legal commentariat, which blogs its instant analysis after each turn in the health care litigation, one assertion in Mondays ruling against the law by Judge Roger Vinson is receiving particular attention.

title: Devastating Earthquake Hits Haiti
description: Huge swaths of Port-au-Prince were in ruins after an earthquake, and thousands of people were feared dead.

title: Party Committees Burdened With Debt Heading into 2012
description: One measure of the intensity of the 2010 midterm election is that all of the major party organizations enter the next two years burdened with millions of dollars in debt even as they ramp up for presidential-year campaigns.

title: Chanel Bridal Shot
description: What is happening in this picture, taken Jan. 24 in the Chanel studio? Karl Lagerfeld is holding the gold-embroidered train of Kristen McMenamys wedding dress while a seamstress makes an adjustment to the back. Ms. McMenamy has just told Mr. Lagerfeld that she wont have a problem with the weight of the train if the neckline is opened a bit. Thats apparently what the atelier did before the show the next morning.

title: Buzz Tracker
description: Fabulous Fab Fights Back Fabrice Tourre, the Goldman Sachs trader at the center of the Abacus controversy, is seeking information from financial institutions as part of his defense against a Securities and Exchange Commission lawsuit. He is seeking documents from the Royal Bank of Scotland and the hedge fund Magnetar Capital Partners among others. The subpoenas seek relevant, non-privileged information demonstrating the sophistication and experience of the very entities who the S.E.C. alleges were misled, and the limited number of documents Mr. Tourre now seeks are thus critical to his defense, says his filing in Federal District Court in Manhattan. Bloomberg News

title: 11.2 Million Illegal Immigrants in U.S. in 2010, Report Says; No Change From 09
description: About 11.2 million illegal immigrants were living in the United States in 2010, a number essentially unchanged from the previous year, according to a report published Tuesday by the Pew Hispanic Center, a nonpartisan research organization in Washington.

title: Signing Day Q. and A. With Tom Lemming
description: Tom Lemming of CBS Sports is a leading college football recruiting expert, who will be featured during Wednesdays signing day coverage on the CBS College Sports network. During a phone call, he answered a few questions about which teams were going to be happy on Wednesday and why the countrys No. 1 recruit is keeping people waiting to hear his decision.

title: Playing to Hedge Funds, a Trophy Rises in Midtown
description: When the developer Harry Macklowe contemplated building a boutique office tower with unparalleled amenities at 510 Madison Avenue in the late 2000s, he expected it would be filled with hedge funds and other financial sector tenants who would pay rents well above $100 per square foot.

title: More on Spotting A.T.M. Skimmers
description: To help readers better protect themselves from thieves who want to swipe their sensitive debit card information, weve shared pictures in the past of how to spot skimming devices on A.T.M.s.

title: The Invisible Devin Harris
description: New Jerseys Devin Harris is entering the prime of his career, and yet a number of factors - the sheer number of talented point guards in the league, an age that puts him just outside fetish range for a young player, and he plays for the 15-34 Nets - have almost completely obscured him from public view. The Nets are a headline fixture this season, but almost exclusively for rumors related to Carmelo Anthonys inevitable exodus from Denver. In those reports, rarely is Harris referred to as anything more than a salary-matching asset. Its as if, because hes not 22 years old with a lifetime of basketball ahead of him, Harris once-high profile has been all but erased.

title: Best Western Offers New Labels Within Its Brand
description: Best Western has announced that this week it is designating two upscale tiers under its brand. In addition to Best Western, travelers now will be able to reserve rooms in Best Western Plus and Best Western Premier.

title: Red Bull Takes Lead as Winter Testing Begins
description: Winter testing for the Formula One season began on Tuesday in Valencia, Spain, with the Red Bull team and its driver, Sebastian Vettel, world champions, setting the fastest times of the day.

title: Producer of Nissan Leafs Home Charger Strikes Distribution Deal
description: With the goal of making home-charger installation as easy as rigging up track lighting, a new partnership was announced Tuesday between Milbank Manufacturing  an electrical-equipment metering and distribution company  and AeroVironment, the official home-charger producer for the Nissan Leaf electric vehicle.

title: An Interview With a Genius
description: LOS ANGELES  Does Jerry Bruckheimer throw around superlatives casually? (Dont answer.) On Monday, Mr. Bruckheimer, the big-budget-entertainment producer, hosted a lunch for Geoffrey Rush to celebrate his performance in The Kings Speech, and called Mr. Rush  who also happens to star as Captain Barbossa in Mr. Bruckheimers Pirates of the Caribbean series  a genius.
