title: Zarela Is Closing
description: Zarela, the Mexican restaurant that has been a fixture at 953 Second Avenue (50th Street) for 23 years, will close after dinner on Feb. 13.

title: Report Says Secret Jails, Run by Iraq, Stay Open
description: BAGHDAD  Iraqi security forces controlled directly by Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki continue to hold and to torture detainees in secret jails despite his vows last year to end such practices, according to a statement from Human Rights Watch released Tuesday.

title: Phantoms of the Mind, No Longer Shocking but No Less Haunting
description: Judith Guests 1976 novel, Ordinary People, and the 1980 film adaptation starring Timothy Hutton, were groundbreaking because they underscored Ms. Guests title. Mental illness could occur in the most ordinary families, these works suggested. It could happen to anyone.

title: Gormans No. 1 Priority Is Fixing Fixed-Income
description: Two weeks after Morgan Stanley reported a loss in its fixed-income group, the firms chief executive, James P. Gorman, told investors at the firms financial services conference that fixing the unit was his No. 1 priority.

title: A Dexterous Sextet Balances Trills and Tempos
description: Many new-music ensembles specialize in a particular aesthetic, but Eighth Blackbird, an adventurous sextet, explored contrasting corners of the compositional spectrum in its concert at Zankel Hall on Monday evening.

title: The Paradox of Corporate Taxes
description: The Carnival Corporation wouldnt have much of a business without help from various branches of the government. The United States Coast Guard keeps the seas safe for Carnivals cruise ships. Customs officers make it possible for Carnival cruises to travel to other countries. State and local governments have built roads and bridges leading up to the ports where Carnivals ships dock.

title: Back at the Keyboard After a Difficult Interlude
description: Le Poisson Rouge is most closely identified with the world of new music, but since its founding it has also regularly featured traditional piano recitals. Its first classical music show, in 2008, featured the pianist Simone Dinnerstein playing the music of Bach and George Crumb, and the roster has since included Jonathan Biss in 2009, Marc-Andr Hamelin in September and, on Monday evening, the charismatic Hlne Grimaud.

title: Clueless in Cairo
description: So President Hosni Mubarak has announced that he wont run for office again in the September elections. That would have been a historic decision if he had made it two weeks ago, and it might have avoided the present mess. But today, its too little, too late. And if the White House has devoted its political capital to getting Mubarak to agree to such a half-measure, then I fear that theres a measure of cluelessness on both sides.

title: Senate Democrats to Allow Early Vote on Health Care Repeal
description: WASHINGTON  Senate Democrats, answering a challenge by Republicans pushing to overturn President Obamas health care overhaul, said the Senate would vote soon, perhaps as early as Wednesday, on a repeal measure, and that they were certain that it would be defeated.

title: Senate Banking Staffer Joins Reed Smith
description: Mark Oesterle, the chief counsel to Republicans on the Senate Banking Committee, has joined Reed Smiths financial regulatory group in the law firms Washington office.

title: Post-Minimalism and Folk Ballads Fuel a Composer
description: Like most composers, Julia Wolfe is often in two places at once psychically: working on new pieces (with working defined as anything from cogitating and experimenting to actually putting the notes on paper) but also seeing that the backlist is getting attention. In recent weeks she has been putting the finishing touches on Iron Maiden, a new solo work for the percussionist Evelyn Glennie, and working on Combat de Boxe, for the Asko Ensemble of the Netherlands. And she has been gathering thoughts for a work for the Ethel string quartet and a vocalist.

title: How Good Is That PMI Number?
description: A good manufacturing survey result. Mostly for my own edification, I thought Id try to figure out how good that number really is. So, using FRED  which now makes it easy to take quarterly averages of monthly data, although the scatterplots arent quite there yet  we can plot PMI against the growth rate of GDP:

title: Senate Wont Allow Earmarks in Spending Bills
description: Bowing to the inevitable, Senator Daniel K. Inouye, the chairman of the Senate Appropriations Committee, announced Tuesday that the panel would not allow pet spending projects known as earmarks to be included in this years appropriations bills.

title: Eugenio Arango, Cuban-Born Musician Known as Totico, Dies at 76
description: Eugenio Arango, better known as Totico, a Cuban-born percussionist and singer who was one of the most celebrated figures in the drumming, dancing and singing culture of New York rumba, died on Jan. 21 in the Bronx, where he lived. He was 76.

title: And Now a Clarification From Ricky Gervais
description: LOS ANGELES  And the headlines just keep coming. Ricky Gervais has offered a clarification to his remarks in Heat magazine. It wasnt the Hollywood Foreign Press Association that suggested he might like to come back and barb them again; it was NBC, which broadcasts the Golden Globes.

title: Comcast and Time Warner Sign Online Streaming Deal
description: In a first-of-its-kind deal, Comcast and Time Warner have signed a new contract that covers the online streaming of channels like TNT, TBS, CNN, and the Cartoon Network.

title: Anatomy of a Scene: 'The Whipping Man'
description: Matthew Lopez comments on a scene from his play.

title: The Bachelor Lifts ABC
description: ABC topped the ratings on Monday night as The Bachelor delivered its largest audience of the season, according to Nielsens estimates. The two-hour episode drew an average of 9.5 million viewers, leading at 8 p.m. but trailing at 9 behind CBSs repeats of Two and a Half Men (11.2 million) and Mike & Molly (9.1 million). Despite a lineup of all reruns, CBS placed second over all. In third place, Fox broadcast a new episode of Human Target at 8 (7.8 million) followed by the season finale of Lie to Me at 9 (7.1 million). NBC was fourth with Chuck (5.6 million) and The Cape (5.3 million), but it won at 10 p.m. with Harrys Law (10.9 million).

title: Rosenfeld Returns to Lazard From Rothschild
description: Lazard said on Tuesday that it had rehired Gerald Rosenfeld as a senior executive, years after the banker left and joined a rival, Rothschild North America.

title: Pictures of the Day: Egypt and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Egypt, Greece and Pakistan.

title: Found: The Owners of That Mysterious Scooter
description: The New York City police on Tuesday solved the case of the serviceable and unsecured cream-colored Vespa that had been left for months in front of 1 Sutton Place South without being driven away, ticketed, towed or taken.

title: Actions of U.S. and China to Shape Deals to Come
description: Harry Campbell

title: Timeline: Hosni Mubarak
description: A chronology of Hosni Mubaraks 30-year rule in Egypt and subsequent fall from power.

title: Obama Urges Quick Transition in Egypt
description: Updated On Tuesday night, just hours after Hosni Mubarak announced he would not seek re-election to the presidency of Egypt, President Obama declared that an orderly transition in Egypt must begin now, but he stopped short of demanding that Mr. Mubarak leave office immediately. Read more

title: Why Dinan Worries About Fate of Small Hedge Funds
description: PALM BEACH, Fla.  For the head of a multibillion-dollar hedge fund, James G. Dinan worries a lot about the fate of the industrys littlest players.

title: A Place of Mystery and Elixirs
description: I KNEW I was lost within minutes of setting foot in the grooming and fragrance outpost MiN New York, a naf in need of a road map.

title: Jaipur Jaunt
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#221", 592, 400, true, chameleonData);

title: Antarctic Cruise Ship Has Close Scrape
Humans, Who Once Buried Their Treasures, Now Bury Their Dangers
description: I am tempted to call Into Eternity the most interesting documentary, and one of the most disturbing films, of the year so far, but such a pronouncement, always dubious in early February, seems especially absurd in this case. The film, directed by Michael Madsen  a Danish Conceptual artist, not the American tough-guy actor  takes an unusually long view. Mr. Madsens ruminative, even-toned narration is directed not at present-day critics but at viewers who may happen upon this visual artifact at some remote date in the future, as much as 100,000 years from now.

title: The Details on Corporate Taxes
description: My column this week mentions several companies that have paid relatively little in corporate taxes in the last five years. Each company explained to me that it was complying with all tax laws, and I have no doubt that every one is.

title: With No Charlie Sheen, CBS Mulls Its Monday Lineup
description: With Charlie Sheen, the star of the hit CBS comedy Two and a Half Men, now in rehabilitation for his persistent problems with addiction, the initial reaction at the network  and at the shows production company, Warner Brothers  has been relief.

title: Packers Presidents Labor Perspective
description: ARLINGTON, Tex. - Green Bay Packers President Mark Murphy has a unique perspective on the N.F.L.s current labor strife. A former player, Murphy was the Washington Redskins union representative and a member of the players negotiating committee during the early 1980s when the N.F.L. was also in the throes of a labor battle.

title: Antiquities Chief Says Sites Are Largely Secure
description: A vast majority of Egypts museums and archaeological sites are secure and have not been looted, Zahi Hawass, Egypts chief antiquities official, said in a telephone interview on Tuesday. He also rejected comparisons between the current situation in Egypt and scenes of chaos and discord that resulted in the destruction of artifacts in Iraq and Afghanistan.

title: Competition for Preschool
description: I moved to the suburbs so that I would not have to put myself through preschool admissions. Yes, you read that right; I did it for me more than my children. I knew I didnt have the stamina or ego strength to get through a process that weeds out three-year-olds based on their academic potential.

title: Toasty Coasters to Protect and Serve
description: What do you mean by toast? These cork coasters from the Museum of Modern Art cover two definitions. They look like slices of bread and come in a plastic bag to suggest a loaf of supermarket multigrain. But then, of course, they hold your wine, beer or spirits after you lift a glass in celebration. They also double as trivets for a hot dish of hors doeuvres to go with the drinks.

title: Dining Calendar
description: Lets Talk Food

title: Off the Menu
description: Opening

title: Salumi, Cheese and Beer at a New Greenpoint Shop
description: Eastern District, the name of this spacious new store, was what they once called the industrial area of Brooklyn encompassing parts of Greenpoint, Bushwick and Williamsburg, said Beth Lewand, who owns the store, along with her husband, Chris Gray. A former Polish butcher shop, its lined with shelves and counters that feature about 50 cheeses and many cured meats, mostly American; and sweets including cupcakes from Robicellis in Sunset Park in flavors like Creamsicle and almond mocha truffle. They stock about 100 different beers and have a rotating selection on tap for filling growlers. And the shelves are lined with condiments and snacks, mostly bearing Brooklyn labels. They also sell cheese boards from Daskam & Dworkis, furniture makers nearby, who fashion the boards from scrap wood and barter them to Eastern District for cheese.

title: Maple Syrup Slightly Spiked, and Vinegars With a Past
description: Aging maple syrup in charred-oak barrels used for bourbon has become something of a trend. Mikuni, a Seattle importer and distributor, uses barrels from Tuthilltown Spirits in Gardiner, N.Y., for its Noble Tonic 01, a maple syrup with a subtly spiked edge, and the flask-like bottle is so handsome I would put it on my breakfast table without decanting it into a pitcher. Once the syrup has been bottled, the company uses the same barrels to age 10-year-old Spanish sherry vinegar for another six months for Noble Tonic 03, giving it a more deeply mellow complexity. Noble Tonic 02 is a maple syrup flavored with vanilla and chamomile. They also age French chardonnay vinegar with Egyptian lemon, similar to Meyer lemon, for an added citric touch in their Noble Tonic 04.

title: In Las Vegas, a Good Story Helps Sell Expensive Sakes
description: ERIC SWANSON was on a mission. He needed to track down the sake of the gods. Each time the Lunar New Year rolls around, casinos in Las Vegas begin bracing for an influx of whales from Asia  high-rolling gamblers who, when dining and drinking between marathon bouts at the gaming tables, tend to specialize in the grandest of gestures. When theyre eating at the top Japanese restaurants in town, the whales dont want nice little $20 (or even $200) bottles of sake. The sake should be ambrosial, sure, but what they really want is something flagrantly expensive and difficult to find.

title: Donatella
description: 184 Eighth Avenue (19th Street), (212) 493-5150, donatellanyc.com.

title: Pepperoni: On Top
description: ACROSS the United States, artisanal pizza joints are opening faster than Natalie Portman movies. But inside those imported ovens, pepperoni  by far Americas most popular pizza topping  is as rare as a black swan.

title: Heartbreak
description: 29 East Second Street (Second Avenue), (212) 777-2502, heartbreakrestaurant.com.

title: Recalling the Reign of Taylor and King
description: Once upon a time in Lotus Land, the Troubadour, a 300-seat nightclub in West Hollywood, Calif., became the center of the singer-songwriter movement that dominated American pop during much of the 1970s. Created by Doug Weston, a wild-haired eccentric whose favorite attire was a green corduroy suit that earned him the nickname Jolly Green Giant, the club is fondly remembered in Morgan Nevilles documentary Troubadours as the place that kick-started a musical genre. Mr. Weston died in 1999, but the Troubadour still flourishes.

title: TimesCast | February 1, 2011
description: President Obama speaks and Egyptians react after President Hosni Mubarak announces that he will not run again in September.

title: Ward Backtracks From Criticisms of N.F.L.
description: In a round-table player discussion about head injuries published by GQ Tuesday morning, Pittsburgh Steelers receiver Hines Ward was rather candid: He said that nobody paid attention to the N.F.L.s video about illegal tackles in October; that the league is hypocritical about player safety; and said that players are still hiding their concussions from doctors as passionately as ever.

title: Talking About the Black Swan Costumes
description: Some of you may have seen this interview with the costume designer Amy Westcott on the Clothes on Film blog, discussing Black Swan and her other work.

title: M.L.S. All-Star Game at Red Bull Arena
description: Major League Soccer will play its 2011 all-star game, against an opponent to be determined, at Red Bull Arena in Harrison, N.J., on July 27.

title: Portuguese Press Jostles for News About Murder Suspect
description: The moment Rodrigo Freixo posted on his Facebook page a message that he was headed to New York, his friends were quick to post snide advice.

title: In Mlaga, a Taste of Picasso (and Iberian Cuisine)
description: A good tapas restaurant can be a budget travelers best friend in Spain: a few small plates, free bread refills, a glass of house wine, and youve got a cheap meal.

title: The Groundhog Develops a Sense of Nuance
description: The following is a work of fiction. Staten Island Chuck the groundhog does not talk. We know nothing of his handlers personal life. Michael Kardos co-directs the the creative writing program at Mississippi State University. He will be reading at Freebird Books in Brooklyn on Saturday at its Punxsutawney Phil retirement party.

title: Two Hints at Stepped-Up Media Rivalry in Online Streaming
description: The increasing importance of Internet rights for television channels and shows has been vividly demonstrated twice in the last few days.

title: Obama Urges Quick Transition in Egypt
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama declared on Tuesday night that an orderly transition in Egypt must begin now, but he stopped short of demanding that President Hosni Mubarak leave office immediately.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,455 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

title: Troy Vincent Says Once a Player Rep, Always a Player Rep
description: DALLAS

title: Undercover Video Released by Anti-Abortion Group
description: An anti-abortion group Tuesday released undercover video taken in its latest attempt to discredit the Planned Parenthood Federation of America. The group, Live Action, said the video depicted an employee at a New Jersey Planned Parenthood clinic offering to help cover up a sex ring so that under-age girls could receive health services. Planned Parenthood said it had promptly notified federal law enforcement authorities after the visit, which was one of at least 11 made by the same imposters to clinics in six states. It said it was investigating whether the employee in the video, which it said had been edited, may have violated the organizations policies.

title: Pennsylvania: Ocean Liner Finds Buyer
description: A private group dedicated to saving the United States, a once-glamorous 1952 ocean liner that has been mothballed in Philadelphia since 1996, announced Tuesday that it had purchased the ship for $3 million. The SS United States Conservancy has been seeking development plans for the rusting hulk, a restoration job that could cost more than $200 million, according to Susan Gibbs, the groups president. In November, the conservancy proposed making the liner part of a casino project in Philadelphia; competing plans for Miami and New York City are also under discussion. Ms. Gibbs called the New York idea especially promising but would not comment further. The group is seeking $1 million in donations to save portions of the ships engine rooms, which are largely intact, and for other preservation work. A $5.8 million gift from H. F. Lenfest, a Philadelphia philanthropist, covered the sale price and about 20 months of maintenance.

title: Canadians Outraged After Report of Cruelty in Mass Killing of Sled Dogs
description: OTTAWA  During the Winter Olympics last year, the main attractions in Whistler, British Columbia, were the skiing and sliding events. But tourists looking for something different could also book dog sled rides pulled by teams of energetic and lovable Alaskan racing huskies.

title: This Is Your Brain on Media Day
description: Nothing mixes the mundane and the insane like media day at the Super Bowl.

title: Special Counsel Named in Ensign Case
description: The Senate Ethics Committee announced Tuesday that it has named a special counsel to help determine whether to bring formal charges against Senator John Ensign, the Nevada Republican who has been accused of using his political influence to help cover up an affair he had with the wife of a former top aide. Carol Elder Brown, a former Justice Department prosecutor and an experienced criminal defense lawyer, was appointed to the unusual role, according to a statement released by the committee. She will help with what the committee said is a preliminary inquiry, which follows an investigation by staff members that has already taken about a year. Mr. Ensign, who is up for re-election in 2012, has been cleared by investigators at the Department of Justice and the Federal Election Commission.

title: Sabres Sold to an Oil and Gas Executive
description: The Buffalo Sabres owner, Tom Golisano, has reached an agreement to sell the club to the Pennsylvania oil and gas executive Terry Pegula.

title: About Two Dozen Arraigned in Credit Card Fraud Scheme
description: About two dozen people have been charged with stealing credit card data and using it to make counterfeit credit cards that they used to buy and resell goods across the country, according to an indictment filed on Tuesday in State Supreme Court in Manhattan.

title: Women at War
description: What do women have to do with the origins of the Civil War? Growing up in Virginia in the 1970s, I often heard this answer: nothing.

title: An Apple E-Book Rule Tightens
description: When you see people flipping through e-books on iPads or iPhones, there is a good chance they bought the books through Amazon.com, not Apple.

title: Rewards for Rebellion: Tiny Nation and Crown for Life
description: PRINCIPALITY OF HUTT RIVER, Australia  Some people do think that Hutt River is really a new, young country, but I get a lot of German tourists through here, and I take pride in telling them that Hutt River is not really a new, young country.

title: Ratings Agencies Keep Their Influence
description: Rating agencies were just branded essential cogs in the wheel of financial destruction. Despite the label from the commission studying causes of the crisis, rating firms are on the mend. Resurgent markets help. But policy makers, especially Basel officials, have failed to dilute their influence.

title: Malaysian Forest Ebbing at Rapid Rate, Report Says
description: Malaysia is cutting down forests at more than triple the average rate of the rest of Asia, with the destruction concentrated in the highly biodiverse peatland forests on the island of Borneo, a new analysis of satellite data reveals.

title: New Chief Revises Goals and Spending for Pfizer
description: Pfizer, the drug maker, announced plans Tuesday to slash its research spending by as much as $2.9 billion in the next two years, including closing the English labs that invented Viagra.

title: Media Day: Brett Keisel
description: Brett Keisel's beard has gotten a lot of attention in Dallas.

title: Egyptian Voices Heard Online
description: In response to the Egyptian's government's restrictions on the Internet, a new social media service allowed Egyptians to post audio recordings using phones and Twitter.

title: Arrival of Nokia Bolsters a Citys Hopes
description: SUNNYVALE, Calif.  City officials are hoping that Nokias new building here, transformed in just six months to a gleaming corporate headquarters from a structural skeleton, will be the catalyst to revive a troubled 36-acre downtown redevelopment project after more than a decade of false starts by one developer after another.

title: Can North Carolina Deliver Again?
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama signaled Tuesday that he would try to follow the same path to re-election that he charted in his first campaign, selecting Charlotte, N.C., to host the 2012 Democratic convention in a decision that instantly confirmed the state as a new presidential battleground.

title: Lottery Numbers
Israel, Alone Again?
description: Jerusalem

title: Ferries to Ply East River Far More Regularly Soon
description: For all their dominance on Staten Island, ferries have long struggled to muscle their way into the citys mass transit mainstream. Experiments in Queens and Brooklyn have been held back by infrequent service, outsize operating costs and low ridership.

title: Yes, the Diners Open. How About a Seat at the Counter?
description: IN a new commercial for Dennys, a man orders chicken wraps at the counter, and when his waitress replies, Anything else, hon? he asks her if she calls everyone that.

title: U.S. General Sees Success Even if Pakistan Doesnt Act
description: WASHINGTON  Lt. Gen. David Rodriguez, the No. 2 commander in Afghanistan, said Tuesday that the United States and NATO could succeed in the war even if Pakistan refused to shut down a lawless frontier sanctuary that militants use for staging attacks on forces across the border in Afghanistan.

title: Bet on Foreclosure Boom Turns Sour for Investors
description: David J. Stern may be the best-known beneficiary of the foreclosure boom, having made millions in recent years from evictions processed by his law firm, the largest of its kind in Florida. But when he took part of his firm public early last year, he had plenty of help from a constellation of investors also looking to cash in on people losing their homes.

title: For Shields, Answers Werent in the Cards, but on the Cards
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  Like anyone trying to learn a new vocabulary, Green Bay cornerback Sam Shields was lost. He could not make sense of his assignments, which was not a surprise considering he played only one year on defense in college and the Packers employ a kaleidoscope 3-4 scheme.

title: Steelers Receiver Brown Made Key Plays in Playoff Victories
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  As the mayhem of media day unfolded all around him Tuesday, Antonio Brown retired to a far sideline at Cowboys Stadium. He wore a baseball cap turned backward and Gucci sunglasses, as if he wished to remain anonymous.

title: Video: This Is Your Brain on Media Day
description: Nothing mixes the mundane and the insane like media day at the Super Bowl. To get an idea of what Im talking about, watch the following video, which captures the scene from one end of Cowboys Stadium to the other. Can you make it to the end without getting motion sickness?

title: Extra Sips of Sake
description: I picked up a lot of fascinating stories while I was reporting this weeks article about sake.

title: Dakota Co-op Board Is Accused of Bias
description: The Dakota, the legendary New York apartment building, has long been famous for its celebrity residents, including Leonard Bernstein, Lauren Bacall and John Lennon.

title: Keisels Beard Is the Scruff of Legend
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  Jack Passion knows a thing or two about beards. With his orange-red waterfall of hot lava, as he called it, spilling from his chin, he is the countrys only full-time professional beard grower. It is not a lucrative job, really, but between the worldwide contests he wins and the book he wrote about beard growing, he can be considered an expert on the subject.

title: City Workers Face Penalty After Storm
description: Tens of thousands of New York City employees who did not report for work during the snowstorm on Thursday could lose a day of leave  even though Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg sent out a predawn message that day saying that all city nonemergency offices and schools would be closed.

title: Metro-North Cuts Service on the New Haven Line
description: With half of their fleet on the New Haven line knocked out by weather-related repairs, Metro-North Railroad officials said Tuesday that they could no longer run regular weekday service on that branch for the indefinite future.

title: Two Cities, Two Parties, One Big Steam Bath
description: Charlotte and Tampa have at least two things in common. Both are likely to be baking in heat and humidity in the summer of 2012. Tampa will have the Republicans sweating, not just from the average high temperatures in August of 90 degrees but because if their nominee fails to impress in Florida, the party may well lose the election. Democrats in Charlotte may be only slightly cooler, as the average highs in September are in the mid-80s. But if President Obama loses North Carolina, he could still win re-election.

title: Google to Microsoft: Search Gotcha
description: Google has weathered criticism in the past that it has copied some features of Microsofts Bing search engine, like background images. Now it has turned the tables, contending that Bing copies something much more important: search results.

title: Panel Votes to Close 10 City High Schools
description: After six hours of public testimony, the Panel for Educational Policy voted early on Wednesday to close 10 city high schools and open a new charter school in the heart of the Upper West Side.

title: Quiet Acts of Protest on a Noisy Day
description: CAIRO  The retired general in the blue suit walked alone, with a cane, as hundreds of Egyptian protesters surged past him, chanting and holding signs. He stopped to catch his breath, grabbing the railing of a bridge so he could look out at the Nile.

title: Group Releases Hidden Tapes of Planned Parenthood
description: An anti-abortion group seeking to discredit Planned Parenthood released an undercover video on Tuesday that appears to show a clinic manager advising a sex trafficker how to get medical care for prostitutes as young as 14.

title: Madoff Had Wide Role in Mets Finances
description: When Fred Wilpons son Jeff was married at Fresh Meadow Country Club on Long Island, Bernard L. Madoff and his wife were there. When Mr. Madoffs son Mark was married at the same country club, Mr. Wilpon, the principal owner of the Mets, was a guest as well.

title: States Diverge on How to Deal With Health Care Ruling
description: States took broadly divergent approaches on Tuesday to a federal judges ruling that invalidated the Obama health care law, while Congressional Republicans used the decision to build momentum for a vote on repealing the act.

title: China Is Poised to Raise Rates Again, Bankers Say
description: HONG KONG  Chinas government, increasingly worried about soaring inflation, plans to continue tightening its money supply and will probably raise interest rates again within the month.

title: N.F.L. Unions Ads Squashed by Network
description: The N.F.L. and its players have been throwing verbal barbs at each other in recent weeks as they try to work out a new labor agreement. The players union, though, appears to have lost at least one megaphone.

title: Report Foresees Quick Gulf of Mexico Recovery
description: The Gulf of Mexico should recover from the environmental damage caused by the enormous BP oil spill last year faster than many people expected, according to new estimates in reports commissioned by Kenneth R. Feinberg, the administrator of the $20 billion compensation fund.

title: A Hacking Case Becomes a War of the Tabloids
description: LONDON  It was a classic tabloid scoop: a young womans account of a two-year affair with the actor Ralph Fiennes, spiced up with racy details of what he liked to do and how he liked to do it. Three newspapers  The Sunday Mirror, The Mail on Sunday and News of the World  carried their versions of the tale on Feb. 5, 2006.

title: Wednesday: Stirring Time
description: WEDNESDAYS PUZZLE  Have you ever been in a group where someone tells an in joke that only a few people understand? Those people who are in break up with laughter, and the rest of us are left wondering why we dont get it.

title: Candles, Matzo, Wine and Some Unusual Hosts
description: New Yorkers both Jewish and gentile are probably aware that Seders come in all styles and sizes. But the ceremony honoring the first night of Passover in The Whipping Man, an atmospheric period drama by Matthew Lopez that opened on Tuesday night at City Centers Stage I, surely has few equals in its arresting strangeness.

title: Video: Brett Keisel at Media Day
description: There may not be a hotter topic right now in Dallas than Brett Keisels beard, which has 20,000 Facebook fans, a Web site and a song. Keisel has denied taking beard-enhancing drugs.

title: Winter Storm Disrupts Much of the Country
description: As many as 30 states could be affected by the latest storm and its accompanying snow and ice.

title: Union Rebuffed in Bid to Keep N.F.L. From Lockout TV Money
description: A court-appointed special master rejected on Tuesday the N.F.L. players unions claim that the league should not have access to $4 billion in television payments if there is a lockout. But he awarded the union $6.9 million in damages in connection with two particular contracts, with ESPN and NBC.

title: Piazza Working on Memoir, Not on Buying Piece of Mets
description: Mike Piazza earned more than $120 million in his playing career, and if he invested wisely, he might have enough to buy a share of his old team, the Mets. But Piazza, who led the Mets to their last pennant, in 2000, is not interested.

title: Jerry Jones Says a 22-Game Season Would Be Doable
description: The N.F.L. will have no trouble playing 18 and even more regular-season games if it can persuade the players to accept an expanded schedule, Jerry Jones, the owner of the Dallas Cowboys, said Tuesday.

title: Beyond Mubarak
description: The announcement from President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt that he would not run for re-election was welcome, if he means it, but it was unlikely to be enough. It is up to the Egyptian people to decide. But as a proud nationalist, Mr. Mubarak can best contribute to Egypts stability and future by stepping aside and letting an interim government take over until truly free elections can be held.

title: 7th Youth Arrested in Bullying of Teenager in Philadelphia
description: PHILADELPHIA  A seventh teenager was arrested on Tuesday in a bullying incident in which a 13-year-old student was kicked and beaten before being hung by his coat from a spiked fence post, the police said.

title: Judicial Activism on Health Reform
description: A ruling by a Federal District Court judge in Florida that the entire health care reform law is unconstitutional was a breathtaking example of judicial activism and overreach.

title: Nassau in a Ditch, Again
description: There is no reason that Nassau County, one of the wealthiest counties in the United States and home to some of the highest property taxes and richest residents anywhere, should be in such a dire state  its budget $176 million out of whack and its finances now subject to a humiliating takeover by a state control board.

title: A Food Manifesto for the Future
description: For decades, Americans believed that we had the worlds healthiest and safest diet. We worried little about this diets effect on the environment or on the lives of the animals (or even the workers) it relies upon. Nor did we worry about its ability to endure  that is, its sustainability.

title: Justice and the I.G.
description: The Department of Justices inspector general, Glenn Fine, stepped down on Friday after a decade of pushing to clean up and depoliticize a hyperpoliticized department. He will be missed.

title: Bye Bye, Mubarak
description: WASHINGTON

title: Echoes From the Revolt in Egypt
description: To the Editor:

title: Penguins Top Rangers in Bruising Win
description: In the first game after the All-Star break, it was all about who was there for the Rangers, who was not there for the Penguins and the possible inadequacy of the N.H.L.s concussion protocols.

title: Paying for Health Care: Different Approaches
description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Israel: Netanyahu Cancels Appointment to Top Army Post
description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu on Tuesday canceled the appointment of Maj. Gen. Yoav Galant, left, as the Israeli Armys incoming chief of staff. General Galant was supposed to take over from Lt. Gen. Gabi Ashkenazi in mid-February but his nomination has been challenged in court over accusations that he illegally took over land around his home in a village in northern Israel. Israels state comptroller said that General Galant lied in a court affidavit about the acquisition of the land. Israels attorney general ruled on Tuesday that he would not be able to defend Gen. Galants appointment. The Defense Ministry said in a statement that the deputy chief of staff, Maj. Gen. Yair Naveh, would assume the top post for up to 60 days.

title: State Support for Education
description: To the Editor:

title: B.E., Before Egypt. A.E., After Egypt.
description: RAMALLAH, West Bank

title: Beat the Crowds to Up-and-Coming Destinations
description: THE upside of visiting an emerging destination is pristine landscapes, reasonable  if not decidedly cheap  prices and the rare opportunity to experience the authenticity of a place before its overrun by tourists.

title: To Judge Knicks, Remember From Where They Came
description: Fans and pundits will surely debate the extent and the quality of the Knicks progress this season.

title: Corrections
description: NATIONAL

title: Alderson Faces Fans and Acknowledges a Perception Issue
description: Sandy Alderson, the Mets general manager, said the only time he had been recognized since coming to New York was when a Transportation Security Administration agent noticed him at La Guardia Airport. Now he is the face of the Mets rehabilitation effort.

title: Shaken-Baby Syndrome Faces New Questions in Court
description: At 4 months, Noah Whitmer was an easy baby. Super tranquilo, remembers Trudy Eliana Muoz Rueda, who took care of Noah at her home day care center in Fairfax County, Va. Rueda and Noahs mother, Erin Whitmer, both noticed when he stopped taking his bottle well and napping as usual in the middle of his fifth month, in April 2009. Whitmer thought this was because Noah had just started eating solid food. She and Rueda talked about it early on April 20, both of them hunched over Noah in his car seat when Whitmer dropped him off.

title: Phys Ed: More Bone (and Less Fat) Through Exercise
description: For those requiring additional reasons to show up at the running path or at the gym in the dreary heart of winter, science has come up with a compelling new motivation. Exercise can, it appears, keep your bone marrow from becoming too flabby.

title: Mubaraks Allies and Foes Clash in Egypt
description: CAIRO  President Hosni Mubarak struck back at his opponents on Wednesday, unleashing waves of his supporters armed with clubs, rocks, knives and firebombs in a concerted assault on thousands of antigovernment protesters in Tahrir Square calling for an end to his authoritarian rule.

title: Word of the Day | blanch
description: blanch \blanch\ verb

title: Slight Rise in Donations to Colleges Seen in 2010
description: The nations colleges and universities received charitable contributions of $28 billion in 2010, an increase of 0.5 percent from the previous year, according to the annual survey by the Council for Aid to Education.

title: Brian Rust, Father of Modern Discography, Dies at 88
description: Brian Rust, a discographic detective who compiled comprehensive guides to recorded jazz and other popular music, in the process setting the standard for the modern field, died on Jan. 5 in Swanage, in southern England. He was 88.

title: Photo Replay: Feb. 1
description: A look at a footrace up the Empire State Building and at media day in Arlington, Tex., the site of the Super Bowl.

title: Alan Uglow, Abstract Painter, Dies at 69
description: Alan Uglow, an abstract painter of light-filled geometries whose expansive fields, bordered with notched lines, reflected in part his passion for soccer, died on Jan. 20 in Manhattan, where he lived. He was 69.

title: Readers Storm Photos
description: Our readers sent in their best shots of the snow storm hurtling through the Midwest and East Coast.

title: Cyclone Lashes Storm-Weary Australia
description: SYDNEY, Australia  With winds howling at up to 185 miles per hour, a huge cyclone made landfall in the predawn hours on Thursday along the coast of the already storm-battered state of Queensland, with widespread reports of property damage and power failures.

title: News Quiz | February 2, 2011
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: Bet on Foreclosure Boom Turns Sour
description: David J. Stern may be the best-known beneficiary of the foreclosure boom, having made millions in recent years from evictions processed by his law firm, the largest of its kind in Florida.

title: From Lolita to Lepidoptera
description: WHAT well-known literary works did Vladimir Nabokov write? WHAT parallel existence complemented his writing career? WHAT hypothesis did he make about the evolution of butterflies?

title: Test Yourself | Math, Feb. 2, 2011
description: Test your math skills with todays question, created by Patrick Honner at Math for America from the article Political Focus on Jobs in Health Fight.

title: Facing Unrest, Yemens Leader Says He Will Step Down in 2013
description: SANA, Yemen  In another reverberation of the popular anger rocking the region, the longtime president of Yemen, Ali Abdullah Saleh, announced concessions on Wednesday that included suspending his campaign for constitutional changes that would allow him to remain president for life and pledging that his son would not seek to be his successor.

title: How Are You Handling This Winter Weather?
description: About six weeks ago, we asked you how you felt about winter weather. But that was before winter even technically began. So in honor of Wednesdays observance of Groundhog Day, we ask: Are you ready for six more weeks of winter? Or do you hope that Punxsutawney Phil predicts that springs calmer, warmer days will come early this year? And if you live in a place thats been very snowy this year, how are you coping?

title: Daily Lexeme: Holophrase
description: Todays word, in association with the voluminous Oxford English Dictionary, is

title: Wishing for the Feel of Hard Pavement
description: Katherine Vasquez cant get enough of New York City. She loves its neon signs. She loves its holiday lights. She loves its museums, its bookshops, its parks, its fashionistas. But for Ms. Vasquez, who was born with spina bifida, getting around can be a challenge. She cant feel her feet, so she navigates the city in a manual wheelchair.

title: At London Show, Art Meets Science
description: Throughout the three-day Kinetica Art Fair, fans of scientific specifics  robotics, wave forms, gravity  will grapple with more human, philosophical ideas  spirituality, relationships. The fair, which runs Feb. 4 to 6, is a place to witness artists harnessing the powers of nature and cosmic energy as a means of expression, according to event organizers.

title: Groundhog Days: A (Chilly) Look Back
description: Sure, if youve read one Groundhog Day story, youve read em all. But over the course of 110 years, The Timess approach to this most contrived of holidays has evolved. So with apologies to Bill Murrays character, here are the beginnings of 24 Groundhog Day stories from the Times archives. Be sure to check out the one from 1933.

title: In Construction, More Spending Can Also Mean Less
description: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago.

title: The Early Word: Eyes on Egypt
description: In Todays Times:

title: There Are Two Kinds of C.E.O.
description: I recently had an interesting conversation with Rafael Pastor, the chairman and chief executive of Vistage, a leading organization for chief executives. He relayed a story that one of his members had told him. This particular C.E.O. has a school-age son who came home one day and asked if his father would call himself something other than a C.E.O. It seems that the boys classmates were giving him a hard time about the fact that his father runs a company  as if it were something to be embarrassed by. My first thought was, What? Maybe I could understand it if his father were a politician! But then I started thinking.

title: Contours of 2012 Campaign Emerge
description: The worlds attention was riveted on Tuesday to the unfolding revolution in Egypt and to President Obamas reaction.

title: Earnings Rebound at Nomura but Miss Expectations
description: Nomura Holdings on Wednesday reported net income  of 13.4 billion yen in the three-month period ended Dec. 31, compared with 1.1 billion yen in the previous quarter. Quarterly profit rose 31 percent on a year-over-year basis.

title: Deals Buttress Profit at Lazard
description: 7:09 p.m. | Updated Lazard said on Wednesday that it had earned $104.5 million in the fourth quarter, as the independent investment banks core deal advisory business picked up.

title: Updates on Day 9 of Egypt Protests
description: On Wednesday, The Lede continues to supplement coverage of street protests in Egypt from our colleagues in Cairo with updates mixing breaking news alerts, reports from other Web sites and video, photographs and eyewitness accounts posted on social networks. A stream of Twitter updates from bloggers and journalists were following is in the right column of this blog. See our 9:21 a.m. update for live video from Cairos Tahrir Square. A slide show below shows where Wednesdays street battles have taken place. Readers can share information in the comment thread below or send photographs or video from Egypt to pix@nyt.com.

title: A Few Sighs of Relief Over Cuomos Budget
description: Given the pressure for deep cuts in hard economic times, New York environmental groups seemed relieved that Gov. Andrew Cuomo was more surgeon than hatchet man in announcing his proposed budget on Tuesday.

title: Weak Earnings and Unrest in Egypt Push Down Shares
description: Most stocks fell on Wednesday as earnings reports from companies including Broadcom and Aflac disappointed investors and as antigovernment protests in Egypt worsened.

description: Todays preferred mode of transit: ice skates with detachable crampons and pontoons. If youre committed to things that go on wheels or tracks, though, heres the deal.

title: Graphic Content | Carter Sans
description: Rarely is a typeface introduced with as much fanfare as a new movie, book or song. But when it is created by Matthew Carter, the first typeface designer to be awarded a MacArthur Fellowship, the unveiling is almost a celebrity event. And if youre a graphic designer, taking it out for a test drive (which is how sampling a typeface is sometimes referred to these days) is much anticipated.

title: Adams/Nixon: A Kitchen Debate on Portraying a President in Opera
description: The world of opera, or the performing end at least, is no Republican Party bastion. The makers of Nixon in China, which opens on Wednesday night at the Metropolitan Opera, made that clear at a panel discussion at the Met on Tuesday. But they took pains to portray the Richard Nixon of the opera, which depicts his ground-shaking visit to China in 1972, as a complicated, multilayered character.

description: MANCHESTER, England  More than halfway through a soccer season in which the worlds most valuable sports team has yet to lose a match, the singing and banners proclaim, Were Man United, we do what we want.

Read it and weep, Mr. Shankman said, adding in another emphatic word we cant use as he pulled the guild card out of his wallet at the groups awards ceremony.

title: Senior Cleric in Indonesia Is Charged With Terrorism
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia  One of Indonesias most senior radical Muslim clerics could face the death penalty after prosecutors formally lodged terrorism charges against him on Wednesday.

title: Oils Well That Ends Well: Dallas Stars Will Return in TNT Sequel
description: Its a dream come true for fans of Dallas, the vintage-1980s prime-time soap opera, and presumably one that doesnt end with Pam Barnes waking up to find Bobby Ewing in the shower and an entire season of the show wiped out. The pilot episode of a new Dallas series being prepared for the TNT cable network will feature Larry Hagman, Patrick Duffy and Linda Gray, reprising their roles from the original CBS series, TNT said on Tuesday night.

title: How Much Does Bing Borrow From Google?
description: I certainly do not have any expertise in Web search. I can claim some, however, in another area that is highly relevant to it: trying to optimize the performance of statistical algorithms.

description: The Op-Ed columnist Nicholas D. Kristof reported from Cairo immediately after Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak announced that he wouldn't seek a new term.

description: Be ready for an icy glaze during your morning commute. Light freezing rain and mist will continue on Wednesday, turning into ordinary rain when the temperature goes as high as 40.

title: What Am I Doing?
description: The response to the departure of my Minimalist column was spine-tingling  to me, if not to anyone else  but the joy Im feeling in beginning a Times Opinion column is immeasurable. There is a line about opinions and how everyone has one (The Times wont let me print it, of course), but opinion pieces about food, right here, can have a real impact  assuming, of course, that I handle my new job well.

title: Cameras, and Rules Against Them, Stir Passions in Delivery Rooms
description: CASCADE, Md.  When Laurie Shifler was expecting her eighth child, she was so upset about a local hospitals new policy restricting photographs of births that she started an online petition. Hundreds of people, near and far, signed it, many expressing outrage that a hospital would prevent parents from recording such a momentous occasion, one that could never be recaptured.

description: Portuguese government borrowing costs fell at an auction Wednesday, and bonds strengthened generally in Europe as expectations grew that policy makers would create a more robust mechanism to assist indebted countries in coming months.

description: Cairo protests turn violent as supporters of President Hosni Mubarak clash with antigovernment protesters.

title: Evercores Quarterly Profit Rises Nearly 100%
description: Evercore Partners on Wednesday announced fourth-quarter profit of $3.27 million, up from $1.65 million in the period a year earlier  results that topped Wall Street expectations.

title: Time Warner Raises Dividend as Earnings Beat Forecast
description: Time Warner, the media company, raised its dividend on Wednesday and reported stronger results for the quarter and the year.

title: Seeing Dance From the Cheap Seats
description: For Fridays Weekend section, Claudia La Rocco is writing about seeing dance performances from the cheapest seats of some of New Yorks important halls. As it happened, all four of The Timess dance critics were in attendance at the Sunday matinee of City Ballet at the David H. Koch Theater. Roslyn Sulcas and Gia Kourlas in orchestra, the chief critic Alastair Macaulay a level up in the First Ring, and Ms. LaRocco in the Fourth Ring (specifically, three rows from the very top of the theater). As it turns out, it does make a difference but its not necessarily what you think.

title: Wheelies: The Powerplant Edition
description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

title: The Car Crashes of War
description: Julian Assanges term for the, largely unreported, low-death-toll killings that, it is claimed, constitute the bulk of civilian casualties in conflicts such as Iraq.

title: The Money Manager Who Is Suing the Dakota
description: A prominent black Wall Street money manager has filed a lawsuit against the Dakota, accusing the legendary New York apartment building of racial discrimination and defamation in preventing him from buying an apartment there.

title: Woody Allens Midnight in Paris Will Open Cannes Festival
description: As Europe continues to ship off its up-and-coming actors to play dashing American superheroes, the United States is apparently responding by sending one of its most virile specimens of manhood to that continent in exchange: namely, Woody Allen. Mr. Allens latest film, Midnight in Paris, will open the Cannes Film Festival on May 11, the events organizers said on Wednesday. The film, the 41st feature-length work that Mr. Allen has directed, is a romantic comedy whose cast includes Owen Wilson, Rachel McAdams, Marion Cotillard, Kathy Bates and Adrien Brody, though one cast member, Carla Bruni-Sarkozy, has received a bit more attention than the others. In a statement, Thierry Frmaux, the director of the Cannes festival, described Midnight in Paris as a wonderful love letter to Paris, adding: Its a film in which Woody Allen takes a deeper look at the issues raised in his last films: our relationship with history, art, pleasure and life. The film will be released in France on the same day it makes its debut at Cannes, though an American release date has not yet been announced. The full Cannes Film Festival runs through May 22.

title: Protesters Clash in Tahrir Square
description: Pro-Mubarak and antigovernment protesters face off in Tahrir Square.

title: A Wealthy Christopher Nolan and a Meta James Franco
description: Perhaps this will be a comfort to him: Christopher Nolans Inception was the big winner at the Visual Effects Society on Tuesday. His film picked up all four prizes for which it was nominated  Outstanding Visual Effects in a Visual-Effects Driven Feature Motion Picture; Outstanding Created Environment in a Live Action Feature Motion Picture; Outstanding Models & Miniatures in a Feature Motion Picture and Outstanding Compositing in a Feature Motion Picture  and Mr. Nolan himself was honored with the inaugural visionary award. In a bit of a surprise, How to Train Your Dragon bested Toy Story 3 in the animated category. For the first time, the show will be broadcast on the Reelzchannel on Feb. 19.

title: Super Bowl Media Day: The Insane and the Mundane
description: A sampling of the madness at Cowboys Stadium, where hundreds of reporters were unleashed on those preparing to play in Super Bowl XLV.

title: Rand Paul Makes First Speech on Senate Floor
description: With self assurance, eloquence and a soupon of mild defiance, Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky gave his first speech on the floor of his new legislative home Wednesday, noting that while he would be sitting at the desk of the great compromiser, Henry Clay, he would not be taking many cues from the 19th-century Kentucky lawmaker and founder of the Whig Party.

title: E.P.A. Plans First Rules Ever on Perchlorate in Drinking Water
description: The Obama administration announced on Wednesday that it planned to regulate toxic substances in drinking water more strictly and would issue the first limits ever on perchlorate, a dangerous chemical found in rocket fuel that has seeped into groundwater in at least 400 locations.

title: Leading Off: Super Bowl Media Day Goes From Silly to Bitter
description: Perhaps the safest statement you could make in the run-up to the Super Bowl is that N.F.L. Commissioner Roger Goodell is not a popular man in Steelerville. First, media day on Tuesday became embroiled in a what he said dust-up over comments Goodell made about the Ben Roethlisberger suspension for a Sports Illustrated profile. Lets just say the Steelers werent happy the commish tossed them under a bus for not supporting their quarterback. Then the reporter, Peter King, quickly scrambled to clarify Goodells supposed comments, and Goodell declared them misreported.

title: The View From Tahrir
description: Today President Mubarak seems to have decided to crack down on the democracy movement, using not police or army troops but rather mobs of hoodlums and thugs. Ive been spending hours on Tahrir today, and it is absurd to think of this as simply clashes between two rival groups. The pro-democracy protesters are unarmed and have been peaceful at every step. But the pro-Mubarak thugs are arriving in buses and are armed  and theyre using their weapons.

title: Dispute Derails Art Loans From Russia
description: Several paintings from Gauguins Tahitian period will probably be missing from a major exhibition of his work at the National Gallery of Art in Washington when it opens this month, as will a canvas in that museums coming show on the Venetian painter Canaletto and his rivals. At the Metropolitan Museum of Art a small but important exhibition of Czannes famous card player paintings, opening next week, will almost surely be short one.

title: E.P.A. Plans New Limits on Toxic Chemicals in Drinking Water
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration said Wednesday that it would impose limits on permissible levels of a new set of toxic chemicals in drinking water, including the first standards for perchlorate, a dangerous compound found in rocket fuel and fireworks that has contaminated water supplies in 26 states.

title: The Daily Makes Its Long-Awaited Debut
description: (This blog post has been superseded by this post.)

title: The First Look at News Corp.s The Daily
description: 11:41 a.m. | Updated Rupert Murdoch on Wednesday unveiled The Daily, a news app that he hoped would put his News Corporation front and center in the digital newsstand of the near future.

title: What Were Reading
description: An aggregation of links by the reporters and editors of Diners Journal.

title: Notes From the Underground | Adam Scher Dance Company
description: The Adam Scher Dance Companys new piece, Five Blind Mice, which was presented last week at the Irondale Center in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, is a tour de force of choreography and technology. Kate Atherton, Molly Merkler, Veronica Carnero, Casey Loomis and Adam Scher performed separate vignettes, each specifically programmed by the technical director, Christopher Langer, to sync with the pieces emotional core. As an opener, Merkler performed in almost complete darkness; a sensor strapped to her stomach detected her breathing and illuminated a light bulb overhead with every inhale. Later in the lineup, Atherton began her more up-tempo piece against the backdrop of a blank projection. As the piece went on, time-lapsed footage of her movements appeared in repetition every 30 seconds, creating an army of her own image that seemingly danced along with the real performer.

title: Once-Reeling Devils Regroup Under Lemaire
description: NEWARK  The morning skate before the 50th game of a rough season for the Devils ended with Jacques Lemaire at center ice, peering at the defensemen, then at the forwards, then back and forth, over and over. He tapped the heel of his stick on the ice as he picked up details.

title: An Online Movement to Help D.J. Kool Herc
description: The minute Jeff Chang heard that the pioneering Bronx hip-hop D.J. Kool Herc was having health problems, he knew it was time for payback. Mr. Chang, a prolific writer on politics and culture, was honored when Herc wrote the introduction to his hip-hop history book Cant Stop, Wont Stop. But this week he was alarmed that Herc, born Clive Campbell, was in financial straits because his lack of medical insurance was complicating his treatment for kidney stones.

title: A Conversation With Eduardo Porter
description: Eduardo Porter and I were colleagues on the economics beat at The New York Times several years ago, and he is now a member of the editorial board. Hes also the author of the recent book The Price of Everything. Our conversation, the latest installment of this blogs Book Chat series, follows:

title: How to Make Your Business Greener (and Save Money)
description: While Joe Santana does not presume to understand all of the latest climate science, he has his own opinions about global warming. But as head of operations at Mi Rancho, a family-owned tortilla producer in San Leandro, Calif., he understands the importance of saving money.

title: At Rtromobile, a Space for Future Classics
description: PARIS  An automobile neednt be considered vintage to fit the bill at this years Rtromobile, the annual classic car show that opened here on Wednesday at the Porte de Versailles Exhibition Center.

description: Seen any good, how-did-he-do-that, highlights from Detroit Red Wings star Pavel Datsyuk lately?

description: Jer Longman of the Times traveled to Englands northwest to look in on whether Manchester United can finish the Premier League unbeaten, and whether its fans  who have taken to singing Were Man United, we do what we want  will accept anything less. Read the entire article, and click the headline above to comment.

description: In a piece in the New York Times Magazine this weekend, Emily Bazelon explores shaken baby syndrome  and the possibility that doctors are not as certain about it as they were once thought to be.

description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.
