title: Shingles: A Few Helpful Links
description: Clearly theres a lot of concern circulating  along with quite a bit of misinformation  about the nasty, painful disease called shingles (herpes zoster, more formally) and how to protect oneself or ones parents against it.

title: Journalists Are Targets of Violence in Cairo
description: As chaos gripped central Tahrir Square in Cairo on Wednesday, journalists covering the scene on the ground found themselves the targets of violence and intimidation by demonstrators chanting slogans in favor of President Hosni Mubarak. One prominent American television correspondent, Anderson Cooper of CNN, was struck in the head repeatedly.

title: Beware Politicians Who Moonlight as Comedians
description: WARNING: Politicians trying to be comedians appear in this post.

title: Marcos, Suharto, Mubarak
description: A quick thought about the Egyptian uprising. Many people have sought parallels either in the Philippines 1986 or in Indonesia 1998; Ive done it myself. But there is a possibly important or revealing difference. As the chart above shows, both of those political crises followed on drastic economic crises  Marcos was caught up in the Latin American debt crisis of the 1980s (in some important ways the Philippines was in effect a Latin American economy at the time), Suharto in the Asian financial crisis. Nothing comparable for Egypt now.

title: On Googles Bing Sting
description: Every now and then, Microsoft undoes months or years of excellent work by pulling off a sleazy tactic. There was the time it hired a P.R. firm to write phony grass-roots letters to the editors of newspapers, defending Microsofts position in the governments antitrust lawsuits. There was the time Microsoft bribed bloggers with free $2,500 laptops to assist in their evaluation of Windows Vista.

title: In Peru, Two Houses and a Pool
description: A two-structure property with a combined seven bedrooms, is a few blocks from the beach in Chorillos, on the outskirts of Lima, Peru. Its on the market for $900,000.

title: House Hunting in ... Peru
description: A FOUR-BEDROOM HOUSE WITH A THREE-BEDROOM COTTAGE IN CHORILLOS, PERU

title: Meet Vera Stark': Sanaa Lathan to Star in Lynn Nottages Follow-up to Ruined
description: Lynn Nottages new Off Broadway play By the Way, Meet Vera Stark, her first since winning the Pulitzer Prize for drama in 2009 for Ruined, has announced its star: The stage and film actress Sanaa Lathan will play the title character, a black maid in Hollywood who pursues her dream of making it in the pictures while also grappling with racial stereotypes through decades of the 20th century.

title: Darden Family Values Quicksilver Resources at $2.7 Billion
description: The Darden family, which holds a major stake in Quicksilver Resources, said in a regulatory filing that it believed the energy company was worth $16 a share, putting its total value at $2.7 billion.

title: Convincing Even the Skeptics to Go Green
description: Centuries of burning fossil fuels to power our modern lifestyles is warming our planet and changing our climate. Or not. So goes the debate. Regardless of where you stand on this issue, making your business more environmentally friendly is just good business, according to L. Hunter Lovins, president of Natural Capitalism Solutions and co-author of Climate Capitalism" (Farrar, Straus & Giroux), which is set for release in April.

title: Anti-Abortion Groups Step Up Campaign Against Planned Parenthood
description: Planned Parenthood has fired a clinic manager who was seen on videotape advising a man posing as a sex trafficker, and anti-abortion groups seized on the episode to step up their campaign to cut off public financing for the organization.

title: Stuffed Cabbage With a Mediterranean Inflection
description: I dont make stuffed cabbage all that often: perhaps once or twice a year. And I generally make it more or less the same way, using paprika, caraway and sauerkraut: a Hungarian inflection, if not a purely Hungarian recipe. A batch lasts through several meals, even when we have company to help eat it, and perhaps that is why I dont need to make it more frequently than I do.

title: Storm Snarls Travel
description: The effects of the storm that blanketed much of the country yesterday are being felt by travelers from the Great Plains to the Midwest to the Northeast, Michael Cooper and Monica Davey report. The weather affected those traveling by air, rail and road. Mr. Cooper and Ms. Davey reported that the storm resulted in the cancellation of 4,892 flights by Wednesday at 7:30 a.m., about 1,500 of them in New Yorks three airports; the temporary closing and delays of Amtrak service along the Northeast corridor, and the closing of Interstate 70 in Missouri.

title: Cathie Black, Catching Flak, Gives Some Back
description: Updated, 4:21 p.m. | Cathleen P. Black, the new schools chancellor, faced an angry crowd of nearly 2,000 people as the Panel for Education Policy voted to close 10 schools. The meeting, at Brooklyn Technical High School, lasted more than six hours Tuesday night into early Wednesday as about 300 people spoke, some of them screaming and taunting Ms. Black until she could not take it any longer.

title: Red, White and Blue: The White Stripes Break Up
description: A moment of silence for the White Stripes, please.

title: Is Your Business Trying to Go Green?
description: It was a no-brainer, says Joe Santana, who is vice president of operations for Mi Rancho, a family-owned Tortilla-producer in San Leandro, Calif.

title: On Our Radar: Take a Fresh Look at Climate Change, Scientists Urge Congress
description: A group of leading climate scientists, including eight members of the National Academy of Sciences, call on Congress to take a fresh look at the science linking human activity to climate change, which they contend is strong. The debate about climate change has become increasingly ideological and partisan, their joint letter states. But climate change is not the product of a belief system or ideology. Instead, it is based on scientific fact, and no amount of argument, coercion, or debate among talking heads in the media can alter the physics of climate change. [The Hill]

title: Gowanus Canal Inquiry Underlines Severity of Pollution
description: A yearlong investigation of the Gowanus Canal in preparation for its cleanup under the federal Superfund program has confirmed the severe extent of its contamination and the threat it poses to public health, particularly for people who eat fish from it or have repeated contact with its water or sediment.

title: Fill-In | Wikipedia and Gender
St. Nicholas Ave. and 169th St., 10:45 A.M.
description: Neither rain nor snow nor sleet nor gloom of day

title: Kepler Planet Hunter Finds 1,200 Possibilities
description: Astronomers have cracked the Milky Way like a piata, and planets are now pouring out so fast that they do not know what to do with them all.

title: U.S. Tries Open-Source Model for Health Data Systems
description: The governments lofty vision of bringing health care into the computer age to improve care and curb costs will come to nothing, unless some mundane technical problems can be solved.

title: As Rajaratnam Heads to Trial, Legal Skirmishes Flare Up
description: Raj Rajaratnam, the Galleon Groups founder, is scheduled to begin trial on Feb. 28 on charges that he engaged in insider trading, and prosecutors and defense lawyers are aggressively sparring over a range of preliminary issues in an effort to frame their cases for the jury. While it is still possible the two sides will agree to a plea bargain, the intensity of the fight certainly makes it look like they are gearing up for one of the biggest insider trading trials ever.

title: Triumph and Agony in Egypt
description: David Brooks: Gail, every few years we turn on the TV and we see the main square of some foreign capital filled with people and before too long, a dictator falls. This is truly a great time to be alive. Now, I understand all the worries that go along with this. I understand my Israeli friends who feel that they are in the process of losing the least bad Egyptian leader. But my bottom line is this: the world will be far safer when more of the world is normal, meaning mostly open and mostly democratic. If we have to go through a period of turmoil to get there, it is more than worth it. Thats especially true in the Middle East.

title: Shippers Concerned Over Possible Suez Canal Disruptions
description: HOUSTON  As violence has broken out in Egypt, concern has turned to the risk of the blocking of the Suez Canal or nearby pipelines, which could pose a threat to world energy supplies.

title: Inquiry Details Gowanus Pollution
description: The Environmental Protection Agency has issued the results of a study documenting the severity of the pollution in the Gowanus Canal in Brooklyn. The agency redoubled warnings that New Yorkers should not swim or fish there, citing the risks to human health.

title: Cheap Seats and Dance: When Children Are Involved
description: We asked The Timess dance critics, who sat in different sections of the David H. Koch Theater for Sundays City Ballet matinee, to compare notes. Heres Part 2 of their conversation, which ranged from dancers expressions to the best place to sit with kids. Check back for the final installment later today and be sure to share your experiences in different seats.

title: Still a Home for Directors, and Big Foot
description: THE Sundance Film Festival has been very, very good for American cinema, and perhaps Hollywood most of all. Great American directors, including those magnificent Andersons, Paul Thomas and Wes (no relation), each made an early splash at Sundance in 1993 with their respective shorts, Cigarettes and Coffee and the first iteration of Bottle Rocket. Both might have found studio patronage without Sundance, but the festival ushered them into the larger film world.

title: S.E.C. Proposes Rules on Derivative Prices
description: 7:03 p.m. | Updated

title: Surviving (Yet Another) Snow Day
description: According to the National Weather Service, 100 million people live in the path of the monster snow storm that has turned my driveway into a sheet of ice. (I am thinking of teaching the poor, confused dog to do an axel.)

title: Los Angeles Has a Stadium Name, but No Stadium (or Team)
description: DALLAS  Maybe its the frigid temperatures outside, or the ever-present talk about how to increase the N.F.L.s revenue, but football in Los Angeles  or the lack of it  has been a topic of conversation here.

title: Rooney Method: Build Methodically and Await Rings
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  Art Rooney II was glancing at the enormous video screen and plush seats, taking in Jerry Joness monument to revenue with a bemused smile. Pittsburgh will probably never have a home quite like Cowboys Stadium, which will be host to the Super Bowl on Sunday. But this week Rooney, an owner and the president of the Steelers, had something that Jones, the owner and general manager of the Dallas Cowboys, wanted desperately: the opportunity to explain how his team keeps returning to the Super Bowl every few years.

title: Pre-Loading
description: Drinking quantities of mixed, cut-price alcohol before going out to bars and clubs.

title: Central Figure in India Telecom Scandal Arrested
description: The former telecommunications minister whose handling of the sale of mobile telephone spectrum licenses may have cost the government as much as $39 billion in revenue has been arrested, officials said. A government report released last year accused the former minister, Andimuthu Raja, of selling the airwaves at giveaway prices to favored companies. The ensuing scandal shook what had been Indias most stable government in decades and raised questions about whether the nations rapid growth could be at risk because of rampant corruption. Mr. Raja and several associates were arrested on Wednesday.

title: U.S. and E.U. Join to Show Support for Belarus Opposition
description: BERLIN  The United States and the European Union joined Wednesday in Warsaw in a show of support for the democratic opposition in Belarus.

title: Shopping for Recliners With Kiel Mead
description: Kiel Mead, a furniture and lighting designer, went shopping for recliners that arent eyesores.

title: The Return of the Cranky Mayor
description: Well, that didnt take long.

title: In Ibiza, a House on Stilts
description: Enrique Polancos home was built to have minimal impact on the surrounding landscape.

title: Artifacts | A Snow Queen for Our Time
description: As one of the most stringently modern skyscrapers in New York, Lever House is an outright snub to the 19th century. Or it was until last week, when the sculptor Rachel Feinstein turned its glass-enclosed lobby into an Old World storybook palace that must have the buildings architect, Gordon Bunshaft, turning over in his grave.

title: Caring for the Chart or the Patient?
description: At a recent medical conference in Miami, I sat spellbound as Dr. Stephen Ferrara, a commander in the Navy, delivered a keynote address describing his work in a mobile hospital in Afghanistan.

title: In Spain, Incorporating the Landscape Into the Design
description: IBIZA, SPAIN  When Enrique Polanco, an art fair promoter in Madrid, decided to build a second home on this island some 100 miles from the Spanish mainland, he said he set out to escape from real life in Madrid.

title: No Way to Run a Republic
description: The State of the Union has been (appropriately) eclipsed by the events in Egypt, but before it fades entirely I want to take up something Matt Yglesias said, explaining why he doesnt find the entitlement evasions of both the president and Paul Ryan particularly worrying:

title: McCain and Obama  Meet in Oval Office
description: 5:35 p.m. | Updated There may be no relationship in Washington more fraught than the one between President Obama and his rival for the White House, Senator John McCain of Arizona.

title: Haunting Images of Denim
description: THE publication in 2000 of a monograph that showcased the work of the Swiss photographer Karlheinz Weinberger  gritty images of Zurich teenagers who appropriated the look of the American rebel with intricately customized jeans and denim jackets  became something of a fetish for fashion designers.

title: Pro and Anti-Mubarak Demonstrators Clash
description: Pro-Mubarak demonstrators clashed with anti-government protesters in Tahrir Square in Cairo on Wednesday.

title: S.E.C. Hurt by Disarray in Its Books
description: WASHINGTON  If a companys financial reporting were so bad that its auditor had pointed out significant weaknesses in its accounting for seven years running, the Securities and Exchange Commission would most likely be all over it.

title: The 10 Things to Talk About This Weekend
description: 1. Northeast Africa. The Tunisnami.

title: Franco Looks Likely to Join Kidman in Sweet Bird of Youth on Broadway
description: The film star James Franco (an Academy Award nominee for 127 Hours) and the theater director David Cromer (the acclaimed Off Broadway revival of Our Town) have had two meetings in recent months to discuss Mr. Francos making his Broadway debut as the gigolo and aspiring actor Chance Wayne in a fall 2011 revival of Tennessee Williamss Sweet Bird of Youth, Mr. Cromer said in an interview on Tuesday.

title: Slipping, Sliding and Watching for Falling Ice
description: Just when New Yorkers thought they had seen it all this winter, along came a new cause for alarm on Wednesday: ice, a danger on the ground and from above.

title: Dive In (Not Literally) to Our Super Bowl Snacks
description: Before the Super Bowl, the only part of a newspaper more predictable than the sports section is the food section. Its time for chili and dips, chicken wings and snacks, all touched up with flourishes like city-themed suggestions (Make your jambalaya a Green Bay jambalaya by adding bratwurst!), nods to simplicity (If kickoff is approaching, you do not have to butcher your own hog,) or healthy living (Discourage guests from diving face first into the cream cheese dip).

title: Yielding to His Natural Self
description: THE sidewalks of the East Village were packed with chain smokers and European bar-hoppers, but Max Goldberg, a self-appointed organic-food guru, ducked into Commodities Natural Market, a modern health-food store on First Avenue. He was conducting product research.

title: Tech Talk Podcast: Revolution
description: This weeks Bits: Tech Talk podcast takes a look at how technology is being used to press both for and against social and political change. Bettina Edelstein speaks to Matt Richtel, a New York Times technology reporter, about the impact and implications of the Internet shutdown in Egypt. And J.D. Biersdorfer speaks with David Perry, global director of education for the security firm Trend Micro, about how technology can be deployed as a weapon.

title: Egypts Upheaval Hardens Israels Stance on Peace
description: TEL AVIV  With neighboring Egypt and other parts of the region in upheaval, Israelis contemplating their own future are taking refuge in familiar positions, and the prospect of the Netanyahu governments making peace with the Palestinians, already distant, receded further.

title: Upheaval Puts Militants in the Lurch
description: BAGHDAD  The ideology of radical Islam was developed in Egypt, and its cadres were hardened in the prisons of the countrys authoritarian president, Hosni Mubarak. But as antigovernment demonstrators battled it out with government supporters in Tahrir Square on Wednesday, jihadi groups found themselves curiously on the outside.

title: Mulberry Project
description: YOU cant heave a handmade sloe gin fizz these days without splashing a speakeasy-style lounge with mixologists, locavore plates and an in-crowd that revels in its erudite tastes. The latest is Mulberry Project, a basement lounge that opened in Little Italy in mid-January. The name, which sounds like an art installation, reflects a collaborative spirit: players include Matty Gee, a cocktail maker from Milk & Honey and the Boom Boom Room; Michael Camplin, a chef from Boqueria; and night-life veterans from GoldBar and Bagatelle.

title: Kenny G Helps Audi Keep Old Luxury in Lockdown
description: It has been said that lifes greatest luxury is idle time. Yet Kenny G, the saxophonist who experienced his commercial high water mark sometime around 1996, has generously dedicated 2 minutes and 47 seconds of his ample supply to a new television advertisement for Audi.

title: China Asks Penn to Remove All Artifacts From Silk Road Exhibition
description: 5:40 p.m. | Updated Its not an easy thing to mount a big exhibition of artifacts from China without any artifacts from China.

title: When a Tax Isnt Really a Tax
description: ALBANY  I say no new taxes, period, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo declared on the day of his inauguration last month, echoing a top promise from his campaign. And after leafing through his first executive budget on Tuesday, lawmakers and others at the Capitol seemed to agree that Mr. Cuomo had indeed kept his pledge.

title: Festival Films Have Minimalist Themes
description: LOS ANGELES  Guy walks into a bar. Maybe you already have enough material for a movie at South by Southwest.

title: In Bay Area, New Peer-to-Peer Car Sharing Offers
description: Three San Francisco start-ups are hoping to persuade car owners to rent their vehicles to locals and out-of-town visitors. The three companies  Getaround, RelayRides and Spride Share  recently launched online services in the Bay Area to help car owners profit from their vehicles when not using them, while allowing drivers to book the cars at rates potentially lower than what major rental companies charge.

title: Google Fixes Its App Store
description: Updated 5:50 p.m. with additional reporting from the event.

title: Hype Central: Tackling Roethlisberger, Minimalism and Warm Boots
description: A brief recap of an afternoon spent bingeing on Super Bowl coverage:

title: Mapping 10 Forested Hot Spots
description: Over the last 8,000 years, forest cover on the planet has plummeted to around 13 million square miles from about 24 million square miles, the advocacy group Global Forest Watch estimates. Rain forests in particular are being felled at stunning rates.

title: Former Lehman Executive to Lead Craftsman Brand
description: Need some tools? Scott Freidheim is your man.

title: Clemenss Co-Counsel to Question Pettitte
description: WASHINGTON  Roger Clemens told a federal judge Wednesday that he was not troubled by the fact that his lawyer briefly represented Yankees pitcher Andy Pettitte, who is expected to be a key prosecution witness in Clemenss perjury trial later this year.

title: In Postcrisis Report, a Weak Light on Complex Transactions
description: Phil Angelides, chairman of the Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission.

title: Shopping Picks for Feb. 3
description: Reports of sales, events, openings and collaborations in the fashion world.

title: Scouting Report
description: SALES

title: Police Search Deutsche Bank Office in Russia
description: 6:10 p.m. | Updated

title: Freescale Hires Advisers for an I.P.O.
description: Freescale Semiconductor, the chip maker acquired by several buyout firms in 2006 for $17.6 billion, has hired a bevy of investment banks to underwrite an initial public offering, people briefed on the matter told DealBook on Wednesday.

title: Amos Lee Tops Billboard Chart in One of Industrys Worst Weeks for Album Sales
description: Citigroup has barely owned EMI for a day, but it has already achieved a dubious distinction: a No. 1 album with notably low sales  even in a season of painfully low sales for the music industry.

title: Mind and Body: Investigating the Health and Science of Meditation
description: Overview  | What is meditation? How have scientists explored the effects of meditation on the mind and body? In this lesson, students participate in a guided meditation, then learn about meditation and current research showing how meditation affects the brain and body. They then annotate diagrams of the brain and body with the information theyve learned about meditations effects.

title: Fortune Brands Big Breakup
description: CNBC discusses the planned split of Fortune Brands into three separate companies, a proposal supported by the activist investor William A. Ackman, who owns an 11 percent share of the company.

title: Chick-fil-A Protests at N.Y.U. Are Muted
description: On some college campuses, students are agitated about the presence of Chick-fil-A, a purveyor of Southern-style chicken sandwiches that has run afoul of some proponents of same-sex marriage. But at a New York University cafeteria, the only place in the city where a craving for Chick-fil-A can be sated, the squawking has been limited.

title: Paul and Nash Run the Pick-and-Roll in Style
description: The pick-and-roll is as foundational as N.B.A. plays come; it occurs on the professional level of the game in both pure and varied forms, in assorted rhythms and placements, all of which serve to modify its orchestration. The elasticity of the pick-and-roll is truly impressive, as the sequence always subscribes to the same basic action but can differ wildly in the style of its execution.

title: The Insider | Joaquin Trias
description: Not yet 30 years old, Joaquin Trias is already revealing a certain kinship with his fellow Spanish designer Cristbal Balenciaga (to whom his grandmother, Countessa Frida Trias, was model and muse). Triass aristocratic roots fostered his reverence for simple elegance, and his technical acumen and focus on innovation, perhaps picked up from his background with pattern makers and seamstresses, are apparent in every seam and silhouette. Gearing up for Fashion Week, Trias shares with us some of his day-to-day inspirations. Is he looking forward to it? Yes, he says. Very much! Thank you.

title: Premier of Jordan Holds Talks With Rivals
description: AMMAN, Jordan  Jordans new prime minister began consultations with key political groups, including the Muslim opposition, on Wednesday. The talks came a day after King Abdullah II, caught in a regional wave of discontent, sought to stave off growing public unrest by firing his government and vowing reform.

title: Behind the Collapse of the J. Crew Settlement
description: There was a heated exchange of letters on Tuesday as the J. Crew settlement over its proposed leveraged buyout collapsed.

title: Buzz Tracker
description: This is Not Gods Work Bill Gross: Fifty years ago, the highest paid and most prestigious professions were that of a doctor or a 707 airline pilot who flew the golden route from Los Angeles to Honolulu. Today the yellow brick road begins on Wall Street or the City. Aside from supernova innovators such as Steve Jobs or Mark Zuckerberg, the money is made from securitizing things instead of booting and rebuilding America. . .. Almost a quarter of the 400 wealthiest people on Forbes annual richest list make their money from money, whereas only 8% could make that claim in its first issue in 1982, and probably close to 0% when I first read my economic primer in 1966. Having been part of this process and even a member of the rogues gallery itself, I know one thing for sure: This is not Gods work  it has the unmistakable odor of Mammon. Pimco

title: Cheap Seats and Dance: The Things You Learn
description: As part of an article coming Friday in the Weekend section, we asked The Timess dance critics to compare notes after seeing the same performance (City Ballet on Sunday) from different parts of the theater. Here are Parts 1 and 2 of their conversation, which ranged from the performances themselves to the people you meet in the cheap seats and even dancers facial expressions, the subject that kicks off the final round:

title: Pictures of the Day: Egypt and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Egypt, Pakistan, and Iowa.

title: Bush and McCain Daughters Reflect Age Divide on Gay Marriage
description: Barbara Bush, one of the twin daughters of George W. Bush, released a video on Tuesday calling on New York to legalize gay marriage.  Meghan McCain, meanwhile, has become an outspoken supporter of gay marriage. Their public support of same-sex marriage, while notable for conflicting with their famous fathers position on the issue, places them right in line with a majority of Americans in their age group (Ms. Bush is 29; Ms. McCain is 26).

title: Who Am I? Wednesday Edition
description: All week, the Fifth Down blog will post Who Am I? quizzes to test your knowledge of Packers and Steelers of the past. Peeking at Pro Football Reference just ruins the fun for everyone, so dont do it!

title: Men in Hats
description: Having exhausted the usual narratives of power and gender as expressed through clothing, designers may have merely been casting about for new tools and communally fell upon the hat.

title: The Cat in the Hat Comes Back
description: THERE was a time when only beggars went bareheaded. This was some while ago, a century or so. But up until World War II and the period just after, a gentleman was not considered properly dressed without a hat. Even the names of hats were rich in character and historical association. The bowler, or derby, with the rigid shape of an upended bean pot, was named for a 19th-century English earl who popularized the style. The fedoras name came from a play of that title, written for Sarah Bernhardt by the otherwise largely forgotten French dramatist Victorien Sardou.

title: Adding SNY to Mets Sale Pitch Would Increase Allure
description: When Fred Wilpon announced his plan to sell up to 25 percent of the Mets last week to one or more strategic investors, he kept the teams majority ownership of the SNY network, which televises the teams games, off the block.

title: Pictures of the Day: Egypt and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Egypt, Pakistan and Iowa.

title: Nabokov Meets Waiver Wire, in Song
description: You may have heard that Evgeni Nabokov isnt happy. He recently went from signing a contract with the contending Detroit Red Wings to being claimed on waivers by the last place Islanders. So far hes refused to report, but he may be running out of options if he wants to continue his career next season.

title: This Old Thing? Actually, Its New
description: WHEN Erin Ogg, 45, of New Orleans and her girlfriends sip cocktails at the Sazerac Bar in the citys historic Roosevelt Hotel, they dress as if its the 1940s or 50s; wearing dresses with cinched waists, or pencil skirts and blouses, accessorized with hats and gloves. We get a lot of compliments, said Ms. Ogg, a waitress and personal trainer. Its a feminine look with a lot more grace and style than a hoodie sweatshirt and Ugg boots.

title: Fifth Third Repays Bailout Funds
description: Fifth Third Bancorp, the large regional Midwestern bank, announced on Wednesday that it had repaid the $3.4 billion taxpayer bailout received at the height of the financial crisis.

title: Pretty Little Underthings
description: Delicate and occasionally naughty bits spiced up spring collections from Alexander Wang to VPL. But what if your taste in underthings is for plain vanilla? Petit Bateau is going back to basics  circa 1893, the year the brand was born  with a new collection of vintage white Oeko-Tex cotton undergarments for men (T-shirt and boxers,$48), women (tank and briefs, $54) and children (baby jumper, $32). They serve as a reminder that sometimes good old-fashioned modesty is the sexiest thing of all.

title: Young Sudanese Start Protest Movement
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  The messages started going up on Facebook about two weeks ago, to any Sudanese who cared.

title: Oppressors Tale, Written in Oppression
description: BOSTON  The Boston Lyric Opera, founded in 1976, presents only a handful of productions a year but clearly intends them to catch the interest of operagoers around the country. Its current season includes only one war horse, Puccinis Tosca, and a few less-traveled works, like Handels Agrippina and Brittens Midsummer Nights Dream, that have significant constituencies.

title: AT&T Sweetens Data Plans Before Verizon iPhone
description: After Verizon announced it would begin selling the iPhone on its network, the company introduced several data plan offerings to help strengthen its position against AT&T, the exclusive carrier of the iPhone in the United States for the last several years.

title: Lighthearted, With a Soupon of Self-Mockery
description: Brooke Shields came out swinging at Feinsteins at Loews Regency, where she made her much-publicized nightclub debut on Tuesday evening. This beautiful strapping actress, model and sometime Broadway performer, now 45, is not one to wimp out (her words) when confronting a challenge. Resplendent in a black sequined dress, Ms. Shields, within minutes of taking the stage, compared her fear of making the leap into cabaret to getting married (which she has done twice), then plunged into a performance that had the feel of an Olympic sprint.

title: Sizing Up National Signing Day
description: National signing day culminates the yearlong recruiting process for coaches and the seemingly boundless obsession of fans who track prospects through online sites. It is also a time for observers to take stake of how each program, and by extension each coach, fared in a given recruiting cycle.

title: Turning Heads (but Dont Call It a Perm)
description: TO get waves in her naturally straight hair, Kristi Koren, 36, used to dampen it, twist it in dozens of curlicues and then sleep on it. But after seeing Anne Hathaways effortlessly voluptuous locks in Love and Other Drugs, Ms. Koren, a mother of one 13-month-old and an entrepreneur in Raleigh, N.C., began wondering if there were a less time-consuming and a less uncomfortable way of creating long, flowing curls. As a child of the 1980s, it didnt take her long to come up with the obvious (and yet terrifying) answer: a perm.

title: Many Basic Weather Tools, but No Great Ones
description: Strange but true: four years after the iPhones debut, software developers and media giants have yet to build a truly great weather app.

title: Medical Detectives Find Their First New Disease
description: Louise Benges medical problems started when she was 25. Walking became excruciating. Her calves got hard as rocks, and every step was agony. Her hands started hurting too. And the condition, whatever it was, only got worse over the next two decades.

title: Art at MoMA: Tuna on Wheat (Hold the Mayo)
description: Only the sharp-eyed might have noticed something amiss at the lunch table of 12 last week in the second-floor cafeteria at the Museum of Modern Art.

title: Beauty Spots
Ron Paul Schedules First Hearing on Fed
description: WASHINGTON  Critics of the Federal Reserve within the new Republican majority in the House will get their first chance to scrutinize the central bank next week.

title: Public Theaters Executive Director Resigns
description: Andrew D. Hamingson has resigned as executive director of the Public Theater after only two-and-a-half years as the companys top financial executive, citing personal issues, Mr. Hamingson and the Publics board chairman, Warren Spector, announced on Wednesday afternoon.

title: In Egypt, the Dawn of Sustainable Politics?
A Warm Reception ... Inside
description: FREEZING drizzle. Sleet. Ice accumulation. That is the death knell for most movie premieres, but for Home, a documentary about the perils of climate change, the forecast last Tuesday night was the perfect billing.

title: Intricate Journey Contained in One Multifaceted Work
description: It scarcely matters whether there is any truth to the old legend about Bachs Goldberg Variations: that they were composed to occupy the restless mind of Count Keyserlingk, the Russian ambassador to the court at Dresden, during bouts of insomnia. The point of the story is that if there is a work that could give an insomniac a universe of material to focus on, this is it.

title: A Return to Power, Properly Punctuated
description: A big-name band instantly selling out a small room: its called an underplay, and its becoming a standard gambit to get a new album noticed. Thats why Panic! at the Disco, which headlined Madison Square Garden in 2006 on the momentum of its million-selling debut album, A Fever You Cant Sweat Out, was at the Bowery Ballroom on Tuesday night, starting the promotional surge behind Vices & Virtues (Fueled By Ramen/Decaydance/Atlantic), its third album, to be released on March 29. The show coincides with the release of a single, The Ballad of Mona Lisa  not a ballad, but a midtempo rocker.

title: Models, Plain and Fancy
description: Karl Smith argues that informal economic arguments  models in the sense of thought experiments, not necessarily backed by equations and/or data-crunching  deserve more respect from the profession. I agree, and not just because he cites my use of the baby-sitting coop, described in a wonderful but ignored article by Sweeney and Sweeney, as an example.

title: Taking Your Own Passport Photos
description: Q. Can I take my own passport pictures with my digital camera or do I have to go to a place that specifically takes these portraits?

title: How to Lower Your Heating Bill
description: With harsh winter weather hitting much of the country, many consumers are probably wondering about simple steps they can take to lower their heating bills.

title: Instagram Raises Money
description: People sure do like taking photos on their iPhone. Just ask Instagram, the popular mobile photo-sharing Web service available on Apples mobile platform.

title: Americans Discover America
description: The mutual fund trade group reports that funds specializing in American stocks have had net inflows of cash in each of the last three weeks. The last time that happened was last April. Then there were net inflows for four consecutive weeks.

title: Inflation and Stock Prices
description: Scott Sumner sends us to David Glasner, who shows that stock prices have had a positive correlation with expected inflation since 2008, strongly suggesting that aggregate demand is at the heart of our problems.

title: Class Action Suit Filed Against Jimmy Carter Book
description: Readers are often warned not to judge a book by its cover, but what about its publicity? That is the basis of a class-action lawsuit against former President Jimmy Carter and his publisher Simon & Schuster over his 2006 book Palestine: Peace, Not Apartheid, which was filed in Manhattan federal court on Tuesday.

title: To Defend Against Disease, a Plant Checks the Clock
description: Plants, like many other organisms, have circadian clocks that help them anticipate various environmental and biological events that occur at precise times of the day. Processes like photosynthesis, fragrance emission and time of bloom are all regulated by this timekeeping mechanism.

title: Asian Cup: Japan Is on the Up
description: TOKYO  Japan has just won the Asian Cup, moved into the top 20 in the FIFA rankings and is clearly the best team in Asia. And if you think it was a fluke, think again.

title: The Dollar and Global Standing
description: From Barry Eichengreen (via Matt Yglesias):

title: A Misjudged Late Discard Unravels the Defense
description: The most successful players at the District 3 Winter Regional last month in Rye Brook, N.Y., were R. J. Becker of New York and Michael Kamil of Holmdel, N.J. They had two firsts, one second and one third, collecting 67.63 master points.

title: Karsans Taxi Introduces Itself to Potential Passengers
description: Karsan, the Turkish company whose taxi design is one of three finalists in New Yorks Taxi of Tomorrow competition, showed off the first prototype of its body at a press event in Manhattan on Wednesday.

title: Enduring Impression of a Fleeting Moment
description: Carl Kiilsgaard, 24, is a freelance photographer in Portland, Ore. He attended Western Kentucky University and has been an intern at The Napa Valley Register and The Palm Beach Post. In 2008, Reportage by Getty Images selected him as an emerging talent. His conversation with Kerri MacDonald for the Turning Point series has been edited.

title: Stevie Wonder to Be Named to Apollo Theaters Hall of Fame
description: The musician who first took the stage of the Apollo Theater in Harlem as Little Stevie Wonder at age 12 in 1962 and then went on to some very big things will receive an honor from the theater later this year. The Apollo is to announce on Wednesday that it will induct Mr. Wonder  hes just Stevie now, thank you very much  into its Apollo Legends Hall of Fame. Mr. Wonder, the best-selling pop and soul artist whose albums include Talking Book, Innervisions and Songs in the Key of Life, was a child performer on Berry Gordys Motown Revue when he made his Apollo debut, and returned several times to the theater for performances including its Save the Apollo concert in the 1980s and a series of solo shows in 2005, the theaters press representatives said. Other artists already named to the theaters Hall of Fame include Michael Jackson, Aretha Franklin, Quincy Jones, Smokey Robinson and Ella Fitzgerald. Mr. Wonder is to be officially inducted on June 13 at the Apollos annual spring gala.

title: Emperor of Atlantis
description: The opera is a satire of Hitler that was written and first performed in a Nazi concentration camp.

title: Falling Ice in Manhattan
description: Wednesday's storm created hazardous conditions for pedestrians in Midtown.

title: Portraits of a Grounded Hawk
description: While we wait for Newshawk, the juvenile red-tailed hawk who injured his wing crashing into the glass-walled atrium at the headquarters of The New York Times a few weeks ago, to continue his recovery, we thought wed share with you these drawings. They were done by Kaye Blegvad, an illustrator and designer based in London who happened to be visiting The Times that day.

title: Documentary Drama at the Oscars
description: In 2007, when the journalists Sebastian Junger and Tim Hetherington set out to make a documentary following a military unit in Afghanistan, they had no awards aspirations.

title: Peltz Reports Other Approaches for Wendys
description: Nelson Peltzs investor group, the biggest shareholder in the Wendys/Arbys Group restaurant chain, said in a filing on Wednesday that it had recent discussions with potential suitors for the company.

title: Street Battle Over the Arab Future
description: CAIRO  The future of the Arab world, perched between revolt and the contempt of a crumbling order, was fought for in the streets of downtown Cairo on Wednesday.

title: Sex Scandals in Italy Fuel Discontent of Women
description: ROME  Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi of Italy has said he is laughing off his latest sex scandal, in which prosecutors are investigating whether he compensated a number of attractive young women, including a 17-year-old nicknamed Ruby Heart-Stealer, for sex.

title: Rodriguez Reflects on His Departure
description: For the past 25 years, Rich Rodriguez had spent each day crossing items off a to-do list, a football coach always consumed by his next task. That has changed since he was fired from Michigan.

title: A New Realm of Celebrity
description: On the world stage, Benjamin Millepied is in his newest and most public role, as companion to Natalie Portman.

title: Benjamin Millepied Leaps Into the Spotlight
description: IT was the laugh heard around the Web. Natalie Portman, glowing in a pink Viktor & Rolf gown, bounded onstage at the Golden Globes last month to accept the award for best actress for her role in the psychological thriller Black Swan.

title: Medical Detectives Find Their First New Disease
description: Louise Benges medical problems started when she was 25. Walking became excruciating. Her calves got hard as rocks, and every step was agony. Her hands started hurting, too. And the condition, whatever it was, only got worse over the next two decades.

title: Ebersol Starts to Reshape Sports at Comcast
description: Dick Ebersol, who has run NBC Sports for nearly 22 years, is wasting little time putting his personal stamp on the sports properties of Comcast, which include the Golf Channel and Versus, and 11 regional sports networks.

title: Activist Funds Oppose Smurfit-Stones RockTenn Deal
description: Three hedge funds, including Third Point Capital, announced on Wednesday that they opposed Smurfit-Stones $3.5 billion sale to a competitor, the RockTenn Company, arguing the deal price was too low.

title: Nomura Evolves, Just Not So Fast
description: Nomura, the Japanese firm, is evolving into a global investment bank even if it does not yet look like one. It reported a strong increase in investment banking fees for the final quarter of 2010, and its traders have begun to prove their worth. The gap with the big league is closing  slowly.

title: Egyptian Crisis Gives CNN a Ratings Boost
description: CNN reaffirmed that it remains a brand for breaking news Tuesday evening, with the protests in Egypt providing the compelling story.

title: New Tiles Based on David Hickss Designs
description: Popham Design, a tile company in Marrakesh, Morocco, has teamed up with the designer Ashley Hicks to produce three new designs inspired by work done in the 1970s by Mr. Hickss father, the late decorator David Hicks.

title: A New Line of Lacquered Furnishings
description: Moste, a line of lacquered furniture and decorative accessories designed by Billy Cotton and Michael Bargo, was inspired by Sottsass Memphis pieces, and Donald Judd, Mr. Cotton said. Although most of the items are not as simple as Judd and not as wild as Sottsass, he added.

title: Sales at Branca, Desiron and Garnet Hill
description: Branca, a home furnishings retailer in Chicago, is discounting everything in the store and online by up to 50 percent, through Feb. 12 (an AB Collection blanket, originally $225, is about $170; a medium-size black Cire Trudon candle with red medallion, regularly $65, is about $33; and a set of eight Louis XVI-style white-painted dining chairs upholstered in ticking, originally $19,000, is $15,000); information: (312) 787-1017 or branca.com.

title: Recliners
description: THERE are few pieces of furniture that cause as much discord as recliners. For some, theyre a guilty pleasure; others consider them an eyesore.

title: Retailers Try Their Hand as Gallerists
description: Design enthusiasts with small budgets, rejoice: there are now so many places to find affordable artwork that it is hard not to have impressive wall art.

title: Nigel Coates at Cristina Grajales Gallery in SoHo
description: Nigel Coatess Baroccabilly furniture and lighting, on display this month and next at the Cristina Grajales Gallery in SoHo, was inspired by the unrestrained style of baroque design and rockabilly music. And by a fantasy narrative Mr. Coates invented in which an imaginary character inhabits a landscape made up of forms, textures and shapes he designed. (As he put it: Form follows fiction.)

title: Pictures at an Exhibition
description: To the Editor:

title: In a Manhattan Studio, Everything Within a Swivel
description: Clever, thrifty touches abound in an Upper West Side apartment that measures just over 200 square feet.

title: Fireside Chat
description: To the Editor:

title: A Camellia Preserve on an Island Known for Tabasco Peppers
description: AVERY ISLAND, La.

title: Margaret Russell Unveils the New Architectural Digest
description: THE Age of Elegance, states the cover of the March issue of Architectural Digest, sounding somewhat hopeful. The bright pink affirmation declares a new brief for a once-mighty title that has been struggling, and a statement of intent from its new editor, Margaret Russell, who was until last summer the very steady helmsman of a competitor, Elle Dcor.

title: Chicken Vanishes, Heartbreak Ensues
description: THE chickens of New York City, for the most part, live fairly sheltered lives, securely tucked into private backyards and padlocked community gardens. Our chickens, by contrast, are public figures  their yard faces 20 feet of busy Bedford-Stuyvesant sidewalk. The chickens themselves chose this bustling thoroughfare, decamping there even when they could have settled in our spacious, semiprivate back garden. They wanted to see and be seen  like so many New York transplants, they seemed to feed on the energy of the street.

title: Emil Fiore on Searching Out Spider Webs
description: If you like authentic, there is nothing like a paperweight made out of an actual spider web, silvered (O.K., aluminum-ed) and preserved in an orb of glass. ABC Carpet & Home, in Manhattan, has been selling them for the past few months, for $45 to $110.

title: 200 Square Feet and Room to Swivel
description: FOR Malena Georgieva, its been a long trip to the Upper West Side of Manhattan. A native of Plovdiv, Bulgaria, a provincial city about an hour from Sofia, she received a degree in Soviet-style industrial management just as the Soviet Union was collapsing. Adapting to the post-Communist world after emigrating to the United States in 1993, she enrolled in a masters program at the University of New Haven, supporting herself as a hotel chambermaid for $4.50 an hour. (I thought, if I ever make $10 an hour, Ill be queen of the world, she said.) Eventually, she was hired by Deloitte & Touche, beginning a career in risk management, and her simultaneous love affair with New York City.

title: Gates for President? Not if He Can Help It
description: A nascent campaign to draft Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates as a 2012 presidential candidate to run against his boss, Barack Obama, is being driven by two 27-year-old Texas A & M graduates who say they had informal conversations with Mr. Gates about their effort this past Saturday night.

title: Democrats Defeat Attempt to Repeal Health Care Law
description: WASHINGTON  Senate Democrats on Wednesday defeated a bid by Republicans to repeal last years sweeping health care overhaul, as they successfully mounted a party-line defense of President Obamas signature domestic policy achievement.

title: Brimming With Clues That Are Hard to Link
description: The Death Instinct opens on that September day when Lower Manhattan was blown apart, and Americans started wondering who could hate them so much. The day the word terrorist became part of our vocabulary, and the country rallied to war.

title: Intel Chip Flaw Causes Delays for PC Makers
description: Computer makers have been forced to shut down some of their assembly lines because of a design flaw in chips produced by Intel.

title: Readers Photos of the Winter Storm
description: A ferocious winter storm blanketed wide areas from the Great Plains to New England in deep snow and left a skin of ice over large sections of the Northeast.

title: Lavish Centennial Plans Testify to the Strength of Reagans Influence
description: SIMI VALLEY, Calif.  Ronald Reagan would have turned 100 this Sunday, and nearly seven years after his death, one might think he were still alive and leading the Republican Party.

title: Memorable, Too
description: Notable events from 1911, the year of Ronald Reagans birth:

title: Printers Adapt to World of the Web
description: Now that you can view maps on cellphones, send pictures directly from a digital camera to photo frames and use a smartphones screen as a virtual airline boarding pass, who needs to print any more?

title: Chicago Humbled by Powerful Storm
description: CHICAGO  When Jenny Theroux plotted her commute home Tuesday afternoon, she was certain she would arrive well before the full force of the blizzard hit. For the final leg of her trip, she turned onto Lake Shore Drive, this citys wide and busy thoroughfare along Lake Michigan, at 4 p.m.

title: Smoking Ban for Beaches and Parks Is Approved
description: After a bitter debate over individual liberties and the role of government, the City Council on Wednesday handily approved a bill to ban smoking in 1,700 city parks and along 14 miles of city beaches.

title: Meeting Mubarak's Supporters
description: The Op-Ed columnist Nicholas D. Kristof spoke to President Hosni Mubarak's supporters in Tahrir Square, Cairo, on Wednesday.

title: What the North Got Wrong
description: In the years and months preceding the Civil War, the Republicans in general and Abraham Lincoln in particular made many mistakes or misjudgments. And these errors were vitally important in bringing on the war. But this is not to say that defective statesmanship was the problem. For the mistakes made were rooted in Republican ideology, and that ideology was, in turn, rooted in the social and economic conditions of the antebellum North.

title: Hackers Shut Down Government Sites
description: The online group Anonymous said Wednesday that it had paralyzed the Egyptian governments Web sites in support of the antigovernment protests.

title: From Space, Giffordss Brother-in-Law Speaks on Shooting
description: When Scott Kelly got word from Mission Control on Jan. 8 that the head of the astronaut office wanted to talk with him directly on a private line, he recalled, I knew whatever it was, it wasnt good.

title: City to Battle Mortgage Fraud With Computer Alert
description: Despite the bright spotlight that the housing crisis shined on mortgage fraud, officials say New Yorkers continue to be duped. Now, the city is taking aim at the perpetuators of mortgage fraud through a program that it hopes will root out questionable property transactions and alert officials and prosecutors when they happen.

title: Park Service Seeks Quiet in the Grand Canyon
description: TUCSON  That the Grand Canyon is a visual spectacle is without question. But the constant droning of tourist aircraft overhead, which has worsened considerably over the years, has prompted the National Park Service to propose measures to make one of Americas premier natural areas much easier on the ears.

title: In Book, Rumsfeld Recalls Bushs Early Iraq Focus
description: WASHINGTON  Just 15 days after the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, President George W. Bush invited his defense secretary, Donald H. Rumsfeld, to meet with him alone in the Oval Office. According to Mr. Rumsfelds new memoir, the president leaned back in his leather chair and ordered a review and revision of war plans  but not for Afghanistan, where the Qaeda attacks on New York and Washington had been planned and where American retaliation was imminent.

title: A Sex Joke and Other Judicial Bad Behavior
description: One judge who was driving drunk led the police on a half-mile chase, and when he was pulled over, asked for professional courtesy.

title: Officials Consider Requiring Insurers to Offer Free Contraceptives
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration is examining whether the new health care law can be used to require insurance plans to offer contraceptives and other family planning services to women free of charge.

title: Summerss Crystal Ball
description: The peripatetic Larry Summers is once again back at Harvard, teaching a class on American economic policy with Martin Feldstein and Jeff Liebman  two other prominent former government economists  and reacquainting himself with the joys of free speech now that he is no longer President Obamas director of the National Economic Council, President Clintons treasury secretary or Harvards 27th president. What better time, then, than winter to check in with the lion?

title: Foreclosed Homeowners Go to Court on Their Own
description: ALBUQUERQUE  Saving your home from foreclosure is increasingly a do-it-yourself project.

title: Judging How Birth Videos Affect a Lawsuit
description: Video is a particular worry in the delivery room because it picks up actions that a still camera might not and the sound can make a situation seem worse than it is.

title: Energy Firms Aided by U.S. Find Backers
description: WASHINGTON  In late 2009, the federal government gave $151 million in grants to advance 37 clean energy ideas deemed too radical or too preliminary to attract much private financing  like electricity storage that mimics photosynthesis and batteries that double or triple the energy stored per pound.

title: Sudden Split Recasts U.S. Foreign Policy
description: WASHINGTON  After days of delicate public and private diplomacy, the United States openly broke with its most stalwart ally in the Arab world on Wednesday, as the Obama administration strongly condemned violence by allies of President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt against protesters and called on him to speed up his exit from power.

title: News Corporation Introduces The Daily, a Digital-Only Newspaper
description: Rupert Murdoch on Wednesday pushed the send button on The Daily, a news application designed for the iPad that he hopes will position his News Corporation front and center in the digital newsstand of the future.

title: The Cheat: A Winters Tail
description: Here is a midwinter cook-up of deep fragrance and lingering heat, a trade-wind stew that emerged in Jamaica and made its way north. It is oxtail stew, brown and steaming, light with ginger and thyme, pungent with allspice and soy, a taste of the Caribbean to warm winters heart. You could make and eat it today while reading Derek Walcott poems as the afternoon vagues into indigo  or allow it to cure into greater magnificence overnight, and stretch out its gravy for the course of a week.

title: Coconut-Scented Rice
description: 2 tablespoons unsalted butter 1 small yellow onion, peeled and diced small 2 cloves garlic, peeled and minced 2 cups white rice 1 tablespoon thyme leaves 1 13-ounce can coconut milk 1 Scotch bonnet pepper, whole (optional) 1 cup cooked pigeon peas 2 tablespoons chopped scallion, green part only Kosher salt and freshly ground black pepper, to taste 1. Melt butter in a medium sauce pan set over low heat. When it begins to foam, add the onion and the garlic, stir, and allow these to soften in the heat, about 3 minutes. 2. Add the rice and the thyme, and stir to combine. Add the coconut milk and 2  cups water, and turn heat to high. Bring liquid to a simmer, then lower heat. If using pepper, place it in center of pot. Cover. Cook until the liquid is absorbed and rice is soft, approximately 25 minutes. Remove from heat and fluff with a fork. If using pepper, remove it. Add peas and scallions, then stir to combine. Season to taste with salt and pepper, then cover pot again and keep warm until ready to serve. Serves 4.

title: Jamaican Oxtail Stew
description: 3 pounds oxtails, cut into segments by a butcher

title: Facebooks New, Simple and Essential Safety Feature
description: Last week, the Facebook chief executive, Mark Zuckerberg, found his personal account hacked. If it could happen to Mr. Zuckerberg, users realized, it could happen to anyone.

title: Bloomberg Seeks a Sweeping Overhaul of Citys Pensions
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg proposed sweeping changes on Wednesday to New Yorks costly pension system, seeking to save billions of dollars by fundamentally altering long-established rules that have awarded generous retirement benefits to municipal workers and have deepened the citys financial hole.

title: A Diner Saved From Extinction Needs Saving Again
description: It seemed kind of sweet when it played out six years ago: one of New Yorks retro diners hovering near death was saved and trucked off intact for a new life in the Catskills.

title: Shake-Up at Network Carrying N.H.L. Games
description: Versus, Comcasts second-tier sports network whose top offerings include N.H.L. games, is getting an expected overhaul after Comcast took control of NBC Universal on Jan. 28. Top officials lost their positions, and a name change could be in the store for the network. Richard Sandomir writes on Media Decoder:

title: News Corp.s Net Income More Than Doubles, Led by Its Cable Networks
description: Joining other media companies in reaping the benefits of a rebounding advertising market, the News Corporation said Wednesday that it had more than doubled its net income in the quarter that ended Dec. 31.

title: On Gulf Oil Spills Effects, Doing Science With a Deadline
description: In mid-December, Wes Tunnells phone rang with a request that would ruin his holiday plans.

title: And Down This Aisle, Many Whole Grain Options
description: CEREAL is a mainstay of the American breakfast, but deciding among the numerous varieties can be daunting  just take a trip down a supermarkets cereal aisle and try to parse the ingredients on any box.

title: For iPhone, Almost Heaven
description: Its here. After almost four years of speculation, the iPhone will finally come to Verizons network on Feb. 10.

title: Thrust From Margins Into a Big Games Glare
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.

title: Faith-Healing Parents Get Probation
description: PHILADELPHIA  A couple who prayed over their dying son rather than taking him to a doctor were sentenced on Wednesday to 10 years probation, and ordered to ensure regular medical care for their seven surviving children.

title: The Packers Modest G.M. Has Plenty to Brag About
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  Ted Thompson stood behind a barricade, apart from the Super Bowl team that he constructed. He answered questions with eyes pointed downward and hands shoved into pockets, forever shy, reserved, uncomfortable, even now.

title: F.D.A. Sued Over Drug Used in Executions
description: Lawyers in Washington sued the Food and Drug Administration on Wednesday on behalf of death-row prisoners, demanding that a Federal District Court prohibit importation and use of sodium thiopental, a drug used in many executions. When the sole supplier of the drug in the United States stopped producing it, executions were delayed in several states, and states obtained the drug from overseas suppliers. The agency has long said it has no authority over executions. The lead lawyer in the suit, Bradford A. Berenson, said it was not about halting executions but rather about ensuring that illegal drugs are not used in carrying out otherwise lawful sentences.

title: Lockout Not Inevitable, League Negotiator Says
description: DALLAS  A lockout on March 4 is not inevitable if the N.F.L. and the players union are close to forging a new collective bargaining agreement, Jeff Pash, the lead negotiator for the league, said Wednesday.

title: Massive Storm Batters States
description: A massive storm debilitated towns and cities across the Midwest.

title: Lottery Numbers
Charles H. Kaman, Helicopter Innovator, Dies at 91
description: Charles H. Kaman, an innovator in the development and manufacture of helicopter technology and, following a wholly different passion, the inventor of one of the first electrically amplified acoustic guitars, died on Monday in Bloomfield, Conn. He was 91.

title: Frank Wisner, the Diplomat Sent to Prod Mubarak
description: WASHINGTON  Once a month or so, a coterie of aging diplomats convenes at the elegant Metropolitan Club of New York. Over lunch in a glass-enclosed restaurant overlooking Central Park, they engage in verbal thrust and parry over the foreign policy issues of the day.

title: Joint Venture Creates a Rival For Concert Ticketing Services
description: In a challenge to Live Nation Entertainment, the music giant created last year by the merger of Ticketmaster and the promoter Live Nation, a rival concert company has made a deal for its own ticketing system.

title: Google Updates Its Latitude Service
description: Android users who upgrade to Google Maps 5.1, available since Tuesday, will find a bunch of new features added to Latitude, Googles location-based social network. The first is the ability to check in to actual places, like restaurants and stores. In the past, Latitude users could indicate where they were on a map, but the actual business or building they were in remained a mystery. (Im in Rockefeller Center is not terribly helpful. Im in J. Crew is.)

title: U.S. Agency to Handle Drug Testing at Tour of California
description: The Tour of California, the most prominent road cycling race in the United States, has hired the United States Anti-Doping Agency to handle its drug testing instead of relying on cyclings governing body to conduct those tests, a race official said Wednesday.

title: Public Theaters Finance Chief Quits With Little Explanation
description: Andrew D. Hamingson has resigned as executive director of the Public Theater after only two and a half years as the companys top financial executive, he and the Publics board chairman, Warren Spector, announced on Wednesday.

title: Parking Rules for New York City
description: Because of the Asian Lunar New Year, alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended on Thursday in New York City. Other regulations will remain in effect.

title: Price-Fixing by KeySpan Will Cost It $12 Million
description: Although price-fixing by an electricity company may have cost New York customers nearly $300 million, the federal government can close the books on the case by collecting a penalty of just $12 million, a judge ruled on Wednesday.

title: When Water, Cold, Gravity and a Building Come Together
description: When ice starts falling from skyscrapers, as happened on Wednesday in New York, the temptation is to fault the modern architect, who is often viewed as long on aesthetic vision but short on practical details.

title: An End to a Long Tenure Defending the Infamous
description: Leonard F. Joy, the lawyer who has led New Yorks influential federal public defenders office for the last two decades, is retiring this month, ending a tenure during which his office represented some of the most infamous defendants being prosecuted by the United States attorneys offices in Manhattan and Brooklyn.

title: Cuomos Budget Whittles at All Corners of the State
description: ALBANY  Homeless shelters in New York City could be forced to cut back on services. State support for cancer research could be curtailed. Some college students receiving help to pay for school could lose their money.

title: As Crisis Unfolds Overseas, Diplomats Gather in Washington
description: WASHINGTON  Nearly all the top United States diplomats from around the world met here on Wednesday, summoned by Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton to consider new strategies to energize diplomacy and streamline development, but their arrival coincided with one of the most tumultuous moments for American diplomacy in recent memory.

title: Sell or Build? Devils Owners Clash Over How to Proceed
description: The Devils may be streaking back into contention, but the teams majority owner, Jeff Vanderbeek, is becoming bogged down in a fight over the clubs future.

title: Sonys New PlayStation Portable
description: NGP (Next Generation Portable) is Sonys code name for the successor to the companys PSP Go portable gaming system.

title: Aesthetics? This Architect Likes the Dirty Work
description: Karen Thomas worked for more than 20 years at architecture firms in New York, including Costas Kondylis and  Beyer Blinder Belle, after graduating from Pennsylvania State University in 1988. But she eventually realized she would rather manage the construction of complex buildings than draw their blueprints. In 2007 she established her own firm, Karen Thomas Associates, an owners representative for high-end residential projects. Ms. Thomas, 45, lives in Greenwich Village with her husband, Ralph Gillis, an architect and former employer of hers, and their 9-year-old son, Henry.

title: Walking With a Jaguar
description: Tourists and volunteers can walk jaguars and pumas without any special training at Ambue Ari, an animal refuge in the Bolivian jungle.

title: Early Maneuvering on Possible Shutdown
description: WASHINGTON  Democrats do not intend to shut up when it comes to a potential government shutdown.

title: Thursday: Dash Away Home
description: THURSDAYS PUZZLE  My brain hurts.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,456 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American this week:

title: Yankees Acquire Potential Backup Outfielder
description: The Yankees continued to round out the fringes of their roster on Wednesday, acquiring the right-handed-hitting outfielder Justin Maxwell from the Washington Nationals. Maxwell, a career .201 hitter over parts of three seasons with Washington, could make the Yankees as a backup outfielder or, at the very least, improve their depth at Class AAA.

title: Bloombergs Plan on Pension Changes
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg proposed sweeping changes on Wednesday to the pension system for New York Citys municipal work force, including raising the retirement age for new employees and eliminating a bonus for retired police officers and firefighters.

title: Return of the Videophone (Part 973)
description: WorldGates Ojo Vision digital videophone is an option worth considering for those who dont want to sit in front of a computer or use a smartphone to make video calls.

title: Daily Show and Jersey Shore Deals for Viacom and Hulu
description: Viacom and Hulu have finally come to terms to provide Web audiences better access to The Daily Show and Jersey Shore.

title: Cuban Declines to Enter Chase for the Mets
description: Mark Cuban is a big baseball fan with a lot of discretionary income who would love the chance to own a major league franchise. But not now and not the Mets.

title: Fund Official Not Neutral, Judge Rules
description: Kenneth R. Feinberg, the administrator of the $20 billion fund to compensate victims of the Gulf of Mexico oil spill, should not claim that he is fully independent of BP, a federal judge overseeing litigation against the company ruled on Wednesday.

title: Out for a Leisurely Stroll in the Middle of a Jungle
description: AMBUE ARI, Bolivia  The mosquitoes descend so ferociously that residents simply call them the plague. Piranhas patrol streams. Caiman lurk in ponds. Then there are the monkeys. Visiting volunteers at this jungle outpost have written verses about their propensity to urinate on human belongings.

title: Egypts Bumbling Brotherhood
description: AS Egyptians clash over the future of their government, Americans and Europeans have repeatedly expressed fears of the Muslim Brotherhood. You dont just have a government and a movement for democracy, Tony Blair, the former British prime minister, said of Egypt on Monday. You also have others, notably the Muslim Brotherhood, who would take this in a different direction.

title: For Debt-Ridden French Region, a Famous Son Is Now an Expensive Proposition
description: SARRAN, France  Corrze is the most indebted of all of Frances 100 departments, and former President Jacques Chirac appears to be the prime reason.

title: India: Arrests in Telephone Scandal
description: The former telecommunications minister whose handling of the sale of mobile telephone spectrum licenses may have cost the government as much as $39 billion in revenue has been arrested, officials said. A government report released last year accused the former minister, Andimuthu Raja, of selling the airwaves at giveaway prices to favored companies. The ensuing scandal shook what had been Indias most stable government in decades and raised questions about whether the nations rapid growth could be at risk because of rampant corruption. Mr. Raja and several associates were arrested on Wednesday.

title: Knicks Are Inconsistent at Both Ends of Floor
description: The offense came in big, loud bursts and disappeared just as quickly. Danilo Gallinari hit shot after shot, then faded into the background. Amare Stoudemire rumbled for 21 points in the first half, and none in the second half.

title: Senate Rejects Repeal of Health Care Law
description: WASHINGTON  Senate Democrats on Wednesday defeated a bid by Republicans to repeal last years sweeping health care overhaul, as they successfully mounted a party-line defense of President Obamas signature domestic policy achievement.

title: New Hampshire: Early Release for Farmer
description: A farmer sent to prison for waving a gun at a trespasser won early release on Wednesday after an outpouring of community support. The farmer, Ward Bird, 49, of Moultonborough, was convicted of criminal threatening with a firearm after warning a woman who said she was lost to get off his property in 2006. Mr. Bird denied brandishing the gun. The case struck a nerve with gun and property rights supporters. After Gov. John Lynch would not allow Mr. Bird to be pardoned, the New Hampshire Executive Council voted unanimously to free him, two and a half months into his three-year sentence.

title: Barney Hajiro, Medal of Honor Recipient, Dies at 94
description: After Barney Hajiro, an Army private, single-handedly wiped out two German machine gun nests and killed two snipers in a gallant charge in World War II, his superiors recommended him for the Medal of Honor.

title: Hardware, Not Jewelry, for Belichick and Brady
description: DALLAS  A fourth Super Bowl ring has been elusive for Bill Belichick and Tom Brady, but they keep winning individual honors.

title: Awaiting the Outcome in Egypt
description: To the Editor:

title: Zimbabwe: Mugabe Opponents Beaten
description: As President Robert Mugabe and his party, ZANU-PF, push for elections this year, political violence in Harare, the capital, and its impoverished suburbs  carried out by youths chanting ZANU-PF slogans  has surged in recent weeks, civic groups and independent journalists reported this week. Doctors said in a written account on Wednesday that they had treated nine supporters of Prime Minister Morgan Tsvangirai, Mr. Mugabes rival. On Monday, they were assaulted with logs and stones and kicked by assailants wearing boots in Mbare, a suburb. Three of the victims were hospitalized with what the doctors described as grave injuries.

title: Bloggingheads: Fear the Brotherhood?
description: Heather Hurlburt, left, of the National Security Network and Eli Lake of The Washington Times debate the Muslim Brotherhood in Egypt.

title: American Idol': A Beautiful Use of Negative Space
description: This is what happens on American Idol when nothing happens on American Idol:

title: From Sadat to Mubarak: A Reminiscence, and a Prayer
description: To the Editor:

title: In Roars February
description: May is out there somewhere. Were sure of it  tulips blooming, trees disbudding and breaking into leaf. Its only a matter of time.

title: New York State Budget
description: To the Editor:

title: Jack LaLannes Legacy
description: To the Editor:

title: No Way to Run a Trade Policy
description: Most Republican lawmakers claim they are pro-trade. Their principled position is evidently no match for parochialism and politics. Last month, a conflict over imported sleeping bags between a company in Alabama and a rival in Kentucky led Senate Republicans to block the extension of the Generalized System of Preferences, or G.S.P., which has granted preferential access to some $20 billion worth of imports from developing countries.

title: Gov. Cuomos Budget
description: Gov. Andrew Cuomo was right this week when he said New York cannot allow special interests and inertia to keep driving up state spending. He was right that painful cuts must be made to close a $10 billion deficit in the states projected $96 billion operating budget.

title: The Man With the Snow Job
description: Our question for today is: Who is to blame for this weather?

title: Word of the Day | disaffected
description: disaffected \dis--fekt-d\ adjective

title: Photo Replay: Feb. 2
description: A look at the day in sports from skiing in Utah to soccer in Spain.

title: Corrections
description: FRONT PAGE

title: James Harrison Hates the 18-Game Schedule
description: Steelers linebacker James Harrison could not have been more forceful Wednesday when he was asked if he expected a lockout next season.

title: The Battle for Tahrir Square
description: Diagram of the clashes between pro- and antigovernment demonstrators in Tahrir Square.

title: Tropical Cyclone Yasi Makes Landfall
description: A huge cyclone made landfall along the coast of Queensland, Australia, with widespread reports of property damage and power failures.

title: Crackdown in Egypt Widens but Officials Offer Concessions
description: CAIRO  The Egyptian government on Thursday broadened its crackdown on a 10-day uprising that has shaken its rule, arresting journalists and human rights advocates across an edgy city, while offering more concessions in a bid to win support from a population growing frustrated with a devastated economy and scenes of chaos in the streets.

title: News Quiz | February 3, 2011
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: The iPhone Challenge
description: The Times's personal technology editor travels far and wide to see whether Verizon's iPhone really does work better than the competition.

title: TV Prices Still Falling, Sonys Profit Drops 8.6%
description: TOKYO  Hit by a strong yen and falling TV prices, Sony said Thursday that its profit fell 8.6 percent in the fiscal third quarter from the same period a year earlier. The decline came as the company made a renewed push in music and gaming with a flurry of new services and gadgets.

title: Daily Lexeme: Rakeshame
description: Todays word, in association with the illuminating Oxford English Dictionary, is
