description: Test your proofreading skills with todays question, created by Danielle Hoagland and Judith McCaffrey at Grammarlogues from the article Proofreading practice: What is the error in the following passage?

title: Citing Delays, Shell Ends Plans for Arctic in 2011
description: HOUSTON  Faced with continued regulatory delays, Royal Dutch Shell announced on Thursday that it was abandoning plans to drill for oil in Alaskan Arctic waters this year but that it remained committed to exploring in the area in the future.

title: S.E.C. Hurt by Disarray in Its Books
description: If a companys financial reporting were so bad that its auditor had pointed out significant weaknesses in its accounting for seven years running, the Securities and Exchange Commission would most likely be all over it.

title: What Will the Future Be Like?
description: What do you predict the world will be like in 50 years? 100? How will we get around? Get information? Interact with each other? What will we wear, eat and do? How will work change? What will we do for fun? What will your city or town look like? For inspiration, have a look at the drawings that depict New York Citys future that never was, predictions from planners and visionaries of the 20th century of what New York City should be.

title: Steel Giants Nippon and Sumitomo Talk of Merger
description: Two of Japans largest steel makers said on Thursday that they were in talks to merge, a move that would form the worlds second-largest producer of steel after ArcelorMittal.

title: The Year of the Rabbit
description: In honor of the Chinese New Year today, we pose questions that link to a variety of Times articles from the past and present, as well as to outside resources. Use this collection to teach students about the holiday and its cultural significance and traditions.

title: Super Bowl Probability: A True 50-50 Game
description: Brian Burke, a former Navy pilot who has taken up the less dangerous hobby of N.F.L. statistical analysis, operates Advanced NFL Stats, a blog about football, math and human behavior.

title: The Woman in the Family of Man Family
description: A lot has been said and written about this photograph. But for me and my brother and sisters, its a family photo  maybe one that put a few of us through school  but a family photo that has taken on a greater meaning with the recent passing of our mother, Lucienne Matthews, the woman in the picture.

title: The Ruinous Fiscal Impact of Big Banks
description: Simon Johnson, the former chief economist at the International Monetary Fund, is the co-author of 13 Bankers.

title: Dance the Night Away at Prague Opera Ball
description: Ladies dressed to the nines, men in tuxedos. A rococo Prague State Opera House is the setting, though the entertainment ranges from arias to a traditional Cambodian dance. Oh, and you are there to waltz. This imaginative evening isnt a dream sequence  its time once again for the annual Prague Opera Ball, scheduled this year for Feb. 5.

title: In Yemen, Protesters Face Off in Peace
description: SANA, Yemen  Thousands of pro- and anti-government demonstrators held peaceful protests in this impoverished capital on Thursday, playing out themes that have rocked nations across the Arab world as autocratic leaders struggle to press back the roaring demands of movements hungry for democracy, accountability and the rule of law.

title: The Early Word: Broken Bond
description: From Todays Times:

title: Rating Heart Risk Tests
description: They rate cars. They rate electronics. And now Consumer Reports is hoping its product-rating system will better inform consumers about why they should avoid some common heart-disease screening tests.

title: Avoiding I.T. Slip-Ups When Going Global
description: Dean Jerrehian, founder and chief executive of JadeYoga, a high-end yoga-mat manufacturer in Conshohocken, Pa., recently stumbled on a trove of his grandfathers letters. Mr. Jerrehian had to laugh when he saw what the man had to go through to set up meetings with clients in his real estate business 70 years ago. It took him months of letters to arrange to meet someone by the side of road, he said. And this was for a client who was all of 40 miles away. I was complaining the other day because it took me three days of swapping e-mail to nail down a deal in Jakarta. Just in the last few days Ive been dealing with customers in Indonesia, Australia, Japan, Israel and Turkey.

title: 2011: The Year of the Anniversary
description: What connects Horace Greeley, Gypsy Rose Lee, the citys first black police officer, the Manhattan street grid, City Hall, the New York Public Library building on Fifth Avenue and the Triangle Shirtwaist fire? Their centennials or bicentennials are being commemorated this year.

title: Australians Take Cover as Cyclone Lashes Coast
description: SYDNEY, Australia  One of the most powerful cyclones ever to strike Australia ripped dozens of houses from their foundations, uprooted trees and shredded millions of dollars worth of sugar and banana crops when it slammed into Queenslands northeastern coast in the predawn hours on Thursday.

title: Auto Repair Shops Reap Winters Bounty
description: Motorists who leave their cars parked on the street this winter are getting ample time to hone their exhumation techniques. However, the subsequent forward-reverse ballet used to get a vehicle onto open pavement is often treated indelicately, damaging vehicle and wallet.

title: Hosni Mubarak Agonistes
description: CAIRO

title: Morning Take-Out
description: MERGERS & ACQUISITIONS

title: Egypt Stymies Republican Message Machine
description: The Republican strategy in the Senate this week was simple: force Democrats to consider a total repeal of President Obamas health care law to draw attention to the fact that the presidents party still supports what Republicans believe is a wildly unpopular law.

title: Central Bank in Europe Leaves Rate Unchanged
description: The European Central Bank on Thursday dampened expectations that it was edging closer to its first interest rate increase since 2008, as Jean-Claude Trichet, the banks president, said rising commodity prices had not yet led to lasting inflation.

title: Preparing to Leave the Amazon, and Telling Tales of Parasites Past
description: Anthony Di Fiore, a primate biologist at New York University, writes from Ecuador, where he is using GPS technology and camera traps to study the behavior of male spider monkeys.

title: A New Sifty Fifty
description: A new edition of the Sifty Fifty has just been released as part of The New York Timess Scoop  app for iPhones and iPads, bringing on some new restaurants to join my list of 50 current favorites here in New York City, and retiring some others to make room. Download  it if you like. Doesnt cost a dime!

title: Q.&A.: Streaming (and Stuttering) Movies
description: Q.

title: PepsiCo to Buy Rest of Russian Beverage Company
description: PepsiCo, which announced on Thursday that it had completed its $3.8 billion acquisition of a two-thirds stake in Wimm-Bill-Dann Foods, plans to pay $132 a share for the remaining piece.

title: BJs Wholesale Club Confirms Its for Sale
description: BJs Wholesale Club said on Thursday that it had decided to explore and evaluate strategic alternatives, including a possible sale of the company.

title: Isolated Amazon Tribes Threatened by Logging, Groups Say
description: Brazilian officials have released new aerial photographs of a highly isolated tribe living deep in the Amazon rainforest in a bid to draw attention to the threat posed to its existence by illegal logging in neighboring Peru.

title: Deutsche Bank Profit Declines 54% in Fourth Quarter
description: Deutsche Bank, the largest investment bank in Germany, on Thursday reported net income of 605 million euros in the fourth quarter, down 54 percent from 1.3 billion euros in the period a year earlier.

title: Income Falls 26% at The Times Company as Print Advertising Drops
description: The New York Times Company reported a drop in fourth-quarter net income on Thursday in a challenging advertising market for newspaper publishers.

title: Request to Drop Dishonorable for Troops Discharged as Gay
description: Now that Congress has approved repeal of the ban on gay men and lesbians serving openly in the armed forces, a Wisconsin congresswoman is urging the Defense Department to reconsider the less-than-honorable discharges issued to some soldiers under the policy.

title: Morning Buzz | Pension Reform on Bloombergs Agenda
description: The skies are paved with blue, but the ground may still be icy. Watch your step this morning. Highs in the upper 20s.

title: Equity Deals Rebounding With I.P.O.s
description: The megabuyouts have turned out to be anything but megabusts.

title: Updates on Day 10 of Egypt Protests
description: On Thursday, The Lede continues to provide updates on the street protests in Egypt. For a summary of the latest developments, read the current report from our colleagues in Cairo. Updates below mix alerts on breaking news and reports from bloggers and journalists posted on other news sites and social networks. A stream of Twitter updates on the protests is in this blogs right column. Readers can share information in the comment thread below or send photographs or video from Egypt to pix@nyt.com.

title: Seeing Things | Louis Kahns Italian Idyll
description: Kahn in Venice, an exhibition at the Italian Cultural Institute in Los Angeles, celebrates the architect Louis I. Kahns special relationship with Italy. His unbuilt 1968 project for a congress hall in Venice is the centerpiece of the show, which was organized in collaboration with the Architectural Archives of the University of Pennsylvania, and which also includes many of Kahns lush, expressive travel sketches of buildings, gardens, bridges and street scenes in Venice, Rome and the hill towns of Tuscany. (The exhibition, which is on view through March 19, was curated and designed by the Los Angeles architects Barton Myers and David Karp, both of whom were Kahns students and apprentices.)

title: Gangs Hunt Journalists and Rights Workers
description: Journalists covering the revolt against President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt have found themselves the targets of widespread anger and suspicion in an apparently coordinated campaign that is intended to stifle the flow of news that could further undermine the government.

title: Arcelor and Nunavut Enlarge Baffinland Stake
description: ArcelorMittal and Nunavut Iron Ore said on Thursday that they had acquired an additional 6.2 million shares of the Baffinland Iron Mines Corporation, moving closer to taking control of the company.

title: Hype Central: The Hate Ben Bandwagon, Beer in the White House, Paging Axl Rose
description: Thursday Morning Updates from nutrient-rich primordial broth of Super Bowl nonsense:

title: Blackstone Posts 56% Rise in Quarterly Profit
description: One year made a very big difference for the Blackstone Group, especially for its huge real estate unit.

title: Economic Growth and Household Income
description: Apologies to Lane Kenworthy  he already took into account the price-index issue I raised here. So the question is, what does account for the divergence between economic growth and median family income?

title: In One Punch, Down Goes DiPietro
description: With less than a minute to go and his team trailing, 3-0, in Pittsburgh on Wednesday, Islanders goaltender Rick DiPietro decided to push back. As Penguins forward Matt Cooke skated by his crease, DiPietro shoved him in the chest, knocking the noted Penguins antagonist down. A few scrums ensued and DiPietro met his netminding counterpart, Brent Johnson, at the Islanders blue line. Both shed their blockers and gloves.

title: No Column Tomorrow
description: Just a heads up: Im taking today off from columnizing, because its my first teaching day this semester, and I want to focus. So dont get either alarmed or triumphant, depending on your attitude, when Im not in tomorrows paper; its just a one-off.

title: More On Simple Models
description: Two followups on my post about the goodness of simple thought experiments:

title: Despite Snowstorms, Many Retailers Posted Gains in January
description: Retailers kicked off 2011 with better-than-expected sales in January, with some relying on discounts to clear merchandise left over from the holiday season. But while the results exceeded forecasts, analysts said there were challenges ahead as rising costs pare profits.

title: A Conversation With Tyler Cowen
description: Tyler Cowen, an economics professor at George Mason University, is best known as one half of the blogging team at Marginal Revolution. Mr. Cowens brief new e-book, The Great Stagnation, on the causes of the American economic malaise, has received a lot of attention in recent days.

title: When the Going Gets Tough
description: the tough go eating. The Times most-emailed list, earlier this morning:

title: Turning Stock Bonuses Into Trading Cash
description: One Danish financial firm is eager to cash in on the frustration felt by some investment bankers who this year received more of their bonuses in stock than cash.

title: Three-Speed Recovery
description: Description of the different 2011 growth trajectories for the economies of the US, the Euro zone, and the worlds emerging markets.

title: Syfy Spins Its Upfront Presentation Into Spider-Man Performance
description: Regardless of what new programs the Syfy cable channel announces at its annual upfront presentation, what ratings statistics it touts or who drinks the most cocktails at the bar, anyone who attends the invitation-only event is sure to go home with a story to tell. On Thursday morning, Syfy said it will hold its upfront on March 22 at the Foxwoods Theater in Times Square, where the presentation will be followed by a special performance of that theaters resident musical  a little production known as Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark.

title: Mick Jagger to Perform at the Grammys
description: Mick Jagger will perform at the Grammy Awards on Feb. 13, his first-ever solo performance at the show. He will be paying tribute to his hero Solomon Burke, who died in October, as part of the ceremonys In Memoriam segment, the Recording Academy announced. Other performers already scheduled for the show, which will be broadcast live on CBS: Eminem, Lady Gaga, Arcade Fire, Justin Bieber and Usher, Katy Perry, and the very intriguing combination of Cee Lo Green with Gwyneth Paltrow and the Jim Henson Company Puppets.

title: Crops Wither and Prices Rise in Chinese Drought
description: HONG KONG  A severe drought in northern China has badly damaged the winter wheat crop and left the ground very dry for the spring planting, fueling inflation and alarming Chinas leaders.

title: For Tucson Survivors, Health Care Cost Is Concern
description: TUCSON  Seconds after gunfire erupted outside a supermarket here last month, Randy Gardner, one of those struck during the barrage, said another potential crisis immediately entered his mind.

title: Newmont Mining Strikes $2 Billion Gold Deal
description: Newmont Mining, the biggest gold producer in the United States, said on Thursday that it had agreed to acquire Fronteer Gold of Vancouver, British Columbia, in a deal valued at more than $2 billion.

title: A Very Laid-Back Front-Runner
description: In our column today, the Bagger looks at the documentary race, where there may actually be some drama. Not that you would know it from the behavior of the presumed front-runner, Charles Ferguson, the director of Inside Job, his dissection of the financial meltdown. Mr. Ferguson, an early Internet millionaire, is soft-spoken and unconcerned with appearances; hes been known to show up at awards shows in sneakers. Hes been through the Oscar process before, with his first film, No End in Sight, in 2008. Whats changed in his approach since then? I have an agent now, which I never did before, he said. Ive spoken to the Sony publicity people a few times. (Sony Pictures Classics is the distributor of Inside Job, which is being re-released in theaters on the back of its Oscar nomination.) But, he added of the Oscar race, this is totally not my department.

title: Thursday Reading: Affordable Wall Art
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: How to Save on Auto Repair Bills This Winter
description: In the Wheels blog, Jonathan Schultz writes in the post Auto Repair Shops Reap Winters Bounty about how business at some auto shops is booming this winter due to drivers who are too overeager to leave their snowy parking spaces and dont take the time to clear their cars with a shovel.

title: Video: Trent Reznors Oscar-Nominated Score
Verizon Customers Report Glitches With iPhone Orders
description: 3:23 p.m. | Updated  Included details from a colleague on their experiences ordering an iPhone from Verizon.

title: A Legendary Look
description: Bettie Page, the most famous pinup girl of the post-World War II era, helped set the stage for the sexual revolution of the 1960s.

title: Poetry Pairing | Feb. 3, 2011
description: In our weekly Poetry Pairing series, we collaborate with the Poetry Foundation to feature a work from its American Life in Poetry project alongside content from The Times that somehow echoes, extends or challenges the poems themes. Each poem is introduced briefly by Ted Kooser, a former United States poet laureate.

title: G.O.P. Hopefuls Leave Egypt Crisis to the President
description: WASHINGTON  A parade of prospective Republican presidential candidates has been visiting the Middle East in recent months, making pilgrimages that are the first steps in a methodical process of building credibility in foreign policy.

title: Whats a Little Swine Flu Outbreak Among Friends?
description: If you or your child came down with influenza during the H1N1, or swine flu, outbreak in 2009, it may not have happened the way you thought it did.

title: Mayor Curses the Beast, and It Didnt Even Bite Him
description: Updated, 3:37 p.m. | The Daily News has published an abridged version  above  of the video that cuts directly to the moment in which the mayor curses Staten Island Chuck.

title: Now Opening | Honor
description: With only one season under her belt, Giovanna Randall, the designer behind the New York-based label Honor, is opening a shop in the meatpacking district. But there is more in store than Randalls girlie cocktail dresses and long chiffon evening gowns. Like the label that shares its name, Honor is all about the prettier, finer points of a womans pleasures. I started asking myself, What do you think Sophia Lorens couch looks like? or What kind of typewriter would Grace Kelly have used?  the designer says. Randall plans to display her collection alongside vintage and new books. Cafe treats like Bellocq tea and espresso are a small step toward Randalls dream of turning Honor into a multidimensional lifestyle brand. I fantasize about coming by the shop and being able to pick up a lovely party dress and wonderful bouquet of flowers en route to a friends birthday dinner. So do we.

title: He Can Serve, but He Cant Run
description: Joseph Chirlee is an American citizen and a private in the United States Army stationed in Colorado. He is also a world-class marathoner with a shot at qualifying for the 2012 Summer Olympics. He had hoped to run in the national cross-country championships Saturday in San Diego.

title: Daniel Bell, Master Builder
description: With the death last month of Daniel Bell, America lost its last great 20th-century big thinker, though this is not necessarily the impression many now have of him. One reason is that Bell was most prolific during a period, 1950-80, bounded by the cold war, that has receded into the half-forgotten past. Another is that for most of his career, Bell was seen less as a singular figure than as one of a club of intellectuals whose pedigrees were so similar they seemed interchangeable  New York City-reared Jews trained in factional combat at City College and groomed as journalists in the pages of small-circulation magazines (The New Leader, Commentary, Partisan Review, Encounter, The Public Interest), with detours into the Luce empire (Bell was for a time the labor editor of Fortune) and university perches (in Bells case Columbia and Harvard).

title: Artest Vows to Stay with Lakers
description: Its getting closer to Feb. 24, also known as the N.B.A. trade deadline, and interesting things are starting to bubble.
