description: An aggregation of links by the reporters and editors of Diners Journal.

title: Schwarzman Says Bonjour to Analysts From Paris
description: 11:56 a.m. | Updated with Mr. Schwarzmans comments

title: Leading Off: Favre Fatigue Fuels Steelermania
description: It is not your imagination if you are sensing the Steelers are more than half of this Super Bowl. Sure, everyone expected the endless stream of Ben Roethlisberger stories. (Todays topic on ESPN.com: is he Hall of Fame worthy? Huh?) But you would figure when everyone grew bored with that, they would mosey over to Packerland and find some stuff to kick around.

title: Eddie Huangs Chinese New Year
description: Chinese New Year came in on a platter of red-cooked pork shoulder on Wednesday night, part of the chef Eddie Huangs three-course holiday banquet at the No. 7 restaurant in Fort Greene, Brooklyn.

title: Franzens Five Goals Stun Ottawa
description: Prior to Wednesday night, Detroits Johan Franzen had never had a hat trick in an N.H.L. regular season game, but he did have three in the Stanley Cup playoffs (including four goals in one playoff game last spring against San Jose). When the powerful wing his teammates call Mule hit the milestone Wednesday in Ottawa, he was not content to settle for a simple three-goal game.

title: Rolls-Royce Names Giles Taylor of Jaguar to Lead Exterior Design
description: Rolls-Royce has poached Giles Taylor from Jaguar to become its new head of exterior design.

title: Do Nothing (Impossible?)
description: Impossible

title: Psst Groundwater and Surface Water Do Mix
description: An article published in the journal Geophysical Research Letters this week describes a new and simple way of measuring groundwaters contribution to small streams on the surface.

title: American Makes Best of Second Chance in Premier League
description: CHORLEY, England  The practice session began as it would for most soccer players across England, with a juggling drill. In a small circle, they kept the ball in the air, passing it to one another. For Bolton Wanderers, an English Premier League team, there was a playfully cruel twist to the game: the first man to let the ball touch the ground would have his ears flicked by every member of the team.

title: Nave and Slightly Woozy
description: I am hungover, and though there was a certain amount of celebrating last night, it isnt mostly alcohol-based. (I know, thats what they all say.)

title: A Week in Egypts Twilight Zone
description: Editors note: Crisis Points is a series of personal accounts and commentary in response to unrest and political events as they develop, now focusing on the situation in Egypt, Tunisia and the Middle East. It will offer a variety of viewpoints from both inside and outside the affected region  from journalists, scholars, citizens and others.

title: Popcast: Ricky Martins New Album and a Look Back at Totico
description: This week on Popcast, The Timess weekly music podcast, Jon Pareles reviews Ricky Martins Msica + Alma + Sexo (Music + Soul + Sex), his first album since coming out of the closet.

title: President Prays for Peace in the Mideast
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama, in wide-ranging remarks at the National Prayer Breakfast, said Thursday that he was praying for the violence in the Middle East to end, and separately called on the country to move beyond polarizing debate to remember that few people are right all of the time.

title: Another Challenge to Greenhouse Gas Regulation
description: Three Republican lawmakers have joined the bandwagon of opponents of Environmental Protection Agency regulation of climate-altering gases. Senator James Inhofe of Oklahoma and Representatives Fred Upton of Michigan and Ed Whitfield of Kentucky are circulating a draft of a bill dubbed the Energy Tax Prevention Act of 2011 that takes aim squarely at the E.P.A.s authority to impose limits on emissions of carbon dioxide and other heat-trapping gases.

title: As Islamist Group Rises, Its Intentions Are Unclear
description: WASHINGTON  After maintaining a low profile in protests led largely by secular young Egyptians, the Muslim Brotherhood, the countrys largest opposition force, appeared to be taking a more assertive role on Thursday, issuing a statement asking for President Hosni Mubarak to step aside for a transitional government.

title: Citys High Abortion Rate Defies Easy Explanation
description: At a time when evidence suggests that people in New York City are smoking less, eating better and biking more, one health statistic that has not budged is the abortion rate.

title: President and Opera, on Unexpected Stages
description: During a panel discussion about Nixon in China on Tuesday at the Metropolitan Opera, Peter Gelb turned to the team of onetime artistic rebels who created this work for its Houston Grand Opera premiere in 1987 and suggested that back then, surely, no one involved had had any ambitions for the Met. Other than for its dismantlement, Mr. Gelb added.

title: Alexander the Great
description: One of the most exciting lines I saw during this recent mens show season in Paris was off the runways, in a small gallery on the rue de Turenne in the Marais. Alexandre Plokhov, a co-founder of the much-missed Cloak label and the recently departed designer of Versaces mens-wear line, introduced his new namesake collection of architectural suiting and design-minded sportswear pieces. Before walking through the racks of clothing, I was shown a short film by Douglas Keeve, whom Plokhov met during the filming of Seamless, a documentary featuring young designers vying for the first CFDA/Vogue Fashion Fund. (Plokhov lost first prize to Lazaro Hernandez and Jack McCullough of Proenza Schouler.)

title: Palin Will Skip Conservative Gathering
description: Sarah Palin has declined an invitation to join leading Republicans in appearing at the next Conservative Political Action Conference, a key gathering of party activists who hold an influential voice in the Republican presidential nominating contest.

title: With Subtraction and Addition, Haiti Sets Its Presidential Runoff
description: MEXICO CITY  After a nearly two-month standoff with international donors over its disputed presidential election, Haitis electoral council on Thursday announced that it had removed the government-backed candidate from the second round of voting in favor of a popular musician whose supporters had protested fiercely when he was initially excluded.

title: Photo of the Week  Guess Where This Is
description: For our Photo of the Week this week, were bringing back one of our favorite features, Guess Where This Is. The rules: We provide a hint and you guess the location in comments below. Well provide the answer later this afternoon.

title: Union Membership Rate Lowest in 15 Years
description: New York and New Jersey may have stopped shedding jobs in 2010, but their labor unions have not, a report released Thursday by the federal Department of Labor shows.

title: After Office Hours, Amy Ryan Plans a Concert Performance
description: 12:56 p.m. | Updated

title: Keeping Score: Kevin Loves Rare Combination of Talents
description: Justin Kubatko is the creator of Basketball-Reference.com, an online basketball encyclopedia. He is also a statistical consultant for the Portland Trail Blazers.

title: Many in Pakistan Fear Unrest at Home
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Protests over crippling prices and corrupt leadership are sweeping much of the Islamic world, but here in Pakistan this week, the government blithely dismissed any threat to its longevity or to the countrys stability.

title: Pride of Place in Every Drop
description: For Joe Santos, producing and distributing his own gin was a way to say goodbye to the lock-step march of the corporate world and hello to creativity and originality. He wanted to give the gin a name that communicated that. So he invoked a certain New York City borough, the one currently outpacing the others in self-satisfaction.

title: Clashes Continue in Egypt
description: Clashes continued near Tahrir Square in Cairo on Thursday. Violence overnight left at least five dead and more than 800 wounded.

title: The Drawing Center Expands Beyond Its Lines
description: After years of casting around for a new home, the space-starved Drawing Center has found a way to stay put and expand its galleries.

title: Virginia to Ask Supreme Court to Rule on Health Law
description: Virginias attorney general announced on Thursday that he hoped to bypass an initial appellate review by asking the United States Supreme Court to consider the constitutionality of the Obama health care law on an expedited basis.

title: Norris and Leonhardt on Jobs
description: 4:41 p.m. | Updated In advance of Fridays jobs report, two Times columnists  Floyd Norris and David Leonhardt  talk about the state of the economy and the job market. [Their conversation continued on Friday morning, after the report was released.]

title: Bernanke Takes Sides on Debt Limit Vote
description: WASHINGTON  The Federal Reserve chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, warned Congressional Republicans on Thursday not to play around with a coming vote to raise the governments legal borrowing limit or use it as a bargaining chip for spending cuts.

title: King Moves to Widen Outreach in Jordan
description: AMMAN, Jordan  King Abdullah II, struggling to stave off growing public discontent, widened his political outreach on Thursday and met with the Muslim Brotherhood for the first time in nearly a decade. He also asserted in a statement that he would fight corruption and foster a broad national dialogue.

title: Nepal Selects a Premier, Ending a Stalemate
description: KATMANDU, Nepal  Nepals bitterly divided legislature elected a new prime minister on Thursday, ending a stalemate that had paralyzed the country for months as competing political parties fought to control the government in this strategically located Himalayan nation.

title: Andy Pettitte Decides to Retire
description: The Yankees frustrating off-season took another discouraging turn with the news Thursday that Andy Pettitte would retire. Pettitte called Hal Steinbrenner, the teams managing general partner, to tell him his plans. The Yankees confirmed in a news release that Pettitte would make a formal announcement on Friday at 10:30 a.m. at Yankee Stadium.

title: Relive the Forgotten Great Super Bowl
description: The folks at Hulu.com are counting down the top 10 Super Bowls of all time, as selected by my colleague Aaron Schatz of Football Outsiders. No. 10 on the list is a forgotten classic: Super Bowl XIV. The Rams threw a scare into the mighty Steelers on Jan. 20th, 1980, but the Steelers pulled away late in the fourth quarter for a 31-19 victory.

title: Teva Warns, and Merck and Glaxo Post Losses
description: One of the worlds largest generic drug makers disclosed Thursday that the Food and Drug Administration had sent it a warning letter over manufacturing problems.

title: The Next Stop on Abercrombies Ohio Express
description: Robert Wright for The New York TimesInside an Abercrombie & Fitch store.

title: Seeking a Deal Duet With EMI
description: Citigroup has taken control of the British music company EMI Group in a deal that significantly cuts EMIs debt. Now that its balance sheet is improved, will suitors emerge to bid for EMI?

title: Wal-Mart Skips Council Hearing as Impact of Stores Is Assailed
description: It was a moment long planned and carefully prepared for  a moment that had twice been delayed by snow. But when the moment finally arrived, the main protagonist was missing.

title: How Aggressive Is Your Hospital?
description: One morning during my training, I noticed that the belly of a patient in the I.C.U. had grown rounder and tighter overnight. The patient had gone through a difficult liver transplant a day earlier and was bleeding, it seemed, into his abdomen. I was the newest member of the transplant team, but even so, I knew what had to be done right away: We had to take this man back to the operating room.

title: TD Ameritrade Pays $10 Million to Settle Charges
description: TD Ameritrade agreed on Thursday to pay $10 million to settle federal charges that it misled customers about the dangers posed by one of its mutual funds that owned commercial paper issued by Lehman Brothers.

title: Orchid Children
description: Children who are biologically sensitive to context  making them more susceptibleto both positive and negativeenvironmental factors.

title: The Benefits of Aggressive Care
description: Doctors and hospitals are sometimes criticized as being too aggressive, meaning they are too quick to offer pills, surgery or another medical intervention.

title: Honoring Art, Honoring Artists
description: WHEN the Denver Art Museums signature American Indian art galleries reopened last week after a seven-month overhaul, the biggest change wasnt the new display cases or the dramatic lighting. Rather, it was in a less obvious place: the wall labels.

title: N.B.A. Fines Knicks $200,000 for Prohibited Workouts
description: The N.B.A. fined the Knicks $200,000 and one of their scouts $20,000 after concluding that the scout, Rodney Heard, conducted workouts of college prospects that violated league rules.

title: Could Prizes Emerge From the Gowanus Muck?
description: As if the Gowanus Canal in Brooklyn werent contaminated enough by toxic chemicals, investigators with the federal Environmental Protection Agency say that debris of all shapes and sizes  bulkhead fragments, construction materials and even a few sunken vessels  is pervasive throughout the waterway, as I reported in Thursdays paper.

title: In Afghanistan, a Lot of Luck Goes a Long Way
description: Late Tuesday morning, two American infantry platoons and an Afghan National Army team were driving along a dirt road through rural Ghazni Province, heading back to their company outpost after finishing an early-morning sweep of Ali Jan Kala, a village where the Taliban is strong. The American soldiers were riding in MATV armored vehicles and the Afghans were in an armored Humvee, picking their way along the road at modest speed.

title: A Ride on the YikeBike
description: The YikeBike, an electric bike with top speeds of 15 miles per hour, folds down so you don't have to lock it to a tree.

title: Deaccessioned Items Exceed Estimates in Sales at Sothebys
description: Items that the Cleveland Museum of Art and the J. Paul Getty Museum were deaccessioning as part of a routine turnover in their collections both exceeded estimates in sales last week at Sothebys in New York. Of 30 lots from Cleveland comprising 32 old-master paintings  two lots were pairs  Sothebys sold 26 for a total of $1.8 million. (The estimate had been $700,000 to $1 million.) Of 15 works from the Getty, 12 sold for $3.7 million. (The estimate had been $1.4 million to $2.1 million.)

title: Zach Randolphs Quiet Stardom
description: On Wednesday night, Minnesotas Kevin Love nearly saw his streak of consecutive double-doubles come to an end against Memphis. Love was physically dominated, moved easily in the post and boxed out by an opponent who clearly got the better of him. After 35 minutes of action, Love would eventually eke out 10 points and 10 boards to keep his streak alive, but there was little question as to the victor of this particular individual matchup.

title: A D.J. Gets Control of His Lifestyle as Well as His Tunes
description: Luis Cedeo knows a thing or two about the right mix. In the 1970s, entranced by D.J. Kool Hercs mastery of the turntables, he got behind the wheels of steel himself and gained fame as Disco Wiz, a trailblazing Latino hip-hop D.J. Three decades later, he is still obsessed with the mix  the one found on his plate.

title: Want to Read The Daily? No iPad? No Problem
description: 2:56 p.m. | Updated  Adding more quotes from the press conference on Wednesday.

title: Elmos World Now to Include the National Childrens Museum
description: Let other museums have their Picassos and Monets; when the National Childrens Museum opens in Prince Georges County, Md., in 2013, the big names in the galleries will be Cookie Monster, Elmo, and Oscar the Grouch. On Thursday, the museum announced a partnership with Sesame Workshop, the nonprofit organization behind Sesame Street, in which the workshop will help the museum develop programming for young children, and Sesame Street characters will be woven into the exhibits.

title: Sheen Eyes Quick Return to Sitcom, Publicist Says
description: The latest episode in the saga of Charlie Sheen is looking more like a repeat.

title: Plea to Expand Enrollment at Top Colleges
description: 9:28 a.m. | Updated The authors have written a follow-up post, in response to some of your many comments. It can be read here.

title: Teenagers, Friends and Bad Decisions
description: Why do otherwise good kids seem to make bad decisions when they are with their friends? New research on risk taking and the teenage brain offers some answers.

title: Shorty Tangs Sesame Noodles Are Alive and Well
description: Those interested in a taste of 1970s Sichuan cooking in New York City will do well to visit Court Street Grocers on Thursday afternoon, where Gilley and Casey Tang are preparing their familys cold sesame noodles in honor of Chinese New Year. Their grandfather, Shorty Tang of Hwa Yuan restaurant on East Broadway in Chinatown, is thought by some to have cooked the best version of that dish ever to be served in Manhattan. And their father, Jerry Tang, had a long career in New York restaurants. Andrew Burman, the Grocers chef, has prepared red-cooked pork belly as well.

title: The Commuter Bike Redesigned and Electrified
description: This week, most people on the East Coast were hunkering down indoors, prepared for this winters fourth Snowstorm of the Century. I, on the other hand, was riding around a hotel ballroom on a YikeBike. And Ill be straight with you: I had kind of a Segway moment.

title: Parents Seek More Action on PCBs in Schools
description: As the father of an 8-year-old attending Public School 36 on Staten Island, Richard P. Ghiraldi was alarmed to learn that students were being exposed to a known carcinogen.

title: New Batch of Debuts, With 80s Forebears
description: Yuck

title: JPMorgan Hid Doubts on Madoff, Documents Suggest
description: Senior executives at JPMorgan Chase expressed serious doubts about the legitimacy of Bernard L. Madoffs investment business more than 18 months before his Ponzi scheme collapsed but continued to do business with him, according to internal bank documents made public in a lawsuit on Thursday.

title: S.E.C. Charges 6 in Insider Trading Cases
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission filed civil charges of insider trading against six people associated with expert network firms after criminal cases brought earlier by the Justice Department against the same group.

title: To the N.F.L., Babies Were (Full-Priced) People Too
description: DALLAS  Rooting for the Packers or Steelers isnt cheap, even when youre a baby and incapable of saying words like Rodgers or Roethlisberger. Thats what Daniel Smith and his family found out.

title: Luker, McGillin Are the Answer for Wheres Charley?
description: Rebecca Luker (Mary Poppins) and Howard McGillin (The Mystery of Edwin Drood) have been cast in Wheres Charley?, the final production in the 2010-11 Encores! season of overlooked and underappreciated musicals.

title: From 1983, Hope for Jobs in 2011
description: The unemployment rate declined four-tenths of a percentage point in one month. There had not been a monthly decline that large in many years, but economists were unimpressed. After all, the decline was caused in no small part by a surprising reduction in the labor force, which could be an indication that more workers were discouraged and no longer looking. That would hardly be an encouraging development.

title: State of the Union | Vera Wangs White Collection
description: Its official, ladies: You can now get married in Vera Wang for less than $1,500. Although the price may scream ABS by Allen Schwartz, design-wise, White, is all Vera. From the draped bodices to the flouncy hems, the swirls of tulle and hand-appliqud lace, the inspiration comes straight out of Wangs two-decades-plus archive  including, yes, the dresses she created for Victoria Beckham and Chelsea Clinton.

title: $1 Million to Inventor of Tracker for A.L.S.
description: BOSTON  Tracking the inexorable advance of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, the deadly neuromuscular ailment better known as Lou Gehrigs disease or A.L.S., has long been an inexact science  a matter of monitoring weakness and fatigue, making crude measurements of the strength of various muscles.

title: Bloomberg Loving Bloomberg? He Loves It
description: He is depicted as the ultimate narcissist: a man so content with himself that hearts spring from his head when he gazes into the mirror and a box of Valentines Day chocolates by his side is labeled, To: Me.

title: Questioning Authority: Evaluating Wikipedia Articles
description: Overview | If Wikipedia is a collaborative project open to all, why are fewer than 15 percent of the sites contributors women? How authoritative and complete do Wikipedia articles tend to be? In this lesson, students evaluate Wikipedia articles and consider the factors that contribute to the articles reliability.

title: App Smart Extra: Android Market Gets an Upgrade
description: A few weeks ago when I decried the current state of Android app stores, I reserved the sharpest blows for Googles Android Market. For a company thats in the business of helping people find things, it was an embarrassment.

title: In Pa., Obama Pushes Investment in Clean Energy
description: STATE COLLEGE, Pa.  President Obama brought a message of economic innovation and clean energy to this key swing state on Thursday, even as his administration continued to grapple with the rapidly changing uprising in Egypt.

title: Buzz Tracker
description: Lords of Leverage Bethany McLean is struck by the amount of Wall Street leverage that is described in the Financial Crisis Inquiry Commissions report: From 1978 to 2007, the amount of debt held by the financial sector increased twelvefold, from $3 trillion to $36 trillion. Maybe underneath all the idiocy, deception and delusion, and all the complexity of financial instruments like mortgage-backed securities and collateralized debt obligations  maybe under all that, the real lesson of the financial crisis is really quite simple: Steeply rising debt isnt healthy for people, and it isnt healthy for banks. Slate

title: Theater Talkback: What Rocco Landesman Should Speak About Next
description: Rocco Landesman probably doesnt need a new nickname, but its tempting to give him one anyway: Cowboy Mouth. With thanks to Sam Shepard and Patti Smith, the authors of a play of that title, it seems a useful handle for the outspoken chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts, whose fondness for cowboy boots was well known when he was the head of Jujamcyn Theaters.

title: 36 Hours in Santiago, Chile
description: LIKE the on-again, off-again construction of the citys Costanera Center, which will include South Americas tallest skyscraper, Santiago is reaching for the skies while progress moves forward in fits and starts, thanks in part to natural disasters like the 8.8 magnitude quake that rocked the country last year. Still, theres a spirit of enterprise in the capital, which was the top destination in the New York Times Travel sections The 41 Places to Go in 2011 feature. From a growing fashion movement to government initiatives to create a Silicon Valley of the South, there is an energy that just cant be suppressed. Long gone are the days when the city was derided for its food scene or seen as sleepy and staid. Arts sites like the Centro Gabriela Mistral, which opened in September, along with cutting-edge galleries, boutiques and stand-out restaurants, attest to an urban scene that has blossomed in the wake of a repressive dictatorship now long dead.

title: A Weekend in Santiago
description: Santiago is reaching for the skies while progress moves forward in fits and starts, thanks in part to natural disasters like last years earthquake.

title: Roger Deakins, the Susan Lucci of Cinematography
description: Roger Deakins is almost the Susan Lucci of cinematography: hes been nominated for an Oscar nine times, starting with The Shawshank Redemption in 1994, and never won. Hes on deck again this year, for the Coen brothers True Grit. Many of his honors came from his collaboration with the Coens; he has been their go-to cinematographer since Barton Fink.They first met more than two decades ago, at a coffee shop in Notting Hill, in London. By then they were great cult filmmakers, Mr. Deakins said, in a phone interview from his home in Santa Monica. I dont know why they had chosen to meet with me, but they did and we got on. Does he understand them any better now? I guess, he said, laughing.But Mr. Deakins professed as much surprise as the Coens have about True Grit being such a box office hit. Its maybe more accessible than most of their films, he said. I think its a great movie, but I think most of their films are great movies.He is currently working on Now, a futuristic thriller from the director Andrew Niccol (Gattaca), his first experience shooting in digital. What does he make of the divide between film and digital? I dont really see the point of the argument, Mr. Deakins said. You use images and light and texture and camera movement to tell a story. I think its a technical argument, and films arent really made by technique.

title: Google Executive Remains Missing in Egypt
description: Google engineers spent last weekend working with Twitter to build a service for people in Egypt without Internet access to post messages to Twitter by leaving a telephone voicemail.

title: Cheerful News on Crime Data and the Integrity Thereof
description: The three panelists Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly tapped to evaluate the integrity of his departments crime-recording system will be visited on Friday by a longtime academic, author and criminologist: Prof. Franklin E. Zimring of the University of California, Berkeley.

title: Last Tango in Paris Star Maria Schneider Dies
description: Maria Schneider, the French actress whose sex scenes with Marlon Brando in Last Tango in Paris set a new standard for explicitness onscreen, died on Thursday in Paris. She was 58.

title: Charlie Peprah's Mother Reflects
description: Excerpts from an interview with Charlie Peprah's mother. Peprah's grandfather, General I.K. Acheampong, was the head of state in Ghana before he was executed. Peprah's mother, Elizabeth, talks about her father's legacy in relation to her son.

title: Let It Roll | Santa Fes Art A Go-Go
description: Its the logical extension of the food truck: Axle Contemporary, the newest addition to Santa Fes robust art scene, is rolling out culture to the masses. Were blending the high and the low, the exclusive and the democratic, and taking those boundaries and crossing them, says Axles co-founder Matthew Chase-Daniel of the old Hostess delivery truck  refashioned with track lighting, plastered walls and skylights  that serves as his gallery.

title: At Martian North Pole, Dunes That Shift and Slide
description: The dark basalt sand dunes around the edge of Mars North Pole are approximately the size of Texas and stand more than 100 feet high.

title: What Can We Learn From Job Numbers
description: It sometimes seems like every era has a crucial economic statistic, the one that everyone thinks will be very important when it comes out.

title: Spare Times for Feb. 4-10
description: Around Town

title: Pictures of the Day: Egypt and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Egypt, Australia, and Turkey.

title: Cuomo Predicts and Welcomes Lobbyists Enmity
description: ALBANY  Gov. Andrew M. Cuomos war on lobbyists has begun.

title: TimesCast | February 3, 2011
description: The view from inside Tahrir Square; increased attacks on foreign observers; and a look at the Muslim Brotherhood.

title: Pictures of the Day: Egypt and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Egypt, Australia and Turkey.

title: The Dude Extends: Gustavo Dudamel and the L.A. Philharmonic Sign a New Pact
description: In only his second season as music director of the Los Angeles Philharmonic, Gustavo Dudamel is signing on for a five-year contract extension, the orchestra said on Thursday. The Venezuelan-born Mr. Dudamel, who turned 30 last month, now will be at the orchestras helm through the Philharmonics 2018-2019 season.

title: Spare Times: For Children, for Feb. 4-10
description: BAMKIDS FILM FESTIVAL

title: Merkel, in Reversal, Urges Rescue of Euro
description: BRUSSELS  For a year, as Europe struggled with its debt crisis, Germanys chancellor, Angela Merkel, lived up to her nickname of Frau Nein, or Mrs. No, by stalling on each rescue effort.

title: Suiting Up Again for U.S.
description: For eight days, some United States military veterans who were injured in Iraq participated in the Parapan American Games.

title: Yahoo Outsources Real Estate Listings
description: Outsourcing areas that fall outside Yahoos strengths is central to its turnaround effort under Carol A. Bartz, Yahoos chief executive.

title: Barney Frank to Seek Re-election in 2012
description: Representative Barney Frank of Massachusetts announced Thursday that he would seek re-election in 2012, ending speculation about whether he would time his retirement with the states loss of a Congressional seat to redistricting.

title: Dance Listings for Feb. 4-10
description: Dance

title: All Bark, No Bite: Settlement Reached in Balloon Dog Dispute
description: Clowns everywhere can breathe easier: Jeff Koonss lawyers have backed down in an intellectual property dispute over balloon dog-shaped bookends. In December, Peter D. Vogl of the firm Jones Day, which represents Jeff Koons LLC, sent a cease-and-desist letter to Imm-Living, the Toronto company that manufactures the bookends, and Park Life, a San Francisco gallery that sells them, arguing that they violated Mr. Koonss intellectual property rights. Mr. Koons is well-known for his stainless-steel versions of the canines.

title: Pop and Rock Listings for Feb. 4-10
description: Pop

title: Letters: Speed and Credibility
description: Here is some reader response via e-mail to my most recent column from last Sunday, Speed and Credibility.

title: More on Finding Cheap Gas
description: In a recent App Smart column, Looking for Cheaper Gasoline, Without the Drive, Bob Tedeschi runs through the various mobile apps that can help you find cheaper gas without planning ahead before leaving the house.

title: Classical Music/Opera Listings for Feb. 4-10
description: Classical

title: A Quest for Life and Sex. And Doritos. And Sex.
description: The first hint that American Sexy is not the modest slice-of-life drama that it appears is its title. Starting with American usually means you intend to make a sweeping cultural statement (American Idiot, American Pastoral, American Psycho), probably about an era or, even more dangerously, a generation.

title: The Princess Wears Plaid
description: Peggy Orenstein has parents everywhere seeing pink. Her new book Cinderella Ate My Daughter: Dispatches From the Front Lines of the New Girlie-Girl Culture is a nuanced look at whether or not the transformation of little girls into sparkly princess worshipers is just a normal stage, or the result of a deliberate assault by marketers.

title: Oyster Reefs Are Vanishing From Overharvesting
description: Roughly 85 percent of the worlds oyster reefs have disappeared since the late 19th century, with many formerly prolific reefs rendered functionally extinct because of overharvesting and other manufactured causes, according to a new study published in BioScience [pdf].

title: Bernanke, a Redskins Fan, Will Still Watch
description: WASHINGTON  Ben S. Bernanke, the Federal Reserve chairman who has faced political pressure over his unorthodox efforts to stimulate the economic recovery, is avoiding picking sides in Super Bowl XLV. But he does have a prediction about the games economic impact.

title: Movie Listings for Feb. 4-10
description: Movies

title: Keeping Score: Which Stats Can Predict a Super Bowl Winner?
description: Carlton J. Chin, a fund manager, and Jay P. Granat, psychotherapist, are authors of Who Will Win the Big Game? A Psychological & Mathematical Method. They have previously written about the World Series, N.B.A. Finals and the N.C.A.A. mens basketball tournament.

title: $32 Billion in Budget Cuts Proposed
description: WASHINGTON  After clamoring loudly about their plans to curtail federal spending, House Republicans announced Thursday that they would cut $32 billion for the remainder of the fiscal year  a minuscule amount compared with a projected annual deficit of nearly $1.5 trillion.

title: Jazz Listings for Feb. 4-10
description: Jazz

title: Theater Listings: Feb. 4  10
description: Theater

title: Mahler Said What to Whom?
description: AT the height of the civil rights movement, two black musicians, a double bassist and a cellist, accused the New York Philharmonic of racial discrimination. It was July 1969, and soon the case, which had been brought before the New York City Commission on Human Rights, was making headlines. The National Urban League called on the orchestra to put affirmative action in place.

title: Museum and Gallery Listings for Feb. 4-10
description: Art

title: Prices So Low, the Shopping Gets Frenzied
description: LOT-LESS CLOSEOUTS is not Less Less. There are reminders posted throughout the store, in TriBeCa, making clear that Lot-Less is not associated with other establishments with Less in their names. This recently became necessary after a Less Less store opened a few doors away. Some people who bought items from Less Less tried to return them to Lot-Less. That did not work out well.

title: The Salads From Me
description: A good friends husband invited eight of her friends to a surprise birthday dinner at an expensive restaurant. He asked for a contribution of $100 a person before the dinner. But he never told his wife that the dinner was paid for by us. I expected him to thank us for pitching in, but he never did. Didnt he take credit for something we paid for?  Anonymous

title: Tomlin Is O.K. With Roethlisbergers Night Out
description: Those who smelled a juicy opportunity Thursday after TMZ reported that Ben Roethlisberger spent Tuesday night wracking up a $1,000 tab at a Fort Worth bar were sent looking for another controversy.

title: As in Life, Timing Is Everything in the Movies
description: Christian Marclay, the wizardly visual artist, composer and appropriator has done it again, and then some. The Clock, his latest excursion into extreme editing and radical sampling, is a 24-hour timepiece that ticks off the minutes  and sometimes the seconds  of a full day, using thousands of brilliantly spliced-together film clips from all kinds of movies. All of them feature clocks or watches or people announcing the time, or more obliquely conjure up the passage of time.

title: A Reading List for the Egypt Crisis
description: It took only a few days for Egyptian protesters to bring the regime of Hosni Mubarak to near collapse. But it took decades for the conditions for revolt to ripen. A range of widely noted books offer clues to the countrys accumulated discontents and thwarted desires. Max Rodenbecks Cairo: The City Victorious is a cultural and social history of the Arab worlds largest city, written by the Economists Middle East Correspondent. Mary Anne Weavers A Portrait of Egypt examines Egyptian society in the 1990s, with an emphasis on Islamist opponents of the Mubarak regime.

title: Performance Art for an Audience of One
description: During the last year the Museum of Modern Art has reinvented itself as a Museum of Performance Art. That change has been most pronounced in the temporary exhibition spaces, on the sixth floor and, especially, in the atrium. Now its creeping into the permanent collection, with Staging Action: Performance in Photography Since 1960, an exhibition of some 50 works drawn from the photography department, nearly half of them acquired over the last five years.

title: As Revenue Rises, Herms To Pay Extra Dividend
description: PARIS  Herms International, the French luxury retailer fighting to ward off the attentions of Bernard Arnault, the chief executive of the rival luxury retailer LVMH Mot Hennessy Louis Vuitton, said on Thursday that it would pay an interim dividend for the first time after posting a sharp increase in annual revenue.

title: A 375-Mile Battery Range: Too Good to be True?
description: Intrigues are not difficult to find in the world of electric vehicles. Whether its the saga of General Motors EV1 or Renaults executive-sabotage case, E.V.s generate intense controversy. The latest involves a battery pack employing what is called Kolibri alpha-polymer technology.

title: Viacom Profit and Revenue Decline as DVD Sales Drop
description: Viacom, the big media company whose MTV show Skins has been in the spotlight for its racy portrayal of teenage sexuality, reported lower earnings and revenue Thursday. Gains in advertising failed to offset a sharp drop in DVD sales at its film studio, Paramount Pictures.

title: Finding Cheaper Gas
description: From our colleagues at Bucks:

title: A Bit of Moscow on the Hudson?
description: Q. Who designed the 1930s District Health Center, at Ninth Avenue and 28th Street? Its the fenestration that I have most liked, with its interplay of single and affiliated units. Its an undersung work, and to me it curiously echoes an early Soviet modernist building in Moscow, Nikolai Ladovsky and Sergei Chernishevs Lenin Institute (now State Socio-Political Library) of 1925-27. ... Joseph Masheck, Manhattan

title: Online Mortgage Shopping Made Easier
description: CONSUMERS who have practically made a national sport out of hunting down the best price for everything from lipstick to laptops online often fail to comparison-shop for mortgages, finding the Web sites unhelpful or difficult to navigate.

title: JEPPE HEIN
description: 303 Gallery

title: ANNIE ATTRIDGE: Hearts of Oak
description: Asya Geisberg Gallery

title: ITALIAN PAINTINGS From the 17th and 18th Centuries
description: Sperone Westwater

title: BUTT JOHNSON: The Name of the Rose
description: CRG Gallery

title: In Asia, Hello to Faster Trades and Goodbye to Lunch Hour
description: HONG KONG  Nearly 25 years after the fictional financier Gordon Gekko declared in Wall Street that lunch is for wimps, Asias leading stock exchanges seem to have gotten the memo.

title: From Man to Robot to Whats That?
description: The Museum of Modern Art has been ground zero for zany crowd encounters these past few weeks as guards, audience members and artists navigated the impractical realities of midday, open-access dance programming in the bustling atrium.

title: Coverage from Cairo Brings Cooper Viewers
description: The intensifying crisis in Egypt continued to provide a boost to CNNs ratings Wednesday night, especially for its host Anderson Cooper, who has been on the scene in Cairo and in the middle of some the violence directed at Western journalists.

title: A New City Handbook Demystifies Zoning
description: SINCE becoming New York Citys planning commissioner in 2002, Amanda M. Burden has presided over the rezoning of wide swaths of the city.

title: Police Chief Is Shot Dead in Mexico
description: MEXICO CITY  Just over a month after he took charge of the police force in one of the countrys most violent cities, Manuel Farfn, a former brigadier general in the army, died Thursday in a torrent of bullets.

title: French Foreign Minister Urged to Resign
description: PARIS  Frances new foreign minister, Michle Alliot-Marie, is facing renewed calls for her resignation, and once again the problem is Tunisia.

title: American Idol Keeps Rolling
description: The new season of Foxs American Idol continued to prove resilient in the ratings, leading Wednesday night with 24.9 million viewers, according to Nielsens estimates, a slight improvement over the same night a year ago. The strong ratings for Idol in the 8 p.m. hour also provided a boost to Foxs Human Target at 9 (9.3 million), which earned its best ratings in over a year. For the night over all, Fox easily ranked No. 1 while CBS surprisingly placed second despite struggling at 8 with Live to Dance (4.8 million) and broadcasting a rerun of Criminal Minds at 9 (9.7 million). At 10, CBSs Blue Bloods (11.2 million) led the hour ahead of NBCs Law & Order: SVU (8.8 million) and ABCs Off the Map (5.3 million). NBC was third for the night, averaging 7.7 million viewers from 8 to 10 for a two-hour edition of Minute to Win It. ABC finished in fourth place with reruns for much of prime time before a new episode of Cougar Town at 9:30 (6.6 million).

title: Getting the Most Ballet (View) for Your Buck
description: Its sometimes said that we critics occupy our own reality. What planet are we from, what seats were we in (and were they perhaps facing backward)? The planet issue is, alas, a question for the ages. But seats, thats easy. Critics tend to be placed midway up the orchestra rows and  especially helpful for quick getaways  on the aisles. On big opening nights you can always spot the critics holding pen by the writing utensils and scraps of paper flying everywhere.

title: House Tour: Southport, Conn.
description: HOW MUCH $1.4 million. Taxes: $17,282.

title: Lost and Gone Forever
description: Species die. It has become a catastrophic fact of modern life. On our present course, by E.O. Wilsons estimate, half of all plant and animal species could be extinct by 2100  that is, within the lifetime of a child born today. Kenya stands to lose its lions within 20 years. India is finishing off its tigers. Deforestation everywhere means that thousands of species too small or obscure to be kept on life support in a zoo simply vanish each year.

title: Music as a Gallant Ballet Partner
description: Following performances of a New York City Ballet season is unlike any other kind of dance-going. The repertory changes nightly, new revivals keep arriving, and theres a wider supply of premieres and recent works than in any other ballet company. Theres also a wide range of distinguished music  the composers of the last three weeks have included Glinka, Chopin, Delibes, Tchaikovsky, Glazunov, Stravinsky, Prokofiev, Hindemith, Ellington, Shostakovich and Thomas Ads.

title: Riccardo Muti Collapses During Rehearsal
description: Riccardo Muti, the music director of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra, collapsed during a rehearsal on Thursday and struck his head in the fall, orchestra officials said.

title: Who Am I? Thursday Edition
description: All week, the Fifth Down blog will post Who Am I? quizzes to test your knowledge of Packers and Steelers of the past. Peeking at Pro Football Reference just ruins the fun for everyone, so dont do it!

title: Weekend Miser
description: This week the miser celebrates diversity, while remaining intolerant of high prices.

title: What If: On Uprisings, Oil Kingdoms and the Energy Gap
description: 7:16 p.m. | Updated  Gal Luft, an analyst of the intersection of energy and security policy, has posted a troubling portrait of what might unfold in the United Statesif the turmoil in Egypt spread to Saudi Arabia, along withthe limited options to respond, given deep dependence on petroleum. [Theres much, much more on the Saudi question.]

title: A Man of Contradictions, With a Collection to Match
description: When Chinas last emperor finally left the premises in 1924, the Forbidden City was renamed the Palace Museum, and a labyrinthine complex of ceremonial and domestic spaces, off limits to all but a few for centuries, was suddenly open to the world.

title: Neeskens to Coach Trinidad and Tobago
description: Johan Neeskens, the former Ajax Amsterdam, Barcelona, Dutch international and Cosmos midfielder, will become the next coach of the national team of Trinidad and Tobago, according to a news release on the teams Web site.

title: Elvis and Toreadors, Aglow on Black Velvet
description: Eric A. Eliason remembers peering out car windows as a child in Ohio in the 1970s, when his parents drove past Mexican street vendors selling black-velvet paintings. Mountainous landscapes and Elvis portraits gleamed on the fibers.

title: Prices So Low, the Shopping Gets Frenzied
description: Lot-Less Closeouts is not Less Less. There are reminders posted throughout the store, in TriBeCa, making clear that Lot-Less is not associated with other establishments with Less in their names. This recently became necessary after a Less Less store opened a few doors away. Some people who bought items from Less Less tried to return them to Lot-Less. That did not work out well.

title: What Can You Find in the New York Philharmonics Archives?
description: The New York Philharmonics digital archive, which went live on Thursday, contains a wealth of documents from 1943 to 1970, some of which are featured in this article. The information is vast, so we invite readers inclined to do some digging to share their discoveries here.

title: Rumsfelds Defense of Known Decisions
description: The title of former Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfelds new memoir, Known and Unknown, comes from a remark he made about whether Iraq had supplied or was willing to supply terrorists with weapons of mass destruction. Reports that say that something hasnt happened are always interesting to me, he quipped in 2002, because, as we know, there are known knowns; there are things we know we know. We also know there are known unknowns; that is to say we know there are some things we do not know. But there are also unknown unknowns  the ones we dont know we dont know.

title: Neighborhood Joint | Lot-Less Closeouts
description: Lunchtime is rush hour for bargain hunters at a Chambers Street closeout shop.

title: Between the Lines of Daily Living, Connecting the Dots That Matter
description: Low-key and lovely, the independent movie Cold Weather opens with a shot of raindrops clinging to a pane of glass, a fitting introduction for a movie about characters who are revealed gradually, as if through a glass  not darkly, but obliquely. With brooding, expressive digital photography, a rooted sense of place and characters that seem as real as the people next door, the director Aaron Katz has created a lived-in world thats so intimate and familiar that even with the storys unexpected turns, you might not initially see its art for its everydayness.

title: Cowen vs. Meyerson on Inequality
description: Harold Meyerson makes a useful critique of Tyler Cowens new book, The Great Stagnation. The book doesnt pay as much attention to inequality as it might have. The shift in income shares since the 1970s  from the middle and bottom to the top, as well as from the top to the very, very top  is a big reason incomes for the middle class and poor have grown so slowly.

title: Ally Financial Picks Four Underwriters for I.P.O.
description: Ally Financial, the lender once known as GMAC, has picked four banks to advise the company on a forthcoming initial public offering meant to sell off some of the Treasury Departments shares, people briefed on the matter told DealBook on Thursday.

title: Skiing Without the Lift Lines and Without the Long Drive
description: The seasons first snowstorm found most warmblooded humans at home, glued to their couches. Not so Gregg Smith and his girlfriend, Pamela Deitrich, who were struggling to stay upright one afternoon in late December on the cross-country ski trails of High Point State Park in Sussex, N.J.

title: Government Backs $1 Billion Plan to Make Gasoline from Wood
description: The Energy Department has offered a Texas company a loan guarantee for a $1 billion project to build four small factories that would turn wood chips into an oil substitute.

title: Ben Roethlisberger
description: The Steelers quarterback spoke to the media on Thursday.

title: Shooting 'Cold Weather'
description: Aaron Katz discusses shooting "Cold Weather" in his hometown of Portland, Ore.

title: J. Crew Buyout Shows BJs Directors What Not to Do
description: Corporate directors in America may be getting a J. Crew makeover of sorts. The anger J. Crew elicited from investors in handling its buyout is causing a stir at other companies in private equity buyers sights. It probably explains the decision by the academic-heavy board of BJs Wholesale Club to kick off an auction after six months of deer-in-the-headlights inaction. Its a good sign for shareholder rights.

title: Network Anchors Leave Egypt Amid Crackdown
description: Two of the most prominent television news anchors covering the protests in Egypt this week, Brian Williams and Katie Couric, have exited the country.

title: A Home Wrecker Faces Many Challenges, Too
description: The Other Woman is a not-bad movie (written and directed by Don Roos) based on a pretty good book (Love and Other Impossible Pursuits by Ayelet Waldman).

title: Up Front: Emma Donoghue
description: This week on our cover, Emma Donoghue reviews Swamplandia!, the first novel by Karen Russell, who has gained attention not only for her fiction, but also for her youth. (Russells debut story collection, St. Lucys Home for Girls Raised by Wolves, came out four years ago, when she was 25, and since then shes been on several Best Young Writer-type lists.)

title: Infested Waters
description: In 2006, Zoetrope published a story by a 24-year-old writer, Karen Russell. That story, Ava Wrestles the Alligator, featured a lusciously strange setting (an alligator theme park in the Everglades) and a tough young heroine with a dead mother and an absent father, as well as a weird problem: how to save her resented-yet-beloved older sister from eloping with a ghost. A few months later, Russells first story collection, St. Lucys Home for Girls Raised by Wolves, with Ava Wrestles the Alligator leading a crazy procession of nine other Florida swampland stories, won her wide acclaim, and last year she was chosen one of The New Yorkers 20 Under 40 top fiction writers.

title: The Emperors Private Paradise
description: Images from the new exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: Dominating the Man Cave
description: BRISTOL, Conn.

title: What Did Chase Know, and When Did It Know It?
description: The Madoff trustees lawsuit against JPMorgan Chase (a k a, at least in this suit, JPMC) reads like no other lawsuit I have read. It begins this way:

title: On the Trails
description: One advantage of snowapalooza: cross-country skiing two hours from the city.

title: Sara D. Roosevelt Park, 1:19 P.M.
description: Celebrating the Chinese New Year in Manhattan.

title: Four Celtics to Be All-Star Reserves
description: The Boston Celtics will have a league-high four players in the All-Star Game, with Kevin Garnett, Paul Pierce, Ray Allen and Rajon Rondo joining the team as reserves, according to a team executive who was made aware of the teams. The official announcement was to be televised Thursday evening on TNT.

title: A Return to Southie, by Way of Broadway
description: BOSTON

title: Just the Guys, Candid and Rugged
description: DONE for the day, the five actors in the new Broadway revival of That Championship Season kicked back in a Chelsea rehearsal room recently and shared wine and beer as they talked about their all-male ensemble, career choices, and the legacy of The Lost Boys and 24.

title: Its Game Day, Even Backstage
description: WITH Lombardi, a surprise hit, and the new revival of That Championship Season, sports has an unusually prominent place on the Broadway stage this Super Bowl week. Its an odd twist since people often presume that sports and theater exist in mutually exclusive universes. Not so, many actors, playwrights and directors insist. Sports fans are not as pervasive in terms of quantity in the theater world, said Thomas Sadoski, a co-star of Other Desert Cities, now at the Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater. But we make up for that with the depth of our fanaticism.

title: In a Shift, Cubans Savor Working for Themselves
description: BAUTA, Cuba  Marisela lvarez spends much of the day bent over a single electric burner in her small outdoor kitchen. Her knees are killing her. Her red hair smells of cooking oil.

title: Beckman Coulter Receives Bids From Buyout Groups
description: Beckman Coulter, a maker of diagnostic research equipment for biomedical companies, has received second-round takeover offers from a number of suitors, including two private equity groups, people briefed on the matter told DealBook on Thursday.

title: Plunging Into the Deep, Hoping for a Way Out
description: Why? someone demands after another disaster in the 3-D grotty grotto adventure Sanctum. Why caves? Wait a minute, I think that might have been me, though given one of the executive producers of this souped-up B movie, the question should have been: Why, James Cameron, why?

title: A Closer Look at the Unrest in Cairo
description: Zoom in on the images below and examine up close the events happening between pro- and antigovernment forces in Cairo.

title: Undying Love in the Time of Arrested Development
description: Is he a holy naf radiating good vibes or a delusional psychotic in dire need of treatment? Will Donner (Tom Sturridge), the homeless street performer who lopes through James Keachs terminally warm and fuzzy Waiting for Forever, may be either or both. For Mr. Keach, who directed this latter-day hippie fairy tale from a screenplay by Steve Adams, Wills clinging to a dream of endless childhood is a sign of otherworldly purity; he is not crazy, just too good to live comfortably in the grubby, grown-up world.

title: Inventing a New Life, Yet Again
description: When she first came to this country and this city in June 2007, Nour al-Khal wore a head scarf, as was proper for a woman from Basra, a Shiite-dominated city in southern Iraq. She continued to wear it for more than a year. Then, on an August day in 2008, the scarf came off.

title: Delaware Diocese Settles With Victims of Abuse
description: The Roman Catholic Diocese of Wilmington, Del., agreed late Wednesday to settle for $77 million with 146 victims of sexual abuse by clergy members and to release internal church documents about how the church hierarchy handled the allegations of abuse.

title: How Hef Got His Groove Back
description: Hugh Hefner already has his final resting place picked out and paid for: a crypt next to Marilyn Monroes in the Westwood neighborhood of Los Angeles. Not that he has plans to use it anytime soon. Hefner, who will turn 85 in April, lives these days what appears to be the life of an invalid, or even of a cosseted mental patient: wearing pajamas all day; rarely venturing out of the house; taking most of his meals in his bedroom  the menu seldom varying, the crackers and potato chips carefully prescreened to remove any broken ones. He is hard of hearing in his right ear and has an arthritic back that causes him to lumber a little when he walks. But he is in otherwise enviable shape for an octogenarian.

title: Food Prices Worldwide Hit Record Levels, Fueled by Uncertainty, U.N. Says
description: UNITED NATIONS  Global food prices are moving ever higher, hitting record levels last month as a jittery market reacted to unpredictable weather and tight supplies, according to a United Nations report released Thursday.

title: Iraq: Bombs in Anbar Kill 10, Mostly Police Officers
description: A series of explosions near the government headquarters in Ramadi, the capital of Anbar Province, killed 10 people, including seven police officers, on Thursday, local officials said. An additional 20 officers were wounded. Insurgents have carried out several attacks against the police and outposts of the central government in Ramadi in recent months, usually in response to the mass arrests of terrorism suspects.

title: Best of Pettitte? Game 5 in 96 Got Ball Rolling
description: Andy Pettitte was 240-138 in his major league career with 19 postseason victories, but one game still stands out. At age 24 in 1996, in his second season and second World Series game, Pettitte allowed five hits in eight and a third innings in an electrifying 1-0 victory over the Atlanta Braves in Game 5. The Yankees had lost the first two games at home, 12-1 and 4-0, then won two in Atlanta. Pettittes gem put them one victory away from their first World Series title since 1978.

title: Exploitation 101
description: AMERICAN GRINDHOUSE

title: White House and Egypt Discuss Plan for Mubaraks Exit
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration is discussing with Egyptian officials a proposal for President Hosni Mubarak to resign immediately and turn over power to a transitional government headed by Vice President Omar Suleiman with the support of the Egyptian military, administration officials and Arab diplomats said Thursday.

title: Bit by Bit, a Citys Attention Returns to Mundane Matters
description: TUCSON  The talk around town this week has been about the weather.

title: Virginia: Second Planned Parenthood Tape Surfaces
description: The anti-abortion group Live Action on Thursday released a second videotape in which a Planned Parenthood staff member in Richmond is heard telling a man claiming to run a sex ring how to get abortions for under-age prostitutes. The agency said the video was misleading. It said the staff member reacted professionally to a highly unusual person posing as a patient, and immediately notified her supervisor. The agency then notified the Justice Department. The release follows one on Wednesday, in which a clinic manager in New Jersey suggested that young prostitutes conceal their ages. In that case, Planned Parenthood said the manager had erred and fired her.

title: An Exit Plan for Mubarak
description: Cambridge, Mass.

title: Our Planets Destruction in Yummy Colors
description: A wake-up call delivered with bedtime-story unctuousness, Home paints the destruction of our planet in the yummiest colors imaginable. Taking the Gods-eye view, the French photographer Yann Arthus-Bertrand flies over 54 countries, centuries of human endeavor and multiple academic disciplines to deliver a finger-wagging indictment of our imperfect stewardship.

title: Letters: Obamas Jobs Search
description: As the White House looks to create jobs, our state, county and local governments are laying off employees and cutting back on services. Every layoff has a ripple effect, creating more unemployment.One approach the federal government should take to address our unemployment problem is to fix our infrastructure. Century-old water mains are breaking, underground drainage pipes are collapsing all overthe nation and many of our bridges are structurally unsafe. Local, county and state governmentsare not allocating adequate resources to correct this national problem. If the president and Congress would set aside significant dollars to our infrastructure, the ripple impact of a national infrastructure-maintenance program would be enormous on job creation.

title: Letter: Turkeys Rules
description: The occasional tensions in the foreign policies of the United States and Turkey are a normal staple of international relations. James Traubs article, though, betrays the arrogance and presumed omniscience of an American empire, which expects every nation to be its apostle, i.e., all nations are equal, but some are more equal than others. That approach neither reflects todays realities, nor would it serve our nations interests. The United States, more so than ever, needs countries like Turkey that are willing to pay their fair share and take initiative and responsibility to create a more stable and peaceful world. Turkey today has the resources as well as the will to be such a partner for the United States. Rather than making light of or dismissing Turkeys well-meaning initiatives to solve conflicts in its neighborhood, our leaders would be well advised to listen more often and more closely to the sage advice of this country. It is this kind of experienced guidance from a friend and an ally, which has existed in that part of the world for a thousand years and ruled it for most of that time, that may well save American blood and treasure in the years ahead.

title: Bonfire of American Vanities
description: Breathtaking, these last few days in Egypt. What started with a scent of jasmine, the worlds biggest Arab country trying to chase out a dictator, is now devolving into violent chaos and police-state terror. Smiling families one day, thugs on camelback the next.

title: Letters: The Way We Live Now
description: Rebecca Traisters thesis in Cowgirl Country lacksthe critical consideration that our political scene needs. Except for personal experience with guns, Gabrielle Giffords and Sarah Palin share few specific, substantive biographical details or political ideas. The cowgirl identity cant explain the political impact of Margaret Chase Smith, Shirley Chisholm, Bella Abzug or Elizabeth Holtzman. To reduce the force of women during the American Revolution and the early republic to a querulous Abigail Adams does a disservice to a long list of American women and slanders one of our great American voices. To seek cowgirls means you wont find women like Susan B. Anthony, Jane Addams or Margaret Sanger. To reduce Hillary Rodham Clintons political appeal to one metaphor ignores the strength of her following.

title: Before Sunday, a Taste of the Bowl
description: For decades, most Super Bowl advertisers followed a simple rule: Keep commercials under wraps until the moment they go on the air.

title: Somalia: Parliament Extends Term for 3 Years
description: The transitional Parliament extended its term on Thursday for three more years. The official mandate of the Transitional Federal Government expires in August. Radical Islamists control most of the country and were it not for the African Union peacekeeping mission, known as Amisom, the government would probably fall within hours.

title: Even More Things in Heaven and Earth
description: Ann Arbor, Mich.

title: A Passion for Fashion
description: In Dressed, David Swajeskis listless profile of the young clothing designer Nary Manivong, a passion for fashion elbows aside every other emotion. Yet even those viewers who share the films conviction that preparing a collection for New York Fashion Week is inherently fascinating may lose interest long before the final frock is fitted.

title: New Jerseys Ethnic Makeup Shifts, and Population Drifts Southward
description: In the last decade, the number of white people in New Jersey declined as the number of Asians and Hispanics soared, and the population shifted southward  some of the many shifts with broad cultural and political implications that were revealed in 2010 census figures released on Thursday.

title: Madoff Victim Says Mets Owners Ignored Signs
description: It is one of the enduring puzzles of the Madoff scandal: how so many sophisticated, even brilliant, investors were duped for so long.

title: Authorities Faulted in Fort Hood Attack
description: WASHINGTON  Various federal intelligence and law enforcement agencies missed an opportunity to prevent the 2009 shootings at Fort Hood that left 13 people dead and dozens injured, even though they had information that the man charged in the attack, Maj. Nidal Malik Hasan, had communicated with a terrorism suspect and harbored extreme political proclivities, according to a new report.

title: Italy: Pair of Victories for Berlusconi
description: Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi survived a pair of political tests on Thursday. First, Parliament denied a request by prosecutors to search his offices as part of an investigation into whether he paid a number of young women for sex. He also weathered a crisis in his coalition when his cabinet approved a measure giving cities a larger role in taxation. The Northern League, the leading party in the coalition, had said it would call for early elections if the measure failed.

title: Maria Schneider, Actress in Last Tango, Dies at 58
description: Maria Schneider, the French actress whose sex scenes with Marlon Brando in Last Tango in Paris set a new standard for explicitness on screen, died on Thursday in Paris. She was 58.

title: Korematsu Day
description: On Sunday, California held its first Fred Korematsu Day. You may never have heard of him. But his unwavering personal courage is matched only by the importance of his role in constitutional law.

title: Uganda: Police Say Killing Is Unrelated to Gay Rights
description: A suspect who confessed to the killing of David Kato, a prominent gay-rights activist, said it was unrelated to Mr. Katos activism, the police said Thursday. The suspect, Enock Nsubuga, 22, said Mr. Kato had reneged on a promise to pay Mr. Nsubuga for sex, officials said. Mr. Kato, left, had received numerous death threats because of his work. Parliament is considering a bill that would call for gays to be executed under certain circumstances, and a newspaper had published photos of Mr. Kato and other activists on the front page under the headline Hang Them. Mr. Kato was beaten to death in his home last week.

title: Cheap Buses May Face Restrictions on Locations
description: Stricter regulation could be on the way for discount bus companies that operate on New York City streets, under a bill to be introduced on Friday in Albany that aims to put an end to complaints that the buses clog sidewalks and block thoroughfares in Chinatown and Midtown.

title: Health Care, Again in the Spotlight
description: To the Editor:

title: Governors Get Advice for Saving on Medicaid
description: WASHINGTON  Fearing wholesale cuts in Medicaid by states with severe budget problems, the Obama administration told governors on Thursday how they could save money by selectively and judiciously reducing benefits, curbing overuse of costly prescription drugs and attacking fraud.

Midway through a ghastly loss, with the Packers playoff hopes in the balance, the veteran receiver Donald Driver decided that Rodgers, his star quarterback, needed some encouragement.

description: To the Editor:

title: In a Town Called Asbestos, a Plan to Restart the Industry That Made It Prosperous
description: ASBESTOS, Quebec  The belief in asbestos lives on in this mining town of 7,000 people, not just in the name  retained despite its association with cancer  but in the ambitions of the minerals long-time champion here, G. Bernard Coulombe.

title: A Jewish Group Makes Waves, Locally and Abroad
description: Hundreds of people, mostly Arab-Americans, are expected to gather Saturday in downtown San Francisco to support anti-government protests in Egypt, and a large contingent of Jews representing a Bay Area peace-advocacy group will join them, one of its leaders says.

title: The Black Eyed Peas Sing Footballs Praises
description: DALLAS  At last years Super Bowl, there were questions if the featured act at the halftime show, The Who, had ever seen an American football game. Roger Daltrey and Pete Townshend, after all, are British and big soccer fans.

description: NEW ORLEANS  When Hurricane Katrina hit and the murky waters rushed through levee breaches, even the facts were drowned.

title: Earnings Soar at Dow
description: The Dow Chemical Company posted fourth-quarter earnings on Thursday that rose more than analysts estimated, helped by its caustic soda and plastics products.

title: A Push to Open Hearings in Judge-Misconduct Cases
description: As it has done periodically for years, the New York State Legislature will consider a proposal this year to open secret judicial-discipline hearings to the public. Some supporters of the measure predict that it will get more attention this time than it has in decades.

title: In the Glee Era, Youth Choruses Pop Up All Over
description: Running a youth chorus is a daunting task. The repertory has to suit young singers, and the experience has to keep tweeting, texting children entertained. Then theres the tricky issue regarding boys: what to do when their voices break.

title: Charging Fees to See Trees at Golden Gate Parks Arboretum Doesnt Even Pay the Bills
description: Charging a fee to see the trees at the botanical garden in Golden Gate Park was not a popular idea when it was proposed last summer, but Phil Ginsburg, general manager of the citys Recreation and Parks Department, desperate to close a budget gap, pushed ahead anyway.

description: Sarah Posner, left, of Religion Dispatches and Haroon Moghul of the Maydan Institute discuss Egypt and anti-Muslim sentiment in America.

description: CAIRO  Members of the Muslim Brotherhood helped run a clinic to treat injured protesters. Construction workers from southern Egypt smashed rocks for the defense of Tahrir Square.

title: After 16 Seasons, Goodbye to a Gamer
description: Free agency is supposed to be the ultimate perk for a player, the chance to choose where to make your next fortune. Andy Pettitte hated it. He never wanted to let people down.

title: Egypts Agonies
description: President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt could have done many things after he announced he would not run for office again. He could have resigned and let his vice president lead an interim government, as the Obama administration reportedly is urging him to do. He could have opened serious negotiations with antigovernment protesters leading to free and fair elections.

title: Lottery Numbers
Protesting School Closings, in a Noisy Annual Ritual
description: The seven-foot, blue-eyed beaver mascot in a red Jamaica High School sweatshirt bobbed his head above teachers and parents chanting, Whose schools? Our schools!

title: Caught in the Gray Area of a Child-Abuser Database
description: Dear future son, the North Texas father wrote last year in a prospective adoption letter filled with promises of family bike rides and road trips. I am a single dad who adopted a middle school boy in 2008. Now we are looking for one more kid so he will have a brother.

title: Now Ireland
description: Irelands government becomes the first, but likely not the last, to be brought down by the shocks battering the euro. Parliament was dissolved this week, and elections are scheduled for later this month. Fianna Fail, the party that has ruled Ireland for most of its independent history, may be headed for an epochal defeat.

title: To Walsh, Attention Is Puzzling
description: When the frenzy escalates and the reporters descend en masse, Donnie Walsh turns satirical. The Congressional inquiry, he says wryly.

title: Affordable Housing and the Gulf
description: The gulf states are still living with the destruction wrought by Hurricanes Katrina and Rita, which swept away more than 70,000 units of affordable rental housing.

title: Friday: Heavenly Radio Source
description: FRIDAYS PUZZLE  The fresh and crunchy wars rage on, as Ashton Anderson presents us with a puzzle containing 10 10-letter entries. Some of them are appearing for the first time today, and some of them have appeared only a few times. Dont believe me? HIT THE ROAD. Just kidding. Insert your favorite term of ENDEARMENT here.

title: Fire Department to Replace New Gloves After Six Suffer Hand Burns
description: The New York City Fire Department has determined that its new fire-retardant gloves have a critical flaw: they do not adequately protect firefighters from burns.

title: Population Decline in New Orleans
description: Maps showing population changes in New Orleans.

title: Russian Ennui, American Idiom
description: It takes a long time to take a picture in the Russian provinces of the late 19th century, when cameras are novelties and exposures are slow. So when the characters of the Classic Stage Companys wonderfully fresh and affecting production of Chekhovs Three Sisters gather for a group portrait, they hold their poses for what feels like an unblinking eternity.

title: Impending Trial Puts a Melting-Pot Neighborhood to the Test
description: Devon Avenue is one of Chicagos richest melting pots, where Indian stores sell colorful saris next to Pakistani halal butcher shops and Islamic bookstores. Farther west are Orthodox synagogues, Jewish bakeries and Russian gift shops. So residents were shocked when two local men were arrested in 2009 on accusations that they had helped plot the November 2008 terrorist attack in Mumbai, India, and a never-realized assault on a Danish newspaper that had published cartoons of the Prophet Muhammad.

title: The Mayoral Campaign Stoops to Political Theater
description: James Warren is a columnist for the Chicago News Cooperative.

title: Retirement Further Erodes a Homegrown Core
description: On May 27, 1995, in Oakland, Calif., after five appearances in relief, Andy Pettitte made his first start for the Yankees. The next day, after a game started by the rookie Mariano Rivera  and in which Bernie Williams homered  the Yankees decided to summon their 20-year-old shortstop, a prodigy named Derek Jeter. That group of homegrown stars, which by seasons end included Jorge Posada, provided a certain validity over the years to a team viewed as a collection of free-agent mercenaries. Together, the five played in six World Series, winning four.

title: Puck Strikes Post as Devils Continue Hitting Stride
description: It was like the late 90s again at Madison Square Garden on Thursday night.

title: In Campaign, Sideshows Take Over
description: The mayoral campaign provided drama again this week with the Jerry Springer Show-like scene of Carol Moseley Brauns launching into an animated tirade directed at Patricia Van Pelt Watkins  a long-shot candidate and, until that moment, low-profile rival in the Feb. 22 election.

title: Union Leader Addresses Differences With League
description: DALLAS  Two days before he was scheduled to meet with the N.F.L. owners to discuss a new collective bargaining agreement, DeMaurice Smith, the executive director of the N.F.L. Players Association, said that his union had fundamental disagreements with the league and that a proposal that players should make $1 billion in concessions made no sense while revenues were at record highs.

title: New Jersey's Changing Population
description: Total population of New Jersey declined in some urban cores, but not in Newark, and grew in places like Lakewood, Franklin and Hoboken.

description: Two miles from the site of Super Bowl XLV, inside the University of Texas at Arlingtons new 234,000-square-foot multi-disciplinary research building, Mario I. Romero-Ortega, an associate professor of bioengineering, investigates how robotic arms could be more reliable and lifelike for amputees returning from war.

title: Tallying the Cost of a Wicked Storm
description: The vast winter storm that left its icy mark on much of the nation has finally moved offshore. But before many people could even shovel out their cars, a cold snap moved in. The snowy, icy roads may have played a role in a deadly accident near Miami, Okla., where three people died after their pickup truck went off a highway bridge into the Spring River, more than 50 feet below. Several other passengers were rescued from the frigid water. Farther south, another storm threatened to bring more snow, sleet and ice to places that dont usually see much, from Houston, which canceled school on Friday, through Louisiana and Mississippi. But before the evidence melts, here is a look back.

title: Charles Sellier Jr., Creator of Grizzly Adams, Dies at 67

Henriques reports in The New York Times.
