description: The AXA Rosenberg Group, a pioneer in the field of quantitative investing, and two affiliated companies agreed to pay more than $240 million to settle charges that they misled customers after discovering an error in the computer code the companies used to manage client assets, Edward Wyatt reports in The New York Times.

title: Parliament Picks Insider as President of Myanmar
description: BANGKOK  A former prime minister and longtime adjutant to Myanmars military dictator was elected president on Friday by the countrys newly inaugurated Parliament, a move that cements the militarys control of a new political system.

title: 1,235 and Counting
description: WHO is the team leader of NASAs Kepler project?

title: American Idol': God, Complex
description: Total scandal on American Idol Thursday night: GB5 is breaking up! Aaron and Mark, two of the five Gutierrez brothers that make up the group, got it in their heads that chasing the Idol dream was compelling enough to break off from the family flock. Oh, the horror.

title: Ed Sabol for the Hall of Fame
description: Ed Sabol is one of the modern-era finalists who will be considered by the selection committee for election into the Hall of Fame on Saturday. Andy Barall writes about pro football history for The Fifth Down.

title: Do You Unknowingly Submit to Peer Pressure?
description: New research shows why teenagers often make bad decisions when their friends are with them or watching them. Are you aware of being influenced by peer pressure? Do you take greater risks  like driving faster and less carefully  when you are with your friends?

title: A Race Between Digital and Print Magazines
description: This morning I decide to try a little experiment:I opened up my iPad, clicked on the little Wired icon and purchased the magazines latest digital issue. After I agreed to fork over $4, it began downloading. For the next phase of the experiment, I grabbed my car keys, left my apartment and drove about 12 blocks to a local magazine store in Brooklyn, where I also purchased the latest issue of Wired magazine, this time in print.

title: Bloomberg Slightly More Popular, Survey Shows
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs job rating took a major hit in the aftermath of the post-Christmas blizzard, but he is starting to recover, according to a new poll released Thursday night.

title: A Year at War: Updates on Soldiers
description: Today on A Year at War, our series about a battalions yearlong deployment to Afghanistan, we have updates on three more soldiers. All are noncommissioned officers  men who came into the Army as privates without a college degree and worked their way up to leadership roles. They have all been deployed previously, to Iraq or Afghanistan or both. They all figured they knew more or less what to expect this time.

title: Before Its Transformation, Tours of Londons BBC Broadcasting House
description: A London institution is getting a makeover. Since 1932 the crossroads of Oxford and Regent Streets has been home to the headquarters for the BBC in a 12-story building known as Broadcasting House. From here, countless historical moments have gone out over the airwaves and been heard around the world, from performances by Vivian Leigh to the worlds longest running soap opera, The Archers. But although the building will soon go through a transformation, visitors can still take a tour of the historic spot.

title: The Early Word: An Orderly Proposal
description: From Todays Times:

title: Critical Day for Protests
description: Stephen Farrell reports on expectations for today's protests in Cairo.

title: Europeans Struggle for Consistency on Egypt
description: BRUSSELS  European leaders condemned the violence in Egypt on Friday but struggled to find a consistent message.

title: Restructuring Medicare and the Rivlin-Ryan Plan
description: Uwe E. Reinhardt is an economics professor at Princeton. He has some financial interests in the health care field.

title: Restructuring Medicare and the Rivlin-Ryan Plan
description: Uwe E. Reinhardt is an economics professor at Princeton. He has some financial interests in the health care field.

title: Taking the Bait: Chicken to Go?
description: Dear Readers,

title: If Worst Comes to Worst
description: Amanda Williams e-mails: When describing whats going to happen when were on the brink of dire circumstances, why do we write if worst comes to worst? Wouldnt it make more sense to write if worse comes to worst, as in, things are bad and they might get worse?

title: Santander Plans to Take British Unit Public
description: Emilio Botn, chairman of Banco Santander, said that he planned to list the lenders British unit in the second half of the year, as he announced the banks results on Thursday.

title: Complaint Box | Standing in the Stands
description: Can you imagine attending a big-time sporting event at a large stadium and actually being able to see the game from the comfort of that expensive seat you bought?

title: ParkWhiz: Super Bowl Parking for a Digital Age
description: The Dallas metro areas public-transportation infrastructure would never be mistaken for Copenhagens. Consequently, ticketholders for this Sundays Super Bowl XLV will arrive at Cowboys Stadium in Arlington, Tex., almost exclusively by car. With 100,000 game tickets sold, the City of Arlington has partnered with ParkWhiz.com, an online parking-reservation service, to not only secure nontraditional parking spaces to handle the remarkable volume, but to guarantee drivers a space on game day.

title: Oil Spill, Redux: Revisiting a Mystery
description: I attended a symposium last week at the University of Georgia on the Deepwater Horizon oil spill, with panelists (I was one) revisiting many of the issues that came up during that disaster last summer. As I chatted him up, one of the scientists in attendance, Ian MacDonald, pointed me toward a recent article of his that tries again to get at one of the central mysteries of the spill.

title: Updates on Day 11 of Egypt Protests
description: On Friday, The Lede continues to provide updates on the street protests in Egypt. For a summary of the latest developments, read the current version of our main news article from our colleagues in Cairo. Updates below mix alerts on breaking news with reports from bloggers and journalists posted on other news sites and social networks. A stream of Twitter updates on the protests is in this blogs right column. Readers can share information in the comment thread below or send photographs or video from Egypt to pix@nyt.com.

title: Tip of the Week: Behind the Pin Tab Feature of Googles Chrome Browser
description: The Pin Tab feature of the Google Chrome browser neatly reduces page tabs down to just the sites icon  which can make it easier to switch between screens full of open sites. To shrink a tab down to its icon, right-click on it and choose Pin Tab. While this makes room for plenty of open tabs, it also hides the number of unread messages that is normally displayed on the full tab of an open Gmail page.

title: Morning Buzz | Fire Dept. to Replace Flawed Gloves
description: Good morning. Alternate-side parking rules are suspended for the 15th straight day. Now it is cold. By afternoon it will be in the mid-30s. It will not snow. On Saturday, it will snow and then rain.

title: Could Palin Use Speech to End Silence on Egypt?
description: Could Friday night be one of those defining moments in the career  and potential presidential candidacy  of Sarah Palin?

title: Leonhardt and Norris on the Jobs Report
description: After this mornings announcement that the United States economy added 36,000 jobs in January, two Times columnists  David Leonhardt and Floyd Norris  are continuing the discussion they began on Thursday about the employment situation and the prospects for the economy. The most recent posts are at the top.

title: Hype Central: Ticket Inflation, Musical Quarterbacks and How to Figurine Yourself
description: Friday morning musings as we head toward lunacys home stretch:

title: Jobs Report Offers a Mixed Bag, but Little Comfort
description: The United States labor market is still having trouble achieving liftoff.

title: Investor Urges Shake-Up at Actelion
description: The investment firm Elliott Advisors is calling from some directors at Actelion, the Swiss biotech company, to step down because they had refused to consider takeover approaches.

title: Harlem Revisited
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#0", 592, 400, true, chameleonData);

title: Good Cheer and Fear on Departure Friday
description: CAIRO  It is a beautiful Friday morning in Cairo.

title: More Attacks and Detentions for Journalists in Cairo
description: Reporters in Cairo faced a second day of violent intimidation and government detention on Friday even as dozens of foreign journalists and rights advocates were still being detained, suggesting that the effort to stifle the flow of news out of Egypt had slowed but not ended.

title: Snow Delays School Production of Joe Turners Come and Gone
description: A student production of Joe Turners Come and Gone that overcame the objections of a school superintendent in order to proceed has been temporarily halted by Mother Nature. The Waterbury Arts Magnet School in Waterbury, Conn., had planned to perform that August Wilson play on Thursday, Friday and Saturday of this week, but has postponed the performances following the heavy snowfalls that have recently hit the Northeast. Dana Manning, the schools fine arts coordinator, told The Republican-American newspaper of Waterbury that the bad weather had prevented rehearsals for the production. Additional performances planned for next week were also likely to be rescheduled and new dates for the play were not immediately announced.

title: Drop in Gold Prices Hurts Hedge Fund Manager
description: John A. Paulson, the hedge fund manager.

title: Honorary Awards to the Rescue
description: Its been, what, two days without an award show this week? The Bagger is nearly going through withdrawal. (Telltale signs: donning a cocktail dress just to blog; introducing ourselves to our neighbor on the subway, and asking them to pass the rolls; clapping at random intervals when our editor speaks; appreciating actors just as much as possible, lest they feel starved for attention.) Luckily, some honorary awards have been announced to stave off our total self-congratulation meltdown.

title: Funding Site Lets Organizations Curate
description: Kickstarter, the Web site that helps people raise money for their creative projects, from films to restaurants, has introduced a new feature: pages that have been curated by arts organizations, schools, media companies, and, in one case, a city.

title: Still Evolving, With an Assist From an Old Pro
description: Madrid

title: Brad Lubman Revives Philip Glasss Glassworks
description: PHILIP GLASS: GLASSWORKS, MUSIC IN SIMILAR MOTION

title: Morning Take-Out
description: MERGERS & ACQUISITIONS

title: S.&P. Continues to Climb as Earnings Top Estimates
description: Stocks rose on Friday, reversing losses and sending the Standard & Poors 500-stock index to the highest level since June 2008, after the unemployment rate unexpectedly dropped and more companies beat earnings estimates.

title: Andreas Scholl and Christophe Dumaux Play Purcell
description: PURCELL: SONGS, ARIAS

title: PAGs and Mother Ships
description: [1] Pirate Action Groups  a term for Somali pirate fleets; and [2] hijacked ships used by pirates to extend their scope of operation.

description: ETHAN WICKMAN:

title: The Week in Pictures, Feb. 4
description: A look back at the weeks events in New York City and the region.

description: Film

title: Public Drawn to Choice by Giffordss Husband
description: He is going.

title: Your Moment of Squeeeeeeeeal: Justin Bieber Does The Daily Show
description: In this Daily Show segment that was technically shown late Thursday night, Jon Stewart and Justin Bieber went all Freaky Friday on us. The nightly news satire opened with its anchors chair occupied by Mr. Bieber, the pint-size pop star, who seemed to be channeling Mr. Stewart  and who was then interrupted by a hoodie-clad Mr. Stewart, who appeared to have Mr. Biebers spirit stuck in his body. With the aid of a magic skull, the two were quickly restored to their correct anatomies, which is too bad, because we really would have liked to have seen Mr. Bieber interview Adm. Mike Mullen, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, later in the show.

title: Verizon Sells Out of iPhone 4 Preorders
description: 10:30 a.m. | Updated  Included reports from Verizon customers that their iPhone orders have been processed and are shipping.

title: Deal Makers Start Year With a Bang
description: The volume of mergers and acquisitions surged 69 percent, to $309.6 billion worldwide in January from a year ago, Thomson Reuters data shows.

title: The Mistake of 2008
description: Gavyn Davies has a good post on core inflation, monetary policy, and all that. He summarizes nicely the thinking behind the Feds belief that a one-time surge in commodity prices is not a reason to tighten. But Im a bit surprised  not so much about Davies as about the discussion in general  at how little attention is given to the ECBs Mistake of 2008, which illustrates the trouble with focusing on headline inflation.

title: Friday Reading: Record High Food Prices
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: Super Bowl Matchup: How the Packers Can Win
description: Four ways the Packers can gain an advantage over the Steelers on Sunday:

title: Super Bowl Matchup: How the Steelers Can Win
description: Four ways the Steelers can gain an advantage over the Packers on Sunday.

title: A Requiem So Big That Performing It Takes a Multitude
description: UNDERSTANDABLY, composers through the centuries have responded to the text of the Roman Catholic Requiem and its evocations of the day of wrath, the last trumpet and other apocalyptic images with music of high drama (Mozart) if not overt theatricality (Verdi). But in the case of the French composer Hector Berlioz and his Grande Messe des Morts (High Mass for the Dead), the dramatic impulse seems to have come first, needing only a pretext  a death or an anniversary  to give it wing.

title: Mortgage Groups Old Building Flipped For a Profit
description: When the Mortgage Bankers Association bought a state-of-the-art office building five blocks from the White House in 2007, the industry trade group thought it was a wise investment.

title: The Inexact Science of the Jobless Numbers
description: THE American economy added 36,000 jobs last month.

title: Prince Calls Pistons Season Wasted
description: The Detroit Pistons have been a mess this season, and it seems less likely that things will get better.

title: No State Charges Against Tucson Shooting Suspect  for Now
description: TUCSON  Jared L. Loughner will not face state murder charges in the Tucson shooting spree that left 6 dead and 13 injured until after the federal government finishes its trial against him, the authorities said Friday.

title: What Were Reading
description: An aggregation of links by the reporters and editors of Diners Journal.

title: Another Kind of Financial Fragility
description: Recent events have a lot of economists working hard at trying to determine the causes of financial fragility  the vulnerability of some economies, ours very much included, to disruptive shocks that cause credit and spending to freeze.

title: The Subway as Stringed Instrument
description: Conductor: www.mta.me from Alexander Chen on Vimeo.

title: Nearly 300,000 Ford F-150 Pickups Recalled for Faulty Door Spring
description: Ford is recalling about 291,000 of its F-150 pickups in the United States because the door might open in a side-impact crash, according to the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration. The affected model years are 2009-10.

title: Leading Off: How Is the N.F.L. in Dire Straits?
description: 3:29 p.m. | Updated With nearly every Super Bowl-related story line picked over endlessly in the two-week period since anyone played an actual football game  the story buffet looks a bit like the grocery aisles the day before a blizzard  we move on to wondering how an event so ostentatiously awash in money is also the stage for people explaining why the N.F.L. is on the verge of a lockout.

title: Childhood: Obesity and School Lunches
description: Researchers say they have identified another risk factor for childhood obesity: school lunch.

title: A Prescription for Fear
description: If youre looking for the name of a new pill to ask your doctor about, as the ads say, the Mayo Clinic Health Information site is not the place for you. If youre shopping for a newly branded disorder that might account for your general feeling of unease, Mayo is not for you either. But if you want workaday, can-do health information in a nonprofit environment, plug your symptoms into Mayos Symptom Checker. What youll get is: No hysteria. No drug peddling. Good medicine. Good ideas.

title: Doing the Outsourcing
description: Except for a few odd jobs, I had been out of work for nine months when I was offered a job setting up an offshore help desk, with the possibility of more such work to follow. I want to refuse. My fathers auto-industry job was outsourced, and I dont feel right helping co-workers lose their I.T. jobs. My wife argues that if I dont take this, someone else will, and that I have no duty to protect an industry that no longer employs me. Would it be ethical to accept the offer? NAME WITHHELD, SEATTLE

title: Postal Mortem
description: I remember walking to the post office in the little town where I grew up. Some summer days, there wasnt much else to do. The postmaster was a remote and taciturn fellow known to me mostly as a blurry hand rifling envelopes into the boxes. This was the early 1970s, and each trip to the building with the flag outside and the Wanted posters in the lobby filled me with a sense of possibility. I might discover I won a sweepstakes. I might receive an issue of one of the magazines that I subscribed to chiefly so I would get mail. And even if my familys box was empty that day, I might overhear a bit of adult gossip or bump into a pal. I might recognize on a poster the scowling face of a man Id seen hanging around the hardware store, making me eligible for a big reward.

title: The Reagan Evolution
description: Your new documentary, Reagan, which makes its premiere on HBO on Feb. 7 in honor of the presidents 100th birthday, includes some wonderful footage of Reagan as a small-town lifeguard, a handsome figure in his swimming trunks who happened to be severely nearsighted. Did you intend that as some kind of metaphor?  Thats exactly right. He had certain blind spots in his priorities but an absolutely genuine desire to be a person who could save peoples lives. No question.

title: Tights and Camo
description: I grew up in a small mill town just south of the Adirondack Mountains, and although I live in Maine now, for many years I lived in places where it didnt really snow, and I would look forward to my trip home for the holidays, when I would go cross-country skiing with my dad. Look forward is a bit misleading; pay obsessive attention to the snow report while ignoring everything else might be more accurate.

title: Iraqs Last Patriot
description: We came in nave about what the problems were in Iraq, Gen. Raymond Odierno, the American military commander in Iraq, told me last August, a few days before he was to end his third tour. He had spent four years in Iraq. I dont think we understood what I call the societal devastation that occurred, we didnt realize how damaged Iraq had been from 1980, in the Iran-Iraq war. The list went on: Iraqs 1990 invasion of Kuwait, the 1991 gulf war, international sanctions that crippled Iraqs middle class. And then, Odierno added, we attacked to overthrow the government. The same navet affected American efforts to mold Iraqi politics, with its ethnic and sectarian divisions. We just didnt understand it, Odierno said.

title: A Graphical Overview of the 2012 Republican Field
description: There is almost exactly one year to go until the Iowa caucuses, which are tentatively scheduled to take place on Feb. 6, 2012. No mainstream Republican candidate has yet declared for the presidency, but that is sure to change soon, perhaps as soon as there is a lull in the news  something we have not had in weeks, because of the Tucson shootings and the Egyptian protests.

title: Financial District Adapts as Banks Leave
description: Next year, Fidelity Investments will move from Lower Manhattan to Jersey City.

title: Egyptians Muster for New Day of Protests
description: Calling Friday a Day of Departure, protesters gathered by the hundreds of thousands in Cairos central Tahrir Square to call for the ouster of President Hosni Mubarak.

title: John Lennons Ferrari Withdrawn From Bonhams Auction
description: John Lennons 1965 Ferrari 330 GT, which was scheduled to be auctioned this weekend by Bonhams at the Grand Palais in Paris, has been withdrawn. The vendor unfortunately decided at the last minute that he could not bear to part with it, wrote Leonora Oldfield, a Bonhams spokeswoman, in an e-mail on Friday.

title: LVMHs Net Income for Year Soars 73%
description: PARIS  Less than two years after the worst financial crisis since the Great Depression, indulgence is back in style. Bernard Arnault, creator of LVMH Louis Vuitton Mot Hennessy, is one of the biggest beneficiaries.

title: Treating Chronic Pain and Managing the Bills
description: MAYBE the question is not who suffers from some type of chronic pain, but who doesnt?

title: France to Resume Search for Plane in 09 Crash
description: PARIS  The French government said Friday that yet another effort to find the wreckage of an Air France jet that crashed in the mid-Atlantic more than 18 months ago would begin next month.

title: He Still Has Arm to Pitch, Pettitte Says, but No Longer the Heart
description: About 45 minutes before he was to announce his retirement Friday morning at Yankee Stadium, Andy Pettitte called Jason Zillo, the teams director of media relations. Im straight panicking, Pettitte told him.

title: Married or Single: Is That in the Facebook Sense?
description: AMONG the many small changes Facebook has wrought on American society is how some of us view, assess and even define what a relationship is.

title: Disparities: A Growing Gender Gap in Doctors Pay
description: Starting salaries for women who become physicians are significantly lower than mens, and the pay gap has grown over the past decade, a study reports.

title: Officers Charged in Fake-Ticket Scam
description: Two Staten Island police officers are facing criminal charges after they were accused of writing fake traffic tickets.

title: Reviewer Spotlight: Emma Donoghue
description: This weekend in the Book Review, Emma Donoghue reviews Swamplandia!, the first novel by Karen Russell (author of the story collection St. Lucys Home for Girls Raised by Wolves). Both Russell and Donoghue have written novels from the perspective of young narrators isolated from the wider world: in Swamplandia! the protagonist is a girl on the cusp of adolescence who lives in an alligator theme park; in Donoghues Room, one of the Book Reviews 10 Best Books of 2010, the narrator is a 5-year-old boy raised in an 11-by-11-foot room.

title: The Master of Movie Makeup Speaks
description: The makeup and effects designer Rick Baker received the first Oscar for makeup, in 1982, for An American Werewolf in London. Hes won five more since, for everything from Ed Wood to Norbit. Mr. Baker also has a long history with wolf creatures; when he first started experimenting with makeup, the second mask he ever made was of a Wolfman. He was 10. (The first mask he made was Frankenstein. He still has a lot of these early efforts in his studio. Im a bit of a hoarder, he said.)

title: George S. Kaufman
description: Mr. Kaufman is the chairman of the Kaufman Organization, which owns and operates commercial properties throughout the New York area and provides brokerage and consulting services. He is also the chairman of Kaufman Astoria Studios, home to Sesame Street.

title: Comparing Recoveries: Job Changes
description: Source: Bureau of Labor Statistics. Chart by Amanda Cox. Horizontal axis shows months. Vertical axis shows the ratio of that months nonfarm payrolls to the nonfarm payrolls at the start of recession. Note: Because employment is a lagging indicator, the dates for these employment trends are not exactly synchronized with National Bureau of Economic Researchs official business cycle dates.

title: The Clash Over Bankruptcy Fees
description: Somehow, Kirkland & Ellis has gotten off to a terrible start with the new United States Trustee in New York.

title: This Weekends Top European Matchups
description: The outstanding matchups in European league soccer this weekend:

title: The Lucky Break of Rent Stabilization
description: THERE are nearly a million rent-stabilized apartments in New York City. Which means that there are at least a million lucky people who know they have relatively low rent that isnt going to rise too far, too fast. These fortunate souls also know that their leases, especially for apartments in Manhattan and parts of Brooklyn, are worth far more than the paper they are written on, should the landlord or a developer decide to buy tenants out.

title: Samurai Shopper | End-of-Season Dregs
description: Dear Sarah Palin: We are all Alaskans now. We live in New York, where 52 inches of great white stuff has come down week after week since December, freezing and melting in endless rounds of arctic folly. It has really been rough sledding, and some of us, cooped up overlong in candlelight, have gone crazy. Weve concocted conspiracy theories, like: The gods must be angry because Mayor Mike bought himself extra innings, or theyre punishing the Jets, or they cant stand the sight of another Sperry Topsider slip-on, and their nerd/cool appeal that is less oxy than moron. Some of us even toyed with the idea of riding above the blackened mounds of snow  just like you  and mowing down anything clad in fur.

title: Threes Company (One of Us Is a Dog)
description: IT was a roommate ad on Craigslist that brought Melissa Tabatabai and David Spevak together.

title: Rescuing the Earths Weather History
description: One of the most profound limitations of climate science arises from a simple fact. While humans have existed on this planet in more or less their present form for perhaps a quarter-million years, the historical record covers only a few thousand years, and the record of accurate weather and climate observations is much shorter than that.

title: Go Figure
description: As a genre of visual communication, the architectural rendering is underscrutinized. When we see one  in a business meeting, on a real estate sign, accompanying an article about a public-works project  we understandably focus on the merits of whats depicted, not the depiction. Recently, however, I happened to spend a lot of time looking at such drawings, and found myself drawn to a recurring feature that, strictly speaking, had nothing to do with the suggested structures: the little human figures who inhabit the rendered world.

title: As Germany Booms, It Faces a Shortage of Workers
description: BERLIN  Dana Russow longs for the day when she will not have to worry about staffing problems.

title: Black-Magic Woman
description: That dog is the very Devil. No, seriously. That shaggy black mongrel is Satan incarnate, and he wants to buy your soul. Kind of cute, though, isnt he, the way he perks up at the least sign of affection? You dont know whether to scratch his belly or make the sign of the cross.

title: Expanding Horizons
description: More has been learned about the cosmos in the past century than in all prior human history. Todays cosmologists can age-date the universe, trace how it evolved into its present form and accurately predict the outcome of fundamental events from here to the far reaches of space and time.

title: Poisoning the Well
description: I havent had the talk yet with my kids: my 11-year-old son and 6-year-old daughter. I mean the one about global warming, about whats coming. But then, we grown-ups havent had the talk yet among ourselves. Not really. We dont seem to know how: the topic is apparently too big and scary. Or perhaps, for the uninformed (or misinformed), not scary enough.

title: Polar Distress
description: In our romantic imagination, the Arctic is a sort of crisp white wonderland, a pristine and remote preserve populated by polar bears. But take a close look at the recent history of the interconnected lands that make up the Arctic and youll also find a dumping ground, ravaged and exploited cultures and a poorly regulated zone in which humanitys worst instincts have been indulged. This distressing reality, and the enduring glimpses of beauty within it, is what Sara Wheelers new book, The Magnetic North: Notes From the Arctic Circle, is all about.

title: Heres Looking at Him
description: Has any leading man ever made women work so hard to get his attention? There he is, just minding his own business when along comes some dame who gets it in her head that they should fall in love. She flirts with him, kisses him first, talks back when he tells her off, stays when he buys her a ticket to go. He puts up a fight with all the grim resolve of a guy closing the shutters on a storm thats about to raze his house. Sooner or later, the dame, who happens to be beautiful, wears him down and he comes around, against his better judgment. Humphrey Bogarts shell was a carapace, as Stefan Kanfer writes about one of his roles, meant to cover the psychic injuries of a decent man trying to forget the past.

title: Snow and Ice Paralyze Texas From Rio Grande to Oklahoma Border
description: HOUSTON  A rare winter storm hit much of Texas early Friday with sleet and snow, creating chaos on icy roads around the state and hampering travelers trying to get to the Super Bowl near Dallas.

title: Twitter Cant Save You
description: Just a few years ago, all anyone could talk about was how to make the Internet more free. Now all anyone can talk about is how to control it.

title: Bruins-Stars Game Turns Ugly
description: 12:35 p.m. | Updated For those who ahbor hockey violence, shield your tender eyes. For old-school types who love fights, Thursdays Bruins-Stars game had more than its share.

title: Colbert Portrait, With Art World Input, to Be Sold at Auction
description: Hey, you, art collector or philanthropist with a prominent space to fill in your museum or over your fireplace: how much would you pay for a painting whose contributors include Shepard Fairey, Andres Serrano and Frank Stella? Before you answer that, know this: its a portrait of Stephen Colbert. The financial value (if not the artistic merit) of such a work will be determined on March 8 at an auction held by Phillips de Pury & Company, where a painting of the Colbert Report host will be sold, Comedy Central said on Friday.

title: Primal Urges
description: Vladimir Nabokov claimed that the initial shiver of inspiration for Lolita came from a newspaper account of an ape in the Jardin des Plantes in Paris that produced the first drawing ever made by an animal. This sketch, he reported, showed the bars of the poor creatures cage. The story neatly encapsulates the tragedy and comedy of Humbert Humbert: for all his preternatural brilliance  no one of his kind has ever set such things down on a page  he knows less than nothing because he doesnt know that a world exists outside himself. The narrator of Benjamin Hales first novel, The Evolution of Bruno Littlemore, has some of Humberts erudition and much of his arrogance. Like Humbert, he is imprisoned for a murder he cant bring himself to regret, and like Humberts, his confession is far less concerned with that act than with the scandalous love affair that precipitated it. The difference is that Bruno knows he is trapped, for he has seen this cage from both within and without. Also, Bruno is an actual ape.

title: Dramatic Revival
description: When he accepted the Nobel Prize in Literature in 1923, William Butler Yeats singled out two players of genius, Sara Allgood and Maire ONeill, for their contributions to the Irish theater. They were sisters, Yeats said, one all simplicity, her mind shaped by folk song and folk stories; the other sophisticated, lyrical and subtle. Sara Allgood had a subsequent career in Hollywood, acting in early Hitchcock films and John Fords How Green Was My Valley. The other sister, born Molly Allgood, has caught the eye of the Irish novelist and playwright Joseph OConnor, a man who knows something about famous sisters  his own is the singer Sinead OConnor.

title: In Text Messages, Signs of a Rigged Sumo Fight
description: TOKYO  It was a sumo bout like any other: two wrestlers grappled at each other at the rings edge, before one sent his opponent tumbling to the dirt in a move known as the over-arm throw.

title: At What Cost
description: In 1992, Lawrence Summers, then the chief economist of the World Bank, caused a minor uproar when it was reported that he had signed a memo arguing that poor countries should lease out land to house waste produced by rich countries. To many, Eduardo Porter writes in The Price of Everything: Solving the Mystery of Why We Pay What We Do, the memo demonstrated that the World Bank believed poor countries were dumps. While Summers backpedaled, calling the argument an exercise in sardonic counterpoint, it nevertheless cost him a lot of political capital in Washington.

title: The Aftermath
description: Most people die before they can witness the historical consequences of their actions. Ulrich, the 100-year-old Bulgarian man at the center of Rana Dasguptas new novel, Solo, is an exception: he is so ancient he lives in a state of perpetual, dazed aftermath. Once the manager of a chemical factory for the Communists, he watches as Bulgarias rivers start oozing familiar poisons: Like all his compatriots, Ulrich had become chemical himself, his blood a solution of cadmium, lead, zinc and copper. Soon after, Communism falls, multiplying the pointlessness of Ulrichs life.

title: Castaways
description: Reading Nathacha Appanahs novel The Last Brother, I was sometimes reminded of Czeslaw Miloszs poem Dedication, which opens:

title: Glamour Goes to War
description: In 1835, the French novelist Honor de Balzac observed that the secret of great fortunes . . . is a forgotten crime. Recast in the English-speaking world as Behind every great fortune lies a great crime, this truism aptly describes the central conceit of Ruth Brandons Ugly Beauty. Reconstructing the lives of two self-made beauty tycoons  Helena Rubinstein, the creator of the cosmetics brand, who died in 1965; and Eugne Schueller, the founder of the corporate behemoth LOral, who died in 1957  Brandon zeroes in on a crime that, in her view, places them in a potentially lethal opposition to each other.

title: Dreaming in English
description: In her recent book Dreaming in Chinese, Deborah Fallows describes coming across a pile of frozen hams on a Beijing street, seemingly forgotten. She has been living there with her husband and spending a lot of time getting daily doses of Chinese life and language. Being tempted briefly to pilfer a ham was like one of those moments when you realize you are dreaming in a foreign language: I realized that I was thinking like a laobaixing, Fallows writes, using the rough Chinese equivalent of Joe Six-Pack. But finally, I crept away, with the words possibly dirty, very likely gone-bad prosciutto nagging me.

title: Editors Choice
description: THE NEOCONSERVATIVE PERSUASION: Selected Essays, 1942-2009,  by Irving Kristol. Edited by Gertrude Himmelfarb (Basic Books, $29.95.) These writings, nearly all previously uncollected, offer a faithful representation of Kristols ideas and evolution.

title: Paperback Row
description: LOSING THE NEWS: The Future of the News That Feeds Democracy,  by Alex S. Jones (Oxford University, $16.95.) Jones, a Pulitzer Prize-winning journalist and director of the Shorenstein Center on the Press, Politics and Public Policy at Harvard, offers a glimpse of the void well inhabit if the task of newspapers withers away. Without the iron core of information, Jones warns, editorial pages, columnists, bloggers, talk-show hosts and others wont have much to say  and the public will have little clue about what those in power are up to.

title: U.S. Critical of Assembly in Somalia
description: BUKAVU, Congo  The American government and the United Nations signaled their displeasure Friday with the Somali Parliaments decision to extend itself for three more years, despite accomplishing almost nothing.

title: Madoff Profits Fueled Mets Empire, Lawsuit Says
description: A lawsuit brought by the trustee for the victims of Bernard L. Madoffs multibillion-dollar Ponzi scheme contends that the owners of the Mets used the profits from their years of investing with Mr. Madoff to enhance their personal fortunes, enrich a number of family trusts and financially fuel their array of businesses  all in the face of repeated warnings that Mr. Madoffs investment firm might have been a fraud.

title: Weekend Competition: Say a Little Prayer
description: This weekend, co-vocabularists of all faiths are invited to share their prayers.

title: Graphic Books Best Sellers: The Last Unicorn
description: The novelist Peter S. Beagle is the latest author to have his work adapted into the graphic novel format. The Last Unicorn, from IDW, lands at No. 2 on our hardcover list this week. The novel, originally published in 1968, was also turned into an animated film in 1982. In her review of the film version, Janet Maslin wrote:  The Last Unicorn is an unusual childrens film in many respects, the chief one being that it is unusually good. This animated fable also features a cast that would do any live-action film proud, a visual style noticeably different from that of other childrens fare, and a story filled with genuine sweetness and mystery. Children, except perhaps for very small ones, ought to be intrigued by it; adults wont be bored. And no one of any age will be immune to the sentiment of the films final moments, which really are unexpectedly touching and memorable.

title: Vintage Homes Lose Appeal
description: BACK before houses became commodities, new wasnt always associated with better. And in the 1980s and 90s, many upper-income buyers in Fairfield County sought out unusual older houses, said Lisa Passavant, an agent who specialized in antique and vintage houses in Stamford at the time.

title: Land Without Pity
description: The first time as tragedy, Marx said of historys repetitions, the second time as farce. He didnt suggest a mode for the third time, but Carlos Fuentes does: the telenovela, the interminable soap opera of conspiracy and delusion, capitalism and its demons. Destiny and Desire is a novel that sprawls and circles, not exactly a parody of War and Peace, but certainly a spectral, playful revision of the idea of a novel that competes with history.

title: Its Not Candid Camera, Its Random Culture
description: PHILADELPHIA  It was just another winter Saturday morning at the Reading Terminal Market, an expansive food hall at the heart of this citys downtown. Toward noon people began flocking to the restaurants in the central court, creating such a din that nobody seemed to pay much mind when the sound of recorded music floated through the air.

title: Ready, Set  Go! | Fashion Week Prep With the Runner Delilah DiCrescenzo
description: Fashion Week is coming up, and that means scads of runway shows and presentations and a whole lot of late nights. So, whats a T fashion editor to do? We turned to Delilah DiCrescenzo, an All-American titleholder for Columbia Universitys cross-country and track team. Shes also a founding member of the New Jersey/New York Track Club, which is sponsored by Puma. We always say two days before the race is the most important night for sleep, DiCrescenzo says. But that doesnt mean overcompensating.

title: Reluctant Seer
description: Cassandra Brooks, the narrator of Bradford Morrows new novel, The Diviners Tale, sees too much, thinks too much and feels too much. And in the telling of her strange tale she also, sadly, talks too much. She is a woman who is visited with unwanted visions, whether of the past or the future or some alternative present she often cant tell. The novel begins with her account of the very first of what she calls her forevisions: when she was 7, she warned her older brother not to go out one summer night, and he was killed in a car crash. In the storys present tense, she is in her mid-30s, living with her 11-year-old twin sons in the upstate New York town where she was raised, and occasionally turning her paranormal gifts to modest advantage by hiring herself out as a diviner; when asked, shell dowse for water in her neighbors fields. In the course of one of these expeditions, she sees something terrible  a young girl hanged from a tree. But when she brings the police back to the scene, the body has disappeared without a trace, as if she had simply dreamed it.

title: Treating Pain That Wont Go Away
description: Todays Patient Money column focuses on the challenges of treating chronic pain and getting reimbursed for treatment.

title: Extended-Stay Hotels Become a Popular Housing Option
description: PLAINVIEW

title: Summing Up the Jobs Report
description: Floyd Norris and I discuss this mornings jobs report in more detail here. My summary follows:

title: My Husband, the Stranger
description: Newly widowed after a 46-year marriage, Sally Ryder Brady looked for solace by reading memoirs and essays on grief by Joan Didion, Nora Ephron and Donald Hall. She found herself losing patience with these authors attempts to avoid feeling sorry for themselves. Why not indulge in self-pity? Brady asks in her own memoir, A Box of Darkness. If not now, for goodness sake, then when?

title: A Look at the Self-Employed
description: Conventional wisdom over the last few years has been that, with staff jobs scarce, more of Americas relentlessly entrepreneurial workers have turned to self-employment. The numbers dont quite bear that out.

title: Brokers Face Challenges in This Snowy Winter
description: SHORT HILLS

title: TimesCast | February 4, 2011
description: Cairo's "Day of Departure" protests end peacefully in Tahrir Square; and Helene Cooper reports on the Obama administration's proposal for President Mubarak to resign.

title: Wheelies: The Global Village Edition
description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

title: Q & A
description: Leak Damage, and Who Pays

title: McLaren Launches New Car
description: A day after the first test session ended in Spain, the McLaren Mercedes team on Friday launched its new car in Berlin. While several teams this year did away with the full-fledged launch to save money, McLaren took the unusual approach of inviting fans to piece together the new car at the launch, with the teams drivers, Jenson Button and Lewis Hamilton, putting on the final pieces. Nice original idea.

title: McLaren Launches New Car
description: A day after the first test session ended in Spain, the McLaren Mercedes team on Friday launched its new car in Berlin. While several teams this year did away with the full-fledged launch to save money, McLaren took the unusual approach of inviting fans to piece together the new car at the launch, with the teams drivers, Jenson Button and Lewis Hamilton, putting on the final pieces. Nice original idea.

title: Williams Team to Float on Frankfurt Stock Exchange
description: The Williams F1 team prepared the ground a few weeks ago, saying that it was considering taking the team public. On Friday, the team announced that it would indeed go through with a listing on the Frankfurt stock exchange.

title: Williams Team to Float on Frankfurt Stock Exchange
description: The Williams F1 team prepared the ground a few weeks ago, saying that it was considering taking the team public. On Friday, the team announced that it would indeed go through with a listing on the Frankfurt stock exchange.

title: Violence and Retribution
description: Two centuries ago last month, a traveler making his way by boat down the Mississippi toward New Orleans would have come upon a ghastly sight: a severed human head rotting on the end of a pole. And no sooner would it vanish around a bend than another appeared along the levee. Then another, and another  and so on without respite for 40 long miles down to the city.

title: A Retirement Program for the Risk-Averse
description: Even the most disciplined savers are heavily relying on the stock market to reach their retirement goals. But that often amounts to a giant gamble, which is the thrust of the thinking behind a new retirement planning program that treats investing in stocks like a trip to the casino.

title: Fatal Flaws
description: In Sam Howe Verhoveks Jet Age, a letter writer contemplates life at 35,000 feet. My darling, he says, the blue Mediterranean Sea is under us and the coast appears in the distance as a dark shadow. In the sky there is much light, and never as now have I been so happy. He paid a heavy price for that transcendent view. Moments later, he and everyone else aboard their de Havilland Comet perished when the plane blew apart in the air.

title: Bloomberg Calls Behavior of Blacks Critics an Embarrassment
description: To the thousands of parents who yelled and screamed this week about the citys plan to close nearly two dozen schools, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has a message: You are an embarrassment.

title: Buzz Tracker
description: Dimons Legacy Elinor Comlay and Matthew Goldstein profile Jamie Dimon: If Dimon seems unusually thin-skinned, many industry insiders say, it is an indication of the importance the 54-year-old Queens, New York, native places on his legacy  and how that will affect his ability to forge a life beyond finance. That life will include politics, if Mr. Dimon listens to Bill Clinton, who thinks the JPMorgan chief would be really good at it. Reuters

title: Ice and Injuries Mar Super Bowl Events
description: DALLAS  As a photographer scheduled to cover Sundays Super Bowl, Win McNamee was walking outside Cowboys Stadium on Friday, shooting weather-related pictures. He heard what sounded like a jet engine overhead, and soon found himself in the middle of the story.

title: Mary Cleere Haran Injured in Florida
description: Mary Cleere Haran, one of the foremost cabaret singers of the 1990s, was gravely injured in a biking accident on Thursday near Deerfield Beach, Fla., where she has been living for the last year, said a friend, Bridge McIntyre. Ms. Haran, 58, is known for her celebrations of the American songbook, especially the work of Rodgers and Hart, Harry Warren, and the music of Doris Day.

title: The Hardest Lesson to Learn
description: I BROKE UP with my boyfriend because too many proper nouns had come between us. He is Nigerian; I am American. He survived the Warri Crisis; I survived art school in inner-city Baltimore. He has been a professional soccer player; I am a former lecturer in English literature. We live in Phnom Penh, Cambodia, which is where we met, at an African bar called Do It All.

title: Suit Says Mets Owners Ignored Warnings on Madoff
description: Barton Silverman/The New York TimesFrom right: Fred Wilpon, Saul Katz and Jeff Wilpon in November.

title: Warm Up With Winter Vegetables
description: Cold weather and winter vegetables lend themselves to comforting, bubbly baked dishes, writes Martha Rose Shulman in this weeks Recipes for Health.

title: Reform? Forget It, Boys, Its Chicago
description: GROWING up in Rockford, Ill., the television writer and producer Shawn Ryan, 44, was always fascinated by Chicago, the big, bad metropolis just 90 miles away. So when his acclaimed series The Shield ended its run on FX in 2008, and he began to think about what he might want to do next, Chicago naturally popped into his mind.

title: For a Struggling Friend, a New Shot
description: LOS ANGELES

title: Dear Grammy, Is It Hawaiian Enough?
description: NEXT Sunday night, when the Grammy Awards are broadcast from Los Angeles, expect to see a lot of the pop melodist Bruno Mars, who has a total of seven nominations. A former child entertainer in the hotel showrooms of Waikiki, Mr. Mars will surely be the most visible product of Hawaii at this years awards. Out of camera range, though, a quiet but compelling drama will be playing out in the best Hawaiian music album category. Yet again.

title: Living In | Jackson Heights, Queens
description: A Queens enclave long known for its mix of immigrants is gaining appeal for another group of migrants: academics, lawyers and other professionals from elsewhere in the city.

title: Remembering the Reagan We May Never Know
description: Lately, the best-known thing about Ronald Reagan is that he was unknowable. His legend has only grown in the 22 years since he left office, but time hasnt demystified his presidency; it has mostly revealed the opacity of his good nature.

title: A Migrants Enclave Attracts a New Breed
description: A WESTERN Queens neighborhood planned by an innovative developer beginning a century ago, Jackson Heights is a vibrant oxymoron: an enclave where much of the world is represented. Long a magnet for immigrants, the area today is dazzlingly multifarious: more than 30 languages are spoken, including Bengali, Korean, Spanish and Urdu. Nearly two-thirds of residents were born abroad, according to census surveys from 2005 to 2009.

title: When Its Tater Tot Day at School
description: Children who regularly buy school lunch are at higher risk for obesity, a new study shows.

title: House Republicans Seek to Extend Antiterrorism Law
description: House Republicans are hoping to push back debate over three expiring provisions of the law that expanded the F.B.I.s counterterrorism powers after the Sept. 11, 2001, terror attacks.

title: Arizona Solar Plant Picks Chinese Supplier
description: Suntech, the Chinese solar giant, has won a contract to supply photovoltaic panels for a 150-megawatt project in Arizona, marking Chinas entry into a lucrative United States power-plant market dominated by American companies.

title: Hiding Money Overseas? Youre Taking a Big Chance
description: ANYONE who squirrels away money in an offshore bank account, confident that it will remain a secret, should think again.

title: A Developer Aims High in Long Island City
description: EVEN in a sluggish market, property developers are continuing to bet on Long Island Citys transformation from towering smokestacks to residential towers.

title: Paltrow and Florence (Minus the Machine) to Croon at the Oscars
description: Following up on her surprisingly decent performance at the Country Music Awards, Gwyneth Paltrow will take the stage at the Oscars, organizers announced on Friday. Ms. Paltrow, the newly minted legit crooner, Oscar winner and lifestyle guru we love to hate, will perform the nominated song Coming Home from her film Country Strong, singing and presumably playing guitar over her awards show finery.

title: Editor Out at New York Observer
description: Updated 8:41 p.m. | The New York Observer on Friday replaced its editor after barely a year on the job, bringing in a new leader whose experience is not in newspapers but in the blogosphere that has eaten away at The Observers exclusivity.

title: Brink of Pink
description: For a pretty pink pucker this Valentines Day, try Chanels new Rouge Coco Shine lipstick in Boy, the shade Vanessa Paradis wears in the campaign for the shimmery new collection. The line has its official debut in April, but the lipstick is available presale from Thursday through Feb. 13 at Chanel boutiques and at department stores. Named after Arthur Capel, known as Boy, the love of Coco Chanels life, it is $32; for stores: chanel.com.

title: Oaktrees Marks Calls for Prudence
description: There is nothing wrong with being wrong, says Howard Marks, chairman of the private equity firm Oaktree Capital  and there are so many ways to be wrong.

title: Habitats | Morningside Heights
description: Masuo Ichida took a break from work and made over his home, a rental apartment on West 109th Street.

title: When All Else Fails, Apply Bamboo
description: AS a child growing up in Jackson Heights, Queens, Masuo Ichida was bathed in the visual arts practically from the cradle. His father, Koji Ichida, an art historian and critic born in Japan, has written 15 books on art and antiques, and the family collected art for generations. Yet the son is as surprised as anyone that he has spent much of the past year designing and decorating his one-bedroom apartment in Morningside Heights.

title: Japans Steel Industry Heats Up on Merger Plans
description: Nippon Steel and Sumitomo Metal Industries said they envisioned merging by October 2012, a move that could reduce costs and ease the effect of rising prices for raw materials. Shares of Japanese steel makers climbed on the news as investors expected the deal to lead to further consolidation in the industry. This Reuters Business video explores the implications of the planned merger.

title: Imam Steps Down From Project Near Ground Zero
description: The imam who was named three weeks ago to lead religious services at the proposed Muslim community center and mosque near ground zero said Friday that he was stepping down. The move is the latest in a string of public relations setbacks for the project.

title: Unions Can Bargain on Behalf of Airport Security
description: WASHINGTON  Seeking to end a debate that has brewed for nearly a decade, the director of the Transportation Security Administration announced on Friday that a union would be allowed to bargain over working conditions on behalf of the nations 45,000 airport security officers, although certain issues like pay will not be subject to negotiation.

title: Dear FloFab: My Brother Wont Let Me Drink in Front of His Kids
description: Each week, Florence Fabricant gives advice on the fine points of entertaining at home and eating in restaurants. Have a dining question? Ask FloFab.

title: An Author Escapes From Chronic Fatigue Syndrome
description: Laura Hillenbrand, the best-selling author of Seabiscuit: An American Legend, is known for her exuberant storytelling and dynamic characters. Her newest book, Unbroken: A World War II Story of Survival, Resilience and Redemption, is a riveting tale of the life of an athlete and war hero, Louis Zamperini.

title: Thomas L. Friedman in Jordan
description: The Op-Ed columnist Thomas L. Friedman discusses the resentment felt by educated and unemployed young men in Amman, Jordan.

title: Using Our New On This Day Feature
description: Finally!

title: On the Chess Board With the Founding Fathers
description: James Madison was Thomas Jeffersons friend and protg, in addition to being his successor as president. He was also often his sparring partner in chess.

title: To the Super Bowl via Ghana: A Packer Familys Journey
description: McKINNEY, Tex.  The mother of Charlie Peprah, the Green Bay strong safety, sat on her couch, VCR remote in hand, and fast-forwarded through the history of her native Ghana until the grainy image of her father, Ignatius Kutu Acheampong, filled the screen.

title: The Ultimate Riding Machine? Previewing BMW DesignworksUSAs Inspiro Train
description: BMW DesignworksUSA has conceived a new vehicle big on headroom, with seating capacity for the entire family  along with several hundred of their closest friends. The new Siemens Metro Inspiro, penned by the BMW Group-owned design consultancy, might lack the acceleration of an M5 sports sedan or the curves of a Z4 Roadster, but it is equipped with enough curious features and functions to give BMWs iDrive interface a run for the money.

title: Nurses Without Borders
description: We tend to think of nurses as yet another item on that expensive list labeled medical care, but around the country about 15,000 nurses, most of them acting as volunteers, provide elderly support services free of charge. The members of the faith community nurse movement, as its called, are available to anyone, regardless of religion. In many communities, getting help is simply a matter of picking up the telephone.

title: Fete Accompli | Gucci and Christies Bamboo Nights
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#399", 592, 400, true, chameleonData);

title: Pictures of the Day: Egypt and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Egypt, Iran, Jordan and China.

title: Political Contribution Limits Are Increased for 2012
description: Donors will be able to open their wallets a little wider for their favorite politicians in 2012 under new contribution limits issued by the Federal Election Commission today.

title: A Brand Where Storytelling Is Part of the Design
description: URBAN Inc., the Philadelphia-based retail empire that includes the folksy, peripatetic stores Urban Outfitters, Anthropologie and Free People, has quietly segued into a higher-end market with Leifsdottir, a Scandinavian-inspired brand sold at Bergdorf Goodman, Neiman Marcus and Bloomingdales that is achieving a kind of stealth success with trendsetters and shoppers alike.

title: Jordan Faces a Rising Tide of Unrest, but Few Expect a Revolt
description: MAFRAQ, Jordan  The tribal elders sat in their gowns and keffiyehs, fingering worry beads and smoking cigarettes, an immense woven image of King Abdullah II on a wall above their heads.

title: Can Entertainment Renew American Inquiry?
description: What does this parody of a Lady Ga Ga video have to do with efforts to renew American inquiry and innovation?

title: Europe Moves to Stabilize Its Energy Supplies
description: BRUSSELS  European leaders agreed on Friday to give unprecedented leeway to the blocs executive agency to help negotiate contracts with energy exporters like Russia in an effort to improve security of supplies and safeguard investment.

title: Paterson Pays the Price Over His Series Tickets
description: The New York Yankees loss in the first game of the 2009 World Series seemed costly at the time only for their hopes for another title. In the end, it proved far costlier to former Gov. David A. Paterson.

title: Letter: More Than Cheese Steaks
description: To the Editor: Regarding Philadelphia Evolves Its Palate (Jan. 23): Yet another article on Philadelphia restaurants trotting out the hoary notion that the city is barely a sauted onion and a glop of Cheez Whiz away from some culinary wasteland. I dont know where your writer has been or whom shes been talking to, but the restaurant scene in Philadelphia started evolving about 30 years ago.

title: Hotel Review: La Amada in Playa Mujeres, Mexico
description: BASICS

title: Mexico City: Hiking Mecca?
description: WHO knew that this was here? said Alejandro Escalante, a young businessman from Mexico City, his suit jacket flapping like a flag in the wind. Above us loomed the serrated edge of Nevado de Toluca, a 15,000-foot-high extinct volcano an hours drive and a short hike from the Mexican capital. From deep within its crater, two shallow emerald lakes reflected patches of snow that, by last spring, still stubbornly clung to the mountains broad shoulders.

title: A Midwest Beer Tour to Cure Winter Blues
description: ICICLES hung from the red awning of the South Shore Brewery in Ashland, Wis. The door opened and a frigid gust off Lake Superior blew a few more folks inside, their collars upturned and stocking hats pulled down past their eyebrows. At the bar, I turned back to the pint glass of midnight black stout with a foamy head. The beers bouquet tickled my nose  zingy peppermint, brisk as the wind off the lake.

title: In New Orleans, Early Mardi Gras Parades Are Family Fare
description: THERES a phrase that New Orleans residents use to describe Mardi Gras that never fails to draw incredulous reactions from visitors to the city: family friendly.

title: Lost in Las Vegas
description: THE minute I walked into the steakhouse, I knew I was in the wrong place. Or maybe exactly the right place. This was N9ne, at the Palms Casino Resort, a few blocks from the Las Vegas Strip, and it was definitely not my scene. The slick design  leather in muted colors, steel and aluminum accents, and silly lighting  was one thing, but Ive dealt with worse. No, it was the clientele: big men with vigorous, voluminous hair, a penchant for untucked dress shirts, done-up women at their sides and a kind of frat-boy bluster that terrifies a balding, neurotic little Brooklynite like me.

title: Driving Through Cambodia: A Road Trip Through Ruins and Unexplored Highways
description: A LIGHT rain started to fall as we drove up to the entrance of Bokor National Park in southern Cambodia. Up ahead lay the decaying remnants of a French hill station where colonists used to while away their weekends when they ruled this Southeast Asian country.

title: In Delhi, an Arty Village Rises by Ancient Ruins
description: Hauz Khas Village, a cluster of cafes, restaurants, bookstores and boutiques, has emerged as a contemporary gateway to the history nearby.

title: Lost in Las Vegas
description: Armed with wary disdain and little else, a visitor to Sin City makes it his own.

title: S.E.C. Names New General Counsel
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission announced on Friday that was promoting Mark D. Cahn to be its next general counsel.

title: Book Review Podcast: Karen Russell
description: This week: Karen Russell discusses her first novel, Swamplandia!; Lee Siegel talks about the dark side of the Internet; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive) //

title: Unmentioned Luxury
description: To the Editor:

title: The Savory Breakfast Department: Progress
description: I have this Japanese shelf or, more accurately, a shelf that holds some of my ingredients for Japanese cooking. Thanks to the no-fish sushi piece I wrote last spring, and thanks to a soba story Im working on for the magazine, that shelf is a little heavier than usual, and it features an embarrassing abundance of nori seaweed, in large part because I misinterpreted a mail order form and order 10 packages instead of 10 sheets.

title: LeBron Jamess Indulgence of Possibility
description: Thursday nights TNT double-header featured two premier matchups, both of which delighted national audiences by living up to their billing. For the first game, the ever-prominent Miami Heat played the latest in its season series (and budding rivalry) against the quasi-contending Orlando Magic. In the second, the best team in the West, the San Antonio Spurs, teed off against the honorary best team in the West, the Los Angeles Lakers. Tremendous individual performances, game-winners, strong defense, and highly competitive play ruled the day.

title: JetBlues Facebook App Offers Rewards
description: Facebook can often be a time suck, but a new initiative by JetBlue offers rewards for logging onto the site.

title: Barneyss New Chief Explains Those Changes
description: Im a worker, not so much a talker, Mark Lee, the chief executive of Barneys New York, said Friday morning, explaining his reluctance these last few months to publicly discuss his makeover plans for the store. Mr. Lee, the former chief executive of Gucci, arrived at Barneys in September.

title: Germany and France Roll Out Plan to Boost Euro
description: BRUSSELS  Initiating a bold effort to strengthen the euro, Germany and France on Friday laid down far-reaching plans to deepen integration among the 17 nations that use the currency. The move prompted immediate opposition, but could lead to embryonic economic government for Europe.

title: Final Volleys Over the Airgas Poison Pill
description: The final briefs have been filed in Air Products and Chemicals legal battle to gain control of Airgas, and a ruling in Delaware Chancery Court is expected next week. The briefs are fine pieces of work, no doubt worthy of the hundreds of thousands of dollars spent to write each of them.

title: Tavern on the Green
description: To the Editor:

title: Special Delivery | A.P.C.s New Digs
description: Unlike the majority of fashion labels, which are subject to a constant wax-and-wane credibility cycle, A.P.C. is ever cool. Thats due in large part to the brands founder, Jean Touitou, a man to whom the conventions of fashion  trend-based collections, high-profile ad campaigns  are so many canards, a conviction that his loyal customers, many of whom wouldnt wear any other jeans, wholeheartedly endorse. A.P.C.s second Manhattan shop will open next week at the corner of Perry and Bleecker Streets in the West Village, to be followed this summer by a third location just a few blocks away. The West Village is classy. SoHo is getting a bit commercial. Every time you turn around, theres a new store. Of course, who am I to talk? Im opening new stores. Touitou said with typical candor when The Moment rang up his Paris office to chat. Here, he talks to us about the fashion habits of 19th-century British aristocrats, the pleasures of sewing and why the classics arent as simple as they look.

title: Mary Sansone
description: To the Editor:

title: Super Bowl Ads Live On at YouTube and Facebook
description: Do you remember which team won the Super Bowl last year? Do you remember which was your favorite ad?

title: A Hefty Payoff for a Comic (and Steelers Fan)
description: Right about the time the Pittsburgh Steelers were starting a run to another Super Bowl, Billy Gardell, a lifelong fan and native son of the Steel City, was beginning his own season as the star of a new CBS sitcom and taping his first prime-time stand-up comedy special  a show that will appear the night before his team takes the field in Dallas.

title: Super Bowls Bit Players Get Their Due
description: Not every Super Bowl feature is about Ben Roethlisberger, Troy Polamalu, or the price of a 30-second commercial. Role players, backups, and coaches suddenly become media darlings, as hometown papers profile neighborhood kids who grew up to become backup linebackers and news outlets cast a wide net for undiscovered coverage angles. No Super Bowl participant is too obscure for a few candelas of the limelight, not even:

title: On Our Radar: Rare Aerial Footage of Isolated Amazon Tribe
description: A film crew accompanying a researcher with Brazils Indian Affairs department captures rare aerial footage of a highly isolated tribe living deep in the Amazon rain forest, near the Peru-Brazil border. Advocates for the regions indigenous people say illegal logging in Peru is driving other isolated tribes across the border into Brazil, causing conflicts over resources and territory. Responding to the release of video and images of the tribe, Peruvian authorities said this week that they would work to stop the intrusion of loggers into protected areas. [Survival International]

title: Some Taxes Went Up
description: A reader thinks I owe you a correction for saying, in my column today:

title: Not Pennies and Not Quite From Heaven
description: THE forecast is in for Super Bowl weekend, and once again, it looks like rain. At least thats the word from Dallas, where news reports surfaced this week that Hines Ward and other members of the Pittsburgh Steelers huddled at the Dallas Gentlemens Club one night, with some of them indulging in a strip-club ritual known as making it rain, i.e., showering dancers with fistfuls of cash.

title: Jessica Phillips and Greg Minah
description: WHAT if you held a wedding but no one came  and thats just the way you wanted it?

title: In New Yorks Little Egypt, the Young Get a New Awareness
description: For Esmaeel El Sayed, the 16-year-old son of immigrants in Astoria, Queens, the hierarchy of life had always been clear: Madonna trumped Naguib Mahfouz, Big Macs were to be savored over baba ghanouj, and being American overshadowed being Egyptian, Arab and Muslim.

title: Best Seats in the House
description: HEY, boobie, talk to me, the Ticket Man said.

title: Shumway to Return Money to Investors
description: Chris Shumway learned a tough lesson in November, when he announced that he was stepping down as chief investment officer of his giant hedge fund, Shumway Capital Partners.

title: Arts & Leisure Preview: Matthew Perry, That Championship Season, Vidal Sassoon and More
description: I used to spend a lot of time just thinking about myself, thinking that the party started when I showed up. Im far from that man, now.Matthew Perry, who is producing and starring in a new comedy, Mr. Sunshine.

title: Off the Menu: Jones Wood Foundry
description: Despite his French training and a previous stint at Orsay, the chef Jason Hicks has gone back to his roots in a Cotswolds village for Jones Wood Foundry, a pub in a part of the city once called Jones Wood. Its opening on Feb. 14.

title: Super Bowl vs. Hockey, Compare and Contrast
description: Its a great weekend to be a sports fan. The N.H.L. has a packed schedule through Sunday afternoon, at which point the Super Bowl takes over the spotlight. But while the games will be entertaining, the transition may be jarring.

title: Bank of America to Create Troubled Loans Unit
description: Bank of America said Friday that it would create a unit to handle 1.3 million soured mortgages as Brian T. Moynihan, the banks chief executive, tried to distance the company from the fallout of the mortgage crisis.

title: Weekend Fare
description: Savoy, which is serving a daily cassoulet special in February, is hosting a tasting festival Saturday at the restaurant, 70 Prince Street (Crosby Street), from 12:30 to 3:30 p.m. Chefs from Back Forty, Cookshop, Fatty Johnsons, Nuela, Vinegar Hill House and WD-50 will prepare different versions of cassoulet. The $65 ticket includes wine, but not tax or gratuity.

title: Lawsuits Claim Tesla Executive Negligent in Airplane Crash
description: Doug Bourn, the Tesla Motors executive who was killed last year when the airplane he was piloting struck high power wires in East Palo Alto, Calif., had not flown for 18 months before the day of the crash, according to two lawsuits filed against his estate by the families of the other men killed in the accident.

title: The Elephant in the Showroom
description: INFINITI has a new hybrid on the way. The M35h, due in the spring, is said to be the only vehicle to offer more than 350 horsepower along with a 30 mile per gallon economy rating on the highway. Thats an admirable achievement, and Im sure that plenty of Infiniti buyers will take note of the new hybrid as they stroll past it on their way to buy a new 400-horsepower, 5,850-pound QX56 4WD. As the sales charts prove, the death of the S.U.V. has been much exaggerated.

title: Fortune Brands on Track For Breakup
description: Fortune Brands, in its fourth-quarter earnings announcement on Friday, said the company was on track to split into three businesses.

title: Erica Rosen, Daniel Stellar
description: Erica Rosen and Daniel Stellar were married Saturday evening at Thalassa Restaurant in Manhattan. Claire Slemmer, a friend of the couple who became an officiant for the occasion through American Marriage Ministries, performed the ceremony.

title: Piraye Yurttas and Nicholas Beim
description: Piraye Yurttas and Nicholas Frederick Beim were married Saturday evening at the main branch of the New York Public Library. E. Leo Milonas, the retired chief administrative judge of the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court in Manhattan and a friend of the bridegrooms family, officiated. On March 19, the couple will take part in a celebration incorporating Turkish wedding traditions at Esma Sultan Mansion in Istanbul.

title: Jessica Mozeico, Jordan Blair
description: Jessica H. Mozeico and Jordan J. Blair were married Saturday on the Kohala Coast on the Big Island of Hawaii. The Rev. A. J. Di Mauro, a Community of Christ minister, officiated at the Fairmont Orchid Resort.

title: Carla Stuart and Habib Azar
description: Carla Stuart and Habib Azar were married Thursday at the Mandarin Oriental, a hotel in New York. Former Mayor David N. Dinkins officiated. On Feb. 15, the couple are to take part in a Masai wedding ceremony at the Whistling Thorn Camp in Tanzania, which is to be conducted by two Masai elders, Kirikindawa Ming-Arana and Sakaya Lomnyaki.

title: Nina Sassoon, Eliav Assouline
description: Nina Sassoon, a daughter of Evelyn and Salomon Sassoon of New York, was married Saturday evening to Eliav Assouline, a son of Mimi and Joseph Assouline of Montreal. Rabbi Haskel Lookstein officiated at the Pierre in New York.

title: Julie Cencebaugh, David Kloth
description: Julie Cencebaugh and Dr. David S. Kloth were married Monday at Point Lookout, a villa on Mustique, a private resort island in the Grenadines. Tamara Gibson-Marks, the registrar of the high court of St. Vincent and the Grenadines, officiated.

title: Mark Maher, Louis Miller
description: Mark Edward Maher and Dr. Louis Hal Miller were married Friday in Greenwich, Conn. Richard F. Kriskey, a justice of the peace, officiated at Greenwich Town Hall.

title: Kristen Landino, Vikrant Agnihotri
description: Kristen Landino and Vikrant Agnihotri were married Friday night at Samode Palace, a hotel in Jaipur, India. Pandit Mukesh Sharma led a Hindu ceremony.

title: Strangest Part of the Jobs Report
description: The unemployment rate has declined more in the last two months than in any two months since 1958.

title: Randy Hadden and Jeremy Silver
description: Randy Hadden and Jeremy Silver were married Wednesday morning in Greenwich, Conn. Jon Hunt, a Connecticut justice of the peace, officiated at Greenwich Town Hall. On Saturday, the couple had a commitment ceremony at the Casa Marina Resort in Key West, Fla., that incorporated readings by friends and family members, with Mr. Silver stepping on a glass in the Jewish tradition and another exchange of vows.

description: Bank of America said on Friday that it would create a unit to handle 1.3 million soured mortgages, as Brian T. Moynihan, the banks chief executive, stepped up efforts to distance the company from the fallout of the mortgage crisis, The New York Times reports.

description: In redesigning the QX, Infiniti put a lot of thought into improving the experience of owning a monster truck.

title: The Net Delusion and the Egypt Crisis
description: Its not often that a nonfiction book appears whose thesis is immediately tested by events. But such is the fate of Evgeny Morozovs Net Delusion, which I review in this Sundays Book Review. Morozovs argument that the internet does more harm than good in political contexts is running up against violent reality in Egypt.

description: To the Editor:

description: Now that Ally Financial has picked four underwriters for its forthcoming initial public offering, banks are getting another chance to pick up a piece of the sale action on bailout stocks.

title: A Special on His Menu
description: LATE in 2009, not long after finishing construction work on Saraghina, his carefully considered pizzeria-restaurant that occupies a street corner in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn, Massimiliano Nanni bought a 65 Ford Econoline pickup.

title: Riccardo Muti to Have Surgery
description: Riccardo Muti, the Italian maestro and music director of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra, will have surgery to repair multiple facial and jaw fractures suffered when he collapsed on the podium during a rehearsal on Thursday and fell to the stage, the orchestra said on Friday.

title: For Car Cassette Decks, Play Time Is Over
description: FOR all of you who were planning to pack up your oldies tapes and go shopping for a 2011 car, there is bad news: youre too late. According to experts who monitor the automotive market, the last new car to be factory-equipped with a cassette deck in the dashboard was a 2010 Lexus.

title: Exploding Bombs and Wounded Eyes: From Blindness Back to Patrol
description: By any reasonable measure, Specialist Peter Sprenger, a radio operator in an Army infantry company, could easily have been dead. It was Dec. 19, 2003, in Talafar, Iraq. An Iraqi man driving an explosives-laden car had breached his companys perimeter. American soldiers fired at him with light machine guns, but the driver accelerated toward the company command post.

title: Rescuing Pet Sounds
description: SHIFTING storage technologies catch up with all of us sooner or later, rendering those Betamax movies unwatchable and tax records stored on floppy disks unusable, at least until they are transferred to a readable medium.

title: A Substitution at the Met
description: Illness will keep Matthew Polenzani out of tonights Metropolitan Opera production of Don Pasquale. Barry Banks will take over for him in the role of Ernesto, the Met said. Banks sang the role at the Met in November 2010.

title: Chrysler Chief Apologizes for Comment on Terms of U.S. Loans
description: Feb. 6, 3:28 p.m. | Updated

title: Who Am I? Friday Edition
description: All week, the Fifth Down blog will post Who Am I? quizzes to test your knowledge of Packers and Steelers of the past. Peeking at Pro Football Reference just ruins the fun for everyone, so dont do it!

description: Far fewer partners switched law firms last year than in 2009, according to an article in The American Lawyer this week.

title: Look of the Moment | Hailee Steinfeld
description: The Look: Bold and beautiful. You dont have to read between the lines. Stripes are big for spring.

title: Dogtooth': No Indifference Allowed
description: In the Oscar competition for best-foreign language film, the entry from Greece, Dogtooth, is definitely the outlier  and underdog. In one fashion or another, all four of the other films are outwardly directed, addressing aspects of relations between the West and the Third World. Dogtooth, in contrast, is hermetic, a study of a family in which the parents have decided to literally wall their children off from the rest of the world in order to protect them from malign outside influences.
