description: CAIRO  We had been detained by Egyptian authorities, handed over to the countrys dreaded Mukhabarat, the secret police, and interrogated. They left us all night in a cold room, on hard orange plastic stools, under fluorescent lights.

title: Chic in Review | Kate Middleton, Spice Girl?
description: All the fashion news of the week thats fit to reprint.

title: Liszt, the Chick Magnet, Tickled Ivories and More
description: Liszt is sometimes remembered as a purveyor of pianistic bling, a virtuoso who wrote flamboyant music that was entertaining but rarely profound. He was undeniably a showman, a 19th-century rock star who seduced his female fans with his jaw-dropping technique. But he was also a devout Roman Catholic who renounced his socialite lifestyle for a brief stint in a monastery, a compositional rehab during which he wrote sacred choral works and piano scores with religious themes.

title: A Violinist and Novelist, and, Yes, Composer
description: The violinist Eugene Drucker is well known as a founding member of the Emerson String Quartet; until recently, few knew that he was a composer as well.

description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration said on Friday that Chinas currency remained substantially undervalued compared with the dollar but declined once again to cite Beijing for currency manipulation.

description: As Stuart Elliott writes, major brands are hoping to build message momentum before Sundays broadcast by posting their Super Bowl commercials online.

description: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

title: From Sputnik to SunShot
description: The energy secretary, Steven Chu, was publicly using the phrase Sputnik moment two months before President Obama picked it up in the State of the Union speech to describe the need for a national effort to improve competitiveness in a technical field. Now he has moved on to a new space-challenge term: SunShot.

title: The Gamble of Lending Peer to Peer
description: When peer-to-peer online lending first became possible in the United States five years ago, using the Web to make money by lending it to fellow citizens in need seemed wonderfully subversive.

title: Peer-to-Peer Lending: What the Future Holds
description: In this weekends Your Money column, I take a look at the two leading peer-to-peer lenders, which are both trying to exit their awkward adolescent phases.

title: Remembering Fondly the Tallest Guy at the Table
description: Harry Stappenbeck, probably the worlds tallest bridge expert at 6 feet 11 inches, died on Jan. 28, at 71. He lived his whole life in Uniondale, N.Y., and never married.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, Feb. 4

title: Appreciating Nene
description: The Carmelo Anthony trade saga has been one of this seasons dominant storylines. With all the focus on whether or not Anthony will still be a Nugget after this seasons trade deadline or next summer, the fact that the Nuggets are currently the best offensive team in basketball has been lost in the shuffle. The Nuggets defense has kept them from being one of the Wests elite teams this season, but they have done an excellent job of surrounding Anthony with efficient offensive players. And no Nugget has been more efficient than Nene.

title: Playing That Outgrows a Cozy Space
description: Three intimate concerts for $64, the New Music in the Rose series of the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center is one of New Yorks great deals. But while the Rose Studio has cozy charm, it was heartening to hear the preconcert announcement on Thursday evening that next season the series will move to the adjacent, larger Kaplan Penthouse because of overwhelming demand for tickets.

title: A Super Bowl Minus the Pompoms
description: DALLAS  A substantial wing of the Dallas Cowboys suburban headquarters is devoted to the Dallas Cowboys Cheerleaders. On Thursday afternoon, in an immense dance studio, members of the worlds most famous cheer squad rehearsed for one of their dozens of appearances surrounding the Super Bowl this week.

description: The Knight Arts Program sponsors pop-up cultural events, such as this chorale performance in a Philadelphia Macy's.

description: WHEN it comes to dessert, my husband is a man of simple tastes, perfectly content as long as chocolate features prominently, and preferably in the form of chewy, dark brownies.

title: Short Allows Ivanchuk to Overtake Him at Gibraltar

title: School Production Of Wilson Play Delayed
description: A student production of Joe Turners Come and Gone that overcame the objections of a school superintendent in order to proceed has been temporarily halted by Mother Nature. The Waterbury Arts Magnet School in Waterbury, Conn., had planned to perform that August Wilson play this week, but postponed the performances after the recent heavy snowfalls in the Northeast. Dana Manning, the schools fine arts coordinator, told The Republican-American newspaper of Waterbury that the bad weather had prevented rehearsals. Additional performances planned for next week were also likely to be rescheduled and new dates were not immediately announced. The Waterbury Board of Education said in January that the schools production of the play, set in 1911 at a Pittsburgh boardinghouse where several freed slaves reside, could proceed, overruling an earlier decision by the superintendent, David L. Snead. Mr. Snead, who is black, had sought to cancel the play because the word nigger appears multiple times in its dialogue. During the board meeting at which the decision was announced, the production was defended by the high school students in its cast, as well as by James Bundy, artistic director of Yale Repertory Theater, where Joe Turner and other Wilson plays were developed.

title: Goldmans Buyout Unit Nears Deal for Applebees Operator
description: Goldman Sachss private equity unit is nearing a deal to buy Apple American Group, the biggest franchisee of Applebees Neighborhood Grill and Bar, a person briefed on the matter said Friday.

title: Death at Soho House
description: SYLVIE CACHAY started the morning of Dec. 8 the same way she started every day before it, wondering what she could do to get her swimwear business back off the ground. She was a promising young designer, but one who was frustrated by having to work for someone elses company, not her own.

title: A Loophole in a Verizon iPhone Rule
description: In my review of the Verizon iPhone this week, I noted that, because its a phone that works on a CDMA network (the type Sprint and Verizon use), you cant make a phone call and surf the Web simultaneously. Thats a crucial difference between the Verizon and AT&T versions of the iPhone.

title: Archive of the American Songbook Finds a New Home in the Heartland
description: Michael Feinstein is perhaps best known as a singer and pianist and the owner of a cabaret on Manhattans Upper East Side that bears his name. Hes also well known as a passionate historian of American song and for his vast collection of memorabilia. Now his collection will be housed at a new performing arts center in Carmel, Ind., a three-hour drive from his childhood home.

title: Coney Island, 4:32 P.M.
Lets Sing About People Who Dont Speak Like Us
description: Theres good news for those who find hilarity in the idea that people who are not native English-speakers tend to speak English imperfectly: The Road to Qatar!, a new musical from the York Theater Company, stands ready to pummel them with that fact for 90 intermissionless minutes. But anyone with a higher threshold for humor, or with a low tolerance for mocking people of different nationalities, will find little to laugh at here.

description: Theres nothing like seeing the seats next to you wrapped in black plastic garbage bags to give you a slight feeling of unease about the performance to come, particularly when a theater employee politely asks people to keep their coats tucked away. Liquids? Bodies?

title: Among the Muslim Brotherhood
description: It is almost impossible to convince yourself that a band of young men holding machetes, pipes and two-by-fours have only your safety in mind when they stop your car. Even after the 20th checkpoint, your heart still beats faster, and that tingle ripples over you until one of the men pops up your windshield wipers, signaling for the next group down the road that your car has been checked.

title: The Tale Those Strings Can Tell
description: You might think that writing program music automatically provides a composer with a structure for a long piece. The way this genre has typically been practiced, the music is supposed to illustrate a story. As long as the story has structure, the music should too.

description: WHITE PLAINS

description: In his Wealth Matters column this week, Paul Sullivan writes that recent disclosures of the names of people holding accounts in overseas banks mean that the wealthy are taking their chances if they think those accounts will remain secret.

5 Likable Players of the Blame Game

description: Its quite strange that Apple chose the name iPad for its tablet computer as you cant actually use it the way one would use a pad of paper, specifically when it comes to drawing or writing with a pen.

title: A Faithful but Strained Adaptation
description: It seems certain that a knowledge of Mandarin, and of the folkways of contemporary Beijings moneyed classes, are necessary to get all the jokes in What Women Want, a Chinese remake of the American romantic comedy that starred Mel Gibson and Helen Hunt. But as you watch this strained, lifeless imitation, it also seems pretty certain that knowing the language wouldnt make the film actually  whats the right word?  funny.

description: WEST SIMSBURY, Conn.

description: CARACAS, Venezuela

title: A Bloodless Ripoff Substitutes Sex for Suspense
description: Substituting sex for suspense and pop music for ideas, the director Christian E. Christiansen drags The Roommate  a bloodless ripoff of Barbet Schroeders deliciously trashy 1992 thriller, Single White Female  from limp beginning to lame conclusion. And while Mr. Schroeder could conjure knife-blade tension from an episode of Antiques Roadshow, Mr. Christiansen succeeds only in conjuring monotony.

title: Better Penmanship, Less Pain
description: SCIENCE has proved that memory does far better at fashioning simple, meaningful stories about ones childhood than objectively preserving truth in amber. Small wonder, then, that memories and narratives often differ  if not outright clash  depending on whom they belong to and whom they serve.

title: Yogas Stress Relief: An Aid for Infertility?
description: KIMBERLY SORANNO, a 39-year-old Brooklynite undergoing an in vitro fertilization cycle as part of her quest to become pregnant, had gone to her share of yoga classes, but never one like that held on a recent Tuesday night in a reception area of the New York University Fertility Center. There were no deep twists or headstands; just easy restorative poses as the teacher, Tracy Toon Spencer, guided the participants  most of them women struggling to conceive  to let go of their worries.

title: Lacking Peace Talks, Israel Offers Economic Package for Palestinians
description: JERUSALEM  Israel announced on Friday a package of steps meant to develop infrastructure and encourage economic growth in the Palestinian territories, in what appeared to be an effort to mollify the Western-backed Palestinian Authority leadership and allay international criticism in the absence of peace talks.

title: 3 SUNY Graduates File Suit to Get a Tuition Break
description: RAQUEL BALSAM enjoyed four memorable years at Binghamton University, majoring in English, playing club tennis, hosting her own television show and volunteering for a local youth program. As an out-of-state student at Binghamton, which is part of the State University of New York, she paid $36,000 in tuition, almost twice as much as in-state students.

title: 40 Years On, Detective Sees Light Shed on a Killing
description: The front door was locked, so police officers broke into the Upper East Side apartment from the back. They found a dead woman lying against an overturned bed, with a rope tied around her neck. Her bra had been pulled up over her head, and someone had bitten her left breast.

title: In Census, Young Americans Increasingly Diverse
description: WASHINGTON  Demographers sifting through new population counts released on Thursday by the Census Bureau say the data bring a pattern into sharper focus: Young Americans are far less white than older generations, a shift that demographers say creates a culture gap with far-reaching political and social consequences.

title: American Makes Best of Second Chance in England
description: CHORLEY, England  The practice session began as it would for most soccer players across England, with a juggling drill. In a small circle, they kept the ball in the air, passing it to one another. For Bolton Wanderers, an English Premier League team, there was a playfully cruel twist to the game: the first man to let the ball touch the ground would have his ears flicked by every member of the team.

title: Ringmaster of the Royal Bachelor Party
description: LONDON

title: Martin Assesses His Hall of Fame Chances
description: DALLAS  Curtis Martins career with New England and the Jets was much like the man himself: understated, consistent, workmanlike. Only Martin and Barry Sanders topped 1,000 rushing yards in each of their first 10 seasons. Only Emmitt Smith, Walter Payton and Sanders gained more rushing yards than Martins 14,101.

title: California Law to Curb Greenhouse Gases Faces a Legal Hurdle
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Californias landmark law on curbing greenhouse gases, which is well on its way to taking effect, has hit a legal snag in the form of a tentative judicial ruling that state environmental regulators failed to follow legally required procedures.

title: A Mere Shovel? Show the Snow Whos Boss
description: It will be beautiful as it falls and magical as it dusts the ground, and seconds later, New Yorks next snowfall will be an urban nuisance, slipping your step, burying your car and lining your curbs with the slushie of doom.

title: How to Grow a Social Business
description: In Tuesdays column, When Microcredit Wont Do, I wrote about microconsignment, a way for village entrepreneurs to sell innovative and important products for which there is no established market  such as solar lamps, water purifiers, stoves and reading glasses  without having to take on debt. Instead, village women are given the products and the training to sell them. Once they make the sale, they repay the supplier and keep a portion of the proceeds. Done right, microconsignment provides new businesses for village women  and helps make life healthier and more prosperous for her neighbors.

title: Lawyer Disputes Portrayal of Detainee
description: WASHINGTON  The lawyer for a prisoner at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, who died this week, apparently of a heart attack, is criticizing the Defense Department for its portrayal of the mans connections to Al Qaeda.

title: Request for an Emergency Rule on Border Gun Sales Is Denied
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration on Friday rejected a request for an emergency rule requiring gun dealers along the Mexican border to report bulk sales of assault rifles, a proposal intended to make it harder for drug cartels to smuggle weapons.

description: Dallas

title: Discontented Within Egypt Face Power of Old Elites
description: CAIRO  It was proclaimed as the Friday of departure, but neither the demonstrators who proved their staying power as a force for change nor their nemesis, President Hosni Mubarak, left. Now a prolonged collision is shaping up between a staggering but entrenched old guard and an outpouring of Egypts discontented over how fast and how deep the changes will be.

title: In Politics, Every Day Is a Workday
description: Sheldon Silver, 66, who has been speaker of the New York State Assembly since 1994, grew up on the Lower East Side, where he still lives with Rosa, his wife of 44 years. Mr. Silver works many Sundays, but also spends time at family meals and takes some of his 18 grandchildren on outings. HELAINA HOVITZ

title: Obama Faults Spy Agencies Performance in Gauging Mideast Unrest, Officials Say

description: PASHMUL, Afghanistan  If the commander of coalition forces, Gen. David H. Petraeus, has sounded triumphant lately  telling his officers they have their teeth in the enemys jugular  this newly conquered patch of southern Afghanistan is one reason for that.

title: Day of Rage for Syrians Fails to Draw Protesters
description: DAMASCUS, Syria  In stark contrast to several other Arab capitals, where hundreds of thousands of people have demonstrated against their governments, a planned Day of Rage in Damascus on Friday failed to attract any protesters against President Bashar al-Assad, a sign that the opposition here remains too weak to challenge one of the regions most entrenched ruling parties.

title: U.S. Trying to Balance Israels Needs in the Face of Egyptian Reform
description: WASHINGTON  The demonstrations against President Hosni Mubaraks government in Egypt are rocking the relationship between the United States and its most important Arab ally. But they are also rocking an even more fundamental relationship for the United States  its 60-year alliance with Israel.

title: Jet From J.F.K. Came Close to 2 Air Force Cargo Planes
description: WASHINGTON  An American Airlines jumbo jet that took off from Kennedy International Airport on the evening of Jan. 20 heading southeast toward Brazil came within a mile of a formation of two Air Force C-17 cargo planes, the National Transportation Safety Board said Friday. The board has begun a major investigation.

title: Iraqi Leader, With Eye on Discontent, Says Hell Cut His Salary in Half
description: BAGHDAD  Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki of Iraq said Friday that he would cut his salary in half, apparently in an effort to defuse growing dissatisfaction among Iraqis about the lack of government services.

title: A Sports Bar Without the Pickup Lines
description: Second Avenue can seem like one long line of watering holes connecting the Upper and Lower East Sides, with high-spirited crowds spilling out from shamrock-adorned pubs, neon-lighted dives and, naturally, sports bars. But BB&R  for Blonde, Brunette and a Redhead  is something of a hybrid, a cozy hangout between 89th and 90th Streets that offers organic India pale ale, Veuve Clicquot by the glass and prosciutto-topped pizza along with the requisite Bud Light and 13 televisions screens that can display their own games in the two rooms. With exposed brick walls accented by panels from wood wine crates, a Ping-Pong table and a pool table, and a photo booth, the bar attracts its share of sports fans, groups of young men and women out for a drink after work and, on Wednesday, two residents of the neighborhood. DIANE CARDWELL

title: E-Readers Catch Younger Eyes and Go in Backpacks
description: Something extraordinary happened after Eliana Litos received an e-reader for a Hanukkah gift in December.

title: It May Be a Sputnik Moment, but Science Fairs Are Lagging
description: Rarely have school science fairs, a source of pride and panic for generations of American students, achieved such prominence on the national stage. President Obama held one at the White House last fall. And last week he said that America should celebrate its science fair winners like Sundays Super Bowl champions, or risk losing the nations competitive edge.

title: In Panels Votes to Close Low-Performing Schools, Rage and Foregone Decisions
description: They knew how the script was going to end. Still, on Thursday night, 2,000 students, parents, teachers and union officials filed into Brooklyn Technical High School, voicing their frustration for five hours.

title: @bergdorfs
description: TWEETING SINCE January 2010

title: Awards That Best Predict Oscar Voting Favor The Kings Speech
description: Nate Silver is providing awards-season insight for Carpetbagger leading up to the 83rd Academy Awards on Feb. 27. Mr. Silver is the author of The Timess FiveThirtyEight blog, which is devoted to the analysis of statistics and data in politics and other areas.

title: Cuomo Takes Aim at Fixed Spending Increases
description: ALBANY  The Sunrise Nursing Home and the Manor at Seneca Hill nursing home sit just a few miles from each other in Oswego County near the shores of Lake Ontario. They each have 120 beds and serve comparable patient populations.

title: Lottery Numbers
Welcome to Jerrys World
description: DALLAS  The most visible owner in Super Bowl history held his own news conference Tuesday. He talked, as only Jerry Jones can talk, for 75 minutes.

title: Awards That Best Predict Oscar Voting Favor The Kings Speech
description: Since I last wrote about this years Academy Award nominees for Best Picture, there has been a significant shift in the conventional wisdom about the probable winner. The Social Network, which was once considered as likely as 90 percent certain to win by betting markets, is now given only about a 20 percent chance. The Kings Speech, instead, has become the heavy favorite.

title: District Liked Its Earmarks, Then Elected Someone Who Didnt
description: In the villages, towns and cities of the 19th Congressional District north of New York City, the signs of federal largess are all over: money for a library in South Salem, road improvements in Peekskill, renovations on an aging bridge in Dover and a communications network for the Police Department in Tuxedo.

title: Caribbean Warmth
description: Elouise Moulton, whose nickname is Tunie, grew up in St. Ann Parish, Jamaica, helping out at her mothers restaurant. She says she always knew how to cook. So it is no surprise that Pon Di Riva, her new restaurant just steps from the Ossining train station, feels a bit like the Caribbean, especially when it comes to warmth.

title: Authentic Thai Food That Stands Apart
description: ALTHOUGH Id heard that Bangkok Spice in Shrub Oak was a strong and authentic Thai spot, I had my doubts, having found much of the Thai offerings in Westchester numbingly similar and often greasy. But after a couple of recent visits to this unassuming restaurant, where the sauces are excellent, the preparation reliably good and the menu a bit more than standard fare, I had to agree  it does stand apart.

title: Politics and the Court
description: When it comes to pushing the line between law and politics, Justices Antonin Scalia and Clarence Thomas each had a banner month in January.

title: Wilpons Ownership of Mets Is Threatened
description: Fred Wilpons ability to hold onto the Mets was cast into more doubt Friday when a lawsuit filed by the trustee in the Bernard L. Madoff fraud case was unsealed and revealed in vivid detail the depth of Madoffs involvement in nearly every aspect of Wilpons empire, particularly his team.

title: Saying Its Time, but Sounding Less Certain
description: On a scale of 1 to 10, Andy Pettittes level of certitude seemed to be a 5. Halfway convinced he couldnt grind out another year with the Yankees in New York, he opted for an unforced retirement in Houston to watch his children play sports and begin to figure out what to do with the rest of his life.

title: Enough for a Polish Banquet
description: Polish Delicatessen is so true to its East European origins that it would be quite at home on a Krakow street corner. Shelves are stocked with jars, boxes and cellophane-wrapped packages of foods made in or near Poland, and many of the magazines for sale are in Polish.

title: Balancing the Tastes of Thai Cuisine
description: THE gentle charm of Ayuthai Royal Thai Cuisine, a family-owned restaurant in Guilford, reveals itself quietly throughout the meal  in good food that is consistently fresh and light, and unobtrusive service that is just formal enough to make the meal feel like a night out.

title: No Frills, Just Sweet Treats
description: Fay Da Bakery, an expanding chain based in New York, has had its only New Jersey outpost tucked inside the Hong Kong Supermarket in East Brunswick since 2000.

title: Saturday: Red Wear for Speedy Gonzales
description: SATURDAYS PUZZLE  I started this puzzle at the bottom for a change of pace, and Im glad I did. Its a very cool ending, even though I think its a tad bossy of Mark Diehl to insist that I get dressed up to solve his puzzle.

title: Cuisine to Match a Striking Setting
description: ITS hard to imagine anyone more eager for the Big Thaw this spring than the owners of Maritime Parc in Jersey City, tucked away in Liberty State Park flush up against the Liberty Landing Marina. It is also flush up against what was once the eastern end of the Morris Canal, which for much of the 19th century linked Pennsylvania coal country to the Hudson River. That bit of Industrial Age history is lost these days, though, amid the bobbing pleasure craft and imposing views of Jersey City and Lower Manhattan to the north and east, and of the Statue of Liberty off to the south.

title: Knife, Fork and Candy Bar
description: Michael Mignano, the chef and owner of Main Street Bakery and Cafe in Port Washington, serves his specialty candy bar on a plate, with a knife and fork (or sliced).

title: Sudan: North-South Clash Kills 9
description: At least nine people, including a United Nations staff member, have been killed in clashes between southern and northern soldiers from a joint-integrated unit, officials said Friday. The fighting began Thursday evening after soldiers from a joint unit in Malakal were ordered to redeploy to the north, and a group of southern soldiers refused. The situation is still very dangerous, said Bartholomew Pakwan Abwol, a state government spokesman. We dont know how many have died.

title: Blighted Area? These Business Owners Beg to Differ
description: Damon Baes commercial laundry on Third Avenue in East Harlem may never be mistaken for the kind of glamorous businesses found near Wall Street, Times Square or Madison Avenue, but it is a thriving concern in this neighborhood of three- and four-story buildings and vacant lots.

title: Corrections
description: NEW YORK

title: Old-Fashioned Charm, Updated
description: FOR over half a century the Old Fields Inn has been a fixture in Greenlawn. Known for its marinated steaks, it was the place where the Kiwanis and Lions Clubs met. When I last visited, a couple of years ago, it was tired and lackluster. Last June, David and Christine Tunney bought the venerable old place, took five months to renovate it and reopened it in November with a shortened name: Old Fields.

title: Britain: Cricket-Fixing Charges
description: Prosecutors said Friday that three members of the Pakistani cricket team that toured England last summer would be tried on charges of spot-fixing elements of a five-day contest in London in August. The three men  Mohammed Amir, Salman Butt and Mohammed Asif  will face charges of conspiracy to accept bribes and conspiracy to cheat. Their agent, Mazhar Majeed, was also indicted. The four are alleged to have accepted tens of thousands of dollars in illicit payments from a News of the World reporter posing as a middleman for Asia-based betting syndicates.

title: Maker That Sold Gloves to Fire Dept. Closes Plant
description: The manufacturer that sold the New York City Fire Department $800,000 worth of flawed fire-retardant gloves sent word to its workers and others this week that it was closing its plant, in Arkansas, officials said. The company, the Glove Corporation, hinted in its announcement to its workers that its difficulties were a direct result of the troubled contract with New York.

title: China: Officials Say Tibetan Lama Is Not a Chinese Spy as India Says
description: A Chinese official, Xu Zhitao, has denied accusations by Indian officials that a revered Tibetan leader living in India is a spy for the Chinese government, Chinese news reports said this week. Indian officials first accused the Tibetan, the 17th Karmapa Lama, left, of being a spy after Indian police officers seized $1.5 million worth of foreign currency, including Chinese renminbi, last month from the lamas home in Dharamsala. There is a dispute over the Karmapa Lama; a rival candidate who has close ties to Indian intelligence officials claims he is the true lama. Tibetan Buddhisms spiritual leader, the Dalai Lama, backs the one in Dharamsala, seen by many Tibetans as a possible future leader.

title: Even the Middle Ground Is Perilous in Cairo
description: Photographers of the increasingly violent upheaval in Egypt are being forced  in the interest of personal safety  to adopt practices that limit their range of coverage at exactly the moment the world is hungriest for as many images from as many perspectives as possible.

title: Health Fund Adds Fraud Checks
description: The Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria announced steps on Friday to strengthen antifraud safeguards, including doubling the budget for internal investigations. The group acted after a Jan. 23 article by The Associated Press described corruption in grants to Mali, Mauritania, Zambia and Djibouti. The fund said it was seeking to recover $34 million from those and other countries, an amount it said was less than 1 percent of the $13 billion in aid it has disbursed in 145 countries.

title: Iraq: Plane Crash Kills 7
description: A private plane crashed in the northern city of Sulaimaniya shortly after takeoff on Friday, killing all seven passengers and crew members, officials said. The plane, bound for Ankara, Turkey, was carrying several businessmen, including an American, according to local officials and an American official. The airport director said the crash was believed to have been caused by technical problems, and there were no indications of terrorism.

title: Bloggingheads: Stability or Human Rights
description: David Corn of Mother Jones and James Pinkerton of Fox News debate Egypt and American foreign policy.

title: 76ers Beat Knicks, Continuing to Surge as Knicks Struggle
description: PHILADELPHIA  The ball found Shawne Williams in the left corner, his corner, the spot where he is most comfortable and where, just seconds earlier, he had hit a critical 3-pointer.

title: CNN Rises to the Top in Egypt Coverage
description: Pro-Mubarak forces once again clashed with anti-Mubarak forces on Friday. The brutal set-to didnt take place in Tahrir Square in Cairo, where as many as 100,000 demonstrators managed to assemble peacefully. The brick-throwing was on cable television, as Fox News and MSNBC anchors continued knocking heads over whats worse: the dictatorship we know or a democratic rebellion we cant control.

title: Drurys Knee Swells, Saving Coach From Tough Call
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  If ever an injury could be called timely, the one revealed when Chris Drury, the Rangers captain, missed practice Friday would qualify.

title: Why Yemen Wont Fall
description: London

title: Photo Replay: Feb. 4
description: A view of the day in sports from a world record attempt in Edmonton, Canada, to snowy conditions in Dallas.

title: Hiring Financier for Advice, Mets Owners Didnt Take It, Lawsuit Says
description: Saul Katz, the certified public accountant who in 1972 started Sterling Equities with his brother-in-law Fred Wilpon, almost never met a Bernard L. Madoff idea he did not like, according to a lawsuit brought by the trustee in the Madoff fraud. The Katz and Wilpon families, who own the Mets, had some 90 percent of their securities positions tied up in Madoffs brokerage for the nearly 25 years they did business with him.

title: The Know-Nothing Mets? Theres a Pattern Here
description: The owners of the Mets keep saying they did not have a clue what was going on in the matter of Bernard L. Madoff.

title: Too Much of a Good Thing
description: When Mayor Michael Bloomberg began his campaign against cigarette smoking eight years ago, most New Yorkers breathed a sigh of relief. The great indoors  bars, restaurants, hotels, office buildings  all are now smoke-free by law, making New York City a healthier place. And, for those already addicted or tempted, the city offered kits to help people stop smoking and gruesome television ads to try to keep them from starting.

title: The Disappearing Ethics Act
description: In a woeful signal to the new Congress, the House ethics committee has decided that when it comes to money and ethics, money nearly always wins.

title: The Kindling of Change
description: It is impossible to know exactly which embers spark a revolution, but its not so hard to measure the conditions that make a country prime for one.

title: The Achievement Gap
description: To the Editor:

title: Sudden Infant Death
description: To the Editor:

title: More Trade Follies
description: Its been more than three years since the Bush administration signed a trade agreement with South Korea. And for more than three years Congress has been balking at it. To overcome that opposition, the Obama administration got Seoul to improve the terms for American carmakers. Capitol Hill seemed happy  until it wasnt.

title: Parents and Adult Children
description: To the Editor:

title: Watching the Struggle for Egypt
description: To the Editor:

title: The Siege of Planned Parenthood
description: As if we didnt have enough wars, the House of Representatives has declared one against Planned Parenthood.

title: Bewitched by the Numbers
description: The data zealots have utterly discombobulated themselves.

title: Health Care in Mexico ... and in the U.S.
description: To the Editor:

title: Fighting Hunger in Yemen
description: To the Editor:

title: The Young and the Restless in Japan
description: To the Editor:

title: Newark Bears Hire Leyritz
description: The former Yankee catcher Jim Leyritz was hired as a pitching coach for the Newark Bears, an independent minor-league team. In November, Leyritz was cleared of manslaughter charges stemming from a fatal 2007 car accident. He was convicted of driving under the influence. The Yankees agreed to minor-league deals with infielders Ronnie Belliard and Eric Chavez that included invitations to spring training. Belliard, 35, who hit .216 last season for the Dodgers, is primarily a second baseman but has experience at all four infield positions. Chavez, 33, a third baseman who won six Gold Gloves with Oakland, has 230 career home runs, but injuries have limited him to 154 games over the last four seasons. chavez BEN SHPIGEL

title: Nocturnalist | How the Horses Got to the Ball
Ren Verdon, French Chef for the Kennedys, Dies at 86
description: Ren Verdon, whose position as the White House chef during the Kennedy administration helped him project the allure of classic French cuisine to the American public, died on Wednesday in San Francisco. He was 86.

title: Lena Nyman, Star of I Am Curious Films, Is Dead at 66
description: Lena Nyman, the Swedish actress whose performance in the sexually explicit movie I Am Curious (Yellow) raised the hackles of censors in the 1960s and helped turn the film into a box office bonanza, died on Friday in Stockholm. She was 66.

title: Gil Brandt Sees Overtime Game for Super Bowl
description: DALLAS  Gil Brandt, the former longtime vice president for player personnel for the Cowboys, has been to 42 of 44 Super Bowls. And he believes Super Bowl XLV is as closely matched as any of them.

title: Palin Keeps Position Clear and Intentions Vague
description: SANTA BARBARA, Calif.  Sarah Palin opened a weekend centennial celebration to Ronald Reagan by declaring that the United States was lurching toward a road to ruin, a nation so beleaguered by debt and out-of-control government spending that an urgent change in direction was needed in Washington.

title: The AgeLab at M.I.T.
description: The AgeLab at M.I.T. is partnering with businesses to develop new technologies geared toward helping seniors stay healthy, active and independent.

title: The Aging of America
description: Baby boomers began turning 65 in January, heralding a seismic shift in demographics worldwide. In the United States, by the year 2035, 1 in 5 people are expected to be age 65 or older.

title: In a Graying Population, Business Opportunity
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.

title: West Backs Gradual Egyptian Transition
description: This article is by Kareem Fahim, Mark Landler and Anthony Shadid.

title: The Weekend Word: Chill Out
description: From Todays Times:

title: Classic Ad: Requiem for the Tape Deck
description: In this Sundays Automobiles section, Stephen Williams documents the dying throes of the car stereo cassette deck, which as of the 2011 model year is no longer available as factory equipment  standard or optional  on any new car sold in the United States. (The 2010 Lexus SC 430 appears to have been the last holdout.)

title: Updates on Day 12 of Egypt Protests
description: The Lede provided updates on Saturday on the street protests and related developments in Egypt. For a summary, read the current version of our main news article from our colleagues in Cairo. Our updates mix breaking news alerts with reports from bloggers and journalists posted on other news sites and social networks. A stream of live Twitter updates appears in The Ledes right column. Readers can share information in the comment thread below or send photographs or video from Egypt to pix@nyt.com.

title: Super Bowl Is Hype. And the Hype Is Us.
description: Super Bowl hype is the sound of Americas conversation with itself.

title: Sexual Identity in Florida
description: Signs at Florida Atlantic University:

title: Voice Recognition, Still Imperfect
description: Ive been experimenting with Google Voice, which provides text versions of voice mails on my cell  quite useful. But not exactly 100% on recognition. My executive editor at Worth Publishers, which does Krugman/Wells, left a voice mail telling me that some student volunteers and the university president wanted a photo shoot before the Worth cocktail party, which they promised would only take about 5 minutes. At least thats what I think he said. The text version said:

title: Are You Paying Too Little in Taxes?
description: In a provocative article in the latest issue of Inc. magazine, Max Chafkin takes a look at the relationship between taxes and entrepreneurship. For the piece, Mr. Chafkin spent two weeks in Norway, which ranks higher than the United States in effective income tax rates and has a 1.1 percent wealth tax  but also has more entrepreneurs per capita and higher rates of start-up creation. The case of Norway, Mr. Chafkin writes, should give us pause: What if we have been wrong about taxes?

title: Protesters Remain in Tahrir Square
description: Protests in Egypt went for for a twelvth day, demonstrators are demanding the ousting of longtime President Hosni Mubarak.

title: Exchange Rates and Price Stickiness (Wonkish)
description: I mentioned recently that the correlation between nominal and real exchange rates is one key piece of evidence that we live in a Keynes-Friedman world of sticky prices, not the classical, perfect flexibility world of real business cycle theorists. Now that I have a few moments, let me elaborate on that.

title: Inflation, an Old Scourge, Plagues Argentina Again
description: BUENOS AIRES  Damian Vsquez used to regularly update the prices of household cleaning products on the sign outside his store. Today he often does not bother. Inflation has been causing prices to rise so fast that he grew tired of the effort to keep up.

title: Tuviah Friedman, Tireless Pursuer of Nazis, Dies at 88
description: In the months before and after the end of World War II, Tuviah Friedman tirelessly hunted Nazis as part of a militia in liberated Poland, and he reveled in his nickname, the Merciless One.

title: Iraq Restores Monument Symbolizing Hussein Era
description: BAGHDAD  As hundreds of thousands in Egypt protested the iron rule of that countrys president, Iraq quietly began restoring a bronze fist of its former dictator, Saddam Hussein.

title: Business News in Pictures
description: Photos reflecting news and features from last week in the business world.

title: Fun Facts, Quarterbacks and the Super Bowl
description: Luis DeLoureiro operates NFLStatAnalysis.net and is a contributor to the Cold Hard Football Facts. A longer version of this post is here.

title: The New Business of Old Age
description: The Times reports this morning on the development of technologies that may help to keep aging Americans out of long-term care facilities.

title: In Turkeys Example, Some See Map for Egypt
description: As Egypt struggles to reinvent itself, many experts in the region say that it might look to Turkey for some valuable lessons.

title: Preapproved: Well, It Sounded Good
description: MELISSA CALDERONE was ready for a fresh start when she made plans last year to move to Florida from New Jersey. Recently remarried, she signed a contract in mid-March on a house to be built in Windermere, Fla., by Pulte Homes, the nations largest homebuilder. The neighborhood had good schools for her three children and two stepchildren. It was also close to where Ms. Calderones parents lived.

title: Afghan Rights Fall Short for Christian Converts
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The jail commander had remained silent as the prisoner, Sayed Mussa, told a reporter about his journey from Islam to Christianity: his secret baptism nine years earlier, his faith in Jesus Christ and the promise of heaven.

title: Super Bowl XLV: The Night Before
description: Members of the Packers and Steelers talk about the emotions they expect to be dealing with on Saturday night.

title: U.S. and Russia Activate an Arms Control Treaty
description: MUNICH  The United States and Russia on Saturday exchanged documents that formally activated New Start, a strategic arms control treaty. It was the final step in a protracted negotiation marked by difficult talks with the Russians and even more difficult talks with Republican holdouts in the Senate.

title: Variety: 3-D Word Hunt
description: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE  Be vewy, vewy quiet. Were hunting wabbits. Sorry, I mean, words. Your puzzlemaster, Will Shortz, is back with his 3-D Word Hunt. Here are the directions, in case you missed them:

title: Twitter Patter | @bergdorfs
description: Tweeting Since January 2010Followers 36,217Twitter Bio Theres only one Bergdorf Goodman. And Im your insider access to the store, the windows, the designers, the fashion, the events and, well, a lot more.

title: Maliki Says He Wont Seek Another Term
description: BAGHDAD  Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki said Saturday that he would not seek re-election as leader of the Iraqi government after his current term ends in 2014. The statement came a day after Mr. Maliki, who began his second term in December, said he would cut his pay in half.

title: Meeting Space? In Her Eyes, Less Is More
description: This interview with Julie Greenwald, chairwoman and chief operating officer of the Atlantic Records Group,  was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

title: Letters: But How Do We Pay for Future Bailouts?
description: To the Editor:

title: Letters: The Pressure on Greece
description: To the Editor:

title: Soaring Food Prices
description: Whats behind the surge in food prices? The usual suspects have made the usual claims  its all about the Fed, or its all about speculators. But Ive been looking at the USDA World supply and demand estimates, and what stands out from the data is mainly that weve had a huge global harvest failure.

title: Capers and LeBeau Created and Share Defensive Blueprint
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  Dom Capers is trying to complete in Green Bay what he started in Pittsburgh 19 years ago.

title: A Second Tour as C.E.O.
description: I GREW up in Del Mar, Calif., north of San Diego. I got my first job the summer after eighth grade at a small Internet service provider. I called the owner, Christopher Alan, one day and asked if he had a summer internship or a job, and he took a chance on me. My mother would drive me to the train, and Id take along my skateboard to go from the San Diego train station to the office.

title: Cracking the Male Code of Office Behavior
description: FOR the last nine years, Ive been engaged in some of the most fascinating work a woman can do: talking to and surveying thousands of men to investigate what they think  and then writing books about it.

title: Rookie Unmoved by a Rapid Rise
description: FORT WORTH  As invisible as black ice during the regular season, James Starks awoke on Thursday to find his photograph on the front page of a national newspaper. Starks, the Green Bay Packers rookie tailback, did not seem impressed.

title: Clouds Part for Fab Fives Coach
description: SAN DIEGO  San Diego State has never won an N.C.A.A. mens basketball tournament game, yet has enough talent to win this years national championship. The team, which has sold out eight games in the programs history, now faces logistical problems with 1,500 students lining up for tickets before dawn on game days.

title: Cameron Criticizes Multiculturalism in Britain
description: LONDON  Faced with growing alarm about Islamic militants who have made Britain one of Europes most active bases for terrorist plots, Prime Minister David Cameron has mounted an attack on the countrys decades-old policy of multiculturalism, saying it has encouraged segregated communities where Islamic extremism can thrive.

title: Palin, Rallying Base, Paints Dark Picture of Obamas Policies
description: SANTA BARBARA, Calif.  Sarah Palin opened a celebration of Ronald Reagan this weekend by declaring that the United States was lurching toward a road to ruin, saying the nation had become so weighed down by debt and excess government that a new direction was urgently needed in Washington.

title: Hackers Gained Access to Nasdaq Systems, but Not Trades
description: Computer hackers have breached the systems of the company that runs the Nasdaq stock exchange in New York but did not penetrate the part of the system that handles trades, Nasdaq said Saturday.

title: Steelers Coach Takes a Quiet Route to Brilliance
description: Fort Worth

title: The Man Behind Spore Explores Gaming as Learning
description: At the National Academies summit exploring ways to use entertainment technologies to foster science education, Will Wright, the mind behind The Sims and Spore, gave a warp-speed talk laying out why game design has great potential in this arena. [Feb. 9, 6:50 p.m. | Updated  Many more views on the up side of gaming are here.]

title: Players Preparing for Chance the Checks Will Stop
description: DALLAS  In the best of times, some N.F.L. players have trouble saving their money. Because of an urge to help family and friends, or an inability to sock away some of their paychecks, a distressing number of athletes end up with little in the bank at the end of their careers.

title: Super Sunday in England, Too
description: In another country, another time zone, another sport, one of the most anticipated games of the English Premier League season will be a nice Sunday brunch (kickoff 11 a.m. Eastern on Fox Soccer Channel) to the days main course in the United States  the Super Bowl (which will be carried on the mother ship, Fox).

title: Egypt Stability Hinges on a Divided Military
description: WASHINGTON  A classified cable sent to Washington from the United States Embassy in Cairo in 2008 reported that a disgruntled midlevel Egyptian officer corps referred to the countrys powerful defense minister, Field Marshal Mohamed Tantawi, as Mubaraks poodle  incompetent and archaic but intensely loyal to his now-besieged president.

title: Why Some Twitter Posts Catch On, and Some Dont
description: AMID the talk last week of a Facebook revolution across the Middle East, Americans and other English speakers took to Twitter  to post about their love lives.

title: Online Courses, Still Lacking That Third Dimension
description: WHEN colleges and universities finally decide to make full use of the Internet, most professors will lose their jobs.

title: Housing Bubbles Are Few and Far Between
In Big Games, a Better Roethlisberger
description: DALLAS  After he arrived at training camp last summer, with his reputation in tatters and his future in doubt, Ben Roethlisberger incongruously spoke of winning a championship.

title: Ripples? Yes. Waves? Maybe.
description: IN 1972, Edward N. Lorenz gave a talk that turned out to be a landmark in the development of chaos theory. Its title was Predictability: Does the Flap of a Butterflys Wings in Brazil Set Off a Tornado in Texas?

title: Early America, Ripe for Counterfeiters
description: THERE is properly no history; only biography, Ralph Waldo Emerson wrote in 1841. In Moneymakers: The Wicked Lives and Surprising Adventures of Three Notorious Counterfeiters (Penguin, $27.95), Ben Tarnoff lends ample credence to that notion. He shows how three con men were able to thrive in Americas early days because of a weak central government, an often-chaotic banking system, a turbulent economy and an entrepreneurial populace.

title: Protest Threats Derail Bush Speech in Switzerland
description: WASHINGTON  A planned trip by former President George W. Bush to Switzerland this week has been canceled in the face of threatened large-scale protests and calls for an investigation into whether his administration committed human rights abuses in the fight against terrorism.

title: A Dot on the Map, Until the Earth Started Shaking
description: GUY, Ark.  Everybody around here is getting used to the earthquakes, and that does not sit well with Dirk DeTurck.

title: Prime Number
description: 39.8: Chicagoans tend to shrug at blizzard forecasts with the knowledge that, after all, theyre from Chicago. But the city, which recorded a snowfall of 21.2 inches Jan. 31-Feb. 2, cant hold a ruler to some other metropolises. Its record snow total of 23 inches on Jan. 26-27, 1967, ranks a middling 13th among the 29 biggest cities (those whose metropolitan areas have two million-plus people). All figures shown here are for snow events up to three days in duration.

title: Champion Quarterbacks Sooner and Later
description: The best quarterbacks are celebrated for the strength of their passing arms, their accuracy in winging a ball to receivers, their wisdom in recognizing defenses, their agility in escaping blitzing linebackers, their instinct for changing a play at the line of scrimmage and their command in the huddle.

title: Laugh Lines
description: JAY LENO

title: Dom Capers on Working With Dick LeBeau
description: The Packers' defensive coordinator, Dom Capers, talks about working with the Steelers' defensive coordinator, Dick LeBeau, during their time in Pittsburgh.

title: Fighting Words
description: A class-action lawsuit was filed last week in Federal District Court in Manhattan against former President Jimmy Carter, claiming his 2006 book, Palestine: Peace Not Apartheid, was falsely marketed as an accurate account of peace negotiations in the Middle East.

title: Damage to Metrodome Is Felt Beyond N.F.L.
description: MINNEAPOLIS  For visitors entering the University of Minnesota baseball office, the first framed poster on the left grabs the eye. It depicts the Metrodome at night, the Teflon roof lighted to a brilliant white, with the backdrop of the Minneapolis skyline behind it.

title: Unpredictable Uprisings
description: With upheaval gripping several Arab nations ruled by oppressive or corrupt regimes, here is a historical sampler of the twists and turns of revolutions. Many start out broad-based, but often not for long.

title: Love, Family and Change in Brooklyn
description: Russell Frederick has been documenting the Bedford-Stuyvesant neighborhood in Brooklyn as part of an ongoing project since 1999. Mr. Frederick, 40, is a member of Kamoinge, a New York-based collective and is working on his first solo exhibition Black. Mr. Frederick spoke with me this week in New York. The conversation has been edited.

title: Little Consolation in Third-Place Game
description: It was an N.F.L. postseason game with several official and unofficial names and no meaning at all. The Playoff Bowl was one name. But you might have called it the Bert Bell Benefit Bowl (for a former commissioner), the Pro Playoff Classic or the Runner-Up Bowl.

title: Americas Journeys With Strongmen
description: WASHINGTON   If the United States is, as so many presidents have said in so many speeches, the worlds pre-eminent champion of democracy, then why does the drama unfolding in Cairo seem so familiar?

title: Gamers Mimic the Season's Ups and Downs
description: Gamers followed real-world N.F.L. headlines, which shaped how they played Madden NFL 11, the most popular football video game.

title: Ruling May End Long Dispute in a Queens Neighborhood
description: A lengthy battle that divided the Jackson Heights business community and swallowed the Queens neighborhoods Diwali festival in the process may be finally nearing an end.

title: Wallflowers at the Revolution
description: A month ago most Americans could not have picked Hosni Mubarak out of a police lineup. American foreign policy, even in Afghanistan, was all but invisible throughout the 2010 election season. Foreign aid is the only federal budget line that a clear-cut majority of Americans says should be cut. And so now  as the worlds most unstable neighborhood explodes before our eyes  does anyone seriously believe that most Americans are up to speed? Our government may be scrambling, but thats nothing compared to its constituents. After a near-decade of fighting wars in the Arab world, we can still barely distinguish Sunni from Shia.

title: Meant to Be Broken? Maybe Not This Time
description: WASHINGTON  The mechanics of legislating should be simple: bring a bill to the floor, fight over amendments, vote the measure up or down and move on to the next one.

title: Why the Arab World Is Seething
description: Egypt is not alone. Anger has begun to boil over across a number of Arab countries. This map of human rights violations gives some clues to the furys depth.

title: China, Twitter and 20-Year-Olds vs. the Pyramids
description: Amman, Jordan

title: Suit Casts Light on Little-Known Mets Partner
description: Around the Mets, Saul Katz played the role of the little-known partner  occasionally seen, almost never heard from.

title: Whos the Boss, You or Your Gadget?
description: GIVEN the widespread adoption of smartphones, text messaging, video calling and social media, todays professionals mean it when they brag about staying connected to work 24/7.

title: Working Constantly, Thanks to Technology
description: I am as guilty as the next person when it comes to reflexively and repeatedly swiping my iPhone to check e-mail, Twitter and LinkedIn. Trust me when I tell you that I am not expecting any earth-shattering updates. Still, as with any bad habit, I have to scratch the itch or suffer mild symptoms of withdrawal.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Blame, Not Shame
description: So many to blame. So little space.

title: Militants, Women and Tahrir Sq.
description: CAIRO

title: For Americans Overseas, a Referee for Paychecks
description: Receiving a late paycheck is an accepted reality for many American basketball players working overseas.

title: On the Hill
description: Mechanics of legislating should be simple: Bring a bill to the floor, fight over amendments, vote the measure up or down and move on to the next one. But in the Senate, that approach had been largely replaced by partisan procedural brawls, writes Carl Hulse in his On The Hill column, Meant to Be Broken? Maybe Not This Time. Now, though, there appears to be growing support for going back to those civics-book basics.

title: The 40 Percent Nation
description: In the 1990s, at the height of the democratic revolutions, many people assumed that getting rid of the dictator was the hard part. If the people in a country could topple the old regime, then their country would make the transition toward democracy.

title: Knicks Hire Warkentien as Pro Personnel Director
description: Mark Warkentien, a former executive of the year, has joined the Knicks as director of pro player personnel, the team announced Saturday.

title: Republican Congressman Takes Aims at Testers Senate Seat in Montana
description: The 2012 race for Montanas Senate seat moved into the high-profile, competitive category on Saturday, with the official announcement by Republican Representative Denny Rehberg that he would seek to replace Senator Jon Tester, the first-term Montana Democrat.

title: Coachs Death Both Saddens and Inspires
description: ALTOONA, Pa.  Mike Lang might have found the inspiration behind the recent 16-game winning streak by the La Roche College mens basketball team. In the office of his younger brother, Scott, the former head coach, he came across some recruiting papers.

title: The Who Gives a Damn Bowl
description: So, another Super Bowl, and my team (the Giants) isnt in it, and chances are yours (no matter who) isnt either.

title: Clean Air Under Siege
description: Shortly after he entered the Senate in 2007, John Barrasso told his Wyoming constituents that the countrys biggest need was an energy policy to deal with carbon dioxide, the main greenhouse gas.

title: Doing the Judicial Math on Health Care
description: WASHINGTON  Put away your copy of the Constitution. Take out your calculator. Its time for some judicial arithmetic.

title: Dutch Returns
description: BACK in 1992, when Ronald Reagan first began to be strange (a bewilderment in his amethyst gaze, a hesitancy in speech and step), he impulsively said that he wanted to visit his birthplace. This desire was a surprise to those around the former president. He had never shown any interest in Tampico, Ill.

title: Mysterious Maladies
description: Patients who come to the Undiagnosed Disease Program at the National Institutes of Health know theyre extremely sick. What they want to know is, what do they call their affliction.

title: From Super Sunday to Stupor Sunday
description: This is the Sunday that football fans look forward to all season.

title: What Is Artificial Intelligence?
description: Urbana, Ill.

title: The Ringmasters Guest Performers
description: I hesitate to describe The Times as a circus, but there is a Ringling Brothers quality to the doings here. Under an expansive tent with the familiar Times T streaming from the tent pole mast high above, an increasingly eclectic set of news providers performs daily in print and online.

title: Bankers and Their Bonuses
description: Bankers are done with contrition. Lloyd Blankfein, chief executive of Goldman Sachs, paid himself a $12.6 million stock bonus for 2010, 40 percent more than in 2009, despite plummeting profits. Brian Moynihan of Bank of America got $9 million in restricted stock despite the banks $2.2 billion loss.

title: Croton-on-Hudson, 1:20 P.M.
The Health Care Tweak
description: For a brief moment last week Republicans and Democrats agreed on something about health care reform. The Senate voted overwhelmingly  the tally was 81 to 17  to repeal a minor provision that had brought vociferous complaints from business lobbyists.

title: Mark Twain and the Fortune-Teller
description: Cairo, Ill., Feb. 6, 1861

title: Stock-Hedging Lets Bankers Skirt Efforts to Overhaul Pay
description: Intent on fixing a banking system that contributed heavily to the recent financial crisis, lawmakers and regulators pushed Wall Street to overhaul its pay practices. Big banks responded by shifting more compensation into stock, a move intended to align employees interests more closely with those of investors and discourage excessive risk-taking.

title: Milton Rogovin
description: In 1994, I was asked to interview the photographer Milton Rogovin because Id written a book about the old Polish East Side of Buffalo. Rogovin, who recently died at 101, had spent years photographing Buffalos downtrodden Lower West Side. In a way, it was like a visitor to Portland, Ore., talking to a resident of Portland, Me., because they both knew something about Portland.

title: What Being Biracial Means Today
description: To the Editor:

title: Male-Dominated Web Site Seeking Female Experts
description: To the Editor:

description: If you can make it to Dallas, you can attend Super Bowl XLV in person, if you have thousands of extra dollars on hand.

description: To the Editor:

title: Rising Stress on Campus: Looking for the Causes
description: To the Editor:
