description: To the Editor:

title: Spider-Man Isnt Just the Talk of Broadway, Its the Punch Line
description: Joan Rivers gave a suggestion to the director Julie Taymor the other night: Hire a stunt person to fall on someone every three or four weeks  thatll keep audiences showing up.

title: Bruins Ference Criticizes Teammates Hit
description: Supporting and defending ones players and teammates are ingrained in hockey culture. So it was unusual on Thursday when Boston defenseman Andrew Ference did not back up his teammate Daniel Paille, who was given a major penalty and a game misconduct for a blindside hit to the head of Dallas forward Raymond Sawada.

title: Tura Satana, Cult Actress, Dies
description: Tura Satana, the actress whose authoritative presence, exotic looks and buxom frame commanded the attention of viewers of Russ Meyers 1965 cult movie Faster, Pussycat! Kill! Kill!, died on Friday evening in Reno, Nev.

title: Sunday: Whats That, Jos?
description: SUNDAYS PUZZLE  David Kahn tells us a joke today, and what starts out as a pleasant reunion of sorts concludes with one of those appallingly embarrassing moments that we all dread. If youre of a certain age, you might have even had a conversation like the one in this puzzle. Of course, Im nowhere near that age, so you can just forget all about my being able to totally relate to the joke, thank you very much. Lets move on, shall we?

title: With Power Play on Blink in Montreal, Rangers Drop Their Fourth Straight Game
description: MONTREAL  The Rangers had better start looking behind them. They lost to the Canadiens, 2-0, here on Saturday and became the first N.H.L. team to complete two-thirds of its schedule.

title: From the Frontlines to the Farm
description: Programs are sprouting around the country to train veterans and active-duty service members interested in organic farming.

title: Three Cases of Cholera Are Confirmed by City Officials
description: The first known cases of cholera in New York since the outbreak of the disease in Haiti last year were confirmed on Saturday by city officials.

title: A Close Super Bowl? Dont Bet on It.
description: Anyone can tell you that its going to be a close game, write Bill Barnwell and Aaron Schatz, two of the smartest football analysts on the planet, in their Super Bowl preview at Football Outsiders.

title: Helping Soldiers Trade Their Swords for Plows
description: VALLEY CENTER, Calif.  On an organic farm here in avocado country, a group of young Marines, veterans and Army reservists listened intently to an old hand from the front lines.

title: The Strange Victory of the Palmetto State
description: Less than two months separated South Carolinas decision to secede from the United States and the creation of a new country, the Confederate States of America. In that time six other states, comprising the entire Deep South  Mississippi, Florida, Alabama, Georgia, Louisiana and Texas  had followed.

title: Detentions, and Aides Role, Anger Egyptians
description: CAIRO  Vice President Omar Suleiman of Egypt has won the blessing of both the Mubarak and Obama administrations as the leader of a political transition toward democracy in Egypt. But human rights advocates say that so far Mr. Suleiman, who also is in charge of Egyptian intelligence, has shown no sign of discontinuing the practice of extra-legal detention of political opponents  a hallmark of President Hosni Mubaraks nearly 30-year rule that is a central grievance of the protesters in the streets.

title: Some of Obamas Favorite Programs to Face Cuts, Budget Director Says
description: WASHINGTON  The budget that President Obama will release next week reflects scores of tough calls that cut deeply into programs that the president supports, in keeping with his proposed five-year freeze on a broad category of domestic spending, according to the administrations budget director.

title: Movement Began With Outrage and a Facebook Page That Gave It an Outlet
description: If there is a face to the revolt that has sprouted in Egypt, it may be the face of Khaled Said.

title: Sweat | 92 Years Old, and Still Ruling The Squash Court
Sanders and Faulk Headline 2011 Hall of Fame Class
description: DALLAS  With a stacked list of finalists hoping to be selected for induction into the Pro Football Hall of Fame on Saturday, little was certain about who would be a part of the 2011 class. But from the start, there was little doubt that Deion Sanders would be the one headlining the group.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Feb. 6
description: Super Bowl XLV fever hits the Sunday television talk shows, as policymakers, diplomats and football players split airtime assessing the matchup between the Green Bay Packers and the Pittsburgh Steelers. But the political turmoil in Egypt remains the center of attention.

title: To Erving, Once a Net, Always at Net
description: Julius Erving took his electrifying high-flying act to three teams and two pro leagues on his way to the Basketball Hall of Fame. But his heart is still with the Nets, and he thinks the team has a bright future landing in Brooklyn, even if it has to share the city with the Knicks.

title: Joining to Bid Farewell to an Almost Unknown Soldier
description: A retired hospital chaplain, Ray Deabel speaks at 80 or so funerals a year, many for fellow military veterans. That is an honor. But sometimes only a handful of mourners show up. That is a shame. At the service for one World War II veteran a few years ago, only the chaplain and the funeral home director were there to say thank you and goodbye.

title: Citys Inequities Belie World-Class Imagery
description: James Warren writes a column for the Chicago News Cooperative.

title: Everybody Hates a Blizzard, but Pity the Politicians Whose Wards Got Short Shrift
description: The day after the blizzard, with election day less than three weeks away, Alderman Freddrenna Lyle (6th Ward) listened wearily to a stream of constituents who phoned to complain that unplowed snow was still keeping them from driving.

title: The Pulse: Alderman Stone, Checking In
description: Alderman Bernard L. Stone (50th Ward), the 83-year-old statesman of the City Council and the vice mayor, can add mayor of City Hall to his title, courtesy of the social-networking Web site Foursquare.

title: New Emanuel Ad Provides Fresh Grist
description: Ahead of what is being described as a major budget-platform announcement scheduled for Tuesday, Rahm Emanuel released his latest campaign television ad, in which he states that city government is not an employment agency.

title: Marathons Tiny School District Grabs at a Lifeline
description: MARATHON  If you close the school, you close the town.

title: As Mubarak Digs In, U.S. Policy in Egypt Is Complicated
description: Twelve days into an uprising in Egypt that threatens to upend American strategy in the Middle East, the Obama administration is struggling to determine if a democratic revolution can succeed while President Hosni Mubarak remains in office, even if his powers are neutered and he is sidelined from negotiations over the countrys future.

title: A Drug Used in Executions Becomes Very Hard to Get
description: A combination of market forces and European objections to the death penalty have left the nations busiest execution chamber with only enough of a key drug  sodium thiopental  to use for two convicted murderers scheduled to die later this month.

title: Looming Over Combs, Abortion Issue in 2014
description: Ross Ramsey, the managing editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column.

title: Rodney Crowells Audacity of Spirit
description: Admittedly, a taco stand in Jacinto City would have been the ideal place to eat breakfast with Rodney Crowell, as East Houston isnt just the setting but virtually the primary character in that singer-songwriters new memoir, Chinaberry Sidewalks.

title: Political Changes in Cairo
description: On a day of political maneuverings, protesters trying to overthrow the Egyptian government found themselves ringed by a much heavier troop presence than usual.

title: Researchers Evaluate Who Is Old Enough for Body Checks
description: The predominant opinion among researchers of serious injuries in boys hockey favors pushing back the age for introducing body checking to 13, and USA Hockey is considering that proposal.

title: Get Married, Save Thousands on Tuition
description: Students worldwide compete to attend the University of California, Berkeley, considered one of the best universities in the United States.

title: Flashy Sanders and the Versatile Faulk Headline the 2011 Hall of Fame Class
description: DALLAS  Only a player with a rsum that includes taking a helicopter from a major league baseball game to an N.F.L. game could be elected to the Pro Football Hall of Fame and have that be the second-biggest event of the day for him. Elected in his first year of eligibility, in a class co-headlined by Marshall Faulk and Shannon Sharpe, Deion Sanders seemed much more concerned with the fact that his Truth youth football team had lost to a team coached by Snoop Dogg earlier in the day.

title: Childrens Fairyland
description: The United States first storybook theme park opened in 1950 near Lake Merritt. Admission ranged from 9 to 14 cents, depending on the visitors age. The park, Childrens Fairyland, still prospers, delighting those young at heart with 10 acres of gentle rides, storybook sets, animal pens and theater stages.

title: PG&E Still Sails Smooth, and Thats the Rub
description: Jonathan Weber writes a column for The Bay Citizen.

title: Oakland Mayor and Police Chief Share Uneasy Alliance
description: During a news conference at Oakland City Hall on Monday, Anthony Batts, the police chief who recently applied  unsuccessfully  for the same position in San Jose, was asked if he intended to stay at the helm of the embattled Oakland Police Department.

title: Cheers, Gibes and a Loss in Lavins U.C.L.A. Return
description: LOS ANGELES  On Saturday, Steve Lavin returned to the scene of his crime, the same crime committed by seven others who have served as coach of the U.C.L.A. mens basketball team. They failed to live up to the impossible standard set by John Wooden.

title: A Victory to Remember for a Young American
description: Until a week ago, the short list of the greatest American tournament victories was limited to Hastings in 1895, Cambridge Springs in 1904, AVRO in 1938 and Palma de Mallorca in 1970.

title: States Struggle to Disarm People Whove Lost Right to Own Guns
description: By law, Roy Perez should not have had a gun three years ago when he shot his mother 16 times in their home in Baldwin Park, Calif., killing her, and then went next door and killed a woman and her 4-year-old daughter.

title: Super Bowl XLV: Squaring Off on Defense
description: The Steelers-Packers game features two of this seasons stingiest defenses.

title: Palin Criticizes Obama on Egypt
description: SANTA BARBARA, Calif.  As Sarah Palin delivered a weekend address here, paying tribute to Ronald Reagan on the centennial of his birth, she directed a forceful line of criticism at President Obama and his administration, though she did not mention the crisis in Egypt. But in a subsequent television interview, she took Mr. Obama to task for his handling of the matter.

title: Pandit Bhimsen Joshi Dies at 88; Indian Classical Singer
description: Even Gods Must Die.

title: Mary Cleere Haran, Cabaret Singer With a Big-Band Style, Dies at 58
description: Mary Cleere Haran, a classic popular singer and writer much admired for her cabaret shows celebrating the American song book, died on Saturday in Deerfield Beach, Fla., two days after a cycling accident. She was 58 and was living in Florida, having taken a break from a career that saw her perform in every major New York supper club.

title: Vows: Louis & Mark
description: After a guy Mark went on a date with suggested that Mark would be compatible with his boss, Lou, Mark sent Lou a Friendster message and the two have been dating ever since.

title: Lottery Numbers
30 Seconds With Packers John Kuhn
description: Fullback John Kuhn is the only active member of the Green Bay Packers with a Super Bowl ring, which he earned during the 2005 season as a member of Pittsburghs practice squad.

title: Should We Worry about Egypt Becoming Democratic?
description: My answer is: No.

title: Dangerous and Deadly 24 Hours on New York Roads
description: On a day when the weather made most New Yorkers want to stay holed up indoors, a series of frightening and fatal car accidents reinforced the sentiment.

title: The Easy Cuts Are Behind Us
description: Washington

title: Sorkin and Nolan Triumph at Introverted Emmys
description: On Saturday night, the Writers Guild of America awards  or the introverted Emmys as the New York host, Kristen Schaal, put it  doled out their prizes simultaneously and bicoastally, as usual. The group honored Aaron Sorkin and Christopher Nolan for their adapted (The Social Network) and original (Inception) screenplays, respectively. Both were in Los Angeles to accept. Inside Job won for best documentary; the director and lead writer, Charles Ferguson, was also in Los Angeles.

title: Looking to Egypts Future, Merkel Recalls Her Past
description: MUNICH  With an eye to her past in trying to build new democratic institutions in former communist East Germany, Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany spoke at the annual Munich Security Conference on Saturday about how Europe should respond to the extraordinary events unfolding in North Africa and the Middle East.

title: After First Talks, Egypt Opposition Vows New Protest
description: CAIRO  Leaders of the Egyptian democracy movement vowed Sunday to escalate their pressure for the resignation of President Hosni Mubarak, even as his government portrayed itself as already in the midst of American-approved negotiations to end the uprising, now in its 13th day.

title: Mumbai to Hold Second Annual Restaurant Week
description: In the last few years, Mumbai has witnessed something of a culinary explosion. In 2010, two internationally acclaimed chefs  Ian Kittichai, who is Thai, and Vineet Bhatia, an Indian  brought their considerable talents to the city. This year, two prominent global restaurant brands, Megu and Hakkasan, will open outposts here. But most of the citys gourmands will tell you that fine dining options in Mumbai are still woefully inadequate. Mumbais population hovers somewhere around 14 million, but there are perhaps no more than 40 high-end restaurants in the city.

title: Super Bowl Hasnt Happened Yet, According to Onion
description: The Onion:

title: Reader Photos: Your Super Bowl Snacks
description: Send us photos of the over-the-top food at your local Super Bowl party  pork shoulder shaped like a football, a Vince Lombardi Trophy made of nachos and other creations that are delicious, regrettable or both. The best will appear here on Diners Journal on Sunday night.

title: For Countries That Own Shorter Web Site Suffixes, Extra Cash From Abroad
description: Logging on to Facebook? You can use the social networking sites full Web address, or you can type www.fb.me.

title: Super Bowl, Commercial Interruption
description: A recent survey found that nearly half of the audience for the Super Bowl will be watching for the commercials, for the halftime show or just for the fun of it.

title: Kubica Involved in Rally Accident
description: Updated | 9:42 a.m.

title: Kubica Involved in Rally Accident
description: Updated | 9:42 a.m.

title: What to Watch While You Wait
description: Looking for a break from the Super Bowl pregame show? Sunday is a sports fans delight beyond the big game in Dallas. Before the Steelers and the Packers kick off, there is an English Premier League grudge match, the resumption of a heated N.H.L. rivalry, a Big Ten basketball showdown and a rematch of the N.B.A. Eastern Conference finals. (All times Eastern.)

title: When to Avoid Using A.T.M.s
description: In a recent Bucks post, More on Spotting A.T.M. Skimmers, John Pearce of the security company ADT Security Services shared tips for spotting the devices, including inspecting the A.T.M. and the area around the A.T.M.

title: In Tehran, Trial Begins of Americans Held as Spies
description: TEHRAN  The trial of the three American hikers accused of espionage and illegally entering Iran began behind closed doors on Sunday, and not guilty pleas were entered on their behalf, their lawyer said.

title: Q. and A. With Kurt Warner
description: Kurt Warner, the most valuable player of Super Bowl XXXIV for the St. Louis Rams, is the only quarterback to pass for more than 300 yards three times in the Super Bowl. The N.F.L.s M.V.P. in 1999 and 2001, he also played for the Giants and the Arizona Cardinals.Warner, 39, retired after a 12-year N.F.L. career and became an analyst for the NFL Network and Fox Sports last year. He is a spokesman for Nutrilite vitamins and Duracell, and founder of the First Things First Foundation, which is dedicated to promoting Christian values.

title: Updates on Day 13 of Egypt Protests
description: On Sunday, The Lede continues to follow the street protests in Egypt. For a summary of the latest developments, read the current version of the main news article from Times reporters in Cairo. Updates below mix alerts on breaking news with eyewitness accounts from bloggers and journalists in Egypt. A stream of Twitter updates on the protests is in this blogs right column. Readers can share information in the comment thread below or send photographs or video from Egypt to pix@nyt.com.

title: Food: The Late Surge
description: Just a note, mainly to myself, about global food prices: food was actually a latecomer to the commodity price surge. Here are IMF indexes for all commodities and just food since the early-2009 low, shown as natural logs so that the slope represents the growth rate:

title: Protests Continue Amid Talks
description: Representatives of the Egyptian democracy movement vowed Sunday to escalate their pressure for the resignation of President Hosni Mubarak.

title: A DreamWorks Rout in a Flawed Contest
description: LOS ANGELES Think about a big homecoming football game featuring cross-town rivals. And then only one team shows up. Kinda makes for a lopsided victory, right?

title: Many Want Rare Earths, but Few Are Mining Them
description: "RARE earth is a historical misnomer. Elements that fall under this label were identified mostly in the 18th and 19th centuries, when the word earths was used to describe a group of geological materials. At the time, a subset of these was thought to be uncommon.

title: Blinis, Gossip and Gogol, Snob-Style
description: What would Gogol eat?

title: Cheney Has Kind Words for Mubarak
description: WASHINGTON  As protesters in Egypt pressed forward with calls for the resignation of Hosni Mubarak this weekend, former Vice President Dick Cheney said that the longtime Egyptian leader had been a good friend to the United States who deserved to be treated well.

title: Culinary Comfort in a Tumultuous Middle East
description: After the shocks of 9/11 many New Yorkers turned their thoughts  and their lonely stomachs  to comfort food, to reassuring combinations like macaroni and cheese and Ben & Jerry. We got a bit plump.

title: Leading Off: Now, They Have to Play
description: Today marks the end of the two-week purgatory sports fans live in before every Super Bowl. Yes, after two weeks of blather the Steelers and the Packers will actually play a game and the collective sigh of relief will be enough to power a giant wind farm. Sometime this evening, you can take your finger off the mute button and tune back in.

title: The Super Bowl of Yellow Pants
description: After two weeks of non-stop, searing comparative analysis of the Super Bowl matchup, you might ask: whats left to discuss?

title: Poll: Packers Have Rooting Edge
description: If public opinion can be used as a predictor, the Green Bay Packers will win the Super Bowl. In the latest CBS News poll, 34 percent of the American public would like to see the Packers win, while 25 percent prefer the Pittsburgh Steelers. More than 40 percent of the 1,137 adults surveyed last week dont care or dont have an opinion about the outcome of the game.

title: Fisher Thanks Titans Fans
description: If Titans fans are feeling a little queasy about their team after the messy breakup between the owner Bud Adams and Coach Jeff Fisher, they might have felt even more queasy after seeing that Fisher took out a full-page ad in The Tennessean Sunday morning to thank them. That served as a reminder of how classy a guy Fisher is and the fact that Adams has not yet hired his replacement.

title: Super Bowl Parties Go Big in Texas
description: DALLAS  Despite the snow, the ice, the storms, the cab strike and all the other issues here at Super Bowl XLV, the nightlife thrived. Of course it did.

title: Finish Line Nears for Sanofi-Genzyme Talks
description: After months of wrangling, a successful end may be near for the merger talks between Sanofi-Aventis and Genzyme.

title: Live Analysis: Super Bowl XLV, Packers Beat Steelers, 31-25
description: The Timess staff provides analysis, pithy commentary and on-the-scene commentary from Super Bowl XLV between the Pittsburgh Steelers and the Green Bay Packers in Arlington, Tex.

title: Stirring Chicagos Corruption Stockpot
description: Chicago has largely been brought to us on fictional television through the defibrillator. So many pulses were revived over so many years on Chicago Hope and ER that the city came to seem like some sort of Lourdes for secularists. Chicago, you could envision a tourist slogan saying, the place to be when you need an emergency triple bypass. Natives must have hungered for a more expansive evocation of their hometown, one that explored the dirty genetics of a place that gave rise to both Al Capone and Rod Blagojevich. Citizens were possibly even irritated when Baltimore received rich dramatic excavation in The Wire before their own city had even been skimmed. Chicago taught Baltimore everything it knows.

title: Stoudemire Snaps Knicks Out of Latest Funk
description: Whenever the Knicks lose, Amare Stoudemire can be found in some corner of the locker room with his head down, voice low and legs wrapped like a mummy from the costs of another wasted effort. Stoudemire then pledges that the Knicks have yet to accomplish anything of substance and notes the urgency to snap out of whatever malaise that is on the verge of setting in.

title: White House Super Bowl Menu: Salts, Fats, Sugars and Bipartisan Brews
description: When the government set out dietary guidelines last week advising Americans to cut back on salts, fats and sugars, perhaps one critical omission was whether the recommendations applied to semi-official national holidays.

title: At War With a Taliban Shadow Government
description: The Third Battalion of the 187th Infantry Regiment arrived in Ghazni Province, in eastern Afghanistan, in September to establish an official government presence in an area where the Taliban had set up an underground rule of its own.

title: Sacred Hearts Enduring Sideline Presence
description: FAIRFIELD, Conn.  The final seconds ticked off the clock on Sacred Hearts 13-point loss. Coach Dave Bike walked the handshake line in front of the scorers table, then turned and headed diagonally off his home court, head down, a stocky 63-year-old grandfather in a gray sports jacket and a matching mood.

title: Bare Bones, Fleshed Out With Music
description: Why hasnt Miro Magloire been offered more opportunities in the ballet world? Companies, after all, are always looking for new talent, and Mr. Magloire creates clean, contemporary work that also has an old-fashioned respect for ballet steps and etiquette.

title: Isnt It Post-Romantic (and Lush, Too)?
description: Young singers dont have it easy. Before they can play plush recital halls, they have to play chilly rooms with pipes clanging, children chattering and seltzer bottles fizzing.

title: Obama and OReilly Talk Mubarak and Football
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama once again passed up the opportunity to publicly call for President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt to resign, but said that Egypt will not go back to the country it used to be before the democracy protests started.

title: Expressing the Pain of Being Left Behind
description: The cumulative lesson of Summation Dance Company could go a little like this: An emotional beginning doesnt automatically lead to a stirring finale. This all-female troupe, which made its debut on Friday night at the Baryshnikov Arts Center with Keep Your Feathers Dry, isnt one for subtlety; instead its the kind of company in which dancers list their astrological signs in their biographies: Sumi is an imaginative Aquarius who comes from California; Taryn is an analytical Virgo who hails from Wisconsin.

title: Change Ahead for League Chief Executive
description: Jay Baum, the chief executive of the American Contract Bridge League since 2002, has announced that he will retire next year. The league is looking for a replacement who plays bridge, knows the tournament and business worlds and is willing to relocate to the Memphis area. (The office is in Horn Lake, Miss.) Details are on leagues Web site.

title: Guitarist, in Charge, Plays Well With Others
description: Eliot Fisk has found a way to enliven the confining format of the solo guitar recital: invite friends and share the spotlight, though not so much that a listener might mistake the concert for a chamber music program. At the 92nd Street Y on Saturday evening Mr. Fisk had two guests who played solo works and duets with him. But his own performances remained the center of gravity.

title: Easygoing Look at Determined Women
description: The singer Anika Noni Rose is not one to push a point. On Saturday evening at the Allen Room, where she made her New York cabaret debut, Ms. Rose chose an easygoing effervescence over showy diva posturing. Certainly Dinah Washington, Eartha Kitt and Nancy Wilson, three of the stars she saluted and to whose music she was introduced by her grandmother, were nothing if not assertive. Ms. Rose is 38, but she radiated the wholesome ingenuousness of someone half her age.

title: Outr Dance Music That Revels in Otherness
description: In some recent interviews Robyn, the Swedish dance-pop semi-star, has expressed ambivalence about her coming tour mate, the medium-wattage yet far more famous pop-tart headliner Katy Perry. The friction had a 1990s familiarity: high versus low, alternative versus mainstream. But this is just a slick sleight of thought: if anything Robyn, a battle ram with uncanny songwriting gifts and only occasional moments of complexity, offers a more straightforward proposition than the quirky Ms. Perry.

title: Orchestral Extremes: From a Pizza Shop to Carnegie Hall
description: The Cleveland Orchestra must have been champing at the bit when it arrived at Carnegie Hall on Friday evening for the first of two concerts that, along with a finale in Newark on Sunday, would end a two-week American tour. The players and their music director, Franz Welser-Mst, started with a three-day residency at Indiana University, then escaped the Midwestern snows for balmy Florida, only to plunge back into the blizzards. Instead of moving on to Chicago, where they were to have performed in the venerable Symphony Center on Wednesday, they remained stranded in Ann Arbor, Mich., where several of the players joined a jam session in a pizza joint.

title: Unafraid of Altering a Winning Formula
description: Many a band promises to reinvent itself. Few have done so as thoroughly as Linkin Park, which played Madison Square Garden on Friday night. Its 2010 album, A Thousand Suns, is strikingly different from the music that made Linkin Park a blockbuster band in the early 2000s, when it was a major instigator, or perpetrator, of rap-rock. At Madison Square Garden, Linkin Park was like two bands sharing a stage: the old hard-riffing rap-rock band and its newer, statelier, electronics-loving successor.

title: In the State Where It All Began, a Cunningham Farewell
description: DURHAM, N.C.  The Merce Cunningham Dance Company was founded in North Carolina, at Black Mountain College, in 1953; over the weekend it danced its last North Carolina performances. Farewells are the pattern for the company this year. Having announced after Cunninghams death in 2009 that it would give its final performances on New Years Eve 2011 in New York, it is saying goodbye to cities and to dances. What makes this so hard is that with the current company Cunningham still seems alive. It feels as if a continually investigative thought process  no mind in dance was ever more exploratory  is at work in the movement.

title: The Work of Art in the Age of Google
description: If art is among your full-blown obsessions or just a budding interest, Google, which has already altered the collective universe in so many ways, changed your life last week. It unveiled its Art Project, a Web endeavor that offers easy, if not yet seamless, access to some of the art treasures and interiors of 17 museums in the United States and Europe.

title: The Artistry Is Apparent, So Wheres the Audience?
description: The quandary in which Teddy Thompson, one of the most gifted singer-songwriters of his generation, finds himself is symptomatic of the confusion and uncertainty that pervade the crumbling record industry. With his abundant talent and commercial potential Mr. Thompson, the son of the British folk-rock aristocrats Richard and Linda Thompson, would seem to have everything.

title: Monday: Come to Pass
description: MONDAYS PUZZLE  Ssshh. Is it DAYBREAK where you are?

title: A Gallery of Species Lost and On the Brink
description: A few of the tens of thousands of species that scientists say have gone extinct or become critically endangered over the past 30 years.

title: Slide Show: Readers Super Bowl Party Food
Elvis Costellos Big Wheel
description: Elvis Costello has announced plans for The Revolver Tour beginning in May. This United States tour, backed by the band the Imposters, will resurrect Mr. Costellos Spectacular Spinning Songbook, a giant game-show-style wheel listing 40 of his song titles. He first used the wheel on tour in 1986. During performances, audience members are selected to spin the wheel to determine the next tune on the bands set list. The Imposters include Steve Nieve on keyboards, Pete Thomas on drums and the bass guitarist Davey Faragher. The tour is to begin on May 7 at the Grand Sierra Theater in Reno, Nev., and end on May 23 at the Beacon Theater in New York.

title: Footnote
description: Christie Brinkley, below, will make her Broadway acting debut in the musical Chicago this spring, she said on The Oprah Winfrey Show on Friday. Ms. Brinkley, who began her acting career in 1983 by driving a Ferrari opposite Chevy Chase in National Lampoons Vacation, will play Roxie Hart during an 11-week engagement, April 4 through June 19, at the Ambassador Theater.

title: Kevin Spacey Plans Middle East Academy
description: The actor and theater producer Kevin Spacey, below, has announced plans to start a theater arts academy in the Middle East, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Spacey, who appeared at a news conference on Sunday in Dubai, on his way to host the Laureus sports awards in Abu Dhabi on Monday, said the Middle East Theater Academy would be a joint project of the Kevin Spacey Foundation and Badr Jafar, executive director of Crescent Petroleum and chief executive officer of Crescent Investments. Mr. Spacey said the academy was to have no specific home but would travel across the region to provide instruction in all aspects of theater and offer a path for Middle Eastern works to travel to Broadway and other international sites. Mr. Spacey is currently the artistic director of the Old Vic theater in London.

title: Los Angeles Schools Block Jamie Oliver
description: Jamie Oliver, the British chef, food reformer and reality television personality, is having a hard time revolutionizing the cafeterias of Los Angeles high schools. Permits for Jamie Olivers Food Revolution to film at local high schools were revoked last week after Mr. Oliver, left, failed to provide the Los Angeles Unified School District with a proposal of his plans for the show, according to Robert Alaniz, a spokesman for the school district, The Los Angeles Times reported. Mr. Alaniz said the district had had a bad experience with another reality show in the past. He also talked of the conflict and drama associated with Mr. Olivers show in Huntington, W.Va., saying, Were not interested in that. Speaking at U.C.L.A.s School of Public Health on Wednesday, Mr. Oliver said his filming permit was terminated because he could not promise the school district it would look good.

title: Kate McGarrigle Tributes
description: The family of Kate McGarrigle, the Canadian singer and songwriter who died last year, has announced two tribute concerts in her honor. Her children, Rufus Wainwright and Martha Wainwright, and McGarrigles sister and longtime musical partner, Anna McGarrigle, are scheduled to perform on May 12 and 13 at Town Hall in Manhattan. They will be joined by their third sister, Jane McGarrigle, as well as by Jimmy Fallon, Emmylou Harris, Antony Hegarty, Justin Bond and several other performers, including Michel Pepin on guitar, Chaim Tannenbaum on mandolin and banjo, and Joel Zifkin on violin, all of whom were regular members of the McGarrigle band. Everyone who met my mother, no matter how briefly, was struck by her worldly character matched with an otherworldly artistic aura, Mr. Wainwright said of the tribute in an e-mail. Its all in the songs now. I cant wait to hear them performed by all of these incredible artists. Ms. McGarrigle learned she had a rare form of cancer in 2006 and died at her home in Montreal in January 2010. She was 63. All proceeds from the shows will go toward the creation of the Kate McGarrigle Sarcoma Research Fund, in association with the Sarcoma Foundation of America. Tickets go on sale at noon on Monday: (800) 745-3000; ticketmaster.com.

title: A Sleepy Winter Continues at the Box Office
description: Movie audiences in North America spent about $75.4 million on tickets over the weekend, a 24 percent decline from a year earlier. The soft result extends Hollywoods losing streak to 13 down weekends in a row. Avatar, which was still raking in box office cash at this time last year, is only part of the explanation. A ho-hum batch of releases in recent weeks has also contributed to lackluster sales. For the weekend, a traditionally slow one because of the Super Bowl, The Roommate (above, with Minka Kelly, left, and Leighton Meester), a horror entry from Sony Pictures Entertainment, was No. 1 with an estimated $15.6 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles box office statistics. Sanctum, a 3-D horror film set in underwater caves, was second, selling about $9.2 million for Universal Pictures and Relativity Media. The romantic comedy No Strings Attached (Paramount Pictures) was third with about $8.4 million for a new total of $51.8 million. The Kings Speech (the Weinstein Company) was a close fourth with roughly $8.3 million ($84.1 million total). The Green Hornet (Sony) chugged away in fifth place with $6.1 million, lifting its total to $87.2 million.

title: Lawyers Try to Stop Lifetime Movie on Killing
description: Lawyers for Amanda Knox and her ex-boyfriend, Raffaele Sollecito, who were found guilty of killing Ms. Knoxs roommate in Italy in 2009, are trying to block the showing of a Lifetime movie about the murder, The Associated Press reported. Carlo Dalla Vedova and Luca Maori, the lawyers, said that they had warned the network that they would try to have Amanda Knox: Murder on Trial in Italy sequestered by a United States court if it was not canceled and a promotion for the movie taken off the networks Web site. There was no comment from Lifetime, according to Les Eisner, a spokesman for its parent company, A&E Television Networks. Ms. Knox and Mr. Sollecito are appealing their convictions. The movie, which features Hayden Panettiere as Ms. Knox, is scheduled for Feb. 21.

title: Ad Watch: The Super Bowl Commercials
description: Stuart Elliott, The Timess advertising columnist, is taking a running look at some of the evenings Super Bowl commercials:

title: Mayoral Sign-Out Sheet? Secretive Jaunts Spur a Thought
description: His poll numbers have slid. His first choice to lead the city schools turned him down. And the budget deficit? Dont even ask.

title: Merce Cunningham Dance Company
description: Photos from the troupes performance in Durham, N.C.

title: Donors Demand a Bigger Voice in Catholic Schools
description: Private philanthropists have changed the face of public education over the last decade, underwriting the rise of charter schools and promoting remedies that rely heavily on student testing and teacher evaluation.

title: A Sardis Meal in Michigan
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: The Decline of Web-Based E-Mail
description: The number of visitors to Web-based e-mail sites, like Gmail and Yahoo mail, declined 5.9 percent from November 2009 to November 2010, according to comScore, a firm that tracks Internet traffic.

title: Egyptians React to U.S. Policy
description: Protesters in Egypt insisted that President Obama could not stop their revolt.

title: Fighting Congos Ills With Education and an Army of Women
description: BUKAVU, Democratic Republic of Congo  Eve Ensler has an audacious plan.

title: A Crisis of Faith in Britains Central Banker
description: LONDON  A central banker need not be loved, but at the least he should command respect  and in Britain these days Mervyn King cannot count on either.

title: Restaurant Nutrition Draws Focus of First Lady
description: WASHINGTON  After wrapping her arms around the retail giant Wal-Mart and trying to cajole food makers into producing nutrition labels that are easier to understand, Michelle Obama, the first lady and a healthy-eating advocate, has her sights set on a new target: the nations restaurants.

title: Obama and U.S. Business Sheath Weapons for Now
description: For Bruce Josten, the feisty top lobbyist for the U.S. Chamber of Commerce, it got personal last fall on a Sunday talk show whenPresident Obamas spokesman invoked his name.

title: Cold Hopes, Warm Dreams, Chilly Schemes
Al Jazeera Hopes Reports From Egypt Open Doors in U.S.
description: DOHA, Qatar  Our bureau in Cairo has been attacked.

title: Economic Reports for the Week
description: ECONOMIC REPORTS Scheduled for this week are consumer credit data for December (Monday); weekly jobless claims and wholesale trade inventories for December (Thursday); trade deficit for December and the Thomson Reuters/University of Michigan consumer sentiment index (Friday).

title: Five Beloved Myths of the Mortgage Market
Just 2 Candidates, but Worries for Haitis Runoff
description: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  Mirlande Manigat walks and speaks with the slow grace of a sophisticated grandmother. She keeps a series of expensive pens in a glass case on her desk.

title: Cuomo, Pushing School Cuts, Offers a Target: Superintendent Salaries
description: Carole G. Hankin, the schools superintendent in Syosset on Long Island, made an unexpected cameo appearance in Albany last week: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo cast her salary as a prime example of wasteful spending by school districts.

title: Cambodia Asks U.N. to Act Amid Clashes With Thailand
description: SIEM REAP, Cambodia  Deepening a bitter border dispute, fighting erupted for a fourth day on Monday between Thai and Cambodian forces near a disputed 11th-century Hindu temple, and a Thailand military spokesman said the time for negotiations had passed.

title: Nassau County Has Everything (Even Debt)
description: Like Ishtar II, it seems an unlikely and unwanted sequel.

title: Ring Helps Rodgers Secure Place in Packers Lore
description: Arlington, Tex.

title: Pregame Show: Many Hours Too Long
description: There have been so many overlong, silly, banal, poorly conceived Super Bowl pregame shows that only one title can describe the drivel perpetrated by Fox on Sunday:

title: The Answers Are Out There, and New Q. and A. Sites Dig Them Up
description: In Internet circles, the hunt is always on for the next big thing. But lately an older idea is enjoying a renaissance: sites where users ask and answer questions. A flurry of start-ups in this field are gathering speed and attracting the eyes and wallets of venture capitalists.

title: Former WikiLeaks Colleagues Forming New Web Site, OpenLeaks
description: LONDON  As the WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange fights extradition to Sweden to face allegations of sexual wrongdoing, a dozen of his former colleagues are creating an alternative Web site for leaks to be governed by what they characterize as a revised vision of radical transparency.

title: Warning Against Hasty Exit for Mubarak
description: MUNICH  Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton warned on Sunday that removing President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt too hastily could threaten the countrys transition to democracy.

title: On Patrol for the Casualties of Potholes
description: Jose Antonio Cruz carries the tools of roadside salvation, but few would describe him as popular.

title: Packers Little-Known Nelson Scores First
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  Perhaps the least known member of the Green Bay Packers productive receiving corps made the most important early contributions in Super Bowl XLV. Instead of Greg Jennings, or Donald Driver, or even James Jones, a third-year wideout, raised on a farm in central Kansas, put Green Bay in front early.

title: Lottery Numbers
Pharmacies Besieged by Addicted Thieves
description: BINGHAM, Me.  The orange signs posted throughout Chet Hibbards pharmacy here relay a blunt warning: We Do Not Stock OxyContin.

title: Killing of Missionary Rattles Texas Border
description: PHARR, Tex.  Mexico has always had a reputation here as a place where things can go wrong in a hurry. But the fatal shooting of a Texas missionary across the border late last month has reinforced the widely held belief in this region that the country has become a lawless war zone.

title: After Tucson Rampage, a Struggle to Stay in Reach
description: FLAGSTAFF, Ariz.  Paul Gosar, a freshman Congressman representing Arizonas vast First District, was holding his first house call with constituents last week when he was interrupted by a seemingly unbalanced man.

title: In Dusty Parking Lot, Both Sides Are Home Team
description: CAVE CREEK, Ariz.  From the moment he realized there was going to be a Packers-Steelers Super Bowl, Adam Stein, the town marshal, knew trouble was going to pay a visit to his tiny desert town. So he began planning for an onslaught of Green Bay and Pittsburgh fans guaranteed to show up and instantly double the areas population of 5,000.

title: Provost of Tufts University Will Be Named President of Cooper Union
description: Cooper Union, the highly selective Manhattan college known for its free tuition, plans to announce on Monday that it has chosen the provost and senior vice president of Tufts University to be its next president.

title: Traffic Deaths in the City Rose Slightly Last Year
description: In the popular imagination, New York Citys streets can resemble an arcade-style obstacle course, a daily life-or-death gamble for pedestrians and drivers alike.

title: Disney Looking Into Cradle for Customers
description: LOS ANGELES  The Walt Disney Company has started an ambitious and risky march toward the one corner of childhood it does not already dominate: newborns.

title: A Ticketholder Without a Seat
description: A Super Bowl fan who was left without a seat talked to The Times's Alan Schwarz while waiting in line.

title: The Joy of Research
description: A bit of personal meta here: I realized a few hours ago that I was actually having a good weekend, and that made me step back and think about what I actually enjoy in my current role as public intellectual.

title: EBay Says Big Growth Is Not Over
description: SAN FRANCISCO  EBay was growing so fast early in its history that Meg Whitman, its former chief executive, liked to joke that a monkey could drive this train.

title: The Hasek Interview: K.H.L. Is a Different Hockey
description: The K.H.L. All-Star Game was Saturday in St. Petersburg, and if you thought the 11-10 score in last weekends N.H.L. All-Star Game was ridiculous, get a load of the 18-16 result in Russia. Consider: Sergei Mozyakin scored five goals in a losing cause. (The skills competition also produced the worlds fastest shot, Denis Kulyashs 110.3 mile-per-hour blast, surpassing Zdeno Charas 105.9-m.p.h. shot in N.H.L. skills competition.)

title: Graph Meta
description: I get questions on and off about graphs on this blog, together with suggestions and/or demands that I do something fancier.

title: Prizing Status Quo, Mubarak Resists Pressure to Resign
description: WASHINGTON  He walks several yards to his office from his living quarters at the presidential palace every day, dressed in his trademark black business suit and tie. On Saturday, he conducted a meeting of his new governments economic team. And on Sunday, he received an envoy from Oman, who delivered a letter from the sultan.

title: Breach Tied to Nasdaq May Have Wider Effect
description: As the company that runs the Nasdaq sought to reassure the public after revealing a computer breach to one of its systems, analysts said that the lingering effects may be to the companys other expanding business lines rather than to its trading.

title: Optimism About Missing Google Executive in Egypt
description: After disappearing in Egypt more than a week ago, leaving an ominous message on his Twitter account, Wael Ghonim, who leads Googles marketing efforts for the Middle East and North Africa, is expected to be released by Egyptian authorities to his family on Monday afternoon, a friend of the Ghonim family said Sunday night.

title: Egypts Ire Turns to Confidant of Mubaraks Son
description: CAIRO  As Egyptians turned their anger on symbols of the state late last month, torching police stations along with the headquarters of President Hosni Mubaraks ruling party, they reserved a special hatred for a garish building with black tinted windows in an upscale neighborhood, setting fire to it three times.

title: F.C.C. to Propose Expanding Broadband Service to Underserved Areas
description: WASHINGTON  The Federal Communications Commission on Tuesday will propose the first steps toward converting the $8 billion fund that subsidizes rural telephone service into one for helping pay to provide broadband Internet service to underserved areas, according to commission officials.

title: Hundreds With Tickets but No Seats
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  Jim Rouleau of Hudson, Wis., a season-ticket holder for Packers games at Lambeau Field, spent $3,900 for each of his two Super Bowl tickets. When he found his seat, with a face value of $900, he was told that his section was closed, and that he could not sit there.

title: As Ice Thaws, Body Is Found Inside a Car in Queens
description: Freezing rain fell on the navy blue BMW that sat on a narrow side street in Astoria, Queens, last week, and the ice-encrusted snow soon concealed its roof and windows.

title: At Night, Protest Gives Way to Poetry
description: CAIRO  It was a few minutes after midnight on Sunday, when an unaccustomed rain washed Cairos somnolent streets, as Ahmed Abdel-Moneim walked with friends across a bridge that was a passageway to a parallel capital in Tahrir Square, an idea as much as a place.

title: Ridiculed, an N.F.L. Owner Goes to Court
description: Back in November, when Daniel M. Snyder, the owner of the Washington Redskins, was pilloried at length in a piece in the Washington City Paper, a local weekly, he had a number of options: He could have ignored the article, contacted the newspaper and asked for equal time or corrections, or he could have used his bully pulpit as the owner of both a pro sports team and a number of local radio stations to respond.

title: A Family Feud Raises Ratings for American Chopper
description: When a father and son have a falling out, land in court and stop speaking, whats a television producer to do?

title: Singing, Aguilera Trips Oer Ramparts
description: The Star-Spangled Banner can be a notoriously difficult song to sing, with its broad range and piercing high notes. But usually, the lyrics work out just fine.

title: Yahoo Is Said to Move Toward Personalized Content
description: For Yahoo, it is getting personal.

title: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

description: Accounts

title: Hip-Hop Comes to the Super Bowl
description: This was the season that hip-hop finally caught up to the N.F.L., something that happened weeks before the Black Eyed Peas took center stage at Cowboys Stadium for the Super Bowl XLV halftime show.

title: Super Bowl Ads Mine Decades of Americana
description: The advertising bowl that took place inside Super Bowl XLV on Sunday offered a wild  and somewhat welcome  ride through six decades of popular culture.

title: How Democracy Became Halal
description: Tel Aviv

title: In Lake George, a Race to, Um, a Seat of Fame
description: LAKE GEORGE, N.Y.  Along Canada Street, this villages main commercial drag, scenes of a sleepy winter were everywhere. Icicles glittered from the rooftops of silent storefronts like the Candy Jar and the Lobster Pot, closed for the season.

title: A Final Farewell to Vang Pao
description: The funeral of Vang Pao, known to his people as the general, the hero of the C.I.A.s long ago secret war in the jungles of Laos, took place in Fresno, Calif. over six days and six nights.

title: A Taste for Lincoln, and Maybe His Honesty
description: As if Abraham Lincoln Halloween costumes and television commercials werent enough, Hollywood is getting the 16th president ready for his close-up. A bunch of them.

description: The Times welcomes comments and suggestions, or complaints about errors that warrant correction. Messages on news coverage can be e-mailed to nytnews@nytimes.com or left toll-free at 1-888-NYT-NEWS (1-888-698-6397). title: When a Storm Intervenes on the Weather Channel
description: The Weather Channel had a new prime-time hit last week: the weather.

title: Their Real Agenda
description: As states groan and stumble through the recession, some politicians are trying to exploit their financial crises for ideological purposes. Many Republicans want to use hard times to fundamentally reduce the role of states and public employee unions, in the same way federal tax cuts forced a debate on how to cut the deficit.

title: Packers Put the Title Back in Titletown
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  When the Green Bay Packers watched Aaron Rodgers sit in the green room as he plummeted down the first round of the 2005 draft, they noted his poise at dealing with his agonizing plight.

title: The Debate Over Tenure for Teachers
description: To the Editor:

title: Planets Galore
description: Not that long ago, the possibility of finding planets outside our solar system was merely theoretical. In 1995, astronomers began to be able to detect Jupiter-sized exoplanets by their gravitational effect on the stars they orbit. And with the launch of the Kepler satellite in March 2009 and the release last week of the data it has so far gathered, astronomy has crossed a major threshold. The Kepler has discovered 1,235 potential planets.

title: Medicaid and Medicare
description: To the Editor:

title: Droughts, Floods and Food
description: Were in the midst of a global food crisis  the second in three years. World food prices hit a record in January, driven by huge increases in the prices of wheat, corn, sugar and oils. These soaring prices have had only a modest effect on U.S. inflation, which is still low by historical standards, but theyre having a brutal impact on the worlds poor, who spend much if not most of their income on basic foodstuffs.

title: Helping Inmates Readjust
description: To the Editor:

title: Regulating Big Coals Bad Actors
description: The Obama administration is proposing tougher mine safety regulation in the wake of the West Virginia explosion that killed 29 miners last April. The disaster highlighted hundreds of violations by the mine owner, Massey Energy, and the endemic failure of federal regulators to shut down the industrys worst offenders.

title: Personal Privacy and the Right to Know
description: For 45 years, the Freedom of Information of Act has invigorated American democracy by obliging the executive branch to make public a splendid range of documents. It serves the peoples right to know, while leaving out data whose disclosure could be harmful.

title: Business Consumption Tax
description: To the Editor:

title: The Good Earth
description: To the Editor:

title: Choosing Dignity
description: To the Editor:

title: Obama the Realist
description: On the campaign trail in 2008, Barack Obama played to two very different foreign policy constituencies. Often he presented himself as the tribune of the anti-war left  the only candidate who had opposed the invasion of Iraq from the beginning, the man who could be trusted to civilize the global war on terror, and the perfect figure to smooth the transition to a post-American world order. To more bipartisan audiences, though, he cast himself as a cold-eyed realist  the rightful heir to George H. W. Bush, if not Henry Kissinger, who would pursue Americas interests without pretending (as the younger President Bush often did) that they matched up perfectly with Americas democratic ideals.

title: Gay Asylum Seekers
description: To the Editor:

title: At War With a Taliban Shadow Government
description: An Army Regiment went to Ghazni Province, Afghanistan, to establish a government presence where the Taliban had set up its own rule.

title: In Eastern Afghanistan, at War With the Talibans Shadowy Rule
description: FORWARD OPERATING BASE ANDAR, Afghanistan  Midway through December, Afghan police officers arrested a man who had hidden a fake bomb near a government office in Miri, a village in eastern Afghanistan. The man, who gave the name Muhammad Mir, confessed, saying he wanted to gauge the security forces reactions to a Taliban attack, according to American intelligence officials.

title: The Twitterverse Responds to the Black Eyed Peas Halftime Show
description: The following posts were published on Twitter accounts around 8:15 p.m. Eastern time on Sunday night, during the Super Bowl halftime show performed by the Black Eyed Peas. They are presented without further commentary.

title: N.Y.U. Report Casts Doubt on Talibans Ties With Al Qaeda
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The Afghan Taliban have been wrongly perceived as close ideological allies of Al Qaeda, and they could be persuaded to renounce the global terrorist group, according to a report to be published Monday by New York University.

title: For a Hmong Hero, a Lavish Farewell
description: FRESNO, Calif.  If Vang Pao had died a simple farmer like so many other Hmong here, his funeral would have been an elaborate affair.

title: Singing, Aguilera Trips Oer Ramparts
description: The Star-Spangled Banner can be notoriously difficult to sing, with its broad range and piercing high notes. But usually, the lyrics work out just fine.

title: Did Groupon Cross the Line in Super Bowl Ad Debut?
description: Groupon may not be making its initial public offering yet  but it has made its mark on millions watching the Super Bowl, anyway. What is not clear yet is whether the start-up has burned through a lot of good will.

title: A Cold Seat
description: Hundreds of people gathered at Lake George to watch a 50-year-old tradition: an outhouse race.

title: Betting on News, AOL Is Buying The Huffington Post
description: The Huffington Post, which began in 2005 with a meager $1 million investment and has grown into one of the most heavily visited news Web sites in the country, is being acquired by AOL in a deal that creates an unlikely pairing of two online media giants.

title: Tura Satana, Actress With a Cult Following, Is Dead
description: Tura Satana, an actress whose authoritative presence, exotic looks and buxom frame commanded the attention of viewers of Russ Meyers 1965 cult movie Faster, Pussycat! Kill! Kill!, died on Friday in Reno, Nev.

title: Emanuel Vardi, a Champion of the Viola, Dies at 95
description: Emanuel Vardi, an American violist who was an ambassador for the instrument in an era when it had few public champions, died on Jan. 29 at his home in North Bend, Wash. He was 95.

title: Word of the Day | panegyric
description: panegyric \pa-n-jir-ik, -ji-rik\ noun/adjective

title: Roethlisberger Is Unable to Bridge a Gap He Helped to Create
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  One by one, the Pittsburgh Steelers mounted podiums, wearing long faces and fancy suits. The last to arrive was quarterback Ben Roethlisberger, who, by unofficial word, needed a few extra minutes of contemplation, needed longer to digest what it felt like to lose a Super Bowl instead of win one.

title: AOL to Buy Huffington Post for $315 Million

description: The exhibition Aint Nothing Like the Real Thing, which opens on Tuesday at the Museum of the City of New York, really aint anything like the real thing, but that is not really its fault. The real thing in this case is almost beyond the reach of a museum show. It is to be found not in Louis Armstrongs trumpet or Miles Daviss flugelhorn, or James Browns black jumpsuit studded with rhinestones spelling Sex, or Ella Fitzgeralds orange dress or Michael Jacksons fedora (all of which are on display here), but in the music those performers made while wearing these clothes and playing these instruments.

title: Now Booking | Glass House Tours
description: Along with the news that Punxsutawney Phil didnt see his shadow, heres another harbinger of spring: At 9 a.m. on Feb. 15, tickets for the 2011 tours of the Philip Johnson Glass House in New Canaan, Conn., will go on sale. To mark the programs fifth year, the Glass House (a National Trust for Historic Preservation site) is adding several new tours to its already varied menu. (The tour season runs from May through November.) Three new two-hour, $45 tours will focus on specific aspects of the 47-acre site: the architecture; the art (Johnson and his partner, David Whitney, assembled a significant collection of postwar and contemporary painting and sculpture); and the landscape, which includes everything from historic trees to Whitneys idiosyncratic succulent gardens.

title: Unrest Continues in Egypt
description: Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak came under more pressure on Monday to step down as opponents said concessions offered in landmark talks were not enough to halt a revolt against his 30-year rule.

title: The White House Waits
description: By late last year, the Middle East peace process had become a process in name only. The Obama administrations hopes of brokering talks between Israel and the Palestinians collapsed after the Israelis dug in their heels over the Palestinian demand for a freeze in settlement construction, a demand backed by Washington. And neither side showed much enthusiasm for the indirect talks mediated by George Mitchell, the State Department envoy to the region. This was the dismal state of play when the Arab world was jolted by an eruption of people power in Tunisia, Egypt and elsewhere. Is it possible that these electrodes can shock some life into the inert peace process?

title: A Plan for Peace That Still Could Be
description: The street demonstrations roiling the Arab world have riveted and moved many Americans, who have visions of democracy sweeping through northern Africa and the Middle East. As I write this, Hosni Mubarak, Egypts president, has announced he will not stand for re-election, as has Yemens longtime ruler, Ali Abdullah Saleh. Tunisias ruler fled, and the nation has a new government; King Abdullah of Jordan replaced his own cabinet and now has a prime minister who promises reform. There are even stirrings in Syria. President Obama has signaled his determination to support democratization in the region, as promised in his 2009 Cairo speech, and not to remain tied to authoritarian regimes.

The setting, the Grand Palais, is a masterpiece of the machine age, an opulent temple of industrial progress built for the Universal Exposition of 1900.

title: Art Directors Give Some Oscar Clues

While fans of the black and yellow, like the Bagger, were crying into their Iron City beer, in Hollywood and New York writers, animators and art directors were celebrating. The latter group presented its prizes on Saturday, and The Kings Speech, Inception and Black Swan won, for period, fantasy and contemporary film, respectively.

title: Leading Off: The Games the Thing
description: The first thing N.F.L. Commissioner Roger Goodell should have done Monday morning was announce A) there would be no lockout and B) he was doubling the Super Bowl shares of the Packers and the Steelers. And he should consider delivering the checks to all of their houses in person. Because although Goodell would never admit it (because his league is dead set on grabbing as much money away from the players as it can), those players bailed out his Super Bowl. The whole production was rapidly descending into one of the leagues most embarrassing fiascoes when they interrupted the chaos by playing a magnificent football game.

title: Ask an Expert About A.D.H.D.
description: Doctors are becoming increasingly aware that attention problems in childhood may not be something that a child simply outgrows. While attention deficit hyperactivity disorder, or A.D.H.D., is one of the most common behavioral disorders in young people, affecting up to 7 percent of the school-age population, up to 4 to 5 percent of adults have A.D.H.D. The disorder can interfere with most domains of life, including education, work, family, relationships and health.

And the Weekend Update segment included Paul Brittains impression of the multi-tasking James Franco, who revealed that hes not just hosting the Oscars and a nominee. Behold the work of the man, said Mr. Janisse, a tour guide, and his audience took it in: the Gaudiesque mashup of towers, cathedrals, fountains and ships, constructed from pipes, broken bottles, seashells and cracked ceramic, climbing 100 feet into the air.

D. Salinger, Raymond Carver and several thousand other proper nouns.

title: Fitness: A Walk to Remember? Study Says Yes
description: In healthy adults, the hippocampus  a part of the brain important to the formation of memories  begins to atrophy around 55 or 60. Now psychologists are suggesting that the hippocampus can be modestly expanded, and memory improved, by nothing more than regular walking.

description: One reason airport security measures frustrate travelers is that screening procedures tend to treat all passengers the same: as potential terrorists.

title: Two Anti-Communists at Odds
description: Daniel Bell, who died last week at 91, is closely associated with a group of New York intellectuals who included Irving Kristol, Nathan Glazer and Daniel Patrick Moynihan. But as I write in an essay for the Feb. 13 Book Review (published early online), Bell deserves our attention as a singular  and singularly ambitious  thinker and writer, who followed in the system-building tradition of Karl Marx and Thorstein Veblen, both heroes of his. Like them, Bell could be impatient with those he judged to be on the wrong side of history or ideas, even in those post-war years remembered for their cozy political consensus, as is clear from Bells correspondence with William F. Buckley Jr. in 1955.

title: Q. and A.: PCBs in School Classrooms
description: As I reported last week, many parents in New York City are worried about the presence of the chemicals known as PCBs in light fixtures and caulking in school buildings. The latest spot inspection by the federal Environmental Protection Agency  on Jan. 29 at Public School 68 in the Bronx - turned up lighting ballasts that were leaking PCBs above the regulatory level of 50 parts per million in 10 of 13 samples taken, the agency announced Monday. Over the past several weeks, the E.P.A. found similar contamination at all three other city schools that it inspected, too.
