It was a curious exercise for a coach with the biggest game of his life ahead, but it was impossible to ignore the 15 stalls that had been mostly empty in Green Bay this season.

title: Big Love Watch: Rhonda Volmers Return
description: I am still applying smelling salts to counter the shock of Rhonda Volmers return on Sunday nights episode of Big Love. Rhonda! Venal, manipulating, lying, obfuscating, scary Veda-in-Mildred Pierce Rhonda!

title: Watch the Oscars Lunch Live
description: This years Super Bowl delivered great ratings, which is probably making the producers of the Oscars  the second-most-watched event in the U.S. after the ball game  extra antsy. This year the producers and the telecasts network, ABC, are aiming to increase viewership among younger people, with younger, weirder hosts (James Franco and Anne Hathaway), hipper singers (Florence of Florence and the Machine) and a promotional campaign aimed at breaking down the events perceived fustiness. The campaign, called Youre Invited, opens up the red carpet and backstage experience to viewers at home via ambitious live streaming  a first, according to Ad Age.

title: Mayor Tells Legislature That Lost Aid Will Ensure Layoffs
description: ALBANY  A week after he criticized Gov. Andrew M. Cuomos budget as unfair to New York City, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg appeared before lawmakers on Monday and offered grim examples to prove his point.Classroom crowding would worsen, he said. More than a third of the citys senior citizen centers would close. The scale of layoffs, in the schools and at government agencies, would be devastating.

title: Outbreaks: A Tool to Track Animal Diseases May Help to Protect Humans
description: VIENNA  A new online mapping tool will enable scientists and the public to track outbreaks of animal diseases that might jump to humans.

title: Robert Kubica, Formula One Driver, Is Recuperating After Crash
description: As reported Sunday by our colleagues at the Formula One blog, Robert Kubica, one of the most fearsome drivers on the Formula One race circuit, sustained multiple fractures on Sunday when he crashed his car in northern Italy.

title: Mets Owners Face Novel Claim in Madoff Clawback
description: Can an investor in a Ponzi scheme be held responsible for losses suffered by other investors even though that person never communicated with them or even knew that a fraud was being perpetrated?

title: Drugmakers Fever for the Power of RNA Interference Has Cooled
description: When RNA interference first electrified biologists several years ago, pharmaceutical companies rushed to harness what looked like a swift and surefire way to develop new drugs.

title: Prize for Phylicia Rashad
description: Phylicia Rashad will receive the lifetime achievement award at the 19th annual Pan African Film Festival, officials said on Monday. The festival, which will take place in Los Angeles Feb. 16 to 23, showcases films by and about people from the African diaspora. This years a lineup includes more than 120 films representing more than 30 countries.

title: Former UBS Exec Joins Emerging Global Advisors
description: Marten S. Hoekstra, the former chief executive of UBS Wealth Management Americas and a member of UBSs Group Executive Board, has joined Emerging Global Advisors as the asset management firms chief executive.

title: In Defense of Energy Drinks (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: A Time to Weep (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Polio in the Balance (3 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: The Matriarch of Modern Cancer Genetics
description: Dr. Janet Davison Rowley, 85, is the matriarch of modern cancer genetics. Without her 1970s finding that broken and translocated chromosomes were a factor in blood cancers, we might not have the treatments for leukemia that are commonplace today. We spoke earlier this winter at her University of Chicago offices and also at the Hyde Park home she shares with her husband of 62 years, Donald Rowley, a research pathologist. An edited and condensed version of the interviews follows.

title: How to Keep Winter From Taking a Toll on Your Back
description: This is your back speaking, and now is the winter of my discontent. With all the snow and ice and cold that have descended on much of the country, there are so many ways I can get hurt. So I want you to know what you can and should do to protect me and keep yourself out of debilitating and disabling pain, now and in the future.

title: Los Angeles Museum  and Getty Trust Jointly Acquire Collection of Mapplethorpe Works and Letters
description: The Los Angeles County Museum of Art and the J. Paul Getty Trust said on Monday they had jointly acquired a huge collection of the prints, negatives and letters of Robert Mapplethorpe, further strengthening Californias position as a major center for 20th-century photography.

title: Ensuring Domestic Tranquillity During Sleepovers
description: In every iteration of the interminable discussion of the new book Battle Hymn of the Tiger Mother, someone inevitably brings up the crucial issue of the sleepover  the childhood ritual in which the author, Amy Chua, wouldnt let her daughters take part.

title: Real vs. Virtual: Examining Works of Art Online
description: Overview | How do the experiences of looking at works of fine art in real life, in photo reproductions and in digital forms compare? What can be revealed by perusing an online trove of paintings and other works? In this lesson, students engage in one or more activities using Googles Art Project to reflect on key issues and questions about art.

title: Quote Unquote | Lost In Translation?
description: The A.P.C. founder Jean Touitou tells Womens Wear Daily that he doesnt care about expanding in Japan. Waiting for the wrath ofRei Kawakubo in 321

title: Barea Offers Glimpse Into Mavericks Future
description: When the calendar rolled over into 2011, the Dallas Mavericks were born anew. As of New Years Eve, the Mavericks were contenders; the acquisition of Tyson Chandler was paying considerable dividends, Dirk Nowitzki was in the midst of possibly his most efficient season to date, and a talented supporting cast had elevated the Mavs defense while keeping the offense afloat.

title: An Addict Crosses a Line, and Is Pulled Back
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  Gregory Reeve could hardly have picked a more Canadian way to become a heroin addict: a hockey puck in a game with friends shattered his jaw.

title: Tribesmen in Jordan Issue Urgent Call for Political Reform
description: JERUSALEM  Several dozen Jordanian tribesmen, historically core loyalists to the monarchy, have issued a rare statement calling for urgent and far-reaching political reform in Jordan. They said that without it, the country was headed down the path taken by Tunisia and Egypt.

title: Washington Invests in Making Wind Pay
description: The energy from ocean breezes is temptingly near, but the effort will require a lot of work, the energy and interior secretaries said Monday in announcing up to $50.5 million in federal spending over the next five years to try to make offshore wind farms viable.

title: The Odds of Picking the Next Apple
description: Carl Richards is a certified financial planner in Park City, Utah. His sketches are archived here on the Bucks blog and on his personal Web site, BehaviorGap.com.

title: Egypt, Inkblots, Agendas and Feeding 9 Billion
description: I recently wrote a couple of pieces aiming to move Beyond the Eternal Food Fight between techno-cornucopians convinced that innovation and efficiency will feed 9 billion prospering people and enviro-calamatists convinced the cliff is nigh, or were already over it.

title: Michael Moore Sues Weinsteins Over Fahrenheit 9/11
description: Fahrenheit 9/11, Michael Moores 2004 documentary about President George W. Bush, is still generating heat. Mr. Moore on Monday filed suit against Bob and Harvey Weinstein, who formed Fellowship Adventure Group to distribute Fahrenheit 9/11 in an alliance with Lionsgate and IFC Films, claiming that the Weinsteins defrauded him of at least $2.7 million in profits from the film. The suit, filed in Los Angeles County Superior Court, charged the Weinsteins with accounting tricks and financial deception in connection with Fahenheit 9/11, which took in about $222 million at the worldwide box office, and millions more on home video. Bert Fields, a lawyer for the Weinsteins, said Mr. Moore had been paid everything he was due, and was trying to make a public spectacle out of what he called a routine kind of auditing dispute. Mr. Moore has put in a number of very inflammatory claims designed for the press, Mr. Fields added. He should be ashamed of himself. Larry Stein, a lawyer for Mr. Moore, said in a statement that Mr. Moore had never sued anyone in his filmmaking career and that its very sad that it had to come to this.Mr. Moore and the Weinsteins have worked together on several films, including Sicko and The Big One.

title: Share Your Darkest Tales of Valentines Day
description: Its time for some predictions about next Monday.

title: Safeguarding Sage Grouse and Their Elaborate Courtship Dance
description: RYEGATE, Mont.  When permanent settlement began in the West some 16 million greater sage grouse lived on the steppes of the high plains.

title: Buffalo Billionaire Lifts Soccer in English Town
description: BEDLINGTON, England  The phone first rang a year ago in January. The caller identified himself as Bob Rich, a billionaire American businessman and sports team owner. He had English royals among his ancestors. For Christmas, his wife had bought him the title Lord of Bedlington. And he wanted to do something, well, lordly.

title: Why All the Noise About Muni Bankruptcies?
True Confessions of a Digital Hoarder
description: Walk into my apartment and youd most likely be hard-pressed to find a book or dish towel out of place. This is, in part, because I live in a studio in New York but also the residual ripples of growing up the youngest of five girls, which ingrained in me an obsessive compulsive disdain for clutter.

title: In Europe, an Effort to Shed Light on Short-Selling
description: Jonathan Fickies/Bloomberg NewsDavid Einhorn, the founder of Greenlight Capital.

title: Armstrong and Huffington on the AOL-Huffington Post Deal
description: AOLs chief executive, Tim Armstrong, and The Huffington Posts founder, Arianna Huffington, discuss on CNBC how the purchase of the news site fits into AOLs strategy. Mr. Armstrong likens AOL to Disney, where many brands exist under one umbrella, and explains how the deal positions the portal well for the strong digital advertising growth he expects. Ms. Huffington expresses her confidence in managing the array of AOL brands while ensuring high-quality content is produced.

title: Russia Expels a British Journalist
description: MOSCOW  Russia has expelled the Moscow correspondent for The Guardian, who has played a role in its coverage of WikiLeaks, the newspaper said on Monday.

title: TimesCast | February 7, 2011
description: AOL buys The Huffington Post, but why; Vancouvers unorthodox method to curb high H.I.V. rates among drug users; and Thomas L. Friedman from Cairo.

title: Super Bowl Ratings Cap Record Year for N.F.L.
description: The National Football League finished off its biggest television year ever with the most-watched television program of all time, as Super Bowl XLV averaged 111 million viewers on the Fox network.

title: Stress of Sliding Plates Builds Near Chile
description: When a magnitude-8.8 earthquake struck off the coast of Chile last February, geophysicists and seismologists were not surprised. The quakes epicenter was on a roughly 200-mile stretch of a fault where stresses had been building for nearly two centuries, and experts had expected that one day the strain would be relieved in a cataclysmic event.

title: My World and Welcome to It
description: Scooter Braun, the stubble-cheeked 29-year-old who serves officially as Justin Biebers manager and sometimes unofficially as the baby sitter of his legions of young admirers, was having trouble getting them to behave on Wednesday night.

title: Social Scientist Sees Bias Within
description: SAN ANTONIO  Some of the worlds pre-eminent experts on bias discovered an unexpected form of it at their annual meeting.

title: Just One Look | Missoni Pre-Fall Collection
description: The Pre-Fall Collections, being shown in New York over the next several weeks, arrive in stores in May to fill the gap between bikinis and furs.

title: Quips From an Oscar Luncheon
description: Did you watch? The Academy nominees luncheon may still be live-streaming nearby, but we decided to take a break to update you on the proceedings. Once upon a time, the Bagger worked in politics, and the luncheon reminded us of the many, many glad-handing events where, before anything actually happened  if anything actually did  there was first a laundry list of acknowledgments for all the officials, bigwigs and F.O.B.s in the room. With 151 nominees present  the largest nominee luncheon ever  this was a laundry list of institutional proportions.

title: Amid Egypt Turmoil, More Clashes in Sinai
description: JERUSALEM  Attacks in recent days suggest that provocateurs are trying to take advantage of the political turmoil in Cairo to spread unrest in Sinai, the desert peninsula that lies between Israel and the main territory of Egypt and near Saudi Arabia and Jordan.

title: Big Lots Shares Surge on Sale Talk
description: Shares of Big Lots, a discount retailer, surged more than 15 percent in late afternoon trading after Bloomberg News reported that the company was exploring its options, including a sale.

title: Lawmakers End of Earmarks Affects Local Programs Large and Small
description: WASHINGTON  Gone for now are the likes of the taxpayer-financed teapot museum, or studies on the mating habits of crabs.

title: On Evolution, Biology Teachers Stray From Lesson Plan
description: Teaching creationism in public schools has consistently been ruled unconstitutional in federal courts, but according to a national survey of more than 900 public high school biology teachers, it continues to flourish in the nations classrooms.

title: Bit by Bit, Business Is Improving
description: Manufacturing companies around the world agree: Business is getting better.

title: Hearts on Sleeves! | How the Fashion Flock Says, Be Mine
description: The fashion flock is putting the amour in glamour this Valentines Day. With that in mind, T caught up with the supremely adored, singles and pairs alike, to find out what they have planned for the Hallmark holiday.

title: Time Runs Out for Snowbound Cars
description: Move your car, people! yelled a Sanitation Department worker as he marched down East 64th Street west of Lexington Avenue on Monday morning. Today, sir! he shouted at Jesus Moreno, a 51-year-old chauffeur who was waiting out the no-parking period in his clients BMW S.U.V.

title: New High Note for Glee
description: A football- and zombie-theme episode of Glee, featuring a guest appearance by Katie Couric and a musical mash-up of Michael Jacksons Thriller and the Yeah Yeah Yeahs Heads Will Roll, received a big boost in the ratings on Sunday from its time slot following the Super Bowl. According to Nielsens estimates, Foxs Glee attracted 26.8 million viewers, a record for this hit musical comedy and more than any other scripted series on television in three years. In comparison, however, ratings for the episode fell short of those for last years occupant of that highly desirable time slot, CBSs reality show Undercover Boss, which garnered 38.7 million viewers. Final audience figures for Glee and Foxs Super Bowl coverage were not immediately available on Monday; however, Nielsens preliminary overnight estimates from the major media markets were up about 3 percent from a year ago, when CBSs Super Bowl broadcast set a ratings record with 106.5 million viewers, the largest television audience in United States history. Opposite the ratings juggernaut on Fox, CBS fared the best with 3.9 million viewers for a rerun edition of 60 Minutes at 7, followed by reruns the rest of the night. ABC was third, averaging 2.7 million viewers for the 2007 movie Knocked Up, while NBC finished fourth.

title: Swimming Against a Demographic Tide in Macao
description: The Macanese, whose roots are found in many places of the former Portuguese empire, retain their own culture and their own language, Patu.

title: Family Dramas of the Rich and Famous
description: One of the reasons we are transfixed by celebrities is because they represent our lives writ large. What is gossip, after all, if not a moderator of social norms. The chatter about other peoples conflicts and choices helps us map our own.

title: Big Banks to Pay More to Insure Deposits
description: Big financial institutions will pick up a greater portion of the cost to protect deposits when banks fail, under a plan adopted Monday by federal regulators.

title: For Obama, Political Risks in Projecting Powerlessness
description: Last Thursday morning, just as the Egyptian crisis was at its bloodiest, President Obama attended a national prayer breakfast. One wonders if he was tempted to recite the Serenity Prayer:

title: The Drawbacks of a Modest Celebrity
description: IVE been traveling to shows as a performing musician for decades. I love music and meeting people, but its not much fun getting to places anymore.

title: A Doctors Guide to the Sleepover
description: Sleepovers and slumber parties are now an intrinsic part of childhood, but a night away from home can create problems for both children and parents, writes Dr. Perri Klass, a pediatrician, in the 18 and Under column.

title: Fire in Rio Damages Carnaval Preparations and Dims Hopes of Many Performers
description: SO PAULO, Brazil  An early-morning fire in a warehouse district on Monday destroyed the costumes and dimmed the hopes of at least three prominent samba schools competing in Rio de Janeiros annual Carnaval parade. But city officials vowed that the event would go forward.

title: Navigating Bromances and Romances
description: The first question likely to arise over Traffic Light, a comedy beginning on Tuesday on Fox, is: Whats up with the name? It suggests transit police, speeding tickets, fender benders, turf wars  a heretofore untapped world of municipal action, much in the vein of Parks and Recreation.

title: Pictures of the Day: Egypt and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Egypt, Tunisisa, Mexico and Bangladesh

title: The Oscar Nominees, Lunching and Hoping
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif.  They came, they smiled, they poured on practiced you-deserve-it-not-me humility. Behind it all? Daggers and crossed fingers that half the room will go kersplat in the immediate future.

title: A Long Run Before a Much, Much Longer Trek
description: Around dawn late last month, Pat Farmer joined a smattering of New Yorkers braving the snow, the slush and the cold to get in a jog through Central Park.

title: Thomas L. Friedman From Tahrir Square
description: The Op-Ed columnist on American foreign policy and the new reality in Egypt.

title: Postholiday Clearance at Retailers Includes Some Senior Executives
description: With the holidays over, its open season on executives at retail companies  especially because, for the first time in three years, many cannot blame their problems on the economy.

title: Decoding the AOL-Huffington Post Deal
description: Related: AOL Is Buying The Huffington Post | AOL Buys Another Crack at a Future

title: Science and Religion on a Collision Course at Galileos Trial
description: Over the centuries, Galileos trial in 1633 for defending heliocentrism  that Earth orbits the Sun, not the other way around  the Inquisitions finding that he was vehemently suspect of heresy and his recantation have grown far beyond just a seminal clash between science and religion. The Galileo affair has become general shorthand for speaking truth to power, a cautionary tale to invoke whenever new ideas challenge the established order.

title: Pictures of the Day: Egypt and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Egypt, Tunisia, Mexico and Bangladesh.

title: Tibetan Lama Faces Scrutiny and Suspicion in India
description: DHARAMSALA, India  His daring escape from Tibet seemed out of a movie. Then only 14, Ogyen Trinley Dorje was one of Tibetan Buddhisms most revered incarnate lamas, and his journey through the icy passes of the Himalayas was viewed as a major embarrassment for China. The youth arrived in India in early 2000 to a euphoric greeting from Tibetan exiles.

title: A Noticeable Absence at Oscars Luncheon
description: Beyond the quips at this years installment of the Oscar nominees luncheon, one of the highlights was expected to be the Scott Rudin/Harvey Weinstein show. These rivals, who have tangled in the past over cinematic awards bait, are both racing hard for best picture this season  Mr. Rudin with The Social Network and True Grit, and Mr. Weinstein with The Kings Speech. But as our colleague Brooks Barnes reports from the lunch at the Beverly Hilton, Mr. Weinstein got to work the room alone. Mr. Rudin was said to be home sick with pneumonia.

title: Democratic Leadership Council Suspends Its Operations
description: The Democratic Leadership Council, which for more than two decades preached a centrist brand of politics embodied by President Bill Clinton, is suspending its dwindling operations, the organizations founder said in a statement e-mailed to The Caucus late Monday.

title: Harbinger to Sell Remaining Inmarsat Stake
description: Harbinger Capital Partners, the hedge fund controlled by Philip A Falcone, will sell its remaining 14 percent stake in satellite operator Inmarsat, according to regulatory filings.

title: Critics Choice: New CDs
description: DELICATE STEVE

title: The Web of Spider-Man
description: A timeline of coverage of the Broadway musical Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark.

title: With a Voice and a Spirit, Triumphing Over Racism
description: Barbara Smith Conrad, a black child of the segregated South, did not seek to vote or to ride in the front of the bus. She just wanted to sing.

title: Eyebrows Raised Over Envoy to Cairo
description: The White House on Monday faced criticism over its decision to send Frank Wisner, a retired ambassador and diplomat, to Cairo last week. At the same time, his seeming support for President Hosni Mubarak put Mr. Wisners employer, a powerhouse lobbying firm, on the defensive about its business dealings in Egypt.

title: Worlds Top Chess Players on Hand for Aeroflot Open
description: The Tradewise Gibraltar Chess Festival, which ended last week, is a popular tournament, attracting many strong players. And the World Open, which is held every year in the Philadelphia area around Independence Day, usually has more than 1,000 players between all its sections.

title: Mens Fall Fashion 2011 | Ralph Lauren
description: Continuing our illustrative coverage of mens fall 2011 fashion, Richard Haines will be traveling alongside me during the New York shows to bring you our favorite looks in vivid color. We lead off with Ralph Lauren, who presented his new collection last week. I was struck by the elegance and purity of the relatively new Black Label Sportswear line. This refined olive cashmere jacket with a hunting patch at the shoulder and bellows pockets was a great distillation of the military mood weve been seeing. Paired with gray flannel trousers and brown Chelsea boots, it is the perfect country-weekend-in-the-city look.

title: Time to Tighten Loose Money
description: The stagflationists are losing the argument. The world is inflating and thats a worry. But inflation is coming from growth that seems increasingly strong and from money thats looking far too loose for a reviving world. The risk is that oil and other commodities will soar much higher now, as they did in 2008, only this time the spike may not recede quickly.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,457 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It recently confirmed the death of the following American:

title: A Pregame Interview Prediction Falls Short
description: The Super Bowl set an audience record for the Fox network, but the Fox News Channels biggest star couldnt quite match his own expectations for his pregame interview with President Obama.

title: A Bedroom Voice to Match His Eyes
description: What a difference a few months can make. The return engagement of Paulo Szot, the smoldering Polish-Brazilian baritone, to the Caf Carlyle, singing largely the same program he performed there in his nightclub debut last fall, is an encouraging example of an opera singer belatedly finding his pop mojo. Thats not to say that Mr. Szot, in treading the treacherous crossover path that has stymied many other singers before him (most notably, Jos Carreras), has turned into Barry Manilow or even Josh Groban.

title: Top Recruit Impressed by Clemsons Class
description: Although national signing day was last Wednesday, there is still plenty of intrigue surrounding the nations top recruit, Jadeveon Clowney, who has put off announcing his decision until Feb. 14.

title: Distinct Mix Holds On in a Corner of China
description: MACAO  Long before words like multiculturalism and fusion cuisine entered the modern lexicon, Aida de Jesus and her forebears were mashing up food, language and DNA from far-flung corners of the globe.

title: Obama Presses Business Leaders to Hire and Invest
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama urged American businesses on Monday to get in the game by letting loose trillions of dollars that they are holding in reserve, saying that they can help create a virtuous cycle of more sales, higher demand and greater profits that will put people back to work.

title: Kindle Books Get Page Numbers and Social Features
description: Kindle e-books are about to become more social. They will also be getting a small change that will make many Kindle owners rejoice: page numbers.

title: Irans Opposition Seeks Rally to Back Egypt and Tunisia
description: TEHRAN  With democracy tremors rocking the Arab world, Irans opposition has challenged its hard-line leaders to allow a peaceful demonstration  ostensibly in support of the uprisings in Tunisia and Egypt.

title: Texas: Inquiry Sought Into Youths Beating
description: Representative Al Green, a Houston Democrat, on Monday asked the Justice Department to begin a civil rights investigation after a videotape surfaced that shows Houston police officers beating and kicking a 15-year-old burglary suspect last March as he lay on the ground. Four officers are awaiting trial on misdemeanor charges of official repression in the case, but prosecutors had blocked release of the tape, arguing that it would taint a trial. An ABC television affiliate, KTRK, obtained a copy and broadcast it on Wednesday, reigniting anger over the arrest. On the video, the teenager appears to be clipped by a police car during a chase. He falls, flips onto his stomach and puts his hands behind his head. Several officers rush in, punching and kicking him as they arrest him. We are outraged at what occurred, Mr. Green said. The teenager, Chad Holley, was later sentenced to probation for burglary.

title: Planned Parenthood to Retrain Public Staff
description: Reacting to the release of videotapes in which its staff members advise an apparent sex trafficker, Planned Parenthood said Monday that it would retrain thousands of staff members across the country on its rules for reporting possible dangers to minors, and would automatically fire anyone who violated them.

title: A Safe Place
description: In Vancouver, a controversial strategy against H.I.V. and AIDS includes a site where drug users can inject themselves using clean needles -- then get tested and treated if they have the virus.

title: A Tampa Bay Redesign
description: Ed O'Hara, C.E.O. of SME Branding, walks through the process of redesigning the logo for the Tampa Bay Lightning.

title: Company Settles Case in Firing Tied to Facebook
description: An ambulance company that fired an employee after she criticized her supervisor on Facebook agreed on Monday to settle a case brought by the National Labor Relations Board.

title: A Bad Documents Good Idea
description: The Southerners who gathered in Montgomery, Ala., a century and a half ago saw themselves as the true inheritors of the original Founding Fathers. Indeed, the Constitution they approved  its sesquicentennial is today  was more imitation than innovation. We the people of the Confederate states, said their preamble, establish justice, insure domestic tranquility, and secure the blessings of liberty to ourselves and our posterity.

title: No Guarantees in Life, Not Even a Booked Room
description: ALLEN STEWART, a Dallas trial lawyer, says he is fed up with hotels that overbook and then turn away people who show up with guaranteed reservations. So hes been collecting stories like this one:

title: Ex-Dow Scientist Is Convicted of Selling Secrets in China
description: A jury in Baton Rouge, La., on Monday found a former Dow Chemical scientist guilty of conspiring to steal company secrets and sell them to firms in China, the Justice Department said.

title: Chicago Conductor Undergoes Successful Facial Surgery
description: A surgeon on Monday successfully repaired broken bones in the face of Riccardo Muti, the music director of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra, who was injured after fainting on the podium during a rehearsal last week, officials said.

title: With One Plan for a Hudson Tunnel Dead, Senators Offer Another Option
description: New Jerseys two Democratic senators, Frank R. Lautenberg and Robert Menendez, have been trying to revive the idea of a trans-Hudson train tunnel ever since Gov. Chris Christie upset them by halting construction on the one that New Jersey Transit started to build last year.

title: What Is Academic Work?
description: In previous columns I have argued that academic work is distinctive  something and not everything  and that a part of its distinctiveness is its distance from political agendas. This does not mean that political agendas cant be the subject of academic work  one should inquire into their structure, history, etc.  but that the point of introducing them into the classroom should never be to urge them or to warn against them. I have never felt that my attempts to explain this point have been entirely successful, but I am moved to try again by the recent experience of a conference that, I believe, exemplifies the point in action.

title: An H.I.V. Strategy Invites Addicts In
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  At 12 tables, in front of 12 mirrors, a dozen people are fussing intently in raptures of self-absorption, like chorus line members applying makeup in a dressing room.

title: In Egypt, U.S. Weighs Push for Change With Stability
description: WASHINGTON  Vice President Omar Suleiman of Egypt says he does not think it is time to lift the 30-year-old emergency law that has been used to suppress and imprison opposition leaders. He does not think President Hosni Mubarak needs to resign before his term ends in September. And he does not think his country is yet ready for democracy.

title: Wall St. Joins S.E.C. in Plea for Bigger Budget
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission is nearly broke.

title: Down and Out on Rodeo Drive
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif.  Just how widespread is the budget crisis in California? Even on Rodeo Drive, whose retail strip is synonymous with luxury, this city has taken a hit.

title: As Hobokens Riverfront Crumbles, the Cost for Repairs Soars
description: In Hobokens evolution from blue-collar port to upscale pocket of bistros and condominiums, the waterfront underwent the most profound transformation. Factories and docks gave way to promenades and parks with drop-dead views of Manhattan, drawing crowds that fed the nearby hotels and shops along the much-promoted Gold Coast.

title: If Mubarak Leaves, Whats Next?
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Plan to Replace Principals Hits Snag: Who Will Step In?
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio  The aggressive $4 billion program begun by the Obama administration in 2009 to radically transform the countrys worst schools included, as its centerpiece, a plan to install new principals to overhaul most of the failing schools.

title: Copper Prices and Incidences of Copper Theft Rise
description: Thieves broke into a muffler shop in Chillicothe, Ohio, and stole cash  and 130 catalytic converters. Pervasive thefts of copper wire from under the streets of Fresno, Calif., have prompted the city to seal thousands of its manhole covers with concrete. And in Picher, Okla., someone felled the towns utility poles with chain saws, allowing thieves to abscond with 3,000 feet of wire while causing a blackout.

title: Scrutinizing Military Cuts
description: To the Editor:

title: Super Bowl Commercials
description: To the Editor:

title: Olbermann Said to Be Going to Current TV
description: 11:02 a.m. | Updated  Keith Olbermann, the former MSNBC anchor, will host a prime time program for Current TV, the low-rated cable channel co-founded by Al Gore. The one-hour program will begin sometime in the spring.

title: Muslims to Be Congressional Hearings Main Focus
description: WASHINGTON  The new chairman of the House Homeland Security Committee said Monday that he planned to call mostly Muslim and Arab witnesses to testify in hearings next month on the threat of homegrown Islamic terrorism.

title: Among Nations Youngest, Analysis Finds Fewer Whites
description: WASHINGTON  Whites continued to decline as a share of the American population in 2009, and they now represent less than half of all 3-year-olds, according to a Brookings Institution analysis of census data released Monday.

title: J. Paul Getty III, 54, Dies; Had Ear Cut Off by Captors
description: J. Paul Getty III, who was a grandson of the oil baron once believed to be the richest man in the world and who achieved tragic notoriety in 1973 when he was kidnapped by Italian gangsters, died Saturday at his home near London. He was 54.

title: Huffington Deal Raises Question: What Site Will Be Sold Next?
description: In agreeing to buy The Huffington Post for $315 million, AOL is putting what appears to be a significant premium on the ability to attract and build a community of readers.

title: For Mets Owners, Court Fight Could Be Costly

title: Ken Olsen, Who Built DEC Into a Power, Dies at 84

title: Mothers-to-Be Are Getting the Message
description: Were used to hearing about public initiatives that get mired in politics or entangled in bureaucracy, but we rarely hear about programs that exceed expectations. So heres one: last week marked the one-year anniversary of a program called text4baby, a service that sends free text messages to women who are pregnant or whose babies are less than a year old, providing them with information, and reminders, to improve their health and the health of their babies.

title: League Rescinds Technical Foul From Stoudemire
description: The N.B.A. rescinded the technical foul that Amare Stoudemire received against the Philadelphia 76ers on Sunday, reducing his total for the season to 13. Stoudemire is still close to the threshold of 16 technicals, at which a player receives a one-game suspension. On Sunday, Stoudemire poked the ball away from Philadelphias Spencer Hawes and was called for a foul. He reacted by racing up the court, and the official Bob Delaney called him for the technical under the N.B.A.s new policy to curtail player complaining.

title: Spring Is Hardly Just Around the Corner, but Baseball Is
description: Around much of this winter-battered country, grass is only a rumor. Winter is but halfway over, and already enough snow has fallen in Boston to blanket its star second baseman, Dustin Pedroia, who stands 69 inches tall. Undoubtedly, another storm  or three  are coming.

In fact, one of the few things that feel wrong with Citi Field is its name.

title: Parrying the Big Cuts
description: After months in a defensive crouch, Democrats are arising to challenge the severe budget cuts planned by House Republicans, which would almost certainly make unemployment worse. And it is not a moment too soon because when the stopgap resolution that is financing the government expires on March 4, the House will have significant leverage to get its way. Without a new spending bill, the government will shut down  a prospect that seems to delight many newly elected Republicans.

title: No One Size Fits All

title: Expensive Prisons
description: In the last decade, crime rates and the prison population have declined significantly in New York State. Yet prison costs have soared. As part of Gov. Andrew Cuomos search for ways to cut spending, his new budget proposes two sensible steps toward the long overdue goal of closing down unnecessary prisons.

Clowney said he had narrowed his choices to Alabama, Clemson and South Carolina. Clemson had a good recruiting class, Clowney said. If I go, they would have an even better one.

description: Wartime artifacts fill museums the world over, but very few showcase the experience from the point of view of children. title: Aaron Rodgerss Very Long Draft Day
description: In this video clip, ESPNs Chris Berman, Chris Mortensen and Mel Kiper Jr. try to buck up Aaron Rodgers on draft day in 2005. At that point, Rodgers had already been handed the role of guy stuck in the green room. He was dropping on the draft board and being treated as if he had a contagious disease. The draft had only reached the 15th pick. Rodgers had nine more slots to fall, and many more minutes to squirm.

What Im about to say may seem obvious, because it is obvious, at least if you approach it the right way; but I still think it needs saying.

title: Valentines Day | Hooked

Like most members of the handbag-toting gender, Im always torn between putting my bag on the restaurant banquette (takes up too much room) and the floor (not too sanitary, and often unsafe). Ive looked at handbag hooks before, but most of them are either too complicated or too cute.

title: A Lawsuit to Welcome Harvey Weinstein Back
description: He was a high-flying, sometimes-vilified character and he was hanging by a thread  no, we dont mean Spider-Man. We mean, of course, Harvey Weinstein, the other entertainment behemoth we love to puncture, and caricature. With a dozen Oscar nominations for The Kings Speech and a few others scattered elsewhere, Mr. Weinstein is officially back, a turn of events proclaimed by our own David Carr, and solidified twice over, by a lengthy new profile in Vanity Fair, and by a lawsuit. As our colleague Michael Cieply reports, Michael Moore filed suit in Los Angeles against the Weinstein brothers, Harvey and Bob, over profits from Fahrenheit 9/11, alleging accounting tricks and financial deception that defrauded him of at least $2.7 million in profits from his blockbuster 2004 documentary (or docbuster, as his acolyte Morgan Spurlock calls them).

title: Schools Facing Cuts if Lunches Arent Paid For
description: Of the 2,200 students at Intermediate School 61 in Corona, Queens, 86 percent receive free cafeteria lunches. Some others pay a reduced price, and some are supposed to pay full price.

title: Buoyed by Strong Earnings, Asahi in the Hunt for Deals
description: Asahi Breweries, the largest beer producer in Japan, on Tuesday reported record annual earnings of 53.1 billion yen for 2010 and said it would use some of its cash pile of four billion yen to make deals this year.

title: Robert Sean Leonard Joining Born Yesterday on Broadway
description: The doctor is out, temporarily, and headed back to Broadway: Robert Sean Leonard, who plays the infinitely patient oncologist Dr. James Wilson on the hit Fox medical drama House, will return to the stage in the coming revival of Born Yesterday, its press representatives said on Tuesday. Mr. Leonard is set to join the production as Paul Verrall, the journalist tasked with educating Billie Dawn, the showgirl and gal pal of the crooked mogul Harry Brock. This latest revival of the Garson Kanin play, which is to begin previews at the Cort Theater on March 31 and open on April 24, previously announced that it would star Jim Belushi (of According to Jim) as Brock and Nina Arianda (Venus in Fur) as Dawn, and would be directed by Doug Hughes (Doubt). The original 1946 Broadway production starred Paul Douglas, Judy Holliday and Gary Merrill, and the 1950 film version starred Broderick Crawford, Ms. Holliday and William Holden.

title: Doughnut Plant Is Set to Open in Chelsea Hotel
description: Mark Isreal, who has been sending forth creative, multi-hued and myriad-flavored doughnuts from his Doughnut Plant shop on the Lower East Side for 16 years, will open his second New York store in the Chelsea Hotel on Valentines Day.

title: Does a Drilling Boom Beckon?
description: The announcement this week by the offshore drilling giant Ensco that it will buy Pride International for $7.3 billion is only the latest sign that oil companies see a bright future for offshore drilling, despite the BP well blowout in the Gulf of Mexico last year. That accident left 11 dead, poured millions of barrels of crude into the sea and put the countrys deepwater drilling on hold.

title: Spotlight Stays on Dallas
description: Maybe we should have suspected something big when a winter storm raked North Texas, or when ice came crashing down on poor, unsuspecting heads from the Cowboys Stadium roof, or when the premier sporting event in America was sidetracked by seats that were not finished in time, even though Dallas knew it was hosting this Super Bowl since May 2007. But it turns out, these events were only the beginning. Dallas is now officially the vortex of sports-related weirdness.

title: Producers Hope Packers Championship Glow Shines on Lombardi
description: The producers of the Broadway play Lombardi are hoping for a halo effect at the box office from the Green Bay Packers victory in Sunday nights Super Bowl, ordering championship T-shirts to display at the theater, inviting Packers players to see the show, and planning a springtime media campaign linking the play to that storied N.F.L. franchises fourth Super Bowl win.

title: Still Nearly 5 Unemployed Workers for Every Opening
description: There were still nearly five unemployed workers for every job opening in the United States in December, according to a Labor Department report released today.

title: Dont Stop Believin (or Tourin): Glee Cast Hitting the Road Again
description: Based on recent episodes of Glee and the ever-changing loyalties of its characters (not to mention their ever-intertwining love lives), we have absolutely no idea where this hit Fox musical-comedy is headed in the weeks to come. But we know where the cast members will be in May and June: theyll be hitting the road for another tour of North American arenas and performance spaces. On Tuesday Fox said that a 16-city Glee Live! in Concert series will begin on May 21 at the Mandalay Bay Events Center in Las Vegas and conclude on June 18 at the Nassau Coliseum in Uniondale, N.Y. (Another performance in the New York area will be on June 16 at the Izod Center in East Rutherford, N.J.; interestingly, no performance has been scheduled on June 12, the date that the Tony Awards are presented.) A statement from Fox said that the show, conceived by the Glee co-creator Ryan Murphy, will feature songs performed on the series, including Empire State of Mind, Toxic, Its My Life and  deal with it  Dont Stop Believin.

title: Broad Majority of Americans Sympathetic to Egyptian Protesters
description: More than 8 in 10 Americans say they are sympathetic to the protesters in Egypt who have called for a change in their government, and most think the changes will be mostly good for Egypt and for the United States, according to a Gallup poll released on Tuesday.

title: Jeff Fager to Be Named Chairman of CBS News
description: 4:00 p.m. | Updated Jeff Fager, the executive producer of 60 Minutes, will be named chairman of CBS News on Tuesday, with Sean McManus, the president of CBS News and Sports, returning exclusively to the sports division as chairman, the network said.

title: Same War, New Theater
description: The Pacific, an HBO mini-series set in World War II by the team behind 2001s Band of Brothers, follows three real-life Marines.

title: A Photographers New Legs
description: Joao Silva, a 44-year-old photographer for The New York Times, lost both his legs last October when he stepped on a mine in Afghanistan. Today, the Lens blog posted a video of Mr. Silva walking for the first time on new artificial legs.

title: U.S. Delegation Is Seeking Deals in India
description: BANGALORE, India  Nearly two years ago, President Obama rankled many people here when he said that American tax law unfairly benefited companies that created jobs in Bangalore and punished companies that hired in Buffalo.

title: One on One: Jane McGonigal, Game Designer
description: Jane McGonigal is a game designer and author of the new book Reality Is Broken, in which she argues that by playing games, people can improve their lives and solve real-world problems. Here is an edited version of our talk:

title: Video: A Tampa Bay Redesign
description: Ed OHara, C.E.O. of SME Branding, walks through the process of redesigning the logo for the Tampa Bay Lightning.

title: Guest Post: James Geary on Metaphor, A Taxonomy
description: Metaphor lives a secret life all around us.We utter about one metaphor for every 10 to 25 words, or about six metaphors a minute.

title: A Conversation With Tobias Moskowitz
description: Tobias Moskowitz and L. Jon Wertheim became friends at a summer camp in Michigan 27 years ago. Mr. Moskowitz became an economist at the University of Chicago. Mr. Wertheim became a Sports Illustrated writer. They remained friends and ultimately decided to collaborate on a book that combined their two fields. Its called Scorecasting (Random House) and it tries to bring the empirical approach of economics to the world of sports.

title: After a False Dawn, Anxiety for Illegal Immigrant Students
description: MILWAUKEE  It was exhilarating for Maricela Aguilar to stand on the steps of the federal courthouse here one day last summer and reveal for the first time in public that she is an illegal immigrant.

description: The new Consumer Financial Protection Bureau is open to your suggestions.

title: Go for Broke | Wes Gordon Chinchilla Cuffs, $995
description: What: Wes Gordon Chincilla Cuffs

title: The Marginal Cost of Children
description: Laura Vanderkams most recent book, 168 Hours, was about how to fit everything into your day.

title: Q&A: Best Cruise Options for a Solo Traveler
description: Im a single woman, have never been on a cruise ship and want to try one this year. I will likely be traveling alone, so what are the best options for single adults who dont want to pay double for a cabin and dont want to room with a stranger?

title: Teaching New Players Old Tricks
description: Glenn Robinsons 40th season as the mens basketball coach at Franklin & Marshall College is not easily distinguished from those that preceded it.

title: House Republican Leaders Joining Obama for Lunch
description: 1:48 p.m. | Updated President Obama will have lunch with the Republican leaders of the House on Wednesday as he continues his outreach to Congress in the wake of his partys heavy losses in November.

title: Disobeying Sorkins Musical Orders
description: The elements behind the success of The Social Network, as its makers rarely tire of telling us, were an odd mix. There were no stars, save for a pop singer; a subject that was an Internet punch line even before the Internet heard its actual punch lines; directed by a visual mastermind, David Fincher, and based on the pulsing dialogue of Aaron Sorkin  both of them big personalities with opposing styles. Mr. Fincher has been nominated for an Oscar and Mr. Sorkin has already been rewarded; he just won the Writers Guild of America award for best adapted screenplay and is likely to pick up the Oscar in that category as well. At the Writers Guild ceremony in Los Angeles, he made sure to spread the credit to his collaborator. I wrote a good screenplay, he said, but David Fincher made a great movie.

title: I.R.S. Offers a Tougher Amnesty Deal for Offshore Accounts
description: Offshore tax evaders received a new incentive on Tuesday to come forward and declare their hidden bank accounts to the Internal Revenue Service, with stiffer penalties than a previous offer but no risk of prosecution.

title: Icahn Threatens Proxy Fight at Mentor Graphics
description: Carl C. Icahn

title: Critics' Picks: 'Tootsie'
description: A. O. Scott looks back at Sydney Pollack's 1982 comedy about show business and sexual identity.

title: A Peek Into the N.H.L. Super Bowl Party
description: If youre like millions of Americans, you spent Sunday evening eating, gambling and watching football at a Super Bowl party. And chances are, you spent most of that time shaking your head at the goofy collection of humanity that you call your friends.

title: Bronx Planned Parenthood Is Target of Undercover Video
description: An anti-abortion group released a videotape Tuesday of a man posing as a pimp and a woman posing as a prostitute, getting information from an employee of a Planned Parenthood clinic in the Bronx about how to obtain abortions and treatment for sexually transmitted diseases for under-age sex workers.

title: Wheelies: Imported From Detroit Edition
description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

title: Ruling Appears to End to Chapter 11 Gift Plans
description: The recent decision by the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit in the DBSD North America case may be the end of gift plans in Chapter 11 bankruptcy cases. The crucial question is whether it will really matter.

title: Timing of Baby Food Tied to Obesity Risk
description: Feeding an infant solid food before 4 months of age increases the babys risk of becoming obese by the toddler years, a new study shows.

title: In Teroldegos, the Thrill of the Obscure
description: PEOPLE often complain to me that wine confuses them. They dont want to memorize the myriad names and places. They want it to be effortless and easy. Just last week, at a trade-sponsored conference on Italian wines in New York City, a noted American importer assailed the complicated nature of Italian wine-labeling laws, which he said were irrelevant to American consumers and should be simplified.

title: Britains Bigger Tax on Banks
description: Britain has imposed an extra 800 million ($1.3 billion) tax on banks this year, bringing the total to 2.5 billion ($4 billion)  as the government tries to negotiate a deal to limit bonuses and encourage lending to businesses.

title: Drought and the Food Chain
description: Six years of drought in southern Australia leads to farming changes.

title: 2 Fall to Their Deaths at Upper West Side Construction Site
description: Two ironworkers died on Tuesday morning after falling 65 feet in an elevator shaft inside a building on the Upper West Side that is being redeveloped for a church, city officials said.

title: With Lack of Stars, College Mens Basketball Finds Parity
description: With Selection Sunday less than five weeks away, two vintage rivalry games Wednesday will offer a glimpse of what has been an unusual college mens basketball season, one defined as much by missing stars as shining ones.

title: Pictures of the Day: Egypt and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Egypt, Germany and Cambodia.

title: Worker Locked in Planes Cargo Hold Avoids Becoming Passenger
description: WASHINGTON  Passengers on a US Airways plane ready for departure from Reagan National Airport here on Monday morning apparently alerted a flight attendant to screams and thumps coming from under the floor, which turned out to be a baggage handler who was trapped in the forward cargo hold.

title: The President Quits His Cigarette Habit
description: President Obama has quit smoking and has not had a cigarette in almost a year, his wife, Michelle Obama, said Tuesday.

title: Electronic Flaws Did Not Cause Toyota Problems, U.S. Says
description: WASHINGTON  After dissecting Toyotas engine control software and bathing its microchips in every type of radiation engineers could think of, federal investigators found no evidence that the companys cars are susceptible to sudden acceleration from electronic failures, the government said Tuesday.

title: Emanuel Unveils Proposed Budget Cuts for Chicago
description: CHICAGO  In a much-anticipated campaign speech on the citys budget, Rahm Emanuel said he would freeze spending on his first day as mayor and ask department heads to find at least $75 million in spending cuts.

title: Mayor Testified in Case Against Campaign Aide
description: Prosecutors on Tuesday revealed that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg had given secret grand jury testimony in the case against John F. Haggerty Jr., a campaign aide who is accused of stealing $1.1 million from the mayor.

title: Fight the Fed
description: If the Fed is buying, perhaps you should sell.

title: An Insider Trading Defendants Tool of the Trade
description: How are Tuesdays insider trading charges against four hedge fund employees different from all the other cases?

title: Drivers on Call
description: Dottie Macdonald, 81, got to the annual crafts fair in Portland, Me., this winter the same way she always does: with six big bins of dolls and quilts and artwork stacked in the back of a 2002 Dodge Caravan, the one her husband, Bob, 86, always drives because Mrs. Macdonald never learned how.

title: Iranian Dissident Says Planned March Will Test Regime
description: Mehdi Karroubi, an Iranian opposition leader, said Tuesday that a demonstration planned in Tehran next week, nominally in solidarity with the protest movements in Egypt and Tunisia, was a test both for the Iranian government and its opponents.

title: Secrets of the White House Press Secretaries
description: What happens when you get four former White House press secretaries spanning two decades of political history into a room?

title: Prosecutors to Recommend Trial for Berlusconi
description: ROME  Prosecutors in Milan said Tuesday that they would seek to try Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi on criminal charges related to prostitution and abuse of office  but in Italys unique political climate, the scandal so far has not forced him from office.

title: The Winklevi Step Up Their Facebook Offensive
description: Its always a good day for the Bagger when there is Winkelvi news. Happily, Cameron and Tyler Winklevoss, the 65 Olympic rowers and Harvard grads (if you listen to everybody) and actual founders of Facebook (if you listen to them), are pretty comfortable in the spotlight. They are featured in a video interview in The Daily, the new iPad publication from Rupert Murdoch (with a logo thats startlingly Facebook blue), in which they again assert their claims to the social networking site, and to looking extremely fit. Their real problem, they maintain, is that Mark Zuckerberg  a real founder of Facebook, according to most courts and viewers of The Social Network  believes that the situation is all about him.

title: Roys Speedy Return Raises Questions
description: Now is this time for basketball fans  and those patriots of the sovereign Blazer Nation  to hope that Brandon Roy and the oft-criticized Portland Trailblazers medical staff know what theyre doing.

title: 1,676 Geese Died for Human Air Travel Last Year
description: Updated Wednesday, 10:35 a.m. | One question that remained from last summers Prospect Park goose slaughter was just how many geese the United States Department of Agriculture rounded up and gassed in an effort to improve air safety.

title: Uncertain Coda for Mansion With a Musical Heritage
description: Up the hill, past where the garbage trucks go when they need a little work, the for-sale signs are on the wrought-iron fence. The mansion  yes, on a forlorn block like this is a mansion, an Italianate villa from when this stretch of Astoria, Queens, was weekend-getaway country  is on the market.

title: Revolt! Comparing Historical Revolutions
description: Overview | What is a revolution, and how is it different from other kinds of revolts and conflicts? How do the protests in Egypt compare with historical revolutions? In this lesson, students work together to define revolution and engage in research to help them create infographics that represent various historical revolutions around the world.

title: The Beginning of a Drilling Boom
description: The news on Monday that the offshore drilling giant Ensco will buy a rival, Pride International, for $7.3 billion is only the latest sign of a bright future for offshore drilling.

title: Critics Picks Video: Tootsie
description: In this weeks Critics Picks, A. O. Scott looks back at Sydney Pollacks 1982 comedy Tootsie, about an actor (Dustin Hoffman) who dresses as a woman to land an audition and creates myriad problems. While the film deals with feminist themes and plays for laughs, Tootsie, Mr. Scott says, is neither a sermon or a farce. Instead, he says the film is about discovering who you really are by pretending to be someone else. Have you seen Tootsie? Please share your thoughts.

title: F.D.A. Offers Device Proposals
description: The Food and Drug Administration, responding to criticism that it is hindering innovation, proposed a new system on Tuesday that would speed the approvals of pioneering medical devices.

title: Whats New in California? Dont Ask Robert Parker
description: And so came the announcement over the weekend that Robert M. Parker Jr. was shuffling the lineup of reviewers at The Wine Advocate, the wine review he founded in 1978.

title: Mexico Hesitates to Intervene as Rising Peso Pressures Its Exports
description: MEXICO CITY  Six years ago, Benjamn Hernndez turned his familys small metal-stamping company into an exporter. Although the firm barely survived the global economic crisis, it bounced back last year. But now he has a new worry.

title: Samurai Shopper | Floral and Hardy
description: For St. Valentine, there were no hearts and flowers. Whichever of his ancient legends you buy, they all end with the devout man getting brutally beaten and beheaded on February 14 in a three-digit year. Not to bum you out or anything, but the Samurai Shopper believes theres a lesson here: whatever lives, dies. Of course, no one deserves St. Valentines fate. Death by chocolate would be far nicer: some passion-fruit filled morsels, from Kee on Thompson Street, say? And wouldnt it be nice if we could preview the peonies, dahlias, zinnias et al. that people send for our funerals, assuming anyone loves us enough.

title: Buzz Tracker
description: The $100 Million Woman How much is Arianna Huffington getting from the deal with AOL? A Wall Street analyst, Laura Martin, estimates a cool $100 million. The Washington Post

title: Griffin Takes Dunk Show to Garden
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Mike DAntonis eyes lighted up when asked to describe Blake Griffins athleticism. In doing so, he used the word unbelievable, stretching it in a way to make Griffins athleticism sound even more, well, unbelievable.

title: TimesCast | February 8, 2011
description: Cairos protests spread to the Parliament; a TV interview inspires Egyptians; and Julian Assange is back in court.

title: Fed Casts A Wide Net In Defining Systemic Risk
description: Federal regulators on Tuesday took an expansive view of the types of companies that could be deemed essential enough to the financial system that they should be subjected to greater oversight.

title: A Bit of Old New Orleans in Williamsburg
description: Habitus of the famous Olde Absinthe House in New Orleans may execute a double-take when walking into Maison Premiere, the new Big Easy-flavored oyster bar in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. Perched on an island within the graceful, marble-topped, horseshoe-shaped bar is an uncanny replica of one of the ancient absinthe fountains found inside the French Quarter watering hole  jade-colored marble column, quartet of brass spigots, Napoleon statue and all.

title: In Good Company': Patti LuPone and Stephen Colbert Join Philharmonic Production
description: When the New York Philharmonic announced in December that it would present a new semi-staged production of Company in the spring starring Neil Patrick Harris, it raised the questions of (a) where the peripatetic Mr. Harris finds the time for so many extracurricular activities and (b) what stars would share the stage with him in that Stephen Sondheim musical.

title: Lymph Node Study Shakes Pillar of Breast Cancer Care
description: A new study finds that many women with early breast cancer do not need a painful procedure that has long been routine: removal of cancerous lymph nodes from the armpit.

title: Winklevoss Brothers, Redux. Again.
description: Facebook was born at Harvard Universityin early 2004, and since then, the company has gone through a lot of changes. But one thing has not changed: the bad feelings between Mark Zuckerberg, Facebooks founder, and his fellow Harvard students, Tyler and Cameron Winklevoss, memorably dramatized in the film The Social Network.

title: Egyptian Government Paid for Visit, French Official Says
description: PARIS  Prime Minister Franois Fillon admitted on Tuesday that he had accepted free lodging and transportation for his family from the Egyptian government during a Christmas vacation. His statement came as the foreign minister, Michle Alliot-Marie, again refused to resign for accepting two free flights from a Tunisian businessman close to Tunisias former first family.

title: Looking Back at Tootsie
description: Sydney Pollacks 1982 film, Tootsie, which stars Dustin Hoffman as an actor who poses as a woman to land a television role, made an impact on the Academy, receiving 10 Oscar nominations, including best picture. Jessica Lange, who was nominated in two categories that year, won the supporting actress Oscar for her performance in the film. This weeks Critics Picks video looks back on the comedy and sheds some light on why it struck such a chord. A. O. Scotts video can be found on our sister blog, ArtsBeat.

title: Elizabeth Bishop, Fighting The New Yorker Over Extra Commas and Steaming Cowflops
description: What I think about The New Yorker, the poet Elizabeth Bishop wrote in 1940 to her mentor, Marianne Moore, can only be expressed like this: *!@!!!@!*!!

title: Reviewing Hunan Kitchen of Grand Sichuan
Behold the Bobbing Fish Head
description: JERRY TANG, a son of the late Chinese chef Shorty Tang, was talking about the business of running Chinese restaurants in New York. This was last week, during Chinese New Year, over coffee in Brooklyn.

title: Disney Parks Help Drive Gain in Profit
description: LOS ANGELES  People are in the mood to spend on leisure time again, if Mickey Mouse is any guide.

title: A Building Forms a Bridge Between a Universitys Past and Future
description: Im sure that a few preservationists are already grumbling about the new interdisciplinary science building at Columbia University. It certainly doesnt fade politely into its brick surroundings. But theyd be wrong to think that it disrespects history.

title: Page Numbers for Kindle Books an Imperfect Solution
description: Since the dawn of the Kindle, theres been one quirky little feature that has baffled or thrilled the multitudes: page numbers.

title: War and Peace on Champollion Street
description: CAIRO  As I write this I can hear the sounds of bullets, banging and shouting on Champollion Street, close to Liberation (Tahrir) Square in central Cairo.

title: A Young Voice Talks to Schools Powerful
description: The Panel for Educational Policy meeting on Feb. 1 offered the spectator a little bit of everything, including humorous moments, like when a parent criticized the citys take on education reform by singing her own lyrics to the tune of Sam Cookes Wonderful World. (They know a lot about charter schools, and they think that merit pay is cool.)

title: Musical Survivor Hustles for a Second Chance
description: A couple of years ago Nicole Atkins, a promising songwriter from New Jersey with a bold siren call of a voice, found herself in splitsville with the two big relationships in her life: she was dropped by her record label after one album and broke up with her live-in boyfriend. Back at home with Mom, and rounding 30, she contemplated a question mark future but was still determined to create.

title: Russia Plays Down Expulsion of British Journalist
description: MOSCOW  The Russian Foreign Ministry on Tuesday sought to play down the expulsion of a British correspondent based in Moscow, saying that he had violated rules for journalists but that he could return if he agreed to abide by them.

title: Fox Builds Night On a Strong House
description: Fresh off a record-breaking Super Bowl Sunday audience of 111 million viewers, Fox delivered its best Monday night ratings of the season. According to Nielsens estimates, Foxs House attracted its highest ratings of the season, with 12.3 million viewers at 8, while the networks new crime drama The Chicago Code earned a solid start in its debut at 9, with 9.4 million. For the night over all, Fox ranked second to CBS and its comedy lineup. CBSs Two and a Half Men drew the nights largest audience, as usual, with 15.1 million viewers at 9, while Mike & Molly led at 9:30 with 12.7 million. CBSs How I Met Your Mother (10.1 million) and Rules of Engagement (9.5 million) fared well at 8 and 8:30, while CBSs Hawaii Five-0 topped the ratings at 10 (10.9 million), outperforming ABCs Castle (9.3 million) and NBCs Harrys Law (9.1 million). ABC finished a close third behind Fox, as an average of 9.7 million tuned in to The Bachelor from 8 to 10. NBC was fourth, with Chuck at 8 (5.4 million) and Chase at 9 (4.6 million).

title: Piano Trios From a Pair of Kindred Masters
description: What did Brahms see in Beethoven, whose marble bust stared down at him while he composed? Someone in many ways much like himself: fascinated by the past but restlessly innovative. Over the next month, the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center offers Manifest Legacy, five programs charting Beethovens influence on Brahms. (Beyond the thematic hook, it is no coincidence that the society is featuring two of the biggest draws for its subscribers.) On Sunday at Alice Tully Hall, the first concert juxtaposed piano trios by the composers.

title: Data Centers Offer Hope for St. Louis Office Market
description: ST. LOUIS  Several recent transactions are raising the possibility that this citys downtown, a depressed office market with an overall vacancy rate of over 22 percent, may become a regional hub for computer software and data-center companies.

description: A selection of WikiLeaks cables on Egypt.

description: If humor lies in the unexpected, then optimism is funny  its so uncalled for.

description: Photographs from Egypt, Germany and Cambodia.

description: With New Yorks alternate-side parking rules finally back in effect, one might think that the city would show some leniency toward the unmoved.

description: Charleston, S.C.

title: A Southern Chef Doesnt Stray Far
description: CHARLESTON, S.C.

title: Some of Charlestons Best: McCradys, Husk and Martha Lous Kitchen
description: A look at three restaurants in one of the great eating towns of the American South.

title: Beef With Farro, Egg, Kimchi Pure and Broccoli
description: Adapted from Sean Brock, McCradys, Charleston, S.C.

title: Actors and Their Roles for $300, HAL? HAL!
description: Does the idea of a machine thats as smart as you are inspire fascination? Or fear? From 2001 to The Terminator, science fiction has conditioned us to dread the metal tap on the shoulder. But Smartest Machine on Earth, a gee-whiz episode of the PBS series Nova on Wednesday night, puts a friendly face on artificial intelligence.

title: Tea Party Magazine Making Debut This Week
description: The first issue of the Tea Party Review, which describes itself as the first national magazine for, by, and about the Tea Party movement, will make its debut during the Conservative Political Action Conference scheduled to begin in Washington on Thursday.

title: George Clooney Answers Your Questions About Malaria
description: My former travel buddy, George Clooney, caught malaria in January on a trip to Sudan (see what happens when Im not around to look out for him?). This seemed an opportunity to shine a spotlight on malaria, one of the scourges of much of the developing world, and George agreed to respond to reader questions. Thanks to all for submitting your questionsand Im truly sorry that the answers were delayed. We were about to post these answers when Egypt intervened and I was too busy dodging pro-Mubarak thugs in Cairo to focus on this. So without further ado, George and I are finally responding.

title: Airgas Ruling Still to Come
description: A decision on the challenge to Airgass poison pill defense will come in the next few days, the judge in the case said on Tuesday afternoon.

title: Wells Fargos C.F.O. Abruptly Retires
description: Howard I. Atkins, Wells Fargos chief financial officer and senior executive vice president, abruptly retired on Tuesday, citing personal reasons.

title: Following the Tracks
description: Tracking a fisher hunting the forests of a highway cloverleaf interchange.

title: How to Be a Frugal Traveler
description: The most common question I get from readers is, How can I get your job? while the most common question I field from friends is, How can you stand your job?

title: Maybe Those Frog Teeth Werent Useless After All
description: Dollos Law, a theory proposed by the scientist Louis Dollo in the 1800s, states that when a particular trait is lost in a species, it never comes back.

title: Gender Balance and Book Reviewing: A New Survey Renews the Debate
description: Why do magazines and periodicals review many more books written by men than women, and choose many more men than women to review them?

title: London and Toronto Exchanges to Merge
description: 5:45 a.m. | Updated

title: Less Surgery for Breast Cancer?
description: New York Times reporter, Denise Grady, reports on a new study that finds lymph node surgery may not be necessary.

title: Spider-Man Early Reviews Set Off a Storm
description: In a rare departure from custom, most of the nations leading theater critics filed their long-anticipated reviews of Broadways Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark for publication on Tuesday, even though that musical had not yet opened. They drew a sharp protest from the production about the fairness of assessing a show while its creative team is still at work.

title: Senate Democrats Go Off to Brainstorm
description: The Senate went dark for a few days on Tuesday as Democrats headed for a policy and political brainstorming session in Charlottesville, Va.

title: A Bipartisan Push to Cut the S.B.A.?
description: Republicans on Capitol Hill have made no secret of their desire to cut deeply and broadly across discretionary spending by the federal government. But a letter sent in late January from leaders of the Senate Small Business Committee must have come as something of a surprise to its recipient, Karen Mills, the head of the Small Business Administration. The letter, drafted by Senators Mary Landrieu, Democrat of Louisiana, and Olympia Snowe, Republican of Maine, called on Ms. Mills to recommend programs within the S.B.A. that you believe could be eliminated or substantially reduced without undermining the S.B.A.s ability to serve the needs of small-business owners.

title: Canons New SLR Cribs Some Sweet Features
description: There may be a certain dj vu to the new Canon EOS Rebel T3i. Not just that it shares DNA with its popular predecessors, but its new features  a swivel-out screen and built-in photography guide  look a lot like those found on a pair of Nikon cameras.

title: Warner Musics Revenue Fell 14% in First Quarter
description: Warner Music Group lost $18 million in the last three months of 2010, or 12 cents a share, as new albums by artists like Josh Groban, Michael Bubl and Kid Rock fell short of expectations, the company announced on Tuesday,

title: Facebook Friends a New Campus
description: Facebook announced Tuesday that it is moving its more than 2,000 employees  and 600 million friends  to a new campus in Menlo Park, Calif.

title: Dining Calendar
description: Wellness in Schools

title: For That Special Valentine, Sugar Flowers and Licorice Hearts
description: Tiny pink and white heart-, ball- and flower-shaped sugars are among the specialties of a 270-year-old company in Nagoya, Japan, that makes them by hand from sugar grown in Japan. Consider them for a tea tray, for your Valentine, for baby showers or as hostess gifts. In addition to these miniatures, there are larger rounds and cubes decorated with flowers, and others in amber and white.

title: Millionaires Meatloaf
description: Adapted from David Burke

title: Doughnut Plant to Open at the Chelsea Hotel
description: Mark Isreal (above), who has been sending forth creative, multihued and myriad-flavored doughnuts from his Doughnut Plant shop on the Lower East Side for 16 years, will open his second New York store, in the Chelsea Hotel on Monday.

title: Passport in Hand, Honey Mussels Inch Their Way to New York
description: The honey mussel, which made its debut in British Columbia several years ago and has been inching its way eastward ever since, has started to show up in New York, mostly in restaurants. The name refers to its exceptionally sweet flavor and also to the touches of amber on the shell. Dale Williamson, who runs the B.C. Mussel Company, said it was developed through selective breeding over many generations.

title: Off the Menu
description: Opening

title: Hot or Not? A Model Turned Guru on What to Eat
description: YOGI CAMERON thought I was hot. Which, I figured, was a flattering thing to hear from a man whose cheekbones used to earn him thousands of dollars a day.

title: Sports Bar Menus Change, but Not Too Much
description: THE shiny 10-inch-wide tin of nachos enticing Carolyn Thalin at the mahogany bar of the Stadium Grill in Manhattan was not your normal gloop-coated pile of tortilla chips. Inspired by the chef David Burkes can o cake at his high-end restaurant Fishtail, it was constructed with layers of chips, cheese, black beans, more chips, cheese and beans, and  once baked, topped with salsa, sour cream, jalapeo, guacamole, scallions and more cheese  it was devised to be suffused with flavor right to the very bottom of the tin.

title: Mile End
description: EARLY evening at Mile End, and the air is heady with the scent of meat. A few breaths, and the head swims. It is unsubtle, reckless, potentially ruinous. A vegetarian, accidentally stumbling by, might wake up the next morning and not remember a thing.

title: On Our Radar: Rhino Poachers Killed in South Africa
description: Four suspected rhino poachers were shot and killed by rangers in two parks in South Africa over the weekend, the authorities said. Three of the poachers were shot in Kruger, one of the nations premier safari destinations, while another was killed in KwaZulu-Natal national park, another popular safari location. More than 333 rhinos were poached in the country in 2010, triple the amount from 2009. [Associated Press]

title: Recipes for Romance
description: Dishes that contain some of the ingredients that experts say may be aphrodisiacs.

title: What Not to Bring to Tahrir Square
description: CAIRO  It is rare that the most important piece of equipment in your bag is the bag itself, even more rare for that bag to be a black plastic trash sack slung over your shoulder as you walk past pro-government thugs on a bridge over the River Nile. The trash bags purpose, of course, is to conceal your large nylon camera bag, which is likely to get you grabbed off the street by the aforementioned thugs.

title: Anelka to M.L.S.? Not So Fast
description: Try a Google search on the words Anelka and LEquipe, and be ready to scroll down a list of articles posted last week when the French sports daily LEquipe passed along a snippet of information about the Chelsea striker Nicolas Anelka.

title: Jos Rafael Moneos New Building at Columbia
description: Columbia Universitys new interdisciplinary building is anticipated as a gateway to a campus planned for West Harlem.

title: When the Puppets Called a Sex Strike
description: For modern viewers, Aristophanes Lysistrata may be easier to admire than to like. The story, of course, compels: Lysistrata leads the Athenian and Spartan women in a sex strike to end the war between their cities. But all that ribaldry and priapism can be tough going. (Hell, perhaps, is other peoples bawdy comedy.)

title: Lohan Faces Felony Theft Charge
description: LOS ANGELES  The actress Lindsay Lohan can now add the prospect of a grand theft charge to her legal woes.

title: The Arts of Cuba, Set to Wow New York
description: The Cuban rumba and dance troupe Los Muequitos de Matanzas hasnt performed in New York in nearly a decade. Danza Contempornea de Cuba, which mixes Afro-Caribbean dance and classical European ballet and was founded in 1959, has never been to the United States. Neither have the socially conscious photographers Adonis Flores and Cirenaica Moreira.

title: Less Is More Is Mattering Most
description: TOM FORDS fashion show at his Madison Avenue store last fall was a tour de force of image control. Staged with little fanfare, documented by a single photographer and attended by no more than a hundred hand-picked guests, the show was a signal departure for Mr. Ford, who, during his tenure at Gucci in the 1990s, was a master of the super-size spectacle.

title: New York Fashion Week Is Here
description: Thursday marks the official start of Fashion Week, with more than 250 designers showing their fall 2011 collections at dozens of locations around the city, including Lincoln Center, now in its second season as home of Mercedes-Benz New York Fashion Week.

title: Ben Heppner Drops Out of the Mets Ring
description: 12:53 p.m. | Updated The Metropolitan Operas new Ring cycle has lost its Siegfried. Ben Heppner, one of the best Wagnerian tenors around, withdrew from performances of the last two installments of the cycle, Siegfried and Gtterdmmerung, next season.

title: For China, Shock Could Be a Good Policy
description: When China raises interest rates, speculators quake. The after-hours move on Tuesday had a nearly instantaneous effect on global markets, initially sending copper back below $10,000 a metric ton and crude oil below $100 a barrel. If only the Chinese economy were so responsive.

title: South Africa: Mines to Stay Private
description: The mineral resources minister, Susan Shabangu, said at a mining industry conference in Cape Town on Tuesday that nationalization of the mines was not an option for South Africa.
