The industry had been concerned about a nationalization campaign by the African National Congress Youth League, and government officials had worried the debate was scaring off investors.

title: Ivory Coast: Fire at the Treasury
description: A fire at the Treasury building in downtown Abidjan on Tuesday destroyed financial records on at least three floors, officials said. The fire comes at a time of increasing fiscal strain for the president, Laurent Gbagbo, who is facing international financial sanctions because he has refused to step down after losing an election in November. Last week, the United States ambassador, Phillip Carter, said Mr. Gbagbo had been extorting businesses to pay their taxes in advance.

title: Texas Governor Offers Optimism on Budget Shortfall
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  Gov. Rick Perry of Texas cannot be faulted for lack of optimism. Facing a two-year budget gap of at least $15 billion, Mr. Perry struck a defiant stance in his annual address to the Legislature, calling the state economy the envy of the nation and promising the budget would be balanced through spending cuts alone.

title: West Bank: Elections Set for July
description: The Palestinian Authority announced on Tuesday that it would hold delayed local elections on July 9. The vote was originally scheduled for last summer, but it was postponed by disagreements over candidates within the Fatah movement. In December, a Palestinian court ordered the authority to go ahead with the elections, and the quick decision is widely attributed to the democratic momentum created by the uprisings in Tunisia and Egypt. Elections were supposed to be held in both the West Bank and Gaza, but Hamas, which rules in Gaza, has said it would not allow them to take place. No election has been held in either territory since 2006.

title: Canada: Quebec Prosecutors Strike
description: Quebecs 450 prosecutors went on strike Tuesday, severely disrupting the provinces legal system. Only a skeleton staff remained in the courts to handle bail hearings and trials in which juries had been selected. The prosecutors union says its members in Quebec earn about 40 percent less than their counterparts in other parts of Canada.

title: Ailing Cyclist Is Said to Cite a Transfusion on Himself
description: The Italian professional cyclist Riccardo Ricc was admitted to a hospital in Modena, Italy, in critical condition Monday after performing a transfusion on himself with blood that may have turned bad, according to several Italian news reports.

title: Grgl Edges Mancuso; Ailing Vonn Is Seventh
description: Elisabeth Grgl of Austria, a veteran of the World Cup circuit whose rsum lacked a major title, won the womens super-G Tuesday during the opening day of the world ski championships. The American Julia Mancuso, meanwhile, again saved her best skiing for the biggest events, finishing five-hundredths of a second behind Grgl to win a silver medal.

title: Facing Title IX Pressure, Cal May Restore the Teams It Cut
description: When the University of California, Berkeley, announced it was eliminating five varsity teams last fall, the decision was sold as a necessary sacrifice by a university reeling from severe cuts in state aid.

title: First Lady Taking Health Work Global
description: WASHINGTON  Michelle Obama, who has planted a vegetable garden, swiveled a hula hoop, done yoga poses, lobbied Congress and crisscrossed the United States to promote the virtues of healthy eating and exercise, wants to take her campaign to reduce childhood obesity to a bigger audience: the global one.

title: A Divisive Indian Official Is Loved by Businesses
description: GANDHINAGAR, India  In a soaring, unfinished conference hall in western India, thousands of businessmen and diplomats from around the world gathered recently for an investment meeting. They were there to pay homage to a politician for accomplishing something once thought almost impossible in India: making it easy to do business.

title: A Cordless Phone That Plays Nice With Wireless Phones
description: You can go without a land line and just use your smartphone. People do it all the time.

title: Health Law Provision Raises Antitrust Concerns
description: WASHINGTON  The new health care law encourages collaboration by doctors and hospitals for cost savings, but a split has developed here as to just how far they can go without running afoul of antitrust laws.

title: Some Diamondback Investors Pull Out Their Money
description: Investors in Diamondback Partners, one of four hedge funds raided by federal authorities in November amid a widening investigation of suspected insider trading on Wall Street, have asked for more than $500 million back from the firm, according to the funds latest investor letter..The amount, totaling $534 million, represents around 9.4 percent of Diamondbacks total assets, according to the letter, defying expectations that the firm would experience enormous outflows after it was implicated in the investigation. Diamondback has told investors that the raid was focused on one of its portfolio managers and that the fund itself was not a target of the federal inquiry.

title: Mystery Over Detained American Angers Pakistan
description: LAHORE, Pakistan  The case of Raymond A. Davis, a former United States Special Forces soldier who is being held in connection with the deaths of two Pakistanis, has stirred a diplomatic furor, sending the precarious relationship between the United States and Pakistan to a new low, both sides say.

title: Whats Always Been So Great About Green Bay
description: In more than 50 years of writing about professional football, my favorite trip was always to Green Bay.

title: Former Judge Is on Trial in Cash for Kids Scheme
description: SCRANTON, Pa.  A former Pennsylvania judge went on trial in federal court on Tuesday, charged with racketeering, bribery and extortion in what prosecutors say was a $2.8 million scheme to send juvenile delinquents to privately run prisons.

title: Robbers Suicide Was Planned, Authorities Say
description: A gunman who held up a central New Jersey jewelry store this week and shot and killed the owner before turning the gun on himself had planned all along to commit suicide, the authorities said Tuesday.

title: Tribes Plan for Catskill Casino, Backed by Paterson, Faces Rejection in Washington
description: A proposed Native American casino on 333 acres in the Catskills is likely to be rejected by federal authorities next week, only three months after Gov. David A. Paterson approved the $560 million project in the waning days of his administration.

title: Are Democrats Better Off Than They Were 25 Years Ago?
description: The Democratic Leadership Council, a proud and sometimes belligerent group that sought to steer Democratic policy toward the right, will reportedly cease its operations.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,459 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

title: Is Eat Real Food Unthinkable?
description: In recent weeks weve seen a big, powerful government agency, a big, powerful person and a big, powerful corporation telling us what to eat. Even with all this big, powerful input, we know nothing that we didnt know last year. We do, however, have a new acronym; unfortunately, its not the one we need.

title: Mannequins Wear a Message for Iraqs Women
description: BAGHDAD  Vendors around the Kadhimiya mosque in northern Baghdad sell all manner of womens clothing, from drape-like black abayas to racy evening wear. But on a recent afternoon, Hameed Ibrahim ushered his family toward a different kind of fashion display.

title: Smoke and the City: Heat and Light
description: To the Editor:

title: Planned Parenthood
description: To the Editor:

title: A Cautionary Tale as Private Equity Exits Two Deals
description: Harry Campbell

title: Under Banner of Fiscal Restraint, Republicans Plan New Abortion Bills
description: WASHINGTON  All but invisible during the midterm elections, the abortion debate has returned to Congress.

title: Anonymous in Stockholm
description: To the Editor:

title: Riches Flow Into Nigeria, but Are Lost After Arrival
description: YENAGOA, Nigeria  The oil money has coursed through this swampy, sprawling settlement in the Niger Delta, a paper gusher that has yielded ambitious unfinished skeletons: a ghostly high-rise hotel; a luxury shopping center-in-waiting; a giant hospital that is mostly empty; housing and other projects, some completed but many not.

title: Life Is an Existential Cabaret, My Friend
description: Were you attacked by a Rottweiler? Has your heart been ripped open? Relax. Pain is a myth.

title: Title IX Test Doesnt Apply to High Schools, Foundation Says
description: A conservative legal foundation sent a letter to the federal Office for Civil Rights on Tuesday arguing that the test used to gauge schools compliance with the Title IX gender-equity law should not be applied to high schools.

title: Hedging Company Stock
description: To the Editor:

title: Too Much Testing
description: To the Editor:

title: Former Liberian President Boycotts War Crimes Trial
description: PARIS  Expectations that an important war crimes trial would conclude this week were upended on Tuesday when Charles G. Taylor, the former president of Liberia, and his defense lawyers boycotted the final stage of the proceedings, contending that the court was unfair and driven by politics.

title: Bad Weather? Try Telecommuting
description: To the Editor:

title: A Slimmer Sabathia?
description: C.C. Sabathia was the heaviest player in baseball last season, but he may be on the verge of ceding that distinction. A sleeker version of Sabathia, who carried a listed 309 pounds on his 6-foot 7-inch frame, is scheduled to report to Yankees spring training after an off-season recovering from arthroscopic knee surgery.

title: For Federal Programs, a Taste of Market Discipline
description: WASHINGTON

title: City Is Looking at Sewage Treatment as a Source of Energy
description: New York Citys sewage presents a daunting and costly challenge: it creates foul odors and often contaminates waterways.

title: Allies Press U.S. to Go Slow on Egypt
description: WASHINGTON  As the Obama administration gropes for the right response to the uprising in Egypt, it has not lacked for advice from democracy advocates, academics, pundits, even members of the previous administration. But few voices have been as urgent, insistent or persuasive as those of Egypts neighbors.

title: Malcolm X Trove Hidden During Feud
description: A feud over the estate of Betty Shabazz, the widow of Malcolm X, has created divisions among the couples six daughters and has resulted in something none of them had intended: keeping part of their fathers legacy from the public.

title: Capt. Ramsey and the Birth of the True Blues
Empty Bench Syndrome
description: San Antonio

title: Plans Near for Freddie and Fannie
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration and House Republicans are settling into a game of chicken over Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, with each side daring the other to advance a plan for replacing the two housing finance companies.

title: Winters Punch Crumbles Roofs in New England
description: MIDDLETOWN, Conn.  The woods may be lovely, dark and deep, but for small New England towns like this one, snow no longer brings the peaceful sweep of easy wind and downy flake.

title: Up With Egypt
description: Cairo

title: Report: C.I.A. Agents Tied to Abuse Escape Punishment
description: In the years since the Sept. 11 attacks, C.I.A. officers involved in detainee abuse and botched rendition cases have repeatedly escaped internal punishment by the spy agency, and some have even been promoted, according to The Associated Press.

title: Latest Hidden Video by Abortion Foes Shows Bronx Clinic of Planned Parenthood
description: An anti-abortion group released a videotape on Tuesday of a man whom the group said was posing as a pimp and a woman who was posing as a prostitute on a visit to a Planned Parenthood clinic in the Bronx. They appear to get information from a receptionist about how to obtain abortions and treatment for sexually transmitted diseases for under-age sex workers.

title: Mr. Suleimans Empty Promises
description: We are a long way from knowing how Egypt will turn out. The government is using all of its power  including a promised 15 percent raise for federal workers  to try to hang on. The opposition is courageously pushing back, and, on Tuesday, it drew thousands of supporters to Liberation Square.

title: Malpractice Bill Raises Issues About a Lawsuit
description: The lawmaker and retired obstetrician sponsoring a Congressional bill to sharply cut medical malpractice awards was involved in a $500,000 settlement of a malpractice lawsuit. The action was brought by a pregnant woman who charged that inappropriate care caused the loss of her fetus and other complications.

title: Anthony Trade Talk Exacts Price
description: Carmelo Anthonys virtual free-agent tour has been strikingly short on theatrics: no self-aggrandizing television show, no parade of executives genuflecting on his doorstep, no cozy backyard interviews with Larry King.

title: Asbury Parks Boardwalk Revival Moves Inland
description: ASBURY PARK, N.J.  For about a decade this Jersey Shore town, immortalized on a Bruce Springsteen album cover, has been on a slow upward trajectory  most visibly along its boardwalk, where dozens of new businesses have opened since 2007, when Madison Marquette of Washington stepped in as developer.

title: Obama Plans to Rescue States With Debt Burdens
description: President Obama is proposing to ride to the rescue of states that have borrowed billions of dollars from the federal government to continue paying unemployment benefits during the economic downturn. His plan would give the states a two-year breather before automatic tax increases would hit employers, and before states would have to start paying interest on the loans.

title: Banks Could Have Key Role in Mets Suit
description: Bernard L. Madoffs arrest on Dec. 11, 2008, shook the pillars of Fred Wilpons world.

title: Inside the Steinway Mansion
description: Michael Halberian, the owner of the Steinway mansion who recently passed away, once calculated that he had spent $4 million to $5 million on fixing up the house.

title: A Friendship of Values, Not Convenience
description: Jerusalem

title: New Gums With Vitamins, Herbs and Varied Claims
description: BEYOND tasting good and freshening breath, chewing gum today increasingly promises dental benefits, like reducing cavities, whitening and even strengthening teeth. Some sugarless brands, including Dentyne, Extra and Orbit, even carry seals of approval from the American Dental Association, for helping to reduce cavities.

title: Young Egyptians Spread Their Message
description: Young protesters have turned a downtown Cairo apartment into a secret hiding place, recharging after long days of protesting and uploading homemade documentaries about life in Tahrir Square to a shared Facebook page.

title: Toyotas Acceleration Problem
description: The finding that Toyotas problems with uncontrolled acceleration were not caused by glitches in its electronic controls is good news for Toyota and the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration. But it doesnt dispel concerns about the weaknesses of the nations vehicle safety regulation.

title: What Are Social-Impact Bonds?
description: My column this week describes a new strategy for improving the performance of government programs. In short, private investors  typically foundations  pay the costs of a new program in its early years, and the government later repays the investors, often with a bonus, as long as the program meets its goals. If it fails, taxpayers pay nothing.

title: Case Dismissed in High-Rise Fall Death
description: A real estate broker was cleared on Tuesday of misdemeanor charges that he served alcohol to the under-age daughter of a United States ambassador before she fell to her death from a Midtown high-rise building in August.

title: What Are They Waiting For?
description: We applauded back in December when the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives announced that it was seeking an emergency rule requiring gun dealers near the Mexican border to report multiple purchases of high-power semiautomatic rifles that use a detachable magazine. It looked as if the Obama administration was finally awakening to the urgent need to combat the illegal trafficking of AK-47s and other assault weapons across the border and into the hands of violent drug cartels. It turns out that we were wrong to applaud.

title: A Conservative Gathering Will Test G.O.P. Hopefuls
description: WASHINGTON  Prospective Republican presidential contenders face an important test this week as they begin navigating the complex crosscurrents between the fiscal and social demands of conservatives while trying to prove their electability against President Obama.

title: The Kilogram to Come
description: The official kilogram, a cylinder of platinum and iridium maintained by the International Bureau of Weights and Measures, is more than 130 years old. It is stored under three glass domes in a safe in a basement in Svres, France, and can be accessed only with three independent keys.

title: Forgive Me, Father, for I Have Linked
description: WASHINGTON

title: A Small Towns Leap of Faith
description: SALISBURY, Conn.  In the northwest corner of Connecticut, where rolling fields and clapboard homes are common and a covered bridge graces the local river, the town of Salisbury has, since 1926, stood out for a different reason.

title: Young Egyptians Spread Their Message
description: Young protesters have turned a downtown Cairo apartment into a secret hiding place, recharging after long days of protesting and uploading homemade documentaries about life in Tahrir Square to a shared Facebook page.

title: Emotions of a Reluctant Hero Galvanize Protesters
description: CAIRO  The television host narrated the pictures of the dead protesters on the screen, young men with sweet smiles whom she compared to roses in a garden.

title: City Weighs Extending a Tax-Break Deadline
description: Hundreds of vacant building sites are strewn about New York City, the scars of the housing crash and credit crunch.

title: Wednesday: Go A-Courting
description: WEDNESDAYS PUZZLE  Warning: forehead slapper ahead.

title: Teachers Colleges Upset by Plan to Grade Them
description: Grades are the currency of education  teachers give them to students, administrators grade teachers and states often assign grades to schools.

title: Patrician Clan That Clings to Its Foibles
description: There are not many fixed verities in the world of the theater, but one of the few is that when A.R. Gurney returns to home territory  writing about the manners and morals of the white Anglo-Saxon Protestant upper class  the results will most likely be gratifying. Mr. Gurneys Black Tie, which opened on Tuesday night at the 59E59 Theaters, is one of this prolific writers most enjoyable plays in years, a modest but effortlessly engaging comedy about the generational shifts in the subset of humanity Mr. Gurney has been writing about with warmth, humor and insight throughout his career.

title: Administration Pitches Big Rail Projects
description: The Obama administration, whose efforts to bring high-speed rail to the United States were sidetracked by Republican governors in a couple of states, pressed ahead with its vision of building a national rail network on Tuesday when it called for spending $53 billion on passenger trains and high-speed rail projects over the next six years.

title: Emotions Rev Stoudemire, but May Stall Him
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Amare Stoudemire responded like the perfect company man during the preseason when addressing the N.B.A.s mandate to curtail excessive complaining by issuing technical fouls.

title: South Carolina: Newborn Abandoned in Restroom
description: The police are reviewing surveillance video to find a woman who gave birth in a restroom stall in Greenville and then left the baby in the toilet. The infant boy is in stable condition, after being discovered Friday by custodians at an arena where a circus had taken place. Dozens of people have volunteered to adopt the 6-pound baby, the police said. The baby is believed to have spent at least an hour in the toilet before custodians heard him crying.

title: Letters: The Boy Who Kicked the Hornets Nest
description: Bill Kellers fascinating account of his behind-the-scenes maneuvering with WikiLeaks is one that I will now assign to my journalism students as required reading. But isnt it unfair for Keller to dump so heavily on Julian Assange, who made it possible for The New York Times to acquire and exploit these documents in the first place? Whatever Assanges personal failings, his indisputable bravery and skill have unearthed important secrets about the foreign policy that our government is waging in our name. Indeed, WikiLeakss ability to thwart censorshipand expose wrongdoing threatens corrupt regimes worldwide  and may prove to be a seminalevent in the history of investigative journalism.

title: Theft Case Offers Window on Bloombergs Bid for Re-election
description: It appeared to be a run-of-the-mill campaign e-mail: in October 2009, a Republican political consultant wrote to Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs two top aides, Kevin Sheekey and Patricia E. Harris, about Election Day operations.

title: Letters: Martin Peretz Is Not Sorry. About Anything.
description: Stephen Rodricks vivid picture of Marty Peretz underplays one ofthe mans essential characteristics: his extraordinary kindness to young people. As a Harvard sophomore in the late 60s, on scholarship in a place that could make you feel unnoticed, I took one of Peretzs extraordinary seminars on McCarthyism. The recently departed 50s seemed musty and irrelevant  until you sat down at one of Martys anything-goes lunchtime discussions, not only with people who had seen Communism as a genuine internal threat but also with others who had been blacklisted for years. Marty was available, enthusiastic, funny, biting, attentive to whatyou were doing and what you had to say. And yes, unorthodox in his opinions and relentless in probing yours. In other words, he was a thrilling teacher.

title: Capacity Crowd at Lambeau, Cheering a Title
description: GREEN BAY, Wis.  The mayor of Green Bay, Jim Schmitt, was walking briskly toward the entrance of Lambeau Field on Tuesday afternoon, his green-and-gold scarf whipping in the frosty breeze. His hands gripped a long, flat, rectangular object that was wrapped in paper.

title: Judge Rules for N.F.L. in Supplement Case
description: In an apparent victory for the N.F.L., a state appeals judge in Minnesota upheld a lower court ruling that allowed the league to suspend two players on the Vikings who were found to have taken StarCaps, a supplement that included a banned substance.

title: Patriot Act Extension Fails in House
description: The House defeated a bid Tuesday to extend for nine months the governments authority to conduct roving wiretaps of terror suspects, along with two other expiring provisions of the Patriot Act. The vote, 277 to 148, fell short of the two-thirds majority needed. Representative Lamar Smith said he hoped to bring up the legislation in two days under rules allowing passage by a simple majority.

title: Walrus on Endangered Species Waiting List
Ohio: Health Law Challenge on Fast Track
description: A second appellate court has set an expedited schedule for hearing a constitutional challenge to the new health care law. The United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit, in Cincinnati, announced Tuesday that it would hear oral arguments during a term that stretches from May 30 to June 10. The appeal stems from a decision upholding the law by a federal judge in Detroit. The United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit, in Richmond, Va., has already announced it will hear arguments in mid-May in the Obama administrations appeal of a Virginia judges decision to strike down a central provision of the law.

title: No Brodeur Is No Problem as Devils Surge Continues
description: NEWARK  Just before what may have been the Devils biggest game in a strange season, goaltender Martin Brodeur, wearing a dark suit, found a seat in a plush suite in the third deck at Prudential Center on Tuesday, far above the spot where he might have come in handy.

title: Stoudemires Tale of the Technicals
description: The Knicks Amare Stoudemire is three technical fouls away from drawing a one-game suspension. Heres how he has gotten on the wrong side of the officials:

title: Photo Replay: Feb. 8
description: A look at the day in sports from defeat on the slopes in Germany to a celebration in Green Bay.

title: A Quest for an Opposition Leader
description: Leaders of opposition groups in Egypt.

title: Corrections
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Phys Ed: Does Loneliness Reduce the Benefits of Exercise?
description: With Valentines Day around the corner, this seems the proper moment to ask whether being in a relationship changes how you exercise and, perhaps even more intriguing, whether relationships affect how exercise changes you.

title: Word of the Day | malleable
description: malleable \ma-le--bl, mal-y-bl, ma-l-bl\ adjective

title: Transforming the Sludge at Newtown Creek
description: The Newtown Creek Wastewater Treatment Plant in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, is being cast by the city as a potential source of renewable energy.

title: Maria Altmann, Pursuer of Familys Stolen Paintings, Dies at 94
description: Maria V. Altmann, a Jewish refugee who in her 80s waged a successful legal battle all the way to the United States Supreme Court to force the Austrian government to return paintings by Gustav Klimt that had been seized from her family by the Nazis, died on Monday at her home in Los Angeles. She was 94.

title: Persevering in Ciudad Jurez
description: Through the crime scenes and economic turmoil transforming demographics in Ciudad Jurez, families, with women at their helm, stick together.

title: A Mexican Citys Troubles Reshape Its Families
description: CIUDAD JUREZ, Mexico  Telma Pedro Crdoba could have left this blood- and bullet-marked city when she lost her husband to a drive-by shooting in 2009, or when an injury kept her mother from factory work, or when gunmen killed a neighbor in front of a friends 3-year-old son a few months ago.

title: Brian Jacques, Writer of Redwall Series, Dies at 71
description: He was a longshoreman and a long-haul trucker; a merchant mariner and a railway fireman; a boxer, a bus driver and a British bobby. But it wasnt until he became a milkman that Brian Jacques found his mtier.

title: Haiti Issues New Passport for Aristide
description: MEXICO CITY  Haitian officials issued a diplomatic passport on Tuesday for Jean-Bertrand Aristide, Haitis first democratically elected president and  even after years in exile  one of the countrys most popular and divisive figures.

title: Korea Talks Ended Abruptly Without Any Ease in Strains
description: SEOUL, South Korea  Military discussions between North and South Korea ended suddenly on Wednesday with no improvement in the countries badly strained relations and no agreement about whether to hold more substantive talks in the future.

title: Lottery Numbers
News Quiz | February 9, 2011
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: Banks Could Have Key Role in Mets Suit
description: Bernard L. Madoffs arrest on Dec. 11, 2008, shook the pillars of Fred Wilpons world, Peter Lattman and Richard Sandomir report in The New York Times.

title: Plans Near for Freddie and Fannie
description: The Obama administration and House Republicans are settling into a game of chicken over Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, with each side daring the other to advance a plan for replacing the two housing finance companies, Binyamin Appelbaum reports in The New York Times.

title: Fed Casts a Wide Net on Systemic Risk
description: Federal regulators on Tuesday took an expansive view of which companies could be deemed essential enough to the financial system that they should be subjected to greater oversight, Erich Dash reports in The New York Times.

title: 75 Years of History at the Apollo
description: WHERE is the Apollo Theater?WHERE is there currently an exhibition about the Apollo and its history called Aint Nothing Like the Real Thing?

title: Test Yourself | Math, Feb. 9, 2011
description: Test your math skills with todays question, created by Bobson Wong at Math for America from the article Imax Finds a Niche in Digital Future.

title: Sanofi, Advancing on Genzyme, Sees Sales Slip
description: Chris Viehbacher, the chief executive of Sanofi-Aventis, said on Wednesday that his company had made very good progress in talks with Genzyme, even as Sanofi released 2010 results showing that earnings had slipped.

title: Daily Lexeme: Muchwhat
description: Todays word, in association with the cherished Oxford English Dictionary, is

title: Dancing With Her Eyes Down Silent Streets
description: New York City is a puzzle of colors and fabrics for Patricia Ordonez. She loves the citys diversity, its people. She loves Columbus Circle on a sunny day, yellow cabs racing the clock on busy streets.

title: Former Liberian President Boycotts War Crimes Trial for Second Day
description: PARIS  Expectations that an important war crimes trial would conclude this week were dampened further on Wednesday when Charles G. Taylor, the former president of Liberia, and his defense lawyers boycotted the final stage of the proceedings for the second day in a row, contending that the court was unfair and driven by politics.

title: What Cause Would Get You Into the Streets?
description: Much of the coverage of the demonstrations in Egypt has focused on how ordinary citizens there have begun publicly expressing their desire for greater freedom. What idea or cause would spur you to join in a public demonstration? On what ideas would you like to express your views to a wider audience  even to the whole world?

title: New Roman Museum Highlights Baroque Church
description: Lovers of Baroque art and architecture can add one more stop to their Rome travel itinerary: the recently inaugurated Museo Missionario di Propaganda Fide. The new museum, which documents four centuries of the Catholic Churchs missionary work, has opened in part of the 17th-century Palazzo di Propaganda Fide, a masterpiece of Baroque architecture designed by the periods leading architects, Francesco Borromini and Gianlorenzo Bernini. Visitors to the museum will have access to halls and chapels in the Palazzo that are open to the public on a permanent basis for the first time.

title: Keep an Eye on Boltons Coyle
description: Last November, Bolton Wanderers Manager Owen Coyle was in Belfast, Northern Ireland, to watch his teams second-string take on a local soccer team, Cliftonville, in a friendly. Most coaches would have been content to sit back and keep warm on a frosty night.

title: Economics on the Go
description: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago.

title: The Early Word: Face-Offs
description: In Todays Times:

title: Update on Refrigerator Perry
description: William Perry, better known as the Refrigerator,  nearly died in 2009. He had Guillain-Barre Syndrome, and he was neglecting his health.

title: Labor Actions in Egypt Boost Protests
description: CAIRO  Labor strikes and worker protests that flared across Egypt on Wednesday affected post offices, textile factories and even the governments flagship newspaper, providing a burst of momentum to protesters demanding the resignation of President Hosni Mubarak, even as his government pushed back with greater force against the opponents demands.

title: Prosecutors Seek Immediate Trial for Berlusconi
description: ROME  A defiant Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi said Wednesday that he would continue to govern Italy even as Milan prosecutors filed a request to try him on criminal charges related to prostitution and abuse of office.

title: Now Showing, an iPad Thats Almost a TV
description: The iPad is not a TV, but it can almost be one. Altec Lansing has produced a stand that enhances sound and charges your pad as you view TV or listen to music.

title: A Good Deed by DeSean Jackson
description: The Fifth Down still thinks DeSean Jackson should wait until he crosses the goal line before celebrating. But he and two of his Eagles teammates deserve credit for appearing on The View to support a boy who spoke about an egregious case of school bullying. The look on the boys face upon seeing Jackson, his favorite player, is worth a click.

title: Testing the Entrepreneurial Life
description: In two recent posts (here and here) I wrote about the business incubator Succeed on Purpose, which coaches corporate layoff victims who want to start their own businesses. The incubator taps into the desire to be your own boss, common among both downsized workers and valued employees. But years of working for someone else can make the prospect of self-employment daunting.To gather insight, I spoke with Pamela Slim, author of Escape from Cubicle Nation (Portfolio, 2009) and a coach who helps would-be defectors through the transition. An edited version of our conversation follows.

title: Bookies and Big Plays at Super Bowl
description: Sunday was not a lucky day for Las Vegas bookmakers.

title: Political Groups Compete to Represent the Center
description: Has the political middle all but died in Washington?

title: Banks in Britain Reach Deal on Pay and Lending
description: The British government on Wednesday announced an agreement with the leading banks in the country to increase their lending to businesses to help the economic recovery, while reducing bonuses and increasing transparency in pay practices.

title: Monopolys New Tower of Power
description: Coming this fall are versions of classic board games like Monopoly that watch your every move and know whose turn is next.

title: Anglo Irish Lost 17.6 Billion Euros in 2010
description: Anglo Irish Bank, the lender whose huge bets on development have come to epitomize the reckless excess of Irelands real estate bubble, said late on Tuesday that it lost 17.6 billion euros in 2010.

title: Harry & Davids Future in Doubt
description: Harry & David Holdings could use one of its own get-well gift baskets.

title: Taiwan General Charged in Spy Case
description: BEIJING  The government of Taiwan has arrested a general on accusations of spying for China in what could be the most prominent espionage case in Taiwan in decades.

title: European Central Bank Candidate Said to Be Wavering
description: FRANKFURT Axel Weber, president of the Bundesbank, may remove himself as a candidate to become president of the European Central Bank, potentially opening up the race for what is arguably the Continents most important public post, according to German media and wire reports on Wednesday.

title: A.I.G. to Take $4.1 Billion Charge
description: The American International Group, the bailed out insurer, announced on Wednesday that it would take a $4.1 billion charge in the fourth quarter to strengthen reserves in its property and casualty subsidiary.

title: E.P.A. Chief Faces House Grilling
description: As Republican lawmakers move to prevent the Environmental Protection Agency from regulating emissions of greenhouse gases, Lisa P. Jackson, the E.P.A. administrator, has been called to testify before the House Energy and Commerce Committees Subcommittee on Energy and Power. The subcommittee is chaired by Edward Whitfield, Republican of Kentucky, a sponsor of a bill that would restrict the agencys powers. The hearing opens at 9:30 a.m.; a live Webcast is planned here.

title: Tracking Urban Fishers Through Forest and Culvert
description: Roland Kays, curator of mammals at the New York State Museum, writes from Albany, where he is comparing the behavior of fishers in urban and wild settings.

title: Sean Payton Is Testing Loyalty of New Orleans
description: It seems straightforward enough. Saints Coach Sean Payton is moving his wife and two children out of the New Orleans area and into the Dallas suburb of their dreams. Payton reaffirmed his commitment to his job. He wont be commuting regularly; in fact, he said hed have more time to spend in the office.

title: Why Expectations Matter
description: Paul Segal has a good post over at the FT about inflation expectations, and in particular about what the UK should do in the face of a recent rise in headline inflation:

title: Morning Buzz | A Peek Into Bloombergs Campaign
description: A little less windy today and still some sunshine, but no break from the cold, with highs of 28.

title: Trailer: 'Circo'
description: The trailer premiere of "Circo," a documentary about a traveling family circus that struggles to keep performing despite mounting debt.

title: One Charger to Rule Them All?
description: The drawer that holds your tangle of chargers could get less cluttered. Or maybe it already has. Or maybe it wont. Stay with me, here.

title: Gimme an A! Gimme an E! Gimme an R!
description: The American Economic Review is celebrating its 100th anniversary with a special issue commemorating the top 20 papers of the past century. You can read the survey article here (pdf); free links to the papers are included in the survey.

title: Fatal Bombs in Iraq Seemed Aimed at Militia
description: BAGHDAD  A series of car bombs shook the northern Iraqi city of Kirkuk on Wednesday, killing 10 people and wounding at least 90 in a large-scale assault that appeared aimed at a local Kurdish militia.

title: Marc Kudisch to Star in A Ministers Wife at Lincoln Center
description: Marc Kudisch and Bobby Steggert will star in Lincoln Center Theaters production of A Ministers Wife, a new musical based on an early 1898 version of George Bernard Shaws Candida.

title: London and Toronto Exchanges Announce Merger
description: OTTAWA  The London Stock Exchange and the TMX Group, the parent company of the Toronto Stock Exchange, announced an all-share merger on Wednesday.

title: Banks Could Face $60 Billion Tab on Bad Mortgage Loans
description: The banking industry may have to spend more than $60 billion to buy back troubled mortgages, according to a report released on Tuesday by Standard & Poors.

title: Feed Your Head | Mister H at the Mondrian SoHo
description: Humphrey Bogart gets off work as a private eye and needs a nightcap; where would he go? asks Armin Amiri, explaining the fantasy behind his latest venture. The answer: A bar run by Mr. Hung. This fictitious proprietor lends his name to Mister H, a Chinatown-inspired bote Amiri will helm at the Mondrian SoHo when it opens this month.

title: Packers Poised for a Special Run
description: Bob McGinn of The Milwaukee Journal-Sentinel is one of the more respected football beat writers in the country. Before the Super Bowl, Peter King of Sports Illustrated noted that McGinn, not prone to overstatement, was very bullish on the Packers future. King published an excerpt from McGinn, who is normally behind a pay wall at The Journal-Sentinel:

title: Morning Take-Out
description: MERGERS & ACQUISITIONS

title: Casing Verizon iPhone Cases
description: Those counting down the moments until they get their Verizon iPhone 4 may be savoring the anticipation by picking out accessories  much the way people buy baby outfits in advance of a birth.

title: Britain Reaches Deal With Banks on Lending and Pay
description: The British Treasury said on Wednesday that it had struck a long-sought deal with the countrys largest banks on two burning issues: lending and compensation.

title: Johnson & Johnson Deal for Crucell Moves Forward
description: Shareholders of the Dutch biotechnology company Crucell voted on Tuesday to change the companys bylaws and the makeup of its supervisory board, two moves that will pave the way for Johnson & Johnsons 1.75 billion euro ($2.4 billion) takeover.

title: Freddie Official Says He Has No Duty to Shareholders
description: As the Obama administration works to determine the fate of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, a director of one of the mortgage finance giants says he has no fiduciary duty to the companys shareholders.

title: Paulson Donation to Finance Research on the Euro Zone
description: The hedge fund manager John A. Paulson has donated more than 2.5 million to the London School of Economics and Political Science to foster research on Europe in the post-crisis financial world.

title: A Bond to Save Lives
description: Health care is an obvious place that could benefit from social-impact bonds, even though the White House is not including health care on its list of areas for pilot projects. (To review, the bonds let governments wait to see that a program is working before spending any taxpayer money on it.)

title: Violence, Hope and an Oscar Nomination
description: Of the five nominees for this years Oscar for best foreign-language film, four are based on original scripts. The exception is Canadas Incendies, which its director, Denis Villeneuve, adapted from the French-language play of the same name, written by the Lebanese-born Canadian playwright Wajdi Mouawad and known in English as Scorched.

title: In Tokyo, a Crackdown on Sexual Images of Minors
description: TOKYO  In a manga comic book that is well known here, My Wife Is an Elementary School Student, a 24-year-old teacher marries a 12-year-old girl as part of a top-secret social experiment.

title: Updates on Day 16 of Egypt Protests
description: The Lede continues to follow the protest movement in Egypt, now in its third week. For a summary of new developments, read todays main news article from our colleagues in Cairo. Updates below mix alerts on breaking news with reports from bloggers and journalists in Egypt. A stream of Twitter updates on the protests is in this blogs right column.

title: Public-Worker Unions Skip Albany Ad Blitz for New Tactics
description: ALBANY  The airwaves are virtually silent. The fiery criticism of years past has given way to conciliatory press releases. And the halls of the Capitol ring not with angry protests but with the quiet hum of lawmakers and lobbyists making their daily rounds.

title: Teaming Tenants and Landlords for Energy Savings
description: Last week I wrote about how small businesses are going green by taking steps that reduce waste and energy use. While personal convictions may drive many business owners to reduce their environmental impact, most still make decisions based on a model that requires a quick return on such an investment.

title: A Role for Gaming in Learning
description: My post over the weekend on growing recognition of a role for gaming in learning generated a great mix of responses that are worth highlighting and building on here.

title: Jargon-aut
description: Those fond of using bureaucratic terms.  (Also Jargonaut.)

title: Developer Chosen to Start Long Island City Housing Complex
description: The Bloomberg administration announced Wednesday morning that it had selected a development team led by Related Companies to build the first phase of a development on the Queens waterfront, which, when completed, will be the largest middle-income complex built since the 1970s.

title: A Closer Look at Boses New (and Only) TV
description: I spent several hours Sunday with Leonardo DiCaprio, Aaron Rodgers, Ben Roethlisberger and Dr. Amar Bose.

title: Ristretto | Fashion Week Coffee
description: Skip the coffee at the tents: theres a better buzz to be had during Fashion Week.

title: Beyond the Acronyms
description: The comments so far on my Opinionator piece today are lively and engaging enough to keep you entertained for a bit, but if youre interested in seeing some of the material I read before writing the column, here it is, with comments of my own.

title: St. Joe Explores Sale
description: 10:37 a.m. | Updated

title: Dot Earth: Games as Learning
description: Andrew C. Revkin explored the idea of a role for games in learning on Dot Earth in a post over the weekend. The piece focused on Will Wright, the mind behind Spore and The Sims, and solicited questions for Mr. Wright as well as others views on the notion that virtual experiences can help fit infinite human aspirations on a finite planet.

title: In Congress, Bernanke Faces Questions About Inflation
description: WASHINGTON  The Federal Reserve chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, parried tough questions Wednesday about rising gasoline prices in the United States and the soaring cost of food and grains in the emerging world as he defended the central banks $600 billion program to shore up the recovery.

title: Defense Agency to Scrutinize Industry Deals Carefully
description: The Defense Department will be keeping close tabs on industry deal-making.

title: Its Alive: U.S. Movie Theaters to Show Danny Boyles Frankenstein
description: When the Bagger last spoke with Danny Boyle on Oscar nominations day, he was treating himself to a cab ride home after rehearsals for his stage production of Frankenstein. The play, now running at the National Theater in London, stars Benedict Cumberbatch and Jonny Lee Miller, who are alternating in the roles of Victor Frankenstein and the Creature; the first 10 weeks are sold out. But American audiences will get a chance to see it anyway; according to a new announcement, it will be broadcast in American movie houses on March 17. Add your own Its ALIVE! joke here.

title: Hyundai Veloster Rally Car and 2012 Genesis Unveiled in Chicago
description: During Wednesdays news media previews at the Chicago auto show, Hyundai introduced a purpose-built rally version of its coming Veloster coupe, as well as a refreshed and refined Genesis luxury sedan.

title: Wednesday Reading: How to Be a Frugal Traveler
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: Official Is Killed In Southern Sudan
description: KAMPALA, Uganda  A leading official of the government of the secessionist region of southern Sudan was shot dead by his brother-in-law on Wednesday morning, according to officials who said the motive was personal and unrelated to the regions recent vote for independence.

title: Can the Catholic Church Atone for Its Sins in Ireland?
description: Sex-abuse scandals involving priests have shaken a nation to its core, but will the anger translate into a separation of church and state?

title: The Irish Affliction
description: Andrew Madden is one of a relatively new breed of Irish celebrities who would just as soon be less well known. He was among the first people in Ireland to go public about being sexually abused by Catholic clergy  one of those who set off the intense bout of soul-searching that has racked the country lately. When I met Madden last fall in Dublin, the early rumbles of the collapse of Irelands economy were shaking the country, and throughout much of a pub lunch he talked about the failures of the government and the banks. It was only later, once we were driving around his old neighborhood, past the pebbledash house where he grew up and where his parents still live, that he began to talk about his childhood. As we sat in his car in front of Christ the King Church, where he spent much of his youth as an altar boy and a choir member, he outlined the four years of torment he suffered in the late 1970s at the hands of the Rev. Ivan Payne, one of the infamous serial sex offenders among the Irish Catholic clergy whose stories have transfixed the country over the past year and a half.

title: Commitment and Accounting in Title IX
description: 1:49 p.m. Feb. 11 | Updated: Cal Restores Three Varsity Sports

title: How to Find Cruise Line Deals
description: WITH cruise bookings on the upswing, bargains are tougher to find this year. But its still possible to nab a deal, if you act quickly.

title: Numberplay: Are Virgos Bad Drivers? Solution
description: Allstate research suggests Virgos are rather accident-prone: They had 700 percent more accidents than Scorpios during 2010, for example. Yet Allstate does not consider astrology in setting rates. Why?

title: 15,000 New Stars Take Form in Empire State Building
description: It took Alfred E. Smith, by then a former governor and a failed presidential candidate, 410 days to get the Empire State Building built with help from an army of construction workers.

title: Minority Students and A.P. Program, a Mixed Report Card
description: More minority high school students are achieving success on Advanced Placement exams that can get them college credit, but they are still underrepresented in the nations A.P. classrooms, according to a report just released by the College Board, which administers the program.

title: A New Musical From Bernhard and Bond
description: The downtown music scene will get an extra dose of glam this spring at a reading of a new musical written by the actress and comedian Sandra Bernhard, the downtown drag artist Justin Bond, and the Scissor Sisters lead singer Jake Shears.

title: Houston Opera Still Embraces Bold Ventures
description: HOUSTON  Whatever happened to the Houston Grand Opera? That this renowned companys international media profile has slipped since the departure of David Gockley, its general director from 1972 to 2005, is obvious. But precisely why is something of a mystery, given the level of performance seen in the companys accounts of its winter repertory, Jake Heggies Dead Man Walking and Donizettis Lucia di Lammermoor.

title: Banksy + Cats = Movie Magic
description: As Oscar campaigns go, the street artist Banksys is unusual  never showing up to schmooze (as far as we know), insulting other contenders, making a documentary that seems liked a hoax and leaving fellow filmmakers to debate whether that matters. A new video parodying his film, Exit Through the Gift Shop, takes his uncampaigning even further. The Exit Through the Pet Shop trailer imagines what Banksys movie would look like if it were populated by Keyboard Cats and I Can Has Cheezburger.

title: Ratings Down for Rangers, Islanders, Devils
description: The television ratings for the local broadcasts of the 30 N.H.L. teams are in, and the news is not good for the three New York metropolitan area clubs. Audiences for the Devils and Islanders are down, and somewhat surprisingly, so are the Rangers.

title: Battier Plans for Life After Basketball
description: Shane Battier is only 32, but hes already thinking about his life after basketball.

title: A Grammy Awards Tribute for Aretha Franklin
description: With Mick Jagger already signed on to perform at the Grammy Awards in a tribute to the singer Solomon Burke, who called himself King Solomon and who died in October, its only fitting that Aretha Franklin, the still-reigning Queen of Soul, should also be honored at the awards ceremony on Sunday in Los Angeles. Christina Aguilera, Jennifer Hudson, Martina McBride, Yolanda Adams and Florence Welch will participate in the homage to the 68-year-old Ms. Franklin. Grammy sponsors are describing it as a valentine and a get-well card to Ms. Franklin, who has won 18 Grammys herself. She was hospitalized in Detroit late last year, underwent surgery for an undisclosed ailment and canceled several months worth of scheduled performances.

title: What Were Reading
description: An aggregation of links by the reporters and editors of Diners Journal.

title: Steven Tyler Escapes From Idolatry
description: FAME isnt all gold, honey and massage oils; its also the successful navigation of a steady stream of unlikely and uncomfortable situations.

title: Condom Rule Sought for Sex-Film Sets
description: LOS ANGELES  The clinic that for the last decade had monitored the health of those working in the multibillion-dollar pornography industry abruptly shut its doors in December.

title: Johnny Reb Economics
description: Mike Konczal has a post about Ron Pauls first hearing on monetary policy, in which he points out that the lead witness is a big Lincoln-hater and defender of the Southern secession.

title: Chris Cannon Names New Chefs at Convivio and Alto
description: Chris Cannon has hired new executive chefs for Convivio and Alto restaurants, the two restaurants that he and his partners control after the recent split with Michael Whites Altamarea Group.

title: Quote Unquote | Poor Baby
description: Rachel Zoe tells Elle about her latest fashion accessory. Sorry Tavi, you will no longer be the youngest in the front row.

title: Senator Webb Will Not Run for Re-election
description: 2:10 p.m. | Updated Senator Jim Webb, Democrat of Virginia, has decided not to run for re-election, avoiding a blockbuster rematch with the man he beat in 2006, George Allen, and giving Senate Republicans another opportunity to help them reclaim the majority.

title: The N.F.L.s Public Relations Problem
description: Being Darth Vader, apparently, is in.

title: Steven Tyler: Idol Anchor or Liability?
description: Many wondered whether American Idol could survive the departure of Simon Cowell, and the addition of Steven Tyler to the judges panel struck some as proof that the ratings powerhouse was entering its twilight.

title: Do Women Shun Science?
description: The absence of women  particularly mothers  in the sciences is making news again.

title: The Rising Cost of Identity Theft for Consumers
description: While the estimated number of identity fraud victims fell steeply last year from the year prior, consumers out-of-pocket identity fraud costs rose, according to a new report from Javelin Strategy & Research.

title: From Tahrir Square to Parliament
description: Demonstrations demanding the ouster of President Hosni Mubarak spread from Tahrir Square to the streets around Egypt's Parliament building.

title: Emanuel Has Commanding Lead in Chicago Mayors Race
description: CHICAGO  With less than two weeks to the mayoral election, a poll released on Wednesday shows Rahm Emanuel, the former White House chief of staff, with a commanding lead, drawing support from 54 percent of those surveyed.

title: Breast Cancer and Lymph Nodes: Q. and A.
description: An article in Wednesdays Times describes how a routine procedure for the treatment of early breast cancer  the surgical removal of cancerous lymph nodes from the armpit  has been found unnecessary for many patients. The finding turns 100 years of standard medical practice on its head.

title: Tout Sweet | The New French Chocolate
description: Toss a pralin truffe in any direction in Paris, and youll hit a chocolatier, whether an award-winning master or a modest neighborhood peddler. But lately the city seems particularly cuckoo for cocoa, as a new breed of chocolate artisans has opened up salons, boutiques and bars all over the city.

title: Ackmans Long and Short on Investing
description: William A. Ackman of Pershing Square Capital Management and Prof. Michael Porter of Harvard Business School talk to CNBC about the tensions that exist in capital markets. Is there a natural conflict between short- and long-term investing? The two discuss whether financial markets are in fact serving the needs of the economy, as opposed to just creating investment vehicles.

title: Protests Spill Beyond Tahrir Square
description: Egypts antigovernment activists called on supporters Wednesday to expand their demonstrations in defiance of the vice presidents warning that protests calling for President Hosni Mubaraks ouster would not be tolerated for much longer

title: JPMorgan Asks to Move Madoff Trustees Lawsuit
description: No one thought that JPMorgan Chase was going to take the claims of the trustee representing the victims of Bernard L. Madoffs Ponzi scheme lying down, and it hasnt disappointed.

title: Tim Wu, Creator of the Term Net Neutrality, Joins the Federal Government
description: The Federal Trade Commission on Tuesday named Tim Wu, author of the book The Master Switch, a senior adviser for consumer protection and competition issues that affect the Internet and mobile phones.

title: Changes to Medicare
description: Even as the federal courts kick around the new health care law, certain improvements for Medicare recipients are nonetheless under way.

title: Zuckerberg Gets Animated
description: Now that the major Oscar races appear decided, the Bagger is feeling the liberty to take some coverage detours (because seriously, how many Kings Speech dinners can we go to, anyway?). So: the Taiwanese company Next Media Animation has produced another of its infamous cartoon news reports, this time about Mark Zuckerberg (the protagonist of The Social Network) and his alleged stalker. It somehow joins the outcry over Facebooks privacy settings with John Cusacks boombox moment from Say Anything.

title: Yielding to Complaints, Groupon Revises Commercials
description: Groupon is changing the commercials that so many viewers complained about on Super Bowl Sunday.

title: Saving Lives From Anal Cancer
description: Paulette Crowthers three children were grown and she was plotting a midlife career change when a routine colonoscopy picked up cancer, but not of the colon  of the anus.

title: Sothebys Plans Chinese Contemporary Art Sale
description: In Asia, Chinese contemporary art is still a hot collecting area. So it was with great fanfare that in Hong Kong on Wednesday morning, Sothebys announced the forthcoming sale of 106 works dating from the 1980s and early 1990s. The works belong to Guy Ullens and his wife, Myriam, Belgium collectors who opened the Ullens Center for Contemporary Art in a former munitions complex in Beijings Dashanzi warehouse arts district in 2007.

title: The Insider | Sydney Albertini
description: A spring-summer 2011 daydream: There is a collision of vehicles carrying bolts of material. Pradas stripes are unfurling in the street near a billowing pouf printed with lemons, grapefruits and oranges (Stella McCartney!). A band of wayward women have wrapped themselves in the cloth, like victorious marathoners. This imagined scene surfaces when presented with the paintings of Sydney Albertini. The East Hampton, N.Y.-based artist is perhaps best known for her whimsical pottery and quilting but is now ready to present her true love: painting. On the occasion of Sydney Albertini: ephemere, a show of 20 large charcoal and oil works opening tonight at New Yorks French Institute Alliance Francaise, she shares her (kaleidoscopic) world.

title: Paterson Remains the Virtual Governor
description: ALBANY  Here at the State Capitol, former Gov. David A. Paterson has most definitely left the building. But his digital presence apparently has not.

title: Sanofi Says It May Extend Genzyme Offer
description: Sanofi-Aventis may seek another extension of its tender offer to acquire Genzyme, Christopher A. Viehbacher, chief executive of Sanofi-Aventis, a French drug maker, said in an interview on Wednesday.

title: Its Collaboratin Time: Spider-Man to Join the Fantastic Four
description: Spider-Man didnt get the kindest reception on Broadway, but in his Marvel Comics adventures hes about to receive a much warmer welcome. The web slinger will become a member of the Fantastic Four  or, more precisely, join the surviving teammates of that superhero group to form a new team  whose exploits will be chronicled in a new series called FF, Marvel Entertainment said on Wednesday.

title: S.E.C. Seeks to Reduce Reliance on Credit Ratings
description: The nations largest credit rating agencies are ingrained in Wall Streets DNA.

title: Aide Says Giffords Is Speaking More and More
description: PHOENIX  Representative Gabrielle Giffords has begun speaking, an aide said Wednesday, telling hospital personnel at one point that she wanted some toast  an encouraging sign a month after being shot in the head at a political event outside Tucson.

title: Where to Roost During Fashion Week? The Line Starts Here, Here and Here
description: GIVEN how, twice a year like clockwork, fashions feathered throng swoops down on New York to roost in tent rafters and crow about next seasons plumage, its tempting to think of them as some species of migratory bird.

title: Dodge Treats Family Movers, Muscle Models to SRT8 and R/T Makeovers
description: Although Chrysler Group introduced new models for its three brands at both the Los Angeles and Detroit auto shows, it reserved a bit of marketing heat for the Chicago show, which opened to the news media on Wednesday.

title: A 23-Year-Old Steve Jobs on TV
description: When Steven P. Jobs, founder of Apple, walks out on stage in front of thousands of people for a new product announcement, he looks more comfortable than an old man taking a nap in aLa-Z-Boy. But the charismatic C.E.O. wasnt always this calm in front of large audiences.

title: Obama Plans to Step Up Talks on Free Trade Pacts
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration on Wednesday pledged to immediately intensify talks with Colombia and Panama on two free trade agreements with the aim of submitting the accords to Congress by the end of the year.

title: Lets Talk About Social Security
description: Gail Collins: David, weve been agreeing too much lately. So lets talk about Social Security.

title: H.P. Introduces a Tablet and New Phones
description: 12:43 p.m. | Updated  More details on software interface and developers at the end.11:14 a.m. | Updated  More details on availability of tablet added.

title: Vocabulinks
description: An occasional assemblage of notable vocabulary and linguistic debate from around the Web.

title: Trailer: 'Traces'
description: Excerpts from the North American tour of "Traces" by the company 7 Fingers. (Video courtesy of Traces USA)

title: Sharing an Ayurvedic Lunch With a Yogi
description: If there was an unexpectedly maddening aspect of my lunch with Yogi Cameron, aside from the inevitable plunge in confidence that comes whenever you sit across a table from someone who looks like that, it was the oddness of eating without a glass of cold water at hand.

title: Nicki Minaj Tops Billboard Chart
description: After hovering close to the No. 1 spot on Billboard magazines music charts since November, Nicki Minaj has finally gained the top slot. Pink Friday, the debut CD by this 26-year-old singer, sold 45,000 copies last week  up 18 percent from the previous week and enough to nudge cumulative sales of the CD past one million.

title: How Will Webbs Retirement Affect Virginia Democrats?
description: After a couple of cycles in which an above-average number of incumbents have lost their seats in Congress, its easy to forget that being an incumbent is normally an extremely powerful advantage. Political science models have generally found that the incumbency advantage amounts to 6 to 10 percentage points for a senator, meaning that an incumbent Democrat would be expected to get 56 to 60 percent of the vote in a state where a nonincumbent Democrat would get about 50 percent.

title: All Eyes on Four Not-So-New Designers
description: ITS fitting that the movie that fashion people are mad for is Black Swan. Its about a bulimic girl obsessed with perfection, poise and control who is really  really!  dying for her breakout moment at Lincoln Center so the world can see how talented she is. Of course, the film is set next door at a fictional ballet company, and the girl is trying to break out of the corps, not the fashion pack. But every year, as the fashion flock gets larger, its harder to spot the cob or pen  boy swan or girl swan, of course  that could rise above the rest, on track to a spotlight in Vogue, a C.F.D.A. nomination and an order from Bergdorf Goodman.

title: Quote Unquote | Runway-ing on Empty
description: The modeling agent Carole White reveals to The Daily Mail just how much times have changed in the industry. No wonder Naomi used to throw phones at people  she was hungry.

title: Dangerous Precedent
description: The Times reports today:

title: Bloombergs Battle for More Say in the Pension Process
description: New York Citys labor force was in revolt in the late 1960s and early 70s. Teachers, sanitation workers and policemen had all been on strike. City officials and unions were at loggerheads.

title: Olympic Sailing Looks to Go Extreme
description: The worlds top Olympic sailors were in South Florida reading wind and waves aboard two-person dinghies, keelboats and windsurfers at the recent Rolex Miami Olympic Classes Regatta. The sailing lineup has not really altered much in the last 20 years.

title: Artifacts | Francesco Vezzolis Temple of Obsession
description: For his first solo show in a New York gallery, Francesco Vezzoli chose an apt title: Sacrilegio. Its irreverence starts with his redesign of that gallery, the expansive Gagosian space on West 21st Street. It is now a stripped-down, dimly lit Gothic church that is painted an Armani gray and is dedicated to a real Madonna, the source of Vezzolis diva complex  his own mother.

title: Powells Books Announces Layoffs
description: The rise of e-books and declining store sales have led to layoffs at Powells Books, the landmark bookstore in Portland, Ore. The stores management said on Tuesday it would lay off 31 employees as part of its response to the unprecedented, rapidly changing nature of the book industry. Ryan Takas, the union representative for the employees who were laid off, said that the 31 employees make up more than 7 percent of the stores 400-person unionized work force. Mr. Takas said that Powells had reduced its work force by about 40 employees in the last year through attrition, but still felt that layoffs were necessary because of a decline in sales of new books and a rise in health care costs. It was the first round of layoffs since the stores workers formed a union in 2000.

title: So Close, He Brought the Barbecue
description: Jonathan Taggart, 26, a photojournalist based in Vancouver, British Columbia, focuses largely on the indigenous communities of Canada. He is a 2008 graduate of Ryerson University in Toronto and teaches photography to aboriginal youths. His work has been published in The Globe and Mail and in Toronto Life Magazine. He is a founder of Boreal Collective, a documentary photo group. Kerri MacDonalds conversation with Mr. Taggart for Turning Point has been edited and condensed.

title: Small-Business Credit Markets, Assessed by a Loan Broker
description: Up until summer 2009, Ami Kassar was a nine-to-fiver, working for Advanta, one of the largest providers of credit cards to small business. But then the company went bust, another victim of the credit crisis, and the newly unemployed Mr. Kassar decided to strike out on his own.

title: Is the Small-Business Credit Crisis Over?
description: In an interview weve just published, Ami Kassar, a business loan broker, assesses the current state of the small-business credit markets. Among other things, Mr. Kassar, who started his company, MultiFunding, last year, has the following to say:

title: The 10 Things to Talk About This Weekend
description: 1. A bill in the Arizona Legislature would allow the state to ignore any federal laws it deems unconstitutional. While everyone else is stuck with the prix fixe, Arizona hits the legislative buffet.

title: For New Yorkers, a Leak Alert
description: Almost buried among the 100 initiatives put forth in a plan released on Wednesday by New York Citys Department of Environmental Protection are a couple of helpful measures for water customers, including a free notification program that would alert consumers to leaks in their faucets, toilets and internal pipes.

title: H.P. Introduces a Tablet and New Phones
description: 11:14 a.m. | Updated  More details on availability of tablet added.

title: Tracing Roots of Belief Across a Quarter-Century
description: In 1985 Ronald K. Brown formed a dance company and named it Evidence. That word, strong and unequivocal, traces a line to truth with the same kind of spiritual elasticity that Mr. Brown has long epitomized in his choreography. For him evidence, or grounds for belief, is rooted in dancing.

title: Sputnik Redux: Creating Science Fair Projects
description: Overview  | What is the Sputnik moment to which President Obama referred in his State of the Union address, and how do educators place this comment in the context of science education? What questions and ideas do students have that can generate innovative science projects? In this lesson, students consider the current state of science fairs, explore the role of creativity and ingenuity in science, and develop science fair project proposals.

title: Super Bowl Ads Assessed, From A to Z
description: For Madison Avenue, the mad rush to create and produce Super Bowl commercials is finished for another year. Now comes the scrutinizing of the results of myriad polls and surveys, which evaluate what consumers made of all the commercials that ran during the game.

title: City Audit of the Water Club Reveals Holes in the Books
description: A boatload of cash  whether dinghy-sized or freighter-sized, no one can say  has washed away at a destination restaurant on the East River, potentially shortchanging the city when it needs every penny, according to an audit that the city comptrollers office issued on Wednesday.

title: Brown Cancels California Lease-Back Deals
description: SACRAMENTO  As states across the country struggle to deal with massive budget deficits, a number  including California  have resorted to attempting to sell state office buildings, pouring the proceeds into the general funds, and lease back the space. Arnold Schwarzenegger, the former governor of California, was one of those, moving to sell and lease back 11 state office buildings, providing $1.2 billion in revenues to a state budget that sorely needs it.

title: New York Fashion Week: Browsing Authentic Local Fashion, Beyond the Tents
description: Stores to explore for those in town for New York Fashion Week: Assembly New York, End of Century, Gargyle and Life: Curated.

title: Take a Number, Mr. Walrus
description: The Pacific walrus is imperiled by climate change, which is melting its icy Arctic home, and merits protection under the Endangered Species Act, the federal Fish and Wildlife Service said this week. Yetprotections must wait until threats to higher-priority species are addressed, the agency said.

title: Sites That Answer Your Money Questions
description: A recent New York Times story, The Answers Are Out There, and New Q. and A. Sites Dig Them Up, described how entrepreneurs were betting that there was an opportunity for a new generation of sites where users asked and answered questions. It also discussed how venture capitalists were showing their support for new question-and-answer models.

title: Rainbow of Fireworks Strews Blackened Bouquets in China
description: BEIJING  Eardrum-piercing explosions. Choking plumes of sulfurous smoke. Showers of sparks that cascade onto homes and heads.

title: In Nokias Overhaul, an Opportunity for Deals
description: Nokias chief executive, Stephen Elop, issued a call to arms last week, warning his troops that the company was standing on a burning platform.

title: In Anguilla, Beachfront With Caribbean Style
description: A home on Anguilla is on the market for $1.75 million. It is divided into two apartments and sits on one acre of land with 200 feet of waterfront.

title: Broadway Backwards
description: Photos from the gay-themed benefit for Broadway Cares/Equity Fights AIDS.

title: From the Heart | Vivienne Westwood Goes to the Palladium
description: Dame Vivienne Westwoods collections have gone through more transformations than Jocelyn Wildenstein. From bohemian to punk and even paganism, Westwoods pieces channel her ideas through fashion. Her latest offering, the Get a Life jewelry collection (produced in conjunction with the Palladium Alliance International), is intended to represent hope, renewal and preservation. Launching during London Fashion Week with a kickoff soiree at the Wallace Collection (Londons answer to the Frick), the pieces are made entirely from  you guessed it  palladium, a natural material. All of the pieces are inscribed with messages from Westwoods eco-conscious spring/summer 2010 collection, which was called Planet Gaia. What better way to wear your heart near your sleeve? The necklace will be available to order this spring at Vivienne Westwood boutiques in Los Angeles, or go to viviennewestwood.co.uk.

title: Pictures of the Day: Iraq and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Iraq, Egypt, Gaza City and Greece.

title: TimesCast | February 9, 2011
description: Labor strikes in Egypt; a vigil in Tahrir Square; and a rare tour of Pixar's studios.

title: House Hunting in ... Anguilla
description: A WATERFRONT HOME DIVIDED INTO TWO APARTMENTS

title: House Republicans Take E.P.A. Chief to Task
description: WASHINGTON  Congressional Republicans on Wednesday opened a formal assault on the authority of the Environmental Protection Agency to regulate greenhouse gases, raising doubts about the legal, scientific and economic basis of rules proposed by the agency.

title: A Fresh Face Behind a Comeback
description: GUILLAUME HENRY, the young designer behind the resurrection of the French label Carven, likes things in the middle.

title: Another Hirschfeld of Flowing Lines. But Bloodlines? Thats a Puzzle.
description: When Colin Quinn Long Story Short opened at the Helen Hayes Theater in November, producers presented Mr. Quinn and the shows director, Jerry Seinfeld, with a Hirschfeld caricature of the two.

title: Ukraine Raises the Pressure on Opposition Leaders
description: KIEV, Ukraine  A year after taking office with a vow to pursue close ties to Russia, the Ukrainian president is overseeing a broad crackdown on the pro-Western opposition that mirrors the kind of pressure tactics used by his allies in the Kremlin.

title: Boehner Says Republicans and President Found Common Ground Over Lunch
description: The speaker of the House, John A. Boehner, said Wednesday that he and his fellow Republican leaders found common ground with President Obama during a lunch at the White House, but failed to reach any specific agreements on how to cut spending to reduce the federal deficit.

title: Pictures of the Day: Iraq and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Iraq, Egypt, Gaza City and Greece.

title: Republicans Fault Democrats on Vote
description: When House Republicans suffered an embarrassing defeat Tuesday in trying to pass an extension of the Patriot Act, they pointed a finger not at defiant members of their own party, but at Democrats who didnt play along as expected.

title: Fans Sue Cowboys and N.F.L. for Seating Fiasco
description: The seating fiasco Sunday at the Super Bowl, in which 1,200 temporary seats at Cowboys Stadium were deemed unusable shortly before the game, has produced an expected response from some angry fans: a class action lawsuit with accusations of fraud and breach of contract.

title: Homes for $1 Million
description: An 18th-century former Quaker meetinghouse in New Jersey, a southwestern-style house in New Mexico and an architects bungalow in Los Angeles.

title: Philadelphia Has the Best Lineup and It Isnt Enough
description: The Philadelphia 76ers dont have a go-to scorer, a promising core, a positive salary cap outlook, or the hope of championship contention in the near future. What they do have, however  as was pointed out by John Schuhmann of NBA.com - is the single most effective lineup in the league.

title: Just One Look | Bottega Veneta Pre-Fall Collection
description: The pre-fall collections, being shown in New York over the next several weeks, arrive in stores in May to fill the gap between bikinis and furs.Tomas Maier may live in a city where it is summer pretty much year-round, but he knows that a light hand with fabric and a strong one with color can help ease the transition into fall. His pre-fall collection for Bottega Veneta was inspired largely by Red Desert, Michelangelo Antonionis first color film. Still, it was this dress  in graphic black and white  that caught our eye.

title: Shopping for Candelabra With Bentley Meeker
description: The Manhattan lighting designer selected candleholders to set the mood for Valentines Day.

title: Medical Treatment, Out of Reach
description: Late last year, Biosensors International, a medical device company, shut down its operation in Southern California, which had once housed 90 people, including the companys top executives and researchers.

title: Buzz Tracker
description: A Weak WikiLeak? Remember all the noise about the Bank of America data dump being prepared by Wikileaks? Reuters reports that Julian Assange has told people that the material is dated and that he personally was unable to make much sense of it. Reuters

title: What You Get for ... $1 Million
description: LOS ANGELES

title: Afghan Rights Groups Shift Focus to Taliban
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  International and local human rights groups working in Afghanistan have shifted their focus toward condemning abuses committed by the Taliban insurgents, rather than those attributed to the American military and its allies.

title: Madison Avenue Turns to Executive Moves and Deals
description: The week or so before a Super Bowl, the flow of industry news in advertising usually slows. That makes sense, given that Super Bowl Sunday is the biggest day of the year for Madison Avenue as well as for football fans.

title: For Rihannas Perfume, a Video Meant for Rewatching
description: WHEN new perfumes are introduced, fragrance companies typically mount introductory advertising campaigns that run widely in womens fashion magazines, often including sample strips.

title: Regulating Student Health Plans
description: Federal regulators proposed a new rule on Wednesday that would make sure the health plans offered to college students by their respective schools would have to comply with regulations in place under the health care law, according to a release from the Department of Health and Human Services.

title: Take Me to the Revolution
description: This is the writers third post from the Tahrir Square protests.

title: Sharing a Profession and Much More
description: GARANCE DOR, a French street-fashion blogger and illustrator, experienced the sort of shutter-quick rise that only seemed possible a few years ago, when fashion blogs were in their infancy.

title: Conversation for Four, With Homeric Accents
description: There are moments, in the tumble of a typical improvisation, when the saxophonist Chris Potter seems to be embarked on a heros journey. With his strong, focused tone and top-to-bottom proficiency on the horn, he brings a robust physical presence to his playing and an onward-driving sense of purpose. His deployment of notes, parceled into staccato bursts or gracefully arcing phrases, suggests a split-second calculation of risk and reward. He works with an intuitive logic, venturing far from a theme and only gradually returning there, all the while responding to the changing conditions set by his band.
