title: The Way to Her Heart | A Valentines Day Cheat Sheet
description: Guys, a word to the wise on Valentines Day: jewelry. Its hard to go wrong. But that doesnt mean any old diamond bauble will do. Ask yourself, Who do you love? And shop accordingly. Silver or gold, rubies or pearls, trendy or vintage  weve put some thought into your Valentines Day gifts so you dont have to.

title: Pinpointing Pedestrian Deaths in New York
description: In addition to being home to the Great White Way, the Canyon of Heroes, and many other important and important-sounding things, Broadway has the dubious distinction of being the citys deadliest street for pedestrians, according to a report released on Wednesday by the Tri-State Transportation Campaign.

title: Psyched to Buy, in Groups
description: You might think that this column is about Groupon.com, the white-hot Web site whose coupons save you 50 to 90 percent at local businesses. But its not. Its about psychology.

title: New Light, Long After His Sun Set
description: WHEN the curtain fell on Broadway on the last night of The Night of the Iguana in September 1962, it would have been impossible for anyone to foresee what the next two decades would bring for its author, Tennessee Williams. Though possessed of an imagination as gothic as anyones, Williams probably could never have fathomed how grim the last acts of his career would become.

title: Photos From the Broadway Backwards Benefit
description: Broadway Backwards, an annual benefit for Broadway Cares/Equity Fights AIDS and the Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual & Transgender Community Center, re-interprets the songs of musical theater by featuring women singing songs originally written for men and men singing songs written for women. This years show, held Monday night at the Longacre Theater, raised $281,243.

title: Cisco Results Top Forecasts, But Growth Is Sluggish
description: SAN FRANCISCO  John T. Chambers, Cisco Systems chief executive, did little Wednesday to lift the dark cloud hanging over his company by reporting sluggish growth in its fiscal second quarter and making a disappointing forecast.

title: Getting His Close-Up for Hollywoods Top Lobbying Job: Senator Dodd
description: As the search for a new chairman of the Motion Picture Association of America grinds on, a longtime candidate has entered into negotiations for the job.

title: Closed Captioning on Netflix Movies
description: Q. On a Roku XD player, is there a way to get closed captions on those Netflix movies that offer them? I am hard of hearing and closed captions are crucial to me.

title: The Many Faces of Black Swan, Deconstructed
description: Few ballet films excite popular fascination, and almost none to the degree of Black Swan. This month, its up for five Oscars. So why has it so intrigued academy voters and the public alike? Surely because it exerts its lurid appeal on multiple levels.

title: Iranian Claims Chess Record
description: To the intense rivalry between Israel and Iran add another facet: the game of chess.

title: NCIS Lifts CBS
description: Despite attracting 26.8 million viewers following the Super Bowl on Sunday, Foxs hit musical series Glee drew only slightly better ratings than usual on Tuesday. According to Nielsens estimates 11.5 million tuned in to Glee at 8 p.m., up modestly from the 11.1 million who watched the shows last Tuesday episode in December. Although Glee led the night among 18-to-49-year-old viewers, the shows audience paled in comparison with the 20.3 million who watched CBSs NCIS in the same time slot. CBS ranked No. 1 over all, winning both the 9 and 10 p.m. time slots with NCIS: Los Angeles (17.1 million) and The Good Wife (11.8 million). After Glee Fox earned lower ratings for its comedies Raising Hope (6.8 million) and Traffic Light, which garnered a disappointing 4.6 million viewers in its premiere at 9:30. NBC was third, and ABC placed fourth.

title: Checking Out a Lot of Beers, Without the Hangover
description: My attention was elsewhere when the craft beer craze started, so I was caught off guard when my friends started talking about ales with a kind of snootiness one normally finds at a Grand Cru wine tasting.

title: App Cant Replace Confession, Vatican Says
description: A new application being sold on iTunes, Confession: a Roman Catholic App, cannot be used as a substitute for confession with a priest, the Vatican said Wednesday. The application was developed by American entrepreneurs with the help of two priests and the blessing of a bishop. It features a questionnaire of sins, and is promoted as a tool both to revive interest in confession and to help Catholics prepare for the sacrament. But some media reports cast the app as a virtual priest for Catholics who do not have time for church, prompting the Rev. Federico Lombardi, the Vatican spokesman, to respond, One cannot speak in any way of confession by iPhone.

title: Franois Nars: Behind the Makeup, a Low-Profile Artist
description: TODAY, the first stand-alone store of Nars, the makeup brand known for its sleek black packaging and luscious color range, will open on Bleecker Street in Manhattan. Like its creator, the Frenchman Franois Nars, the store is a study in contrasts. Close to Marc Jacobss cluster of boutiques and the Magnolia Bakery, it has Old World charm, with moldings and a marble fireplace from Chesneys. In line with todays eco-conscious imperatives, its distressed black-stained wood floors are reclaimed from the Ohio River Valley.

title: The Sex Life of Parents
description: As Valentines Day approaches, thoughts turn to romance. If you have young children, Lisa Tucker McElroy writes in a guest post today, those thoughts are not what they once were.

title: A Playwright Whose Time Seems to Be Now
description: Writing a play about the death penalty should put you squarely in the middle of a moral debate. Yet Nathan Louis Jackson, whose When I Come to Die traces the emotional turmoil of an inmate whose execution goes mysteriously awry, insists that his play is not political and that it takes no sides.

title: Conservative Leader Steps Down on Eve of Conference
description: David Keene, the longtime leader of the group that sponsors the annual Conservative Political Action Conference, officially stepped down on Wednesday, a day before the 2011 conference begins.

title: E.P.A. and Carbon Dioxide: The Prequel
description: As a committee of the Republican-controlled House settled in to interrogate the Environmental Protection Agencys administrator, Lisa P. Jackson, about her agencys efforts to regulate greenhouse gases like carbon dioxide, a senior House Democrat released three-year old documents showing that the Bush administrations E.P.A. sought to follow exactly the same course.

title: Inflation, in One Picture
description: On Capitol Hill, members of Congress are grilling Ben Bernanke, the Federal Reserve chairman, about his attempts to lift economic growth by reducing long-term interest rates  the Feds so-called Q.E.2 program, or quantitative easing. Some members of Congress think Mr. Bernanke is fighting the wrong battle. They want him to take steps to stamp out inflation, which they believe is dangerously high or soon will be.

title: Social Apps for Losing Weight
description: These apps and Web sites can help you lose weight the social way.

title: A $60,000 Payday for Parkinsons Disease
description: Zeke Jabbour of Boca Raton, Fla., an eight-time national champion, organizes an annual charity bridge event for the Parkinson Foundation. This years, held last month at St. Andrews Country Club in Boca Raton, raised nearly $60,000.

title: A 16th-Century Palazzo in Palermo
description: In Italy, two art collectors established a home and a gallery in a building that once belonged to a prince.

title: Apps to Share Your Pride at the Gym
description: About four years ago, when I started working at home, I plugged into a laptop to write about Silicon Valley. I made thousands of new friends on Facebook and Twitter, and, thanks to the proximity of my refrigerator, put an additional 35 pounds on an already rotund body.

title: A Toyota Timeline
description: On Tuesday, the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration ruled that no software glitches or electronic malfunctions would have caused Toyota vehicles to accelerate against their drivers wishes, instead faulting previously identified mechanical problems. As Matthew L. Wald wrote in The New York Times,

title: 15% of High School Seniors Passed an A.P. Test Last Year
description: 12:07 p.m. Thursday | Update

title: As Investors Become Savvy, an Intermediary Loses Favor
description: After the financial crisis, the Alberta Teachers Retirement Fund decided to reassess its strategy. At the time, the Canadian pension had roughly $150 million, or 3 percent of its assets, devoted to private equity, with the bulk in so-called funds of funds that invest across several different portfolios.

title: Animation Advocacy, Pixar Style
description: EMERYVILLE, Calif.  Sheriff Woody was doing some unnatural things. Of course, hes a cartoon character, an invention of the wizzes at Pixar, but on the screen in front of me, Woody  voiced by Tom Hanks in the Toy Story franchise  was spinning his neck uncontrollably, torquing it to Exorcist angles and grinning while he did it. I moved the mouse and watched him convulse. Oh, man, animation is fun.

title: Scotland Yard Expands its Hacking Inquiry
description: After reopening its investigation into telephone hacking by the News of the World, Scotland Yard said Wednesday that it was going to contact more people who may have had their voicemail messages illegally intercepted by reporters at the London newspaper.

title: Irans Chief Prosecutor Criticizes Planned Rally Backing Revolts
description: TEHRAN  Irans chief prosecutor on Wednesday called an opposition request to hold a rally in support of the uprisings in Tunisia and Egypt divisive and political. His comments suggested that officials would not grant permission for the rally, planned for Monday.

title: New York Congressman Resigns Over Shirtless Photo
description: Update, Feb. 10 Read the final version of this article that ran in Thursdays newspaper.

title: When Hats Had Heart
description: Remember when hats were hattier?

description: fl = new Object();fl.id = '613';fl.swf = 'http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/flash/tmag/templates/TmagMultipleChoiceQuiz/TmagQuiz.swf';fl.base = 'http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/flash/tmag/templates/TmagMultipleChoiceQuiz/';fl.width = '592';fl.height = '750';fl.as = '2';fl.domain = 'www';fl.caching = 'true';fl.bgColor = '#FFFFFF';fl.vars = [{name:'dataURL',value:'http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/flash/tmag/templates/TmagMultipleChoiceQuiz/data/2011_quiz_modeliq.xml'},{name:'',value:''},{name:'',value:''},{name:'',value:''},{name:'',value:''},{name:'',value:''},{name:'',value:''},{name:'',value:''},{name:'',value:''}];writeNYTFlash(fl,2);

title: Downtown Skyscraper for the Digital Age
description: Many New Yorkers have been following the construction of the new residential tower at 8 Spruce Street, just south of City Hall, with a mix of awe and trepidation.

title: New York Congressman Resigns Over Shirtless Photo
description: Representative Chris Lee of New York, caught in the midst of a scandal involving a shirtless photo he reportedly sent to a woman on the Internet, has stepped down, according to a senior Congressional official. Read more on City Room

title: Success of Spina Bifida Study Opens Fetal Surgery Door
description: For years, surgeons have been trying to find ways of operating on babies in the womb, reasoning that medical abnormalities might be more easily fixed while a fetus is still developing. But with tremendous risks to babies and mothers, and a mixed record of success, fetal surgery is mostly used when babies are likely to die otherwise.

title: An Oscar Front-Runner Amps Up the Campaigning
description: The Oscar front-runner, The Kings Speech, hasnt stopped with the campaigning, holding dinners and picking up even more awards on both coasts, as Melena Ryzik writes on the Carpetbagger blog.  (The post, which had been here, has moved to Carpetbagger, where it belongs in this awards season.)

title: Race Directors Raise Concern Over Proposed Police Fee
description: In an effort to generate revenue to cope with the citys budget deficit, the New York Police Department wants to charge the organizers of the New York City Marathon and dozens of other races the full cost of controlling traffic and other services.

title: An Oscar Front-Runner Amps Up the Campaigning
description: As promised, back to our regularly scheduled programming. Where were we? Oh yeah: at this point, who isnt in the tank for The Kings Speech?

title: A Seamless Addition to the Skyline
description: Frank Gehrys new residential tower at 8 Spruce Street, clad in a rumpled stainless-steel skin that helps it blend into the skyline, stands at the northern edge of the financial district.

title: Piet Oudolfs Cold Weather Landscapes
description: A look at how the Dutch designer uses form and texture in his winter gardens.

title: Q&A: Piet Oudolf on Designing a Winter Garden
description: GARDENS in winter are typically deemed dormant, but Piet Oudolf believes that they shouldnt be. Mr. Oudolf, who is Dutch, is the leading exemplar of the New Perennials landscape movement, which holds that plants should be chosen for shape and texture more than for color.

title: In a 16th-Century Palazzo, Home for Art
description: Palermo, Italy

title: Sales at Aero, Alessi, Modani and OLighting
description: At the Aero sale, through March 5, lamps, furniture, rugs and baskets are at least 25 percent off, and some vintage furnishings and holiday items are as much as 75 percent off (a Chippendale occasional chair in bone leather, originally $2,997, is $950; the Dara bar stool by Thomas OBrien for Hickory Chair, regularly $1,386, is $550); 419 Broome Street (Lafayette Street), (212) 966-1500, aerostudios.com.

title: A Feng Shui Cube Brings Intimacy to a Loft
description: THERE was a time when Liu Ming, a teacher of Chinese traditional medicine and feng shui in Oakland, Calif., did a few hundred prostrations a day as part of his practice of Tibetan Buddhism  full prostrations, that is, in which you begin standing and end with your head on the floor. That wouldnt work these days, as Mr. Lius meditation area is on top of an eight-foot cube in his loft. Were he to stand up, Mr. Liu would hit his head on the ceiling.

title: Oxo Introduces a Childrens Collection
description: There were 27 babies born to employees of our company in the five years prior to launching this line, said Alex Lee, president of Oxo, explaining the companys foray into childrens goods with the Oxo Tot line.

title: Diane Von Furstenberg Moves Into Housewares
description: Everything happens in bed, Diane Von Furstenberg was saying last week while explaining the latest spinoff from her wrap-dress empire, DVF Home.

title: Backgammon Tables, Without the Clubby Feel
description: To us, a backgammon table is like a fireplace  youve got to have one, Louise Brooks, a partner in Oomph, said of the design companys latest creation. We felt there was a huge need for a backgammon table that didnt look like it belonged in a mens club. Something more fun than mahogany with ball-and-claw feet.

title: Candelabra
description: BENTLEY MEEKER, a Manhattan designer, has been in business for 20 years, creating lighting for events as diverse as weddings (he did Chelsea Clintons) and concerts (Kanye West, Aerosmith and Elton John are all clients).

title: A New Act for a Midcentury Sofa
description: Like a great midcentury screen siren, the Valentine sofa refuses to be upstaged by anyone or anything in the room.

title: Speck by Speck, Dust Piles Up
description: THE world has a dust problem. There is more of it than there used to be. Apparently, the amount of airborne dust doubled in the 20th century, according to a recent scientific paper in the journal Atmospheric Chemistry and Physics.

title: Annie Modica on Turning Crafts Into Collectibles
description: If you are an artsy-craftsy sort whose friends are always saying you should take those fabulous whatevers you make and start a business, you might want to meet Annie Modica, of Mill Valley, Calif. Ms. Modica started out making decoupage trays in her dining room about 15 years ago, and last year she billed about $750,000. Her decoupage home accessories  every one of which bears her fat and happy signature  are carried by Saks Fifth Avenue and Gracious Home, and they are not inexpensive. Her trays can run as much as $400.

title: Poems of Pain, the Raw and the Remembered
description: Cancer and racism, immigration and terrorism: each topic is a predictable way station on the circuit of the 24-hour news cycle. In the following books, though, poets wrestle with these staples of newspaper and TV headlines (and much more) and alchemize them from eye-glazing abstractions into well-wrought literary gold.

title: Cuomo Says Hell Push for Vote to Legalize Same-Sex Marriage
description: ALBANY  Fourteen months after the State Senate soundly rejected legislation that would have legalized same-sex marriage, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo is preparing to pursue another vote on the matter in the next few months.

title: A Rapper Loves America, but Dont Expect Another British Invasion
description: In the back of S.O.B.s on Tuesday night, the members of N-Dubz, a sort of British version of the Black Eyed Peas, were being filmed by their own videographer as they did, well, not very much. They werent there to perform, so they stood and looked at the stage. Sometimes they whispered to one another. Sometimes they mouthed along to the songs playing over the loudspeaker. Throughout, the camera, unlike the people in the room, stayed focused on them.

title: Tech Talk Podcast: Kitchen Technology
description: This weeks Bits: Tech Talk show gets into the kitchen. Bettina Edelstein chats with Jeff Potter, author of Cooking for Geeks: Real Science, Great Hacks and Good Food. Mr. Potter, who has a background in software engineering, says one of his goals is to explain how cooking works. His book also includes recipes and interviews with food scientists, food bloggers and technologists. If youve ever wondered how to make ice cream in 30 seconds using liquid nitrogen, hes your man.

title: Yuzu Chiffon Cake
description: For the cake:

title: Japanese Coffee Products
description: A. The woodneck has a cloth filter that makes a coffee with exceptional clarity. The device is also called a nel drip  nel is short for flannel.

title: A Circus That Lets Its Freak Flag Fly
description: Los Angeles

title: Coffees Slow Dance
description: A few years ago, I mothballed the fantasy of getting a professional-grade espresso machine and setting it up in the kitchen next to the meat slicer. In part, I gave up because of cost. It turns out a starter machine runs about $600, and if I wanted to own the same technology and firepower as whats on the counter of the coffee bar around the corner, the price jumped to $6,500. Thermal-stable dual-boiler systems, assembled by hand in Italy, dont come cheaply.

title: Another Season, Another Show
description: AT the close of Joseph Altuzarras fashion show in Chelsea last September, spectators sprang to their feet, jostling toward the far end of the runway to congratulate the designer, or maybe just to bask in his glow. Within moments, industry power brokers like Linda Fargo, the sleekly imposing fashion director of Bergdorf Goodman; Simon Doonan of Barneys New York, and a visibly captivated Hamish Bowles of Vogue were rushing backstage to throw their arms around Mr. Altuzarra and to pose for the scrum of paparazzi bellowing their names.

title: Stepping Carefully in Commodities Markets
description: IS there a way to invest in inflation-tracking vehicles that also benefit from growth in emerging markets?

title: Yankees Add Luis Ayala to Bullpen
description: The Yankees agreed to a minor league deal with the right-handed reliever Luis Ayala, who has not pitched in the majors since 2009.

title: Innovation Far Removed From the Lab
description: Daniel Reetz loves trash bins. A big one in Fargo, N.D., was where he found most of the materials he used to build a scanner that was fast enough to scan a 400-page book in about 20 minutes without cracking the binding. The two Canon PowerShot A590 cameras and two lights that he lashed together with a few pieces of acrylic and wood cost him about $300 in all, considerably less than the $10,000 commercial book scanners that were on the market.

title: In This Market, Safe May Be the New Risky
description: EVEN though the bear market officially ended nearly two years ago, investors have shown a stubborn aversion to risk since then. The usually reliable steps taken to protect portfolios may prove ineffective, however, some investment professionals warn. In this market backdrop, safe may be the new risky.

title: The Hands-On Investor
description: JEANNIE KRIEGER is not your average widowed grandmother.

title: Certainty on Tax, but Just for Two Years
description: WHEN Robert Hassler of Larchmont, N.Y., went to see a lawyer last fall about devising an estate plan, he received two pieces of unexpected advice: wait until Congress enacted changes in tax law, which it did in December, and remain flexible in your planning, so that whatever you do will withstand further changes from Congress.

title: What Level of Risk Can You Tolerate?
description: WERE you among the millions of investors who stampeded out of stocks in 2008 and corralled most of your liquid assets into bonds?

title: A Late Oscar Push for Inception
description: LOS ANGELES Warner Brothers has had a nightmarish Oscar season. First, The Town ran out of gas. Clint Eastwoods Hereafter didnt seem to have any to begin with. Then Christopher Nolan failed to get a directing nomination for Inception. But none of that is stopping the studio from making another campaign push, doubling down on its dreamworld thriller.

title: Efforts to Avoid Probate Can Carry Their Own Risks
description: THE new tax law signed by President Obama in December gives many people a reason to revise their estate plans. In the process, some will try to avoid probate. Others may be surprised to find that much of what they leave behind will not go through probate anyway.

title: Tax Cut Deal Could Benefit Charities
description: ALTHOUGH many critics have denounced the tax deal reached in December by Congressional leaders and the Obama administration as tax cuts for the rich, personal wealth advisers who specialize in philanthropy also foresee benefits for charities.

title: As Their Attendance Falls, Mets Try Giving Tickets Away
description: By most standards, the Mets have had an off-season to forget. Yes, they hired a new manager and several high-profile executives, including Sandy Alderson as general manager. But, despite two straight fourth-place finishes, the Mets have not signed any star players, and they let several key players go, including the pitchers Pedro Feliciano and Hisanori Takahashi.

title: Dead Zone for iPhones No More
description: Four years and a few upgrades ago, the first iPhones were sold in the United States.

title: Adjusting Insurance to Fit Your Needs
description: WHEN a 1930 Duesenberg Dual Cowl Phaeton came up for bidding at a recent vintage-car auction in Scottsdale, Ariz., Jim Fiske, an insurance executive, surveyed the clutch of well-heeled bidders.

title: A Battle Across the Border in Recruiting
description: Patrick McCarron, 16, is a defenseman with the St. Michaels Buzzers in Toronto, a team owned by his father that plays in provincial Junior A hockey. Last summer, McCarron was drafted by the Oshawa Generals of the Ontario Hockey League. The Generals put a contract in front of him, but he would not sign it.

title: Russia: Expelled British Journalist Offered New Visa
description: A British journalist who was expelled from Russia over the weekend is considering an offer from the Russian Foreign Ministry to receive a new visa and return to work in Moscow, his newspaper said Wednesday. The journalist, Luke Harding of The Guardian, left, was detained after landing at a Moscow airport and sent back to London despite having a journalists visa in his passport. Russian officials at first refused to explain why Mr. Harding was deported, then said that he had violated rules for foreign correspondents because he did not pick up a press card. Mr. Harding and his editors have suggested that he was expelled because Russian authorities were displeased with his coverage. On Wednesday, it appeared that the Russian Foreign Ministry was all but acknowledging that the authorities had made a mistake and were trying to persuade Mr. Harding to return.

title: Life Lessons for Children on a Family Vacation
description: JOHN-PIERRE L. CONTE approaches family travel planning the same way he approaches other aspects of his busy life. I hire the best people, they start out with a template, and I do the editing, said Mr. Conte, a single father of four children, ages 2 to 12, and chairman of Genstar Capital, a private equity firm based in San Francisco.

title: Britain: Crematory to Heat Swimming Pool
description: Sharp government spending cuts have forced contentious choices on local authorities, perhaps none more so than one councils decision to heat a community swimming pool with energy diverted from a crematory. The council in Redditch, near Birmingham, has approved the diversion of waste heat from the crematorys incinerator to a next-door leisure center and its new pool. Councilor Carole Gandy said the plan was consistent with the need for energy efficiency and had been widely backed by local residents once officials had explained the technology involved, which she described as common elsewhere in Europe. Labor union officials said the plan encapsulated the extremes forced on local authorities by national austerity cuts. Roger McKenzie, regional secretary for Unison, Britains largest public sector union, condemned the plan as sick and an insult to local residents.

title: The New Knits of M. Patmos
description: New York Fashion Week starts Thursday, right? Not quite. A number of independent designers got a jump on the season with small presentations around the city, and one of the sharpest shown on Wednesday belonged to Marcia Patmos. (See the full collection.)

title: Counting by Race Can Throw Off Some Numbers
description: The federal Department of Education would categorize Michelle Lpez-Mullins  a university student who is of Peruvian, Chinese, Irish, Shawnee and Cherokee descent  as Hispanic. But the National Center for Health Statistics, the government agency that tracks data on births and deaths, would pronounce her Asian and "Hispanic." And what does Ms. Lpez-Mullinss birth certificate from the State of Maryland say? It doesnt mention her race.

title: Israel: Unions Threaten to Strike Over Rising Prices
description: Israeli union officials threatened Wednesday to call a general strike to protest recent price increases that have sent the cost of gasoline, water and basic foods spiraling upward. Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu is expected to announce measures to ease the burden on the public on Thursday. A news conference was originally planned for Wednesday but was postponed after Finance Minister Yuval Steinitz was hospitalized, suffering from flu and exhaustion. Mr. Netanyahu is facing growing public anger over the increases: the cost of gasoline has gone up by 13 percent, the price of water has increased by more than 100 percent and many basic food items have risen by up to 8 percent over the past year.

title: Tax-Free Life Insurance: An Untapped Investment for the Affluent
description: ITS viewed as an insiders secret for the affluent: a legal way to invest in hedge funds and other potentially lucrative assets, all without paying taxes on the gains.

title: France: President Tells Ministers to Vacation at Home
description: President Nicolas Sarkozy tried to put a lid on the political furor over senior ministers taking free flights in Tunisia and Egypt last Christmas by telling his cabinet to vacation in France. Mr. Sarkozy said that government ministers would now have to get permission from the prime ministers office before accepting invitations to visit other countries. Prime Minister Franois Fillon vacationed with his family last year at the invitation and expense of the Egyptian government. Foreign Minister Michle Alliot-Marie vacationed in Tunisia when demonstrations were already under way and accepted two free flights from a businessman close to the family of Tunisias president, who was later ousted.

title: Birding in the Lower Rio Grande
description: The Rio Grande Valley is South Texass birding mecca.

title: Fake Twitter Accounts Get Real Laughs
description: WASHINGTON  When a blizzard blanketed Chicago last week, Rahm Emanuel took to Twitter to chronicle his day  making a snow angel on Lake Michigan, shoveling out David Axelrods Civic, drinking whiskey in an igloo made by a tireless campaign intern named Carl.

title: Jordan: New Cabinet Members Are Sworn In
description: Eight days after King Abdullah II fired his cabinet and named a new prime minister, the rest of the new government was sworn in on Wednesday. The 27-member cabinet included a number of holdovers  notably the foreign, interior and economy ministers  as well as a few leftists. The opposition Muslim Brotherhood, which declined an invitation to be part of the government, said it was less interested in who held the portfolios than what they would do. Prime Minister Marouf al-Bakhit promised to institute a fairer election law and a more liberal public assembly law. The government was expected to maintain its close ties to the United States.

title: Isles, Their Luck Long Gone, Are Nearly Out of Goalies, Too
description: Kevin Poulin, the 20-year-old Islanders goaltender who had been the latest replacement for the often-injured Rick DiPietro, will miss the rest of the season after dislocating his left kneecap while warming up for a game Tuesday, the team said.

title: Doing Well After Not Knowing What to Do
description: When Gregory Auditore balked at the time and expense required to get a college degree, his mother, Margaret, a nurse, suggested a compromise: Put in two years of study, become a certified radiology technician, and start making $25 an hour. (His first job paid $32 an hour, a windfall.) Mr. Auditore, 21, graduated from the School of Radiologic Technology at Long Island College Hospital in Brooklyn in 2009 and is employed by Continuum Health Partners as an X-ray technician at Beth Israel Medical Center. He lives on Staten Island with his parents.

title: New Questions Raised in Mortgage Financing
description: Banks have been fighting with disgruntled bond investors and insurers for months, arguing that they do not need to buy back soured mortgages they placed inside securities before the financial crisis.

title: Wake Forest Baseball Coach Donates Kidney to Player
description: ATLANTA  When Wake Forest offered him a baseball scholarship, outfielder Kevin Jordan focused his research on what any high school athlete would: the opportunity for playing time.

title: Costs Soaring, New Jersey Bond Rating Is Lowered
description: A top credit-rating firm lowered New Jerseys bond rating on Wednesday, citing ballooning pension and other costs, and Gov. Chris Christie and Democrats in the Legislature wasted no time in blaming each other.

title: Hotels Offer Their Own Fashion Events
description: Hotels in New York City have long offered after-parties during fashion week. But this season, the trend extends beyond inviting well-paid international DJs to spin for the fashion set when the shows are over. Hotels are increasingly taking their marketing a step further by pairing up with designers and fashion purveyors to host their own shows and events. Heres what a few lodgings are doing this season:

title: Sports Replay: Feb. 9
description: A skier, a jumper and a full day of soccer friendlies.

title: Playing Catch-Up, Nokia and H.P. Try to Innovate
description: In technology markets, playing catch-up is a bruising, costly and often futile game, even for corporate giants.

title: House Republicans Battle Turmoil in Their Ranks
description: WASHINGTON  Under pressure to make deeper spending cuts and blindsided by embarrassing floor defeats, House Republican leaders are quickly discovering the limits of control over their ideologically driven and independent-minded new majority.

title: U.S. Proposes Aquaculture Guidelines
description: The federal government on Wednesday issued the nations first policy guidelines for aquaculture, opening the way for farm-raised seafood to be produced in federal waters as long as the operations do not threaten wild fish stocks or saltwater ecosystems.

title: Delay of State Money for Merger May Force a Hospital in Brooklyn to Close
description: A struggling Brooklyn hospital is making plans to shut down in March after a decision by the Cuomo administration to delay grants to help finance a merger intended to rescue the institution, officials said on Wednesday.

title: Cloud Follows UConn as It Changes Course
description: The University of Connecticut mens basketball team is in the midst of an abrupt and surprising turnaround. After finishing 18-16 last season, the Huskies are ranked 10th nationally, have a star in guard Kemba Walker and appear poised for a top seed in the N.C.A.A. tournament.

title: Team Chosen for Work on Big Middle-Income Complex in Queens
description: The Bloomberg administration announced Wednesday that it had selected a team led by the Related Companies to construct the first phase of a development on the Queens waterfront that will be the largest middle-income complex built in the city since the 1970s.

title: The Choctaw Confederates
description: Doaksville, Indian Territory, February 1861

title: German Brse in Talks to Buy the Big Board
description: 9:00 p.m. | Updated

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,460 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American on Wednesday:

title: New Star in the Front Row
description: FOR two reasons, the choice of Emmanuelle Alt as editor in chief of French Vogue, in January, was anticlimactic. First, there was all the weirdness of her predecessors departure. Was Carine Roitfeld, who held the post for 10 years, fired or did she resign, as Cond Nast maintained? Second, the swift promotion of Ms. Alt from the No. 2 position of fashion director suggested that her bosses werent looking for much change. As she herself said, They know my work by heart, and probably they felt like it was safe for them.

title: City Settles Suit in Death of an Inmate
description: The City of New York has agreed to pay over half a million dollars to settle a wrongful death lawsuit filed by the family of a South Carolina man who was killed  while in custody on Rikers Island in 2009.

title: Even if Loughner Doesnt Testify, Jurors Could See Videos, Officials Say
description: TUCSON  Videotaped messages recovered from a computer at the home of Jared L. Loughner, the man accused of opening fire at a congresswomans public event in Tucson last month, could mean that a jury will hear from Mr. Loughner in his own words even though he is unlikely to testify at trial, law enforcement officials said.

title: As Verizons iPhone Sales Begin, Gauging the Effects on AT&T
description: The race between AT&T and Verizon Wireless kicks into hyperdrive on Thursday as Verizon begins selling the iPhone 4 to new customers, ending AT&Ts exclusive hold on the phone in the United States.

title: Century Club Letters About the Garrick
description: Letters from the Century clubs president and its members show differing opinions on whether to continue a relationship with the all-male Garrick club in London.

title: Boots for Snow and for Show
description: WELCOME to New York Fashion Week, everyone. Watch out for your shoes!

title: Charges Against Muslim Students Prompt Debate Over Free Speech
description: IRVINE, Calif.  When administrators at the University of California, Irvine, decided to suspend the Muslim Student Union for a quarter over the disruption of a speech last year by the Israeli ambassador to the United States, most thought the latest controversy on campus had ended.

title: A Beginners Guide to Unemployment
description: surreal adj. marked by the intense irrational reality of a dream; unbelievable, fantastic. (Merriam-Webster)

title: The Buzz: Fashion Weeks Top Parties
description: FASHION Week storms into town. A preview of the must-attend parties and openings for the week ahead. Stay tuned for party photos this week at nytimes.com/fashionweek.

title: The First Ladys Look, in a Book
description: THE pale yellow dress by Isabel Toledo she wore at the inauguration. The Jason Wu ivory chiffon gown she danced in. Thakoon Panichguls magenta frock she packed for Europe.

title: Lawmakers Hear of Threat by Domestic Terrorists
description: WASHINGTON  The House Homeland Security Committee on Wednesday opened a wide-ranging review of terrorist threats facing the United States as the 10th anniversary of the Sept. 11 attacks approaches.

title: Brown Cancels Predecessors Deal to Sell State Buildings
description: SACRAMENTO  As states across the country struggle to deal with overwhelming budget deficits, a number of state officials, including those in California, have resorted to trying to sell state office buildings, pouring the proceeds into the general funds, and then leasing back the space.

title: New York Congressman Resigns Over E-Mails
description: WASHINGTON  Representative Christopher Lee of New York abruptly resigned on Wednesday night after a shirtless photo of himself, which he had e-mailed to a woman, was published on the Internet.

title: Virginia Democrat Opts to Stop at One Senate Term
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Jim Webb, Democrat of Virginia, has decided not to run for re-election, avoiding a blockbuster rematch with the man he beat in 2006, George Allen, and giving Senate Republicans another opportunity to try to reclaim the majority.

title: Implications of Study on Breast Cancer
description: An article on Wednesday described how a routine procedure for the treatment of early breast cancer  the surgical removal of cancerous lymph nodes from the armpit  has been found unnecessary for many patients. The finding turns 100 years of standard medical practice on its head. The author of the article, Denise Grady, answered questions online from readers about the finding and its implications. More at nytimes.com/science.

title: North Carolina Man Admits to Aiding a Jihadist Plot
description: Daniel Patrick Boyd, a North Carolina man whose arrest on terrorism-related charges surprised the residents of his bucolic town, pleaded guilty in Federal District Court in New Bern, N.C., on Wednesday to conspiring to assist violent jihadists and to participate in attacks in foreign countries, Justice Department officials said.

title: What the Muslim Brothers Want
description: Cairo

title: Obama Recognizes Men Who Died in the Collapse of a Radar Tower in 1961
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama on Wednesday recognized 28 men who died when their cold war radar station collapsed into the Atlantic Ocean 50 years ago.

title: Police and Firefighters Vow to Fight Bloombergs Plan to Cut a Retirement Benefit
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs proposal to strip a treasured perquisite that retired police officers and firefighters won under the Lindsay administration four decades ago has driven a deep wedge between himself and the unions representing uniformed personnel.

title: Lottery Numbers
Lakers Say They Are Not Among Suitors for Anthony
description: BOSTON  If the opportunity presented itself, the Los Angeles Lakers would trade a big man to obtain Denvers Carmelo Anthony.

title: Growing Bloomberg L.P. To Rent Half of a Tower
description: In another sign of Bloomberg L.P.s growth, the company announced on Wednesday that it had signed a lease for 16 floors in the former Philip Morris building, across from Grand Central Terminal.

title: Wired and Shrewd, Young Egyptians Guide Revolt
description: CAIRO  They were born roughly around the time that President Hosni Mubarak first came to power, most earned degrees from their countrys top universities and all have spent their adult lives bridling at the restrictions of the Egyptian police state  some undergoing repeated arrests and torture for the cause.

title: Two Construction Workers in Fatal Fall Are Recalled as Dedicated Family Men
description: The two men worked in construction for 30 years, their passion for building equaled only by the dedication they had for their families.

title: The Road to Tahrir Square
description: Cairo Bureau Chief David D. Kirkpatrick and Mona El-Naggar took a ride to Tahrir Square with Islam Lotfi, a young activist who helped spark the uprising in Egypt, to learn how it all started.

title: Goddess Worshipers and Tax Authorities Clash in an Upstate Town
description: PALENVILLE, N.Y.

title: Thursday: Red Hot Chili Pepper
description: THURSDAYS PUZZLE  Where do you start in a crossword puzzle? Some people insist on starting at 1 Across every time. Me, I look for any easy entry into the grid. And because Im basically an overgrown child, my first conquest today was 24 Across: MERRIE Melodies.

title: Unions to Press Chase on Modifying Additional Mortgages
description: Leaders of two large New York City unions said Wednesday that they would push for their pension funds to sell their stocks and bonds in JPMorgan Chase if the bank did not help more struggling homeowners avoid foreclosure.

title: Gawkers Scoop Draws Eyes to a New Format
description: Representative Christopher Lees sudden resignation on Wednesday was triggered by an article on Gawker, the Manhattan-based gossip Web site.

title: Judges Rush for Vacation Marred Murder Trial, Appeals Lawyer Argues
description: The 2009 conviction of a Queens doctor for hiring a relative to fatally shoot her husband outside a Queens playground was marred by hearsay and a distracted judge who wanted to get to a tropical vacation, the celebrity lawyer Alan M. Dershowitz argued in an appellate hearing on Wednesday.

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

description: Washington

description: To the Editor:

title: Toronto Exchange Merger May Be Capitalist Test for Canada
description: More than the queens visage on their money binds the financial centers of London and Toronto. They are two of the worlds preferred destinations for raising capital in the mining and metals businesses. So sort of a merger of equals, like the one announced by the TMX Group and the London Stock Exchange, carries strong industrial logic.

title: Syria Restores Access to Facebook and YouTube
description: The Syrian government began allowing its citizens Wednesday to openly use Facebook and YouTube, three years after blocking access to Facebook and other sites as part of a crackdown on political activism. Human rights advocates greeted the news guardedly, warning that the government might have lifted the ban to more closely monitor people and activity on social networking sites.

title: Jeers and Big-Game Feel Greet High-Profile Visitor
description: For a good part of this season, the Knicks have not stunk as badly and as regularly as they did in the past decade. This made it possible for New Yorkers to remember they actually love this sport, not hate it, the way so many fans had begun to feel.

title: Missouri: Busch Friend Died of Drug Overdose
description: The woman found dead last month at the home of August Busch IV, the former head of Anheuser-Busch, died of an accidental overdose of oxycodone, a powerful prescription painkiller that is sometimes used recreationally, the St. Louis County medical examiner said Wednesday. The woman, Adrienne Martin, 27, had been in a relationship with Mr. Busch, 46, who was C.E.O. of the company his family founded when it was sold to a Belgian company, InBev, three years ago. The rest of the results, including a toxicology report that would show whether any other drugs were in her system, were forwarded to the county prosecutors office, which is investigating the case, and not released.

title: Mark J. Hulkower, Who Prosecuted Aldrich Ames, Dies at 53
description: Mark J. Hulkower, who successfully prosecuted one of the nations most notorious traitors and followed up by defending high-profile executives accused of white-collar crimes, died on Saturday in Arlington, Va. He was 53.

title: At a Club for Civil Discussions, Polarizing Debate
description: A prominent author was startled by the ferocious tone of the debate. Some of the rhetoric, she said, was scary. A wealthy art collector stopped logging into his e-mail account, for fear of discovering yet another new screed. And by the end, an acclaimed cultural critic could barely stand to look at people she had once considered close friends. I just try not to think of what they said when I see them, she said.

title: What Would Shirley Do?
description: The news that 41 percent of pregnancies in New York City end in abortion was eye-catching enough, but what really caught my eye in a report on the statistic were the comments of a New York legislator, State Senator Rubn Daz Sr. They might think that we will take over, and that theyve got to stop us, Senator Daz was quoted as having told a group of fellow anti-abortion ministers last month. What they did, they are killing black and Hispanic children.

title: Stoudemire Says Focus, but Knicks Dont Listen
description: Blake Griffin did not venture outside the laws of gravity. He did not bend minds or rims or emasculate any Knicks on Wednesday night in his Madison Square Garden debut.

title: What Egyptian Repression Looks Like
description: In my column today, I talk about two videos that demonstrate the brutality exhibited by elements of the Egyptian regime. Both have been on TV, but if you havent seen them take a look. Theyre stomach-churning, and I think that after seeing them youll find that its harder to counsel stability, patience, and order.You understand more clearly why young people want change so fervently and are so distrustful of the regime.

title: Police Say Worker Took Late-Book Fees
description: A Yonkers woman has been charged with stealing more than $160,000 from the Yonkers Public Library over seven years  money that came in large part from overdue book fines, the authorities said on Wednesday.

title: Franoise Cachin, a Director of French Museums, Dies at 74
description: Franoise Cachin, a museum director who helped found the Muse dOrsay in Paris, organized major exhibitions of modern art and wrote important books on 19th-century French painting, died on Friday. She was 74.

title: Alan Slifka, Who Promoted Arab-Jewish Ties, Is Dead at 81
description: Alan B. Slifka, a New York investment manager who used his fortune to promote harmony among Israeli Arabs and Jews and to give the Big Apple Circus its start, died on Friday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 81 and also had a home in Manhattan.

title: Immigration Laws
description: To the Editor:

title: Digging a Hole Instead of a Tunnel
description: With states and cities in such a bad way, it is worth remembering how a previous generation rebuilt America during the Depressions bleakest years. The elegant George Washington Bridge opened in 1931. The Triborough Bridge followed five years later. Ribbons were cut for the Lincoln Tunnel in 1937, and La Guardia Airport opened officially in 1939.

title: Dont Worry. Be Happy.
description: In troubled times its important to pace yourself. Theres only so much you can worry about at once, and weve already got Egypt, the weird weather, rising food prices and unemployment. Plus, the secretary of homeland security says the terror threat is really high. It would be at least reddish-orange if we hadnt gotten rid of the color code.

title: A Debate Bigger Than Reform
description: While the federal courts consider whether the health care reform law is constitutional, there is an intense and even wider debate playing out in political and legal circles about the Constitution and Congresss power to solve national problems.

title: Obama and Egypts Future
description: In Tahrir Square, I saw a young man holding a sign over his head. The sign urged President Hosni Mubarak to flee the country: Hurry up! My arms are tired.

title: Relief for States and Businesses
description: So many people now receive jobless benefits that 30 states have run out of their unemployment trust funds and are borrowing $42 billion from the federal government. Three of the hardest-hit states  Michigan, Indiana and South Carolina  have borrowed so much that they triggered automatic unemployment tax increases on employers, and the same thing is likely to happen to 20 more states this year.

title: .24 Karat Gall
description: When we last wrote about National Collectors Mint, in 2004, the company was in trouble with New Yorks attorney general for selling Sept. 11 commemorative coins that it claimed were legal tender from the Northern Mariana Islands, supposedly struck from silver recovered at ground zero. It was a galling case of deceptive advertising for which the state extracted more than $2 million in fines and penalties.

title: North Korea Reacts Angrily to Breakdown of Talks
description: SEOUL, South Korea  North Korea reacted angrily Thursday to the breakdown of preliminary military talks with South Korea, saying the "scoundrels and "traitors in the South were not interested in a genuine dialogue and were trying to derail the resumption of six-party talks involving the Norths nuclear programs.

description: NATIONAL

title: Queens Little League Coach Is Accused of Sex Assault
description: A convicted sex offender who had risen up through the ranks at his local Little League was arraigned Wednesday on new sex offense charges, the Queens district attorney, Richard A. Brown, announced.

title: Hackers Breach Tech Systems of Oil Companies
description: At least five multinational oil and gas companies suffered computer network intrusions from a persistent group of computer hackers based in China, according to a report released Wednesday night by a Silicon Valley computer security firm.

title: American Idol':  and Dont Forget J.Lo!
description: Its been Steven Tylers season so far on American Idol  the facial expressions, the outfits, the basic gifts of decency and wisdom. Sometimes its been tough to remember that the shows other new judge, Jennifer Lopez, was meant to be the bigger draw.

title: Dozens Killed at Pakistan Army School
description: MARDAN, Pakistan  A teenage suicide bomber walked onto the parade ground of a major military training school in northwest Pakistan on Thursday and blew himself up, killing 27 cadets, officials said.

title: New Questions Raised in Mortgage Financing
description: Banks have been fighting with disgruntled bond investors and insurers for months, arguing that they do not need to buy back soured mortgages they placed inside securities before the financial crisis, Louise Story reports in The New York Times.

title: Q&A: Red Bulls Joel Lindpere
description: Joel Lindpere, a tenacious but largely unknown and decidedly unglamorous Estonian midfielder, joined the Red Bulls on a free transfer last year. From his first game, when he scored the first goal at Red Bull Arena, Lindpere proved he was one of the finds of the season, an adept move by the clubs sporting director/general manager, Erik Soler. Lindpere, the teams most valuable player in 2011, spoke with The Timess Jack Bell late last week before the club left for preseason training in Mexico.

title: Test Yourself | English, Feb. 10, 2011
description: Test your vocabulary skills with todays question, created by Danielle Hoagland and Judith McCaffrey at Grammarlogues from the article Tuesdays Forecast: Horrific.

title: Video Exclusive | Shirin Neshat Models for Ohne Titel
description: Flora Gill and Alexa Adams named their label Ohne Titel (German for no title) after Anselm Kiefer, the German artist who frequently left his works untitled and who inspired their first collection in 2007. So it stands to reason that they would again turn to the art world when recently casting for a new model. The new Ohne Titel spring 2011 campaign, which goes live tomorrow, stars the Iranian-born, New York-based artist Shirin Neshat, whose work often deals with the politics of appearances and the complex theater of female personae.

title: What Are Your Best Sleepover Memories?
description: Sleepovers have apparently become an essential part of childhood, for boys as well as for girls, writes Perri Klass in Ensuring Domestic Tranquillity During Sleepovers. Though this article was written for parents of younger children, it inspired us to ask what you remember about great sleepovers youve attended, whether as a younger child or now. What makes for a fun sleepover? When, if ever, have you had an unpleasant sleepover experience? What advice do you have for younger children going on their first sleepovers?

description: CAIRO  President Hosni Mubarak told the Egyptian people on Thursday that he would delegate authority to Vice President Omar Suleiman but that he would not resign, enraging hundreds of thousands gathered to hail his departure and setting in motion a volatile new stage in the three-week uprising.

title: Madrids ARCO Art Fair Hits Its 30th Year
description: ARCO, Madrids International Contemporary Art Fair, celebrates its 30th anniversary this year, from Feb. 18 to 20, by showcasing art from 197 international galleries. With works ranging from the historical avant-garde to acclaimed contemporary pieces, it draws hundreds of artists, collectors, critics, curators, museum directors, academics and other members of the art-loving public, some interested in Picasso prints, others crazy about Bill Viola videos.

title: Trump Will Speak at CPAC
description: Donald Trump is telling friends and advisers that he is seriously considering jumping into the Republican presidential race in 2012. To make his point, he has accepted an invitation to appear with other potential candidates at a gathering of conservative activists in Washington.

description: A Fifth Down post that suggested that the Packers were poised to become a dynasty drew skepticism from some of our readers.
