title: Will Obama Ask Kaine to Seek Virginia Senate Seat?
description: The first time Tim Kaine was approached to work for President Obama as chairman of the Democratic National Committee, he said no and promptly marched out to reporters  just in case Mr. Obamas lieutenants had not gotten the message.

title: Hong Kong Exchange Open to a Deal
description: Amid a flurry of deal activity among its rivals, the Hong Kong Exchange said on Thursday that it would consider joining up with other players in the rapidly consolidating sector.

title: Dan Snyders Lawsuit and P.R. Strategy
description: Its hard to imagine any American sports owner having had a rougher past two weeks than Jerry Jones, much less a fellow one from the N.F.C. East.

title: Republicans Begin Regulation Battle
description: This week, Congressional Republicans fired their opening salvos against the Obama administrations regulatory apparatus. On Wednesday, Representative Sam Graves of Missouri, chairman of the House Small Business Committee, held a hearing on the health care law provision that expands 1099 reporting*, and the Energy and Commerce Committee questioned the Environmental Protection Agency administrator, Lisa P. Jackson, on global warming limits. On Thursday, Representative Darrell Issa of California, continues the assault in the Oversight and Government Reform committee, with a hearing on  Regulatory Impediments to Job Creation.

title: Afghan Government Says Prisoner Directed Attacks
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  A cell of suicide bombers active in Kabul was run for three years by a Taliban commander operating from the citys main prison, Afghan officials said Thursday.

title: Bank of England Keeps Rates Unchanged
description: Caught between weak growth data and rising price pressures, the Bank of England chose Thursday to leave unchanged interest rates as well as its broad asset buying program.

title: Paris in Springtime May Not Include the French Open
description: It sounded outlandish at first, like nothing more than a thinly disguised bargaining chip. But the prospect of moving the French Open to the suburbs has gradually developed into a legitimate option or, if you are Mayor Bertrand Delano of Paris, a legitimate threat.

title: Requiem for the Bears?
description: In a recent article, I wrote about the unusual weather patterns of the last two winters, with excessive cold and snow in the eastern United States and western Europe occurring at the same time as unusual warmth in parts of the Arctic. One thing I did not mention in that story was what the likely effect on Arctic wildlife would be if this sort of thing continues.

title: White House Outlines Wireless Spending and Bandwidth Sales
description: President Obama, who pledged in his State of the Union address to extend next-generation wireless coverage to 98 percent of all Americans, will call on Thursday for a one-time, $5 billion down payment to achieve that goal, White House officials said.

title: Morning Take-Out
description: MERGERS & ACQUISITIONS

title: Opening Day: Verizon iPhone 4
description: 12:03 p.m. | Updated   Adding accounts from Twitter and eyewitness reports from Bits commenters.

title: India and Pakistan Agree to Renew Peace Talks
description: NEW DELHI  India and Pakistan announced on Thursday that the two countries would resume peace talks that have been stalled since 2008, when Pakistani militants staged coordinated terrorist attacks in Mumbai, India, killing 163.

title: Ben Roethlisberger and the Hall of Fame
description: Before Super Bowl XLV, many experts and pundits started speculating about Ben Roethlisbergers Hall of Fame credentials if the Steelers defeated the Packers. Some thought that a third Super Bowl title would mean very close to automatic enshrinement; others thought it was too soon to discuss the topic, given Roethlisbergers limited body of work.

title: New American Idiot Cast Members Include Davey Havok of AFI
description: 11:39 a.m. | Updated

title: Morning Buzz | Fierce Debate at a Club for Gentle Discussion
description: Thursday will be mostly sunny and cold, with highs in the upper 20s dipping into the teens at night.

title: Updates on Day 17 of Egypt Protests
description: The Lede continues to follow the protest movement in Egypt, now in its third week. For a summary of new developments, read todays main news article from our colleagues in Cairo. Updates below mix alerts on breaking news with reports from bloggers and journalists in Egypt. A stream of Twitter updates on the protests is in this blogs right column.

title: Tweet, Tweet! Its Fashion Week
description: A picture may paint a thousand words, but what can 140 characters tell you about Fashion Week? A lot, actually. Throughout New York Fashion Week, our writers will be posting live updates on Ts Twitter feed, http://twitter.com/themoment, giving you our impressions from the shows as well as from attendant parties and events. This season, we are also following some of our favorite up-and-coming designers and live-blogging their crunch time via Twitter. Today from 12 p.m. to 2 p.m., we will be going backstage at the Wes Gordon show, and from 3 p.m. to 7 p.m. well be at Jonathan Simkhai, to give you a behind-the-scenes look at the busiest and most exhilarating moments before the shows.

title: Och-Ziff Posts Increase in Earnings and Assets
description: 3:42 p.m. | Updated

title: Paying for Health Care Results (Cont.)
description: Jon Baron, the president of the Coalition for Evidence-Based Policy in Washington, agrees that health care is a promising area for the government to issue social-impact bonds. (A short description of the bonds is here, and a longer one is here.) Mr. Baron offers a few other candidates for health-care bonds, in an e-mail:

title: The Investors Behind the Exchange Mergers
description: The owner of the New York Stock Exchange is in advanced talks on a deal that could see Deutsche Brse shareholders own 59 to 60 percent of a combined company that would be incorporated in the Netherlands. In addition to the United States and Germany, the merged entity would have exchange operations in 12 European nations.

title: Galderma Raises Q-Med Bid to $1.2 Billion
description: Galderma, a joint venture between LOral and Nestl, said on Thursday that it was raising its bid for the Swedish beauty products maker Q-Med to 79 kroner a share, or 7.9 billion kroner ($1.2 billion) for the entire company.

title: N.Y.S.E. Must Keep Its Name, Florida Congressman Says
description: Many details of the planned merger of NYSE Euronext and Deutsche Brse need to be ironed out. But one American legislator is already making one demand: the New York Stock Exchange must keep its name.

title: Leprosy, Plague and Other Visitors to New York
description: When New York Citys health department revealed last weekend that three people had contracted cholera, it was a reminder that the city is not just a world capital of arts, business and the like  but also of exotic diseases.

title: Blast Kills 5 in Pennsylvania
description: ALLENTOWN, Pa.  For the residents of a block of brick row houses here on North 13th Street, Wednesday night went from ordinary to horrific in one unexpected flash.

title: Bombing Kills Shiite Pilgrims in Iraq
description: BAGHDAD  A car bomb exploded near a procession of Shiite Muslim pilgrims south of the holy city of Samarra on Thursday, killing nine people, including one child, and wounding 39 people, 5 of them children, a police official said.

title: Search for Low Airfares Gets More Competitive
description: The familiar world of online air travel search is about to get a major shake-up.

title: Chanoss Short Story on the Markets
description: James Chanos, founder and president of Kynikos Associates, talks to DealBooks Andrew Ross Sorkin on CNBC about his bearish views on some sectors, including the Chinese property market and integrated oil.

title: Kathy Griffin Coming to Broadway
description: The salty comedian and reality TV star Kathy Griffin has two Emmy Awards, a best-selling autobiography and a Grammy Award nomination. And shes not being shy about her desire to add a Tony Award to her rsum when she makes her Broadway debut in a new one-woman show next month.

title: Banksy Shenanigans Not Welcome at Oscars
description: The will-he, wont-he riddle about Banksy and the Oscars  will he show up? wont he be in disguise?  has a solution. After the Oscar nominees luncheon on Monday, Steve Pond reports, the Academy president, Tom Sherak, and executive director, Bruce Davis, huddled at a table with Jaimie DCruz, a producer of Exit Through the Gift Shop, Banksys Oscar-nominated documentary. They worked through the potential situations of Banksy winning and having to appear on stage, which he would presumably do in costume, his costume of choice being a monkey mask. Undignified, the Academy felt. If Banksy isnt comfortable showing his face on the Kodak stage, Sherak said, then the Academy isnt comfortable having him on that stage, Mr. Pond writes. Instead, the Academy officials and Mr. DCruz agreed, if the movie wins, Mr. DCruz will accept without any additional shenanigans.

title: Bachmann Opens Conservative Conference
description: The Conservative Political Action Conference opened Thursday morning with an address by Representative Michele Bachmann of Minnesota, who accused President Obama of being a socialist and urged the conservative faithful to focus on making Barack Obama a one-term president.

title: Yet Another Route to Cellulosic Ethanol
description: There are myriad routes to making car fuel from waste, using mix-and-match technologies assembled in novel ways, but none has worked yet on a commercial scale. On Wednesday, Ineos Bio, the subsidiary of a major international chemical firm, broke ground on a plant that aims to use yet another combination.

title: Profile in Style | Jenn Lombardo
description: The pint-size branding genius behind the Terminal Presents, which oversees Fashion Weeks M.A.C. & Milk events hub, has fierce personal style, mixing cutting-edge designers with semi-destroyed garage-sale and flea-market finds. More

title: Galleon Founders Trial Is Pushed Back
description: A federal judge on Thursday pushed back by a week the trial of Raj Rajaratnam, who has been accused of being at the center of an insider trading network.

title: Peering Into a Reclusive Life
description: The well-known dedication of J. D. Salingers Raise High the Roof Beam, Carpenters and Seymour: An Introduction reads: If there is an amateur reader still left in the world  or anybody who just reads and runs  I ask him or her, with untellable affection and gratitude, to split the dedication of this book four ways with my wife and children.

title: Afghan Proposal Would Clamp Down on Womens Shelters
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  After her parents threw her out of the house for refusing to marry a 52-year-old widower with five children, Sabra, 18, boarded a bus that dropped her, afraid and confused, in downtown Kabul. She slept in a mosque for days, barely eating, until a woman took pity on her and put her in touch with human rights workers, who escorted her to a womens shelter.

title: Can Gay Marriage Save State Budgets?
description: Legalizing gay marriage in Rhode Island could bring the state an additional $1.2 million over a three-year period, according to a study from the Williams Institute at the School of Law at the University of California, Los Angeles.

title: That Hair! Those Eyes! His Fans!
description: Jon M. Chus Justin Bieber: Never Say Never is billed as a concert documentary, but fewer than half of its 105 minutes are devoted to Mr. Bieber onstage. That was the right choice, because hes more engaging as a star than hes ever likely to be as a performer.

title: Zoobiquity
description: An approach to health care that combines knowledge from human and veterinary medicine.

title: It Was the SilverCup Hotel; Now Its the Vetiver
description: The not-yet-open SilverCup Hotel in Long Island City, Queens, which was locked in a trademark dispute with the nearby Silvercup Studios, changed its name on Wednesday to the Hotel Vetiver.

title: Poetry Pairing | Feb. 10, 2011
description: In our weekly Poetry Pairing series, we collaborate with the Poetry Foundation to feature a work from its American Life in Poetry project alongside content from The Times that somehow echoes, extends or challenges the poems themes. Each poem is introduced briefly by Ted Kooser, a former United States poet laureate.

title: Popcast: The Grammy Awards and an Interview With Betty Wright
description: This week Popcast, The Timess weekly music podcast, takes a look at the 53rd annual Grammy Awards, which will be broadcast live from Los Angeles on Sunday night at 8 p.m. Eastern time.

title: Asked & Answered | Lauren Santo Domingo and Aslaug Magnusdottir
description: We live in an age of instant gratification, where everything our hearts desire  news, information, groceries  can be had with the click of a mouse. And starting on February 16 at 11 a.m., you can add fashion to that list. Yes, there are plenty of shopping sites out there, but Moda Operandi, a new e-tail concept from Lauren Santo Domingo and Aslaug Magnusdottir, will allow shoppers to see and purchase their favorite looks right off the runway.

title: A Life of Melting the Status Quo
description: LYNDA BENGLIS has gone her own way since first taking on the New York art world in the 1960s. She one-upped Jackson Pollocks action paintings in the late 1960s by pouring pools of swirling pigmented latex directly on the floor and obscuring the distinction between painting and sculpture. She challenged the rigidity of Minimalism in the early 70s with her hardened flows of polyurethane careening off walls and bristling with allusions to the body and landscape. She lampooned both the machismo of the art world and the way artists were expected to promote themselves in a market-driven system by exposing herself, with a dildo between her legs, in a 1974 Artforum advertisement that she paid for, earning her as many fans as detractors.

title: Leaked Cables Reveal U.S. Concerns Over Saudi Peak Oil
description: Saudi Arabias ability to boost oil production much above current levels is questionable and the countrys overall crude reserves may have been overstated by up to 40 percent, American diplomats in Riyadh warned in confidential cables written between 2007 and 2009. The dispatches were released by Wikileaks and published on Tuesday by The Guardian newspaper in Britain.

title: Pushing Paladino to Take His Bat to the Beltway
description: An unlikely message ricocheted across the blogosphere on Wednesday: Run, Carl, Run!

title: New Details Emerge About Morgan Stanley and Citi In the Crisis
description: Big banks like Citigroup and Morgan Stanley, which were battered by the 2008 financial crisis, are once again on solid ground.

title: In New California Gold Rush, Old Mines Reopen
description: SUTTER CREEK, Calif.  Standing in a cramped, slanted and slippery crevice some 500 feet below the earths surface, David Cochrane turned his eyes to a ribbon of marbled quartz  mainly gray, amber and white  and found the one hue he was actually looking for.

title: How to Make Your Google Account More Secure
description: We all know there are risks to storing personal information online, yet few of us take even the most basic precautions, like choosing unique and hard-to-guess passwords.

title: Sole Fed Governor With Close Ties to Conservatives Resigns
description: WASHINGTON  Kevin M. Warsh, who was the Federal Reserves chief liaison to Wall Street, will resign from the central banks board at the end of March, giving President Obama yet another chance to leave his stamp on the Fed.

title: What Were Reading
description: An aggregation of links by the reporters and editors of Diners Journal.

title: On Edge-Pushing Statistics and Climate Basics
description: Feb. 11, 3:40 p.m. | Updated Theres a young field at the interface of science and mathematics called spatial statistics. Its so new that its first international conference* is taking place next month in the Netherlands.

title: Arizonas Kyl Latest Senator to Retire
description: PHOENIX  Senator Jon Kyl of Arizona said Thursday that he would not run for re-election in 2012, a long-rumored announcement that will end a 25-year political career and prompt a fierce scramble to succeed him.

title: At Chicago Auto Show, Throaty V-8s and Man Vans
description: A blizzard that stranded hundreds of cars on Lake Shore Drive, followed by a series of subzero nights, might have left Chicago motorists vulnerable to dreams of summertime tire burnouts and top-down drag races. Automakers will gladly stoke those fantasies during the Chicago auto show, which will open to the public on Friday and run until Feb. 20.

title: Are Baby Boomers Ready to Exit Their Businesses?
description: Its official: as of Jan.1, the oldest of Americas baby boom generation started turning 65 at a rate of 10,000 a day  a trend that will last for the next 19 years. As articles like this one point out, the coming wave will mean big business for many industries. Many of us who offer financial services linked to retirement have been anticipating the day when the largest wealth transfer in our nations history officially begins.

title: Deconstructing Black Swan
description: The Baggers colleague and pal Alastair Macaulay, the chief dance critic of The New York Times, takes a stroll through Black Swan today, and finds a lot to talk about.

title: Options for Travelers Headed to Egypt
description: This was meant to be a banner year for Egyptian tourism. The ministry of tourism was anticipating more than 14 million visitors in 2011, a record. It was hardly unrealistic, considering that Egypt had 12.5 million visitors in 2009, and in the first nine months of 2010, despite the continuing global recession, had already seen 10.5 million visitors pass through the country.

title: A Witness Sees History Restaged and Rewritten
description: WHATS it like to watch your own experience turn up as grand opera: in my case, finding my reporting about Nixon in China suddenly evoked by the Metropolitan Operas production of John Adamss Nixon in China? Very weird. I kept imagining myself onstage in the prepositioned press crowd as Air Force One dropped from the sky in Beijing. And there I was again among the toasters clinking glasses that night at Chou En-lais banquet for the president.

title: Dish Network and EchoStar a Fit for AT&T, Report Says
description: As Dish Network expands its broadband spectrum, the satellite television provider is becoming an attractive target for AT&T, according to a Credit Suisse analyst report, released on Thursday.

title: Just Buy a Verizon iPhone? Here Are the Best Apps
description: So youve gotten a new iPhone on Verizons network. Mazel tov. For those new to the iPhone ecosystem, you may want to check out our many guides to the various apps available for your new smartphone.

title: Maximal Flavor for Minimal Cash
description: This week there are questions from visitors: some have a budget in mind, others are focusing on a celebration. As always, send your queries to dinejournal@nytimes.com.

title: Mens Fall Fashion 2011 | Gilded Age
description: Stefan Miljanic of Gilded Age brought his guys in from the cold for an urbane take on outdoorsy layering. Great washed and worn leather jackets, including one with a fur hood,topped hand-knitted patterned sweaters and denim jackets that were belted and worn with tucked-in jeans and boots. All of these looks could have easily walked right out of the presentation and onto the snowy streets, making them Lower East Side- and climate-appropriate.

title: Thursday Reading: The Marginal Cost of Children
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: Babcock Fumes as Listless Wings Fumble
description: The boos were hearty and clear Wednesday evening, as fans expressed their dissatisfaction with the Detroit Red Wings.

title: When Patients Share Their Stories, Health May Improve
description: A gifted artist in his early 60s, the patient was a liver transplant candidate who learned he had hepatitis B some 20 years earlier. Despite the worsening fatigue that accompanied his liver failure, he threw himself into preparing for his transplant. He read everything he could about the procedure and the postoperative care, drilled doctors with endless questions and continued to drag himself to the gym each day in the hopes of being better prepared to withstand the rigors of the operation.

title: Healing Through Storytelling
description: Todays Doctor and Patient column explores how storytelling can lead to better health. Dr. Pauline Chen writes:

title: Should Strollers Be Banned?
description: The story began in Halifax just after New Years, when a couple were told they could not board a city bus with their 6-month-old twin sons because their stroller was too big.

title: Theater Talkback: Good Glitch, Bad Glitch
description: The woman I was sharing a taxi with the other night, after a dinner party, told me that she would rather report from a high-risk combat zone than do what I do for a living. This, by the way, is a quintessentially urban woman who values highly her creature comforts. So what she was saying to me was that theater was, to her, a form of unspeakable torture.

title: Answers to Your Tax Questions
description: David Cay Johnstons article about the new tax law appears in todays Wealth special section. Below, his answers to questions submitted by readers.

title: Straight-Up Olive Oil Brownies
description: Without coconut, the brownies that I wrote about this week are more savory and exotic tasting, with a pronounced snappy bite. To make them, leave out the coconut, and instead of 3/4 cup olive oil, use 1/2 cup plus 2 tablespoons olive oil, plus 4 tablespoons melted butter. Make sure to sprinkle the top with a flaky sea salt like Maldon or fleur de sel, and be generous. Biting into a crunchy flake is the best part about these  next to the chocolate, that is.

title: Photo of the Week  Guess Where This Is
description: Last week, every reader who guessed the location of the Photo of the Week was correct. This week, were reviving the guessing game, but with fewer clues.

title: Fashion Week Drinking Game
description: Maybe its the curse of my nature, or the nature of my curse, but Im partial to a drink. I like to bend the elbow in much the same way that, say, Richard Burton liked the odd whiskey. So it should surprise exactly no one that I am also fond of drinking games. My favorite involves having a sip every time a character on a reality-TV show says the word journey. (Its become such a cliche that unless you have Burtons constitution, I recommend a sip instead of a shot.) As far as games go, its as elastic as a pair of Spanx and works equally well while watching the crimes against fabric on Project Runway or the unbeweavable hair donts on Hair Battle Spectacular. But real-life fashion people care more about instant gratification than the process. I suggest, then, that you turn to the person next to you, toast and gulp every time you see a ponytail on the runway or hear someone mention one of the following:

title: A Little Stress to Go With the Pixar Fun
description: If youve taken the behind-the-scenes tour of Pixar Animation or read about what its like to work there, you may think its a non-stop fun factory. We were googly-eyed pretty much the entire time we were there.

title: Ford Beats Ferrari in Name Dispute
description: Remember in 1991 when the Ferrari team dropped its world champion driver, Alain Prost, for calling the illustrious racing car a truck? Well, this year the team named the car after a truck  at least, that is what Ford Motor thinks.

title: Ford Beats Ferrari in Name Dispute
description: Remember in 1991 when the Ferrari team dropped its world champion driver, Alain Prost, for calling the illustrious racing car a truck? Well, this year the team named the car after a truck  at least, that is what Ford Motor thinks.

title: And the Winner Is  Anonymous
description: Saturday, 9:06 p.m. | Updated

title: Farewell (for Now) to Guitar Hero
description: LAS VEGAS Wednesday may be remembered as the day the music died in the video game business. While announcing its latest financial results, the big game publisher Activision Blizzard revealed that it would not release a Guitar Hero or DJ Hero game this year and that it was disbanding its Guitar Hero publishing division.

title: News Reports Say Cardinal Protected an Abuser
description: BRUSSELS  The sexual abuse crisis in the Roman Catholic Church in the Netherlands deepened Thursday when one of its senior figures was said to have shielded a pedophile priest.

title: Financial Planning: Invasive, Overpriced and Misplaced?
description: In the lead article in The Times special section on Wealth today, Paul Sullivan, the Wealth Matters columnist, takes a look at the trend toward more hands-on portfolio management by investors who are working with financial advisers.

title: Spousonomics
description: The application of economics to explore and improve relationships.

title: Consultant in City Fraud Case Pleads Guilty
description: One of four consultants who were charged with an $80 million scheme to steer city contracts for an automated employee timekeeping program to businesses they controlled pleaded guilty this week to bribery and other crimes, court records show, and is now cooperating with investigators.

title: Kitsch of the Day | Mandy Smiths I Just Cant Wait
description: Stripes are big this season, and few people wore them better than the English tween sensation Mandy Smith. For a short time in the mid-1980s, Smiths multitracked voice conquered the airwaves and she ruled European and Japanese teen magazine covers with her hyper-teased mane of blond hair, oversize shoulder pads, tiny waist and pouty Lolita looks. Her breakthrough single was I Just Cant Wait (her signature striped sweater appears at 0:39 in the video above), a fluffy tune about a love story against all odds produced by the 80s hitmeisters Stock Aitken Waterman.

title: Can You Outgrow A.D.H.D.? Or Get It as an Adult?
description: If you have attention deficit hyperactivity disorder, or A.D.H.D., as a child, do symptoms ease with age? Can you have adult-onset A.D.H.D.? These are among the questions recently posed by readers of the Consults blog.

title: 3-D Channels to Begin Broadcasting Full Time
description: Two 3-D television channels will start broadcasting full time in the next week.

title: A Quiet February
description: My already-intermittent blogging will cease for most of this month. Real posting will resume once Ive figured out how to successfully juggle punditry and fatherhood.

title: Updates to the Campaign Finance API
description: Political campaigns dont have an off-season, but the brief lull between last Novembers general election and now has given us time to make some updates to our Campaign Finance API. This round of changes focuses on additions to committee and filing responses, with particular emphasis on customizable collections of electronic filings and PAC contributions to candidates. Weve also added support for JSONP requests. And in saying hello to the 2012 election cycle, were saying goodbye to Version 2 of the API, so all users should now be using Version 3.

title: Gingrich Would Put Obama on Guest List
description: Newt Gingrich, the former Republican House speaker, called his partys 2010 midterm victories the appetizer and said 2012 is the entree in a speech to conservative activists on Thursday.

title: Possible Successors to Mubarak
description: Scott Shane, from The New York Times's Washington bureau, looks at leaders who could succeed President Hosni Mubarak.

title: For Oil Exec, an Electric Car Can Wait
description: There sure is a lot of excitement percolating around plug-in hybrid and electric cars these days. Chevrolets Volt and Nissans Leaf are the talk of the car world, city governments are installing battery chargers, and the Obama administration has promoted them. Even the TV commercials for the battery chargers are cool.

title: Stroke Rising Among Young People
description: More young people and adults in their 30s and 40s are being hospitalized for stroke, even as stroke rates are dropping in older people, new data show.

title: Irish Eyes Not Smiling Over Bloomberg Remark
description: The gathering was meant to be a carefree celebration of the citys St. Patricks Day Parade. But it took a different tone when Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg made some off-the-cuff remarks.

title: Defying Crowds, Mubarak Refuses to Step Down
description: In a televised address, President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt said that he would not step down, surprising demonstrators who had gathered to hail his departure.

title: Second Super Bowl Sponsor Revises Spot
description: Madison Avenues post-Super Bowl apology tour is continuing as a second advertiser has made changes to the commercial it ran during the game on Sunday.

title: Passion Prompts: Sentence Starters for Writing About Relationships
description: Love may be a many splendored thing, but its not always easy to write about. In honor of Valentines Day, we thought wed offer some sentence starters to help.

title: Fashion Week Video | Casting Call
description: For every breakout runway star there are hundreds of aspirants each season. In this video above, Greg Kessler  the photographer of Model-morphosis, our popular interactive beauty feature  drops in on the casting director Natalie Joos and turns the spotlight on some of the new faces who are hoping that this will be their moment.

title: Yahoo Opens a Digital Newsstand
description: Yahoo on Thursday announced the debut of Livestand, a publishing platform that aims to deliver personalized content to mobile devices. As The New York Times first reported on Sunday, the platform, a digital newsstand, will offer a continuous stream of programming based on users interests. Yahoo plans to push the platform across multiple formats, including tablets, smartphones, and Web browsers, according to the companys press release.

title: Waze iPhone App Crowd-Sources Info on Road Hazards
description: If you ever harbored ambitions of being a traffic reporter, heres your chance.

title: SXSW After Dark
description: What do a skateboarding hedgehog, a video game dance whiz, a right-wing Argentinean terrorist, an alien-fighting teen gang and a hobo (with a shotgun) have in common? Theyll all be wreaking havoc in Austin, Tex. next month as part of South by Southwests midnight features lineup. Fantastic Fest, the fall film festival that has become known for its wild genre programming, will present a series called SXFantastic. Included in that lineup is The FP, which turns the popular video game Dance Dance Revolution (here dubbed Beat-Beat Revelation) into an all-out turf war.

title: Bucks Pay for Off-Season Spree Sooner Than Expected
description: After surging in the second half of the 2009-10 season and making a somewhat unexpected trip to the playoffs, the Milwaukee Bucks looked to improve their roster in the most straightforward way possible. They had a woeful lack of free throw attempts, so General Manager John Hammond traded some roster fodder for Corey Maggette, who has made a career out of consistently getting to the line. They were below average in offensive rebounding, so Hammond signed Drew Gooden, a proven glass cleaner. Then, in an effort to take two steps forward without taking that dreaded step back, Hammond locked up John Salmons, who had been so crucial to the Bucks march into the postseason.

title: Obama Unveils Wireless Expansion Plan
description: MARQUETTE, Mich.  Declaring that we cant expect tomorrows economy to take root using yesterdays infrastructure, President Obama traveled to this snowbound town in a remote corner of Michigan on Thursday to make the case that expanding wireless access is critical to the nations economic recovery.

title: The Art of Dating in New York City
description: Using the city as his canvas, Eric V. Copage offers mini-adventure dating ideas.

title: So What is Hu Jintao Thinking Now?
description: As I prepare to watch Hosni Mubarak give his speech, Im wondering what Chinese President Hu Jintao of China is thinking these days. Tahrir Square today is so reminiscent of Tiananmen Square in 1989, which I also covered  although it looks as if the ending will be different (touch wood).

title: Busy Tonight? I Know a Nice Subway Ride...
description: MY date and I had perused the Brooklyn Flea and were on the Q train heading back to Manhattan for a snack. As the subway rumbled toward the Manhattan Bridge, I saw from the corner of my eye a colorful flicker on the tunnel wall.

title: Tis Nobler to Dive in Front of a Train? Discuss
description: In The Sunset Limited, an HBO film directed by Tommy Lee Jones and starring Mr. Jones and Samuel L. Jackson, two men are locked in a room but have almost nothing in common save their time together. In the movie, based on the play by Cormac McCarthy, White, Mr. Joness character, is a college professor at the end of the line, a man so pummeled by despair that he attempts to throw himself in front of a train driven by ... Black, a redeemed, religious ex-convict played by Mr. Jackson. White is brought back to Blacks spare New York tenement, and they commence a mortal, desperate debate about the value of life and whether ending it  taking the Sunset Limited  is a valid choice given the amount of misery and alienation that can go hand in hand with everyday existence.

title: Exchange Mergers Raise Question of Whos Next
description: 8:46 p.m. | Updated

title: The Ethics of Free Cellphone Calls
description: When I last wrote about the quest to get free phone calls forever, a number of readers wrote to point out a very sneaky trick that lets you achieve that frugal heaven  even from your cellphone. Yes, its a way to get free cellphone calls, without listening to an ad, without being in Wi-Fi, without using any minutes.

title: Fashion Week Parties: amfAR Turns 25
description: A galaxy of stars turned kicked off New York Fashion Week last night at the Foundation for AIDS Research event at Cipriani Wall Street.

title: No More Looking Backward: Professor Has Camera Removed From His Head
description: The New York University professor who had a camera inserted in the back of his head as part of an art project was forced to remove part of the camera on Friday because his body had rejected it, the Chronicle of Higher Education reported. The camera was to take a photograph every minute as the professor, Wafaa Bilal, went about his day. The project, which raised privacy concerns at the university, was called The 3rd I, and was organized by a new Qatari museum called Mathaf: Arab Museum of Modern Art. According to the Chronicle, the device, which was installed by a body modification artist in a tattoo shop in Los Angeles, was originally mounted on three posts that were attached to a titanium plate implanted between Mr. Bilals skin and his skull. But Mr. Bilals body rejected one of the posts, despite treatment with antibiotics and steroids, and he was in constant pain. So on Friday he had the post removed. While the wound heals, he is tying the camera to the back of his neck. Why didnt he do that in the first place? Its a performance, he told the Chronicle. With the performance comes endurance. But also its a commitment. And I didnt feel that strapping something around my neck would be the same.

title: A Winning Slogan for the History Books?
description: To the long list of presidential slogans  the New Deal (F.D.R.), the New Frontier (J.F.K.) and the Great Society (L.B.J. )  we can now officially append Winning the Future.

title: Press Aides Name Floated for Congress
description: With the sudden resignation of Representative Chris Lee of New York, Democrats are floating an interesting name as a potential candidate to replace him: Bill Burton, a deputy press secretary at the White House.

title: Photos of the Moment | BCBG Max Azria
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#223", 592, 490, true, chameleonData);

title: Rare Portrait of the People Who Keep the City Clean
Explosion in Pennsylvania
description: A blast sparked by an apparent natural gas leak left at least five dead. Jawaidhi Cox of Allentown filmed the fire with her cell phone.

title: Buzz Tracker
description: Googles Schmidt Sees Bubble  Google has made 87 acquisitions worth $8.4 billion in the last 10 years, but the recent high valuations placed on some high-profile Internet companies has Eric Schmidt scratching his head. There are clear signs of a bubble, Mr. Schmidt told the Swiss magazine Bilanz. But valuations are what they are. Reuters (For those DealBook readers who read German  or who perhaps those who will work at the New York Stock Exchange  heres a link to Bilanz.)

title: Wheelies: Geneva Calling Edition
description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

title: Galleon Founder Objects to Evidence
description: Lawyers for Raj Rajaratnam  the billionaire founder of the Galleon Group facing insider trading charges  are objecting to some evidence they expect the government to present at trial in early March.

title: Pogues Posts: The Ethics of Free Calls
description: David Pogue discusses on his blog a very sneaky trick that lets you make free phone calls from your cellphone, a way to get free cellphone calls, without listening to an ad, without being in Wi-Fi, without using any minutes. He writes:

title: Less Hopes to Be More at Williamstown Theater Festival
description: Williamstown Theater Festival has announced three mainstage productions for summer 2011: a Broadway-bound revival of Moss Hart and George S. Kaufmans You Cant Take It With You, directed by Christopher Ashley; Oliver Goldsmiths Restoration comedy She Stoops to Conquer, directed by Nicholas Martin; and Ten Cents a Dance, a celebration of the songs of Rodgers and Hart, directed by John Doyle.

title: Second Day of N.F.L. Labor Meetings Canceled
description: Efforts to jump-start N.F.L. labor talks seem to have stalled just days after the owners and players promised to work harder to reach a deal before the collective bargaining agreement expires on March 3.

title: WikiLeaks Angry About Ex-Staff Members Book
description: LONDON  WikiLeaks said it is taking legal action over a tell-all book to be released Friday by a former staffer that is critical of its founder, Julian Assange, and says the Web site was disabled by a spate of defections last year.

title: House Tour: Piermont, N.Y.
description: A house for sale in the tiny downtown of Piermont, N.Y., was once a fire station and has a balcony with Hudson River views.

title: House Tour: Piermont, N.Y.
Vonns Racing Plans Uncertain After Concussion
description: Lindsey Vonn has crashed many times in her nearly 20 years of ski racing. But since falling last week in training  she was flipped backward, the back of her head smacking the hard snow  she has entered the murky world of concussions, and it has left her uncertain in the middle of the biggest races of the year, the world ski championships.

title: New Nikons for Dark and for Distance
description: Nikon just released the specifications on eight new cameras, many with upgrades from existing models, but two with notable advances.

title: Piling On at Richard Chai
description: Fashion Week started in earnest this morning with Richard Chais 11 a.m. show, and the mood in the audience seemed a tad impatient. There was such a short gap between the prefall collections and the fall collections this year that this Fashion Week is running the risk of feeling tired before it begins.

title: The Pharaoh Refuses to Go
description: 7:33 p.m. | Updated with video.

title: Time-Warped at Vena Cava
description: The preshow music at Vena Cava was blaring  you couldnt talk to the person sitting next to you  so there wasnt much to do during the wait except read the cute magazine that the designers, Lisa Mayock and Sophie Buhai, had left along the seats. It was called Zina Cava. Heh, heh.

title: Trump Tells Conservative Audience Hes Presidential Material
description: Donald Trump wanted the crowd of activists at the Conservative Political Action Committee to know just who he thinks has the skills, smarts and guts to be president: Donald Trump, of course.

title: Neighborhood Joint | Babycastles
description: An independent video game arcade in Ridgewood, Queens, with a low-fi, do-it-yourself aesthetic.

title: Notes to Lady Hamilton, Who Drove Admiral Nelson Wild
description: Emma Hamilton preserved a paper trail of her love affairs. As a teenager in the 1780s, she was passed around as a mistress among British aristocrats, and is perhaps most famous for running off to a London suburb with Adm. Horatio Nelson while they were each married to other people.

title: Brooklyn Museum Experiments With First Impressions
description: Ever since she read Malcolm Gladwells 2005 best seller, Blink: The Power of Thinking Without Thinking, Shelley Bernstein has been pondering ways to use what she learned about the impact of first impressions. As the chief of technology at the Brooklyn Museum, she was specifically interested in marrying the wisdom of the museums loyal Web followers with the more conventional knowledge of a curator.

title: Lincoln Moves
description: With this post, Disunion begins two weeks of daily reporting on the historic railroad journey of President-elect Abraham Lincoln, as he traveled from Springfield, Ill., to assume the presidency in Washington, D.C.

title: An Arcade to Make Gamers Cry
description: ON my first visit to Babycastles, an independent arcade in Queens, I watched as two young women explained to a friend the rules of a video game. It didnt involve fighting, special moves or guns, but it was full of big-headed cartoon characters wandering through a jewel-toned landscape.

title: Workers at Rest: Smoking and Playing Cards
description: Czannes Card Players, at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, sounds like a show for our high-stakes moment. But the real appeal of this mini-blockbuster is its modest vision of a rural pastime, rendered with infinite patience. The big players who dominate the art world today would have a hard time identifying with Czannes peasants and laborers: men quietly passing the time, happy enough with the hand that life has dealt them.

title: Court Revives Suit Over Blackstone I.P.O.
description: A Federal Court of Appeals reinstated a lawsuit that accuses the Blackstone Group of inadequately disclosing information in its initial public offering documents  claims that echo an oft-heard criticism about the opaque business results of publicly traded private equity firms.

title: Effort to Provide TV Ratings by Brand Moves Ahead
description: For decades, advertisers and agencies involved in advertising on television  meaning, practically all of Madison Avenue  have been seeking something their counterparts overseas have long had: brand-specific ratings, or the ability to track TV ratings on a commercial-by-commercial basis.

title: Want a New York Landmark? Act Now!
description: And so it has come to this: Trading begins not with the customary ringing of the bell, but with the blast of a French horn. Pierre squints at the big board, yanks off his beret and shouts  vendre!  vendre! (Sell! Sell!). Outside on Wall Street, the steakhouses, cigar bars and elite private clubs stand empty, as brokers and traders stream into beer halls for steins of pilsner and plates of hot schnitzel.

title: Calculating the Annual Percentage Rate
description: THE lending industry has tried to make it easier for borrowers to understand the true cost of a mortgage by disclosing both its interest rate and its annual percentage rate, or A.P.R. But consumers may often wonder which figure they should focus on when buying or refinancing a property.

title: 2011 Oscar-Nominated Shorts
description: Images from the films nominated in the three shorts categories for the Academy Awards.

title: Egypt: The Cultural Revolution
description: The festive protests that broke out on Jan. 25 in Cairos Tahrir Square have become a window into what Egypt might look and sound like without the regime of Hosni Mubarak. Tahrirs troubadour collective has specialized in the invention of slogans that are witty, abusive and aimed directly at the president, e.g., Mubarak, you rhinoceros (kharteet), / get out, get out, you pest (ghateet). Sometimes, perhaps to signal a certain gravitas, they dispense with rhyme and say it straight: The people want the fall of the regime. Along with the chanting, there has been much baladi music  a catchy, popular style, heavy on hooks and reverb  as well as poetry recitations and effigy hanging. This is Egypts folk culture: profane, bawdy, politically sophisticated. It stands as a direct challenge to the version of culture propagated by the Mubarak regime and its predecessors.

title: Exhibit Designer Chosen for Museum of African American History and Culture
description: The National Museum of African American History and Culture, the new Smithsonian museum set to open in 2015, has chosen a designer for its exhibitions. The museum has hired Ralph Appelbaum Associates, whose past projects include the United States Holocaust Memorial Museum, the William J. Clinton Presidential Center, several major permanent exhibitions at the American Museum of Natural History and the U.S. Capitol Visitor Center. In a conversation earlier this week, the museums director, Lonnie G. Bunch III, said that Mr. Appelbaum had brought together a group of young, culturally diverse designers to work on the project. The Smithsonian will pay Mr. Appelbaums firm roughly $3 million to design of the museums planned 82,000 square feet of exhibition space.

title: Victims Who Deserve Their Fate
description: The securities laws of the United States substitute a philosophy of disclosure for the philosophy of caveat emptor, Justice Arthur Goldberg wrote in a Supreme Court decision nearly half a century ago.

title: An Innocent Abroad, at a Convention in Iowa
description: Everythings up to date in Cedar Rapids, which not only has skyscrapers, but also a hotel with a pool sparkling in the atrium like a blue diamond. For Tim Lippe (rhymes with yippee), the 34-year-old naf at the center of this wistful, equally tender and raunchy comedy of self-discovery, also called Cedar Rapids, the hotel and the pool signal that hes reached the big time. What he cant yet know is that by entering the hotel, having guilelessly said no to the friendly neighborhood prostitute outside, he has crossed a Rubicon. Hes on his way to a moral awakening in a story laced with Oedipal overtones and giddy with longing and smut.

title: Spare Times for Feb. 11-17
description: Around Town

title: More Figures From the Police Watchdog
description: In the news business, timing and freshness are everything. It was just a week ago that the Civilian Complaint Review Board trumpeted the news that complaints against city police officers had dropped 18 percent for the first half of 2010  figures that were widely reported, debated and analyzed.

title: A Move in the Direction of More Life
description: THOUGH Anne Bauso grew up in Middle Village, Queens, she was always fond of Brooklyn. Her parents were from Bushwick, and on Saturdays she went there with her father and brother, visiting the extended family and shopping for food in the Italian section of Knickerbocker Avenue. I had very warm feelings for Brooklyn from the start, she said.

title: Spare Times: For Children, for Feb. 11-17
description: Miss Nelson Is Missing!

title: Hospitals Shift Smoking Bans to Smoker Ban
description: Smokers now face another risk from their habit: it could cost them a shot at a job.

title: Schools Use Celebrity Wake-Up Calls to Battle Truancy
description: If the phone rings one morning and you hear a cheery good morning from Magic Johnson on the other end of the line or the R&B singer Trey Songz telling you to get your education, dont hang up and roll over, bury yourself under your blanket and go back to sleep. This is no prank call. Its the citys latest attempt to get students who persistently skip class to start showing up more often.

title: Classical Music/Opera Listings for Feb. 11-17
description: Classical

title: Farewell Tour Brings Jackson to the Garden
description: BOSTON  Phil Jackson can tell you about Madison Square Gardens eccentricities, about the way the floor sometimes jumps when the crowd reaches a fever pitch.

title: A Weekend in Brooklyn, New York
description: Brooklyn, New York Citys most populous borough, is a destination in its own right.

title: 36 Hours in Brooklyn
description: THE Brooklyn Cruise Terminal on the Buttermilk Channel has picturesque views even when the Queen Mary 2, which docks there regularly, is at sea. There is verdant Governors Island across the water and, behind it , the heaving, jagged rise of Manhattan. To the north are the great bridges of the East River. To the west, the Statue of Liberty. And to the east, beyond chain link and forbidding streets, there is Brooklyn itself, New York Citys most populous borough, a destination in its own right.

title: Back Then, a Mans World of Loyalty and Adventure
description: The Eagle, a solemn and muscle-bound tale of valor and brutality on the northern fringes of the Roman Empire, treads the boundary between old school and retrograde. Following a Roman military commanders lonely mission to retrieve the golden bird of the title, the movie, directed by Kevin Macdonald, plays less like a 1950s Technicolor sword-and-sandal epic than like a western of the same era, but with foggier visuals and skimpier political and sexual subtext. Lumbering along for a bit less than two hours, which passes like three, it feels more like a chore than like an adventure.

title: Top Gear Is Renewed for Second Season
description: Despite a lukewarm initial reception, the American version of Top Gear, which airs Sunday nights on the History cable channel, has been renewed for a second season, Jalopnik has reported.

title: Museum and Gallery Listings for Feb. 11-17
description: Art

title: DealBook Portraits: Gary Gensler
description: Gary Gensler, Commodity Futures Trading Commission chairman, left Goldman Sachs after 18 years to join government. He is now a key figure in the Obama administration's efforts to regulate Wall Street.

title: Pictures of the Day: Egypt and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Egypt, Somalia, France and India

title: Arizona Sues Federal Government for Failing to Enforce Immigration
description: 8:41 p.m. | Updated PHOENIXStriking back at the Obama administration, Gov. Jan Brewer of Arizona said Thursday that she will raise private funds to counter-sue the federal government for failing to enforce immigration laws.

title: Tyson Settles U.S. Charges of Bribery
description: When top executives of Tyson Foods discovered that the companys Mexican chicken plants were paying bribes to government inspectors, they not only allowed the practice to continue, they formed a committee to find a more acceptable way to make the illicit payments, according to federal court documents released on Thursday.

title: Consider an Apple, Consider the World
description: The women and few men sitting at their desks in the film Poetry have open faces and smiles. Theyre good pupils, these older people who have come to the cultural center to learn. Perhaps because they have chosen to be there, they dont have the look of sullen resentment and cultivated boredom that glazes the faces of the high school students glimpsed now and again. Instead these latter-day bards gaze at the man who has come to say something to them about art and maybe life. Instead he holds up an apple and talks about seeing.

description: Movies

description: Egypts Supreme Council of the Armed Forces statements and key leaders

title: Harsh Course to Test Skiers in Mens Downhill
description: GARMISCH-PARTENKIRCHEN, Germany  If the super-G on the exceedingly bumpy, shady and highly demanding Kandahar piste was any indication, the worlds elite speed skiers are surely in for an even more rigorous test Saturday when the downhill is contested at the world ski championships.

title: How Do You Feel About Dining on the Cheap?
description: In his State of the Art column in Thursdays Times, David Pogue writes about Groupon and its deep-discount coupon offers  Internet-organized group buying, as Groupon calls it. A host of questions arise in this matter. Here are a few:

description: Pop

title: At Center of Derivatives Debate, a Gung-Ho Regulator
description: WASHINGTON  Gary Gensler has his work cut out for him.

title: Dance Listings for Feb. 11-17.
description: Dance

title: The Other Valentines Day
description: Indifferent, hurt, on the run or dumped? Too busy, too gloomy, too independent, too guilt-ridden, too too? What are we supposed to do on Valentines Day: crawl into bed and weep into our Kindle covers? Not all of us are ready to whip out the flowers and chocolate or snuggle up over a mortgage-size bottle of Champagne and some celebrity chefs five course tasting. In fact, Valentines Day as packaged by the Valentine industry is a big to-do for the very few  the happily mated, romantically inclined and reasonably solvent. Which is why we need the Other Valentines Day, a day of celebration for those who would rather not celebrate romance right about now. At least not that way. Here is a gift list for us.

title: Jazz Listings for Feb. 11-17
description: Jazz

title: Theater Listings: Feb. 11  17
description: Theater

title: "Rachmaninoff's Second Concerto" Performed by Lang Lang
description: Listen to an excerpt of "Rachmaninoff's Second Concerto" performed by Lang Lang with the Orchestra of the Maryinsky Theater in St. Petersburg, conducted by Valery Gergiev.

title: J. D. Salinger: A Life
description: In the opening lines of The Catcher in the Rye, Holden Caulfield refuses to share his parents past with the reader, deriding any recount of how they were occupied and all before they had me, and all that David Copperfield kind of crap. My parents, he explains, would have about two hemorrhages apiece if I told anything pretty personal about them. This apparent elusiveness on the part of Holdens parents was imported directly from the attitudes of Salingers own mother and father. Sol and Miriam rarely spoke of past events, especially to their children, and their attitude created an air of secrecy that permeated the Salinger household and caused Doris and Sonny to grow into intensely private people.

title: A Night of High Drama in Cairo
description: To the Editor:

title: The Social Network Takes the Top Prize at London Film Critics Circle Awards
description: Tut tut: the worlds most English film did not sweep the London Critics Circle Film Awards. Instead The Social Network took the top prize over The Kings Speech, and it won best director (David Fincher) and best screenwriter (Aaron Sorkin) to boot. In what could be cold comfort to Londoners, Andrew Garfield won best British actor in a supporting role  for playing a Brazilian-American Harvard student in The Social Network.

title: Iraq Tells Refugees in Egypt and Yemen: Well Pay You to Return
description: BAGHDAD  As unrest shakes Egypt, Iraq is seizing the moment to make an audacious pitch to thousands of its citizens living abroad: Come back  were stable by comparison.

title: Pictures of the Day: Egypt and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Egypt, Somalia, France and India

title: When Picasso Changed His Tune
description: Its 1912, and Pablo Picasso is in Paris, thinking: All right, whats next?

title: A Potential Hazard of Electronic Keys
description: CONCERN over the implications of a 2006 revision to a federal safety standard is spurring regulators at the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration to reconsider their change. At issue is whether the change, which redefined what constitutes a cars ignition key, has effectively increased the possibility of accidents caused by a vehicle rolling away.

title: A Single Brownstone Remains Between 62nd and 63rd
description: YOU can barely see it now, the little 1871 brownstone at 815 Fifth Avenue, concealed by construction netting. Indeed, all its peers have vanished, too, although those were lost to the wreckers ball. This block of Fifth, between 62nd and 63rd Streets, had the earliest town house on Fifth Avenue opposite Central Park, and its thumbnail biography paints a picture of Fifth as a street of single, not multiple, dwellings.

title: An Oscar Film Festival, All in One Screening
description: In addition to the 10 candidates for best picture and the smattering of contenders in other major categories, there are 15 movies whose titles will be mentioned at the Oscars on Feb. 27 that very few nonvoters are likely to have heard of. These are the nominees for best short film, which are divided into three groups: animated, live action and documentary. In the past, opportunities to see the shorts were scarce, but lately they have been showing up in theaters and also on iTunes and cable.

title: Its the Craftsman, Not the Singer or the Song
description: Guitar Heroes, an exceptionally interesting exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, has nothing to do with the video game that enables nonmusicians to imagine themselves playing like rock stars. The heroes here are three craftsmen known for producing some of the most sought-after jazz guitars of the last seven decades: John DAngelico (1905-1964), James DAquisto (1935-95) and John Monteleone (born 1947).

title: Inside the List
description: BRAVE NEW WORLD: The Hidden Reality is the title of the latest mind-bender by the physicist Brian Greene, which enters the hardcover nonfiction list at No. 4. But it could also describe the strange new vistas on the publishing multiverse opened up by the redesigned best-seller lists, which make their debut this week. In addition to the familiar hardcover and paperback lists, this column will now have two entirely new sets of rankings to ponder. The e-book list tracks the top fiction and nonfiction titles available across a range of e-reader platforms. And the combined list ranks the titles that readers are clamoring for in all formats: e-book, hardcover, trade paperback, mass-market paperback.

title: Turning the Grammys Into an Interactive Event
description: LOS ANGELES

title: Plot Twist? If Viewers Say So, Let It Be
description: THOUGH they both had good reasons for being there, Al Gore and Will Wright seemed somewhat out of place at Current TVs presentation for the news media on Wednesday morning. Maybe it was the cramped space of the presentation room at the Paley Center for Media, the vintage photographs of John Lennon that hung on the wall or the sound of AC/DCs Back in Black blaring from the sound system.

title: Keeping Score: The Story Arc of the 3-Point Shot
description: Justin Kubatko is the creator of Basketball-Reference.com, an online basketball encyclopedia. He is also a statistical consultant for the Portland Trail Blazers.

title: Modernism From a World in Convulsion
description: There are pros and cons to The Great Upheaval: Modern Art From the Guggenheim Collection, 1910-1918 at the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum. It exemplifies a museum trying to make the most of its permanent collection, combining fiscal sense with in-house creativity. Money is tight, and collections are often roomy, full of underexposed artwork awaiting the illumination of curatorial insight. This is a good thing.

title: First Round of Republican Cuts
description: This is a preliminary list of cuts proposed by Republicans on the House Appropriations Committee for the rest of the fiscal year ending Sept. 30.

title: A Ray of Sunshine for ABC
description: Mr. Sunshine, ABCs new sitcom with Matthew Perry, made a promising start on Wednesday, even as Foxs American Idol and its round of San Francisco auditions led the night with 23.7 million viewers, according to Nielsens estimates. The new ABC comedy drew 10.6 million viewers and delivered ABCs best ratings of the season for a series premiere in the demographic of adults 18 to 49. The show benefited from a time slot following Modern Family, which earned 13.1 million viewers at 9 p.m., as well as from not having to compete directly opposite Idol, which trounced ABCs sitcoms in the 8 p.m. hour, The Middle (8.8 million) and Better With You (6.8 million). ABC ranked third over all, struggling at 10 with Off the Map (5.6 million), while CBS trailed Fox in second place with strong results for Criminal Minds (14.3 million) and Blue Bloods (12.5 million).

title: Japanese Isle in Sea of Contention Weighs Fist Versus Open Hand
description: YONAGUNI ISLAND, Japan  This remote island in the rough East China Sea is known for its gigantic moths, fiery Okinawan alcohol and an offshore rock formation that some believe to be the submerged ruins of a lost, Atlantis-like civilization.

title: Pointed Choreography, Rooted in South Africa
description: The South African choreographer Robyn Orlin has a long history of annoying people, but from talking to her, you would never know it. She is candid to a fault, thoughtful and rather adorably scattered. Her e-mails are filled with exclamation marks and signed with xs, denoting kisses. And yet Ms. Orlin, 55, has long been one of her countrys most provocative artists, a white woman from the comfortable Johannesburg suburbs fearlessly confronting the truths and myths of a complex political and social history.

title: By the Water, but Down to Earth
description: ON a recent frigid day, crusty snow covered the deck of a boat named Paradox, docked at the Halloween Yacht Club in Shippan Point, a section of Stamford that juts into Long Island Sound.

title: Weekend Miser
description: Do you really want to go with that same old candy-and-flowers routine this week? Here are some different takes on love that wont take it out on your credit card.

title: LEE LOZANO: Tools
description: Hauser & Wirth

title: Astoria, Queens, 4:58 P.M.
description: Patrons at the El Khayam Hooka Lounge watched President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt tell the nation  and the world  he was not stepping down.

description: Knoedler & Company

title: PATRICK JACOBS: Familiar Terrain
description: Pierogi

title: IMAGES FROM A FLOATING WORLD: 18th & 19th Century Japanese Erotic Prints and the Echo in Modern and Contemporary Art
description: Fredericks & Freiser Gallery

title: Abstract and Fluid Jazz
description: Back when the Wayne Shorter Quartet made its first tour, in 2001, it sometimes gave the impression of holding back. It seemed infinitely elastic, as if its members could theoretically push the music far into abstraction and still make sense but that they preferred to work within limits.

title: Mario Cuomo to Mediate Mets-Madoff Case
description: A federal judge on Thursday appointed former New York Governor Mario M. Cuomo to try to resolve the $1 billion dispute between the owners of the Mets and the trustee representing victims of Bernard L. Madoffs financial fraud.

title: Warming Up to a Cold Run
description: DREAD. Thats the first word that pops into my head when I think about running in the winter. But its quickly followed by fat, a fate I would like to avoid. When I was a child, my mother had to buy me clothes in husky sizes. In my 20s I maxed out at about 220 pounds. These days, just shy of the big 4-0, Im about 165, but the psychology of having been overweight remains, so keeping up with exercise, particularly in winter, is important.

title: Kinder Morgan Shares Rise on Debut
description: Friday, 4:25 p.m. | Updated

title: In China, Tentative Steps Toward Global Currency
description: SHANGHAI  Now that it has passed Japan to become the worlds second-largest economy after the United States, China is considering the next step as a world power: making its money a global currency.

title: PayPal Will Play an Even Bigger Role at eBay
description: Hoping to counter concerns that their business has become an online has-been, eBay executives on Thursday laid out plans to restore its luster over the next three years.

title: Hosni Mubarak's Speech
description: President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt addressed the Egyptian people on state television on Thursday, announcing that he will remain in office until September and hand off some duties to his vice president, Omar Suleiman.

title: Republican Leaders Yield to a Push for More Budget Cuts
description: WASHINGTON  House Republican leaders said Thursday that they would accede to demands from conservatives and dig deeper into the federal budget for billions of dollars in additional savings this year, exhibiting the power of the Tea Party movement and increasing chances of a major fiscal clash with Democrats.

title: Readers Weigh in on Efforts to Track Races
description: An increasingly multiracial nation strives to get a better portrait of its people, and, in many ways, it is successful in gathering more information. But it also sows some confusion in the process, perhaps making it harder for researchers to detect racial and ethnic injustice.

title: Lynda Benglis
description: The artists work is the subject of a retrospective at the New Museum.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,461 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American on Thursday:
