description: Jonathan Klinger is driving his 1930 Model A Ford for a year as his regular transportation.

title: Bypass the Bookstore: Fiske Guide Goes iPad
Keep Your Government Hands Off My Government Programs!
description: In a smart column today, Bruce Bartlett looks at why it will be so hard for politicians to cut government spending: because so many Americans who say they support cutting government programs dont realize just how much they benefit from them.

title: An Ebert Cheat Sheet for Your Oscar Pool
description: If youre already filling out your New York Times interactive Oscar ballot, and need a cheat sheet, check out Roger Eberts picks. An illustrious critic and Twitter maestro, Mr. Ebert has posted his choices for every category, from short documentary to best picture, and he, too, thinks it will be a near sweep for The Kings Speech, even in categories like best supporting actor and best score. Personally, though, he preferred The Social Network. (It was not only the best film of 2010, but also one of those films that helps define a year, he writes.)

title: Level Global to Close, Hurt by Link to Insider Case
description: 8:22 p.m. | Updated

title: New Track Surface a Wild Variable at Daytona 500
description: The Nascar Sprint Cup Series opens its 36-race schedule on Feb. 20 with its premier event, the Daytona 500. This years race may turn out a little different  meaning, a little more exciting  than past runnings.

title: Q & A: Philip-Lorca diCorcia
description: On Thursday night, at the start of Fashion Week, several hundred people came to the David Zwirner Gallery to see an exhibition of Philip-Lorca diCorcias photographs. Originally published in W magazine, between 1997 and 2008, the images are a remarkable record of a free-spirited period in publishing that seemed to come to an end with the recession and, as well, the Internet. They speak directly to the eye of Mr. diCorcia, with their capacity to excite and disturb, and to seek truth about human behavior in the most banal of scenes. These photographs were also the result of a fortuitous collaboration between Mr. diCorcia and Dennis Freedman, the former art director of W, who gave the artist carte blanche to shoot fashion stories in places like Havana, Cairo and New York. They have collected all 11 shoots in a new book, Eleven (Damiani Editions).

title: Mass Effect 2 Takes Top Prize at Interactive Achievement Awards
description: LAS VEGAS  In an upset victory for Electronic Arts and its BioWare studio, the science-fiction adventure Mass Effect 2 won game of the year here on Thursday evening at the 14th annual Interactive Achievement Awards ceremony. Voted on by members of the video-game industry under the auspices of the Academy of Interactive Arts & Sciences, the Interactive Achievement Awards are the most prestigious in video games and are the industrys equivalent of the Oscars. The awards are announced each year at the academys DICE conference, which stands for Design, Innovate, Communicate, Entertain.

title: Give the City Your Thoughts on Livery-Cab Proposals
description: Should livery cabs be allowed to pick up street hails in the boroughs outside Manhattan? The city wants your opinion.

title: With C-Max, Ford Plans a Comeback for the Tall, Small Wagon
description: WHETHER its called a small minivan or a tall wagon or a people mover or a multipurpose vehicle, the basic idea behind the redesigned 2012 Mazda 5 is one that has long been popular with manufacturers. But in North America at least, it hasnt been all that popular among actual customers.

title: Bei Gaotie
description: Chinese phrase for being forced to take expensive high-speed trains.(Bei is a Chinese character indicating a passive voice;Gaotie means high-speed train.)

title: Spill Commissioners Call for Review of Energy Policy
description: Two members of President Obamas commission on the Deepwater Horizon explosion and spill said at a Congressional hearing on Friday that regulatory failures and industry overconfidence helped lead to the catastrophe and called for an overhaul of federal oversight of offshore drilling and a transition to safer, cleaner forms of energy.

title: Fun Stuff
description: Since January 2004, when this column first appeared, the American consumer zeitgeist has evolved. Some argue, in fact, that a decisive change has occurred, and that a result of the wrenching economic downturn is that we just dont care about stuff anymore. I suspect this conclusion is rash. There are, however, interesting traces in the culture that suggest somewhat more subtle shifts  attempts, perhaps, to reconcile the more virtuously possession-resistant stance that some now strike with the stubborn reality that, ultimately, people really like stuff.

title: When Med Students Post Patient Pictures
description: Some of my Facebook friends are medical students who post cellphone pictures of patients with what these friends believe to be comical maladies, with captions like A 5-foot-9 Hispanic male walks into a bar . . . under a picture of a patient with a piece of rebar piercing his abdomen. The postings dont include faces or names but still seem questionable. Doesnt this violate patient privacy? NAME WITHHELD, NEW YORK

title: Photos of the Moment | Vena Cava
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#693", 592, 440, true, chameleonData);

title: On Peer Review and (Climate) Progress
description: Louis A. Derry, a Cornell researcher and the editor of the journal Geochemistry, Geophysics, Geosystems, provides a valuable look inside the peer review process in a comment on my piece assessing the debate over Antarctic temperature trends. It merits space here as a Your Dot contribution (a feature aimed at encouraging constructive non-anonymous discussions).

title: Friday Reading: Refunds for Planned Travel to Egypt
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: A Hatchet Man Stands Up for Mad Men
description: If youre among the devoted viewers of Mad Men who read Daniel Mendelsohns recent takedown of that period drama in The New York Review of Books with tears in your eyes and your hands clenching into fists, it may satisfy you to learn that another man of letters has fired back at Mr. Mendelsohn and his articulate evisceration of the show. And that man isDale Peck?

title: Morgans Hotels to Offer a Minibar Stocked With Conversation Starters
description: Imagine that you land in an unusual city. Youre whisked away to your luxury hotel room, where you drop your luggage and immediately lock eyes with your traveling companion. And then it hits you: You have absolutely nothing to talk about.

title: At Pebble Beach, Caddies Are the All-Seeing Eyes
description: PEBBLE BEACH, Calif.  The invisible Monterey Peninsula is in plain sight, beneath tilting fairways and tiny, sloping greens. Subtle shifts of terrain over time have created nearly imperceptible bumps, hollows and breaks. Eagle-eyed golfers often cannot see them. Even high-definition television cameras cannot read the optical illusions that obscure a slope, pulling a putt right that should go left.

title: Everyone Wins in Deals for Fisher and Beauchemin
description: A pair of Western Conference clubs improved their lineups for playoff runs this week by acquiring veteransfor future assets. Continuing a trend from a year ago, when the Devils acquired Ilya Kovalchuk and the Maple Leafs dealt for Dion Phaneuf, the Nashville Predators and Anaheim Ducks did not wait until the Feb. 28 trade deadline to make their moves.

title: Head of German Central Bank Is Stepping Down
description: FRANKFURT  Axel Weber took himself out of the running Friday to become president of the European Central Bank, leaving deep uncertainty about who else can handle a job that is crucial to the survival of the euro.

title: Twitter Patter | @judyblume
description: Tweeting Since October 2009Followers 13, 986Twitter Bio Are you there Twitter? Its me, Judy.

title: Ford Raptor: Tonka Toy for Big Sandbox
description: TESTED: 2011 Ford F-150 SVT Raptor

title: Avoiding a New Pharaoh
description: So Hosni Mubarak is out. Vice President Omar Suleiman says that Mubarak has stepped down and handed over power to the military. This is a huge triumph for people power, and it will resonate across the Middle East and far beyond (you have to wonder what President Hu Jintao of China is thinking right now). The narrative about how Arab countries are inhospitable for democracy, how the Arab world is incompatible with modernity  that has been shattered by the courage and vision of so many Tunisians and Egyptians.

title: Romney Calls Obama Weak in Speech to Conservatives
description: Mitt Romney, the former governor of Massachusetts, called President Obama a weak president who had been caught unawares by world events, began an expensive failed social experiment and shrugged off the nations economic crisis by saying it could be worse.

title: Text of Omar Suleimans Address
description: The following is a BBC translation of the brief address delivered by Omar Suleiman, Egypt's vice president, announcing that Hosni Mubarak has resigned:

title: Oh Pioneers! | Lizzie Fortunato Forges Ahead
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#600", 592, 440, true, chameleonData);

title: Examining the Drawbacks of Smart Key Fobs
description: This Sundays Automobiles section looks at a change in a federal safety standard that expanded the definition of the word key  and in so doing accidentally undermined its primary goal, which was to prevent vehicles from rolling away.

title: Dress Up Your Salad
description: If youre using low-fat dressing on your salad, youre cutting more than calories from the dish. Thats because many of the nutrients in leafy green vegetables are fat-soluble, which means they need to be eaten with some fat so that the body can adequately absorb the nutrients.

title: A Wonderland at Sea
description: The Allure of the Seas is a cruise ship built for those longing to get lost in a strange, wondrous, digital world of lights and colors.

title: Adam Smith, Marriage Counselor
description: WHEN my husband offered this one up  Im sorry I didnt finish Ellas preschool applications  as we slogged through traffic somewhere between Exits 7 and 8 of the New Jersey Turnpike, I didnt miss a beat. Seriously? I said. I asked you to do that a month ago.

title: Terrible Swift Tongue
description: I cannot be the only person who read, with something of a sinking heart, the undeniably likable letter defending her mother that 18-year-old Sophia Chua-Rubenfeld published last month in The New York Post.

title: Osama Bin Laden: The Specter
description: Aye, aye! they were mine  my irons, cried Ahab, exultantly. . . . Aye, I see  wanted to part it; free the fast fish  an old trick  I know him. For a good generation now, the former chief of the C.I.A.s bin Laden unit, Michael Scheuer, has insisted that he knew the tricks of Osama bin Laden, that he was on to him from the start, that he and the unit he headed from 1996 to 1999 had given the government multiple chances to kill or capture the Saudi master terrorist. The bureaucracy had not gone along; indecisive leaders who didnt know the man they were trying to snag, who didnt read his writings, had thwarted and betrayed the hunt. And still, after the calamities, after all the disasters inflicted upon us by this elusive and cunning adversary, we havent yet understood what we are up against. A view has crystallized that the trail of terror now goes beyond bin Laden, that the man on the run no longer pulls the strings of the jihad. Scheuer has come forth to challenge this complacency.

title: From Here to There and Back, Melody Swirls Its Way Around
description: Why fleest thou throughe the worlde? Its a 16th-century question with resonance today for successful young artists like the composer Nico Muhly, who find themselves perpetually on the go. Mr. Muhlys blog and Twitter feed are proudly cosmopolitan, but lately his music has explored his ambivalent emotions about airports and hotel rooms, planes and taxicabs.

title: Flame Retardants Found in Butter
description: For about a decade, scientists have known that most Americans have minute quantities of flame retardants called polybrominated diphenyl ethers, PBDEs, in their bodies, but they were not sure how they got there.

title: What Were Reading
description: An aggregation of links by the reporters and editors of Diners Journal.

title: Chaos, Food, Lodging
description: Every college town is heaven, Justin Taylor writes in The Gospel of Anarchy, his first novel, each one different but the same. This book may be set in Gainesville, Fla., but it will resonate with anyone whos ever worked at a burrito joint in Chapel Hill, played Hacky Sack in Madison or fomented revolution in Eugene. These incubators of young adult weirdness  affordable and open-minded enough for even the crispiest burnouts  might be the last ecosystems in America able to sustain life at the fringes.

title: Model-Morphosis | Vena Cava
description: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of New York Fashion Week. Here, the model Gracie Carvalho from Marilyn Management before (left) and after (right) transforms, with makeup by Christian McCulloch for M.A.C. and hair by Ted Gibson. (Drag the orange bar left to reveal the full transformation.)

title: Two Voices
description: Memoir has become in recent years a kind of hard-luck lit, and at first glance Henry Cockburn is just another young man dropped into trouble, as the sparks fly upward. Not that the particulars arent his own, or attention-grabbing. At 20, Cockburn hears a few trees request that he dance in some frostbiting February water. (Oh that my words were now written! even Job said. Oh that they were printed in a book!  so the confessional impulse, at least, isnt entirely new.) Fishermen save Henrys life; police officers reassign him from general to mental hospitals. He rides out the next seven years in more and more secure institutions, a prisoner guilty basically of skinny-dipping. The story is sad, but Henrys Demons is more than just that.

title: 2010 Marijuana Arrests Top 1978-96 Total
description: Updated, 12:55 p.m. | More people were arrested last year in New York City on charges of marijuana possession than during the entire 19-year period from 1978 to 1996, according to an analysis released this morning by the Drug Policy Alliance.

title: This Weekends Top Matches
description: The outstanding matchups this weekend in soccer:

title: Graphic Books Best-Sellers: I Think I Do
description: The ups and downs of planning a wedding are many: where to do it (and how much to spend), whom to invite (and what the invitation will look like), what to serve, how to entertain your guests and more. In Scenes From an Impending Marriage, which lands at No. 2 on our hardcover list this week, the cartoonist Adrian Tomine chronicles his own march down the aisle in a series of comic strips. The end result also served as an atypical wedding favor for the guests at his nuptials. The publisher, Drawn & Quarterly, has a six-page preview available for download.

title: What Am I So Afraid Of?
description: The British journalist Allison Pearsons frothy, peachy smoothie of a first novel, I Dont Know How She Does It, surged with a certain inevitability to best-seller glory when it was published in 2002. So-called chick lit, about shopping and dating and cocktails, was on the wane, and its natural successor, mommy lit, was rolling in, with madcap tales of botched baking experiments, wayward nannies and extramarital e-mail flirtations. Could a wave of divorce narratives (split lit?) be far behind?

title: Investigation Begins in Neighborhood Where Blast Killed 5
description: ALLENTOWN, Pa.  Investigators were preparing Friday to insert cameras into an underground gas pipeline here as they continued their hunt for the cause of an explosion that killed five people.

title: Peter Som Tones It Down
description: Its far too early in the season to be talking about fall trends, but there certainly has been some consensus among the first shows at New York Fashion Week, which have included an abundance of dark and somber designs. There have been great textural coats as well, some in athletic sportswear shapes, at Richard Chai, Wayne Lee and, this morning, at Peter Som, but perhaps that is to be expected after the winter weve seen in New York. (Is it a coincidence that both Ms. Lee and Mr. Som showed variations of baseball jackets in luxury fabrics?)

title: A Chat With the Man Behind Biutiful
description: The Mexican director Alejandro Gonzlez Irritu first met the Spanish actor Javier Bardem at the Academy Awards in 2001. Both had been nominated for the first time: Mr. Gonzalez Irritus Amores Perros for best foreign language film and Mr. Bardem for best actor in Before Night Falls. And while neither won, afterward our losers party was the best, as Mr. Bardem recalled, and the two of them talked about collaborating.

title: Mubarak Steps Down
description: The Op-Ed columnist Nicholas D. Kristof on President Mubarak's handover of power and his expectations for what comes next.

title: A Brittle Leader, Appearing Strong
description: Hosni Mubaraks legacy was supposed to be stability. During almost three decades in power, he rejected bold action in favor of caution. He took half-steps at economic liberalization, preserved the peace with Israel, gave his police force the power to arrest without charge and allowed only the veneer of democracy to take hold.

title: Homage to Catalonia
description: In Graham Greenes novel The Quiet American, a French police officer is incongruously smitten with his wife, a flashy blonde said to be sleeping with his subordinates. But the policeman turns out to be an uncommonly good detective, since, as Greene argued, you cannot love without intuition. In The Second Son, Chief Inspector Nikolai Hoffner is also skilled at reading people (he recognizes a British spy in minutes), and he too has a great capacity for love.

title: Swashbuckling Spymaster
description: In January 1940, William J. Donovan sat in a Manhattan radio studio plugging The Fighting 69th, a Hollywood movie about the cocky, mostly Irish New York regiment whose exploits during World War I had made Donovan a national hero and earned him the Medal of Honor. The release of the film, starring James Cagney and Pat OBrien, with George Brent as the rakishly handsome Donovan, put the then wealthy and well-connected corporate attorney back in the spotlight just at the moment President Franklin Roosevelt was looking for men who could help mobilize the country for war.

title: Nuclear Reaction
description: The title of Elizabeth Stuckey-Frenchs latest novel is playfully retro, hinting that the radioactive ladys revenge will be nutty and kooky, not dark and messy. And if the lady in question is 77, how dangerous can she be?

title: Revolution From Within
description: Nelson Mandela was circumcised as a 16-year-old boy alongside a flowing river in the Eastern Cape. The ceremony was similar to those of other Bantu peoples. An elder moved through the line making ring-like cuts, and foreskins fell away. The boys could not so much as blink; it was a rite of passage that took you beyond pain. They exclaimed, Ndiyindoda! (I am the man!). A brambly leaf was wrapped around the wound to stop the bleeding. The boys had to lie in a certain position, and at midnight they were woken. One by one, they went out into the cold and buried their foreskins in stony soil. For Mandela, the circumcision was something that linked him with his Thembu ancestors; in losing a part of his manhood, he became a man.

title: Photos of the Moment | Duckie Brown
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#591", 592, 440, true, chameleonData);

title: Would You Like a Shake With That Workout?
description: The idea seems sort of silly, just another exercise gimmick. Stand for a few minutes on a platform that vibrates. Get off and try to do some weight lifting  squats, for example. Or try a short sprint. Or see how high you can jump. You are somehow supposed to be able to lift heavier weights, sprint faster, jump higher.

title: The Computer Made Me Do It
description: Humanity is migrating to cyberspace. In the past five years, Americans have doubled the hours they spend online, exceeding their television time and more than tripling the time they spend reading newspapers or magazines. Most now play computer or video games regularly, about 13 hours a week on average. By age 21, the average young American has spent at least three times as many hours playing virtual games as reading. It took humankind eight years to spend 100 million hours building Wikipedia. We now spend at least 200 million hours a week playing World of Warcraft.

title: Up, Up, Up
description: Edward Glaeser, a Harvard professor of economics, has spent several decades investigating the role cities play in fostering human achievement. In Triumph of the City, he has embedded his findings in a book that is at once polymathic and vibrant.

title: Time and Possibilities
description: At the age of 54, in the middle of a distinguished career as a scholar of the Hebrew Bible, the Harvard professor James L. Kugel received a diagnosis of cancer and was given a few years to live. Seven years later, with his cancer in remission, he began writing a book about the experience. Or rather, he began writing a book, In the Valley of the Shadow, that uses his encounter with death to investigate and report on a state of mind notoriously resistant to literary exploration: the state of mind in which you intuit something on the order of God.

title: The Parisienne
description: How can you not like a heroine who invents lascivious confessions to shock the priest and finds that kneeling in church makes naughtiness spring to her mind?

title: Solving Bobby Fischer
description: In the summer of 1972, the worlds attention was directed toward Reykjavik, the capital of Iceland, to watch a championship chess match. Called the Match of the Century, the contest between the Russian champion, Boris Spassky, and the American challenger, Bobby Fischer, attracted that attention because of its cold war implications.

title: Finding a Way
description: From the very first sentence of his unusual memoir, House of Prayer No. 2, Mark Richard brings together the vernacular and the performative. Say you have a special child,  the book begins, at once inviting us in folksy terms to suppose this to be the case and commanding us to summon the child into existence through the sheer act of saying so. The opening pages, Genesis-like, call the childs world into being, his early life created via a series of severe directives: Birth him with his father away and Move the family to a tobacco county in Southside Virginia and Make the mother cry and miss her mother. The special child in question, we come to understand, is Richard himself. Its an uncommon way to introduce the protagonist of a memoir, but an apt way to frame this absorbing account of growing up in the 1960s South, living with a disability, becoming a writer and finding faith. Richards book attests to the power of words (and the Word) in shaping a life, while at the same time challenging some dearly held beliefs about memoir as a genre.

title: Sudden Awakening
description: Long before publishers began branding the books of an author or illustrator with an identifiable look, Allen Says picture books have had a modest but singular and immediately recognizable design. His name and the title appear in a calm and unfancy font on the cover, anchoring a single image from the book. Endpapers are plain and the page design is consistent, with a brief text on white pages facing framed or full-bleed watercolor illustrations. Reading a book by Allen Say feels like looking through a succession of windows while someone quietly tells you a story  often a small but resonating incident from a persons life that demonstrates bravery of one kind or another.

title: Liberty or Death
description: The specter of full-grown adults festooned in tricorn hats may have retreated in the post-Tucson landscape, but the American Revolution and its reputed lessons are still in the air, making this an interesting time for Laurie Halse Anderson to publish Forge, her new novel about the Revolution and colonial-era slavery, and a sequel to her prize-winning Chains.

title: Urban Myths
description: When a magical glass staircase appears over a lake in Central Park, 10-year-old Rose, trailing behind her father and brother, brooding about how much she wants a dog, is the only one who sees it before it disappears. Like the talking White Rabbit in Alices Adventures in Wonderland, the sudden appearance of a curious impossibility in The Steps Across the Water propels the story into the realm of fantasy. But unlike Alice, who quickly pursues her new acquaintance down the rabbit hole, Rose returns to the routines of her daily life as a New York schoolgirl, keeping this secret to herself.

title: Kristols Brute Reason
description: To the Editor:

title: The Center of Attention
description: To the Editor:

title: The Violence of Peace
description: To the Editor:

title: Up Front: E-Book Best Sellers
description: This week we introduce our revamped best-seller lists, the result of many months of planning, research and design.

title: On Our Radar: Namibia Designates Entire Coast as National Park
description: Namibia designates its entire 976-mile coastline a national park, consolidating several existing preserves into the 26.6 million-acre Namib-Skeleton Coast National Park. The Namibian authorities have recently expanded wildlife conservation efforts in a successful effort to boost tourism; in one notable success, a population of lions has been re-established along the arid Skeleton Coast after being totally extinguished by hunting and poisoning in the 1980s. [The Telegraph]

title: Inside the List
description: GREEN ACRES: Four years ago, Ree Drummond was just another sometime city girl turned Oklahoma ranch wife with a flock of home-schooled children and a blog. Now, shes a full-fledged media star, with millions of page views a month at ThePioneerWoman.com, a long list of television appearances and a new memoir, subtitled Black Heels to Tractor Wheels, at No. 2 on the hardcover nonfiction list. (Its also No. 8 on the e-book list, on Page 23.) Call Drummond the Prairie Dog Mother: she mixes the chipper can-do spirit of Laura Ingalls Wilder, the slick production values of Martha Stewart and steely domestic ambition that Amy Chua might approve. At her Web site, vicarious homesteaders can read instructions on topics ranging from how to load hay onto your feed truck and knock down fences to how to make Pasta ai Quattro Formaggi and spiff up digital photographs. (Photoshops define and sharpen feature is apparently really good for animal hair.) Drummond has said she started her blog mainly as a way of sharing photos with her mother. Now, she offers lavish down-home food porn like a 39-shot pictorial on Perfect Potatoes au Gratin, a perfect accompaniment to the copious beefcake shots of her Wrangler-rocking husband, a k a Marlboro Man, cuddling a baby or wearing chaps or nourishing cows, his face usually shadowed under the brim of a cowboy hat. When my husband and I got married, we became one flesh, Drummond wrote in a recent post. So when he spends eight hours tearing down and building fence, its like I do, too. I just love the one flesh concept! It makes me one of the hardest workers Ive ever met.

title: Paperback Row
description: THE NEAREST EXIT,  by Olen Steinhauer (Minotaur Books, $14.99.) Milo Weaver, the C.I.A. spy who first appeared in Steinhauers 2009 thriller, The Tourist, has grown sick of his trade and longs to settle down. But his stab at domesticity is cut short when hes dispatched on a mission and becomes embroiled in the sordid world of human trafficking, a blackmail plot involving German intelligence officials and a search for a mole in the agency.

title: Editors Choice
description: SWAMPLANDIA!,  by Karen Russell (Knopf, $24.95.) Russells exuberant first novel, which works as a kind of expansion of her story Ava Wrestles the Alligator, concerns the pleasures and miseries of life in a failing alligator theme park in the Everglades.

title: Artifacts Will Be on View at Silk Road Exhibit
description: An exhibition of ancient Chinese artifacts will go forward at the University of Pennsylvania Museum of Archeology and Anthropology, after all. The exhibition, Secrets of the Silk Road, which includes materials, including two mummies, recently excavated at desert burial sites in western China, was organized by the Bowers Museum in Santa Ana, Calif., and was shown there last year and subsequently at the Houston Museum of Natural Science, where it closed on Jan. 2. It was scheduled to open at the Penn Museum on February 5, but last week, three days before the planned opening, the museum announced that China had requested that none of the artifacts be displayed. As a result, the museum would only show photographs, multimedia presentations, and a recreation of an excavation site; it offered refunds to those who had bought advance tickets and said that the exhibition would now be free.

title: Twisted Trails
description: Its getting harder and harder to tell the good guys from the bad guys in a modern western, of which Urban Waites first novel, THE TERROR OF LIVING (Little, Brown, $24.99), is one fine specimen. Phil Hunt, thoughtfully described as a good man, made up of all the bad things in the world, did a 10-year stretch in prison for killing a shopkeeper during a dumb robbery. But this flawed man was rescued by a strong woman who became his wife, and in the 20 years that Hunt has been out, theyve made a quiet, decent life together on a small farm south of Seattle where they raise and board horses.

title: Carmelo Anthony Flirts With High Efficiency
description: The prevalence of Carmelo Anthony trade rumors has brought forth an understandable amount of analysis and criticism concerning the exact nature of Anthonys game. After all, in order to best understand how Anthony would fit with a team like the Knicks or the Nets, it is crucial to look closely at the way he plays with and without the ball. Some players are more compatible with certain systems or teams than others, in no small part because of the way those players go about contributing to their teams success.

title: The IRS, Breast Pumps and other Updates
description: Some updates.

title: Gauging the Chances of Euro Zone Defaults
description: 8:39 p.m. | Updated  to correct reference to countries in final paragraph.

title: In Groupon Ad, Even the Mountain Was a Problem
description: Theres no question that Groupon is one of the hottest Internet start-ups, a small elite group that includes the likes of Facebook, Twitter and Zynga. But when it comes to playing in the big leagues of advertising, Groupon still has much to learn.

title: Grilled Cheese Sandwich, the Appetizer Edition
description: What to serve with a predinner drink? When no one else is around, the answer is, often, another predinner drink. What passes for a cocktail hour in our house involves a glass of whatever wine or beer my wife and I are going to drink with dinner, followed by another glass of the same as we move from kitchen to table.

title: Protesters Cheer Mubaraks Resignation
description: The streets of Cairo exploded with jubilant cries of protesters after it was announced that President Hosni Mubarak had passed all authority to a council of military leaders.

title: Andrew Mann
description: Mr. Mann, 55, is the managing director of the United States operations of Gardiner & Theobald, a project management and construction consultant with offices worldwide.

title: Backstage Beauty | Peter Som
description: Peters inspiration was a very fabulous American artist called Cindy Sherman, said the (very fabulous French) makeup artist Tom Pecheux backstage at Peter Som. She does self-portraits where she takes herself on a crazy journey. She always brings a twist into her face, so in terms of makeup we wanted to do that. This translated into nearly nude skin (with a bit of rosy blush and a touch of shimmery powder topping cheeks), bare brows, lashes and eyelids, punctuated with a statement lip. We started with a red lipstick, the definition of a grown-up woman, said Pecheux, noting that the designers fall 2011 collection seemed more adult to him than previous seasons. To twist it, we are adding a layer of metallic color. Lips were lined with M.A.C. Cherry Lip Pencil, filled in with a lipstick color being tested for fall tentatively called Runaway Red (according to M.A.C., Dare You is the closest shade currently available), dusted with M.A.C. Invisible Powder, and then dabbed with M.A.C. pigments in silver, rose gold and melon. Im not a fan of a lip with shimmer, a frosted lip  I think its cheesy, said Pecheux of his matte metallic creation. The look was paired with a hairstyle inspired by Tippi Hedrens character in The Birds, using Wella Ocean Spritz for texture and extensions with roots dyed into them. It gives the hairstyle depth, it makes hair look thicker, the minute you have a root it makes hair look thicker and a bit denser, the hairstylist Eugene Souleiman, who crafted the look, explained of the extensions. Its a little like when I used to do Prada and Miu Miu. It has that 90s take on the 50s  its slightly minimal, but now its a bit more raw.

title: Is Inflation Baked In?
description: Whenever I write about inflation or the lack thereof, I get a lot of remarkably angry mail from people who are focused on commodity prices; they just cant imagine how people like me or Ben Bernanke can be relaxed about the overall inflation picture when the prices of wheat, oil, etc. have risen so much lately.

title: Groupon Withdraws Contentious Super Bowl Spots
description: Groupon is ending a campaign that made its debut on Super Bowl Sunday, days after making changes in response to considerable criticism of the ads.

title: How to Groom Your New Facebook Profile
description: Facebook recently introduced a new profile format to all 600 million or so of its members. The new layout is more photo-driven, and allows you to customize your profile more meticulously than before. But unless you go digging, you may miss some of its better features.

title: At 78, Clive Davis Still Commands the Stage
description: No figure in the music industry is more closely associated with the Grammy Awards than Clive Davis, who for more than 30 years has held his see-and-be-seen party at the Beverly Hilton the night before the show. This year Mr. Davis, 78, expects plenty of the usual pop stars and industry bigwigs at the fete, as well as boldface names from sports like Magic Johnson and Serena Williams  a guest list large enough that he has had to make some unpleasant choices in who doesnt make the cut. This year I really cant go out to public restaurants, he said in an interview.

title: Donations Preserve 3 Varsity Teams at Cal but Cant Save Baseball
description: The University of California, Berkeley, announced Friday that it was reinstating three of the five varsity teams it cut in September after a group of donors, alumni and fans raised as much as $13 million in private donations to restore the teams.

title: Lucy Walked Tall, a Foot Bone Suggests
description: Lucy may well be the worlds most famous fossil hominid. She is the best-known specimen of the species Australopithecus afarensis, and her partial skeleton, found in 1974, revealed that she and her kin could walk upright.

title: With Wal-Mart Silent on Plans, Critics Focus on Rumored Site
description: It isnt much to look at, just a big empty lot packed with snow and some struggling cattail plants sandwiched between the Starrett City apartment complex and a shopping mall. But a field in the East New York section of Brooklyn has become one of the most hotly debated spots in New York City. All because it may  possibly, one day be home to the citys first Wal-Mart store.

title: Picking Up Good Vibrations at the Gym
description: In todays Personal Best column, Gina Kolata writes about vibrating platforms used by some exercisers and athletes in hopes of improving performance.

title: Battling Mold Infestations
description: TOXIC mold continues to be a problem in New York City. Last year the Department of Housing Preservation and Development issued 14,290 violations for mold in residential buildings.

title: Interim Coach Has Pacers Winning Again
description: The Pacers started the season with a surprising 9-7 record, which at the end of November was good enough for fifth best in the Eastern Conference (percentage points ahead of the Miami Heat).

title: In the Mood For Hot Pink
description: Just in time for Cupid-appropriate gifting, Agent Provocateur, the naughty but very nice English lingerie label, has opened a sprawling new flagship on Madison Avenue. Boasting black lacquer furniture, hand-painted silk walls and a giant vintage chandelier, the sexy, boudoirlike space has a mezzanine level for private appointments. Pieces in this hot-pink lace and peony print are $140 to $220; 675 Madison Avenue, (212) 840-2436.

title: Its O.K. to Throw Up
description: Midfielder Yael Averbuch, a Montclair, N.J., native by way of the University of North Carolina, will be contributing to the Goal blog in the runup to the third season of Womens Professional Soccer and as the United States womens national team prepares to play in the Algarve Cup and the FIFA Womens World Cup in Germany later this year.

title: Emanuel Leads by 30 Points in Chicago Mayors Race
description: Rahm Emanuel, the former White House chief of staff, leads his nearest rival by 30 percentage points in the race to become the next mayor of Chicago on Feb. 22, according to the latest Chicago Tribune/WGN poll.

title: In New York Citys Little Egypt, Infectious Joy
description: The jubilation in Egypt at news of the resignation of President Hosni Mubarak spread quickly to New Yorks Little Egypt neighborhood in Queens, where hundreds of Egyptian-American Muslims and others massed at Friday prayers to offer thanks.

title: Southern Sudan Suffers a Blow as Fighting Ends a Truce
description: KAMPALA, Uganda  Fresh battles between renegade soldiers and the southern Sudanese military in recent days have left more than 100 people dead in southern Sudan, sending tremors through a heavily militarized region that only days ago celebrated the final results of a referendum to separate from the rest of the country.

title: Bronx Hospitals Medical Records of 1.7 Million People Are Stolen
description: Update, 3:15 p.m. | Some 1.7 million patients, staff members, contractors and vendors had their medical and other personal records from city hospitals in the Bronx stolen, the citys Health and Hospitals Corporation said Friday. The affected hospitals were Jacobi Medical Center, North Central Bronx Hospital and two affiliated clinics. The overwhelming majority of those who had their data stolen were patients, the agency said.

title: Habitats | NoHo
description: Zak Tucker and Vilmari Ayala acquired roof rights to turn their tiny top-floor co-op into a triplex.

title: Thomas Campbell on Tapestry
description: Mr. Campbell discusses the 2007 exhibit Tapestry in the Baroque at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: Majestic Tapestries
description: Images from "Tapestry in the Baroque: Threads of Splendor" at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: Splendid Threads Off the Walls of Monarchs
description: Forty-four tapestries will be on display as part of "Tapestry in the Baroque: Threads of Splendor," which opens Wednesday at the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: Sweden Toxic for Assange, Lawyers Contend
description: LONDON  Lawyers for Julian Assange, the founder of WikiLeaks, said Friday that he should not be sent to Sweden to face allegations of sexual abuse there because he was now seen as public enemy number one in that country.

title: Globetrotters Head to the Hudson
description: While it may seem like a relatively new phenomenon, trick shots were invented and perfected by the Harlem Globetrotters over the last 85 years.

title: Mens Fall Fashion 2011 | Duckie Brown
description: In a fur-filled season, this curly shearling teddy bear coat from Duckie Brown, worn with gray flannel wrap-waist trousers, was an original.

title: World Leaders Cheer but Remain Wary
description: As the streets of Cairo erupted in celebration, leaders and officials around the world greeted the departure of President Hosni Mubarak on Friday with full-throated expressions of support for the people of Egypt along with some measured words of caution ahead for an uncertain period of political transition.

title: Weekend Competition: Conversation Stoppers
description: This weekend, co-vocabularists are invited to share conversation stoppers  comments guaranteed to end all social intercourse.

title: Where Beauty Meets Substance
description: WHO was it who said all you need to know is that beauty is truth and truth beauty?

title: The Accordion Apartment in NoHo
description: THE apartment in NoHo where Zak Tucker lives with his fiance and the couples new baby has come a long way since he arrived seven years ago.

title: Religion Is Relative
description: In a report by the Center for Applied Research in the Apostolate (CARA) at Georgetown University, which was released last week by the U.S. Conference of Catholic Bishops, theres one small paragraph that has started me musing, once again, on what parents really want for their children when it comes to religion.

title: Egypt Captivates Worlds Attention Except at CPAC
description: UPDATE, 4:35 p.m.: Three weeks of historic protests in Egypt upended President Hosni Mubaraks regime on Friday with the world looking. But here at the Conservative Political Action Conference, hardly anyone took any notice.

title: A New Way to Think About Valentines Day Gifts
description: In this weekends Your Money column, I take a somewhat grouchy look at Valentines Day gift-giving, in an attempt to prove that you dont have to spend lavishly (or hand over anything at all) on Feb. 14 to have a successful marriage.

title: Landry Fieldss Day Job at Modells
description: In this video, the Knicks rookie Landry Fields plays the part of Leroy Jenkins, employee of the month at Modells, and hilarity ensues.

title: European Officials Urge Fourth Round of Financing for Greece
description: ATHENS  Officials with the European Union and the International Monetary Fund recommended on Friday that Greece receive its fourth round of bailout financing.

title: Q & A
description: A Former Roommate Threatens to Sue

title: Double Duty: 88th Precinct and 88 Keys
description: Officer Ka Kit Yip of the 88th Precinct in Fort Greene, Brooklyn, is 5 feet 6 inches tall. On Saturday afternoon, he will face what some would consider an adversary that measures 6 feet 11 inches long.

title: More Focus Groups for Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark
description: The going rate for your thoughts used to be a penny. Now the producers of the Broadway musical Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark are offering $60 goodie bags to people who serve in focus groups that will respond to several performances. Two focus groups attended Thursday nights performance, and four more are scheduled to be at Friday nights show and the Saturday matinee. Its not unheard of for Broadway producers to use focus groups, and the musical has used them before since preview performances began on Nov. 28. But these are the first since largely negative reviews of the show by theater critics across the country were published on Tuesday. OnTrack Research, a marketing and consulting firm, is coordinating the focus groups, and heres the rub: participants only get to see Act I or Act II, not both. They are then asked to fill out surveys and join in discussions in a V.I.P. room. The details of the focus groups were outlined in an e-mail to participants from OnTrack Research. Here is the full e-mail, which a focus group participant passed along and which was authenticated by the production on Friday.

title: Photos of the Moment | Ruffian
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#469", 592, 440, true, chameleonData);

title: Stalling Complaints Prompt Investigation of 97,000 TDI Volkswagens and Audis
description: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration has expanded an investigation into stalling complaints involving 97,000 late-model Volkswagens and Audis equipped with 2-liter 4-cylinder turbodiesel engines.

title: Dorothy Furlong and Charlie Hall
description: AN ice king married a snow queen on Feb. 5 in Minnesota, making for one of the warmest celebrations ever to grace the 125-year-old St. Paul Winter Carnival.

title: When Love Outgrows Gifts on Valentines Day
description: As if we needed another sign that Valentines Day is getting awfully expensive, the coupon Web sites have now gotten into the game.

title: Both Sides Are Braced for Debt-Limit Debate
description: WASHINGTON  With a showdown approaching over the need to raise the federal debt limit, White House officials feel they have the upper hand over Congressional Republicans who want to use the debate on the measure to force deep spending cuts, people familiar with the administrations thinking say.

title: Take the Stairs
description: For some buyers, only a duplex will do. Stairs create zones for sleeping and for everything else. And best of all, they suggest a house.

title: Bonds's Journey to 756
description: The significant moments in the career of Barry Bonds, the all-time leader in career home runs.

title: The Added Value in a Staircase
description: OF all the must-have items for a New York City apartment, stairs generally dont figure very high on the list.

title: Fashion Week Parties: Night 1
description: Thursday night of Fashion Week began with a variety of parties, featuring young designers, animal rights supporters and a graffiti artist.

title: Men, Women and A.D.H.D.
description: Do men and women exhibit different symptoms of attention deficit hyperactivity disorder, or A.D.H.D.? What about boys and girls? These are among the questions recently posed by readers of the Consults blog. Dr. Russell A. Barkley, clinical professor of psychiatry at the Medical University of South Carolina and author, most recently, of Taking Charge of Adult A.D.H.D.,  responds to one reader whose wife has a whopping case of A.D.H.D.

title: Suspect in Stolen-BMW Assault Case Dies in Florida Shootout
description: A former convict wanted on charges that he stole a BMW sports car last month and stuffed its critically injured owner in the trunk was killed Friday in a shootout with officers on a fugitive task force in Florida, officials said.

title: The Fleet of 2011
description: With features like a water park and a culinary school, the new cruise ships of 2011 are trying to catch your attention.

title: From African Rivers to French Impressionism
description: Cruise lines offer trips to more remote destinations, stay in port longer and designate new theme cruises.

title: A Creative Corner in Wanchai, Hong Kong
description: The Star Street neighborhood in Hong Kongs Wanchai district is quickly becoming a magnet for creative entrepreneurs, with new boutiques and restaurants cropping up alongside design firms in this pedestrian-friendly enclave.

title: 14 New Cruises for 2011
description: IF your mental image of a cruise conjures a party boat island-hopping in the Caribbean with little passenger interest in its ports of call, think again. Though the Caribbean remains the most trafficked destination for cruise ships, cruise lines are now piloting trips to more remote destinations both at home and abroad. They are also staying in port longer and designating theme cruises that are far from singles mingles. The following is an overview of some of 2011s most interesting new sailings.

title: 10 Restaurants Worth Leaving the Ship For
description: Cruises rarely lack for dining options, but the times when ships are docked  either in ports along their routes or before they set sail  offer rare opportunities to explore local cuisines. Here, then, is a list of restaurants in ports of call around the world  some storied, some new  that should entice travelers to leave the comfort of the ship behind.

title: A Bit of a Working Vacation
description: When it comes to shore excursions, travelers are often steered toward tourist-friendly entertainment rather than the reality that lies beyond souvenir shops. But this year, Crystal Cruises offers one volunteer excursion per cruise, providing a chance for travelers to give time to causes that benefit destinations on their itineraries.

title: 25 Years on the Sea and Counting
description: ON April 15, 2010, in Cape Town, South Africa, Capt. Dag Dvergastein left the Regent Seven Seas Voyager after 18 years with the Seven Seas line. Passengers who had known him for years were beside themselves. Liz Ruwitch, 95, who had been on four world cruises with him, said that instead of going on the next Voyager world cruise as she had planned, she signed up for the South American one instead. Gladys Vallone, 82, who hardly ever misses a world cruise, decided to stay home this year with her husband in New Jersey.

title: On the Worlds Largest Cruise Ship, the Sea Is an Afterthought
description: I WAS standing in Central Park in the middle of the Caribbean Sea near an Indian mangosteen tree, a Malaysian olive tree, a number of elephant ears and a total of 96 other species of plant. Birds were tweeting and mothers, as diversely global as the plants, pushed strollers along the paths. A little girl twirled in a pink dress.

title: Ship Designers Look Outdoors
description: Cruise lines are shifting their focus from interiors to design features that emphasize the outdoors.

title: Cruising With the Stars
description: Cruise lines have their own celebrity culture, one that favors reality and cable TV stars as well as authors and politicos youd expect to see on the lecture circuit.

title: Brought to You by Your Favorite Sponsor
description: Corporations have enlisted cruise ships to extend their brands, resulting in a name-dropping spree on the high seas. Consider:

title: When House-Hunting Is a Wild Ride
description: MUFFIN DOWDLE of Ginnel Real Estate in Bedford Hills has found resourceful ways of selling real estate in this harsh winter. When unable to slog through the snow via four-wheel drive, she saddles up one of her three horses and takes off, often with the other two in tow so clients can ride alongside her.

title: Southwestern Water: Going, Going, Gone?
description: The glum projections of the growing gap between demand for water in the Southwest and the dwindling supplies have never been optimistic, but two new studies one a research report based on satellite data, and the other an analysis of rainfall, water use and the costs associated with obtaining new water  make earlier forecasts seem positively rosy.

title: Freescale Plans to Go Public
description: Freescale Semiconductor, the chip maker acquired in 2006 in one of the biggest technology leveraged buyouts ever, filed to go public on Friday, seeking to raise money to pay down its debt load.

title: Chris Bosh and the Self-Fulfilling Prophecy
description: The sports analytics movement has given basketball decision makers more valuable information than they have ever had, but, in a way, their experience in implementing their findings is atypical in the information age. The modern world is marked by the rapid dissemination of incredible amounts of information to relevant and interested parties; people from all over the planet know more today about one another and the world they inhabit than any human beings have before, primarily because of how freely information is exchanged. When it comes to analytical data in sports, however, coaches in particular face a unique challenge in passing along the statistical information they deem important. Its not enough to know that a player is most effective running one type of play or shooting from one area of the floor. Coaches today must also understand how to convey that information in a way that makes it digestible and useful.

title: Look of the Moment | Elle Macpherson
description: The Look: Model citizen  from the tee to the boots, this look gives new meaning to the words hot momma.

title: A Farmhouse Looks for a Home
description: IN 2009, a developer named Michael Davis paid $5 million for a 2.3-acre lot in the Sagaponack Greens subdivision, with plans to build a 7,000-square-foot English country-style mansion and sell it for close to $20 million. Before he could do so he had to decide what to do with the four abandoned structures on the former farm property: two old barns, an 1840s Greek Revival house and a 1930 American Foursquare.

title: Geithner Takes Aim at Fannie and Freddie
description: Treasury Secretary Timothy F. Geithner discusses the administrations effort to wind down Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac and overhaul the housing market, in an interview with CNBC.

title: In New Brunswick, a Mixed-Use Project Is Bustling
description: IN this sluggish real estate market, how is it possible that a major mixed-use project with 150 rental units and 42 condominiums can actually be proceeding?

title: Race and the Oscar Race
description: A gallery of black Academy Award winners.

title: The Bohemian Fashion Muse
description: FLORENCE WELCH, the titian-tressed lead singer of Florence and the Machine, has become an idol of the frenetic indie set. But when she received word in December of her first Grammy nomination, for best new artist, she was lounging around her parents London home in classic languorous-bombshell mode.

title: 3 Shot Dead, 3 Wounded in Virginia; Suspect Is Arrested
description: A 37-year-old illegal immigrant was under arrest Friday after three people were found shot to death and three others were wounded at two houses just blocks apart in the northern Virginia city of Manassas, the police said.

title: Hollywoods Whiteout
description: CRAMMED into this years field of 10 best picture Oscar nominees are British aristocrats, Volvo-driving Los Angeles lesbians, a flock of swans, a gaggle of Harvard computer geeks, clans of Massachusetts fighters and Missouri meth dealers, as well as 19th-century bounty hunters, dream detectives and animated toys. Its a fairly diverse selection in terms of genre, topic, sensibility, style and ambition. But its also more racially homogenous  more white  than the 10 films that were up for best picture in 1940, when Hattie McDaniel became the first black American to win an Oscar for her role as Mammy in Gone With the Wind. In view of recent history the whiteness of the 2011 Academy Awards is a little blinding.

title: Interview: Kareem Abdul-Jabbar
description: Kareem Abdul-Jabbar talks about his new documentary about the Harlem Renaissance (Photos by The New York Times. Associated Press, Smithsonian American Art Museum and Getty Images).

title: Preparing for the Future: Improving College Readiness
description: This weeks education news includes the finding that fewer than half of New York Citys high school graduates were prepared for college or a well-paying career. Statewide, 77 percent of students graduate, but correlating state standards to college performance reveals that far fewer of those graduates are equipped for success in college or the workplace.

title: Bill Would Make University Sell a Pollock for Scholarship Money
description: A bill that has been proposed in the Iowa state legislature would require the University of Iowa to sell Jackson Pollocks Mural, an 8-by-20-foot painting, to pay for scholarships. The work was valued at $140 million in 2008, the Iowa City Press-Citizen reported on Thursday.

title: Fashion Week Video | Siki Im Casting
description: Siki Im, the Ecco Domani Award-winning mens wear designer, was born and raised in Cologne, Germany, and graduated from Oxford University with a first-class honors degree in architecture. After moving to New York 10 years ago, Im transitioned to fashion by working for Karl Lagerfeld and Helmut Lang before establishing his own mens wear collection in 2009. The Moment caught up with Im as he and the stylist David Vandewal were creating looks, shooting a look-book and preparing for his fashion week presentation, which is at 9 oclock Friday night at Metropolitan Pavilion.

title: Quiet Worries as Israel Watches an Ally Depart
description: JERUSALEM  As the streets of Gaza exploded with celebration on Friday night with masked Hamas militants marching defiantly to cheer the resignation of President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt, Israelis reacted with quiet and deep concern because the regional leader on whom they had relied most was suddenly gone.

description: Many doctors order imaging scans when patients complain of lower back pain, but they are unnecessary in most cases and may do more harm than good, the American College of Physicians stated in new practice guidelines.

Bundled with the Iacocca Silver 45th Anniversary Edition Mustang is a feature as novel as the vehicle itself: a Los Angeles lunch with Mr. Iacocca.

title: Photo of the Day: New York Fashion Week
Obama Leaves Wishy-Washy Behind
description: Ive been critical of the Obama administrations wishy-washy, weather vane approach to people power in Tunisia and Egypt. But President Obamas statements yesterday were a big step forward, and his speech just now was pitch perfect. Its our job as journalists to criticize, but I thought he got it exactly right. He put the United States unambiguously on the side of Egypts youth and future and freedom, all while making it clear that Egypts future is up to Egyptians to decide.

title: Yale and Peru Sign Accord on Machu Picchu Artifacts
description: Three months after Yale University and the government of Peru announced a tentative accord under which Yale would return a group of artifacts excavated at Machu Picchu, Yale formally signed a partnership agreement on Friday with a Peruvian university to establish a joint center where the objects will be conserved, studied and displayed. The center will be at the Universidad Nacional de San Antonio Abad del Cusco, in Cusco, the city closest to Machu Picchu, and will be called the U.N.S.A.A.C.-Yale International Center for the Study of Machu Picchu and Inca Culture. It will include a museum exhibition space; a storage site for the archeological artifacts, which include stone tools, ceramics and human and animal bones; and a laboratory and research area. Students and faculty members from Yale are expected to visit the center for training, research projects and field work; students and faculty members of the Peruvian university will also visit Yale. Meanwhile, a small number of artifacts will be loaned to Yale for display at the Yale Peabody Museum of Natural History.

title: Big Deal | A Home Off Off Off Broadway

title: Detective Accidentally Shoots Self in Thigh
description: A police detective accidentally shot herself in the thigh as she adjusted her firearm while riding in a van on Rikers Island this morning, the police said.

title: Reviewing the Mazda 5
description: In Sundays Automobiles section, Richard S. Chang reviews the redesigned Mazda 5, a smallish minivan on which Mazda has deployed its Nagare design language (inspired by a concept car at the 2006 Los Angeles auto show). Mr. Chang writes that the 5 offers a generally pleasing blend of useful features at a relatively low price. And it proved adept on a family outing:

title: Stockholm Design Week | From Modern to Mod
description: In most peoples minds, there are only two settings on the Nordic furniture dial: Then (meaning postwar Modern) and Now. While I went to this years Stockholm Design Week, which ends on Sunday, excited solely about the latter, it turned out that the fair had something to offer in the former department as well. The Danish manufacturer Gubi recently shifted its attention towards resurrecting mid-century design icons, and the first fruits of that effort are on display this week. It has reissued Greta Grossmans 1947 Grasshopper lamp and the 1966 Stokke Chair by Jens Qvistgaard, and is now the sole owner of reproduction rights for the cult Hungarian designer Mathieu Mategots work, starting with a multicolored coat rack and two pieces in his signature perforated metal: the Nagasaki chair and the Dedal bookcase. Mategot fans accustomed to 1stdibs sticker shock should rejoice.

title: Obamas Parting Gift to Gibbs
description: When President Obama delivered the keynote address to the Democratic National Convention in 2004, he borrowed a pale blue tie from his press secretary Robert Gibbs, who has since gained a reputation for his love of pastel-colored neckwear.

title: Finchers Musketeers Talk Shop
description: As a filmmaker, David Fincher has the reputation of an extreme perfectionist, so finely attuned to detail that he doesnt trust anyone else to get even minor secondary shots. That vision earned him an Oscar nomination as the director of The Social Network  but what about the guys who have to work with him? While Mr. Fincher is celebrated for doing dozens and dozens of takes , whats often forgotten is that other people then have to look at each and every one of those takes to put the film together. Apparently they dont mind; the editors Kirk Baxter and Angus Wall, and the sound designer, editor and mixer Ren Klyce have all worked with Mr. Fincher multiple times, on films like The Curious Case of Benjamin Button and Zodiac. They are all Oscar-nominated for The Social Network, and are working with Mr. Fincher on his next film, The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo.

title: Obama Presses Egypts Military on Democracy
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama heaped praise on the peaceful protesters who deposed Hosni Mubarak on Friday, declaring, Egypt will never be the same, even as his national security team acknowledged that the swift uprising would almost certainly upend American strategy in the Middle East.

title: Artifacts | Philip-Lorca diCorcias Perfect Eleven
description: One thing to love about fashion is its extravagance. Fashion wouldnt be fashion without it. What matters is the look. It has to dazzle the eye before anything else, and so do the photographs that sell it. Its the image that counts and Philip-Lorca diCorcia is one photographer who knows from imagery. The fashion spreads he created for W magazine from 1997 through 2008 are lavish productions that dont just illustrate a moment in style but tell a story about representation itself.

On Wednesday, Stephen Elop, the companys recently appointed chief executive, sent a note to Nokia employees warning that their company was in major trouble, like a man standing on a burning platform in the middle of an icy sea, who had to take drastic action to save himself.

description: The panel found 2004 Bordeaux wines to be light and graceful, with distinctive personalities.

description: Ashlin Halfnight, 35, is a playwright on the verge. Moving from Toronto to Harvard to a stint in professional hockey to downtown theater, he has a biography that is catnip for profile writers. So is his glamorous name.

title: Sensitive Revelations, Free of Anguish
description: Vulnerability is a quality that most male singers measure out in teaspoons. But for T. Oliver Reid, it isnt a discreetly added emotional flavoring to a love song; it is its essence. To witness Mr. Reid infuse popular standards with the immediacy and intensity of diary entries on Thursday evening at the Metropolitan Room was to observe an unfaltering emotional high-wire act.

title: Painting It Red: Midcareer Minnelli
description: VERMEER had his yellow, Yves Klein had his blue, and Vincente Minnelli had a shade of red all his own: a bursting, tactile one, with a texture somewhere between velvet and vegetable. Its a shade that rendered particularly well in the color processes of the 1950s and early 60s, when Minnelli was in his prime, and it bursts out all over the four remastered Minnelli films that have recently been released by the Warner Archive Collection: The Cobweb (1955), Tea and Sympathy (1956), The Reluctant Debutante (1958) and Two Weeks in Another Town (1962).

title: Users of iPhones Put a Flourish in E-Signatures
description: WHEN it came to getting a cellphone, Ben Shine prided himself on being the last of his friends to do so. So when he bought an iPhone in 2009, he was afraid that the default signature appended to every e-mail (Sent from my iPhone) made him look like a conformist.

title: Take a Look at His Life: They Sound a Lot Like Him (Well, Sometimes)
description: The skeletal mysteries of Neil Youngs songs humbled many and emboldened a few at Music of Neil Young on Thursday night at Carnegie Hall. It was the seventh annual songwriter tribute in a concert series produced by Michael Dorf of City Winery to benefit music programs for children. The format was crisp: 20 singers and groups performed one song each and got together for a finale. They included musicians directly indebted to Mr. Young (who didnt attend) and some from more distant musical spheres, like the Roots, the Brazilian pop singer Bebel Gilberto and the New Orleans master Aaron Neville.

title: Major Donation to Help Conserve L.A.s Watts Towers
description: LOS ANGELESThe Watts Towers, an aging cultural landmark in the southern part of Los Angeles that has become the subject of a major restoration effort, is receiving $500,000 from the James Irvine Foundation to help fund an evaluation of damage to the structures and small day-to-day repairs.

title: A Romantic Classic, Subject to Revisions
description: WASHINGTON  The first six months of 2011 are bringing America a good many different productions of the old Romantic classic Giselle. In January there were live simulcasts from the Royal Ballet in London and the Bolshoi in Moscow. By the end of this month, the Alabama Ballet, Richmond Ballet and San Francisco Ballet will all have staged revivals. And coming up we can expect American Ballet Theaters version and a new production by Pacific Northwest Ballet in Seattle that will try to restore many details lost since the 19th century.

title: A Visitor Arrives, Armed With a Sprawling Score
description: It is hard for a technically adept conductor not to make a big impression with Shostakovichs gripping Fifth Symphony. But it is just as hard for an interpretation of this well-known piece to stand out.

title: Psst, So-and-Sos Got a Crush
description: MOST of us entertain little crushes on folks in the public eye. Dont bother denying it. There may be dashes of physical attraction (hello, Rafa Nadal), but just as often, our fancies run to the wildly ingenious (Mark Zuckerberg), or wickedly funny (Amy Sedaris), the purely inspiring (President Obama in Tucson) or all of the above (Kim Kardashian  kidding!).

title: Kitsch of the Day | Takarazuka
description: For the modern YouTube hunter the world of Japanese television and pop culture can be a seemingly bottomless treasure trove. Among some of the finest gems are clips like the one above of Takarazuka, a 98-year-old Japanese song and dance troupe that specializes in performing adaptations of Western pop songs, classic musicals, operas, plays, novels or films as well as Japanese folk tales. (The clip above shows the musical number The Great Century, which incorporates the 80s soft rock anthem Final Countdown.) But in a bizarre twist on the idea of an all-male Shakespearean cast, the members of the ensemble are all women  making Takarazuka perhaps the only Vegas-style musical theater group in the world with professional drag kings on permanent payroll. But despite appearances, Takarazuka was never meant as an early-20th-century chorus line for Japanese womens liberation. To this day, cast members are put through a rigorous and patriarchally organized training program for several years before they are even allowed to set one foot on stage, with female (musumeyaku) and male (otokoyaku) actresses strictly separated in classrooms and dormitories. The inevitable lesbian overtones were largely ignored until the mid- to late 1930s, when Japanese officials were alarmed to a point that a ban on contact between the male cast members and their passionate female fans was imposed. To this day, most of Takarazukas over-2.5 million-strong annual audience consists of women, and so do the performers: an attempt in the 1940s to introduce male actors was successfully boycotted by Takarazukas own disgruntled cast.

title: Detroit Pistons May Be Sold Soon to Gores
description: DETROIT  It appears the Detroit Pistons are moving closer to being sold to the private equity financier Tom Gores, according to sources with knowledge of the negotiations who were not allowed to speak publicly because of a confidentiality agreement.

title: App Smart Extra: BrewBerry
description: This weeks App Smart column raises a glass to the best Android and Apple software for beer drinkers.

title: Lots of Beats, but No Drum in Sight
description: FOR about 12 minutes at a recent installment of One Step Beyond, a monthly party at the Rose Center for Earth and Space at the American Museum of Natural History in Manhattan, no one danced. Instead people were clustered around the stage, watching dumbfounded as Araabmuzik pounded out live drumbeats with his fingertips on a pair of Akai MPC 2500s.

title: The Grammy Awards Before the Grammys
description: BY the time Eminem, Lady Gaga and Arcade Fire are battling it out in prime time Sunday for the top Grammy Awards, 98 other statuettes will already have been handed out in a brisk pre-show Webcast. Those are the awards that seek to satisfy every niche in the recording business, and tucked into those niches are worthwhile recordings from way outside the mainstream. These nominations offer a brief chance for attention, and perhaps a few seconds of Webcast glory.

title: The Scene: Fashion Week Day 2
description: Scenes around the city from New York Fashion Week.

title: Together, Nokia and Microsoft Renew a Push in Smartphones
description: LONDON  Nokia, the struggling world leader in mobile phones, said on Friday that it would discard its own cellphone operating system and begin using software made by Microsoft, in an alliance to shore up the halting efforts in smartphones of two market leaders.

title: Salaried Workers at Chrysler and G.M. to Receive Bonuses
description: DETROIT  General Motors and Chrysler, which posted much-improved results last year after reorganizing in bankruptcy court in 2009, said Friday that they would pay bonuses to salaried workers in the United States.

title: Lincoln Center, Round Two
description: Has Lincoln Center already lost its luster? The question may seem premature. It has been only six months, after all, since IMG, the producer of Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week, transferred its spectacle from Bryant Park to New Yorks premier cultural campus.

title: Medicare Recipients Against Handouts
description: You know, Id always thought that the dont let the government get its hands on Medicare contingent, while picturesque, wasnt all that large. But noooo: 44 percent of Social Security recipients, and 40 percent of Medicare recipients, believe that they dont benefit from any government social program.

title: A Long Life That Peaks Quite Young
description: Any Human Heart is a kind of Forrest Gump for the literate: an intimate, picaresque chronicling of the life of a fictional British writer who intersects with notable events, ideas and personages of the 20th century in ways both amusing and catastrophic. Based on the novel by William Boyd, who wrote the teleplay, the story is an examination of dissipated ambition  an affecting look at the ways in which the burdens of love, and living, eventually erode the aspirations of youth. Though this surely makes the enterprise sound entirely dismal, the Masterpiece Classic series (beginning on Sunday on PBS) works tirelessly to squelch the overgrowth of its bleak roots.

title: The Perfect Spot for a Date, or to Run Away From One
description: Even in a guide to restaurants for dating and dumping  with categories like hottest servers, about places where you can ogle, flirt and get a not-so-hot reaction out of your date  one section stands out. The one listing restaurants with multiple exits.

title: Pictures of the Day: Egypt and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Egypt, Iran and Pakistan.

title: Looks Familiar, but Its Full of Surprises
description: EVEN on your first visit to Pepe Rosso 24 in Port Washington, the place may seem familiar. Chances are youve been to Italian restaurants like this before; nearly every town on Long Island has one. As you enter, theres a pizza parlor to the right, a casual dining room to the left.

title: A Versatile Boutique Winery
description: Clovis Point, a Jamesport vineyard planted in 2001, draws on history. It is named for Clovis points, stone spear tips attributed to the Clovis people, who were Paleolithic Indians believed to have inhabited the North Fork. Two such points, around 8,000 to 10,000 years old and now in the Southold Indian Museum, have been found in the area. A photo of one decorates the labels of Clovis Point wines.

title: Top Public High Schools Admit Fewer Blacks and Hispanics
description: The percentage of black and Hispanic students offered admission to the citys elite public high schools inched lower this year, continuing a decade-long slide, according to the results of the citys admissions process released Friday.

title: Amid All Those Words, An Animated Argument
description: MONTCLAIR, N.J.  Its not every artist who will list prominently in her biography that her national nickname is a permanent irritation. But so the South African choreographer Robyn Orlin proclaims in program notes for Walking next to our shoes ... Intoxicated by strawberries and cream ... We enter continents without knocking ..., which had its American premiere on Thursday night as part of the Montclair State Universitys Peak Performances series.

title: Opening the Folkways of Perception: Outsider Arts Wide World of Inclusion
description: I once asked an art dealer how he determined whether someone was an outsider artist, and he offered this criterion: anyone who called up and said he or she was an outsider artist was immediately disqualified. In his view, outsider artists dont self-identify and they dont operate telephones.

description: Mindy Mosca started working with chocolate as a hobby about 10 years ago. Her goodies, including the chocolate-covered pretzels she would make for presents and party platters, soon developed a following, and she began filling small orders. Sales, however, quickly took off.

title: Idol Reigns in Ratings
description: With the auditions over and the Hollywood round in full swing, American Idol led Fox to its fourth consecutive Thursday night victory in the ratings. According to Nielsens estimates, 21.7 million viewers tuned in to the show at 8, far more than any other program that night. Although Idol boosted Foxs Bones, which delivered 10.1 million viewers at 9, that show trailed behind both ABCs Greys Anatomy (10.4 million) and CBSs CSI (12.6 million) in its time slot. CBS placed second for the night over all, with its largest audience at 10 for The Mentalist (14.7 million). ABC was third, while NBC finished fourth.

title: Fred Kirby, Who Built Giant Title Insurance Company, Is Dead at 91

title: Vogueing in a Playground of Gender, Celebrity and Fashion
description: The postmodern choreographer Yvonne Rainer said no to rather a lot of things in her famous 1965 manifesto: No to spectacle no to virtuosity no to transformations and magic and make believe no to glamour and transcendency of the star image. And more.

title: Seattles Intiman Theater Announces Emergency Fundraising Campaign
description: Seattles esteemed Intiman Theater, which in recent months has acknowledged financial problems, announced on Friday that it would have to close unless it could raise $500,000 by the end of March and another $250,000 each by June and September.

title: TimesCast | February 11, 2011
description: David Kirkpatrick and Anthony Shadid report from Cairo on the aftermath of President Mubarak's resignation.

title: Pigs Feet That Dont Step on Anyones Toes

Critics concurred that the publishers of Zina Cava offered an instructive object lesson Thursday that if your name isnt Kate Moss  or perhaps, Tavi Gevinson  some days it may simply be best to bundle up and move on.

I did it in ignorance, the way I do everything, he added. I never really know whats going on.

title: Cause of Muti Collapse Determined
description: The cause of Riccardo Mutis fall from the podium during a rehearsal of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra on Feb. 3 has been determined. In a joint statement with Mr. Muti and officials of the orchestra, two cardiologists at the Northwestern University Feinberg School of Medicine, Donald Lloyd-Jones and Bradley P. Knight, reported on Friday that Mr. Muti had fainted because of a common heart rhythm disturbance. Although their tests reveal that he retains excellent heart function, they added, he has had a pacemaker installed to monitor his heart rhythm and deliver a small electrical charge if the heart rate should fall too low. Patients with pacemakers live full and active lives with excellent prognosis, the doctors concluded. Mr. Muti remains in Northwestern Memorial Hospital, where he is recovering from surgery for facial injuries incurred in the fall. He has canceled his remaining performances this winter, which were to run through Feb. 19. His next scheduled appearance with the orchestra is a concert performance of Verdis opera Otello on April 7, to be repeated twice in Chicago and, on April 15, in Carnegie Hall.

title: After Saving a Jumper, The Chat That Ensues
description: The Sunset Limited on HBO is 90 minutes of Tommy Lee Jones, Samuel L. Jackson and Cormac McCarthy locked (symbolically, at least) in a room together. The two actors do everything they can to make that a tolerable situation, but they can never entirely distract us from the fact that theyre trapped in Mr. McCarthys dorm-room argument masquerading as a drama.

title: The Week in Pictures for Feb. 11
description: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include a winter carnival, a Viennese ball and a workshop to encourage civilian-veteran dialogue.

Anyway, you dont need a runway to feel the flow of goods, like a tidal surge. Go to Times Square or Herald Square, where the tourists and the teenagers drain the merchandise out of H & M and Forever 21 during the day, and trucks return more at night.

A former academic and industry consultant, Dr. Carter, as he likes to call himself  he has a doctorate in theoretical physics, in case you were wondering  is the Defense Departments under secretary for acquisitions, technology and logistics. That is, hes the Pentagons chief weapons buyer.

The debate over the propriety of using apps, already hot, is intensifying.
