description: A quick review of the Hall of Fame voting last weekend:

title: Rangers 6-Game Skid Ends After a Pep Talk
description: The Rangers fell behind by two goals just over five minutes into the game Sunday afternoon, an ominous sign for a team in the midst of its longest losing streak of the season.

title: Stillness Amid A Shifting World
description: The Palestinian director Kamal Aljafaris elliptical film Port of Memory occupies ground somewhere between documentary and fiction. The port of the title is Jaffa in Israel, and Mr. Aljafari shows its streets, its crumbling walls, the interiors of its houses. He also shows people engaged in the banal activities of daily life: a woman washes her hands; people sit on a couch and talk. And is that the sound of gunfire in the background?

title: Monday: Word Puzzle With Pictures
description: MONDAYS PUZZLE  Victor Fleming and Lynn Lempel bring us a Valentine of sorts today, and if this doesnt raise your self-esteem, I cant imagine what will.

title: Housing Market Looks Sickest in Cities That Once Seemed Immune
description: SEATTLE  Few believed the housing market here would ever collapse. Now they wonder if it will ever stop slumping.

title: At Media Companies, a Nation of Serfs
description: Some of the fizz, if not a great big bubble, seems to have returned to media, depending on how you define media.

title: Leagues Penalties Frustrate Lemieux
description: Two Islanders were suspended for a total of 13 games and the team was fined $100,000, yet it was Mario Lemieux, a Pittsburgh Penguins co-owner, who was most upset by the punishments handed out by the N.H.L. in the wake of the teams brawl-filled game Friday night.

title: Clayton Dubilier to Buy Emergency Medical Services
description: Monday, 7:41 p.m. | Updated

title: The Best Amid the Blur
description: Fashion Week is really the collective fashion brain, and its filled with a lot of stuff nobody will remember an hour later. People go to the shows to get buzzed and tweet one another, just as people used to go to Studio 54 to lose their underwear. Nobody expects a genuine emotional lift. Jetweet jet?

title: Italy Seeks to Use Forces to Halt Illegal Immigrants From Tunisia
description: ROME  Italys interior minister said Sunday that the country hoped to send its armed forces to Tunisia to help stem the flow of illegal immigrants, after more than 3,000 Tunisians arrived by boat on an Italian island in recent days.

title: Heritage Shouldnt Reek of Mothballs
description: Heritage has been the prevailing buzzword in mens wear since stylish guys started gravitating toward labels that suggest, as marketers like to say, authenticity. You know the look: Filson tin cloth hunting jackets and woolly plaid shirts from Pendleton or Woolrich worn with Red Wing work boots.

title: Quad Q&A: Stanford Quarterback Andrew Luck
description: Andrew Lucks decision to return for his senior season as Stanfords quarterback drew both praise and criticism. Pete Thamel recently sat down with Luck to discuss the decision, how the Cardinal will do now that Jim harbaugh is no longer coach and what its like to run into Condoleeza Rice on campus.

title: China Works to Stave Off Wheat Crisis
description: HONG KONG  It is weather with global breadbasket implications.

title: The Shock of Losing a Spouse
description: Three years ago this month Joyce Carol Oates lost Raymond J. Smith, her husband of more than 47 years, after he was hospitalized with an apparent case of pneumonia and died of a secondary infection. She has written  unflinchingly, as her publisher inevitably puts it  about the pain and madness that enveloped her during the year that followed.

title: NASAs Second Close Encounter With a Comet
description: The last time NASA visited the Tempel 1 comet, it was with fireworks, on July 4, 2005. On that day, the Deep Impact spacecraft slammed an 820-pound projectile into Tempel 1, excavating a plume of ice and dust.

title: In Spokane, a Mystery With No Good Solution
description: SPOKANE, Wash.  The bomb was sophisticated and potentially deadly, but it did not detonate. No one was hurt, and no one has been arrested. So Spokane became a mystery.

title: New York Takes Step on Money in Judicial Elections
description: New Yorks top court officials will bar the states hundreds of elected judges from hearing cases involving lawyers and others who make significant contributions to their campaigns, a move that will change the political culture of courts and transform judicial elections by removing an important incentive lawyers have for contributing.

title: Closing the Achievement Gap Without Widening a Racial One
description: ALEXANDRIA, Va.  There is no more pressing topic in education today than closing the achievement gap, and there is no one in America who knows more about the gap than Ronald Ferguson.

title: Leniency of Sentence for Somali Hijacker Is at Issue
description: A Somali man who pleaded guilty to hijacking an American-flagged cargo ship off the coast of Africa is to be sentenced in Manhattan on Wednesday. His lawyers and the prosecutors disagree about whether he should be granted leniency because of his age and other factors.

title: Twin Journeys, Destination Unknown
Uneven Rise for Groupon in Japan
description: NIIGATA, Japan  In this blustery provincial city on Honshus northwest coast, dotted with rice paddies and pachinko parlors, a popular new service has people buzzing: Groupon.

title: JPMorgan to Start Social Media Fund
description: Hoping to seize upon investor excitement over social networking companies like Facebook, JPMorgan Chase is planning to start a new fund to invest in an array of Internet and new media companies, people briefed on the matter told DealBook on Sunday.

title: Thakoon: Masai Meets Marie Antoinette
description: At 6 p.m., editors and buyers were lined up in the lobby of the Plaza Hotel, waiting for one of two elevators to ferry them to grand ballroom on the third-floor for the Thakoon show. Ding. The doors of one were held open, but the guests were told to wait.

title: Campaigns for a Holiday That Marketers Love
description: IF you listen carefully this Valentines Day, you may hear men shouting love declarations from a mountaintop in California. But before you start looking at the man by your side and wondering why hes not doing the same thing, know that the screaming men are were hired by AT&T for the companys Valentines Day promotion.

title: Fake Liquors Flow as Demand Soars for Chinas Fabled Sorghum Spirit
description: MAOTAI, China  If history is indeed written by the victors, then this isolated mountain hamlet in southern Guizhou Province hit the jackpot when Red Army soldiers sought refuge here in the spring of 1935. Exhausted by their long-distance retreat from Nationalist forces, Maos guerrillas used the towns bracing 144-proof liquor to disinfect wounds, tame diarrhea and take the edge off their jangled nerves.

title: In Digital Era, Music Spotters Feed a Machine
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Sure, Shazam, the popular music-spotting cellphone application, can identify that Rihanna track. But what about the new song from the Sandwitches, a Bay Area folk-rock band?

title: Surfings Big Money Heading to Long Island
description: When Will and Cliff Skudins grandfather gave surfing lessons on an 11-foot longboard on Long Islands Gilgo Beach in the 1960s, it should have been easy to predict that surfing would grow in popularity in New York.

title: A Conglomerates Tack to Quash a Parody Site
description: Satire, George S. Kaufman once said, is what closes on Saturday night. And if that doesnt happen, some corporations may try to close it down in court.

title: Strat-O-Matic Devotees Celebrate Its 50th Anniversary
description: On July 15, 1990, Brett Carow, then 10 years old, and his father were killing time at a mall, looking at board games, when Bretts father suggested he might enjoy Strat-O-Matic Baseball, the popular dice-and-cards game. That proved a serious understatement.

title: A House Democrat Relishes Role Reversal
description: Two years ago, Representative Chris Van Hollen and fellow House Democrats were responsible for settingPresident Obamas legislative agenda in motion. It was heady, historic  and hard.

title: Charles E. Silberman, Who Wrote About Racism in the U.S., Dies at 86
description: Charles E. Silberman, a journalist whose books addressed vast, turbulent social subjects including race, education, crime and the state of American Jewry, died on Feb. 5 in Sarasota, Fla. He was 86 and had lived in Sarasota in recent years.

title: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: Word and Lyric, Giffords Labors to Speak Again
description: PHOENIX  Representative Gabrielle Giffords, an eloquent speaker before she was shot in the head last month, is relearning the skill  progressing from mouthing words and lip-syncing songs to talking briefly by telephone to her brother-in-law in space.

title: Oh, Right: The North Fought, Too
description: PEEKSKILL, N.Y.

title: Sports Illustrateds Bundled Android Subscriptions
description: Time Inc. has a memo for Apple: Were not waiting at the altar forever. We have Google.

title: New York Archbishop May Face Deposition on Milwaukee Funds
description: A lawyer for victims of sexual abuse by priests says he plans to seek depositions from Archbishop Timothy M. Dolan and other church officials over the lawyers accusations that the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Milwaukee, while Archbishop Dolan was its leader, moved $130 million off its books to avoid paying abuse claims.

title: A Cautious Approach Seeking Bipartisan Appeal
description: WASHINGTON  With the budget he is to unveil Monday, President Obama has not opted for the bold, comprehensive approach to reining in the fast-growing federal debt that his own fiscal commission has said is needed, now.

title: From 9/11 to 2/11
description: Cairo

title: Red Carpet at the 2011 Grammy Awards
description: Celebrity fashion at the annual music awards ceremony in Los Angeles.

title: Iranian Leaders Vow to Crush March
description: TEHRAN  The Iranian leaders who cheered the popular overthrow of an Egyptian strongman last week have promised to crush an opposition march planned for Monday in solidarity with the Egyptian people.

title: Optimism for Further Lift in Global Markets
description: Investors remain nervous about the longer-term picture in the Middle East, but the easing of tensions in Egypt removes one major worry for global markets and could encourage further gains in the short term, analysts say.

title: China Replaced Japan in 2010 as No. 2 Economy
description: TOKYO  Japans economy contracted in the fourth quarter when compared with the previous three months, though analysts are optimistic about the countrys prospects for the rest of the year.

title: Hilfiger Show Hits All the Seasons Trends
description: Tommy Hilfiger may someday be known as the patron saint of young designers. Mr. Hilfiger, over the years, has quietly invited several up-and-coming or struggling fashion stars to consult on his collections, though lately this has become a point of pride at the fashion company. The entire industry is obsessed with youth, and it benefits Mr. Hilfiger to have an outsiders perspective both in terms of his image and his clothes.

title: Tunisian Revolt Topples Midtown Cultural Center
description: Like many Tunisians living abroad, Naima Remadi Nour said she was overjoyed by the popular revolt in January that led to the ouster of the countrys authoritarian president, Zine el-Abidine Ben Ali.

title: Russia Reinstates a Reporter It Expelled
description: MOSCOW  A week after a British journalist was expelled from Russia, the authorities allowed him to return on Saturday night  all but acknowledging that they had made a mistake that had harmed the countrys effort to improve its image abroad.

title: G.E. to Buy John Wood Unit for $2.8 Billion
description: General Electric said on Sunday that it had agreed to buy the John Wood Groups well-support business for about $2.8 billion, as it sought to bolster its unconventional oil and natural gas production services.

title: D. A. Points, Playing With Bill Murray, Wins at Pebble Beach
description: PEBBLE BEACH, Calif.  As it almost always does, the Pebble Beach National Pro-Am delivered on Sunday. This time it was because the stars aligned behind the quirky dynamic of pros and amateurs inside the ropes at the same time, turning slapstick comedy into high drama and producing a compelling story line that could not be overshadowed even by the spectacle of the worlds three top-ranked players half a world away in Dubai.

title: A Chicken War in New York, Where Afghans Rule the Roost
description: Abdul Haye, the self-styled Colonel Sanders of New Yorks Afghan community, has declared a fried chicken war.

title: Appreciation of Old Hardships From a Richly Paid Beneficiary
description: On Thursday in Los Angeles, Kareem Abdul-Jabbar will screen his documentary, On the Shoulders of Giants: The Story of the Greatest Basketball Team You Never Heard Of, which tells the story of the legendary Harlem Renaissance Big Five.

title: Jews in U.S. Are Wary In Happiness For Egypt
description: Across the political spectrum, American Jewish leaders say that when they consider the future in Egypt and what it means for Israel, it is as if they are standing on a shaky tightrope stretched between poles of hope and dread.

description: DEAR DIARY:

In the Suburbs, When the Cold Is Biting, and So Are the Fish
description: Wind cut across the acres of frozen water, as dozens of ice fishermen trudged out at dawn, their astronaut-size waterproof boots fitted with metal spikes for better traction.

title: Twitter Feed Evolves Into a News Wire About Egypt
description: While people debated whether Web sites like Twitter were important in organizing protests in Tunisia and Egypt, Andy Carvin was organizing information about the protests in an innovative way.

description: The French Open will remain at Roland Garros Stadium in Paris and expand after a decision Sunday by French tennis federation officials.

title: Concussion Protocols Fail Vonn
description: She took silver  which, the thinking goes, means she was right.

title: A Tunisian-Egyptian Link That Shook Arab History
description: CAIRO  As protesters in Tahrir Square faced off against pro-government forces, they drew a lesson from their counterparts in Tunisia: Advice to the youth of Egypt: Put vinegar or onion under your scarf for tear gas.

title: Eat the Future
description: On Friday, House Republicans unveiled their proposal for immediate cuts in federal spending. Uncharacteristically, they failed to accompany the release with a catchy slogan. So Id like to propose one: Eat the Future.

title: In Defense of Marriage, for All
description: The 1996 Defense of Marriage Act is indefensible  officially sanctioned discrimination against one group of Americans imposed during an election year. President Obama seems to know that, or at least he has called on Congress to repeal it. So why do his governments lawyers continue to defend the act in court?

title: Running on Empty
description: The new financial regulation law gave the Securities and Exchange Commission a big new job to police hedge funds, derivatives dealers and credit agencies  some of the main culprits in the financial meltdown. It authorized raising the commissions budget to $2.25 billion, over five years. Now Congress is threatening to deny the S.E.C. the necessary financing to carry out its duties.

title: The Risk to Bristol Bay
description: Last year, the Obama administration permanently banned oil drilling in Alaskas Bristol Bay, Americas richest salmon fishery and the heart of a $2.2 billion regional fishing industry. One huge threat to this extraordinary ecosystem remains: a proposed gold and copper operation known as the Pebble Mine. If built, it would affect a huge area of clear-running headwater streams and wetlands that feed the bay.

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Wall Streets Dead End
description: THE stock market has been big news in recent days. Last weeks report that Deutsche Brse, a giant German exchange, intends to buy the New York Stock Exchange, creating a company worth some $24 billion, arrived shortly after the Dow broke the 12,000-point barrier for the first time since before the financial crisis.

title: Lottery Numbers
A Day Like Any Other, Shattered in a Knife-Flash
description: It was Saturday, shortly after 9 a.m.: Joseph Lozito was on his way to work at Lincoln Center.

title: States Aim Ax at Health Cost of Retirement
description: Governors and mayors facing large deficits have set their sights on a relatively new target  the soaring expense of health benefits for millions of retired state and local workers.

title: Scorecard | Alexander Wang Wins!
description: Hey, you there, want to know a secret to the Scorecard rankings game? If youre one of New Yorks wonderboy designers, dont show on the same day as Alexander the Great. For even if you manage to make critics kvell over your vamping up grunge or making Karlie Kloss look the height of Dickensian undone, the prince of downtown cool with an opening party Wednesday for his new flagship on Grand Street will go back to black and prove that this is Wangs world  we just play in it.

title: Before Deadly Rampage, Some Saw Warning Signs
description: He was caught up in drugs, some people said, as both a dealer and a user. Other people knew him for the graffiti he scrawled alongside a desolate freight line that runs between Brooklyn and Queens. They saw him as a short-tempered bully, who had come to the United States as a child from Ukraine and never found his way.

title: At Ethics Bowl, L.I. Teenagers Debate Slippery Issues
description: BETHPAGE, N.Y.  Ethics are a good thing, and almost everyone is said to have them. But by some accounts, they are like muscles in the brain, strong or atrophied, depending on exercise.

title: Hot Topics
description: Some of the cases debated on Saturday at the Long Island High School Ethics Bowl:

title: Netbooks Lose Status as Tablets Like the iPad Rise
description: Remember the Last Big Thing in computing? Youll be forgiven for having forgotten it was the netbook  a small notebook computer with a slender price tag, about $300.

title: Taking Sides in News Reports About a Luge Tracks Safety
description: OTTAWA  Last week, news reports appeared about an internal e-mail suggesting that nearly a year before a Georgian luge athlete crashed and died hours before opening ceremonies for the 2010 Winter Olympics, organizers were concerned that high speeds on their sliding track might result in a serious, possibly deadly accident.

description: The Times welcomes comments and suggestions, or complaints about errors that warrant correction. Comments on editorials may be e-mailed to letters@nytimes.com or faxed to (212) 556-3622.

title: News From the Advertising Industry
description: Accounts

title: Economic Reports for the Week
description: ECONOMIC REPORTS Scheduled for this week are retail sales and import prices for January, and business inventories for December (Monday); producer price index, housing starts and industrial production for January (Wednesday); weekly jobless claims, consumer price index and leading economic indicators for January, and the Philadelphia Fed manufacturing index for February (Thursday).

title: Prime Times for Smartphone Use
description: On weekdays, users of smartphones frantically start to make calls and send text messages just as work gets out, according to Zokem, a research company that tracks mobile consumption. But on weekends, they gear up in the early afternoon. E-mail use, by contrast, is flat throughout the day.

title: From Japan to Twins: Flash, but Less Brash
description: TOKYO  The Japanese infielder Tsuyoshi Nishioka is a brash opportunist with flair. Those traits were on display long before he signed this winter with the Minnesota Twins.

title: Schwarzenegger Tells Twitter Fans Hell Act Again
description: LOS ANGELES  Arnold Schwarzenegger, no longer the governor of California, told his Twitter followers on Thursday that he was back in the film business and looking for offers.

title: Landing the Jump From Gymnastics to Aerial Skiing
description: LAKE PLACID, N.Y.  Ashley Caldwell willed her body higher with every squeak of the trampoline. She started with basic head-over-heel back flips, then added midair twists as her confidence grew.

title: Betty Garrett, Antsy Cabby in On the Town, Is Dead at 91
description: Betty Garrett, the brassy comic actress who played Frank Sinatras ardent, taxi-driving pursuer in the movie On the Town, Archie Bunkers liberal foil of a neighbor in All in the Family and a sardonic landlady in Laverne & Shirley, died on Saturday in Los Angeles. She was 91.

title: Spreading Revolution
description: Six turning points helped to bring the people of Tunisia and Egypt, who have long felt abused by their governments, into the streets to revolt.

title: Intense Communication, via the Piano
description: Dozens of terrific pianists perform in New York every season, playing with impressive technique and thoughtful musicality. But only a few regularly cross the threshold of mere excellence to transporting brilliance.

title: Man Guilty of Aiding Al Qaeda Is Released Early From Prison
description: A Queens man who pleaded guilty in 2004 to helping terrorists and had a connection to the leader of the 2005 bombings of the London transit system has been released from prison after serving a small portion of his sentence, according to federal court documents.

title: U.S. Postpones Meeting With Pakistan and Afghanistan
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  The United States this weekend postponed high-level talks to be held in Washington with Pakistan and Afghanistan, a sign of the displeasure with Pakistan over the arrest of an American official accused of murder.

title: Word of the Day | iridescent
description: iridescent \ir--de-snt\ adjective

title: Grammys 2011 Winners
description: Lady Antebellum and Arcade Fire were among the big winners at the 53rd annual Grammy Awards, held Sunday night in Los Angeles.

title: A Swan Of Complex Shades
description: Will Natalie Portman be dancing Swan Lake? I cant help hoping the rumors are true: that people have called the ballet box offices in New York and London with that question. Certainly the film Black Swan helps explain why tickets to the New York City Ballets performances of Swan Lake are selling unusually fast.

title: In Dark Temple, Antiquitys Sober Doings
description: When the Metropolitan Opera gave the American premiere of Glucks Iphignie en Tauride in 1916, the critic for The New York Times, Richard Aldrich, praised the work but added, Whether the opera will make a place for itself in the admiration of this public is something of a question. It was too sober, too strange, he said, to be popular.

title: Student Players Leap Into Deep Water
description: It was brave of Mannes College the New School for Music to present its orchestra in a Maher program at Carnegie Hall on Wednesday evening. The works the Mannes Orchestra played  the Adagio from the unfinished Symphony No. 10, and Das Lied von der Erde  are hefty scores that make tremendous technical and interpretive demands on any orchestra, let alone a student group. And since this is a Mahler year  the centennial of his death  some of the worlds great orchestras have been bringing high-voltage performances of these pieces to New York.

title: Deconstructing Sousa, And Other New Ground
description: Bang on a Cans Peoples Commissioning Fund uses small contributions from the organizations fans to pay for new works scored for the Bang on a Can All-Stars. Three of those works were unveiled at the annual performance, on Thursday evening at Merkin Concert Hall, which this year was also part of the Kaufman Centers Ecstatic Music Festival. It was streamed live on Q2, WQXRs Internet-only station, and will have a later broadcast on WNYC (93.9 FM), as part of John Schaefers popular New Sounds program. (Mr. Schaefer, the concerts host, conducted enlightening interviews with the composers and performers between the works.)

title: A Touch Of Finian Friskiness
description: Because the theater and Hollywood composer Burton Lane wrote the music for only two major Broadway hits (Finians Rainbow, with lyrics by E. Y. Harburg, and On a Clear Day You Can See Forever, lyrics by Alan Jay Lerner), he is perennially treated as an also-ran in the pantheon of great American songwriters. Lane, who died in 1997 at 84, was a natural melodist, but he didnt fully come into his own until the late 1940s, when Harburg invited him to write the music for Finians and told him he wanted it to be as artistically lofty as Porgy and Bess. (George Gershwin had been Lanes close friend and mentor.)

title: Looking for Ms. Right, Online and in Sitcomland
description: In honor of Valentines Day I devote this review to new television about love, or more specifically to new television about how people get together in our crazy, frenetic, high-tech, isolating, fat-fearing world. As it is succinctly explained in When Strangers Click, an absorbing documentary about Internet dating (to be shown Monday on HBO2), women are terrified of meeting serial killers online; men are terrified of meeting women of above-average weight.

title: A Team to Help Earnhardt Jr. Live Up to His Name
description: If it is sometimes a burden to own the name Dale Earnhardt Jr., with all the pressure of expectations that comes with it, then it surely must be a challenge as well to own the racecars he drives.

title: Bright Melodies, Sometimes Offset by Dark Moods
description: Eliza Doolittle knows too much: How to be a slick, hungry soul singer, or a bashful jazz vocalist. How to write songs that make her sound modern, and how to write songs that make her sound like a well-preserved relic. How to use pouty lips and saucer eyes that stare out hard (with the certainty that few people will muster the temerity to stare back) to suggest that, just maybe, she knows even more than shes letting on.

title: Those Crazy Swans
description: With its unhinged ballerinas, lurid hallucinations, surfeits of blood and makeup, and one mad mother, the film Black Swan is hard to match as catnip for satirists of camp. The downtown theater artist Jack Ferver and his QWAN (Quality Without a Name) Company will take a stab with Swan!!!, a parody of the 2010 movie that will be staged as a dramatic reading from March 10 to 12 at Performance Space 122 in the East Village. The show is a follow-up to Mr. Fervers Notes!!!, a like-minded treatment of the Judi Dench-Cate Blanchett film Notes on a Scandal that developed a cult following during performances downtown last spring and fall. According to production notes Swan!!! focuses on the ballerina Nina (Natalie Portmans role in the film, played here by Jenn Harris), who is freaking out because she is crazy. Also crazy is her mother, played by Randy Harrison of Showtimes Queer as Folk (and Barbara Hershey in the movie); her Swan Lake choreographer; and a former prima ballerina. Mr. Ferver will play the hot new bad ballet girl in town, Lily (Mila Kunis in the film), who becomes Ninas frenemy. Mr. Ferver said in an interview that he had not gone through legal hoops with the creators of Black Swan because he and his collaborators were appropriating the work into a camp spectacle, meaning that parody is protected under fair-use exceptions to copyright law. It is going to be insane, Mr. Ferver promised. Black Swan has been nominated for five Academy Awards, including best picture and best actress for Ms. Portman; the Oscars ceremony is Feb. 27.

title: At the Grammys, Spectacles and Upsets
description: LOS ANGELES  Asserting the power and versatility of the new Nashville, the country-pop trio Lady Antebellum was the big winner at the 53rd annual Grammy Awards, which were presented on Sunday night at the Staples Center arena here.

title: Sandler Goes With It At the Box Office
description: Never bet against a crude Adam Sandler comedy. Just Go With It, about a man who pretends to be unhappily married to pick up women, was No. 1 at the box office over the weekend with about $31 million in ticket sales. Its the 11th movie starring Mr. Sandler (above, with Jennifer Aniston) to open in first place, according to Sony Pictures Entertainment, which bankrolled Just Go With It to the tune of $80 million. Justin Biebers 3-D concert movie, Never Say Never, was a close second for Paramount Pictures with an estimated $30.2 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles box office statistics. Gnomeo and Juliet (Walt Disney Studios), with Elton John songs, was third with about $25.5 million, benefiting from a lack of animated competition in the marketplace and a hefty marketing campaign. The Eagle, a Focus Features release starring Channing Tatum as a Roman soldier, was a distant fourth with a projected $8.6 million. The Roommate (Sony) was fifth in its second week of release with $8.4 million, bringing the total for that low-budget thriller to $26 million.

title: Iran in Brooklyn
description: Iran usually gets attention because of international politics, but the Brick Theater in Brooklyn wants to focus on the countrys rich cultural fare. From March 3 to 26 the Brick is hosting an Iranian Theater Festival with plays in Persian and English. The roster includes newly commissioned works from playwrights in Iran as well as plays by more established authors and groups, like the Iranian exile Assurbanipal Babillas Something Something Uber Alles and Two Stories That End in Suicide by Piehole, an experimental theater group in Brooklyn. Audiences will also be able to see The Hip-Hop Waltz of Eurydice and Quotations From a Ruined City, two works by Reza Abdoh, an Iranian-born artist who died in 1995 at the age of 32. Most tickets are $15 and can be purchased online at bricktheater.com or by calling(212) 352-3101.

title: Footnotes
description: s Runaway video featured ballerina characters last year. But a year earlier Princes Crimson and Clover video highlighted Misty Copeland of American Ballet Theater, and his association with the art form continues. Prince, left, has given Ballet Theater a $250,000 grant for arts education, along with gifts to the Uptown Dance Academy and the Harlem Childrens Zone, ABT announced on Friday. ... The Glee star Matthew Morrison said that he sings a duet with Elton John on his forthcoming CD, The Associated Press reported.

title: Ten Years On, Nascar Yearns for Another Intimidator
description: The Nascar circuit makes its pilgrimage to Daytona International Speedway twice every year, visits that inevitably rank among the highlights of any season. But not for the racecar owner Richard Childress. Each time he drives through the tunnel to the infield and looks at the track around him, Childress finds himself staring at perhaps the most sorrow-filled stretch of pavement on that hallowed ground.

title: A Dutch-British Hybrid Wins the NEC Cup
description: The 2011 NEC Cup, decided in Yokohama City, Japan, on Saturday, was captured by David Bakhshi and David Gold from England and Ricco van Prooijen and Louk Verhees from the Netherlands. They won by 142 international match points to 82, their opponents, Li Xiaoyi, Liu Haitao, Peng Jianfeng and Wang Kui from China, conceding after 48 of the scheduled 64 boards.

title: Highlights From the 53rd Annual Grammy Awards
description: Arcade Fire captured the album of the year award at the Grammys for the The Suburbs, a surprise win that left Eminem shut out in all the top categories.

title: Photo Replay, Feb. 13
description: A broad look at sports around the world on Sunday: soccer, handball, basketball, skiing, dogs.

title: Photo Replay: Dale Earnhardt
description: A look back at Dale Earnhardts accomplishments and the crash that ended his life in February of 2001.

title: A Mix of Genres and Generations
description: Hit makers of the present got the awards, the strobe lights, the rhinestones and the video razzle-dazzle. And titans from the 1960s got some respect on the 53rd annual Grammy Awards show, broadcast on CBS from the Staples Center in Los Angeles.

title: Scenes From Swan Lake
description: New York City Ballet performed Swan Lake Friday night at the David H. Koch Theater at Lincoln Center.

description: Test your math skills with todays question, created by Patrick Honner at Math for America from the article Maybe Japan Was Just a Warm-Up.

title: Daily Lexeme: Bumbaste
description: Todays word, in association with the brilliant Oxford English Dictionary, is

title: How Do You Feel About Valentines Day?
description: As you may have noticed, today is Valentines Day. Do you like this holiday? Hate it? Generally ignore it? Why? What memorable Valentines Day moments have you had, whether wonderful or awful? How will you celebrate this year?

title: Luminous Moods in Shards of Tiffany
description: Salvaging someone elses throwaways is a New York City tradition. But to this day, few curbside discoveries can compete in beauty and utility with what Vito DAgostino piled into his Model T almost 80 years ago.

title: To Cricket, With Love From Anshu Jain
description: You can rave and moan all you want about baseball, but the game has a global rival in cricket. And cricket now has a champion in the world of finance.

title: Clashes Erupt in Bahrain as Tumult Ripples Across Mideast
description: MANAMA, Bahrain  The police officers, 20 of them, raised their weapons and fired rubber bullets and canisters of tear gas directly into a small group of protesters chanting slogans and holding signs on Monday. One man fell instantly and was shot at as he squirmed on the ground. Another was trapped against a wall and writhed as an officer shot rubber bullets at him, again.

title: Egypt Army Sets 6-Month Blueprint, but Future Role Is Unclear
description: CAIRO  The military officers who have governed Egypt since the ouster of President Hosni Mubarak on Friday have laid out a brisk six-month timetable in which to draft constitutional amendments, submit them to a referendum and elect a new government, stirring debate about the militarys long-term intentions.

title: Credit Suisse Issues About $6 Billion in Contingent Bonds
description: Credit Suisse said on Monday that it had issued Qatar Holding and the Olayan Group about six billion Swiss francs worth of contingent convertible bonds, a fairly untested debt instrument.

title: The Early Word: Happy Budget Day
description: From Todays Times:

title: Tours of a London Palace Offer History and Ghosts
description: One of the more colorful characters from Tudor England, Henry the VIII, left behind marriage scandals, a country full of newly turned Protestants, and perhaps a few ghosts. Evidence of all of these, and many more of his legacies, can be found at Hampton Court Palace along the Thames River.

title: The Plight of Generation Un
description: Nancy Folbre is an economics professor at the University of Massachusetts Amherst.

title: Obamas Budget Focuses on Path to Rein In Deficit
description: WASHINGTON  With President Obamas release on Monday of a budget for next year and House action this week on a Republican plan for immediate deep spending cuts, the nation is getting its clearest view since the president took office of the parties competing visions of the role of government, the urgency of addressing the deficit and the best path to long-term economic success.

title: Congressional Week Ahead
description: After last week proposing $100 billion in federal spending cuts, House Republicans will consider going even deeper this week as their bill to fund the federal government through Sept. 30 hits the floor.

title: Tunisia Rejects Italian Plan to Deploy Forces Against Illegal Immigrants
description: ROME  Tunisia on Monday rejected Italys offer to send its armed forces to help stop what one Italian official called an unprecedented biblical exodus.

title: Iran Uses Force Against Protests as Region Erupts
description: Hundreds of riot police officers in Iran beat protesters and fired tear gas Monday to contain the most significant street protests since the end of the 2009 uprising there, as security forces around the region moved  sometimes brutally  to prevent new unrest in sympathy with the opposition victory in Egypt.

title: Europe Seeks Ways to Lower Data Roaming Charges
description: BARCELONA  The European telecommunications commissioner said on Monday that she probably would seek new regulations to end the high charges Europeans face when using data services on smartphones outside their home countries.

title: Tinkering With a Longer N.F.L. Season
description: Commissioner Roger Goodell has said that fans are behind the plan to expand the season to 18 games. He has cited their dissatisfaction with the quality of preseason play, and he said they simply  want more football.

title: A Barn-Find Bentley, With Papers to Prove It
description: Being able to document the history of a collectible car adds significantly to its value. Finding an undisturbed vintage vehicle  with complete service records, sale invoices, owners manuals, log books and period photos  gives car enthusiasts a sensation probably akin to that of archaeologists who find an unrobbed royal tomb.

title: For Indias Farmers, a Bare-Bones Drip System
description: During a recent trip to a rural part of western India to report on rising food prices, I met two kinds of farmers  those with access to irrigation and those without. The differences between the two were stark.

title: Palestinian Leader Dissolves Cabinet
description: JERUSALEM  The prime minister of the Palestinian Authority dissolved his cabinet on Monday and was immediately reappointed by the president to form a new one. It was the latest in a series of political steps taken by the authority after the popular uprisings in Tunisia and Egypt.

description: Stocks were mostly higher on Monday, sending the Standard & Poors 500-stock index to an almost 32-month high, helped by optimism about Egypts democratic transition plan and a decline in Chinas trade surplus.

title: Violence Erupts on Fourth Day of Protests in Yemen

description: Casablanca Capital, an activist hedge fund, on Monday put forward a slate of three nominees  for the board of Mentor Graphics, as it presses for change at the software company.

title: Passengers Speak Out in Taxi Survey
description: Passengers in New York City taxicabs like to pay by credit card. They take cabs because they are late, tired or weighted down by unwieldy bags, and they are most likely to hail a taxi once a week. Cabs should be easier to get in and out of, they say, and those backseat televisions ought to be banned entirely.

title: A Fateful Call for Colin Firth
description: It wasnt a total rout for The Kings Speech Sunday night at the Baftas, the British version of the Oscars. The ur-British movie did take home trophies for best film, best British film, best original screenplay, best score and best acting prizes for Geoffrey Rush, Helena Bonham Carter and Colin Firth. But David Fincher won best director for The Social Network, which also took best adapted screenplay for Aaron Sorkin. Mr. Sorkin attended, Mr. Fincher did not  hes shooting The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo  so his award was accepted by his stars Jesse Eisenberg and Andrew Garfield. But it was Mr. Firths speech that was the hit of the event in London on Sunday night. (Mr. Firth also won a Bafta last year, for A Single Man.)

title: Vain Glorious | Juicy News
description: The high-end company Organic Avenue, which offers cold-pressed raw juices and smoothies a la carte or as part of structured cleanses, began a decade ago in the Lower East Side apartment of Denise Mari and was soon embraced by fashion and health devotees alike. The various beverages are now made in Long Island City, Queens, and shipped to doorsteps and counters at the Norma Kamali store and David Barton Gym, as well as to the brands brick-and-mortar outposts, of which two more locations have just been added  one in SoHo and one on the Upper East Side.

title: Gulf Suffered a Gas Surge, Study Finds
description: A new scientific paper reports that so much natural gas flowed into the Gulf of Mexico during last summers oil spill that, in spots, the amount in the ocean reached 75,000 times the normal background amount.

title: Russia Sells Stake in State-Owned Lender VTB
description: Russia raised $3.3 billion selling a minority stake in the state-owned bank VTB Group, the lender said on Monday in a London Stock Exchange filing.

title: Richard Chai and Patrik Ervell Stick to Their Guns
description: There were quite a few mens wear shows around the city over the weekend, more than I can remember in a while, and, alas, too many to cram into todays review. A couple that I did see, Richard Chai and Patrik Ervell, I thought were excellent, and for the same reason: Each designer seems to be intent on refining a signature look until he reaches its apotheosis.

title: IFC Orders Second Season of Portlandia
description: The dream of the 90s will remain alive at least through 2012: IFC announced on Monday that it had picked up a new batch of episodes of Portlandia, its original comedy series created by Fred Armisen of Saturday Night Live and Carrie Brownstein, a former guitarist and singer of the rock band Sleater-Kinney. The series, which chronicles a fanciful, not-all-that-alternate-from-reality version of the slacker paradise of Portland, Ore. (and which gave rise to hit viral videos like Dream of the 90s ), has become a modest hit for IFC. The cable channel, which has been emphasizing a lineup of new and classic comedy programs alongside its schedule of independent films, said the first three episodes of Portlandia have been viewed by 1.1 million total viewers, with most of them in the 18-49 age group that recognizes the grunge bands referenced on the show and the cameo appearances by Kyle MacLachlan and Aimee Mann. IFC said the second season of Portlandia, consisting of 10 half-hour episodes, will make its debut in January.

title: Insider Trading, the Valentines Edition
description: Romance is not the first thing that comes to mind when we think about insider trading. But after all, its Valentines Day.

title: Head in the Stars, Feet on the Ground
description: BOSTON  Gazing upward I can see the skylines of Cambridge and Boston on the horizon as twilight falls. In the growing hush of full darkness, more than 9,000 stars appear, with so many gradations of intensity that binoculars can reveal more detail than the naked eye. And as I lean back in cushioned comfort, I am gradually swept off into the heavens.

title: Afghan Guards Called Heroes After Thwarting Attack
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The heroes in the suicide bombing at the Kabul City Center shopping mall on Monday were not among the police officers or NATO coalition and American Special Forces soldiers who showed up later.

title: Confusion and Abs: Everybody!
description: Since I was once an aerobics instructor (yes, its true), I can say with some authority that the average teaching outfit doesnt include a diaperlike confection around your loins, a leopard-print shrug and a garland of balloons. And most participants do not come to class wearing a body suit with a fake penis, a tutu or an animal mask. But at Miguel Gutierrezs DEEP Aerobics at Danspace Project on Thursday night, such was the attire of the instructor (Mr. Gutierrez) and audience members who opted to take part as students. (A transformation station was on hand for those who didnt arrive in appropriate outfits.)

Several video clips said to show protests and clashes in villages outside Bahrains capital, Manama, late Sunday and Monday morning have been posted on YouTube.

title: Big Love Watch: A Family in Crisis
description: Im the sunny face of polygamy. Lets just acknowledge that this line, delivered by Margene, was surely the best of Sundays episode of Big Love. Margene, who is getting deeper into the crazy pyramid scheme that is Goji juice, has also become the spokeswoman for a family increasingly in crisis. But before we get to that and the impending divorce proceedings, I have a bone to pick with the haphazard unfolding of the episode. The matter of Alby hiring Verland to attack Don during his ice fishing trip felt random and pointless. This is the best way the writers could think of for Albys getting back at Bill for getting Lura away from him? Even as the scene was transpiring it seemed as if the writers were doing it on a lark and were fully conscious that the plotting was arbitrary and almost jokey. (The jaunty music accompanying the attack made this especially clear.)Also: Bills mothers dementia isnt feeling fully integrated either. Her dementia may be relevant to the seasons theme of the Henricksons general deterioration, but beyond that symbolic value, its hard to see how Loiss condition will matter much to the final outcome of the show. Another plot development that felt half-baked was the sudden turnaround of Bills fate at the legislature. The tabling of the impeachment felt way too abrupt.

title: Gingrichs Energy Policies Rile Conservative Critics

title: A Renovator Gets a Taste of Compromise

title: In Former C.E.O.s Words, the Last Days of Lehman Brothers
description: The few public statements by Richard S. Fuld Jr. about the demise of Lehman Brothers have often been in front of the glare of a Congressional panel. In 2008, Mr. Fuld, the investment banks chief executive, known for his temper, appeared defensive and angry during televised testimony in which he faced a barrage of pointed and politically charged questions. As one congressman noted at the time, Mr. Fuld was the designated villain.

title: Dale Earnhardt Jr.s Front-Row Seat
description: If the past week shed unflattering spotlight on some sports in desperate need of a public relations boost, they are now being bumped out of the top spot by Nascar. After two years of fiascos derailing its showcase Daytona 500 (see: monsoon, 2009; potholes, 2010), the driving-in-circles set could use a lift  and being reminded that it has been 10 years since Dale Earnhardt was killed in this race does not exactly fall in the uplifting category.

title: A Fight to Win the Future: Computers vs. Humans
description: STANFORD, Calif.  At the dawn of the modern computer era, two Pentagon-financed laboratories bracketed Stanford University. At one laboratory, a small group of scientists and engineers worked to replace the human mind, while at the other, a similar group worked to augment it.

title: For Suspect, Ties to Possible Path to Escape

title: Todays To-Do List
description: The restaurant is closed. The hiatus is exhausting. Here I am, with endless commitments, meetings, telephone calls, e-mails. Lists appear on paper plates and backs of envelopes. So many things to do. So many friends left in the lurch in this Facebook world. So many tennis ball cans unopened.

title: Backstage Beauty | Thakoon
description: I was really looking at tribes, at the different sorts of tribes and tribal sensibilities and habitual things tribes do, from the Masai tribe culture to the people during the Rococo period, the designer Thakoon Panichgual said backstage before his fall show. There was a sense of uniformity about the way that they were dressing. This translated into a collection he described as electric, and for the hair and makeup, Panichgual said he decided to go for bold instead of tempering the clothes with a basic look. The makeup artist Diane Kendal used Nars Velvet Matte Lip Pencil in Dragon Girl on eyelids and on top of it, and applied three blushes  Desire, Taj Mahal and Exhibit A, in that order from inner lid to outer lid to an ombre effect  which she blended out past the bleached eyebrows. We wanted to have that feeling of sun and hotness but then also exotic, Kendal explained. The hairstyle created by Odile Gilbert using Kerastase products echoed that sentiment, with pieces provided by the designer weaved into a complicated-looking updo. Panichgual explained, The hair is superslick  almost posh, really  in the front, and then its pulled back and its got this weird chignon whipped up with yarn and hats that weve cut up and put into the bun. Theres a reality base there, but its a bit hyper.

title: Slimmer Sabathia Noncommittal About Contract

Sabathia improved his eating habits and exercised twice a day to shed 25 pounds after undergoing knee surgery in October, he said, a change that could help extend his career  and position himself for another lucrative long-term deal after this season. Sabathia can opt out of his seven-year contract at the end of the season, and for the first time he did not rule out the possibility of exploring free agency again.

But what separates those young talents from sophisticated veterans is the discretion to isolate the right play and the patience to wait for it.

title: New Budget Includes Increase for the Smithsonian Institution
description: President Obamas proposed budget for fiscal year 2012 includes $861.5 million for the Smithsonian Institution, an increase of $100 million over the Smithsonians last appropriation, in fiscal year 2010. The difference is accounted for by $125 million the administration is requesting for the construction of the National Museum of African American History and Culture, set to open in 2015. The Smithsonians 2010 appropriation included $20 million for the museums design and planning process. The museums total construction budget is $500 million, half of which is being paid for by the federal government.

description: Just when you were looking forward to an almost-shirtsleeve day with a predicted high of 52 degrees, lets talk snow. But in a good way.

title: Numberplay: The Musical Shuffle
description: Today is Valentines Day, a day when you want to set the romantic mood by choosing the perfect music. To inspire us, last night was one of the music worlds biggest nights: the Grammy Awards. All you have to do now is to pick the right songs  todays digital musical players and smartphones make it a snap to select them from your playlist to suit every mood. But what if you were stuck with a player that (thanks to Apples marketing genius) makes a virtue of randomness, like the iPod shuffle? This is the conundrum that gives rise to a fascinating puzzle contributed by Dion Wong of Australia. Previously, in When Randomness Produces Certainty, we saw how randomness acting over and over can create order. The question that arises in Dions puzzle is: How can we optimally combine randomness and order? Its a fitting question for today because, no matter how orderly a plan you might have made for a perfect Valentines Day, randomness might just intervene. And the connection of randomness to the Grammy Awards ceremony is clear too  what random pattern of clothes (or what passes for them) did Lady Gaga wear? That might take us too far afield, so without further ado, heres the puzzle.

title: Asked & Answered | Xavier
description: Artists as diverse as Ashford and Simpson, Lena Horne, Del Marquis of the Scissor Sisters and Bread and Puppet Theater have all had the pleasure of being sung to, backed by or collaborating with Xavier Smith, a dreadlocked, extremely tall (66) fixture on the downtown Manhattan performance circuit. For the past several years, Smith  who grew up in New York, has a gently soulful voice and prefers to be called simply Xavier (with a hard X, he notes, like Ex-ayvier)  has produced a Valentines song as a love letter to his friends, fans and whomever he might have been in love with that year. It started in 2004 with a cover of the Beatles In My Life, and this years offering is a heartbreaking rendition of Curtis Mayfields The Makings of You set to a small orchestral arrangement. From Bushwick, Brooklyn, where Xavier lives with Dima, his once-vicious but now sweet Himalayan blue-eyed cat, Xavier told T why he does the yearly Valentines song.

title: Aid Cuts Have Texas Schools Scrambling
description: HUTTO, Tex.  The school superintendent in this rural town outside the state capital has taken steps to trademark the districts oddly un-Texan school mascot  the Hutto Hippo  in a frantic effort to raise cash. He is also planning to put advertisements on school buses and to let retailers have space on the school Web site.

title: Obamas Budget Proposes a Significant Increase for Schools
description: President Obama proposed a 2012 Department of Education budget on Monday that would, if approved, significantly increase federal spending for public schools, and maintain the maximum Pell grant  the cornerstone financial-aid program  at $5,550 per college student.

title: Trade and Monetary Issues Top Agenda at G-20
description: PARIS  Developed economies still recovering from the financial crisis are looking for ways to regain momentum as the global economy shifts in favor of China and other emerging markets.

title: Valuable Artifacts Missing From Egyptian Museum
description: A full inventory of the Egyptian Museum in Cairo has found that 18 valuable artifacts are now missing after a break-in on Jan. 28, Egypts antiquities minister, Zahi Hawass, wrote on his blog on Sunday. Previously, Mr. Hawass had only said that objects were damaged. Among the most important of the missing items are a limestone statue of the god Akhenaten holding an offering table and a gilded wooden statue of Tutankhamen being carried by a goddess. On Monday, however, CNN reported that 2 of the 18 objects  a heart scarab and a funerary statuette of the nobleman Yuya  had been found on museum grounds. Mr. Hawass also said that a storeroom at Dahshur was broken into on Saturday night. He told Ahram Online that eight amulets were missing. Meanwhile, there were accounts on Twitter of protests outside the offices of the Supreme Council of Antiquities, the government body run by Mr. Hawass, who was appointed by former President Hosni Mubarak.

title: Morning T | Michael Kors
description: In this installment of our video interview series, Horacio Silva sits down with Michael Kors, known to many of the television-viewing public as a judge on Bravos Project Runway, and to fewer as the designer whose disastrous show partly led to the creation of New York fashion week. Among the topics discussed: growing up in Merrick, Long Island, his fashion world bombast on Project Runway, and his 30 years in fashion. His advice to designers? Stay light on your feet, and be ready for whatevers gonna happen. Something always does.

title: A Plastic Heart That Beat for Three Days
description: Nearly 42 years ago, the worlds first artificial heart was implanted in a history-making operation at St. Lukes Hospital in Houston.

title: European Officials Want to Expand Bailout Fund
description: BRUSSELS  European finance ministers said on Monday that they wanted their permanent rescue fund to be able to lend 500 billion euros  double its current lending capacity  beginning in 2013, but held off making any formal decisions.

title: Few Significant Changes in Energy-Area Spending
description: WASHINGTON  President Obamas budget, released Monday, essentially treads water on energy and the environment, trying to maintain momentum for alternative energy research even as it cuts deeply into some environmental protection programs.

title: S.E.C. Questioned on Disclosure of Criminal Inquiries
description: It is no mystery that the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Justice Department work closely together in pursuing cases, often filing parallel criminal and civil cases on the same day. For lawyers involved in S.E.C. investigations, an important consideration is whether there is any criminal interest in the case  information that the agency has historically been loath to reveal.

title: Can Polio Be Eradicated? A Skeptic Now Thinks So
description: Two weeks ago, at the end of an interview about whether polio really can be eradicated, Bill Gates muttered aloud to an aide escorting the interviewer: Ive got to get my D. A. Henderson response down better.

title: Japan Plans Worlds Fastest Train
description: For decades, Japan has been at the forefront of high-speed rail technology. Now, the Central Japan Railway Company has announced that it plans to build the fastest train in the world, between Tokyo and Nagoya, to be completed by 2027.

title: Unrest Spreads Across the Mideast
description: Antigovernment demonstrations appeared in Iran, Yemen and Bahrain Monday.

title: Taking Her Art Seriously, Not Herself
description: LOS ANGELES  Judi Dench has been a Dame of the British Empire for 23 years. She has an Oscar, a Tony, two Golden Globes and nine Baftas. The greatest stage actress of all time? Maybe. A recent London poll thought so.

title: New Help for Figuring Out a Used Cars Worth
description: If youre in the market for a used car or want to sell your used car, you may want to check out a new free tool from TrueCar Inc. called ClearBook.com.

title: Upheaval Opens the Exits in Tunisia
description: SEDOUIKECH, Tunisia  A dozen young men left this village of olive groves and whitewashed houses near the Mediterranean coast last week, bound for the Italian island of Lampedusa aboard an overcrowded fishing boat. They were part of a flotilla of would-be migrants that has created a humanitarian crisis and stirred a political furor in Italy.

title: Photos of the Moment | Duro Olowu
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#143", 592, 440, true, chameleonData);

title: New York Fashion Week: Moncler Fall 2011
description: The Moncler fashion show included a flash mob at Grand Central Station and included 150 dancers and 300 extras.

title: PCBs 5, New York 0: School Tests Continue
description: The pattern is by now well established: the fifth New York City school building inspected by the federal Environmental Protection Agency for contamination with PCBs showed results above the regulatory limits.

title: Zimbabwe: Fewer Extramarital Partners and Dollars Push Precipitous Decline in H.I.V. Rate
description: Defying expectations in a region devastated by AIDS, rates of H.I.V. infection in Zimbabwe have fallen precipitously in the last decade.

title: Obama Budget Upholds Energy Research
description: John M. Broder reports that President Obamas proposed 2012 budget, unveiled on Monday, seeks to maintain momentum for research on alternative energy but would cut deeply into some environmental protection programs.

title: Shedding a Protective Cocoon, Woven by Delusions
description: The woman described the sensation as a delicate flicker, like a moth trapped in a small gauze bag. She ran her slender fingers repeatedly over the spot in her slightly distended abdomen and said, Doctor, right here.

title: Florence Welch at the Grammys
description: In the profile of Florence Welch, lead singer of Florence and the Machine, that ran in the Sunday Styles section this weekend, Ms. Welch and her stylist, Aldene Johnson, were somewhat coy about what fashion choices they would be making for the Grammys on Sunday night.

title: A Simple Map to the Land of Wholesome
description: For the first time since it began issuing dietary guidelines, the government offered new recommendations last month that clearly favor the health and well-being of consumers over hard-lobbying farm interests.

title: Cold, Hard Facts
description: Q. My husband, in his late 80s, has already had three colds this year. You would think I would catch them, but I do not. Early in his career he would become anxious around the first of each month  and catch a cold. Does stress make colds more likely?

title: Eye to Eye With a Murder Suspect
description: How does it feel to come face to face with a man whom the police have charged with murdering four people and assaulting two others in the last two days? Michael Appleton, a 33-year-old freelance photographer on assignment for The New York Times, describes his experience  from about four feet away  covering Maksim Gelmans arrival at Central Booking in Brooklyn on Sunday. On Lens.

title: A College Opts Out of the Admissions Arms Race
description: In an era in which universities are expected to draw more and more applicants each year  as if they were Fortune 500 companies being forced to show annual profits  Ursinus College, a liberal arts institution outside of Philadelphia, would seem to have little reason to celebrate this year.

title: Pacemaker, 1933
description: On Sunday, June 11, 1933, The New York Times reported on a meeting of the American Medical Association that would begin the next day. Along with exhibits on high-voltage X-ray treatment of cancer, on instruments used in famous murder cases and on poisons removed from the organs of homicide victims, it said, Here will be demonstrated the artificial pacemaker, by which hearts that have stopped beating may sometimes be resuscitated.

title: Reader Ideas | Three Ways to Weave In The Times
description: Here is another in our Great Ideas From Readers series.

title: Backstage Beauty | Carolina Herrera
description: Few designers create pieces as timeless as Carolina Herrera, and backstage at her fall show, the beauty team was hard at work creating a look to match. The makeup artist Diane Kendal painted on what she called a classic Carolina face: black cream eyeliner on the top lash line only with a bit of a wing, M.A.C. Haute and Naughty Mascara only on outer lashes, M.A.C. Eye Gloss on lids and M.A.C. Blush in Angel on the cheeks. On the lips were using a new [M.A.C.] color called Prince Noir, and were applying it with a lip brush and then blotting it with tissue so it gives a really beautiful stained burgundy look, Kendal said. Nails were kept relatively short and painted with two coats of a shade from Creative Nail Design called Dark Ruby followed by a generous coat of Super Shiney Top Coat, to contrast the matte textures such as fur, velvet, suede, said CNDs Wanda Ruiz. The hairstylist Orlando Pita, who took the big, beautiful necklines into account when creating his polished, rolled bun-chignon hybrid using Moroccanoil products, clearly also had the Carolina Herrera client in mind. Ive seen messy updos for a long, long time, and Im moving away from them, he said. This collection is too polished for that.

title: Transformers Land in New York, and the City Responds
description: As part of the American International Toy Fair in New York this week, Hasbro parked Optimus Prime, the hero of the Transformers movie series, on 41st Street near 8th Avenue in front of The TimesCenter, where Hasbro is displaying its line of toys.

title: Mens Fall Fashion 2011 | Calvin Klein
description: Italo Zucchellis explored proportion and volume in addition to the signature tech-y fabrications hes compelled by in his latest Calvin Klein show. In a nod to the late 80s style of Rhythm Nation, models in caps and closely-cropped hair marched in oversized, drop-shoulder bomber jackets and slim pants in heavy felted wool in charcoal and olive drab. It made for a mildly militaristic look that was quite arresting.

title: Donna Karans White Winter
description: This is a call to power for women, Donna Karan said after showing her collection, which was called Pearls of Wisdom.

title: TimesCast | February 14, 2011
description: Unrest reignites across the Middle East; Egypts military proposes reforms; and when will the tourists return to the pyramids?

title: Obama Proposes Bigger Budget for Regulator
description: 8:28 p.m. | Updated

title: For Grammys, the Best Ratings in a Decade
description: The pattern of growing interest in live big events on television continued Sunday night with the Grammy Awards on CBS, which expanded its audience even over the 2010 edition, when the show recorded a huge 35 percent increase.

title: Pictures of the Day: Bahrain and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Bahrain, Iran and Egypt.

title: Walk Like a Man
description: At the Calvin Klein mens show on Sunday, one model walked into a wall, a few awkwardly bumped into each other as they passed on the runway, and one looked as if he was going to keel over from the sheer effort of trying to walk in a straight line.

title: Calm Even Around Maoist Guerrillas, Shes the Girl for Me
description: IM not your average American business traveler. Ive lived and worked on four different continents: North America, Europe, South America and Australia.

title: Recalled Devices Mostly Untested, New Study Says
description: Most medical devices recalled in recent years by the Food and Drug Administration because they posed a high risk to patients were not rigorously studied before being cleared for sale, according to a study in a medical journal released Monday.

title: Backstage Grooming | Billy Reid
description: Unlike designers who approach collections with a particular theme or era in mind, Billy Reid, the recipient of this years CFDA/Vogue Fashion Fund, designs his piece by piece, which explains his infectious passion for the unique. For his fall collection, Reid said backstage, My focus was on construction, a lot of tailoring. I spent an inordinate amount of time perfecting each piece. My mens looks are cleaner, with more subtle details than before. In line with Reids penchant for individuality, the hairstylist Marcos Diaz created looks that were groomed but not Don Draper. Using just the newly launched Mat Forming Ground from Davines (a supermatte clay) and his fingers, Diaz formed a natural-looking side part and left the rest of the hair dry-looking and clean. Emphasizing approachability, Diaz said, Im interested in keeping hair more realistic, something you could easily create at home. The makeup artist Nadine Luke relied on a few key players from M.A.C. and her belief of a little goes a long way for mens makeup. Luke hydrated skin with Studio Moisture Fix, concealed as necessary, moisturized lips with Lip Conditioner, and tamed unruly brows with Brow Set (which she considers a guys secret weapon, as it instantly grooms both brows and mustaches). Luke finished the look with Mineralize Skinfinish, a shimmer-free bronzer that contours and provides a matte finish in a pinch, noting that Billy Reids guy is someone you wouldnt imagine grooming because hes slightly rugged. But really, hes a polished gentleman.Runway slide show

title: When Love Meant Letters
description: Speaking of love and the Army, there is an exhibit at the National Army Museum in London chronicling the letters exchanged between soldiers in battle and those they left at home. The hundreds of pages  some from as far back as 200 years ago  capture a longing and a loneliness that will sound familiar even to modern lovers who close the distance with tools like Skype.

title: Dale Earnhardt Jr. Earns Daytona 500 Pole Position
description: Nearly 10 years after the death of his father at the same speedway, Dale Earnhardt Jr. averaged 186.09 miles per hour in his Chevrolet on Sunday to earn pole position for the Sprint Cup Series Daytona 500, scheduled for Feb. 20. It was the second consecutive Daytona 500 pole for Earnhardts team, Hendrick Motorsports, which also won the coveted starting-line position in 2010 behind Mark Martins qualifying performance.

title: Photos of the Moment | Calvin Klein for Men
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#438", 592, 440, true, chameleonData);

title: Photo Replay: Feb. 14
description: The day in sports included the super combined at the world ski championships in Germany and the first signs of spring at baseball stadiums in Florida.

title: Pictures of the Day: Bahrain and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Bahrain, Iran and Egypt.

title: Tough Without a Gun
description: The End Depends on the Beginning

title: Fostering Progress on a Finite (and Budget Strapped) Planet
description: 9:13 p.m. | Updated Dueling budgets are now out from House Republicans and the White House, and particularly intense fights are already under way over what to slash and what to preserve  whether your interest is environmental protection or heating assistance for the poor.

title: Overseas Travelers Set Record for Citys Airports
description: Despite the hard economic times around the world, New York City was more popular than ever for international travelers last year, according to statistics compiled by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.

title: Forsbergs Sad Goodbye
description: Peter Forsbergs latest comeback of sorts  all of two games long, neither of which was played in front of the Colorado Avalanche fans who adore him  is a tough way to bid goodbye to one of the games great players. Forsberg will never show up in a lot of all-time great lists because his career was hampered by injuries, but those who watched him in his prime can recount tales of one of the most gifted players on the planet. His two Stanley Cups, two Olympic gold medals, one Hart Trophy and 885 career points in 708 games are ample evidence as well.

title: Wades Peculiar Struggles Against Boston Continue
description: The Miami Heat of last season were equal parts depressing and inspiring. The Heat roster (Dwyane Wade aside) was limited, and as a result, Jermaine ONeal and Michael Beasley became the pillars on which Miami was forced to stand. Their season wasnt one of disaster, merely of reality; although the Heat had the leagues sixth-best defense, they lacked competent offensive players to produce consistently or distract defenses away from Wade.

title: Making a Mighty Sound for Berlioz, but Delicately
description: Given that practically every piece left to us by the French composer Hector Berlioz offers examples of his vivid, unruly imagination, it comes as no surprise that his Requiem, an 1837 adaptation of the Roman Catholic Mass setting, takes impracticality to an extreme virtually unknown in his day, and hardly more common in ours. Among its more outlandish features is the small army required to perform it: an orchestra 140 strong, including a small cadre of timpanists; 210 choristers; and additional phalanxes of brass players offstage.

title: Talent Is What Made Him Dangerous
description: He was the very image of the quintessential American hero  loyal, unsentimental, plain-spoken. An idealist wary of causes and ideology. A romantic who hid his deeper feelings beneath a tough veneer. A renegade who subscribed to an unshakeable code of honor.

title: New York Fashion Week: Under the Influence
description: Young designers like Joseph Altuzarra and Jason Wu are taking design cues from vetern designers like Oscar de la Renta and Carolina Herrera.

title: A Soulful, Virtuosic Player Holding the Spotlight Alone
description: The Brazilian guitarist Odair Assad performs mostly as half of the Assad Brothers, and though his older brother, Srgio, has pursued an independent musical life as a composer, arranger and player, Odair, until recently, seemed disinclined to build a solo career.

title: Central Park, 1:37 P.M.
description: The juvenile red-tailed hawk that injured his wing crashing into the glass-walled atrium at the headquarters of The New York Times last month was released at Tupelo Meadow in the Ramble at Central Park, after a recuperative stay at Wildlife in Need of Rehabilitation and Rescue on Long Island.

title: The Silence of the Fishers
description: Roland Kays, curator of mammals at the New York State Museum, writes from Albany, where he is comparing the behavior of fishers in urban and wild settings.

title: Perez Tells Mets He Wants to Start
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Oliver Perez, one of the more vilified Mets in team history, was back on the field Monday and threw his first ball on a Mets mound since his last, disastrous appearance, in the last inning of the last game of a very forgettable 2010 season.

title: Superstar Tenor Grapples With the Operatic Canon
description: Even if it doesnt know a thing about singing, even if it cant tell Handel from Haydn, an audience perceives when a singer is uncomfortable. You can feel it in the air, hear it in the applause.

title: Risks: Side Effects Fueled by High-Energy Drinks
description: A wide-ranging review of the effects of high-caffeine energy drinks on children and young adults finds that they have been linked to an array of serious events  including heart palpitations, high blood pressure and even cardiac arrest and death  and may pose special risks to young people who take medication or have chronic illnesses.

title: As Games Shrink, an Industry Considers Growth
description: LAS VEGAS  Mike Morhaime, co-founder, president and chief executive of Blizzard Entertainment, is one of the most successful people in the history of video games. His company  home of the Diablo, StarCraft and Warcraft franchises  is known for spending many years and many millions of dollars making some of the worlds deepest and most extensive games.

title: Wariness on Surgery of the Mind
description: In recent years, many psychiatrists have come to believe that the last, best chance for some people with severe and intractable mental problems is psychosurgery, an experimental procedure in which doctors operate directly on the brain.

title: Carlyle Names Chief Financial Officer
description: The Carlyle Group has named Adena T. Friedman as chief financial officer, a move that will fuel further speculation that the private equity giant is moving closer to an initial public offering.

title: Ridding a Moody Cunningham Work of Ambiguity, One Gesture at a Time
description: The small-scale New York Theater Ballet concentrates on repertory overlooked by larger troupes. Often enough its stagings of rare works add to the knowledge of most dancegoers. Sometimes the fare, however, makes it look merely quaint. Both aspects were on display in the Signatures 11 program last weekend at Gould Hall, sometimes within the same offering.

title: Extra, Extra! Newsies Musical to Open Paper Mill Playhouse Season
description: Stop the presses! Or should that be, restart the presses? Either way, Newsies, the misunderstood but much-loved Disney movie musical about the New York City newsboys who organize a labor strike in 1899, is getting a second edition. On Monday, the theater said that a stage version of Newsies would be the opening production at the 2011-12 season of the Paper Mill Playhouse in Millburn, N.J., and would feature music by Alan Menken (the films original composer) and Jack Feldman (its original lyricist) as well as a new book by Harvey Fierstein.

title: 'Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind'
description: A. O. Scott looks back at Michel Gondry and Charlie Kaufman's film about loss, memory and love.

title: Web of Popularity, Achieved by Bullying
description: For many teenagers navigating the social challenges of high school, the ultimate goal is to become part of the popular crowd.

title: Soaking Up the Sun to Squeeze Bills to Zero
description: GOLDEN, Colo.  The west-facing windows by Jim Duffields desk started automatically tinting blue at 2:50 p.m. on a recent Friday as the midwinter sun settled low over the Rocky Mountain foothills.

title: Obamas Shout-Out for Energy
description: Over all, the Obama administration has pledged to hold the line on discretionary spending in its budget for the 2012 fiscal year  that is, everything it can control, which leaves out areas like Medicare and Social Security. But on energy, it is still going gangbusters, at least as proposed on Monday.

title: Buzz Tracker
description: @Twitter + @Google = Rumor At the Mobile World Congress in Barcelona, Twitters chief executive, Dick Costolo, dismissed reports that Google held takeover discussions with his microblogging site as rumor, Reuters said.REUTERS

title: Last-Minute Primping
Excerpts From New Yorks Doomsday Legal Manual
description: Following are excerpts from the New York State Public Health Legal Manual, published this month by the state court system and the state bar association. It is a guide for judges, lawyers and health professionals in large-scale emergencies like terrorist attacks, epidemics and mass contaminations. In trying to synthesize the law of calamity, it says that the patchwork of court decisions, agency rules and state and federal laws includes many guideposts for disasters adopted at a time when recent emergencies could not have been foreseen.

title: Dressing Up in Rodarte
description: The artist Jane Moseley and friends play dress up in Rodarte's new collection for opening ceremony.

title: Huawei Wants to Woo the U.S. With Cheap Tablets
description: BARCELONA  The new tablet PCs are everywhere around the showroom floors of the Mobile World Congress in Barcelona this week.

title: Best-Kept Secret Now Has a Grammy
description: Who is Esperanza Spalding?

title: A Legal Manual for an Apocalyptic New York
description: Major disasters like terrorist attacks and mass epidemics raise confounding issues for rescuers, doctors and government officials. They also pose bewildering legal questions, including some that may be painful to consider, like how the courts would decide who gets life-saving medicine if there are more victims than supplies.

title: Mercedes-Benz C-Class Coupe Previewed Before Geneva Auto Show
description: Mercedes-Benzs new-product parade continues apace, with the all-new C-Class coupe scheduled to be revealed at the Geneva auto show next month. In its base C250 trim, the coupe is powered by the brands new 1.8-liter turbocharged 4-cylinder engine, developing 201 horsepower and 229 pound-feet of torque, while the higher-spec C350 receives a 3.5-liter V-6 with 302 horsepower and 273 pound-feet of torque.

title: Kitsch of the Day | Baptiste Giabiconi Showtime
description: Lovers of all things Lagerfeld are already familiar with Baptiste Giabiconi, whether its from Chanel couture shows, where the 21-year-old French male model and muse to Kaiser Karl invariably closed the show by sashaying around the runway with a giant lions head, or frolicking in the hay with Lara Stone. Or they might know him from his various photo shoots (signs Lagerfeld, of course) or public outings with his septuagenarian mentor, including a memorable St. Tropez trip in the summer of 2010, when Giabiconi and Lagerfeld stopped by a local newsstand, dressed to the nines and trailed by hordes of paparazzi and curious tourists. But being the male face for Chanel, Fendi and Karl Lagerfeld (as well as starring in a Coca-Cola Light campaign) is apparently not enough for the slightly cross-eyed little Corsican that could; in late 2010 Giabiconi also embarked on a singing career and released his first single, Showtime. Even though the song has been out for a few months and enjoyed considerable chart success in France, its gone largely unnoticed by the American public. Granted, under normal circumstances the epic video (above) accompanying the release of the heavily auto-tuned single would not be considered kitsch; its Wild West theme, with Giabiconi saving a bodacious brunette from her abusive boyfriend, complete with explosive super powers in the Californian desert, is pop video clich at its best. And Giabiconis English (Woz wrong wiz you, man?) is certainly better than Lady Gagas French.
