But the fact that it has Karl Lagerfelds blessing and the remote possibility of him doing a special cameo as a Bond-style villain makes it all the more enjoyable. That sadly doesnt happen, but then again, Giabiconi knows how to keep us on our toes: the video ends with a promising To be Continued.

title: East 59th Street, 1:41 P.M.
Despite the Reviews, Spider-Man Grosses Go Up
description: Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark had strong tickets sales last week, despite the fallout from largely terrible reviews, according to the first slice of box-office data to be released since critics weighed in on Tuesday before the oft-delayed shows official opening.

title: Putting Oscar Wilde on the Back Seat
description: It seems a worthy enough pursuit for a playwright to shift Lord Alfred Douglas, a k a Bosie, into the spotlight, rescuing Oscar Wildes troublesome bit of crumpet from the sidelines. But instead, Thomas Kilroys My Scandalous Life buries Bosie in the indignity of dramaturgical stodginess.

title: Rewards Program Irks Some Southwest Loyalists
description: I WAS in line at a Southwest Airlines gate in Tucson for a flight to Washington the other day, listening to the amplified announcement from a nearby gate where an American Airlines flight was boarding.

title: Meyer Critical of Coaches and the N.C.A.A.
description: Last Friday, the former Florida coach Urban Meyer had strong words for the N.C.A.A. during a radio interview with Dan Dakich. The Web site SportsbyBrooks has a link to the audio interview and has also transcribed some of Meyers statements. Here is a sample of what Meyer has to say about the N.C.A.A. and what he thinks is its ineffective way of dealing with those that break the rules:

title: The S.E.O. Rapper Drops Science on Search Optimization
description: Maybe you read my colleague David Segals eye-opening story about search-engine optimization on Sunday.

title: City Operas New Chairman Is Singing an Uplifting Aria
description: It could not have sounded like the most enticing offer: become the chairman of New York City Opera, which had a $20 million deficit in 2009, raided its endowment to pay off debts and cut its season to just five productions. But Charles R. Wall, who took over as the operas chairman on Jan. 1, nonetheless signed on.

title: Marriott to Split Into Two Companies
description: Marriott International announced plans on Monday to split into two separate companies  one focused on lodging and another on timeshares.

title: I.R.S. Takes on Tax Abuse by Charity Support Groups
description: In the last five years, the Internal Revenue Service has revoked the tax exemption of 72 groups, known as supporting organizations, that obscure philanthropies created to support specific charities.

title: Bridging a Gap Between Fear and Peace
description: CIUDAD JUREZ, Mexico  The short trek from danger to calm starts before dawn. First, there is the grind of a turnstile  total cost: 3 pesos, or 25 cents  then thousands of legs push forward, broomlike, onto the Paso del Norte bridge and away from Ciudad Jurez.

title: Model-Morphosis | Kirsi Pyrhonen at Theyskens Theory
description: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of New York Fashion Week. Here, the model Kirsi Pyrhonen from DNA Model Management before (left) and after (right) transforms, with makeup by James Kaliardos for M.A.C. and hair by Odile Gilbert for Kerastase. (Drag the orange bar left to reveal the full transformation.)

title: On Screen, the Frenzied Yet Friendly World of Justin Bieber
description: At the beginning of Justin Bieber: Never Say Never, the speedily assembled but not frantic biopic and concert extravaganza that was released last week, the first clips you see arent of Mr. Bieber but of popular YouTube videos: the surprised kitty, the sneezing panda.

title: Sexiness of Male Flies Takes Them Only So Far
description: Its not all about being sexy.

title: Joint Chiefs Support Rise in Health Care Fees for Military Retirees
description: WASHINGTON  The militarys No. 1 priority is fighting the nations wars, but No. 2 is taking care of the troops that fight those wars.

title: Photos of the Moment | Donna Karan New York
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#718", 592, 440, true, chameleonData);

title: Can Ctes du Rhnes Take the Heat?
description: ONCE upon a time you knew what you were getting when you opened a Ctes du Rhne. More than likely it would be a light-bodied red with flavors of spicy fruit and Provenal herbs. While these Ctes du Rhnes of old might have varied from undistinguished to highly pleasing, you knew that you could order a carafe, a bottle, maybe even two, and expect a wine that would go down easily. Indeed, Ctes du Rhne became something of a synonym for blithe, gulpable bistro wines.

title: Iraqi Protesters Seek Not a New Regime, but Jobs
description: BAGHDAD  Iraq would seem to have virtually every ingredient for upheaval: crippling poverty, few good jobs, creaky public services, anger at an entrenched political elite and thousands of young people who meet online to vent their grievances and organize protests.

title: Stoudemire and Gallinari Miss Practice
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Amare Stoudemire  the Knicks leading scorer, rebounder and relevancy revivalist  missed a game Saturday night, and his team surprisingly did not implode or disintegrate without him. Pushed by Raymond Felton and Wilson Chandler, the Knicks played just fine without Stoudemire, who sat out the 105-95 win over the Nets with an injured toe.

title: Breathe! (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Go Ahead, Cry (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Massachusetts as Model (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: About Liberal Bias (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Critics Choice: New CDs
description: P J HARVEY

title: After Mubarak: A Time to Look Ahead
description: To the Editor:

title: And What Is the State of Our Democracy?
description: To the Editor:

title: The Scene: Fashion Week Day 5
description: Scenes around the city from New York Fashion Week.

title: Highlights of the Obama Budget
description: On Feb. 14, 2011, President Obama released his budget proposal for fiscal year 2012, and Times reporters offered insight into some of the proposed changes.

title: Ratings Up for Grammys
description: CBSs broadcast of the Grammy Awards on Sunday attracted the largest audience for the show in 11 years. According to Nielsens estimates, 26.7 million viewers tuned in to CBSs live coverage, up from the 25.9 million who watched a year ago. CBS easily led the night over all, including the 7 p.m. hour preceding the three-and-a-half-hour show with a Grammy edition of 60 Minutes (12.2 million) that included Anderson Coopers interview with Lady Gaga.

title: Thom Brownes Convent
description: After staging a bizarre banquet spectacle for his mens collection in Paris last month, Thom Browne presented his  womens line on Monday in the New York Public Library. The scene must have looked a little odd to anyone trying to read a book.

title: Helping Small Business
description: To the Editor:

title: Hello, Cleveland!
description: Pittsburgh to Cleveland, Feb. 15, 1861

title: More Than Meets the iPhone Lens
description: Like media and entertainment, fashion now unfolds across several platforms, with different audiences and levels of taste. Tory Burchs presentation on Sunday  not a show per se but a continuous loop of models  drew top retailers but also a throng of enthusiastic young people, many of whom look at the clothes through their cameras or cellphones with a concentration seldom warranted by 70s-style sportswear with an English twist.

title: Berkshire Closes Out Its Bank of America Stake
description: Warren E. Buffetts investment company, Berkshire Hathaway, sold off its remaining five million shares in Bank of America last quarter, according to regulatory documents filed on Monday.

title: A Cautious Faith in the Army
description: CAIRO  In December 2007, six weeks before Kosovos independence I was privileged to sit in Pristina with a group of young, idealistic rising stars in the Kosovar political scene, as they tirelessly discussed their thoughts, hopes and plans for their nation to be born strong, democratic, dynamic, and politically mature. And I felt jealous. And I hoped I would, one day, I would too have such an animated discussion on the future of my country.

title: Reading at Some Private Schools Is Delayed
description: When Drake Roth was 18 months old, he would read the names of characters in Thomas the Tank Engine videos from his playpen as they flashed across the screen. At 2, he was onto cereal box labels; at 3, his preschools director told his mother to watch what reading material was within his reach on the kitchen table.

title: Farewell to Il Fenomeno: Ronaldo Retires
description: Ronaldo, the gap-toothed Brazilian striker who once dominated world soccer with an astonishing blend of strength, speed and skill, announced Monday that he was retiring from the game at age 34. Worn down by knee injuries, fitness problems and nearly two decades as a professional, he tearfully confirmed his plans at a news conference in Sao Paulo.

title: What Were Reading: Valentines Day Math
Partying Amid Poverty Stirs South Africa Debate
description: SANDTON, South Africa  Kenny Kunene, a former gangster turned businessman, gave what he called the mother of all parties for his 40th birthday. With his small paunch protruding from a white tuxedo and his eyes hidden behind Roberto Cavalli sunglasses, he ate sushi from the belly of a woman who was wearing nothing but black lingerie and high heels while hundreds of guests looked on.

title: Common Cause Asks Court About Thomas Speech
description: WASHINGTON  Discrepancies in reports about an appearance by Justice Clarence Thomas at a political retreat for wealthy conservatives three years ago have prompted new questions to the Supreme Court from a group that advocates changing campaign finance laws.

title: World Wide Mind
description: CHAPTER 4: The Most Intimate Interface

title: Imagining a World of Total Connectedness, and Its Consequences
description: Imagine, Michael Chorost proposes, that four police officers on a drug raid are connected mentally in a way that allows them to sense what their colleagues are seeing and feeling. Tony Vittorio, the captain, is in the center room of the three-room drug den.

title: Egypt's Upheaval Inspires New Protests
description: Demonstrations continued in Yemen, police officers were deployed in Tehran and skirmishes broke out in Bahrain, as the ouster of Hosni Mubarak ignited protesters across the Middle East.

title: Penske Cuts Ties to Smart USA, Mercedes-Benz Steps In
description: 9:27 a.m. |Update

title: Should Republicans Fret Over Their Presidential Field?
description: Republican insiders, reports the Washington Posts plugged-in Jennifer Rubin, are worried about the quality of their slate of presidential candidates for 2012. Indeed, it has become the conventional wisdom to assert that the Republican field is a fairly weak one. (Ive also made some off-handed remarks to this effect.)

title: Airlines Beat Storms by Canceling Ahead
description: This has been a terrible winter for flying.

title: Gates Sees Crisis in Current Spending
description: WASHINGTON  Even as the Obama administration on Monday rolled out its budget for 2012, Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates was dueling with Congress over military spending for this year, saying the Pentagon cannot do its job with cuts of more than $9 billion.

title: N.Y.S.E. Merger Deal No Threat to U.S. Markets
Egypt's Military Plans for Reform
description: The Egyptian military has met with protest organizers to discuss a brisk timetable for electing the country's new leadership.

title: Facebook Officials Keep Quiet on Its Role in Revolts
description: With Facebook playing a starring role in the revolts that toppled governments in Tunisia and Egypt, you might think the companys top executives would use this historic moment to highlight its role as the platform for democratic change. Instead, they really do not want to talk about it.

title: Police Departments Downsize, From 4 Legs to 2
description: CHARLESTON, S.C.  He was a 10-year veteran of the Charleston Police Department, specializing in patrolling this citys palmetto-lined streets, improving community relations and keeping big crowds in check  until his unit was disbanded, a victim of budget cuts.

title: Men Accused of Plot to Sell Drugs to Arm Taliban
description: A group of men agreed to assist the Taliban in a conspiracy to ship narcotics through West Africa to the United States and with the proceeds buy weapons for use against American forces in Afghanistan, federal prosecutors in Manhattan announced on Monday.

title: Egypt's Tourism Industry Devastated
description: As demonstrations in Tahrir Square wain, entrepreneurs are selling protest-inspired shirts while Egypt's tourism industry hopes for a new surge of business.

title: House Votes to Extend Patriot Act Provisions
description: WASHINGTON  The House on Monday voted to reauthorize and extend through Dec. 8 three ways in which Congress expanded the Federal Bureau of Investigations counterterrorism powers after the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001.

title: Companies Warn That Higher Prices Are Looming
description: A package of Oscar Mayer cold cuts. A pair of Nine West boots. A Whirlpool washing machine.

title: Investigators of Turkish Plot Detain 4 Journalists in Raid
description: ISTANBUL  Turkish prosecutors, conducting an extensive investigation into longstanding allegations that the military secretly plotted to overthrow civilian rule in 2003, ordered a police raid Monday on a news Web site that is critical of the pro-Islamic government and ordered four of the sites top officials detained.

title: If Its All About Pitching, Its All About the Phillies
description: CLEARWATER, Fla.

title: In Northwest, a Clash Over a Coal Operation
description: SEATTLE  A plan to build the United States first West Coast facility for exporting coal to Asia has come under increased scrutiny after the disclosure of documents suggesting that the company proposing the project did not convey the full scope of its plans to state regulators here in Washington.

title: Scorecard | Thakoon Wins!
description: In fashion one day youre in, and the next On the fourth day of New York fashion week, Scorecard knows designers were facing challenges like receiving less-than-luxe cashmere and silks from suppliers. Ever industrious, Thakoon Panichgul set to work marrying Masai checks with Marie Antoinettesque panniers. That move turned out to be better than any fringe benefits.

title: Dog Shows Rare Breeds Are Glimpse of History
description: As Baxter the otterhound bounded around the show ring at the Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show on Monday, his owner, Cathy Glenn, felt sure he would win best in breed  and not just because he had won the prize three years running.

title: U.S. Policy to Address Internet Freedom
description: WASHINGTON   Days after Facebook and Twitter added fuel to a revolt in Egypt, the Obama administration on Tuesday announced a new policy on Internet freedom, intended to help people get around barriers in cyberspace while making it harder for autocratic governments to use the same technology to repress dissent.

title: A Nationwide Day for Honoring Charles Darwin, but Handled With Caution
description: There was trepidation on both sides when a squadron of biologists set out to celebrate Darwin Day in rural America during the weekend.

title: Bold Step for Fair Courts in New York
description: New Yorks chief judge, Jonathan Lippman, is taking on the problem of money in judicial elections. At his urging, a state judicial board is proposing to bar more than 700 elected judges from hearing cases involving any lawyer or party who contributed $2,500 or more to the judges campaign in the preceding two years.

title: Quinn to Offer Proposals to Ease City Drivers Pain
description: New York City has gone out of its way in recent years to cater to the nonmotorized, turning part of Times Square into a pedestrian plaza and making room for bicycles on gridlocked streets.

title: From Established Agency, Bets on Upstarts of the Future
description: JUST when it looked as though Kirshenbaum Bond Senecal & Partners was done reinventing itself, the agency has decided to add a new business to its suite of offerings with the announcement on Tuesday of K.B.S.& P. Ventures.

title: Sewards Folly
description: By February 1861 the Republican Party was on the verge of taking complete control of the federal government. But internally, the party was split in two by the secession crisis and how to respond: the first, by far the majority, believed that concessions to Southern demands would simply produce more threats and demands down the line; the minority, on the other hand, believed that such an uncompromising stance risked a suicidal civil war.

title: The Obama Budget
description: On paper, President Obamas new $3.7 trillion budget is encouraging. It makes a number of tough choices to cut the deficit by a projected $1.1 trillion over 10 years, which is enough to prevent an uncontrolled explosion of debt in the next decade and, as a result, reduce the risk of a fiscal crisis.

title: Texas Coach Demands Best, Has Record to Prove It
description: GRANBURY, Tex.  At 7:15 a.m. on Monday, the girls basketball team at Granbury High assembled for practice. As always, shirts had to be tucked in, hair pulled back. If a shoelace came untied, it meant running the bleachers. Questions had two acceptable answers: Yes maam and no maam.

title: In Love With Each Other, and With a New Country
description: Amr Abdo and his wife, Ghada Bayoumy, had mixed feelings about the big step they were about to take. Born in Egypt and wed there, but living in the United States the past 15 years, they were moments away from becoming newly minted Americans on Monday.

title: Ecuador Judge Orders Chevron to Pay $9 Billion
description: CARACAS, Venezuela  A judge in a tiny courtroom in the Ecuadorean Amazon ruled Monday that the oil giant Chevron was responsible for polluting remote tracts of Ecuadorean jungle and ordered the company to pay more than $9 billion in damages, one of the largest environmental awards ever.

title: More Shame
description: The Roman Catholic hierarchy in this country has promised accountability and justice for children sexually abused by priests. We fear it has a long way to go. A new inquiry has found that nearly a decade after the scandal engulfed the American church, children are still in peril and some leaders are still stonewalling investigations.

title: Israel and a New Egypt
description: Hisham Hellyer, left, of the University of Warwick and Shadi Hamid of the Brookings Institution discuss Israel and Egypt's Muslim Brotherhood.

title: Several ESPN Broadcasters Have Had Shoe Contracts
description: Erin Andrews, who signed an endorsement deal with Reebok last month, is not the only ESPN personality or member of its College GameDay team to have a contract with a major shoe company.

title: On Jeopardy, Watson Rallies, Then Slips
description: Two men stood on the bright blue set of Jeopardy Monday night, on location in Yorktown Heights, N.Y., to begin a three-day competition against a celebrity contestant: an IBM super computer named Watson.

title: Arizona: Border Activist Is Convicted
description: Shawna Forde, the leader of a border security group, was convicted of first-degree murder Monday in the 2009 shootings of a man and his daughter. Ms. Forde, claiming to be a law enforcement officer, barged into the Flores home in Arivaca with accomplices. Raul Flores and his daughter, Brisenia, 9, were killed. The jury also convicted Ms. Forde of the attempted murder of Gina Gonzalez, Mr. Floress wife. Trials for Jason Bush and Albert Gaxiola, accused of accompanying Ms. Forde, are scheduled for this spring. Prosecutors said the attackers considered Mr. Flores a drug smuggler and wanted to use his drug proceeds for a paramilitary organization to seal off the border to immigrants.

title: Warning on Thyroid Treatment
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission said Monday that it strongly discourages sending thyroid patients who receive radioactive iodine to hotels after treatment. Use of hotels has become common because some doctors who administer the drug work in places that cannot quarantine the patients while the radiation dies down. Critics said that could result in vulnerable hotel personnel receiving significant doses.

title: N.F.L. Claims Union Is Not Bargaining in Good Faith
description: The N.F.L. filed an unfair labor practice charge against the players union Monday, alleging that the union has failed to bargain in good faith because, the league said, it plans to decertify.

title: Obama Proposes Health Agency Cut but Spares Medicare Fees
description: WASHINGTON  Spending by the Department of Health and Human Services would decline in 2012 for the first time in the agencys 30-year history under President Obamas budget request.

title: Clinton Says G.O.P. Cuts Would Hurt U.S. Interests
description: WASHINGTON  Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton warned Monday that Republican-proposed cuts in foreign aid to be considered by the House this week would harm the nations security interests and standing across the globe.

title: In Art, Recalling a Century-Old Tragedy
description: Anthony Giacchino thumbed through a stack of letters, all of them marked with yellow stickers, red stamps or a simple, final X slashed through the addressees names: Clotilde Terranova. Rosie Friedman. Rosaria, Lucia and Catherine Maltese. Return to sender, he said. Return. Return. Return. Its like, Who is this person? Theyre forgotten, and unfortunately theres a lot of truth to that.

title: Villages Without Doctors
Would the Bard Have Survived the Web?
description: ARCHAEOLOGISTS finished a remarkable dig last summer in East London. Among their finds were seven earthenware knobs, physical evidence of a near perfect 16th-century experiment into the link between commerce and culture.

title: Spain Supports Contador in Fighting Drug Charges
description: Alberto Contador has persuaded the Spanish cycling federation to clear him of all charges stemming from his positive drug test at last summers Tour de France, according to news reports Monday in Spain.

title: To Stand Out, Retailers Flock to Exclusive Lines
description: To find Miley Cyruss line of clothes, shoppers head to Wal-Mart. For Selena Gomezs, they go to Kmart. Jennifer Lopezs line is at Kohls, and Demi Lovatos at Target. Rachel Bilson dinnerware can only be found at Macys, while for the Kardashian Kollection, fans must go to Sears.

title: Vanishing Act: Advisers Distance Themselves From a Report
description: A new study backed by pro-business groups takes a harsh stance on rules intended to bring transparency to the $600 trillion derivatives market. The report, published on Monday, claims that proposed regulation could cost 130,000 jobs and could cut corporate spending by $6.7 billion.

title: Seaport Museum Furloughs Staff Members
description: The struggling Seaport Museum New York put 32 staff members  about half its staff  on unpaid furloughs on Monday the museums chairman, Frank J. Sciame, said through a spokesman.

title: The Experience Economy
description: Tyler Cowens e-book, The Great Stagnation, has become the most debated nonfiction book so far this year. Cowens core point is that up until sometime around 1974, the American economy was able to experience awesome growth by harvesting low-hanging fruit. There was cheap land to be exploited. There was the tremendous increase in education levels during the postwar world. There were technological revolutions occasioned by the spread of electricity, plastics and the car.

title: Reagan and Reality
description: Early in Eugene Jareckis documentary, Reagan, you hear the voice of Ronald Reagan saying, Someday it might be worthwhile to find out how images are created  and even more worthwhile to learn how false images come into being.

title: Westchester Officer Isnt Indicted in Pace Students Death
description: A Westchester County grand jury concluded that there was no reasonable cause to indict a police officer who shot and killed a college football player in a car outside a bar last fall in Thornwood, prosecutors announced on Monday.

title: Tuesday: Something Everybody Is Aware Of
description: TUESDAYS PUZZLE  Do you have a favorite day of the week for solving?

title: As Schools Face Cutbacks, a Debate Over Whats Fair
description: ALBANY  It is an annual tradition on the day the governor unveils his budget. Flipping page after page of stapled booklets collated by the states Education Department, lawmakers search through tiny print for a series of magic numbers.

title: Britain to Look Into Freezing Assets of Mubarak Associates
description: LONDON  Three days after Hosni Mubarak resigned the Egyptian presidency, the British government announced on Monday that it would consult with its European allies on a request from the new authorities in Egypt to freeze the assets of several former officials in the Mubarak government.

title: Grief, Unedited
description: EVER since Joan Didions book The Year of Magical Thinking began its long run as a best seller in 2005, a number of first-person accounts of losing a husband have been published. Among them are Kate Braestrups Here If You Need Me, Anne Roiphes Epilogue and Kay Redfield Jamisons Nothing Was the Same. This week, they are being joined by Joyce Carol Oatess memoir A Widows Story, which recounts the death of her 77-year-old husband, Raymond Smith, from complications of pneumonia in 2008. While these memoirs are often moving, they are also highly subjective snapshots that dont teach us much about how we typically grieve, nor more important, for how long.

title: Lottery Numbers
Marc Jacobs: The Beautiful People
description: One way to interpret the padded vinyl columns and mirrored runway at the Marc Jacobs show tonight was that it evoked the sophistication of a 1950s dressing room. Backstage, Mr. Jacobs, in a jovial mood, said he was thinking of New York this winter  hence the chilly arctic blue of the vinyl.

title: Corrections
description: THE ARTS

title: Westminster Dog Show Kicks Off
description: Poodles, corgis and terriers all made appearances as the Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show began at Madison Square Garden.

title: Argentina Accuses U.S. of Sneaking in Cargo
description: SO PAULO, Brazil  Argentina has accused the United States military of trying to bring guns and surveillance equipment into the country under the cover of supplying a police training course, creating the latest diplomatic rift between the countries.

title: Mounted Patrols Put Out to Pasture
description: Like police departments around the country, budget pressures have forced Charleston, S.C., to shut down its mounted police unit.

title: When Principals and Teachers Are Replaced
description: To the Editor:

title: Arrests of Brazilian Police Spur Drive Against Graft
description: SO PAULO, Brazil  After the federal police arrested 30 police officers in Rio de Janeiro on Friday who were suspected of working with drug traffickers, Jos Mariano Beltrame, the states senior police official, said that rooting out corrupt officers would be a priority this year.

title: At Arts Club, an Honest Cabby Is Rewarded
description: Around 3 p.m. Sunday, John James, twin brother of the longtime president of the National Arts Club, O. Aldon James Jr., hailed a taxicab on West 25th Street in Chelsea and directed the cabby to the clubs Victorian mansion on Gramercy Park South, where he keeps an apartment.

title: Pakistan and Afghanistan to Get New U.S. Envoy
description: WASHINGTON  Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton has chosen Marc Grossman, a retired senior diplomat and former ambassador to Turkey, as the Obama administrations new special representative for Afghanistan and Pakistan, a senior State Department official said Monday.

title: Backstage Beauty | Marc Jacobs
description: You know those old women in the street who are a little bit eccentric? Theres always one living next to you. They put too much blush on and they dont do their eyeliner quite well, but it looks fabulous in the end. Thats what the idea was, explained the makeup artist Franois Nars backstage at the Marc Jacobs show. This translated to a black eyeliner NARS is releasing this fall called Via Venetto applied with a downward curve (the opposite of Audrey Hepburns look, explained Nars) and NARS Lokum Cream Blush applied low, near the mouth. I think it looks like a grandmother who put lipstick on her cheeks, said Nars with a laugh. The hairstylist Guido Palau gave this aging glamor girl a Croydon facelift, creating what he called a dominatrix ponytail using Redken Blow Away, a gel for blow-drying, and Shine Flash for serious gloss (models wore berets made of PVC by the milliner Stephen Jones secured with black chin straps). Nails were painted a shiny peach Jacobs chose from the polish brand Zoya. Marc is very hands on, said the manicurist Elisa Ferri, pun unintended. He has an amazing eye.

title: Perez Arrives at Spring Training, but Wary Mets May Want Him Gone
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Spring training has not officially begun for the Mets, yet perhaps the most toxic issue from last year was revived Monday. Oliver Perez, one of the more vilified players in team history, threw his first ball on a Mets mound since his last, disastrous appearance in the last inning of the last game of a very forgettable 2010 season.

title: First Things First: Jeter Will Be Leadoff Batter
description: TAMPA, Fla.  There will be competition for the two vacancies in the Yankees rotation and for bullpen jobs, for the backup catchers position and on their bench, but not for the spot atop the batting order. That was made unequivocally clear Monday by Manager Joe Girardi, who quashed speculation that Derek Jeter, coming off his worst season, would drop in the lineup.

title: Sabathia Loses Weight and Keeps His Options Open
description: TAMPA, Fla.  C. C. Sabathia used to eat Capn Crunch by the box, not the handful, a habit conducive to maintaining his 315 pounds but detrimental to his long-term goals. Sabathia envisions himself pitching for another 8 years, maybe 10, and so after having surgery on his right knee in October, he consulted a chef and a nutritionist, improved his eating habits and began exercising twice a day.

title: Inflation Hits Nearly 5 Percent in China, With Food Costs Soaring
description: BEIJING  Consumer prices in China rose 4.9 percent in January when compared with the same month a year earlier, the government reported Tuesday, as inflation continued to bedevil the economy.

title: Word of the Day | estrange
description: estrange \i-stranj\ verb

title: Report Details Sabotage of Birth Control
description: Men who abuse women physically and emotionally may also sabotage their partners birth control, pressuring them to become pregnant against their will, new reports suggest.

title: Stabbed in Rampage, Brooklyn Cabdriver Is Then Put in Jail
description: He sat in the emergency room at Brookdale University Hospital and Medical Center in Brooklyn, thankful he was alive after being ambushed by a stranger who seemed set on killing him.

title: Blanche Moyse, Music School Founder, Dies at 101
description: Blanche Moyse, a founder of the Marlboro Music School and Festival and, as a conductor, a leading interpreter of Bachs choral works, died on Thursday at her home in Brattleboro, Vt. She was 101.

title: Josefa Iloilo, Leader Who Revoked Fiji Constitution, Dies at 90
description: Josefa Iloilo, the president of Fiji who in 2009 provoked worldwide censure by tossing out the island nations Constitution, firing its judges and naming himself head of state, died on Feb. 6 in Suva, Fijis capital. He was 90.

title: David F. Friedman, Horror Film Pioneer, Dies at 87
description: David F. Friedman, a film producer who cheerfully and cheesily exploited an audiences hunger for bare-breasted women and blood-dripping corpses in lucrative low-budget films like Blood Feast and Ilsa: She-Wolf of the S.S., died on Monday in Anniston, Ala. He was 87.

title: News Quiz | February 15, 2011
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: Irans Leader Derides Protests; Lawmakers Urge Death for Opposition Leaders
description: A day after the largest antigovernment protests in Iran in more than a year, President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad on Tuesday dismissed opposition attempts to revive mass demonstrations as certain to fail, while members of the Iranian Parliament clamored for the two most prominent leaders of the protest movement to be executed.

title: Pakistan: Kerry Visits in Hopes of Easing Tensions
description: Senator John Kerry traveled to Pakistan late on Monday to help defuse a diplomatic furor over the arrest of an American official accused of murder, White House and Senate officials said. Senator Kerry, Democrat of Massachusetts, the chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, planned to meet with senior Pakistani officials, and his visit was being coordinated with the White House. Tensions have been rising between the United States and Pakistan over the case of Raymond A. Davis, an American official who killed two motorcyclists in Lahore on Jan. 27 while driving his car. American Embassy officials say that Mr. Davis fired in self-defense when two armed men tried to rob him, but prosecutors in Pakistan have charged him with murder. American officials have insisted that he is protected by diplomatic immunity and should be released.

title: In One Slice of Egypt, Daily Woes Top Religion
description: CAIRO  A generation ago, Ahmed Mitwallis parents were Islamists in this neighborhood along the Nile once nicknamed the Islamic Republic of Imbaba. But their son is not, and his convictions, echoed in the caldron of frustrations of one of the worlds most crowded quarters, suggest why the Muslim Brotherhood is not driving Egypts nascent revolution.

title: Mens Fall Fashion 2011 | Tommy Hilfiger
description: In the main skylit dining room of The Lion, Tommy Hilfiger trotted out suits, scarves, cropped jackets and overcoats sporting stripes akin to those on Hudson Bay blankets. It was a clever use of a preppy signature mashed up with sleeker shapes and richer colorations. The grey-on-grey asymmetrical toggle coat on the long haired blonde surfer looked very Love Story via Montauk.

title: Barclays Profit Drops Less Than Expected
description: 7:17 p.m. | Updated

title: Daily Lexeme: Quidnunc
description: Todays word, in association with the remarkable Oxford English Dictionary, is

title: The President Proposes a Budget for 2012
description: WHO will be affected by changes to the Pell grant program?

title: Fosters to Separate Wine and Beer Businesses in May
description: The Fosters Group said on Tuesday that it would complete its plan to split its wine and beer businesses in May.

title: Test Yourself | English, Feb. 15, 2011
description: Test your vocabulary skills with todays question, created by Danielle Hoagland and Judith McCaffrey at Grammarlogues from the article  Kings Speech': The Film to Beat and to Bad-Mouth.

title: Coming of Age in Dublins Underworld
description: Joy riding  stealing and destroying cars  is a rite of passage in the lawless but ritualistic world of disaffected youth in Ballymun, a community on the north side of Dublin. In Joyrider, through a series of cinematic black-and-white shots awash in light and movement, the photographer Ross McDonnell documented youths coming of age in a world of drugs, gangs and arson.

title: What Are Your Ideas for School Fund-Raisers?
description: Many school districts around the country have been hit by serious budget cuts, prompting the need for creative fund-raising campaigns. Is your school or district facing a budget crisis? How do you think your school could raise more money? What fund-raisers do you think would be interesting and enjoyable and would attract more participants?

title: Bahrain Takes the Stage With a Raucous Protest
description: MANAMA, Bahrain  Thousands of protesters poured into this nations symbolic center, Pearl Square, late Tuesday in a raucous rally that again demonstrated the power of popular movements that are transforming the political landscape of the Middle East.

title: The Early Word: Making the Cut
description: From Todays Times:

title: Schlichters Arrest and a Harrowing Tale
description: The Associated Press:

title: A Prague Musical Returns, Funny and Dark
description: Homo sapiens are piggish and dirty  despite the species absurd pursuit of cleanliness through creepy beauty treatments. That is the darkly funny and often frightening theme of the musical Here I Am Human!, which plays (in English) from Feb. 20 to 22, at Archa (Na Porici 26; 420-2 21-71-63-33; www.archatheatre.cz), Pragues leading alternative theater venue.

title: Beyond Fannie and Freddie, a New Approach
description: Edward L. Glaeser is an economics professor at Harvard and the author of Triumph of the City.

title: The Champions League Returns
description: If it seems like months since youve seen a Champions League match, thats probably because it has. But the wait ends this week and next with the first-leg Round of 16 matches, and the good news is that there are a couple of mouth-watering matchups to get everything restarted.

title: Trial Is Set for Berlusconi in Prostitution Case
description: ROME  A Milan judge on Tuesday ordered Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi to stand trial in April on charges of paying an under-age girl for sex and abuse of office, dealing the most serious blow to his leadership in the 17 years that he has dominated Italian politics.

title: The TV Watch: Man, Machine and a Trivial Pursuit
description: Its not the match of the century, its more like the letdown of a lifetime. The first round on Monday in this weeks Jeopardy! competition between two former champions and Watson, the I.B.M. computer, was supposed to be a man vs. machine, guys against gadget, brain vs. Braun showdown. It was closer to Bambi vs Godzilla.

title: Europes Economy Grew More Slowly Than Expected in 4th Quarter
description: FRANKFURT  The European economy grew more slowly than expected in the fourth quarter of 2010, a sign that some countries are still suffering from too much debt and not enough competitiveness.

title: Money Buys a Lot, but Not Everything, in Soccer
description: LONDON  The Champions League is back in play, and so is the wealth league.

title: New York Fashion Week Tweets | Tuesday
description: Today from 2 p.m. to 5 p.m., we will be going backstage at Sophie Theallet, to give you a behind-the-scenes look at the busiest and most exhilarating moments before the show.

title: How Good a Boss Are You?
description: Last weeks post about subpar employees certainly got a spirited response. Not surprisingly, some people wanted to vent about subpar bosses. Fair enough. Lets give that a look.

title: Venture Between Two Tour Bus Companies Is Stopped
description: In the annals of antitrust cases it will fall somewhere below Standard Oil and Microsoft, but a decision by a federal transportation agency last week may at least please the citys sightseers.

title: Getting a Glimpse Into Hedge Funds Holdings
description: American hedge funds reported their quarterly holdings on Monday, offering the public a rare  albeit delayed  insight into the stocks held by top money managers.

title: Afghan Official Says Womens Shelters Are Corrupt
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Afghanistans top female official began a sustained verbal assault on womens shelters on Tuesday, accusing them of corruption and mismanagement, and insisting that the government was determined to take control of them, whether or not donors continue to give financial support.

title: Obama Budget Escapes Liberal Backlash, for Now
description: The response to President Obamas proposed 2012 budget from Republicans was predictably negative. But the reaction from what Mr. Obamas spokesman once called the professional left was remarkably muted.

title: Google Asks Users to Weigh In on Content Farms
description: Google has been facing swelling criticism from tech types over the quality of its search results because they often include links to sites like eHow, which critics disparagingly refer to as content farms.

title: Singapore and Australian Exchanges Modify Deal
description: The Singapore and Australian stock exchanges said on Tuesday that they had revamped their merger proposal in an attempt to win regulatory support for the $8.4 billion deal consolidation in the sector gathered steam.

title: A Reluctant Redgrave, on Daisy and More
description: After more than 50 years of acting, Vanessa Redgrave understands the art of pausing and listening. At the heart of her latest Broadway play, Driving Miss Daisy, is a set of conversations between her snappish title character and James Earl Joness Hoke, Daisys chauffeur, whose decades-long friendship with Daisy forces her to face her own prejudice and frailties.

title: Narciso Rodriguez Casting
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#1", 592, 490, true, chameleonData);

title: Top 10 Composers: A Young Reader Responds
description: My two-week project to select the 10 greatest composers, which involved a series of articles, blog posts and videos, concluded with an article in the Arts & Leisure section on Jan. 23. But I continue to receive lively, interesting reactions from readers. My favorite was a hand-written letter from Lucas Amory, who is 8 years old and lives on the Upper West Side of Manhattan. Lucas is a serious piano student and the son of two noted violists, Misha Amory of the Brentano String Quartet and Hsin-Yun Huang.

title: Twitter Wants to Go Multilingual Faster
description: BARCELONA, Spain  During the protests and rallies that erupted in Egypt, Twitter emerged as a crucial way for demonstrators to communicate and for journalists to quickly broadcast reports and observations from the ground.

title: Federal Royalties for Gold and Copper?
description: A tiny item in the Obama budget puts the administration on the environmental side of one of the longest-running questions in the West: What do the companies that mine gold, silver, copper and other hard-rock minerals owe the Treasury for the valuable materials they extract from public lands?

title: Morning Take-Out
description: MERGERS & ACQUISITIONS

title: Lifestyles Of The Rich But Not Famous
description: OK, make that the fairly affluent. Today, David Brooks suggests that economic growth has slowed because these days the affluent are more into self-improvement and life quality than they are into money. In effect, were suffering from a decline in materialism.

title: Morning Buzz | A Manual for Coping With Horror
description: Mondays vernal temperatures are gone, replaced by a bright, brisk Tuesday with highs around freezing.

title: Markets Retreat as Exxon Leads Energy Shares Down
description: Stocks retreated, pulling the Standard & Poors 500-stock index down from a 32-month high, after a report showed retail sales increased less than forecast, and Exxon Mobil led a decline in energy producers.

title: A Man Without a Face
description: Its nearing the bitter end of the race, when even the most minor royals from The Kings Speech have spoken and every friending metaphor has been exhausted on The Social Network. But  and this is totally in the spirit of uncovering all there is to know about this seasons contenders and not at all meant as a last-minute notebook dump  the Bagger would like to direct you to our pals over at New York magazines Vulture, who have a behind-the-scenes look at how two distinct and (very) handsome men came to play the identical Winklevoss twins in The Social Network.

title: Friends With Benefits | Rodarte for Opening Ceremony
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#386", 592, 400, true, chameleonData);

title: Tuesday Reading: Doctors Call for Fewer Back Scans
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: Russia Embraces Offshore Arctic Drilling
description: MOSCOW  The Arctic Ocean is a forbidding place for oil drillers. But that is not stopping Russia from jumping in  or Western oil companies from eagerly following.

title: CB Richard Ellis to Buy ING Real Estate Business
description: 7:24 p.m. | Updated

title: Obama Sets Tuesday Morning Press Conference
description: President Obama has scheduled a news conference for Tuesday morning, one day after unveiling his 2012 budget and just weeks before a potential showdown with Republicans over government spending.

title: BATS in Talks to Create Brazilian Bourse
description: BATS Global Markets, a privately owned exchange operator in the United States, said on Tuesday that it was talking with the asset manager Claritas about setting up a new Brazilian bourse.

title: Versteeg Joins Vanquished Stanley Cup Opponent
description: For the second time in less than a week, a contending team gave up a late first-round draft pick to acquire a second-line forward. The Flyers, in first place in the Eastern Conference, acquired right wing Kris Versteeg from Toronto on Monday night for first- and third-roundselections in the June draft.

title: A Rising Natural Rate
description: Lots of buzz about this San Francisco Fed paper on indications that we may have a new normal unemployment rate of between 6 and 7 percent. So a few notes on how to interpret the results.

title: New York and German Exchanges to Merge in $10 Billion Deal
description: 8:34 p.m. | Updated

title: The Calories Are Listed, but Teenagers Dont Care
description: Researchers at New York University have found that calorie-posting in fast-food restaurants has little influence on the foods teenagers order.

title: Police Horses Are Diminished in Number, but Not Presence
description: They are as woven into the fabric of Times Square as the Armed Forces recruiting center, or at least the Naked Cowboy. They pop up regularly around the Coney Island Boardwalk, outside Rockefeller Center, at Yankee Stadium, and at many of the street demonstrations that form a regular part life in New York City.

title: Feb. 15: Updates on Middle East Protests
description: On Tuesday, The Lede continues to follow protests and unrest in Bahrain, Yemen and Iran, as well as Egypts post-Mubarak transition. Updates below mix alerts on breaking news with reports from bloggers and journalists on the ground. A stream of Twitter updates on regional protests is in this blogs right column.

title: In Egypt, a Panel of Jurists Is Given the Task of Revising the Countrys Constitution
description: CAIRO  The military officers governing Egypt on Tuesday convened a panel of jurists, including an outspoken Muslim Brotherhood politician, to revise the countrys Constitution in the first tangible evidence of a commitment to move the country toward democracy after President Hosni Mubaraks ouster.

title: CIT Profit Falls 35% in Fourth Quarter
description: The CIT Group, the small businesses and middle-market lender that emerged from bankruptcy in 2009, reported profit of $75 million for the fourth quarter of 2010, a 35 percent decline from the third quarter.

title: A Cinematic Upset in the Making?
description: What makes a sure thing?

title: A Valentine to Mom and Dad (Mostly Dad)
description: Midfielder Yael Averbuch, a Montclair, N.J., native by way of the University of North Carolina, will be contributing to the Goal blog in the runup to the third season of Womens Professional Soccer and as the United States womens national team prepares to play in the Algarve Cup and the FIFA Womens World Cup in Germany later this year.

title: On Our Radar: Costner Is Sued Over Spill Technology
description: The actor Stephen Baldwin sues the actor and director Kevin Costner, asserting that he cheated Mr. Baldwin out of profits from an oil-spill cleanup device licensed to BP during the Gulf of Mexico oil spill last year. In a federal complaint, Mr. Baldwin and a business associate claim they were duped into prematurely selling their interests in the company behind the technology, which was dubbed the Costner solution despite the machines minimal impact on the spill. Mr. Costner denies any wrongdoing and has sought to dismiss the complaint. [The Los Angeles Times]

title: T on Go Try It On
description: You might have seen Go Try It Ons 80s-inspired cursive logo plastered over downtown fitting room mirrors this past weekend. Now Marissa Evans, the founder and CEO of Go Try It On, has asked some of Ts fashion team to take a break from New York fashion week and virtually style her online community. The almost one-year-old social network site (they launched last year at SXSW) is committed to answering the eternal question What should I wear? with positive criticism only  negative or inappropriate comments and photos are screened and removed immediately, says Evans. An iPhone app allows members to easily upload images of outfits in question from any location, so go ahead, take the plunge and get fashion tips from our fashion editors on gotryiton.com. Ts Rae Boxer leads off today and will answer your questions between 12-1 p.m.

title: Apple Offers Subscriptions for Apps
description: 8:31 p.m. | Updated Apple on Tuesday cleared the way for media companies to begin selling subscriptions to their magazine, newspaper, music and video content on the iPad and its other devices.

title: A Handymans Special With Hot and Cold Running Rumors
description: LOS ANGELES  From Kirk Morgans perch, in a mansion at the top of Los Angeles, he can see it all: The snow-covered mountains from the vast windows in one of the seven bathrooms. The Hollywood sign, eye level from the kitchen. And, from the master bedroom, a sweep of Los Angeles stretching from downtown to the Pacific Ocean.

title: Photos of the Moment | Thom Browne
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#662", 592, 440, true, chameleonData);

title: ClearBook: A New Online Tool for Judging a Used Cars Worth
description: From our colleagues at Bucks:

title: What Were Reading
description: This American Life: Here it is, folks, the recipe for Coca-Cola, revealed at last. (If the first link is down, try this.)  Sam Sifton

title: At Rye High, Knicks Coach Is Just a Face in the Crowd
description: RYE, N.Y.  For the coach of the Knicks, the clamor of a high school gymnasium was a welcome diversion from the daily chorus of inquiry that comes with the territory. Here, there were no demands to explain away on-court misfortune or need to deal with the Carmelo Anthony distraction. Here, the responsibility of prepping the team for the next days must-win game was somebody elses responsibility.

title: Critics Picks Video: Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind
description: This week, A. O. Scott explores the director Michel Gondry and the screenwriter Charlie Kaufmans film about the beginning and end of a relationship. Mr. Scott says that while most movies reduce love to a greeting card sentiment, Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind treats it as a subject for extended philosophical inquiry. He celebrates the film for being cerebral, formally and conceptually complicated, dense with literary allusions and as unabashedly romantic as any movie youll ever see.

title: Near-Field Communication: Beyond Mobile Transactions
description: BARCELONA, Spain  Among the many buzz words  Androids, tablets, LTE  being tossed around the showroom floor here at the Mobile World Congress, theres one that I still havent quite been able to wrap my head around.

title: Expert Panel Is Critical of F.B.I. Work in Investigating Anthrax Letters
description: WASHINGTON  A review of the Federal Bureau of Investigations scientific work on the investigation of the anthrax letters of 2001 concludes that the bureau overstated the strength of genetic analysis linking the mailed anthrax to a supply kept by Bruce E. Ivins, the Army microbiologist whom the investigators blamed for the attacks.

title: Pushing the Budget
description: Gov. Dannel P. Malloy of Connecticut spends a day promoting his budget ahead of his speech on the proposal, scheduled for Wednesday, Feb. 16.

title: Connecticut Governor, Tackling Budget, Criticizes Christies Approach
description: HARTFORD  There is Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey: blustery and bellicose, hectoring the unions, enthralling fellow Republicans with his tax caps and spending cuts, already generating presidential murmurings after barely a year in office.

title: Net Zero Energy, Transmuted Into Art
description: The relationship and, often as not, tension between hardheaded engineers and design-conscious architects is woven into the fabric of every great building.

title: Clearing the Fog in Nursing Homes
description: The woman, who was in her 90s, had lived for several years at the Ecumen Sunrise nursing home in Two Harbors, Minn., where the staff had grown accustomed to her grimaces and wordless cries. She took a potent cocktail of three psychotropic drugs: Ativan for anxiety and the antipsychotic Risperdal to calm her, plus an antidepressant. In all the time shed lived at Sunrise, she hadnt spoken. It wasnt clear whether she could recognize her children when they came to visit.

title: Photos of the Moment | Marc Jacobs
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#880", 592, 440, true, chameleonData);

title: Burnett Reflects and Looks Ahead
description: TAMPA, Fla.  A. J. Burnett moved recently. Not far, just a few doors down in the Yankees clubhouse, to the corner locker on starters row once occupied by Andy Pettitte. The contrast was striking: where reliability dressed for more than a decade, volatility now hangs his designer T-shirts.

title: Bloomberg Family Foundation to Support Arts
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs family foundation is planning to distribute $32 million in grants to arts organizations around New York City, The Wall Street Journal reported on Tuesday. The announcement comes a year after the mayor ended a charitable program administered through the Carnegie Corporation of New York, which over a decade funneled $200 million of his personal fortune to arts and social-service groups around the city. (The Carnegie program was ostensibly supported by an anonymous donor, but that donor was widely known to be Mr. Bloomberg.)

title: Bold Predictions: Always Enticing, Often Wrong
description: Carl Richards is a certified financial planner in Park City, Utah. His sketches are archived here on the Bucks blog and on his personal Web site, BehaviorGap.com.

title: When Mimi Met Duro
description: For newcomers like Mimi Plange, it is increasingly hard to stand out from the fashion fray. So a few days after showing her fourth collection, which is titled Scarred Perfection (a reference to African tribal scarification), Plange jumped at the chance to meet with Duro Olowu, the London- and New York-based designer who made a name for himself when his high-waisted Duro dress caught the eye of key editors in 2005, including Ts editor in chief, Sally Singer.

title: Model-Morphosis | Alana Zimmer at Marc Jacobs
description: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of New York Fashion Week. Here, the model Alana Zimmer from Ford Models before (left) and after (right) transforms, with makeup by Franois Nars for NARS and hair by Guido Palau for Redken. (Drag the orange bar left to reveal the full transformation.)

title: Phrases We Love Too Much
description: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style. (Some frequently asked questions are here.)

description: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style. (Some frequently asked questions are here.)

title: On the G-20 and a Leadership Void
description: The economist Nouriel Roubini and Ian Bremmer, president of the Eurasia Group, discuss what they perceive as a lack of global economic leadership, during an interview on CNBC.

title: The Latest Museum Restaurant Will Be Untitled
description: Fitting its locale, the restaurant that Danny Meyers Union Square Hospitality Group is to open next month in the lower level of the Whitney Museum of American Art will be called Untitled. The museums director, Adam Weinberg, came up with the name. Its chef will be Chris Bradley, who was the executive sous chef at Gramercy Tavern. It will serve breakfast and lunch on days when the museum is open, as well as dinner, with a set menu, on Saturdays and Sundays.

title: Parents Without Parents
description: Allison Gilbert misses her parents. They both died before their grandchildren could remember them (her mother before her children were born, and her father when her oldest child was 18 months old) and every day she realizes anew that the loss was not hers alone, but also her sons and her daughters. There is a hole in her parenting, she believes, where her own parents should be.

title: Grabbing a Piece of the New York-German Deal
description: Putting together a merger as complicated as the deal between NYSE Euronext and Deutsche Brse  which are forming the worlds largest financial market for stocks and derivatives  is no easy task.

title: Following Sloan, Corbin Seeks His Own Path
description: Talk about conflicting emotions. New Utah Jazz Coach Tyrone Corbin is happy to have his first N.B.A. head coaching gig, a great promotion after years of working hard. But the new position has come in the wake of his mentor and friend, Jerry Sloan, resigning Feb. 10 after leading the Jazz for 23 years.

title: Obama Offers Defense on Budget and Egypt
description: 12:38 p.m. | Updated President Obama on Tuesday defended his budget as a difficult step toward stabilizing the nations finances, urging for bipartisan cooperation in Washington to address the risks from the nations growing long-term debt.

title: Wheelies: The Choosing-Sides Edition
description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

title: Kansas Is King for a Day
description: Recent events have made it perfectly clear why its so much easier to bear college basketballs ethical potholes than college footballs: in the end, the politicking and elbow-rubbing and who-knows-how-many-dollars handshakes give way to a tournament that decides a champion. So there can be carnage and chaos in the rankings, No. 1s can fall like ducks in an arcade, unbeatable teams can be humbled and, in the end, they all still get to play it out.

title: Eminem, Arcade Fire and Buffalo Springfield Among Top Acts at Bonnaroo
description: If you enjoyed the musicians you saw on Sundays Grammy Awards show, youll see plenty of comfortingly familiar names on the lineup for this years Bonnaroo music and arts festival. And if you didnt, well, youll still have lots of other acts to choose from.

title: MIST
description: Acronym for a new group of emerging economies: Mexico, Indonesia, South Korea and Turkey.

title: Fashion Week Parties, Night 5
description: Scenes from Monday night, including an after-party for Marc Jacobs and Olivier Theyskens.

title: Mushroom Hash With Black Rice
description: When I made this hash, I thought hard about adding cooked grain to the chopped mushrooms, as theyre so good on their own. You may choose to serve this without the black rice, but add it if you want a more substantial dish.

title: New Phones That Put Facebook Front and Center
description: Update 6:50 pm: Facebook says dozens of new phones this year will be built around its social network

title: Funeral for 2 Victims of Stabbing Rampage
description: Mourners of Yelena Bulchenko and her mother, Anna Bulchenko, gathered for their funeral at Arbat Memorial Chapel on Flatbush Avenue in Marine Park, Brooklyn, on Tuesday morning. Yelena Bulchenko was a love interest of Maksim Gelman, the man accused of killing four people over the weekend, including Yelena and Anna Bulchenko.

title: Alderson Says He Is Not Facing Any Limitations
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  One day before the official opening of his first spring training camp as the Mets general manager, Sandy Alderson said Tuesday that he did not expect the entanglement of the teams ownership in a $1 billion lawsuit in the Bernard L. Madoff case to affect his handling of the baseball operation.

title: Hockey Brawls: A Nostalgic Look Back
description: February has been fight month in the N.H.L. With a line brawl here, a sucker punch there, and goalie-on-goalie violence seemingly everywhere, there are nights when the league seems like its taken a ride in a time machine.

title: Now Sipping | A Cocktail Coco Would Have Liked
description: Fashion Week has helped inspire a new cocktail for ladies and dandies alike at Jimmy, the new rooftop bar at the James Hotel in SoHo. Chanel No 9 ($18), named after the venerable French fashion house, is a not-too-sweet blend of nine different floral and botanical liquors, including Chartreuse, St Germaine and Crme de Violette, topped with Champagne. Its not so different from a perfumer making a scent to mix these different liquors together, said Johnny Swet, one of Jimmys owners. A Parisian melon baller is used to make tiny pearls of juicy strawberries (8 to 10 pearls per berry) that bounce up and down in the flute. Coco would approve.

title: Anna Nicole, Jimi Hendrix and Handel in London
description: LONDON  Almost everyone I meet here has heard about Anna Nicole, the new opera by the British composer Mark-Anthony Turnage, which will have its premiere on Thursday by the Royal Opera at Covent Garden. The company has clearly done a good marketing job. The operas tragic heroine is Anna Nicole Smith, the Playboy Playmate, model, actress and reality show host who died in 2007 from combined drug intoxication, according to forensics reports.

title: Insights From a Honeymoon in Zambia
description: Zambia is burning.

title: With Etherea Concept, Infiniti Downsizes for European Market
description: On Monday, Infiniti released images of a compact four-door crossover hatchback called the Etherea, which the Japanese luxury brand intends to display at the Geneva auto show next month.

title: Climate Change Drives Instability, U.N. Official Warns
description: The United Nations top climate change official said on Tuesday that food shortages and rising prices caused by climate disruptions were among the chief contributors to the civil unrest coursing through North Africa and the Middle East.

title: Muslim Brotherhood in Egypt to Be Political Party
description: CAIRO  The Muslim Brotherhood, the outlawed Islamic group that has long constituted Egypts main political opposition, said Tuesday that it would apply to become an official political party as soon as the necessary changes were made to the Egyptian Constitution.

title: Republicans Push for Exemptions to Derivatives Rules
description: 8:56 p.m. | Updated

title: Mainstream Media Still Drive Majority of Twitter Trends
description: Hewlett-Packards Social Computing Research Group, which explores how people find information on social networks, released a new study on Tuesday about howconversations on Twitter become a so-called trending topic on the site.

title: Devils Climb to Playoffs Looks a Little Less Steep
description: NEWARK  The Devils walk past a board with the Eastern Conference standings in their dressing room almost every day. They concede the board is not as pleasant to look at as it has been in other seasons. But they also know that the board will be updated for almost two more months.

title: Interior of Fifth Ave. Bank Building Is Named a Landmark
description: It comes too late to save a sculptural screen by the artist Harry Bertoia that was removed last year, but on Tuesday the Landmarks Preservation Commission voted to grant landmark protection to the midcentury modern interior of 510 Fifth Avenue  the squat, transparent former Manufacturers Trust Bank Building with the gleaming circular vault door in the lobby.

title: Q&A: Tackling Two Twitter Accounts
description: Q.

title: When the Diagnosis Is A.D.H.D.
description: Millions of children, adults and families are affected by attention deficit hyperactivity disorder, or A.D.H.D., a troubling condition that can cause problems with work, school and relationships. But when is it time to seek professional help? And is the diagnosis of A.D.H.D. handed out too often? These are among the issues recently raised by readers of the Consults blog.

title: Crafts Retailer A.C. Moore Considers a Sale
description: A.C. Moore Arts and Crafts announced on Tuesday that its board was considering strategic options, including a possible sale of the company.

title: Trump and the Mets? Anything Is Possible
description: He saved Central Parks Wollman Rink and has been vocal about wanting to reopen a restaurant at the Tavern on the Green site.

title: Crawley Town Video Hits the Rocks
description: With most of the soccer world focused on the resumption of play in the European Champions League on Tuesday and Wednesday, a minor league team in England has muscled into the spotlight days before the biggest game in club history.

title: The Sound of Inception
description: As the Bagger discovered last season, its almost impossible for even the Academys experts to predict who will win the Oscars for sound design and mixing. But over the weekend, the sound team from Inception won Baftas from the British Academy of Film and Television Arts , and the group  sound designer Richard King, recording mixer Ed Novick and re-recording mixer Gary Rizzo, along with his partner Lora Hirschberg  have been talked up all season long for their work on Christopher Nolans film, for which they are all nominated for Oscars. Creating a soundtrack for his multilevel dreamscape thriller involved technical and creative challenges born of multiple locations and complicated storytelling.

title: Eric Schmidt Predicts a Smartphone-Fueled Future
description: BARCELONA, Spain  In a keynote address here Tuesday evening at the Mobile World Congress, Eric E. Schmidt, chief executive of Google, outlined his vision for the future of search, which he said would become easier, more intuitive and more serendipitous.

title: Pleats Meet Parkas at Vera Wang
description: Vera Wang kept her fall collection to two main looks: the pleated chiffon dress and the parka. You could say she was keeping things simple, since there were none of the usual big-statement jewelry pieces.

title: Did a Reporter Have a Stroke on TV?
description: It began as a typical segment on the local news  a beaming television journalist preparing for a live report from the Grammy Awards. But as Serene Branson, a Los Angeles CBS reporter, began to speak, she uttered a few real words that turned into a stream of gibberish.

title: House G.O.P. Pushes $61 Billion in Cutbacks
description: WASHINGTON  Even as the White House threatened a veto, House Republicans pushed ahead Tuesday with their plan to slice tens of billions of dollars from current federal spending, with some arguing for even deeper cuts.

title: New York Courts Vow Legal Aid in Housing
description: New York court officials outlined procedures Tuesday aimed at assuring that all homeowners facing foreclosure were represented by a lawyer, a shift that could give tens of thousands of families a better chance at saving their homes.

title: Scorecard Update | Marc Jacobs
description: Marc JacobsDesigner: Marc JacobsDate and Location: Monday, Feb. 14, New York State Armory, 68 Lexington AvenuePhotos: slide show

title: Apple Says Chinese Supplier Made Changes After Suicides
description: Apple sent Timothy D. Cook, its chief operating officer, to China last year to review the operations of a principal manufacturing partner after nearly a dozen suicides by factory employees raised concerns about working conditions.

title: Point Guards Extension Looks Better Every Day
description: It was a shock in November when the Memphis Grizzlies signed the starting point guard Mike Conley to an extension of his rookie scale contract on the extension deadline day. Given his average play until that point, an extension was not expected.

title: Rodarte on the Prairie
description: The Mulleavy sisters of Rodarte, in their fall collection, picked up in much the same place as they left off in their hit spring collection. Some of the shapes, like high-waist pants with crisscross tops, and dresses with paneled overlays, were reprised here in new fabrics, embroideries, tablecloth lace and dotted prints that suggested they were looking again to the homespun corners of Americana for their ideas, and had settled somewhere in prairie life and the great migration to California in the 1930s.

title: The $100 Paris Weekend
description: ONE Friday night last month, I stood watching a North African band called Daxar perform at the Satellit Caf world music club in Paris and was considering having a beer. By the time the band had finished its Magrebian take on the Rolling Stones Paint It Black (Do you know this one? the band leader asked coyly. Its not ours.), I had decided against it. Such luxury could cost me the Louvre on Sunday, or wine with lunch Saturday.

title: LAddition: How $100 Lasted a Weekend in Paris
description: The check of the French couple who sat next to me and ordered duck confit, along with drinks.

description: Q.
