description: 9:21 p.m. | Updated

title: Pictures of the Day: Egypt and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Egypt, India and Russia.

title: Minnesota Governor Proposes Tax Increase for Wealthiest Residents
description: While many of the nations governors are proposing budgets that suggest anything but a tax increase, Gov. Mark Dayton of Minnesota on Tuesday advocated for higher taxes on the states wealthiest residents.

title: Do as I (Usually) Say, Not as I (Often) Do
description: A few of you have e-mailed to ask for a Motherlode discussion of Spousonomics, the new book by Jenny Anderson (a reporter for The New York Times) and Paula Szuchman (aneditor at the Wall Street Journal). The book looks at how economic principles  things like game theory and comparative advantage  can smooth the give-and-take between husband and wife.

title: A New Entrant in Adventure Travel Outfitters
description: Looking to race dune buggies in Baja California or trek through the South Pole? Try Momentum Adventure (www.momentumadventure.com), the newest entrant in the growing genre of outfitters specializing in adventurous luxury getaways. The company, which is based in East Sussex, England, makes its United States debut this month.

title: Elder Bush Receives Medal of Freedom
description: The patriarch of the Bush family dynasty stood in the White House he once led, a bit unsteady but with a large smile on his face, and accepted the nations highest civilian honor from President Obama on Tuesday.

title: Backstage Beauty | Rodarte
description: Backstage at the Rodarte show, held at the Gagosian Gallery, it was a flurry of delicate fabrics in soft shades, Native American beading, cut-out boots in burgundy, navy and forest green, and then what seemed like a non sequitur: a couple of red sequined pieces hanging in off to the side, designated for the models Karlie Kloss and Lindsey Wixson.

title: CUNY Graduate Center, 12:43 P.M.
description: City Council Speaker Christine C. Quinn delivered her 2011 State of the City address Tuesday.

title: Del Monte Ruling Challenges Cozy Bids
description: 8:43 p.m. | Updated

title: Googles Schmidt Sees Payments as a Big Business
description: BARCELONA, Spain  Eric E. Schmidt, Googles chief executive, thinks wireless transactions, enabled by the coming wave of Android smartphones outfitted with near-field communication technology, could turn into a serious business for the company.

title: Laurents-Hatcher Award Announced
description: The foundation of the Broadway director Arthur Laurents and his longtime partner, Tom Hatcher, announced on Tuesday that its first playwriting award, worth $150,000, would go to Jeff Talbott, a New York City actor who has branched out and will make his Off Broadway debut as a playwright next season. The award, which is to be given annually, provides $50,000 to the writer and $100,000 toward the production costs for mounting the recipients play. Mr. Talbotts winning play, The Submission, described as an exploration of the importance of cultural authenticity in authorship, will be produced next season at MCC Theater, which is led by Robert LuPone, Bernard Telsey, and William Cantler. The Laurents/Hatcher Foundation Award is among the most generous in playwriting, and it is intended for emerging writers. Mr. Talbott, 46, has written only a few plays and, as a playwright, still lacks an agent. Mr. Laurents, the book writer for Gypsy and West Side Story and the Tony Award-winning director of the original La Cage aux Folles, created the award last year. At 93, he is still writing plays himself; Mr. Hatcher, his partner of 52 years, died in 2006.

title: Pratt Institute Takes an Interest in Making a Neighborhood Nicer
description: Myrtle Avenue, a major east-west route through Brooklyn and parts of Queens, was named for the trees that once dotted those boroughs. But by the 1980s, the section of Myrtle that runs through the Brooklyn neighborhoods of Fort Greene and Clinton Hill had earned the nickname Murder Avenue for its high crime rate and derelict appearance.

title: Like Bloomberg, People in Thailand Like Icy Beer, Too
description: Updated, 4:55 p.m. | When the mayor said Monday that he likes to drink his beer with ice, beer connoisseurs criticized him as a wimp, a philistine and worse. On Twitter, some wondered if suds on the rocks were grounds for impeachment.

title: In Washington, a Historic Retail Strip Is Revived
description: WASHINGTON  In recent years Barracks Row, a shopping strip on Eighth Street southeast of the Capitol that had languished since the 1960s, has been transformed building by building and block by block into a popular destination for residents and Congressional employees seeking an ethnic meal or an offbeat gift.

title: Scorecard Update | Theyskens Theory
description: Theyskens TheoryDesigner: Olivier TheyskensDate and Location: Monday, Feb. 14, Center 548, 548 West 22nd StreetPhotos: slide show

title: SAC Capitals Cohen Opens Up
description: Steven A. Cohen likes Green Mountain Coffee.

title: A Tale of One City: Examining Urban Decay and Renewal
description: Overview | Why do some cities drastically lose their industries and populations? How can cities that have fallen on hard times be revitalized? In this lesson, students examine the plight and recent revitalization efforts of Braddock, Pa., and explore various urban renewal strategies implemented around the United States. They then apply their learning to their own communities or put them into historical context.

title: Rubber, a Thriller About a Tire, to Open Online
description: Automotive thrillers are a movie genre unto themselves. They range in subtlety from Christine, the Stephen King novel adaptation about a sensitive young man and the Plymouth Fury he loves, to the more superficial (if faster-paced) Death Race 2000.

title: Sanofi and Genzyme May Strike Deal by Wednesday
description: The French drug maker Sanofi-Aventis may finally announce a $19 billion takeover of Genzyme as soon as Wednesday, a person briefed on the matter told DealBook, ending months of negotiations between the two drug makers.

title: German Aide Thought Likely to Become Head of Bundesbank
description: FRANKFURT  The economic policy adviser to Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany appeared Tuesday to be the favorite to replace Axel A. Weber as president of the Bundesbank. Some analysts took the assumed appointment to mean that Germany would not push its own candidate to be president of the European Central Bank.

title: Off the Menu: Colonie in Brooklyn Heights
description: To help start their Brooklyn Heights restaurant, opening Thursday, the team developing Colonie used Kickstarter, the online system that lets entrepreneurs raise money through many small investors.

title: The Swimsuit Cover? Runs in the Family
description: Last Friday afternoon, at Blue Ribbon Sushi on Sullivan Street in SoHo, two ebullient female editors of the Sports Illustrated Swimsuit Issue were seated at a table, about to order a lot of raw fish. With them was a 30-year-old photographer named Bjorn Iooss (thats pronounced YOOOS). He was drinking a Sapporo, dressed in a stylish short-sleeved shirt with a tuxedo collar that was unbuttoned to his sternum. His curls, Grecian in their luster, fell like a mop around his chiseled face. Iooss says he likes to surf, and while he mostly does this in Montauk, N.Y., where he grew up, he somehow has a tan in February. He is exactly the kind of photographer around whom most models would automatically undress.

title: Reviewing Bar Basque
TimesCast | February 15, 2011
description: As protests continue throughout the Middle East, authoritarian governments limit Internet access.

title: Gore Vidal Political Play Returns
description: Are the Iowa presidential caucuses really less than a year away? How time flies. But an election year looms, as does the return of Gore Vidals The Best Man, the deliciously tart (when done well) play about politics, campaigns and the presidency. Jeffrey Richards and his fellow producers announced on Tuesday that they would revive that 1960 play in the spring of 2012 with hopes of catching election fever. Originally titled The Best Man, Mr. Vidals play involves a showdown at a presidential convention between two candidates, in essence an Adlai Stevenson character and a Richard Nixon type, brokered by an ill ex-president and complicated by secrets, machinations, and troubled marriages. Broadway had a revival of The Best Man not so long ago, during the campaign between George W. Bush and Al Gore and the subsequent legal battle in the fall of 2000. With political resonance and a cast led by Spalding Gray, Chris Noth, and Charles Durning, that production started off strong at the box office but had mixed reviews and declining ticket sales before closing in late December. (Mr. Gore had conceded two and a half weeks earlier.) That 2000 revival was the first Broadway producing credit for Mr. Richards, who has been a press agent since the 1970s and is now one of Broadways busiest producers. He is reuniting his producing team from 2000  Jerry Frankel, Michael B. Rothfeld, and Darren Bagert  to mount this production. The director will be Michael Wilson (The Orphans Home Cycle, Dividing the Estate). No cast members have been announced.

title: Bar Basque
description: THE codfish at Bar Basque is ethereal. It provides a taste of the North Atlantic that is as soft on the tongue as a cloud. The fish comes bathed in a gorgeous shellfish velout that owes much to the Basque sauce known as pil-pil, an emulsion that uses olive oil to elevate the flavors of fish and garlic to lordly heights. Baby root vegetables sit around the plate as throw pillows might surround a feather bed.

title: Fan Advocacy Group Wants to Witness Negotiations
description: Should fans be present if and when the N.F.L. and the players union continue face-to-face negotiations on a new labor contract?

title: The Means-Testing Mirage
description: Every once in a while people start suggesting that we save money by means-testing Medicare and Social Security  hey, Bill Gates doesnt need them.

title: Chemistry and Showstoppers at the Oscars Ceremony
description: With the Academy Awards a mere 12 days away, details are beginning to leak out about the telecast  or rather, be meted out in a very methodical, public relations-managed way. The Oscar producers, Bruce Cohen and Don Mischer, told Entertainment Weekly that the early promos featuring the shows hosts, James Franco and Anne Hathaway, were filmed on the first day they met, capturing their instant chemistry. They really play very well off of each other, Mr. Cohen told Mandi Bierly. Anne is like this hilarious Type-A overachiever who will just try anything, and James can just kind of look at her, and its funny. Both stars are pitching ideas to the writers, who include, as usual, the veteran joke-slinger Bruce Vilanch. (Hes already made some cracks about Ernest Borgnine in a Black Swan outfit.)

title: ReachLocal Buys a Daily Deal Site
description: For local businesses looking to advertise, the print Yellow Pages have been edged out by Web sites like Google and Yelp and, more recently, by daily deal sites like Groupon.

title: Deadly Error Correction
description: Skynet hasnt arrived yet  but the machines are already trying to kill us: Text Message Typo Leads to Murder:

title: CBS Says Lara Logan Suffered Brutal Attack in Cairo
description: 6:14 p.m. | Updated | Lara Logan, the CBS News correspondent, was attacked and sexually assaulted by a mob in Cairo on Feb. 11, the day that the Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak was forced from power, the network said Tuesday.

title: Photo Replay: Feb. 15
description: The day in sports included the first workouts for pitchers and catchers at spring training sites and snow polo in China.

title: Model-Morphosis | Ming Xi at Thakoon
description: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of New York Fashion Week. Here, the model Ming Xi of Ford before (left) and after (right) transforms, with makeup by Diane Kendal for NARS and hair by Odile Gilbert. (Drag the orange bar left to reveal the full transformation.)

title: American Slavery Project Focuses on Black Playwrights
description: In this sesquicentennial year of the Civil War, the New Black Fest  which aims to showcase innovative black playwrights  and 651 Arts have teamed up for the American Slavery Project. Set to begin on March 7 at the CAP 21 Theater with Fast Blood, Judy Tates play about an enslaved couple who find a man hanging from a tree and barely alive, the project is a free reading series to highlight the work of black playwrights who explore issues of slavery and the Civil War.

title: Excerpt: 'Mr. Dial Has Something to Say'
description: Scenes from a documentary about Thornton Dial, a self-taught artist from Alabama who only began making art after his retirement. (Courtesy of Ovation and Alabama Public Television)

title: The Scene: Fashion Week Day 6
description: Scenes around the city from New York Fashion Week.

title: Photographer David LaChapelle Sues Rihanna
description: Though he describes himself as a good friend of hers, the fashion and art photographer David LaChapelle has decided to settle his differences with the pop star Rihanna in a place where friends dont usually end up: court. Mr. LaChappelle, known for his candy-colored, sexually over-the-top images, claims in a suit filed Monday in federal court in Manhattan that Rihanna helped herself to too many of the images in the recently released video for her sexually over-the-top song S & M.

title: Investors Ask Diamondback for $1 Billion in Redemptions
description: 9:11 p.m. | Updated

title: Competing for the Cover of the Rolling Stone
description: AS Dr. Hook and the Medicine Show famously sang in 1973, getting your picture on the cover of the Rolling Stone signaled that a band had officially arrived. But for the first time in its 44-year history, Rolling Stone editors are ceding to readers the final decision about what band to put on a forthcoming cover.

title: Carter, Reagan and Freaky Times
description: The cultural politics of the 1970s is irresistible to historians, the way the decades dance music is irresistible to D.J.s at weddings. Thus a book like Dominic Sandbrooks Mad as Hell: The Crisis of the 1970s and the Rise of the Populist Right arrives in bookstores every six months or so. Nixon, Ford, Carter: theres little greatness there, but these presidencies are so familiar that you can hum nostalgically, dismally along.

title: Quinn Criticizes Bloomberg Plan to Cut Spending
description: Christine C. Quinn, the speaker of the City Council, on Tuesday criticized a proposal by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg to cut spending on capital projects by 20 percent over 10 years, saying it would stunt economic growth in the city.

title: Pictures of the Day: Egypt and Elsewhere
description: Photographs From Egypt, India and Russia.

title: For Cathleen Black, a First Test in Albany
description: ALBANY  One by one, school officials hunched over a microphone on Tuesday and appealed to lawmakers for relief from Gov. Andrew M. Cuomos proposed budget cuts. For many of them, the annual hearing was a familiar exercise, a wintertime rite marked by its tediousness more than anything else.

title: France Presses Case of Woman in Mexican Prison
description: PARIS  Tensions between France and Mexico over the case of a Frenchwoman serving a 60-year prison sentence in Mexico City boiled over this week, complicating relations just as a symbolic yearlong celebration of friendship has gotten under way.

title: When the Wave Hits Afghanistan
description: As reports of the riots in the Middle East continue to flood news outlets, I follow with a distance that is rather peculiar considering my history and interests. Having spent nearly seven months of my four years at West Point in Egypt and Tunisia, I hold a special place in my heart for the people of both countries. After all, they helped me learn their language, and thus gave me a conduit to understanding the depths of one of the worlds most misunderstood regions. And while a call for liberation is certainly worthy of praise, its difficult for me to feel proportionally excited for my friends in Egypt and Tunisia, because there is a third country close to my heart that few have considered in this equation: Afghanistan.

title: Music Box Makes Its Bobby Fischer Move
description: It has been almost 40 years since Bobby Fischer won the world chess championship, and more than three years since he died. Now, thanks to a documentary that made its debut at the Sundance Film Festival last month, audiences who may not know the story of Fischers brilliant but disturbed life will get a chance to learn about it this summer and fall.

title: The Ghost of Bill Blass
description: Mortimers glory years are long gone, and with them the hope of spying Gloria Vanderbilt or Anne Slater in her blue-tinted shades, seated at a window looking out on Lexington Avenue. But the passing of that fabled society haunt  it shuttered a dozen years ago  has not deterred young designers from drawing on its patrician charms. In Mortimers heyday, those charms were conferred by its patrons, and not less by their chum Bill Blass, who swathed his ladies in fox and the witty pinstripes and foulards that were the genteel uniforms of the Uptown set.

title: Dangerous Visions, Seen Then Pursued
description: Do dreams, especially the portentous kind that you cannot easily shake off, predict the future? That question is investigated in The Edge of Dreaming, a deeply personal film by Amy Hardie, a Scottish science documentarian whose world was shaken after she experienced a series of related nightmares.

title: In the Kitchen at Next
description: The first menu at Grant Achatzs new restaurant, Next, will feature food from France in the early 20th century.

title: Liberals Fight to Preserve Abortion Funding
description: Liberals rallied on Tuesday to defend funding for clinics that provide abortions and other family-planning services as lawmakers debated measures that could drastically curtail womens access to reproductive health care.

title: A New Policy on Radioactive Hotel Guests
description: A drawn-out fight over the guidelines for thyroid patients who are given radioactive drugs has taken a new turn, with a decision by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission urging them not to stay in hotels after receiving treatments.

title: Pennsylvania Employees Fired in Clinic Inquiry
description: Gov. Tom Corbett of Pennsylvania said Tuesday that several state workers had been fired and the states abortion clinics would be subjected to stricter oversight as a result of an investigation into a Philadelphia clinic where, according to the district attorney, a woman and seven newborn babies were killed in deplorable conditions.

title: British Anger Over Release of Man Linked to Bombs
description: LONDON  Amid mounting outrage in Britain, the government said Tuesday that it would press American officials for an explanation of why an operative of Al Qaeda who admitted to aiding one of the plotters of the July 2005 terrorist attacks in London was released early from prison.

title: Rising Food Prices Push Millions Into Poverty, Study Says
description: A sharp rise in food prices since June has pushed 44 million people in developing countries into extreme poverty  having to live on less than $1.25 a day  according to a new study by the World Bank.

title: Unearthly Harmonies, Best Heard in the Dark
description: During Georg Friedrich Haass In Vain, the listener experiences a heightened state of awareness, becoming acutely attuned to the intricacies of a psychedelically beautiful soundscape that often unfolds in total darkness.

title: Dells Earnings More Than Double on Sales of Computing Gear to Big Corporations
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Businesses loaded up on new computers and servers from Dell during its fourth quarter in a sign that companies are increasing their spending on technology despite a weak economy.

title: Valentines Day Postscript: The Prix Fixe Follies
description: This last weekend, I encouraged readers to rethink the annual ritual of public devotion to ones spouse or partner. And in a Bucks post on Friday, I noted that my better half and I did, in fact, plan to go out for dinner on Feb. 14, even though my column suggested that living (and eating) it up the night after Valentines Day might be a better bet.

title: A Mountain of Ai Weiweis Sunflower Seeds Sells for $560,000
description: Despite reports that it gives off hazardous porcelain dust and that there are traces of lead in the paint, one of the Chinese artist Ai Weiweis works Sunflower Seeds sold at Sothebys in London Tuesday evening for 349,250 ($559,394).

title: Crazy Little Thing Called Love, in Some of Its Many Variations
description: The course of true love never does run smooth, as listeners at the New York Philharmonics Valentines Day concert were reminded during a lineup of songs about melancholic, suicidal and incestuous love.

title: Bridges Can Still Exist in a Divided Land
description: Tariq Tapas debut feature, Zero Bridge, begins promisingly with a Kashmiri teenager being schooled in petty crime, a scene thats reminiscent of the Chinese director Jia Zhang-kes Unknown Pleasures in its immediacy and bleak authenticity. The film loses momentum after that, handicapped by Mr. Tapas sometimes sketchy screenplay and the limitations of his nonprofessional cast. (His clumsy staging of their dialogue scenes doesnt help.) But it remains a moving slice of life from a corner of the world usually seen only in news reports or as a mountainous backdrop for Bollywood musicals.

title: House Members Offer Hundreds of Budget-Cutting Amendments
description: More than 400 times, members of the House of Representatives have proposed new and different ways to cut the federal budget, from dropping all efforts to block Arizona from enacting its new immigration law, to eliminating money for Planned Parenthood to saying to Department of Agriculture employees engaged in loans for marketing mohair  Sorry! No funds for you!

title: Peltz Offers More Than $7 Billion for Family Dollar
description: The activist investor Nelson W. Peltz.

title: The Edward I. Koch (Fill In Name of Landmark Here)
description: The bridge that links Manhattan to New Jersey bears the name of a former president, George Washington. The bridge that connects Manhattan, Queens and the Bronx carries the name of a former senator, Robert F. Kennedy. Two months ago, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said that he wanted to rename the Queensboro Bridge after another political figure, this time a quintessential New Yorker: the former mayor, Edward I. Koch.

title: On the Scent of Psychopaths: Penetrating the Criminal Mind
description: Forest Whitaker, who played Idi Amin in the 2006 movie The Last King of Scotland so convincingly that he won an Oscar, has one of the most distinctive and off-kilter faces in Hollywood. So it says something about Criminal Minds: Suspect Behavior that his wardrobe is so distracting that it almost overshadows his character.

title: Tablets for Tots From Vtech and Leapfrog
description: Soon, it will be possible to hand your child their very own tablet computer, providing, of course, you can pry your smartphone out of their hands.

title: TV Series Tries to Revive Civil Rights Cold Cases
description: The murder has never been solved: On Feb. 27, 1967, Wharlest Jackson, a father of five and the treasurer of the Natchez, Miss., branch of the N.A.A.C.P., was killed by a car bomb, making him just one of dozens of victims of racial violence during the civil rights era. To add an element of horror, Mr. Jacksons 8-year-old son heard the explosion, bicycled to the scene and discovered his own father.

title: For Cold Virus, Zinc May Edge Out Even Chicken Soup
description: Scientists still havent discovered a cure for the common cold, but researchers now say zinc may be the next best thing.

title: An Oscar Turn for White House Decorator
description: What were we saying about the public relations Oscar drip? Oh, right. So this year the Academy Awards green room  sponsored for the ninth consecutive year by Architectural Digest  will be designed by Michael S. Smith, were now allowed to exclusively announce. Mr. Smith, who was chosen to help redecorate the White House, envisions the nominees and presenters lounging around in his elegant, 1940s-style library  complete with a sophisticated color palette and furnishings that celebrate Hollywoods golden era, according to a statement from the magazine. Margaret Russell, the editor in chief, added that though his design reflects midcentury Hollywood glamour, his interpretation of the space is state of the art. Also, the space is officially called the Architectural Digest Oscar Greenroom, which is, were sure, how everyone will officially refer to it on the night of the show.

title: Buzz Tracker
description: Dont Sue Fabulous Fab: Lawyers for Fabrice Tourre, the Goldman Sachs trader accused of misleading investors on a mortgage investment, asked a judge to throw out the lawsuit filed by the Securities and Exchange Commission.BLOOMBERG

title: Knicks Stoudemire Ready for Rematch With Hawks
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Amare Stoudemire and Al Horford will be teammates Sunday at the All-Star Game in Los Angeles in a mostly friendly and largely ceremonially celebration.

title: The Commercial War on Teacher Layoffs
description: When Cathleen P. Black, the schools chancellor, testified before the State Legislature on Tuesday about what she called the unavoidable teacher layoffs in New York City that would take place if the governors proposed education budget were approved, a line from her remarks might have rung familiar to regular watchers of television ads.

title: Kerry Says U.S. Will Investigate Case of American Accused of Killing 2 Pakistanis
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Senator John Kerry, sent by the White House to win the release of an American official held in prison and accused of killing two Pakistanis, expressed remorse on Tuesday for the episode and pledged that the United States would conduct a criminal investigation once the official was returned.

title: Lindsay Lohan to Read Top 10 on Letterman
description: One of David Lettermans favorite subjects of jokes in recent monologues will now get a chance to deliver a few laughs on her own: Lindsay Lohan will appear on Late Show with David Letterman Thursday night to present that nights Top-10 list.

title: The Wristwatch Looks For a New Use
description: Last year while writing about students entering their first year of college I made an interesting observation: these newly commissioned freshmen dont use wristwatches. In fact, the wristwatch is so alien to this group of late teens, that even the mere action of pointing to a wrist to ask someone the time is akin to speaking anunfamiliarforeign language. (They use mobile phones and laptops to tell the time.)

title: Egypt Leaders Found Off Switch for Internet
description: Epitaphs for the Mubarak government all note that the mobilizing power of the Internet was one of the Egyptian oppositions most potent weapons. But quickly lost in the swirl of revolution was the governments ferocious counterattack, a dark achievement that many had thought impossible in the age of global connectedness. In a span of minutes just after midnight on Jan. 28, a technologically advanced, densely wired country with more than 20 million people online was essentially severed from the global Internet.

title: Planets Named for Banks, and Snobbish Robots
description: Green is a smart, evocative play title for the age we live in. But Chris Harcums Green, at the Metropolitan Playhouse in the East Village, has nothing to say about sustainable fuels or chemical-free foods or any aspect of environmentalism. Green is just a guys name.

title: In-Laws Are Core Issue for This Adam and Eve
description: A satirical cartoon about an America increasingly enfeebled by its fear of anything outside the sanctioned norm, Lynn Rosens comedy Apple Cove is part eco-fable, part Stepford Wives riff, part cautionary tale for a hermetic society. This play is many things, just not as funny or clever as it should be.

title: Air Products Bid Dies as Airgas Poison Pill Lives On
description: 7:02 p.m. | Updated

title: A Playwrights Fictions Stay Close to Real Life
description: CHICAGO  Midway through the second of the three Trinity River Plays at the Goodman Theater here, a small moment takes place that is hauntingly familiar to anyone with an elderly parent.

title: 3 States Challenge Federal Policy on Storing Nuclear Waste
description: WASHINGTON  The attorneys general of New York, Connecticut and Vermont sued the Nuclear Regulatory Commission on Tuesday, challenging a new commission policy stating that nuclear waste can be safely stored at a nuclear power plant for 60 years after a reactor goes out of service.

title: Secrets of a Mind-Gamer
description: How I trained my brain and became a world-class memory athlete.

title: Laughter Lifts CBS in Ratings
description: CBS topped the ratings on Monday with new episodes of Two and a Half Men, starring Jon Cryer, above left, and Charlie Sheen, above right, and Mike & Molly. Those sitcoms delivered the largest audiences of the night, according to Nielsens estimates, with Two and a Half Men drawing 14.5 million viewers at 9 p.m. and Mike & Molly attracting 13.1 million at 9:30, a record for the series. CBS broadcast the premiere of its new comedy Mad Love (8.8 million viewers) at 8:30 p.m. after How I Met Your Mother (9.6 million). CBSs Hawaii Five-0 led the 10 p.m. time slot with 10.6 million viewers, outperforming ABCs Castle (8.8 million) and Harrys Law on NBC (8.5 million). ABC was second for the night, Fox was in third and NBC finished in fourth.

title: 3-D Comes to Met Opera, but Without Those Undignified Glasses
description: Purveyors of entertainment, in the ever-urgent quest to grab audiences attention, have used 3-D imagery in movies and, more recently, television. Now it is coming to live theater.

title: Another Day, Another Restaurant-Discount Web Site
description: Start-up restaurant-discount Web sites are becoming more numerous than those Chinese menus stuffed in New Yorkers mailboxes. Now comes DineTonite, which offers real-time reservations and discounts from 20 to 40 percent at nearly 30 restaurants. Most of them are neighborhood spots in Manhattan, and many are already moderately priced. The roster includes some of the Ninos group of old-school Italian restaurants; the upscale Italian steakhouse Padre Figlio, and Nocello, the Tuscan standby near Carnegie Hall.

title: Scientists See Success in Flu Vaccine Made by Faster Method
description: A flu vaccine made by a new, faster method works just as well as existing products, researchers reported Tuesday.

title: Nonfiction: Print vs. E-Books
description: The 10 best-selling nonfiction titles and how their sales ranked in print  including both hardcover and paperback  and in E-book formats.

title: Revisiting Escoffier: Grant Achatzs New Restaurant, Next
description: A tryout dinner, painstakingly reproduced from the classical French repertoire, for the Chicago chefs new restaurant.

title: Little Marc Goes Long
description: Marc Jacobs did not apply the same degree of strictness to his Marc by Marc Jacobs collection (or Little Marc, as we like to call it) today as he did in his signature collection shown last night. But it did look more oriented toward grown-ups than usual, certainly with more tweedy pantsuits and long-sleeve silk dresses and less of the playful sportswear.

title: At Westminster Dog Show, Familiar Breeds Get Little Respect
description: In the hours before a dog competes at the Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show, tensions can mount as owners and handlers furiously prepare their canine divas for the ring. Hair is blown straight or teased into fanciful poufs. Snouts and paws are daubed with talcum powder. Wayward hairs and whiskers are trimmed with precision.

title: Iona College Names a New President
description: Iona College, a Roman Catholic institution run by the Christian Brothers in New Rochelle, N.Y., has named the head of an Illinois childrens center as its next president.

title: Chicago Is Now Smaller and Less Black, Census Shows
description: CHICAGO  As Chicagoans prepare to vote next week for their first new mayor in decades, the city itself looks different from how it did during much of the era of Mayor Richard M. Daley, who is retiring: it has shrunk, and black people in particular have left.

title: Halstons Disco Revival
description: The Halston collection for fall 2011, shown on Tuesday in an event space in Chelsea, wasnt much different from the last couple of Halston collections by the designer Marios Schwab, nor, for that matter, from those shown by Halston himself in the 1970s. Thats not much of a surprise, as the companys latest revival seems intent on sticking to the jersey dress formula.

title: Its Good to Know Its Not All About Posing
description: Fashion is perversely and infinitely unfair. Both Marc Jacobs and Ralph Rucci possess know-how, no small thing in an era of disappearing hand arts and factories. Yet Mr. Jacobs is considered cool, and Mr. Rucci is not. And by offering his shows as conceptual and social experiences, Mr. Jacobs in a way acknowledges the breakup of traditional fashion over the last 20 years. Mr. Rucci continues to make elegant clothes.

title: For Actresses, Is a Big Appetite Part of the Show?
description: MINKA KELLY, the sexiest woman alive, slides a fork into a tangle of spaghetti carbonara. Zo Saldana has a basket of fried calamari. Jennifer Lawrence, an Oscar nominee for her leading role in Winters Bone, wants it known that a skimpy morning repast is not going to satisfy her.

title: Sound Bites: Actresses on Their Love of Food
description: Actresses who have gushed to journalists about how much they love to chow down.

title: A Cookie Paste Squeezed in the Middle of a Debate
description: EEKLO, Belgium

title: From a Fashionista, a Candy Thats Loved in Brazil
description: For Brazilians, brigadeiro, a cross between fudge and a chocolate truffle, is an iconic sweet. Paula Barbosa (above), a fashion producer from Rio who moved to New York and who has been making brigadeiros since she was a teenager, started My Sweet Brigadeiro and makes them in a commercial kitchen in Lower Manhattan. Her lush candies come in several flavors: milk chocolate, white chocolate, coconut and pistachio. All can be ordered with toppings like chocolate sprinkles or coconut. Little brigadeiro cups and larger jars have the consistency of soft caramel (cue dulce de leche).

title: Wild Blueberry Juice Offers a Sip of Summer
description: Sip some rich, intense Van Dyks Wild Blueberry Juice from Nova Scotia and instead of wintry gloom, think camping among the pines in August and berry picking near a meadow. You can enjoy it alone or over ice, without worrying about mosquitoes, but given its price, a little can do a lot to add dimension to afternoon tea, provide a base for a granit or sorbet and give new personality to that cosmo or martini. It has no sweeteners or other additives and is worth keeping on hand year-round.

title: Off the Menu
description: OPENING

title: Porsena
description: 21 East Seventh Street (Third Avenue), East Village; (212) 228-4923.

title: Crackers With a Good New England Crunch
description: Taking the name to heart, the folks in Castleton, Vt., actually hand-crack the sheets of thin flatbread they make for their crackers. They have nailed the texture perfectly: sturdy enough for spreading and dipping, but flaky enough for nibbling like potato chips.

title: Dining Calendar
description: Tasting History

title: A Skinny Clam Thats Big With Chefs
description: UNTIL recently, the long, narrow razor clam was easier to find on a beach than in a restaurant. Except in Asian places, it rarely made the cut.

title: Razor Clam Ceviche
description: Time: 20 minutes plus 3 hours chilling

title: Air Products Drops Its Bid for Air Gas
description: Air Products and Chemicals dropped its $5.9 billion hostile bid for Airgas Tuesday after a Delaware judge upheld Airgass main anti-takeover defense.

title: I.M.F. Said to Have Harsh Assessment of Troubled Kabul Bank
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  An International Monetary Fund review of the Afghan governments progress in determining what went wrong at the nations largest bank and the steps necessary to fix it has concluded that so little has been done so far that there is no possibility of renewing the funds program here, diplomats in Kabul said.

title: Role for Teachers Is Seen in Solving Schools Crises
description: DENVER  Secretary of Education Arne Duncan, convening a two-day labor-management conference here on Tuesday, argued that teachers unions can help solve many of the challenges facing public schools.

title: England Finds 2012 Olympics Dont Spur Exercise
description: When London was awarded the 2012 Olympics, organizers promised an ambitious legacy: to get two million more people in England involved in sports and physical activity.

title: Nourishing Family Roots to Help a Campaign Bloom

title: Riding the Clippers Roller Coaster
description: To say the Los Angeles Clippers have had an up-and-down season would be something of an understatement. First, the team lost 13 of its first 14 games and 21 of 26. Then the team got hot and won 14 of its next 21 games. The Clippers successful stretch included wins over the Bulls, Heat and Lakers, nine consecutive home wins, and a 47-point performance from All-Star rookie Blake Griffin. All of a sudden, the Clippers were a team on the rise. People even started talking about the possibility of the Clippers making the playoffs.

title: WikiLeaks Allies Fight Order on Twitter Data
description: ALEXANDRIA, Va.  Lawyers for three Twitter users on Tuesday asked a judge to vacate an order requiring the social-networking Web site to turn over its account records to prosecutors who are investigating WikiLeaks for its role in disclosing secret government documents last year.

title: Contador Is Cleared of Doping Charges and Will Return to Racing
description: The three-time Tour de France champion Alberto Contador, cleared on Tuesday by the Spanish cycling federation of doping charges from last summers Tour, called his exoneration bittersweet.

title: For Egypt, a Fresh Start, With Cities
description: It would be easy to look at the images coming out of Cairo over the last few weeks and think of Egypt as a highly urbanized society. It would also be wrong.

title: Red Bulls in Black  er Dark Blue
description: 12:34 p.m. | Updated  A Red Bulls spokesman pointed out Wednesday morning that although the picture of Tim Ream, right, the team used to promote its new away jersey appears to be black, it is actually dark blue. It is the teams new away jersey, not a third jersey. Some old eyes are not what they used to be!

title: Somalia: Government Forces Fire on Demonstrators, Killing 5
description: Witnesses and a local government official said that at least five people were killed and an additional 10 were wounded on Tuesday when government forces fired on a demonstration against the Shabab, a radical Islamist group that has taken over many parts of the country. It is not yet clear why the government forces, which are plagued by a lack of discipline, fired on the demonstrators, and the government did not issue a statement on the violence.

title: Feeling Noirish
description: These days we tend to think of film noir  The Big Sleep and Laura top our list  as nothing less than masterpieces. But there was no such thing as film noir in the 1940s and early-1950s when the best of them first came out. Many of the classics of the category were, in fact, B films  lesser creations with a dark, brooding presence made at a time when movies were still filmed in black and white on actual 35 mm stock and not on the 1s and 0s of todays digitally recorded movies.

title: N.F.L. Labor Dispute: Words but No Talks

title: Why Arent G.M.O. Foods Labeled?
description: If you want to avoid sugar, aspartame, trans-fats, MSG, or just about anything else, you read the label. If you want to avoid G.M.O.s  genetically modified organisms  youre out of luck. Theyre not listed. You could, until now, simply buy organic foods, which by law cant contain more than 5 percent G.M.O.s. Now, however, even that may not work.

title: The Skirmish Over High-Risk Pools
description: As part of the new health care reform, the federal government and 27 state governments are establishing temporary high-risk pools to offer coverage for people with pre-existing conditions until the law takes full effect in 2014. The effort has gotten off to a slow start, and Republican critics have, predictably, seized on that as proof that the government will be incapable of managing the much more complex changes lying ahead.

title: Obama, Conceding Budgets Limitations, Seeks Consensus
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama conceded on Tuesday that his new budget does not do enough to resolve the nations long-term fiscal problems, but he counseled patience, suggesting that he would eventually come together with Republicans on a broad deal.

A Conversation With Edward L. Glaeser

The current issue of The Atlantic includes a version of his chapter on skyscrapers, and The Economist and The New York Times have reviewed the book. The Times Magazine profiled Mr. Glaeser in 2006. Our conversation follows.

description: Personal shopping and cleaning services for the disabled would be eliminated, weak hospitals could be merged and brand-name drugs would be limited under a series of budget-cutting proposals announced on Tuesday by the New York State Health Department.

Yet as much as it pains Scorecard to say it, critical consensus was to support fashions erstwhile enfant terrible Olivier Theyskenss new Theory that when it comes to a lot of look, less meta is more.

title: Montana: $9.4 Million to Protect Flathead River
description: Efforts to protect the Flathead River, which flows down from Canada in a wild region of the northern Rockies, got a boost Tuesday with a commitment of private conservation money to stave off mining development. Wildlife use the Flathead River basin as a corridor of migration, making it an anchor of a 10-million-acre swath of wilderness in Montana and Canada called the Crown of the Continent. The Nature Conservancy and Nature Conservancy Canada committed $9.4 million, which would be paid to lease holders of gold and coal claims in British Columbia pending completion of the deal. KIRK JOHNSON

title: Narciso Rodriguez: Not Trying to Be Groovy
description: The music for Narciso Rodriguezs show on Tuesday night was throbbing, layered, with a kinky voiceover breaking into the beat. I was compelled to listen, just as I was interested at all times in the clothes. This was a terrific collection, different than what he has done in several years. It was looser, more abstract, with a downbeat attitude that felt true and fresh, and masculine elements that worked so smoothly into the collection that you didnt really notice them at first.

title: Yankees A. J. Burnett Knows Pressure Is On
description: TAMPA, Fla.  A. J. Burnett recently moved. Not far, just a few doors down starters row in the Yankees clubhouse, to the corner locker once occupied by Andy Pettitte. The contrast was striking. Where reliability dressed for several years, volatility now hangs his designer T-shirts.

title: Israel: Four Foreign Missions Closed
description: Israel temporarily closed four of its diplomatic missions abroad in recent days because of suspicions that they were under threat of attack, an Israeli official said on Tuesday. He refused to specify their locations, for security reasons, but he said that two had partially reopened. The precautions were taken after unusual occurrences were identified recently around a few missions abroad, the Israeli government said in a statement. The Israeli Counter-Terrorism Bureau had issued a travel advisory on Friday warning of a heightened threat against Israeli and Jewish targets abroad because of anniversaries this week of the deaths of two senior Hezbollah figures. It listed Egypt, Turkey, Georgia, Armenia, Ivory Coast, Mali, Mauritania and Venezuela as countries with a heightened risk. Imad Mugniyah, a Hezbollah commander, was killed by a bomb in Damascus in February 2008, and Hezbollah blamed Israel for his death. Sheik Abbas Musawi, a leader of Hezbollah, was killed by Israeli forces in February 1992.

title: Russia: 10 Die in North Caucasus Clashes
description: At least 10 people died Tuesday in clashes between the police and militants in the Russian North Caucasus. The police in Chechnya said that they surrounded a house where two militants were hiding, and that one of the fighters set off an explosion that killed both of them. Meanwhile, three police officers and five militants died during a shootout on the border between the regions of Karachayevo-Cherkesiya and Stavropol. The news comes a day after two suicide bombers blew themselves up in front of police stations in Dagestan, killing three and injuring 26. The two bombers, who police said they believed were a married couple, had been sought in connection with a botched suicide bombing planned for New Years Eve in central Moscow.

title: A College Thats Pleased With Its Drop in Applicants

title: Notes From the Underground | Amber Martin
description: Last week, the multitalented Amber Martin wrapped up a four-week run of her latest show, Amber Alert, in front of a sold-out house at the Wild Project in the East Village. Martin seamlessly floated between multiple costumes, personae and skits, never once leaving the stage, and carrying the calm of a seasoned performer through comedic routines, duets and classic vocal covers. Martins first such transformation was from Daydra, a walking trailer-trash disaster complete with raspy smokers voice and greasy mullet, into the very vision of a solo diva, in a floor-length gown and heels, launching into a pitch-perfect rendition of Dionne Warwicks first hit, Dont Make Me Over. Guest performers included the Scissor Sisters frontman Jake Shears, the hysterical Bridget Everett and the gender-bending guitarist NathAnn Carerra, with whom Martin performed a very curious duet.

title: What Urban Legends Are There About Places in Your Area?
description: According to About.com, an urban legend is an apocryphal, secondhand story, told as true and just plausible enough to be believed, about some horrific, embarrassing, ironic or exasperating series of events that supposedly happened to a real person. This Times story, about a cursed mansion in Hollywood, is one example. What urban legends are there about houses, parks, stores or other places in your area? title: Staying Connected Overseas (Cheaply)
description: I do a modest amount of international business travel, including Asia. I pretty much always have multiple projects in various stages of production, which typically means I cant afford to be out of touch for much more than a few hours. (Also, I want to be available for family emergencies, like the time the TV went on the fritz.) Ive put a lot of effort into figuring out tricks for being reachable by phone and e-mail without spending a fortune. Trust me, its easy to run up a thousand-dollar bill on your cellphone in a single trip if you dont know the ins and outs. And not being in touch at all can be even more costly. Here are some of the lessons Ive learned:

title: A Bohemian Marriage for the Met and Juilliard
description: For any savvy operagoer, an evening spent with The Bartered Bride, a rustic comedy by Smetana more widely known about than actually seen, is an evening spent waiting for the other shoe to drop. Introduced in 1866 and completed in 1870, this romantic frolic is built on a plot twist predictable from miles away, a triumph of true love over cynical calculation. The ending is never in doubt, yet the opera remains irresistible for its charming characters and lively pace, and, above all, for its rich, colorful score: part bubbly operetta, part Bohemian folk pageant.

Here, the model Sigrid Agren of New York Models before (left) and after (right) transforms, with makeup by Lucia Pieroni for Cle de Peau and hair by Orlando Pita for Moroccan Oil. (Drag the orange bar left to reveal the full transformation.)

title: New Phones Being Shown at Mobile World Congress
description: Sony Ericsson, LG, INQ and HTC all introduced new phones at the trade show in Barcelona.

title: The Short Timeline in the Borders Bankruptcy
description: That the Borders Group has filed a Chapter 11 petition is not so much news. Its fate will undoubtedly be blamed on e-books and Amazon.com, but big box retail companies like Borders, Barnes & Noble, Blockbuster and Circuit City long ago decided to compete solely on the basis of price, and they rise and fall on that basis alone. It seems to me that this is not so much about e-books as competition with a lower priced rival.

title: Phones Try to Stand Out in a Crowd
description: BARCELONA, Spain  It is the modern phone makers quandary. In the touch-screen era, how do you stand out from the crowd when most phones are near-identical glassy rectangles?

title: Feb. 16: Updates on Middle East Protests
description: On Wednesday, The Lede is following news of Egypts transition online and reports of new unrest in Libya, Bahrain, Yemen and Iran. Updates below mix alerts on breaking news with reports from bloggers and journalists on the ground. A stream of Twitter updates on regional protests is in this blogs right column.

title: Visas, Fancy Dresses and a Garbage-Strewn Documentary
description: The last time the Bagger encountered Lucy Walker, a director of the Oscar-nominated documentary Waste Land, she was worried about two things: Whether a star of her film, a Brazilian trash picker named Sebastiao Carlos dos Santos and known as Tiao, would be able to get a visa to get into the United States for the ceremony; and what she would wear to it.

title: Household Debt Falls for 9th Quarter
description: This week the Federal Reserve Bank of New York released its quarterly report on household debt and credit, which showed that total consumer debt declined again in the fourth quarter, continuing what is now a nine-quarter-long slide in household debt.

title: Hockeys Code: Be Boring
description: Hockey fans love to talk about the code, the mythical set of guidelines that determine what sort of behavior is acceptable on the ice. But those in the hockey world live by a different code once theyre off the ice and in front of a microphone, and that code can be summarized as be boring.

title: Things That Make Me Stop Reading
description: Avinash Persaud:

title: Sebelius Clears the Way for Arizona to Shed Adults From Medicaid
description: The Obama administration gave a green light on Tuesday to Arizonas plan to remove about 250,000 adults from its Medicaid rolls, instructing the state that it could circumvent a requirement in the new health care law that prohibits reductions in eligibility.

title: There Is Still No Such Thing As Socialsecuritymedicareandmedicaid
description: And President Obama, Im glad to see, knows that:

title: What Were Reading
description: The Washington Post: How can you get by for a week following the governments recommended limit of 1,500 milligrams a day of salt?  Nick Fox

description: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of New York Fashion Week. Here, the model Edita Vilkeviciute from DNA Model Management before (left) and after (right) transforms, with makeup by James Kaliardos and hair by Odile Gilbert.
