title: Wednesday Reading: The $100 Paris Weekend
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: Asterisks: The Gall
description: Yay Bob Greenstein! The very judicious, careful president of the very judicious, careful Center on Budget and Policy Priorities has the courage to say that the emperor has no clothes:

title: Arena Stage Plans 11 Productions in New Home
description: Arena Stage on Wednesday announced 11 productions for its second season in its $135 million new home in southwest Washington, D.C.  a lineup that reflects its commitment to mounting home-grown plays, new works and American classics.

title: Angry Demonstrations in Wisconsin as Cuts Loom
description: MADISON, Wis.  As four game wardens awkwardly stood guard, protesters, scores deep, crushed into a corridor leading to the governors office here on Wednesday, their screams echoing through the Capitol: Come out, come out, wherever you are!

title: Photos of the Moment | Marc by Marc Jacobs
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#490", 592, 440, true, chameleonData);

title: Merkel Names an Adviser to Lead the Central Bank
description: BERLIN  Chancellor Angela Merkel on Wednesday named a trusted economics adviser, Jens Weidmann, to be the next head of Bundesbank, the German central bank in Frankfurt, leaving a big gap in her administration as she tries to lead Europe out of its sovereign debt crisis.

title: Crystal-Clear Conversation Amid the Pounding Music
description: As part of our continuing quest to help you win your Oscar pool  and again, not at all as part of an end-of-season notebook dump  the Bagger returns to the hard-to-predict sound design category.

title: Decade Later, Waltrip Deals With a Crash at Daytona
description: The DVD was sitting in Michael Waltrips house for nine and a half years while the accident churned inside him.

title: Non-English Tip Policy Raises Eyebrows, Then Fades
description: HONOLULU  Asian visitors make up a major part of Hawaiis tourism trade, as reflected in window signs all across the island of Oahu, particularly in restaurant and hotel-heavy districts like Waikiki.

title: Job Worries Override Health Concerns
description: Getting employees to focus on their health can be challenging in the best of times, but may be even harder during tough economic times, according to Towers Watson, a consulting firm that advises employers on health benefits.

title: Mainland Shivers, and Hawaii Basks in Tourism
description: HONOLULU  One recent afternoon, as the temperature in their native Nashville dipped to a slim 7 degrees, Blythe Grant and Jordan Tlumak walked along the beach at Waikiki with beers in hand and smiles on their faces.

title: Save on Your Next Trip With Local Deal Sites
description: I LIKE a good deal as much as anyone. So when daily deal sites like Groupon.com and LivingSocial.com, which negotiate major discounts from local businesses and distribute them via e-mail to those who sign up, became all the rage, I quickly signed up for as many as I could find. But I wanted to go beyond the local concept and search for travel bargains in other cities  a $129 surf lesson for $49 in Dana Point, Calif.; a $165 guided rock-climbing adventure near Denver for $55; a $159 dinner cruise for $90 in Chicago.

title: Byfuglien Commits to Thrashers, Even as Their Future Is Unclear
description: Dustin Byfuglien has heard the speculation of the Thrashers uncertain future in Atlanta, but it did not stop him from signing a five-year contract extension with the club.

title: Bosphorising
description: Giving in to the beauty of the Bosphorus.

title: Photos of the Moment | Sophie Theallet
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#370", 592, 490, true, chameleonData);

title: Onstage, Only His Guitar Gently Weeps
description: At 58, Mark Vaccacio is the oldest of the four men in the band, but in his mop-top wig, dark glasses and pointy boots, he is also the most boyish. For he is by far the thinnest, swaying in his black suit as if he were an extension of the cord plugged into his vintage guitar. Mr. Vaccacio is the same weight as the young George Harrison he plays onstage, but not out of a sense of authenticity  all of his beloved Irish-bar cheeseburgers and onion rings and milkshakes do not add any pounds.

title: Skiing Your Way to Hedonistic Sustainability
description: If youre itching to visit the new advanced waste management plant that will open in 2016 in Copenhagen, be sure to bring your skis. An urban ski park will cover the plant, which will incinerate the waste from five municipalities to generate heat and electricity for 140,000 homes. While their trash is burning inside, locals will be able to take an elevator to the top of the building, then ski down one of three different slopes, graded by difficulty, that jointly run about 5,000 feet.

title: Chase Waives Foreign Exchange Fees for Continental and United Cards
description: There is more good news for international travelers tired of fees that credit card companies tack on when merchants process a transaction outside of the United States.

title: Jos Gregorio Has Left the Bar; Its Owners Want Him Back
description: Kidnapped! reads the Web site of Barbs, a Park Slope, Brooklyn, bar and restaurant popular for its live music. Beneath the striking red text is an image of a statue  the bust of a man with jet black hair and a matching mustache and eyebrows. It is about two feet tall and sits in a cubbyhole.

title: A Sweet Show, With Blasphemy and Cussing
description: NOT long into Act I of The Book of Mormon, a new Broadway musical comedy written and composed by Trey Parker, Matt Stone and Robert Lopez, two young Mormon missionaries arrive in Uganda after an arduous journey from Salt Lake City, during which they have suffered a cramped flight and the theft of their luggage.

title: Holy Terrors: A Conversation With the Creators of The Book of Mormon
description: What happens when you put Trey Parker and Matt Stone, the unrepentant provocateurs behind Comedy Centrals animated series South Park, together with Robert Lopez, who tarnished sacred childhood memories as a co-creator of the Tony-winning puppet musical Avenue Q? At the very least, you get The Book of Mormon, their new musical comedy  nearly eight years in the making  about a pair of young Mormon missionaries whose sunny dispositions and understandings of their faith are seriously challenged when they are dispatched to remote Uganda.

title: Style Setters | Van Cleef & Arpels at the Cooper-Hewitt
description: In the late 1930s, the Duchess of Windsor proposed a fashionably novel and, for the time, technologically complex idea to Van Cleef & Arpels: make her a piece of jewelry that zips. More than a decade later, the duchess got her wish. The necklace that resulted was really a kind of partnership, says Sarah Coffin, the curator of the Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museum. This wasnt just a little brooch, she says, noting the necklaces intricacy and the intervening war, which brought French jewelry production to a near standstill. This piece and many other diamond-encrusted feats of ingenuity will be on display at the Cooper-Hewitt from Feb. 18 to June 5 as part of Set in Style: The Jewelry of Van Cleef & Arpels.

title: CERV: A New Kind of Army Green
description: Just beyond the stands of mainstream manufacturers during last weeks Chicago auto show press previews, stood an unusual, rugged-looking vehicle. Though its crude appearance might suggest otherwise, the Clandestine Extended Range Vehicle, or CERV, is an all-wheel-drive diesel hybrid that $14 billion in federal financing for dual-use advanced technology helped to build.

title: New Security Plan for Statue of Liberty Is Delayed
description: While in New York on Thursday, Interior Secretary Ken Salazar had hoped to announce changes in how visitors to the Statue of Liberty are screened for weapons and other hazards.

title: Photos of the Moment | Halston
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#342", 592, 440, true, chameleonData);

title: Floridas Governor Rejects High-Speed Rail Line, Fearing Cost to Taxpayers
description: In the most significant blow yet to the Obama administrations vision of a national high-speed rail network, Gov. Rick Scott of Florida on Wednesday rejected plans for a high-speed link between Tampa and Orlando, in the process turning down more than $2 billion in federal money.

title: Korss Relaxed Glamour Turns 30
description: On Tuesday night, during fittings, Michael Kors said he cried for the first time in his 30 years in fashion. He was overcome, he said, by the moment and by just how fast it seems that three decades have passed.

title: ING Posts $585 Million Profit
description: The ING Group, the Dutch financial services company, reported on Wednesday a net income of 433 million euros ($585 million) in the fourth quarter of 2010, compared with a loss of 712 million euros in the same period of 2009.

title: Somali Pirate Sentenced to Nearly 34 Years
description: A Somali man who pleaded guilty to hijacking an American-flagged cargo ship off the coast of Africa in 2009 was sentenced on Wednesday in Federal District Court in Manhattan to 33 years and 9 months in prison.

title: Comcast Posts 7% Rise in Revenue as Subscribers Buy Bigger Cable Packages
description: The Comcast Corporation, the largest cable company in the United States, reported Wednesday that its revenue rose 7 percent in the fourth quarter, its last before taking control of NBC Universal.

title: To Ecuador, With Sea Turtles in Mind
description: Lekelia D. Jenkins, a postdoctoral researcher at the University of Washington, writes from Ecuador, where she is studying factors in the cross-cultural adoption of marine conservation technologies like turtle excluder devices and circle hooks. She co-leads this project with Patrick Christie, who is an environmental sociologist and Associate Professor at the University of Washington.

title: Go Hands-Free, or Risk Points on Your License
description: Drivers, put down your phones, for the good of your licenses. Starting today, a ticket in New York State for talking on a cellphone while driving will cost you two points, in addition to the $100 it has cost since 2001, way back when New York became the first state in the nation to ban hand-held phone use while driving.

title: Louise Goldin Takes Manhattan
description: Louise Goldin, one of the bright young things of English design, chose to unveil her collection in New York this time round. Its because of my engagement, says Goldin, 28, flashing her sparkling ring finger. Its always because of a guy. Not that her work is taking a second seat to her man  today she leaves for Los Angeles to dress Rihanna for her birthday bash and then its back to London. Its easy to imagine Rihanna loving the designers metal hardware leather and suede lace-up booties (Manolo Blahnik teamed up with her this season), cashmere knit body-con dresses and sweaters (inspired by South African murals). There is also a punky quilted leather skirt and a jacket lined with fox fur and embossed with a leather tribal print that is a nice addition to Goldins usual all-knit collections.

title: Best in Show II  This Time Its for Real
description: Fred R. Conrad has been shooting for The Times for 34 years. Theres little he hasnt experienced. When he set out to photograph the Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show this week, he knew his dog portraits would have to be taken quickly and that he might have trouble with some of his subjects  or their handlers.

title: The A, B, Cs of Limiting Climate Risk
description: There appears to be a breath of fresh air wafting through the environmental community, reflected in Degrees of Risk: Defining a Risk Management Framework for Climate Security, a new report from the Britain-based nonprofit group Third Generation Environmentalism, or E3G. The report is enthusiastically endorsed by Bill Becker, the head of the Presidential Climate Action Plan, in a guest post at Climateprogress.

title: Photos of the Moment | Narciso Rodriguez
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#745", 592, 440, true, chameleonData);

title: Snapshot of One Colleges Admissions Process
description: The segment linked above, which was broadcast this morning on NBCs Today show, takes viewers behind the closed doors of the admissions process at Grinnell College in Iowa. Grinnell, which has received nearly 3,000 applications for an incoming freshman class of about 400, follows an intensive, holistic process similar to those used at dozens of other selective (and in some cases fiercely competitive) colleges, both public and private.

title: Make Art, Get Art in Return at Tribeca Film Festival
description: 2:22 p.m. | Updated

title: Joking, to a Point, About a Property Tax Cap
description: ALBANY  Unable to afford shoulder pads, the members of the high school football team swaddle themselves with pillows before taking the field. Emergency dispatchers have been replaced by an automated system to save money. After teacher layoffs, school principals are calling for volunteers to teach basic subjects.

title: Irrational Design, a San Francisco Start-Up, Tries to Fly Solo
description: Last April, Jared Cosulich and Adam Abrons founded Irrational Design, a technology company, in San Francisco. Since its debut, the start-up has introduced three online commercial products. The founders, who met while working at a software engineering company, Pivotal Labs, are determined to build a business that is free to take risks.

title: Google Announces Payment System for Digital Content
description: SAN FRANCISCO  A day after Apple stirred up online publishers by announcing a digital subscription plan that some called too restrictive and financially burdensome, Google on Wednesday announced its own payment service for digital content that aims to be more publisher-friendly.

title: Backstage Beauty | Narciso Rodriguez
description: Weve never done anything like this at Narciso, the hairstylist Eugene Soulemain said backstage at the Narciso Rodriguez show. I scared the life out of him. The style, a simple and somewhat haphazard knot just above the nape of the neck, was roughed up further with the addition of a few pats of Wella Professionals Texture Touch pressed in near the hairline, followed by a few spritzes of Wella Professionals Shimmer Delight to make it look like shes been running and sweating. Soulemain said the edgier cast of models, which included Jamie Bochert (who had never walked for Rodriguez), inspired the look. Even though the clothes are incredibly expensive, not everythings pretty and so fitted, Soulemain explained. Its not a red-carpet feeling. Clearly, Rodriguez was convinced, seeing as he rang the manicurist Deborah Lippmann at 3 p.m. yesterday with some color direction. He said, I want a color thats not charcoal and not blue and not black, but strong  they wanted to have some strength and toughness, Lippmann said. (The gray she created will be named by Rodriguez and produced later this year.) The makeup artist Dick Page lined eyes with Shiseido cream shadows in Purple Dawn and Caviar, a black (available this fall). Im trying to leave the skin alone as much as possible. Since were at the beginning of the season, there are no big skin disasters yet, Page said, joking that his own disaster  a black eye he acquired last week  inspired the look. One skin care product even made it onto models faces: Shiseido Benefiance Full Correction Lip Treatment, which was smudged onto the lids just before the show to create a melty effect. Its a ridiculously expensive lip balm, Page said(its $36). What, you expected the Narciso woman to use Carmex?

title: Becoming My Grandmother
description: There is a moment when the lens shifts, and you see life through the eyes of the person you are becoming rather than the person you have been. I am becoming my mother, we say, and sometimes we are joking, but sometimes we have learned something deep.

title: Moon Walk | Bernardo
description: Certain shoes have the aesthetic legs to stand the test of time. Consider the Bernardo sandal, that 1960s staple of Euro-hippiedom favored by Jane Birkin, fashions perennial boho. Dennis Comeau, president of Bernardo Vintage Couture, is realigning the brand for this century. The difference with Bernardo is that you can put on a pair of sandals made in 1967 and look completely 2011, Comeau says. Several classic styles are being reissued this month at Bergdorf Goodman. Theres a navy Bandeau platform, a chocolate Moon disc flat (updated from the original pink and priced at $225) and a jeweled thong called the Goldfinger.

title: Jeff Wilpon Reiterates Family Wont Sell Mets
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Jeff Wilpon, the Mets chief operating officer, spoke to reporters Wednesday for the first time since a lawsuit seeking as much as $1 billion from the teams owners was unsealed on Feb. 4.

title: A Heavy Chamberlain, a Reticent Cashman
description: 1:15 p.m. | Updated  Chamberlain said he felt awesome and that he was in better shape than last season.After answering a few questions about his weight, he called it a dead issue and said he wouldnt speak about it again.

title: Living Without Discretionary Fiscal Policy
description: Alex Tabarrok makes an interesting point: recent experience seems to suggest that Keynesian policies, even if appropriate, turn out not to be politically feasible when you need them. I dont think we need to take that as an immutable fact of life; but still, what are the alternatives?

title: Winners and Losers in the Airgas Poison Pill Case
description: The Air Products and Chemicals hostile pursuit of Airgas ended with a legal whimper.

title: A Lohan Booking Miscue for Letterman
description: It turns out that Lindsay Lohan wont be reading David Lettermans Top 10 list on Thursday night, after all.

title: Feingold Forms Political Group to Combat Corporate Influence
description: Russ Feingold, the former Democratic senator from Wisconsin who lost his bid for re-election in November, has formed a new political organization aimed at countering the impact of corporate money in politics.

title: Can You Start a Tech Company Without Venture Capital?
description: We just published a case study that highlights the challenges confronting Irrational Design, a tech start-up that is determined to bootstrap. Founded in April by Jared Cosulich and Adam Abrons, the company has introduced three products: a dating Web site, an application that serves as an online suggestion box for businesses and a goal-sharing message board.

title: Budget Politics
description: David Brooks: Gail, over the past few days Ive had a series of conversations with people in both parties about the budget. Its like traveling to two different countries.

title: Fte Accompli | Alexander Wang and Co.
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#370", 592, 440, true, chameleonData);

title: Borders to Close 3 of 8 Stores in New York City
description: The giant bookstores that ate the smaller bookstores are not fit enough to survive, it turns out. And readers in Manhattan are going to feel it.

title: Signs of Spring on Governors Island
description: Between seasons in an urban wild place.

title: New Directors/New Films Series Sets Lineup
description: J. C. Chandors directorial debut, Margin Call, a feature that takes place over the course of 24 hours on the trading floor of an investment bank, will be the opening night feature of the 40th annual New Directors/New Films series, the Museum of Modern Art and the Film Society of Lincoln Center said on Wednesday. Margin Call, one of 28 films that will be presented during the series, features a cast that includes Kevin Spacey, Paul Bettany, Zachary Quinto, Demi Moore, Stanley Tucci and Jeremy Irons, and chronicles a day that brings layer upon layer of human and professional wrongdoing that jeopardizes the entire fabric of the banking system, according to a statement from MoMA and the Film Society. The closing night film of the series, which runs from March 23 through April 3, will be Maryam Keshavarzs Circumstance, about two Iranian women who begin to step outside the boundaries of their oppressive lives, and which won the Audience Award at this years Sundance Film Festival.

title: Grinnell's Admissions Process
description: Jacques Steinberg, of The Choice blog, discusses the college admission process on the today Show.

title: Developers Wary of New App Store Rules
description: BARCELONA, Spain  Apples announcement that it would begin taking a 30 percent cut of subscription fees for services sold through its App Store sent a shudder through some of the developers and vendors showing off new products at the weeklong mobile conference here in Barcelona.

title: Heidfeld Replaces Kubica at Lotus
description: The Lotus Renault GP team announced Wednesday that Nick Heidfeld would replace Robert Kubica to drive for the team this year, after the Polish driver injured himself in a rally accident.

title: Heidfeld Replaces Kubica at Lotus
description: The Lotus Renault GP team announced Wednesday that Nick Heidfeld would replace Robert Kubica to drive for the team this year, after the Polish driver injured himself in a rally accident.

title: Freed Mans Suit Accuses Brooklyn Prosecutors of Misconduct
description: When Brooklyn prosecutors vacated his murder conviction last year, granting him freedom after 16 years behind bars, Jabbar Collins was naturally elated.

title: Heats Miller Sidelined After Blows to Head
description: Much ado is rightfully made about the impact of concussions on athletes in the N.F.L. and the N.H.L.

title: After Menu Labels, Parents and Kids Order Same Foods
description: Most parents and older children notice calorie counts posted in New York City fast-food restaurants, but the information doesnt stop them from ordering their favorite burgers and fries, new research shows.

title: New York City Can Buy More Watershed Land, State Says
description: New York City can continue to buy land to protect its watershed in the Catskills and Hudson River Valley from development under an agreement announced on Wednesday by the city and state.

title: Life at the Dakota
description: To New Yorkers, there are few apartments more legendary than the Dakota, at the corner of 72nd Street and Central Park West. Most of us know that we could never hope to live there, assuming we did not win the state lottery a few times. But I had no idea just how expensive it was.

title: Grey Bearding
description: The loss of knowledge caused by the ageing and retirement of those with (engineering) expertise.

title: Metropolitan Opera Announces New Season
description: The Metropolitan Opera, announcing next seasons program, said on Wednesday that it would mount its first production of Donizettis Anna Bolena, with Anna Netrebko portraying Henry VIIIs second  and headed for beheading  wife.

title: Pujols and Cardinals Call Off Talks
description: JUPITER, Fla.  In explaining how the St. Louis Cardinals have reached the end of negotiations to extend the contract of Albert Pujols, the teams owner, Bill DeWitt Jr., really did not have to utter much more than one short declarative sentence.

title: 'Criminal Minds: Suspect Behavior'
description: Forest Whitaker stars as an F.B.I. profiler who hunts serial killers on "Criminal Minds: Suspect Behavior," a new CBS spinoff.

title: The Illusory Importance of Starting
description: For N.B.A. players, being in the starting lineup is viewed as a broadcast of their worth as a player. That makes sense to a degree, but one has to wonder if the act of starting  of exchanging high-fives and half-hugs with teammates and opposing players while Van Halen or House of Pain blares over the loudspeakers  is often mistaken in importance for all that comes with it.

title: Behind the Barks at Westminster
description: When Fred Conrad set out to photograph 179 different dog breeds at the Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show on Monday and Tuesday, he thought he knew what he was getting himself into.

title: Its Curtains
description: and coffee tables at Albert Hadleys posh retirement sale.

title: Fed Forecasts Faster Growth as Economy Improves
description: WASHINGTON  The Federal Reserve disclosed on Wednesday that policy makers had substantially upgraded their forecasts for how much the economy will grow this year, though they expect unemployment to remain painfully high for some time.

title: Pictures of the Day: Bahrain and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Bahrain, Uganda and New York.

title: Adopting a Look, No Boys Allowed
description: BACK in the dark ages of my misspent youth, the cost of used clothing was always inversely proportional to the difficulty of finding it. Dumpster diving, though the least expensive, was the biggest long shot, and potentially the most nauseating and dangerous experience. Next came straight thrift  i.e., any rummage store named for a Catholic saint or the Salvation Army (a k a Sals).

title: N.Y.U. Fellow Resigns After Tweeting About Lara Logan
description: The journalist Nir Rosen has resigned as a New York University fellow after a series of controversial Twitter posts about the attack on the CBS News correspondent Lara Logan.

title: When the Battle With Cancer Cant Be Won
description: A diagnosis of advanced cancer is usually difficult for you and your family, the booklet says. Theres an understatement.

title: CNN Is Back to Covering Fashion
description: IT has been 10 years since CNN pulled the plug on Style With Elsa Klensch, and in that time weve gone from seeing a camera crew at Fashion Week as a novelty to seeing anyone in the audience without a camera phone as a nobody.

title: A Scent to Match the Socialite
description: PAMELA GROSS was the last guest to arrive for lunch at the Palm Court of the Plaza Hotel on a recent Tuesday. She was 20 minutes late, actually.

title: MoMA PS1s Young Architects Program Announces Winner
description: Interboro Partners, a nine-year-old New York architecture firm, has won the annual Young Architects Program competition to transform MoMA P.S. 1s courtyard for its summer outdoor music program, the museum announced Wednesday. The architects took their inspiration from the community around the museum, which is located in Long Island City, Queens, interviewing the proprietors of local businesses and nonprofits about what materials might be of use to them and then incorporating those materials into their design, with the intention of donating them at the end of the summer.

title: Ecuadorean Villagers May Hold Secret to Longevity
description: People living in remote villages in Ecuador have a mutation that some biologists say may throw light on human longevity and ways to increase it.

title: Koch Says Let the Bridge Debate Play Out
description: A city councilmans opposition to Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs plan to rename the Queensboro Bridge after former Mayor Edward I. Koch might have gone unnoticed by Mr. Koch, who left Buenos Aires last week on a 16-day luxury cruise across the southern Atlantic.

title: House Votes to End Alternate Jet Engine Program
description: In a sign that more than half the Republican freshmen are willing to cut military spending, the House voted 233 to 198 on Wednesday to cancel an alternate fighter jet engine that the Bush and Obama administrations had tried to kill for the last five years.

title: Photos of the Moment | Michael Kors
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#46", 592, 440, true, chameleonData);

title: Speaker Boehners 200,000
description: When I read that John Boehner, the speaker of the House, had said that the federal government added 200,000 federal workers under President Obama, I wondered, Really? Where? Im not aware of any major federal hiring initiatives since January 2009.

title: Why Watson Will Beat Humans on Jeopardy!
description: In the run-up to the Jeopardy! showdown between computer and humans, there was one thing that I worried might turn the contest into a farce. After watching for two days, I think I was right.

title: Credibility Shaken, Hedge Funds Are Punished by Investors
description: Now for a bit of good news: Rationality may be breaking out in the hedge fund world.

title: For Germanys Banks, a Grim Future
description: FRANKFURT  Want to buy a money-losing bank with a damaged business model in an overcrowded market? Neither, it seems, do many other people.

title: Auditors Find Federal Oil and Gas Oversight Still Lacking
description: The Government Accountability Office, weighing in somewhat belatedly, has found the Interior Departments oil and gas regulation and revenue-collection offices to be beset by problems and in need of a major overhaul.

title: Carneys First Press Briefing Draws a Crowd
description: Jay Carney did look nervous as he took the podium on Wednesday for his inaugural briefing as President Obamas press secretary.

title: Getting a Visual on New Yorkers 311 Calls
description: The Bloomberg administration announced a new Internet tool for New York City residents that combines the crowd-sourcing lessons of the Facebook age with a time-honored city tradition: complaining.

title: Lance Armstrong Retires From Cycling
description: Lance Armstrong, the seven-time Tour de France winner who is the target of a federal investigation into doping in cycling, announced Wednesday that he had retired from his sport  this time for good.

title: Unseating the Chronicler of the Night
description: FOR a certain slice of New Yorks social set, Patrick can be used as a verb, much the way that Google and Facebook can be slang for getting someones 411.

title: Buzz Tracker
description: Rage Against the Money Machine Matt Taibbi is frustrated and angry at the lack of prosecutions stemming from the financial crisis: The mental stumbling block, for most Americans, is that financial crimes dont feel real; you dont see the culprits waving guns in liquor stores or dragging coeds into bushes. But these frauds are worse than common robberies. Theyre crimes of intellectual choice, made by people who are already rich and who have every conceivable social advantage, acting on a simple, cynical calculation: Lets steal whatever we can, then dare the victims to find the juice to reclaim their money through a captive bureaucracy. Rolling Stone

title: How Green Is My School? Conducting an Energy Audit
description: Overview | How can new buildings be designed in ways that minimize their energy use? How can energy be used more efficiently in existing buildings? In this lesson, students learn about green building design, perform energy audits of their schools and then develop proposals for making their schools more energy efficient.

title: The Banks Run an Experiment
description: There is a delightful sentence in todays very good Wall Street Journal article on house down payments:

title: No Refuge From Fear in Afghanistan, Even at Prayer
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  People of Afghanistan are very religious, but nowadays a lot of them are afraid of their own mosques and religious leaders.

title: A Political Divide Over the Inquiry of the Financial Crisis
description: WASHINGTON  The government inquiry into the causes of the 2008 financial crisis was the focus of intense partisan bickering on Wednesday at a House hearing. Republicans called the final 545-page report a political exercise whose findings were mostly inevitable, while Democrats defended its main conclusion: that Wall Street risk-taking and regulatory negligence combined to produce an avoidable disaster.

title: The Feds G.D.P. Forecast, in Context
description: Minutes from the Federal Reserves Federal Open Market Committee meeting released today revealed a somewhat more upbeat set of monetary policy makers, with a forecast for output growth of 3.4 to 3.9 percent this year. Thats slightly higher than their last projection of 3 to 3.6 percent, released in November.

title: Medicare And Medicaid Are Big
description: Update: People: this isnt my chart, its the governments, as you would see if you clicked on the link. And the pie on the right adds up to 71 percent because, as the figure clearly shows, insurance accounts for 71% of total spending. Before you complain about a post, try reading it first.

title: Christie Accuses Washington of Ignoring Fiscal Crisis
description: Chris Christie, the Republican governor of New Jersey, accused Democrats and Republicans in Washington on Wednesday of ignoring Americas fiscal crisis while they played a political game of chicken that threatens the future of the next generation.

title: Vain Glorious | To the Moon With Cartier
description: Fragrance is the most ephemeral of subjects. If you follow such things, you rapidly lose the impulse to bat an eyelash when told a scent is inspired by a flower that actually has none (Marc Jacobs Daisy), a chick flick (Freshs Eat Pray Love trio) or the High Line (Bond No. 9)  especially when told by a well-dressed French person. So it doesnt sound unreasonable (quite romantic, in fact) that the new fragrance Cartier de Lune is meant to smell like a bouquet picked in the moonlight, but the reality is that those of us without a trained nose (or fantastic imagination) have no idea how that smells.

title: J.F.K. Security Agents Charged With Stealing $40,000
description: Updated 5:23 p.m. | Two federal officers assigned to work in security jobs at Kennedy International Airport have been arrested and charged with stealing $40,000 in cash from a piece of checked luggage, the authorities said.

title: Video: Hacking Microsoft Kinect and a Roomba
description: As soon as the Microsoft Kinect came out last year, programmers and hackers pounced on it in the hope of using it for anything but its intended useas a wireless addition for the Microsoft Xbox that uses a persons movement as a game controller.

title: In Memoriam: Margaret K. McElderry
description: On Monday, the world of childrens publishing lost one of its last great 20th century editors, Margaret K. McElderry, who died at age 98. As Douglas Martin noted in his obituary today, Ms. McElderry came to be known as the grande dame of childrens publishing. She was the first childrens book editor to earn an eponymous imprint  Margaret K. McElderry Books  which continued, even after her retirement in 1998, and still publishes within Simon & Schuster today.

title: A Five-Bedroom Town House in the French Alps
description: Ski-chalet style, and five bedrooms, for about $2.6 million

title: Atlantic City to Get a New Golden Nugget
description: After an absence of more than two decades, the Golden Nugget brand is returning to Atlantic City. Landrys, the casinos parent company, announced this week that it would buy the Trump Marina Hotel and Casino and open a Golden Nugget on that site.

title: Helping the Teenager With A.D.H.D.
description: Millions of people suffer from attention deficit hyperactivity disorder, or A.D.H.D., many of them teenagers who face problems in school. Here, Dr. Russell A. Barkley, clinical professor of psychiatry at the Medical University of South Carolina and author of Your Defiant Teen and other books, responds to concerns from parents of teenagers with A.D.H.D.

title: Deputy Press Secretary Leaving White House
description: Bill Burton, who has been a deputy press secretary for President Obama, is leaving the White House to form a political consulting firm with Sean Sweeney, another West Wing veteran.

title: New Hacking Tools Pose Bigger Threats to Wi-Fi Users
description: You may think the only people capable of snooping on your Internet activity are government intelligence agents or possibly a talented teenage hacker holed up in his parents basement. But some simple software lets just about anyone sitting next to you at your local coffee shop watch you browse the Web and even assume your identity online.

title: Solutions for an Overstuffed Hard Drive
description: Q. The hard drive on my laptop is about to burst with all my pictures and music, and Id like to be able to remove it all to external storage. Ive tried external hard drives, but I use them only as back-up since they are cumbersome to use with a laptop if I want continual access to my files.

title: The 10 Things to Talk About This Weekend
description: 1. Ten Downing Street acquires a cat to combat the residences rodent problem. No wonder Margaret Thatcher always looked so irritated.

title: Mom Wakes, Dad Sleeps
description: In the Things You Already Knew But Its Nice to Have Them Confirmed So You Know You Arent Imagining Things department, the Washington Post ran news this week of a new research study that concluded that Women are more likely than men to give up sleep to care for children.

title: Fashion Week Parties, Night 6
description: Scenes from Tuesday night, including a live concert with Lauryn Hill, dinner with Chlo Sevigny and more Kanye.

title: Pictures of the Day: Bahrain and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Bahrain, Uganda and New York.

title: Oscars Gold Rush
description: The price of gold at the time of Oscar de la Rentas show today was hovering around $1,375 an ounce. It occurred to me that if I could somehow melt down his collection, I could probably afford to retire.

title: Mumford & Sons Get Big Grammy Lift
description: The Grammy Awards have always had an effect on record sales. But in the digital age that effect is felt more quickly than ever, since fans impulse buys made during the show on Sunday night register as part of the tail end of Nielsen SoundScans sales week.

title: A Lawmakers Critique of Obamas Energy Stance
description: The new Republican chairman of a House energy and power subcommittee delivered a decidedly mixed verdict on President Obamas energy policies on Wednesday.

title: Full of Apologies, Mets Rodriguez Arrives in Camp
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  A contrite Francisco Rodriguez arrived in Mets camp Wednesday and promised that he had learned from his mistakes and had become a better person. At the same time, Rodriguez vowed that in some respects he would not change.

title: Photo of the Day: New York Fashion Week
A Phone Thats the Life of a Laptop
description: Does the redundancy of your gadgets ever bother you?

title: House Hunting in ... the French Alps
description: A FIVE-BEDROOM SKI CHALET IN THE VILLAGE OF LE PRAZ IN LES TROIS VALLES (THE THREE VALLEYS), A FRENCH ALPINE RESORT

title: U.S. Cracks Down on Armenian Crime Syndicate
description: GLENDALE, Calif.  Law enforcement officials cracked down Wednesday on a growing Southern California criminal organization with extensive international ties, arresting 74 members and associates of the Armenian Power crime group.

title: Iranian Warships Bound for Syria Are Set to Transit Suez Canal, Israel Says
description: JERUSALEM  Israel warned on Wednesday that two Iranian warships were poised to pass through the Suez Canal en route to Syria, something it called a provocation that had not happened in years.

title: Revivals Are Nice, but Revel in the New
description: RECYCLING, though normally a virtuous activity, has been the essence of New York theater for far too long. So Im celebrating the arrival of a slew of brand-new works from major playwrights, including Jez Butterworth, Stephen Adly Guirgis and no less than three Pulitzer Prize winners (David Lindsay-Abaire, Tony Kushner and Lynn Nottage). Also worth an anticipatory glass of Champagne: some singing Mormons, a reprise of Tom Stoppard and a horse with heart.

title: A Famous Big Cat, and Stars on the Rise
description: AMID the increasing preponderance of starry nights at the theater this spring, one of the most intriguing is the arrival of Robin Williams in an exciting new play by an up-and-coming young writer, as opposed to a commercially driven revival. But some of the performances that most entice are from lesser-known actors with luminary potential: Nina Arianda, a breakout talent from last season; John Douglas Thompson; and the delectably odd Off Broadway mainstay David Greenspan.

title: New York Fashion Week | Wine Time
description: As the New York shows approach the finishing line, it would seem that everyone from Alexander Wang to Victoria Beckham is serving the same thing for winter  a fruity yet rich Bordeaux. The color has been brightened and lightened, making it appear more like a Beaujolais nouveau rather than a deeper Pauillac, with bursts of fuchsia in the mix to provide balance. Although it appeared on upper-length leather gloves and platforms on heels, designers sought to liven up their looks with a new color. Olivier Theyskenss second collection for Theory took a traditional approach with his wine-colored chunky knits, while Marc Jacobs played with the shade in all textures and lengths ranging from a pailette knee-length skirt to a pleated maxi version. The newcomer Prabal Gurung showed all varietals in a color-saturated fur coat over a sheer black dress, but no one did it like Posh, who provided standouts in the form of loose dresses in cashmeres and double-faced wools. As they say in Paris, sant!

title: Homes for $800,000
description: A four-bedroom Queen Anne in Beaufort, S.C.; a modern ranch in Paradise Valley, Ariz.; and a two-bedroom condo in a 1921 building in Seattle.

title: Raine Hire Signals Focus On Sports Media
description: The Raine Group, which is in the middle raising roughly $500 million for a private equity fund focused on media deals, has made one of its first big hires, signaling the firms focus on sports media.

title: What You Get for ... $800,000
description: BEAUFORT, S.C.

title: Globetrotters Conquer the Hudson
description: As promised, the Harlem Globetrotters took to the Hudson River Tuesday, sinking 4-pointers from one Circle Line boat to another. Both Nate Lofton and Anthony Blakes connected from the 35-foot distance.

title: Browsing: Shopping Picks for Feb. 17
description: The owner of Bird sees fuller silhouettes for spring; Alexander Wang opens a flagship; and Guess moves into a large space on Fifth Avenue.

title: Shopping for Minimalist Pieces With Messana ORorke
description: The architects who run the Manhattan firm Messana ORorke shopped for simple furnishings for devoted minimalists.

title: Stitch by Stitch and Block by Block
description: ON a recent blustery Friday night near McCarren Park in Brooklyn, Nayantara Banerjee, a k a the Williamsburg Seamster, was armored in a poncho sweater, knee-high snow boots from Urban Outfitters and a black-and silver-threaded scarf knotted over her long, jet-black hair. Despite the frigid air, Ms. Banerjee was happy to stretch her limbs. She had spent most of the day hunched over her sewing machine, one of five in her living room, hemming a damaged skirt, fixing a botched tailor job on a pair of pants and cinching the waist of a vintage leopard-print dress.

title: Spaghetti and Meatballs
description: 1 loaf fresh ciabatta, crusts removed, whirred in a blender or food processor to make crumbs (about 2 cups)

title: Cooking With Dexter: Busy Signal
description: My father left the office at 5. If he wasnt home by 5:30, we knew he had hit traffic. To the opening theme of the 6 oclock news, we sat down to eat the meal my mother prepared.

title: The Oscar Envelope Gets a Makeover
description: LOS ANGELES Its the equivalent of discovering that the Oscar statuettes are purchased at Spencers Gifts. The sealed envelopes used at the Academy Awards apparently come from . . . Staples.

title: When in Rome, Let Your Smartphone Do the Translating
description: You can use a smartphone to save a few dollars on an airline ticket, buy a Starbucks latte or gain the inside edge on draft news in fantasy sports leagues.

title: In Memoir, Scott Brown Says He Was Molested As a Child
description: BOSTON  Senator Scott Brown reveals in his memoir that he was molested by a camp counselor as a child, according to a 60 Minutes interview to be broadcast Sunday.

title: Blaise Kavanagh | Something for the Ladies
description: This week, Blaise Kavanagh is quietly presenting his second collection and showing himself to be a serious craftsman. He makes his patterns and sews the majority of his samples himself. Part of that may be out of necessity  the 26-year-old is fresh out of Pratt  but more likely it is because he is passionate about what he does.

title: Range Rover Autobiography Ultimate: $170,000
description: On the same Geneva stage as the 2012 Evoque  the lightest, most fuel-efficient model ever to wear the Range Rover name  Land Rover will unveil the Autobiography Ultimate edition: a limited-production S.U.V. festooned with teak, hand-stitched leather surfaces and the latest talisman of automotive chic, an Apple iPad. Make that two iPads.

title: Skull-Cups in British Cave Conjure an Ancient Rite
description: The three human braincases, two from adults and one from a child, were carefully skinned and cleaned with flint tools. The soft tissue was removed and probably consumed, leaving a well-shaped cup, perhaps made for use in some sort of ritual.

title: Signs of Beautiful Isolation, and Even Spring, on a Walk on Governors Island
description: On a brisk morning on Governors Island, as winter begins to surrender to spring, the fake palm trees that greet the ferry on Water Taxi Beach appear even more surreal than usual, poking up out of snow above the empty picnic tables.

title: At Marc Jacobs, the Show Before the Show
description: EIGHT days before the Marc Jacobs show on Monday  the stylistic tent pole for the circus of New York Fashion Week  Robert Duffy, the president of Marc Jacobs, found himself running around Canal Street carrying a swatch of fabric necessary to create the quilted 20-foot columns for a runway show whose inspiration, Mr. Duffy said, only half-joking, was a padded cell.

title: Fosse Revival Coming to Roundabout
description: Two years after scrapping its original plans, Roundabout Theater Company announced Wednesday that it would produce Bob Fosses Dancin  this fall at Broadways Studio 54 theater, with director Graciela Daniele recreating Fosses original choreography from his hit revue Dancin.

title: Uninhibited Color
description: A penthouse apartment in Berlin has a doughnut-style layout, with a circular flow to most of the rooms, each with a different color palette.

title: Marchesa: Miss Havisham Regrets
description: One thing you do not want to see on the way into a fashion show is an ambulance at the door. Walking on West 22nd Street this afternoon, a few editors en route to the Marchesa show were nearly run down when an ambulance pulled onto the sidewalk in an attempt to bypass the stalled traffic, but another had beaten them to the scene by turning onto the street from the opposite end. All this for what turned out to be a bloodied nose.

title: Music in Review
description: MUSIC FROM JAPANBaruch Performing Arts Center

title: CBS Reports Higher  Revenue
description: The CBS Corporation said Wednesday that its fourth-quarter revenue rose 11 percent over the same period in 2009, helped by growth in local advertising.

title: In Berlin, a Penthouses Rainbow of Colors
description: BERLIN  Most German fashion designers are not known for their uninhibited use of color. That makes the eye-popping penthouse apartment here of the designer Mischa Woeste, the creator of the Smeilinener label, and her husband, Eghard Woeste, an architect, that much more remarkable.

title: Prints of the City
description: Prova, Irini Arakass five-year-old accessories line of kaleidoscopic beads, jewels and scarves favored by Michelle Obama and the electro punker TK Wonder, now includes dresses. The patterns  in a short day dress and maxi style  have the deceptively slinky curves and sassy detailing of the 40s (sleeves! knee length!) with the louche glamour of the 70s (florals, animal prints and disco fringe!). Arakas says shes found the zipper factor: You know, when you zip yourself into a dress and it just feels so good and perfect and makes you happy. By all means, zip us up. From $595, at Ikram (Chicago) and Blue Tree (New York), or go to kirnazabete.com.

title: The Scene: Fashion Week Day 7
description: Scenes around the city from New York Fashion Week.

title: Motown at the Apollo, Suspended in Time
description: Smokey Robinson said he was tripping to be back performing at the Apollo Theater on Tuesday night, calling the theater the real beginning of my show business life. He reminisced about doing five shows a day there as part of Motowns Motortown Revue in the early 1960s, when the Apollo crowds reputation for booing acts offstage was so fearsome, Mr. Robinson said, that I was afraid to look out in the audience. Now, a few days before his 71st birthday on Saturday, Mr. Robinson wasnt just engaging the audience. He was trusting it, and seducing a good part of it. What might have been an oldies show became a singers teasing, obsessive tour de force.

title: Kaleidoscopes of Patterns Against Backdrop of Mozarts Chivalry
description: High among my memories of the most illustrious dance performances are those that New York City Ballet gave in the early 1980s of Balanchines Divertimento No. 15. This ballet, with the most sublime choreography ever made to music by Mozart, creates an ideal realm in which courtesy, chivalry, brilliance, serenity and expansiveness coexist and give off light. In those performances, Balanchine style was at a peak of refinement: resplendent in line, dazzling in speed, calm in phrasing, tingling in musical precision. The huge box of stage space around the dancers was animated by their ardent three-dimensional physicality and their dynamics.

title: In Surprise Finding, Bald Mice Find Their Fur Again
description: Mouse researchers conducting stress hormone experiments have stumbled onto a surprising new discovery  a potential treatment for hair loss.

title: The Accomplished Joined by the Young and Promising
description: McCoy Tyner, the august and thunderous jazz pianist, had an assignment at the Blue Note this week. He didnt seem too enthusiastic about it on Tuesday night. The engagement was billed as A Contemporary Exploration of John Coltrane & Johnny Hartman, referring to a beloved ballads album on which Mr. Tyner appeared as a sideman in 1963. Standing in for Coltrane was a trustworthy tenor saxophonist, Eric Alexander. Hartmans role was entrusted to a young vocalist, Jos James.

title: As U.S. Agencies Put More Value on a Life, Businesses Fret
description: WASHINGTON  As the players here remake the nations vast regulatory system, they have been grappling with a subject that is more the province of poets and philosophers than bureaucrats: what is the value of a human life?

title: Players Boycott Could Affect Canadas Bid for 2015 Womens World Cup
description: Canadas designs on hosting the Womens World Cup in 2015 were tarnished a bit last week when members of the national team issued a threat to boycott coming international matches because the teams successful Italian coach had tendered her resignation, as of July.

title: In Florida Slough With the Gators and Family Ghosts
description: Karen Russell, author of the wave-making debut novel Swamplandia!, was on New York Magazines 2005 list of 27 impressive New Yorkers under the age of 26. In 2009 she received a 5 Under 35 award from the National Book Foundation. Last year she wound up on The New Yorkers 20 Under 40 list. Nice numbers. But cut to the chase: Ms. Russell is one in a million.

title: Excerpt: 'Diary of a Madman'
description: In this production of Nikolai Gogol's play, Geoffrey Rush plays a civil servant who is slowly being driven mad by bureaucracy. (Video courtesy of the Brooklyn Academy of Music)

title: A Mission Documented With a Filter of Despair
description: The Battle for Marjah enters the crowded field of Iraq and Afghanistan battlefield documentaries, where films like Restrepo, Gunner Palace and The War Tapes have already made their marks. What will distinguish this British production for the American viewer is its mood of poetic fatalism, even despair.

title: Canadians Who Still Have Fun Being Somber
description: Haunted songs by the Cowboy Junkies like Lonely Sinking Feeling and To Love Is to Bury wont be turning up on Glee one day, but this band has turned somber into a mysterious sort of success for 25 years.

title: Wariss New York
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#421", 592, 440, true, chameleonData);

title: Newly Released Books
description: This being the month for romance, or at least a good marketing hook, Februarys books are bound in red. A mean old man, a teenage runaway, a psychiatrist and an American student in Paris all get to fall in love. In the novel Solo, as the title suggests, a man remembers a life without it.

title: Williams to Split Into Two
description: Breaking up, it would seem, is not that hard to do.

title: Sound Thats Lush and Slow, Speedy and Precise
description: Hilary Hahn has been playing Jennifer Higdons Violin Concerto around the world since 2009, and Ms. Hahns Deutsche Grammophon recording of the work with the Royal Liverpool Philharmonic has been available since September.

title: In a Boom, Whats a Bankruptcy Specialist to Do?
description: In the world of restructuring, few academics hold the stature of Edward I. Altman, the professor who created a widely used metric for predicting when a company might file for bankruptcy.

title: The Dreamer Caught in the Spotlight
description: Dressed in white, her hair a corona of silver ringlets, Judy Collins suggested a seasonal Glinda the Good Witch ushering out one of the most punishing New York winters in memory on Tuesday evening as she sang The Blizzard at the Caf Carlyle. One of her great later songs, for which she accompanied herself on piano, The Blizzard describes a brokenhearted woman driving alone through a winter storm in the Colorado Rockies and taking shelter with a stranger with whom she has a healing romantic encounter. The next morning she awakens in dazzling sunlight and continues her journey through the mountains, her faith in herself restored.

title: Spider-Man Producers Have Their Eye on Script Doctor with Superhero Credentials
description: The producers of the Broadway musical Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark have asked Roberto Aguirre-Sacasa, a playwright who also written Spider-Man stories for Marvel Comics, if he is interested and available to help rewrite the script for the big-budget, critically assailed musical, according to two people familiar with the discussions.

title: A Requiem Unwraps Stillness Swathed in Silk
description: The dances of Jacqulyn Buglisi could be likened to a powdery musk. At first her work gives off an antique allure, but over time that bouquet turns into something oppressive. She sprays it on thick.

title: Met Opera Plans Anna Bolena and Faust
description: The Metropolitan Opera, announcing next seasons program, said on Wednesday that it would mount its first production of Donizettis Anna Bolena, with Anna Netrebko portraying Henry VIIIs second wife. David McVicar will direct the work, along with two other Tudor-era operas by Donizetti, Maria Stuarda and Roberto Devereux, in successive seasons. They will also be Met premieres.

title: Planning Comeback, Democrats Huddle with Ousted Members
description: Its never too early to bring the old faces back.

title: Gender Blitz on a High School Gridiron
description: Who says girls cant play football? Or that you dont go to Bushwick in Brooklyn to see a play? And if you think deconstructionist, experimental theater must be dry and dreary, the Half Straddle, an emerging troupe, has another surprise for you.

title: Cinema in Berlin
description: Images of some of the films in the Berlin International Film Festival.

title: Tracing the Myth of a Chinese Leader to Its Roots
description: LIANGJIAHE, China  The cave is dim and narrow and musty. A platform bed covered with a reed mat sits by the door. A green canvas satchel and a lantern hang from two rusty nails on a wall  possessions supposedly left behind by a lanky teenage boy from Beijing sent here four decades ago to do hard labor.

title: Bucking Trend, College Will Cut Price
description: For those who wonder how college tuition costs manage to keep rising year after year, apparently defying laws of economic gravity, Sewanee, a liberal arts college in Tennessee, has an answer: they cant.

title: The Musical Rhythms in Images Out of Time
description: Ive gone only twice to see parts of Christian Marclays 24-hour video, The Clock, at the Paula Cooper Gallery in Chelsea, which closes on Saturday. Wish I could have seen more. The first time, for only half an hour, I took it in as a movie. On the second viewing, much longer, it felt like music.

title: Flock Around The Clock
description: Even when they involve 14-foot tiger sharks preserved in formaldehyde or pictures of Jeff Koons in flagrante delicto, commercial art gallery exhibitions in New York dont often draw capacity crowds. And they almost never move people to line up along the postindustrial streets of Chelsea on weekday winter mornings as if a sample sale were under way.

title: Video: The iPhone for Advanced Beginners
description: With Verizon iPhones now out in the wild, many people are still figuring out how to use them. Here are a few tips for those who are ready to move beyond the basics.

title: New Female Police Chief Is a First for Rio
description: SO PAULO, Brazil  With a police corruption scandal growing in Rio de Janeiro, Jos Mariano Beltrame, the security chief for Rio de Janeiro State, has ousted the head of the beleaguered Civil Police and named the first woman ever to head the force in the city.

title: The Sound and the Feel of Oscar-Worthiness
description: With just over a week to go until the little gold men are handed out at the Kodak Theater, film aficionados and cineastes are thinking one thing: How can I win my Oscar pool?

title: Two Kings Against a Slam Prove to Be Not Quite Enough
description: Perhaps the diagramed deal featured the best declarer play during the NEC Festival of Bridge, which ended last Sunday in Yokohama City, Japan. It was described by West, Ron Klinger from Australia, on his blog.

title: A Collector of Everyday Objects on His New Museum in Mexico City
description: Bruno Newman, the founder and a director of Zimat, a large communications firm in Mexico, has spent more than 50 years collecting various kinds of objects  more than 30,000, in 30 categories (including household products, food packages, medicine bottles, cosmetics and toys). Enough to open a museum, in other words. So thats exactly what Mr. Newman, 66, did. El Museo del Objeto del Objeto, or the Museum of the Object of the Object, opened last fall in the Colonia Roma of Mexico City, in a 1906 Art Nouveau building that was once Mr. Newmans home.

title: Crash Puts Earnhardt Jr., a Daytona 500 Favorite, at a Raceday Disadvantage
description: Dale Earnhardt Jr., the 2004 Daytona 500 winner and the pole sitter for this Sundays race, crashed his Chevrolet in a practice session at Daytona International Speedway on Wednesday.

title: He Rested on the Seventh Day
description: Buffalo, Feb. 17, 1861

title: Obama Talks to Kaine About Running for the Senate
description: 8:02 a.m. | Updated President Obama talked on the phone Wednesday with Tim Kaine, the chairman of the Democratic National Committee, two Democratic sources said, as the pressure mounts for Mr. Kaine to run for the Senate in Virginia.

title: Computer Wins on Jeopardy!: Trivial, Its Not
description: YORKTOWN HEIGHTS, N.Y.  In the end, the humans on Jeopardy! surrendered meekly.

title: Christie Proposes Ending Tenure for Poor Teachers
description: PRINCETON, N.J.  One month after Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey used his annual state address to call for an end to tenure for teachers, his administration unveiled a plan on Wednesday that would take away tenure from ineffective teachers but stopped short of eliminating it.

title: Gauging the Feds Recent Forecasting
description: The Federal Reserve periodically polls the members of its Open Market Committee  board members and presidents of the regional Fed banks  on their economic outlook. Their expectations are worth looking at because those are the forecasts that affect monetary policy decisions, and are therefore more important than other forecasts whether or not they are better forecasters.

title: Obama Calls Lara Logan of CBS
description: President Obama this afternoon called Lara Logan, the CBS News correspondent who is recovering at home in Washington after a brutal sexual attack last Friday in Cairos Tahrir Square, an administration official said.

title: A Red Hook Summer Cottage
description: An uninhabitable 1899 carriage house in Brooklyn, transformed into a home with a vacation cottage theme.

title: His Real Estate Agent? Craigslist
description: THOMAS WARNKE found his house on Craigslist, and he knows how odd that will sound to some people. Normally one goes to Craigslist for used bikes and rentals, not properties in the hundreds of thousands, said Mr. Warnke, 43, an architect who moved here from Germany 11 years ago. And, of course, I was aware that for some other things it could be seen as a little sketchy.

title: France: Sarkozy Signals Support for Foreign Minister
description: President Nicolas Sarkozy sent a handwritten message of support to his embattled foreign minister, Michle Alliot-Marie, on Wednesday, the day after embarrassing new revelations about her Christmas visit to Tunisia with her husband and her parents. Not only did she accept two free flights from a businessman close to the family of the deposed president, Zine el-Abidine Ben Ali, but her parents bought a real estate company from the same businessman on the trip. Ms. Alliot-Marie said the investment had nothing to do with her, but there were new calls for her resignation, including in an editorial in Le Monde.

title: A New Line of Chairs, Inspired by Paper Planes
description: The British designers Nipa Doshi and Jonathan Levien had math on their minds when creating the Paper Planes chair for Moroso, the Italian furnishings company. Our inspiration was folded graph paper, Mr. Levien said.

title: Alpha Workshops Wallpapers to Be Offered by Thibaut
description: The hand-painted wallpapers and other finishes from New Yorks Alpha Workshops, which trains people with H.I.V. and AIDS in such arts, have long been staples of high-end designers. Now, in partnership with the wallpaper company Thibaut, six of the nonprofit groups patterns (the Ginkgo style, left) are becoming more accessible.

title: A Touch of Spring From a Cherry Blossom Rug
description: Shirley Shivhon, an interior designer in Los Angeles, was working on a house in Maui in 2008 and planned a home office with a red chinoiserie desk and a rug decorated with cherry blossoms. But in designing the rug, she rejected the look of traditional Chinese paintings.

title: Sales at Broadway Panhandler, Mxyplyzyk and Others
description: At Broadway Panhandlers sale, through Monday, many items are as much as 70 percent off (a Le Creuset eight-inch skillet, regularly $135, is about $40); 65 East Eighth Street (Broadway), (212) 966-3434, broadwaypanhandler.com.

title: Objects for Minimalists
description: BRIAN MESSANA and Toby ORorke, architects who run the Manhattan firm Messana ORorke, favor interiors that are white, bright and clutter-free.

title: Shelter Strategies
description: To the Editor:

title: Curator Moms
description: To the Editor:

title: Warm Nights, Cold Noses
description: EVERY night for the last year, Kathy Ruttenberg has been taking a bath, putting on pajamas, turning on CNN and getting into bed with a little pig named Trixie.

title: The Weavers
description: To the Editor:

title: The Online Market 1stdibs Goes Brick and Mortar
description: The online marketplace 1stdibs, which functions as a portal to more than 1,000 art and antiques dealers in the United States and Canada as well as Paris and London, is opening a physical showroom Friday. The new space, 1stdibs@NYDC, will display the wares of 53 dealers and occupy all 33,000 square feet of the 10th floor of the New York Design Center in Midtown.

title: Let it Snow. Then, Attack.
description: MAYBE its a New York thing.

title: Earnhardt Goes From Pole to Back of Pack
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla.  Dale Earnhardt Jr. crashed during practice at Daytona International Speedway on Wednesday, costing him the pole position for the Daytona 500 on Sunday.

title: Chobani, Greek Yogurt Leader, Lets Its Fans Tell the Story
description: THE leading brand in a growing grocery category is introducing its first television advertising in an effort to stay ahead of a growing field of competitors.

title: Calling on RoboCop to Help Detroit
description: DETROIT  On a list of Detroits biggest problems, the lack of a statue honoring RoboCop would seem to rank rather low.

title: Heavy Rains Linked to Humans
description: An increase in heavy precipitation that has afflicted many countries is at least partly a consequence of human influence on the atmosphere, climate scientists reported in a new study.

title: Looks That Pop From Anna Sui
description: The opening looks in black-and-white graphic prints at Anna Suis show on Wednesday night really popped. Thats saying something for a designer who doesnt shy away from the psychedelic, the mod, the groovy, the Art Nouveau and the Art Deco, all of which made an appearance on her runway.

title: Human DNA Contamination Seen in Genome Databases
description: Nearly 20 percent of the nonhuman genomes held in computer databases are contaminated with human DNA, presumably from the researchers who prepared the samples, say scientists who chanced upon the finding while looking for a human virus.

title: Italy: Berlusconi Says Hes Not Worried About Trial
description: Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi said on Wednesday that he was not worried about a judges order that he face trial on charges he paid for sex with an under-age woman and abused his office to help release her from police detention for theft. In his first comments since the ruling on Tuesday, Mr. Berlusconi said he had the parliamentary majority needed to carry out judicial and economic reforms. At a news conference with Finance Minister Giulio Tremonti, Mr. Berlusconi barely mentioned the sex scandal: Out of love of my country, I wont talk about this. I can only say one thing: Im not worried at all. The center-left opposition is calling for early elections, and political analysts say the government is not likely to last long.

title: Mets Clickable Moment: Fans Want to Buy Team
description: In late 1999, three friends created a Web site to solicit fans to acquire the Jets.

title: Senator Tells of Sexual Abuse and Shoplifting in Memoir
description: BOSTON  Senator Scott Brown reveals in his memoir that he was molested by a camp counselor as a child, according to a 60 Minutes interview to be broadcast Sunday.

title: Germanys Economic Assertiveness Shakes Euro Zone
description: BRUSSELS  For decades, Germans wanted to become more European and took care not to be seen bossing around their allies on the Continent. But now that the government in Berlin wants Europe to become more like Germany, the temperature is rising.

title: Ex-Freddie Mac C.F.O. May Face Civil Charges

description: Some neighbors call the 311 help line. Others say they now take a different route to walk their dogs. Parents complain of headaches. Children say they cannot sleep.

description: Ah, the sidewalks of New York fashion! How many dead bodies can you walk on?

title: China Acts to Tighten Grasp on Rare Earths Production
description: HONG KONG  Premier Wen Jiabao of China and his cabinet decided Wednesday to streamline the countrys rare earth industry by consolidating production, clamping down on illegal mining and clearly deciding which government agencies would oversee it, the government said.

title: Scorecard | Rodarte Wins!
description: The sixth day of New York Fashion Week found Americas pre-eminent female designers fashioning diverging conceptions of national identity. So whose heroines were chicest? At Vera Wang, it was pleats, please. But Scorecard knows critics were over the rainbow with the Mulleavy sisters wearable distillation of their former wool cobweb-cheesecloth-macram creations as tailored prairie dresses. Thats one way to do country strong.

title: Contingent Rights Shouldnt Catch On
description: Contingent value rights are a nice idea. The ones structured for Sanofi-Aventiss purchase of Genzyme helped seal the $20 billion deal. But the drawbacks posed by these rights should limit their use to special cases.

title: The Artwork Isnt Offensive. But to Some, Well, the Very Idea of It ...
description: GREENWOOD LAKE, N.Y.

title: Sure Recipe for Decline: Neglect and Gluttony
description: WASHINGTON

title: Mexicans Knew They Shot U.S. Agents
description: MEXICO CITY  The gunmen who attacked two American law enforcement officials in Mexico on Tuesday, killing one and wounding the other, knew they were firing on foreign officers but proceeded anyway, current and former American officials said Wednesday.

title: Heftier Chamberlain Arrives With Thud at Yankees Camp
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Joba Chamberlain arrived at the most important spring training of his young career listed at 230 pounds, just as he was all last season. This would not be a problem except that Chamberlain weighs more than 230 pounds, and the Yankees are hardly pleased that he does.

title: Mubaraks Funds Found by Swiss
description: Funds belonging to the family of Hosni Mubarak, the former Egyptian president, or his senior ministers have been discovered in Switzerland, a Swiss government official said Wednesday. But the official declined to specify how much money had been identified or who controlled the account.

title: For Tough Baseball Man, a Hurt That Wont Leave
description: CLEARWATER, Fla.

title: Borders Bankruptcy Shakes Industry
description: After Borders, the 40-year-old retail chain that helped define the age of the book superstore, filed for bankruptcy protection on Wednesday, the struggling book industry was left wondering what was next  and maybe even who was next.

title: Forecast at Northern Trust Open Sees Rain and Stars
description: LOS ANGELES  So what if the weather on the horizon is as forbidding as the matre d at Koi glaring at the common people? The specter of three days of rain in Southern California has not deterred the field at Riviera Country Club for the Northern Trust Open.

title: Repaving Leads to New Racing Style at Daytona
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla.  A year after potholes led to embarrassing delays in the Daytona 500, a $20 million repaving job at Daytona International Speedway is helping to create another set of concerns for Nascars season-opening showcase event.

title: Staying in Touch With Home, for Better or Worse
description: KUNDUZ, Afghanistan  Forget the drones, laser-guided bombs and eye-popping satellite imagery. For the average soldier, the most significant change to modern warfare might just boil down to instant chatting.

title: Miles of Sewer Lines, and He Knows Them Well
description: New York City has 7,400 miles of sewer lines, more than any other city in the nation. Luis Baerga, 57, knows those miles better than most people: He is the longest-serving sewer inspector in the city. Mr. Baerga, a supervisor with the Department of Environmental Protection, has worked in the sewer system for 35 years. He was a 21-year-old former Marine when he started in April 1975. He lives in Brooklyn with his wife and three children.

title: Tech Talk Podcast: A Museum of Media
description: This weeks Bits: Tech Talk show features a look at site-specific digital art. Bettina Edelstein chats with the Adobe Museum of Digital Medias first guest curator, Tom Eccles, and the first artist to exhibit on the site, Tony Oursler. Mr. Oursler, who created his piece Valley for the museum, explains that it reflects the human relationship to the Internet. And Mr. Eccles discusses his impressions of working with a digital environment.

title: What the South Got Wrong
description: Between Lincolns election in November 1860 and his inauguration the following March, seven states of the Deep South left the Union. Each of them did so amid scenes of jubilation and rejoicing.

title: How Goldman Killed A.I.G.
description: The conventional wisdom has it that the final report of the Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission was a low-budget flop, hopelessly riven by internal political disputes and dissension among the commissions 10 members. As usual, the conventional wisdom is completely wrong. Actually, the report  and the online archive of testimony, interviews and documents that are now available  is a treasure trove of invaluable information about the causes and consequences of the Great Recession.

title: Unrest Spreads, Some Violently, in Middle East
description: From northern Africa to the Persian Gulf, governments appeared to flounder over just how to outrun mostly peaceful movements, spreading erratically like lava erupting from a volcano, with no predictable end.

title: A New Crackdown Yields 14 Indictments Against a Youthful Harlem Gang
description: All but one of the reputed gang members were born in the 1990s. The lone female among them was a student at Deerfield Academy, an elite Massachusetts prep school.

title: A Case Against Helmets in Lacrosse
description: Camille Richardson has heard all the arguments, read all the comments, and sees the logic. But as a freshman midfielder for the Columbia womens lacrosse team who is fully aware of the dangers of head trauma, Richardson makes one thing clear: She has no interest in wearing a helmet, as the men must.

title: Boehner in His Element as Spending Cuts Elicit Free-Flowing House Debate
description: WASHINGTON  For Speaker John A. Boehner, the budget-cutting frenzy taking place on the House floor merges two of his animating political passions  the need to shrink federal spending and the willingness to risk a free-flowing debate.

title: Court Considers Revising Chinas Marriage Law
description: BEIJING  Sallying forth into the ancient battleground of extramarital affairs, Chinas top court appears poised to side with wronged wives against philandering husbands and greedy mistresses.

title: The Fate of a Patch of Open Space Stirs Anger and Accusations
description: Residents in densely populated Jackson Heights, Queens, are so desperate for public green spaces that they recently temporarily closed down a blocklong section of 78th Street and laid down clumps of synthetic grass bought, on Craigslist, from a suburban house in New Jersey.

title: Lottery Numbers
Shy U.S. Intellectual Created Playbook Used in a Revolution
description: BOSTON  Halfway around the world from Tahrir Square in Cairo, an aging American intellectual shuffles about his cluttered brick row house in a working-class neighborhood here. His name is Gene Sharp. Stoop-shouldered and white-haired at 83, he grows orchids, has yet to master the Internet and hardly seems like a dangerous man.

title: Secret Report Ordered by Obama Identified Potential Uprisings
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama ordered his advisers last August to produce a secret report on unrest in the Arab world, which concluded that without sweeping political changes, countries from Bahrain to Yemen were ripe for popular revolt, administration officials said Wednesday.

title: Reaction to Arsenal-Barcelona
description: Roma might have been booed off its home field in a 3-2 loss to Shakhtar Donetsk on Wednesday, but there was nothing but praise for Arsenal and Barcelona after the Gunners 2-1 victory on Wednesday. A sampling of the principals reactions:

title: Filet Mignon? Winner Turns Up Nose
description: Its not every day that Max Klimavicius, the owner of Sardis, personally cuts a customers filet mignon into bite-size pieces. Then again, not every customer has just won Best in Show at the Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show.

description: People no longer need to be quite as obese as before to qualify for weight loss surgery.

description: Arthur Avenue in the Bronx is known for its Italian restaurants, its cappuccino cafes and its old-school Italian-American population. It is also known as one of the safer streets in the borough, a reputation that made a bold jewelry store robbery there on Wednesday all the more surprising.

title: Four States Get Waivers to Carry Out Health Law
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration said Wednesday that it had granted broad waivers to four states allowing health insurance companies to continue offering less generous benefits than they would otherwise be required to provide this year under the new federal health care law.

title: Bloombergs Budget to Include Teacher Layoffs
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, escalating his battle with Albany over cuts to city programs, will announce plans to lay off nearly 4,700 teachers as part of a bleak budget to be released on Thursday.

title: South Dakota Shelves Bill Aimed at Defending Unborn
description: A state bill to expand the definition of justifiable homicide in South Dakota to include killing someone in the defense of an unborn child was postponed indefinitely Wednesday after an uproar over whether the legislation would put abortion providers at greater risk.

description: The Manhattan district attorneys office is investigating whether the former longtime president of New Yorks leading abortion-rights group abused her expense account, two people briefed on the inquiry said Wednesday.

description: WASHINGTON  Greenhouse gas emissions in the United States declined in 2009 for the second consecutive year, reflecting the impact of the recession on industrial production and overall energy use, the federal government reported on Wednesday.

description: Before there was Watson, there was Deep Blue.

description: Thousands of public workers in Wisconsin protested a proposal to cut benefits and remove most of their unions ability to bargain.

description: The Knicks settled into the All-Star break on Wednesday at nearly the same point where they started the season. Only now they have two more wins than losses. For the Knicks, any progress is significant toward ending a six-year playoff absence.

title: Raymond DAddario, Photographer of Nazis, Dies at 90
description: Raymond DAddario, an Army photographer whose images of Hitlers top henchmen during the Nuremberg war crimes trials put their faces before the world as it became increasingly aware of Nazi atrocities, died Sunday in Holyoke, Mass., his hometown. He was 90.

Chris Christie of New Jersey arrived here Wednesday, opened with a few jokes to an audience not far from the White House and Capitol Hill and then delivered a bipartisan scolding to President Obama and Republicans in Congress, bluntly suggesting they lack courage to confront the nations rapidly growing debt burden.
