title: ABC Correspondent Attacked in Bahrain
description: In the latest instance of an American journalist coming under attack while covering the spreading unrest in the Middle East, Miguel Marquez, an ABC News correspondent, was set upon and beaten while covering protests in Bahrain on Wednesday, the network said.

title: True Grit and Title IX
description: Last week, the University of California at Berkeley announced that it will restore three varsity teams it eliminated last fall: womens gymnastics and lacrosse and mens rugby. It will not, however, restore mens baseball and gymnastics. This Solomonic solution would very likely have been worse without Title IX, the federal law that bans gender discrimination in education.

title: When the Mayors Away
description: Everybody deserves some corner of privacy, even the mayor of New York City. The problem comes when there is a big event  like a Christmas snowstorm  and the mayor has gone away (destination secret) and the deputy mayor is unavailable as well.

description: Are there any adults in charge of the House? Watching this weeks frenzied slash-and-burn budget contest, we had to conclude the answer to that is no.

title: An End to Fannie and Freddie?
description: When Congress considers the Obama administrations proposals to phase out Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, it needs to keep several goals clearly in mind. It must keep the jittery housing market going and reduce taxpayer risk while enticing private companies back into the mortgage business. And it must keep homeownership affordable to moderate-income and working families.

title: Jerry Ames, Tap Dancer With Airy Style, Is Dead at 80
description: Jerry Ames, a tap dancer and choreographer known for his airy, balletic style and eclectic approach, died on Feb. 7 in Woodbury, N.Y. He was 80 and had lived in Manhattan for many years.

description: Old Navy is sending its spokes-mannequins back to the sales floors and storerooms.

title: The One-Man Political Machine
description: On a brutally cold morning in mid-December, Rahm Emanuel, hatless and wearing a glove on only his left hand, stood for an hour in front of the turnstiles at the Paulina el station, which sits in his old Congressional district on Chicagos North Side. As the trains slammed and screeched overhead, he offered his hand to the mostly young and professional commuters heading downtown. Emanuels manner seemed more studied than spontaneous. He employed standard lines  nice hat, good book  and relied on the logos on riders head wear and jackets for conversation starters. He addressed both sexes as man, and when a woman asked about his plans for the Chicago Transit Authority, he was characteristically a trifle abrupt  Heres the deal, he said to start  and egocentric. As he did with me, he told her the elevated line right above us was something I built, before saying we, apparently realizing he was discounting the work and leadership of many others. He hardly seemed like an irresistible force.

description: A look at the day in sports from a soccer field in London to a baseball camp in Phoenix.

title: Stolen Egyptian Statue Is Found in Garbage
description: Zahi Hawass, the Egyptian antiquities minister, said on Wednesday that a statue of the pharaoh Akhenaten holding an offering table, left, one of the most valuable objects revealed earlier this week to have been stolen from the Egyptian Museum, had been found. In an interview, Mr. Hawass also defended himself against charges that he did not report the missing objects promptly. In the days after the museum was broken into on Jan. 28, Mr. Hawass claimed that, while 70 artifacts had been damaged, none had been stolen. Last Sunday he said that, in fact, 18 objects were missing from the museum. Two of the other objects, a heart scarab and a funerary statuette, as well as the goddess from a statue of a goddess carrying Tutankhamen, were found earlier this week. The Akhenaten statue was found in the garbage near Tahrir Square, Mr. Hawass said, by a boy whose uncle was a professor at the University of Cairo. His uncle called me today, and I sent some of the police and archaeologists, and they found it is the statue of Akhenaten, Mr. Hawass said. We are going to look inside all the garbage that they collected from Tahrir Square to find the rest of the objects.

title: Bahrain Turmoil Poses Fresh Test for White House
description: MANAMA, Bahrain  A brutal government crackdown on pro-democracy protesters here on Thursday not only killed at least five people but, once again, placed the Obama administration in the uncomfortable position of dealing with a strategic Arab ally locked in a showdown with its people.

title: News Quiz | February 17, 2011
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: For Germanys Banks, a Grim Future
description: Want to buy a money-losing bank with a damaged business model in an overcrowded market? Neither, it seems, do many other people, Jack Ewing reports in The New York Times.

description: In the wake of the overthrow of the leaders of Tunisia and Egypt, here is a look at countries across the region.

description: WHO won Best in Show at the 135th Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show?

title: Rock Star
description: Deborah Pagani, a willowy Manhattan-based jewelry designer, may well be her own best model. A fashion lover whos usually clad in cutting-edge ensembles by Azzedine Alaa, Haider Ackermann and Rick Owens, she often gets stopped in shops and restaurants by women who want to know where she got her jewelry. Ive been tempted to sell things right off my body, she jokes. Pagani (left, in a Versace dress and her own jewelry) describes her Queen Bee collection as a cross between Joan Crawford and Anita Pallenberg. I dont like classic stones by themselves, she says. Instead, she mixes diamonds, sapphires and amethysts with moodier materials like jasper zebra agate, purple turquoise, Nubian opals and moonstones. My pieces are a bit dark, but dark in a sophisticated way. The earrings above are $16,105 at Ikram, in Chicago.

title: Libyan Unrest Spreads to More Cities, Reports Say
description: PARIS  Exiled opponents of the Libyan leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, said on Thursday that protests mirroring the turmoil in the Arab world had broken out in several parts of the country on a so-called Day of Rage to challenge his 41-year-old iron rule  the regions longest.

description: Canal+ France, the pay television company, said on Thursday that it had filed to sell 20 percent of its shares owned by the conglomerate Lagardre in an initial offering that might raise more than a billion euros.

title: Test Yourself | English, Feb. 17, 2011
description: Test your vocabulary skills with todays question, created by Danielle Hoagland and Judith McCaffrey at Grammarlogues from the editorial In Roars February.

title: How Important Is Fashion to You?
description: Its Fashion Week in New York City, and many designers, including Michael Kors and Mary-Kate and Ashley Olsen, are showing their fall collections. How important is fashion to you? Even if you cant afford to dress in the latest styles, do you follow the trends? Whats your favorite piece of clothing? Why?

title: Los Angeles  Elegiac and a Touch Evil
description: On Sept. 12, 2001, the magazine photographer Thomas Michael Alleman took a $20 plastic Holga camera and began walking the streets of Los Angeles.

title: Egypts Antiquities Minister Says Valuable Statue Found
description: Zahi Hawass, Egypts antiquities minister, said on Wednesday that a limestone statue of Akhenaten holding an offering table, among the most valuable of the objects revealed earlier this week to have been stolen from the Egyptian Museum, had been found among garbage collected at Tahrir Square. Mr. Hawass described the discovery, which he said he planned to announce formally on Thursday, in an interview in which he also defended himself against charges that he did not report the missing objects promptly and responded defiantly to protesters who have called for his resignation.

title: Protesters Face Off for 7th Day in Yemen
description: SANA, Yemen  Yemeni police fired shots into the air on Thursday as thousands of demonstrators, some supporting President Ali Abdullah Saleh and some seeking his downfall, clashed for hours in central Sana, bombarding one another with a hailstorm of rocks on the seventh straight day of violent unrest here.

title: Pakistan Delays Ruling on Jailed American
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  A provincial court on Thursday gave the Pakistani government three weeks to decide whether the American official in custody for killing two Pakistanis has diplomatic immunity, a delay that is likely to intensify a standoff with the United States, the nations biggest donor and an ally in the fight against terrorism.

title: Billionaire Russian Parliamentarian Said to Be Biggest Buyer of VTB Stock
description: Suleiman Kerimov, a Russian billionaire and member of Parliament, became the largest individual shareholder of the state-run bank VTB, buying a $500 million stake in its partial privatization, according to the business daily Vedomosti.

title: Popular Rage Is Met With Violence in Mideast
description: Thousands of Libyan protesters defied threats of violence and arrest in several cities on Thursday, mounting one of the sharpest challenges to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafis 40-year rule in a day of rage modeled on the uprisings coursing through neighboring countries.

title: Hong Kong Arts Festival Gets Interactive
description: Arts festivals are often a passive experience, with viewers sitting quietly, watching performances. But this years Hong Kong Arts Festival invites the public to get up and get outside as they interact with the festivals first outdoor installation, Power Plant, staged at Kowloon Walled City Park.

title: Dumping Violence on the Poor
description: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago.

title: Backstage Beauty | Phillip Lim
description: Phillip Lims inspiration board for his fall collection included references as disparate as bicycle wheels and a picture of a black swan in a green lake. We take little bits from each element and somehow translate that into hair and makeup, said the makeup artist Lisa Butler backstage before the presentation.

title: Questions About Giffordss Future Hover Over Arizona Politics
description: As Representative Gabrielle Giffords of Arizona continues to make progress toward recovery from a gunshot wound to the head, an uncomfortable question is beginning to seep into the political conversation in Arizona and Washington.

title: Former JPMorgan Executive Starts Advisory Firm
description: William T. Winters, a former senior executive at JPMorgan Chase, has teamed up with the investment firms of Jacob Rothschild and the South African billionaire Johann P. Rupert to set up an asset management and advisory firm in London.

title: What Obamas Budget Means for the S.B.A.
description: In recent weeks, President Obama has traveled the country calling for renewed government spending to foster small-company innovation, but on Monday his administration unveiled a Small Business Administration budget (pdf) for 2012 that limits growth in its most important program, government-guaranteed general business loans. It proposes making cuts, modest and substantial, to other S.B.A. programs as well, and would eliminate two initiatives altogether. Still, over all the cuts are not as drastic as the administration may want to convey.

title: In N.F.L. Labor Dispute, Remember the Little Guy
description: A reader, Richard Fox of Roslyn, N.Y., says the news media have been ignoring the people who would be most harmed by an N.F.L. work stoppage.

title: One World Trade Center Is Halfway Up (By Our Call)
description: In 2010, so much progress was made at the World Trade Center that officials saw no need to cook up fabricated milestones, as they had in the past. But in December, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey showed that old habits die hard. It announced in a press release (accompanied by this picture) that 1 World Trade Center  the building formerly known as Freedom Tower  had reached halfway to the top. Meaning what? That the structural steel had reached the level of the 52nd floor in what will be a 104-story building.

title: PPR Chief to Run Gucci Group Himself
description: PARIS  The French fashion and retailing magnate Franois-Henri Pinault surprised the luxury world on Thursday, saying he would personally take charge of the Gucci Group as he reorganized its parent company, PPR, to focus on the most profitable businesses.

title: A Carriage House for Horseless Classics
description: Classic Car Club Manhattan, which offers a fleet of classic and contemporary sports cars to dues-paying members, will expand early next month from its original SoHo branch to the Upper East Side. Its a turn-of-the-century carriage house, said Michael Prichinello, co-founder of the club, of the new outpost. We chose it because physically its in the right area: easy to get in and out of town.

description: MERGERS & ACQUISITIONS

title: New Advice on Preventing Falls
description: For the first time since 2001, the American Geriatrics Society and the British Geriatrics Society have updated their guidelines for preventing falls in older people. The update includes two notable changes: One recommends tai chi  the meditative, slow-motion Chinese exercise  as an effective way to prevent falls, while another suggests that doctors review medication use by all elderly patients, with an eye toward reducing use of those drugs that increase the risk of falling.

title: Cocktails With a Twist: Zing but No Alcohol
description: A column that celebrates drinking should pause every once in a while to celebrate not drinking, given that alcohol is a two-edged sword: catalyst for delight and engine of destruction; handled with restraint by some people, abused and best avoided entirely by others. Its a drug, with all the attendant dangers, and its not the only way to experience liquid pleasure in a restaurant or bar. Others exist and warrant praise.

title: LWren Scott Casting
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#42", 592, 490, false, chameleonData);

title: A Chat With the Man Behind Outside the Law
description: The Franco-Algerian director Rachid Bouchareb has got to be hoping that the third time is the charm. He received Oscar nominations for best foreign-language film in 1996 for his Dust of Life and again in 2007 for Days of Glory, both of which are films that tackle difficult aspects of the relationship between the West and the Third World. And now he is back with Outside the Law, which addresses the long and violent struggle in which Algeria sought its independence from France, finally achieved in 1962.

title: BP Says Spill Settlement Terms Are Too Generous
description: In the eight months since Kenneth R. Feinberg took over the $20 billion fund to compensate victims of the Gulf of Mexico oil spill, he has been attacked by many of those filing claims and by coastal state politicians who argue that the process is opaque, arbitrary and slow. Many of them have also argued that Mr. Feinbergs recently published estimates of future damage to those in the gulf are too optimistic, and thus his offer of compensation in a final settlement is too low.

title: Feb. 17: Updates on Middle East Protests
description: On Thursday, The Lede continues to follow protest movements in Bahrain, Libya, Yemen, Iran, Iraq and Egypt. Updates below mix alerts on breaking news with reports from bloggers and journalists on the ground. A stream of Twitter messages on the protests is in this blogs right column.

title: Morning Buzz | Teacher Layoffs in Bloomberg Budget
description: High temperatures will approach a near-tropical 60 degrees on Thursday, and skies will be partly cloudy with a slight chance of drizzle later. The sultry weather should continue Friday.

title: Lazard Officer Resigns to Focus on Charity Work
description: Naguib Kheraj, the chief executive of Lazard International, resigned on Thursday after less than two months in the job to focus on his philanthropic work with the Aga Khan Development Network.

title: U.S. Consumer Prices Held in Check in January
description: Higher energy costs helped push up consumer prices in the United States last month, according to government statistics released on Thursday, but inflation remained subdued. Economists said the new data showed that the risk of a protracted decline in prices had receded.

title: ISS of Denmark Moves Toward $2.4 Billion I.P.O.
description: ISS, the Danish services company owned by private equity, said on Thursday that it was considering a $2.4 billion initial public offering, the proceeds of which would be used to reduce debt.

title: Thursday Reading: Sharing a Bed With Your Pet
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: Foot Fetish
description: The Paris-based shoe designer Laurence Dacade, whose in-demand studded biker-style boots are sported by the likes of Vanessa Paradis and Erin Wasson, keeps her footwork in step with her vanity case. Her new mesh bootie, the Tiffany, was inspired by the scent of rose gardens. The crimson peep toe, which is sultry and light, is gracefully adorned with a trellis of satin petals. Its sexy and sensual-feeling, Dacade says. The effect is as subtle as a whiff of perfume.

title: Protests Spread to More Iraqi Cities
description: BAGHDAD  Unrest continued to spread in Iraq on Thursday, with new protests erupting in several cities and reports from law enforcement officials that private security guards in a city in Kurdistan fired on a group of protesters who tried to storm the political offices of the regions leader.

title: Some College Needed to Step Up and Say, Enough
description: Those wondering when a prominent college might take the bold step of actually cutting tuition would do well to cast a glance toward Tennessee, where Sewanee, a liberal arts institution, has announced it is doing just that.

title: Remaking Wookiee: Chewbacca Becomes a Character on Star Wars: The Clone Wars
description: Chewie, is that you? In this case, the answer is a resounding Rrrrrrrowwwwr, which were fairly certain means yes.

title: Morning T | Cecilia Dean
description: In this installment of our video interview series, Cecilia Dean, one of the founders of Visionaire, discusses the ongoing dialogue between the worlds of art and fashion, making it on Vogues worst-dressed list and how its not easy being green.

title: Democrats Missing, Wisconsin Vote on Cuts Is Delayed
description: MADISON, Wis.  The fury among thousands of workers, students and union supporters rose to a boil on Thursday, as state lawmakers prepared to vote on landmark legislation that would slash collective bargaining rights for public workers. Protesters blocked a door to the Senate chambers. They sat down, body against body, filling a corridor. They chanted Freedom, democracy, unions! in the stately gallery as the senators convened.

title: Bahrain GP2 Race Canceled
description: The organizers of the GP2 Asia series released a very short statement today announcing that the rest of its race weekend in Bahrain has been canceled. Obviously, this does not bode well for the F1 event itself, but there is still time to see how things work out in Bahrain.

title: Bahrain GP2 Race Canceled
description: The organizers of the GP2 Asia series released a very short statement today announcing that the rest of its race weekend in Bahrain has been canceled. Obviously, this does not bode well for the F1 event itself, but there is still time to see how things work out in Bahrain.

title: Banksy Sightings in Hollywood (of a Sort)
description: Banksy has made it to Hollywood, or at least some of his work has. In the last few days, several pieces by the British street artist have appeared around Los Angeles: a urinating dog (placed in Beverly Hills), a mischievous Charlie Brown and a drunk Mickey and Minnie Mouse, with the slogan Living the Dream. (All the images are viewable on Banksys Web site.) Though Banksys reps confirmed to The Los Angeles Times that the work belonged to him, they did not mention whether it was part of his ongoing un-campaign for his Oscar-nominated documentary, Exit Through the Gift Shop. But since Banksy rarely does anything without it being carefully thought out, we can assume its more than a coincidence.

title: What Were Reading
description: The James Beard Foundation: The semifinalists for the chef and restaurant awards are announced.Nick Fox

title: Speaking In Rhythm Of Footwork
description: THE thought of flamenco on the concert stage does not exactly fill me with cheer. The tradition is gorgeous, but too often the shows are dishearteningly high on affectation and low on artistry. And so, gleeful I was not when I trudged to Town Hall in 2007 to review the Paco Pea Flamenco Dance Company.

title: Modifying Californias Petroleum Diet
description: Memo

title: Weighing Madoffs Claims of Complicity
description: Bernard L. Madoff, in his first interview for publication since his arrest in 2008 for running the largest Ponzi scheme in history, makes claims that echo those of the trustee, Irving H. Picard, in various lawsuits: some of the bankers and fund investors had to know about the fraud.

title: Scorecard Update | Proenza Schouler
description: Designers: Lazaro Hernandez and Jack McColloughDate and Location: Wednesday, Feb. 16, 330 West StreetPhotos: slide show

title: Princely Majesty, Sensuous Simplicity
description: ITS true that 59 sounds ancient for a dancer, but the sight of Vicky Shick might change your mind. The lithe Ms. Shick has been dancing for most of her life, something that over the years has appeared only more effortless. She possesses the kind of considered grace that comes from another world  she was born in Hungary  and perhaps another time.

title: Anticipating Glory From a Newcomer And a Guest Star
description: ALINA COJOCARU is a ballerina who makes you understand why that title should be reserved for a select few. Of course she has a fabulous classical technique and a beautiful line. Of course she has a weightless, airy jump and limpid, exquisite arms. Of course she is both musical and a superb actress. But Ms. Cojocaru, a Royal Ballet principal who will appear as a guest with American Ballet Theater this season, is even greater than the sum of those parts. In her heart-wrenching portrayal of a simple peasant girl betrayed by the man she loves in Giselle; in the extreme, imploding articulations of Wayne McGregors Chroma; or as the radiantly youthful princess of The Sleeping Beauty, she brings an ineffable combination of steely strength and lyrical delicacy to her dancing that is ever-changing and ever-fascinating.

title: A Grand Finale: Cunninghams Last Dances
description: AMID the worlds wide range of illustrious dancers, I draw attention to a rare species that may soon become extinct: the Merce Cunningham performer. Since Cunninghams troupes began in 1953 it has consistently contained a number of the worlds most extraordinary dancers. But on New Years Eve, at the end of the two-year Legacy Tour, the Merce Cunningham Dance Company gives its final performance, and nobody knows yet if much of his choreography will survive in performance anywhere.

title: Feb. 20  26
description: Art

title: For Microsoft and Nokia, Difficult Choices After Smartphone Deal
description: BARCELONA, Spain  With so much uncertainty surrounding Nokias smartphone alliance with Microsoft, one thing is becoming clear: Both companies will have to make some difficult changes, a top Microsoft executive said on Thursday.

title: A Competitor on Any Turf
description: Mike Repole has had a pretty good winter. St. Johns, his alma mater, is inching closer to a berth in the N.C.A.A. mens basketball tournament for the first time since 2002. His racehorse Uncle Mo is the early favorite to win the Kentucky Derby. His beloved Mets have started spring training.

title: Standing Small, Singing Big, All Sulfur and Zest
description: COLORBLINDNESS on the opera stage is a fact of life, yet it never hurts for a singer to look the part, as the bass Kwangchul Youn recognizes. It takes courage to cast a short Korean in parts where people expect a tall, blond European, Mr. Youn said with a broad smile in 2008, after singing the betrayed King Marke in Wagners Tristan und Isolde at the Metropolitan Opera for the first time. Mr. Youn stands a little over 5-foot-7 (1-meter-71, he says, not yielding a centimeter).

title: Caught Unawares by an Anti-Immigrant Mood
description: FALLS CHURCH, Va.  When Mohamed Mejri, a Tunisian immigrant with a limousine business here, first learned that the State Department of Motor Vehicles had refused to issue him a new drivers license, he thought it was a mistake. After all, he had been a licensed driver in Virginia for years.

title: Ring Resumes, With All Eyes on Brnnhilde
description: THERE is much at stake for the Metropolitan Opera with its new production of Wagners Ring cycle. So the premiere of Die Walkre (April 22), the second installment of Robert Lepages high-tech staging, will be the most anticipated event of the spring. The first installment, Das Rheingold, opened the Mets season in September. It returns for two performances (March 30 and April 2), and I am eager to see it again.

title: Calling All Orchestras: Bring a Creative Program
description: WHEN I moved to New York, in 1970, I haunted Carnegie Hall (even more than I do now). Still less than a decade into my late-found obsession with classical music, I couldnt get enough of orchestras: Chicago, Boston, Cleveland, Philadelphia; occasionally even the London Symphony or the Berlin Philharmonic.

title: At Tully Hall, the Norm Is a Festival
description: AT a time that advance ticket sales and season subscriptions have plunged because of economic concerns, arts presenters everywhere have turned to special events as a means to drum up excitement and shore up the bottom line. But now that celebrations are everywhere, how can any institution hope to compete? With Tully Scope, a monthlong series that starts on Tuesday, Lincoln Center proposes a novel solution: When festivals are the norm, why not make the norm a festival?

title: Donizetti and Schwartz Fill Out Opera Program
description: AFTER a sparse season and a half of largely excellent productions under its general manager George Steel, New York City Opera is still struggling to attract audiences, a problem its eclectic spring season may address: there is something for everyone.

title: Festivals of Cubas Finest And of the Avant-Garde
description: NEW YORK CITY music fans can get smug, thinking that sooner or later everything worth hearing will come to us. But some music has been in short supply. Musicians from Cuba, after a thaw in the 1990s around the Buena Vista Social Club, had a hard time negotiating performances in the United States during the Bush administration.

title: Pop Sirens Flirt With Today And Yesterday
description: REMEMBER when it was just the coquette and the rebel? The current Lady Gaga mode of female pop star is both of those things and many more, all encased in latex and chains and ideas about the nature of performance. But about a decade ago, the rules were simpler. There was Britney Spears, injecting teen pop with knowing seduction, and a couple of years later came Avril Lavigne, a bratty mall punk who seemed to be the rejoinder to the hypersexuality of Ms. Spears (and Christina Aguilera).

title: Metal, Electronica, Country and Jazz Are All on Tour
description: POP music festivals in 2011 face the same challenge as always: branding new dishes from the communal stew of touring bands. But through social media the tastemaking classes keep expanding, along with every alternative subculture; the festivals, in turn, keep swelling and diversifying, despite the economy.

title: Fervent G.O.P. Freshmen Ignite Budget Fight
description: WASHINGTON  The last speaker was Representative Steve Southerland, freshman lawmaker from Florida, and so he dug deep.

description: In our weekly Poetry Pairing series, we collaborate with the Poetry Foundation to feature a work from its American Life in Poetry project alongside content from The Times that somehow echoes, extends or challenges the poems themes. Each poem is introduced briefly by Ted Kooser, a former United States poet laureate.

description: DUNEDIN, Fla.  The leading home run hitter in baseball has reportedly agreed to a contract extension. Its not Albert Pujols.

title: Backstage Beauty | Proenza Schouler
description: Fashions latest hairstylist darling, the charming Paul Hanlon, knows the Proenza Schouler girl quite well. Last season, he imagined shed fallen asleep on a bus, and created what was meant to look like a French twist that had been battered by a long day (and a long commute, one assumes). This season, shes grown her hair nearly to her elbows (Hanlon used 22-inch extensions) and pulled it into a low ponytail with some knotty nubs at the end. When [designers Jack McCollough and Lazaro Hernandez] called me in London, the first thing they said to me was that they loved the idea of the girls having really long hair. The first test we did, the girls had this really long straight hair, very blunt, but it didnt feel like their woman  it was a bit army, said Hanlon, adding that the boys were inspired by a cross-country road trip theyd just been on. As an alternative, Hanlon referenced photographer Edward S. Curtis portraits of American Indian women, their hair parted in the middle, heavy behind their shoulders. He began a very low braid, which he then tied with a black elastic, leaving the last loop halfway pulled through. After the tips of the hair were razor cut, the entire head was sprayed with Frederic Fekkai Sheer Hold Hairspray (through a net, a favorite Hanlon technique) for some crunch. Its like when girls go out and they leave their ponytail tucked into their jackets, and when they take it off it looks kind of wrong. Im looking around at Dianes assistants, Hanlon said, referring to the makeup artist Diane Kendal, and some of them walked in with their hair like that. Its nice to have a wearable look. Hairstylists get a bit carried away sometimes.

title: Rivera Still Has the Love and the Passion
description: TAMPA, Fla.  As Mariano Rivera prepared to leave for the airport Wednesday, his 8-year-old son, Jaziel, tugged at his hip. He was crying.

(It has even earned a Tumblr feed  the sign of a true, or at least truly ridiculous, Web meme  showing dozens of perplexed Twitter posts.)

title: Mens Fall Fashion 2011 | Michael Kors
description: Michael Kors stuck to basic black, gray and camel in elegantly sparse outfits that were primarily one color, with shoes to match. His charcoal cashmere double-breasted great coat with floor-sweeping length and powerful shoulders was as dramatic as it was luxurious.

title: Ralph Lauren: Into the East
description: The stepped border around the entrance and the glossy black runway at Ralph Lauren suggested an Art Deco moment, but the clothes made clear that the designer was one of the many who had China on their minds. Actually, the clothes suggested a mood of Orientalism, as seen through an Art Deco lens, with long, sleek black beaded columns, or a creamy white wrap blouse and shiny black trousers, accented with a touch of red on satin peep-toe pumps.

title: Diamondback Redemptions Total $1.3 Billion
description: Spooked by the broad insider trading investigation, investors have asked to pull more than $1.3 billion from Diamondback Capital Partners  amounting to nearly 23 percent of the hedge fund firms total assets, according to a letter sent to investors Thursday.

title: Roger That: Slattery Supports Same-Sex Marriage
description: Fans of Mad Men, who may be wondering when the fifth season of the series will begin, can watch at least one member of the cast in a video clip that is part of a campaign to legalize marriage for gay men and lesbians.

title: Hevesi Adviser Is Sentenced in Pension Scandal
description: 4:00 p.m. | Updated Hank Morris, once a political adviser to Alan G. Hevesi, a former state comptroller, received a maximum sentence of one and a third to four years in prison on Thursday for his role in a pay-to-play scheme involving the states pension fund.

title: Pentagon Watching Unrest in Bahrain
description: WASHINGTON  The United States Navy headquarters in Bahrain, the tiny Persian Gulf nation whose capital was rocked Thursday by a violent police crackdown on antigovernment protesters, oversees warships and combat aircraft that carry out long-range missions across Afghanistan and Iraq, conduct antipiracy patrols off the Horn of Africa  and keep a wary eye on the activities of a bellicose Iran.

title: John Gallagher Jr. Joins Cast of Jerusalem on Broadway
description: The coming transfer of Jez Butterworths Jerusalem will combine members of the plays original Royal Court and West End cast with a few familiar Broadway veterans, including one soon-to-be-available Tony Award winner: John Gallagher Jr., the Spring Awakening star who is slated to leave American Idiot at the end of the month. Mr. Gallagher will appear in Jerusalem as Lee, one of the many lovably seedy characters who inhabit the world of the plays protagonist, Johnny Rooster Byron, press representatives for the production said on Thursday. It was previously announced that Mark Rylance (of La Bte) and Mackenzie Crook (of Britains The Office) will reprise their roles as Johnny and his chum Ginger; they will be joined by Max Baker (Cyrano de Bergerac) as Wesley, Geraldine Hughes (Translations) as Dawn and Molly Ranson (August: Osage County) as Pea.

title: How Do Working Parents Do It?
description: From January 2009 until this week, I wrote a column called Cooking With Dexter that ran in The New York Times Magazine. Although the title and much of the action focused on my older son, who was 4 when the column began, I wasnt particularly interested in writing about my adorable children. What I was really trying to do each month was to write as honestly as I could about the kitchen life of a working father who cooks.

title: Wilpon Says His Family Will Be Vindicated

title: A Doctor at the Funeral
description: Death is a given in medicine. That truism, though, doesnt offer much comfort when its your patient who has died. I was in clinic the other day, showing the ropes to a fresh-faced medical student, when a nurse leaned toward me and whispered that L.W. had died over the holiday weekend.

title: Tallying Coals Hidden Cost
description: Coal may be among the dirtiest fuels, but it is also cheap and plentiful in the United States, where it still accounts for nearly half of electricity generation.

title: Explaining Teen Pregnancy to a 6-Year-Old?

Shes always been honest and straightforward with the girls, prided herself on it, in fact, and has started talking to them about sex before it becomes awkward  matter-of-factly introducing the subject, just as the advice books say.

title: Seeing Things | Donald Wexler, Desert Modernist
description: This weekend marks the kickoff of Modernism Week, Palm Springss annual celebration of all things midcentury modern. One of its highlights is Steel and Shade: The Architecture of Donald Wexler, an exhibition at the Palm Springs Art Museum. Wexler, 85, has practiced in Palm Springs for almost six decades, developing an architecture that is acutely sensitive to the extremes of the desert climate. Wexlers all-steel Alexander houses, designed in 1962 with the structural engineer Bernard Perlin for the developers George and Robert Alexander, were sustainable before sustainability was trendy. Affordable, elegant and quick to assemble on site, thanks to a prefabricated structural system, Wexlers houses (their framing, roofs and exterior siding are steel, with drywall interior siding) were the perfect answer to the postwar housing boom. Steel, concrete and glass are ideal materials for the desert, Wexler says. They are inorganic and dont deteriorate in the extreme temperatures of the desert. And since these structures are relatively maintenance-free, the seven Alexander houses in a north Palm Springs enclave are as pristine today as they were almost 50 years ago.

title: Critics' Picks: 'Rosemary's Baby'
description: A.O. Scott looks back at a movie probing themes of paranoia, persecution and motherhood.

title: TimesTalks: Julianne Moore
description: Melena Ryzik interviews the actress Julianne Moore.

title: Carpetbagger: Colin Firth
description: Colin Firth, an Oscar front-runner for his role in "The King's Speech," attends a posh luncheon in his honor.

title: Critics' Picks: 'Solaris'
description: A .O. Scott looks back at Andrei Tarkovsky's film about space and consciousness, memory and loss.

title: Protests in Bahrain
description: The Op-Ed columnist Nicholas D. Kristof spoke to protesters in Manama, Bahrain.

title: Opinion: Tahrir Square, a Forum for All
description: The Op-Ed columnist Roger Cohen discusses how Tahrir Square opened up dialogues between westernized and Islamist Egyptians.

title: Egyptian Protester Back on the Airwaves
description: Mohamed Safi, an Egyptian DJ, looks back on his participation in the antigovernment protests as he heads back to his day job.

title: WikiLeaks: The Back Story
description: The executive editor, Bill Keller, and other journalists from The Times discuss dealing with Julian Assange, reporting on the leaks and the impact of the adventure.

title: In Concert: Girl Talk
description: A behind-the-scenes look at a show by Gregg Gillis, who performs under the name Girl Talk. Known for his mash-ups, his instrument is his laptop.

title: Behind 'The Scene Makers'
description: The New York Time Magazine's Director of Photography Kathy Ryan gives a behind-the-scenes look at the video feature of the Oscar issue.

title: Eli (Paperboy) Reed, New-Old Soul
description: The singer-guitarist performs the title track from his new album.

title: Assange in Court
description: Wikileaks Founder, Julian Assange is facing extradition as well as new competition from his former partner.

title: How to Save Money at the Car Dealership
description: If youre in the market for a new car and dont want to buy it online, heres a helpful car shopping tip from Edmunds.com: When you walk into the dealer, ask to work with an Internet salesman rather than the traditional sales staff.

title: Pregame Huddle: B.C.S. Bowl Preview
description: There are plenty of marquee matchups besides the B.C.S. title game. Paul Myerberg tells Connor Ennis who he thinks will come out on top.

title: Google Search Results Get More Social
description: Google is taking its biggest step yet toward making search results more social.

title: Shirin Neshat for Ohne Titel
description: The New York-based artist discusses posing for the designers Flora Gill and Alexa Adams.

title: The Starlet So Far
description: Highlights of Megan Foxs career.

title: Technology and the Trenchcoat
description:
Burberry's Chief Creative Officer Christopher Bailey talks with Suzy Menkes about his strong partnership
with CEO Angela Ahrendts and the ups and downs of designing in a digital world.

title: Southern Sudan's Referendum
description: As southern Sudan's referendum nears an end, the Abyei region on the disputed border is still rife with conflict. (An interview that was incorrectly translated has been removed from this video.)

title: Southern Sudan's Referendum
description: Locals reflect on what the vote to make the region of Southern Sudan fully independent from the rest of the country means to them.

title: Auto Ego: Food Truck
description: Massimiliano Nanni has made room in a crowded life for a vintage Ford Econoline pickup.

title: The Search for Julian Assange
description: In this exclusive behind-the-scenes video, filmed during the last week of September, our features and entertainment director Jacob Brown and the photographer Max Vadukul track the elusive Assange to London.

title: T Exclusive Video | 'Dorothea'
description: The filmmaker Barnaby Roper transforms the model Dorothea Barth Jorgensen into a three-dimensional otherworldly beauty.

title: Victoria Beckham: Star Fashion Designer
description:
Speaking at the IHT Luxury Conference in London, Fashion Editor Suzy Menkes sits down with designer Victoria
Beckham to discuss her label and being nominated for a British Fashion Award.

title: Republican Response

title: Rep. Michele Bachmann's Response
description: Representative Michele Bachmann of Minnesota provides a Tea Party response to President Obama's State of the Union address.

title: CPAC Provides First Look at 2012 Race
description: Republicans attended the Conservative Political Action Conference, hearing speeches from some prospective presidential contenders.

title: Bill Clinton Campaigns for Rahm Emanuel
description: At a campaign appearance in Chicago, former President Bill Clinton urged Chicago voters to support his former staff member who is now running for mayor.

title: Obama Calls for Civility in Politics
description: President Obama addresses a memorial event in Tucson for the people who were killed and wounded in the assassination attempt on Representative Gabrielle Giffords.

title: From Washington to Chicago
description: The move from chief of staff at the White House to a run for mayor has been harder than Rahm Emanuel may have expected.

title: Obama's Second State of the Union
description: President Obama called for Americans to unleash their creative spirits and join in a goal of outcompeting other nations.

title: An Interview With Tim Pawlenty
description: The former governor of Minnesota sits down with Michael Shear of the Caucus.

title: Trailer: 'Desert Flower'
description: Liya Kebede stars as a Somalian nomad turned supermodel in this film based on the autobiography of Waris Dirie.

title: Behind the Scenes With Nicki Minaj
description: Behind the scenes on our photo shoots with the hip-hop sexplosion Nicki Minaj.

title: Doug Aitken's 'We'
description: Aitken's exclusive 3-part video piece goes behind the scenes at rehearsals for this year's MoCA benefit.

title: Morning T | Alan Cumming
description: The actor discusses his new fragrance, his fashion sense and the name of his autobiography.

title: Bottega Veneta's Tomas Maier
description: The creative director of Bottega Veneta reflects on his formative years, the importance of the personal touch and his vision of fashion's future.

title: Video: Corice Canton Arman
description: The wife of artist Arman discusses her late husband, his process, his life and his home.

title: The Fashion Designer Giambattista Valli
description: The independent designer talks about his first standalone store that just opened in Paris, his love of collaborations and the reason why he doesn't show his clothing during haute couture.

title: Siki Im Casting
description: The Moment caught up with the men's wear designer as he and stylist David Vandewal were preparing for the Siki Im fashion week presentation.

title: Karl Lagerfeld: In His Own Words
description: Speaking at the IHT Luxury Conference in London, Fashion Editor Suzy Menkes sits down with designer Karl Lagerfeld to discuss his career and the the history of Chanel.

title: An Interview With Alber Elbaz
description: Suzy Menkes talks with Lanvin's artistic director, Alber Elbaz, about how he incorporates the spirit of Jeanne Lanvin into his designs and what his collaboration with H&M has taught him about fashion.

title: Excerpt: 'Compulsion'
description: Mandy Patinkin in a scene from Rinne Groff's play at the Public Theater. (Video courtesy of the Public Theater)

title: The iPhone for Advanced Beginners
description: Sam Grobart shows iPhone users a few features that they may not be aware of.

title: Fed Chief Says U.S. Bolstered Its Ability to Handle Failure of a Big Bank
description: WASHINGTON  The chairman of the Federal Reserve said on Thursday that banking regulators would be better able to deal with the failure of a large bank today than they were two years ago, thanks in part to the Dodd-Frank Act, which overhauled financial regulation after the crisis of 2007-8.

title: Cut in Federal Fuel-Cell Financing Is Criticized by Proponents
description: On Monday, the Energy Department proposed a fiscal 2012 budget that would increase financing for wind, solar, geothermal and battery technologies, but cut spending on hydrogen technology by nearly $70 million, roughly 40 percent of the programs 2010 budget of $174 million

title: Citadel in Talks to Sell Itself
description: 7:22 p.m. | Updated

title: New Fed Rule for Mortgage Brokers
description: STARTING April 1, under a new compensation rule from the Federal Reserve, borrowers who get their mortgages through brokers will most likely pay less for their services and must be offered the lowest possible interest rate and fees for which they qualify.

title: In Uganda, Unrest Gains Little Ground
description: KAMPALA, Uganda  Fresh from fighting in the bush, Ugandas president, Yoweri Museveni, a former rebel commander, electrified the crowd at his inaugural address in 1986 when he declared that the problems of Africa, and Uganda in particular, are caused by leaders who overstay in power.

title: Sony Streams Music From the Cloud
description: Joining a growing number of companies that offer digital music from the cloud  that is, streamed to personal devices from remote servers  Sony is introducing a new service on Thursday that will operate on its own televisions and home-entertainment products, but not yet on mobile devices.

title: Abbas Casts Doubt on Palestinian Elections
description: JERUSALEM  The Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, cast doubt on Thursday about the chances of holding presidential and parliamentary elections this year, despite an announcement over the weekend that they would be held by September.

title: Cast Changes at the Met
description: The soprano Anna Netrebko is ill and has pulled out of Saturdays matinee performance of Don Pasquale, the Metropolitan Opera said on Thursday. Rachelle Durkin will sing the role of Norina in her place.

title: The Gender Pay Gap by Industry
description: From the Bureau of Labor Statistics comes a cool chart on the gender pay gap for full-time jobs, sorted by industry:

title: Viewpoints: The Relevancy of Exchanges
description: DealBooks Andrew Ross Sorkin speaks to Felix Salmon, a finance blogger at Reuters, about whether the recent merger between Deutsche Brse and NYSE Euronext marks the impending death of exchanges.

title: Digging Deeper on Macondo
description: The commission appointed by President Obama to plumb the causes of the blowout of BPs Macondo well in the Gulf of Mexico last year presented its findings a month ago. The seven-member panel essentially concluded that the accident and subsequent oil spill were the result of a cascade of management failures, regulatory oversights, missed signals and time-saving shortcuts that combined to take 11 lives and produce the worst offshore oil release in the nations history.

title: Editor Outfits | Sara Moonves and Chelsea Zalopany
description: Sara Moonves, Fashion EditorThe Balenciaga boots are my all time favorite. I got them so many years ago and still wear them every winter, says Moonves. They are incredibly warm and although they look impossible to walk in, they are actually quite comfortable. Its freezing this week and Im always cold, so I pile up on shearling! Moonves is also wearing: Givenchy coat, J. Crew T-shirt, Balenciaga skirt, motorcycle bag and boots.

title: Agnotology
description: An interesting exchange between John Quiggin and Jonathan Chait on right-wing agnotology  that is, culturally-induced ignorance or doubt. The specific issue is birtherism, the claim that Barack Obama was born in Kenya or anyway not in America, which polls indicate is a view held by a majority of Republican primary voters.

title: Budgetary Zugzwang
description: There is a situation in chess called zugzwang in which any legal move leaves the player worse off (in other words, hed be better off to pass his turn). Oftentimes, in fact, the zugzwang is mutual: both players would rather that the other one move next. A typical situation  blacks only legal move would lead to a loss, but whites only legal moves would turn an advantageous position into a draw  is illustrated below.

title: Standoff in Yemen's Capital
description: Thousands of demonstrators, some supporting President Ali Abdullah Saleh and some seeking his downfall, clashed for hours in central Sana on Thursday.

title: A Happy Orlando Homecoming for Lewis
description: The former Magic star Rashard Lewis found out Wednesday that warm feelings still flicker for him in Orlando. Lewis was traded to the Washington Wizards on Dec. 18, as part of a three-team deal that helped the Magic acquire Gilbert Arenas.

title: Theater Talkback: Missing Maggie Smith
description: I am surely not the only theater fan suffering serious Downton Abbey withdrawal symptoms. Masterpiece may have surgically removed the word theater from its official title, as if the word were somehow a vestigial appendage of the pre-modern era. (Its presentations are now classified as Masterpiece Classic or Mystery or Contemporary.) But the pleasures afforded by this long-running television series overlap considerably with the satisfactions for which many of us look to the theater: a heightened literacy, refined wit, rich characterizations, absorbing narrative, plummy British accents.

title: Digital Age Is Slow to Arrive in Rural America
description: COFFEEVILLE, Ala.  After a couple of days in this part of rural Alabama, it is hard to complain about a dropped iPhone call or a Cee Lo video that takes a few seconds too long to load.

title: Daytona 500 Tribute Set for Earnhardt
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla.  The 10th anniversary of the fatal crash of Dale Earnhardt at Daytona International Speedway will pass Friday without an official tribute as a lower-level Camping World Series truck race is held at the track.

title: Fiat to Recommend Premium Gasoline for 500 Subcompact
description: Prior to delivering the keynote address to the International Motor Press Association in midtown Manhattan on Thursday afternoon, Laura Soave, head of Fiat Brand North America, stopped by The New York Times to discuss the brands positioning in the American market.

title: Guess Where This Is
description: Our guessing game last week may have been a little too easy. So this week, were trying something new: Were asking you to guess the location of the photograph above, but were not giving you any hints.

title: BP Challenges Spill Settlement Terms
description: BP is complaining that the proposed settlement amounts for people who suffered damages in the gulf spill are too generous, John Schwartz reports.

title: Mizrahi: Let Them Eat Cake
description: Its always such an annoyance that Fashion Week overlaps with the Westminster dog show, since few editors have time to keep up with the canine competition. A shame, too, considering theres not that much difference between the two events  a bunch of preening poodles paraded around in a circle before an audience ready to point out their slightest flaws, or tell them theyre too fat.

title: Now Streaming | Calvin Klein
description: The Fall/Winter 2011 womens wear collection from Calvin Klein at New York fashion week, which will start at about 2:30 p.m.

title: HTC Design Chief Talks About Its First Tablet, the Flyer
description: BARCELONA, Spain  Hardware makers are engineering new ways to make their mobile devices stand out. For HTC, the Taiwanese phone manufacturer, that meant revisiting an older idea: a tablet that can be scribbled on with a stylus.

title: Some Spanish Savings Banks Want More Time to Recover
description: MADRID  Spanish savings banks, which have been ordered to raise more capital by the government, are facing an uphill struggle to persuade investors to help them improve their balance sheets.

title: Hibernating Black Bear
description: A snoring black bear under infrared illumination during its hibernation in Fairbanks, Alaska.

title: Progress Reported on Oil Plugging System
description: The big oil companies have a long way to go to recover from the BP well blowout that spilled millions of barrels of crude into the Gulf of Mexico. But on Thursday they took a step in the direction of drilling again by unveiling a new well-blowout plugging and spill containment system.

title: Hibernating Bears Keep Thermostat Turned Up
description: Thanks to a few adventurous black bears that wandered too close to human communities in Alaska, scientists gained a rare glimpse into the species hibernation habits.

title: Mattingly Provided Fitting Ending for His Biographer
description: PHOENIX  Mike Shalins biography of Don Mattingly will be published in March, a few weeks before Mattingly makes his managerial debut with the Los Angeles Dodgers against the reigning World Series champion San Francisco Giants.

title: Family Maid Files Suit Against Author of The Help
description: JACKSON, Miss.  There is The Help and then there is the help. And she is not happy.

title: Traction-Control Override a Possibility for 2012 VW GTI and Golf R
description: The sportiest Volkswagen models available in Europe for 2012  the GTI, the Golf R and the Scirocco  will come standard with a new electronic stability system that can be fully disabled.

title: A Historical Sleeper, on So Many Levels
description: LAST fall the Landmarks Preservation Commission extended the Upper East Side Historic District to include an odd, gangly patch mostly between Lexington and Third Avenues in the 60s and 70s.

title: Visualizing Science
description: Some of the winning photographs and illustrations from the 2010 International Science and Engineering Visualization Challenge, sponsored by the journal Science and the National Science Foundation.

title: Palin, on Long Island, Answers Budget and Worldview Questions
description: WOODBURY, N.Y.  Sarah Palin urged Congressional Republicans on Thursday to stand against raising the nations debt ceiling when the issue is debated this spring, declaring, It doesnt necessarily have to result in a government shutdown.

title: Pictures of the Day: Bahrain and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Bahrain, Yemen and Afghanistan.

title: Weighing the New Subscription Services
description: Brian Stelter and David Carr discuss the new Apple and Google digital subscription models.

title: Vocabulinks
description: An occasional assemblage of notable vocabulary and linguistic debate from around the Web.

title: Google One Pass vs. Apple iPad Plan
description: Related: Google Announces Payment System for Digital ContentRelated: Apple Offers Subscriptions for Apps

title: Mattingly Takes the Reins of the Troubled Dodgers
description: PHOENIX  It was Don Mattinglys opening news conference at his first spring training as the Dodgers manager, and a seat at the head of a picnic table was reserved for him. Mattingly demurred and folded his 6-foot frame into another chair on an outdoor patio after casually brushing off a dried bird dropping stuck to it.

title: Suez Canal Workers Join Broad Strikes in Egypt
description: CAIRO  Hundreds of workers went on strike on Thursday along the Suez Canal, one of the worlds strategic waterways, joining others across Egypt pressing demands for better wages and conditions. The protests have sent the economy reeling and defied the militarys attempt to restore a veneer of the ordinary after President Hosni Mubaraks fall last week.

title: A Word From Stieg Larssons Partner, and Would-Be Collaborator
description: PARIS  Eva Gabrielsson, the longtime partner of the late Swedish novelist Stieg Larsson, has written her version of their life together. Millennium, Stieg and Me is a slim memoir published in France, Sweden and Norway last month with a co-author, the French journalist Marie-Franoise Colombani.

title: What Is President Obama Asking Tech Leaders?
description: Last year, I had an absolute blast writing a book called The World According to Twitter. The concept was this: every night, Id pose a provocative question of my Twitter followers (then 500,000 of them; Im @pogue on Twitter). Id say, Compose the subject line of an e-mail you really, really dont want to open. Or Describe your first kiss. Or Tell the story of your brush with greatness.

title: Michigan Governor Proposes Budget Cuts and Lower Taxes
description: Rick Snyder, the newly elected Republican governor of Michigan, had promised to make big changes to state government on the campaign trail. When he released his first budget on Thursday, Mr. Snyder did just that by proposing huge spending cuts and lower business taxes.

title: Asked & Answered | Charlotte Dellal
description: Nothing seems to faze her. Charlotte Dellal, the soul behind the soles of Charlotte Olympia, is in the middle of Fashion Week and her second pregnancy. Shes been traveling from London to New York and back to present her fall 2011 collection. Next up: Los Angeles for Coachella and, later this month, the premiere of charlotteolympia.com, her e-commerce site. Dellal is one-part Brazilian, one-part English and a total riot. She spoke with The Moment at the shoe salon at Bergdorf Goodman to reveal how she makes it all happen.

title: Top Silicon Valley Execs to Meet With Obama
description: In the latest in a series of meetings involving President Obama and business leaders, a small group of top Silicon Valley executives plans to meet with Mr. Obama at a dinner on Thursday at the home of John Doerr, a prominent venture capitalist.

title: Meet the Oscars, at Grand Central
description: Movie buffs eager to get up close to some Oscar glamour have a few options across the country. In New York, head to Grand Central for the Academys annual Meet the Oscars exhibit, in which you can put your grubby paws all over the naked little guy, for a few seconds at least. In Times Square, you can get yourself photographed with a virtual Oscar, and experience a few seconds of red carpet fame. But for the real deal experience we recommend getting a bunch of your photoblogger friends together and having them shout and point at you as you stand in front of a cardboard backdrop. Then stop to chat awkwardly with Ryan Seacrest, or maybe the Naked Cowboy.

title: Military Crackdown in Bahrain
description: Thousands of people gathered at a hospital in Manama, the capital, just hours after the police opened fire on pro-democracy demonstrators camped in Pearl Square.

title: Forecasting Is for the Birds (and Rats)
description: Apparently pigeons are better at forecasting than humans are. A reader sends along an article from The Durango Herald in Colorado, which says:

title: Keeping Score: Sizing Up the All-Stars
description: Justin Kubatko is the creator of Basketball-Reference.com, an online basketball encyclopedia. He is also a statistical consultant for the Portland Trail Blazers.

title: Excavating the Origins of Maya Civilization
description: Takeshi Inomata, a professor of anthropology at the University of Arizona, writes from Guatemala, where he and Daniela Triadan are excavating the Maya site of Ceibal, Guatemala.

title: Q&A: Music and Lyrics on an iPod Touch
description: Q.

title: Improving Elementary Education in India
description: A five-year-old project is trying to change how students are taught and tested in a country where rote memorization is the norm.

title: Skipping Rote Memorization in Indian Schools
description: PANTNAGAR, India  The Nagla elementary school in this north Indian town looks like many other rundown government schools. Sweater-clad children sit on burlap sheets laid in rows on cold concrete floors. Lunch is prepared out back on a fire of burning twigs and branches.

title: Palin, on Long Island, Takes Questions on Budget and Worldview
description: The Caucus blog, reporting from Woodbury, N.Y., on Long Island, has published a post on Sarah Palins speech there on Thursday. Speaking at a luncheon appearance before the Long Island Association, she urged Congressional Republicans not to shut down the government in order to pass the budget. Read the full post on The Caucus.

title: Photo of the Day: New York Fashion Week
Model-Morphosis | Jac Jagaciak at Ralph Lauren
description: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of New York Fashion Week. Here, the model Jac Jagaciak at IMG before (left) and after (right) transforms, with makeup by Tom Pecheux and hair by Guido Palau for Redken. (Drag the orange bar left to reveal the full transformation.)

title: Bieber Fever: Casting a Critical Eye on Celebrities and Popular Culture
description: Overview | What are pop culture idols and icons, and how do they both reflect and influence the prevailing culture? What does media coverage about popular stars say about them, the publications and the culture overall? In this lesson, students analyze the teenage singing sensation Justin Bieber through the lens of cultural criticism and consider some of the ways critics deconstruct other cultural heroes and heroines.

title: A.D.H.D.: To Medicate or Not to Medicate?
description: Do drugs for attention deficit hyperactivity disorder need to be taken for life? Are they dangerous? Are there alternatives to medications? There are among the questions posed by readers of the Consults blog. Dr. Russell A. Barkley, clinical professor of psychiatry at the Medical University of South Carolina and author, most recently, of Taking Charge of Adult A.D.H.D.,  responds.

title: Whale Wars Waits on Japanese Government
description: Reports that Japan has suspended whaling in the waters off Antarctica and is considering canceling the remainder of its current season have whale lovers wondering whether their favorite seagoing mammals might get a permanent reprieve from hunting, at least in the Southern Hemisphere. But reality-television lovers have another question: What does this mean for Whale Wars?

title: Bill Monroe, Meet the Press Host, Dies at 90
description: Bill Monroe, a television journalist whose long career with NBC included stints as the networks Washington bureau chief and moderator of its Sunday interview program, Meet the Press, died on Thursday at a nursing home in Potomac, Md. He was 90.

title: House Forges Ahead on Spending Cuts
description: House Republicans on Thursday continued their steady march toward approving the largest spending cuts in modern history  a swift, huge slash of more than $60 billion from domestic programs and foreign aid that Republicans said would fulfill their promise to shrink government outlays, but Democrats said would harm the fragile economic recovery.

title: Calvin Kleins Controlled Take on the Season
description: Francisco Costas womens collection for Calvin Klein was the last major show of New York Fashion Week, before editors head off to London, then Milan and Paris for more shows. Mr. Costas runway was, as usual, full of controlled and clean sportswear looks, some in the same materials weve seen popping up from runway to runway.

title: When Trauma Lingers
description: Post-traumatic stress disorder doesn't only affect war veterans. It may also affect that young girl walking her dog down the street.

title: Remedies: Clove Oil for Tooth Pain
description: More than a third of American adults use some form of complementary or alternative medicine, according to a government report. Natural remedies have an obvious appeal, but how do you know which ones to choose and whether the claims are backed by science? In this occasional series, Anahad OConnor, the New York Times Really? columnist, explores the claims and the science behind alternative remedies that you may want to consider for your family medicine cabinet.

title: Letting His Lifes Work Do the Talking
description: Bessemer, Ala.

title: Viewpoints: Wall Street's Dead End?
description: DealBook's Andrew Ross Sorkin speaks to Felix Salmon, finance blogger at Reuters, about whether the recent merger between Deutsche Boerse and NYSE Euronext marks the impending death of exchanges.

title: How Would You Tinker With Graduation Requirements?
description: Last week, New York State education officials released a new set of statewide graduation statistics showing that only 41 percent of students are leaving high school prepared for college and well-paying careers, even though 77 percent of students are graduating.

title: Pogues Posts: What Is Obama Asking Tech Leaders?
description: On his blog, David Pogue writes about how he inspired an outburst of humor on Twitter with a message about President Obamas meeting with technology leaders.

title: In Belgium, Beer and Frites Honor Political Failure
description: BRUSSELS  What does it take to form a government?

title: Lucas, Burns, Souter Among Those Named To New Commission on the Liberal Arts
description: As public and private colleges and universities have been forced to make painful budget cuts in the past couple of years, many educators have worried that the humanities are getting short shrift. To bolster support for teaching and research in the liberal arts, the American Academy of Arts and Sciences on Thursday announced the creation of a national commission on the humanities and social sciences. The panel was established at the request of a group of Democratic and Republican senators who asked the academy for a top 10 list of actions that government, educators and philanthropists could take to maintain excellence in the humanities and social sciences and strengthen civil society.

title: The Toy Story Gang to Ride Again
description: LOS ANGELES Toy Story fans, rejoice. Pixar will release two new short films starring Woody and pals by years end. The first short, Hawaiian Vacation, will run with Cars 2, which will arrive in theaters on June 24. Pixar unveiled Hawaiian Vacation at a gathering of about 300 Disney investors and analysts in Anaheim, Calif., on Thursday. (Barbie and Ken try to stow away with Bonnie for a Hawaiian trip but get left home, to their enormous disappointment; Woody, Buzz and the other toys try to console the pair by improvising an island vibe but . . . it doesnt go well.) The second short  a title was not announced  will run with The Muppets, a Disney feature film set for a Thanksgiving release.

title: In Miami, Flames Take Vacant Art Deco Buildings
description: Someone is apparently trying to burn down vacant, but once grand, Art Deco buildings in Miami Beach, home to one of the worlds largest collection of such buildings.

title: Guest List for Obamas Dinner With Technology Leaders
description: President Obama will sit down for dinner with a dozen of the titans of the American technology industry Thursday night at the Silicon Valley home of the venture capitalist John Doerr, according to two people familiar with the presidents plans.

title: TimesCast | February 17, 2011
description: The United States' response to Bahrain's crackdown; Egypt's military economy; and evidence of illegal detention and torture in Egypt.

title: Eagle-Eyed Urbanites Winter Treks
description: IS that the murder scene? the woman beside me asked in hushed tones.

title: Nordstrom to Acquire Online Retailer for $180 Million
description: Rick Bowmer/Associated PressA Nordstrom store in Portland, Ore.

title: 36 Hours in Downtown Los Angeles
description: The long-blighted center has become an accessible, pedestrian-friendly destination in recent years.

title: 36 Hours in Downtown Los Angeles
description: THE sprawl, the scale, all that freeway time  for many, Los Angeles is an acquired taste. But not downtown. New York-like in its density and mishmash, the long-blighted center has become an accessible, pedestrian-friendly destination in recent years; Angelenos walk around en masse, using their actual legs. The immense L.A. Live entertainment complex is largely responsible for this comeback, but the studiously vintage bars and imaginative restaurants that seem to open every other day are also part of the revival. Skid Row and the drifts of homeless camps havent vanished altogether, and the grittiness still varies by block. But this part of town is alive again, in ways that make sense even to an outsider.

title: Mileys Fathers Regrets
description: Billy Ray Cyrus has regrets. In a long article by Chris Heath in the March issue of GQ he talks about watching his marriage unravel, and of seeing videos of his apparently stoned daughter, Miley, go viral.

title: Fashion Week Parties, Night 7
description: Scenes from Wednesday night, including an uptown gala for Van Cleef & Arpels, and downtown fetes for Proenza Schouler and Adam Kimmel.

title: Way Back Machine | Name That Bridge, 1931 Edition
description: Editors Note: This post includes descriptions of the historical background similar to material the same author published in The Daily News in 2000. Had editors known of the earlier article, those passages would not have been used. Two other posts by this author also included descriptions similar to material he had previously written for The Daily News.

title: New York Fashion Week: Wrap-Up
description: Eric Wilson highlights the fall season's emerging trends and the collections of Jason Wu, Marc Jacobs and Alexander Wang, which embraced lace, new silhouettes and big coats.

title: Long After Fall, Countrywides Mozilo Defended His Legacy
description: More than two years after Countrywide Financial nearly collapsed under the weight of souring subprime home loans, Angelo R. Mozilo passionately defended the mortgage lender that he founded before a government panel.

title: Artful Commentary, Oozing From the Walls
description: The New Museum has become a busy place this year, and it is not yet even March. In January it opened a popular tribute to the market-hardy paintings of George Condo. Now it is offering a startlingly excellent resurrection of the prescient Post-Minimalist renegade Lynda Benglis and her gaudy, multidexterous and often gender-bending segues among Process, Performance and Body Art.

title: Cindy Shermans Guises All in a Single Place
Pictures of the Day: Bahrain and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Bahrain, Yemen and Afghanistan.

title: When Enamel Wares Adorned Chinas Imperial Courts
description: Many human beings evidently share with the magpie a gene causing an irrational attraction to bright and shiny objects. If you suffer from this disorder, you will love Cloisonn: Chinese Enamels From the Yuan, Ming and Qing Dynasties, a ravishing exhibition at the Bard Graduate Center.

title: TimesCast | February 16, 2011
description: As protests spread across the Middle East, the United States delivers a different diplomatic message to its friends and its foes; and Nicholas D. Kristof from Bahrain.

title: A Museum Isnt Rebuilt Every Minute
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn.  This was the most contaminated room, Kathleen Maher said, pointing to powdery debris, paint flakes and glass shards on shelves and carpeting in a dimly lighted ground-floor gallery at her work space. She is curator and executive director at the Barnum Museum here, where last June a tornado struck its 1890s brick building.

title: Fight Club | Danielle Levitts Pride of Lowell
description: The photographer Danielle Levitt has an eye for disaffected youth. Her 2008 monograph We Are Experienced compiled more than 100 portraits of American teenagers taken over several years as Levitt hopscotched across the country shooting features and fashion editorials for Interview, Arena Homme Plus and The New York Times Magazine, among many others. Levitt began her career shooting a street style column for The Wall Street Journal, a natural window onto the downtown scene, and her work has evolved to include werewolves in Texas for Dazed & Confused and sissy bouncers for Arena Homme Plus. This fall, she was sent to Lowell, Mass., to shoot Mickey Ward and Dicky Eklund, the real-life characters behind David O. Russells Oscar-nominated film The Fighter; the magazine assignment turned into a new series of portraits and a collection of short films. Pride of Lowell, curated by Naheed Simjee, will opened on Wednesday at Los Angeless Known Gallery. T caught up with Levitt via e-mail to talk about the show.

title: Taking a Hard Line: Immigrants and Crime
description: After months of internal wrangling and confusion over an ambitious nationwide program allowing state and local police agencies to identify immigrants with criminal records, Obama administration immigration officials have decided to take a hard line against communities that try to delay or cancel their participation in the program, according to documents made public late Wednesday.

title: Dress Code Snaps Back
description: My friend and I work as legal assistants at the same law firm. We both bought jeggings, and wore them to work with long tops. Her boss didnt say anything, but mine told me they were inappropriate for the office, and that I shouldnt wear them again. I dont think thats fair. What do you think?

title: Britain Begins an Overhaul of Welfare
description: LONDON  The British government on Thursday introduced legislation meant to simplify and reduce the cost of the countrys welfare system, saying that it wanted to change a culture in which welfare recipients risked losing income if they found jobs.

title: Backstage Beauty | LWren Scott
description: A dangerous eye  thats what LWren said to me, said the makeup artist Aaron de Mey backstage at LWren Scott. It conjured up images of smokiness. I also love this kid Taylor Momsen very much  its interesting to see how a teenager would apply her makeup. To wit, de Mey created an exaggerated version of the kind of black eye makeup he said Scott herself always wears, which included heaps of Lancome Hypnose Mascara (in black, of course) and black eye shadow layered over pencil for a gothic look. Theres no highlight, no skin showing through, he said. The hairstylist Serge Normant also was inspired by the designer: The way LWren wears things, it doesnt look overly done. The girls arent supposed to look like her, but I wanted that easiness. Hair was brushed into a deep side part with volume added through the crown of the head for a just woke up look, which Normant set with products from his new namesake product line. The manicurist Yuna Park filled out the look with one coat of a gold-flecked black nail polish from Lancome called Noir 29, available this fall. You know you love it. XOXO.

title: On Our Radar: Britain Drops Plan to Sell Forests
description: Conservative Party leaders in Britain abandon a controversial plan to sell off virtually all of the countrys publicly owned forests over the next decade. The proposal, which would have sold off even historic woodlands like the Forest of Dean and Sherwood Forest, generated widespread public outrage that had shown no signs of abating. I am sorry, we got this one wrong, but we have listened to peoples concerns, Environment Secretary Caroline Spelman told the House of Commons. [The Guardian]

title: Castaways, Soldiers and a Good Car Chase
description: The programmers for Film Comment Selects possess the refined tastes of practiced cine-mixologists, along with a yen for the outr. For the 11th edition of this two-week annual festival, which starts on Friday at the Walter Reade Theater, they have exhumed the old and rounded up the new, unearthing treasures and curiosities to put next to recent movies with and without American distribution. This is one event in which you can see the latest from a giant of cinema like Claude Lanzmann and spend the rest of the time with French castaways, two of the fastest fists ever to fly out of China and a gang of British thieves whose whiplashing car chases in Peter Yatess Robbery (1967) anticipate the burning rubber in his next film, Bullitt.
