title: A Benefit to Keep Bartenders Healthy
description: Tipplers can drink to the future health of bartenders on Monday at Salud! Bartenders for Healthcare, a charity cocktail party co-sponsored by the United States Bartenders Guild. The event will be held on the second floor of Freemans, the Bowery-area bar that has produced some of the citys best mixologists. Proceeds will help pay bartenders medical bills.

title: The Band Plays On: An Economic Study
description: Rock stars normally hand out lessons about sex, drugs and trashing hotel rooms. But a battle between a dance-rock outfit, LCD Soundsystem and ticketing agents over the bands last show offers a strange insight into the laws of supply and demand. On top of that, the kerfuffle reveals the distortions underlying the music business.

title: Hoop Dreams Next for Lombardi Producers: A Larry Bird-Magic Johnson Play
description: The producers behind Lombardi, about the storied Green Bay Packers football coach Vince Lombardi, are shifting to basketball for their next Broadway-aimed sports play. Magic/Bird will dramatize the fierce on-court rivalry and friendship between two Hall of Fame stars: Magic Johnson and Larry Bird.

title: Bahrain: A Diplomatic Puzzle
description: Does the unexpected violent crackdown in Bahrain mean the U.S. will change its relationship with its close ally?

title: One Prospect for President Isnt Talking, but France Is
description: PARIS  The latest play to grip France might be called En Attendant D.S.K. Dominique Strauss-Kahn, the managing director of the International Monetary Fund, is absent, like Godot in Samuel Becketts famous play, En Attendant Godot, or Waiting for Godot, making it easier to argue about him.

title: A Wagnerian Quest in Proper English
description: LONDON  The English National Opera introduced the German director Nikolaus Lehnhoffs production of Wagners Parsifal in 1999, and since then this influential modern staging, which presents the Knights of the Grail as a spiritually decaying brotherhood in a bleakly gray, postapocalyptic and timeless setting, has traveled far. It was presented by the San Francisco Opera and the Lyric Opera of Chicago, the stagings co-producers; it played the Baden-Baden Festival in Germany in 2004, where it was filmed for a DVD release; and it had a run at the Gran Teatre del Liceu in Barcelona.

title: In His Own Words, a Singular Mans Double Life
description: The British travel writer and novelist Bruce Chatwin (1940-89) had blond hair, flinty blue eyes and delicately firm features  he looked like a bookish member of the Police, Stings band, circa 1983  and the kind of narcissism that can be a byproduct of talent mixed with charisma.

title: Canada Hit by Cyberattack
description: OTTAWA  A federal cabinet minister said Thursday that hackers, perhaps from China, compromised computers in two Canadian government departments in early January, leaving bureaucrats with little or no Internet access for nearly two months.

title: Classical Mash-Up and Remix
description: The Tune-In festival at the Park Avenue Armory promises to explore musical connections between past and present, as well as a few philosophical notions, like whether music has the power to express anything. (Stravinsky said that it does not; others have disagreed.)

title: A Soft Pop Chanteuse, Striking Delicate Poses
description: Poised and whispery, Vanessa Paradis played her New York City debut as a headliner at Town Hall on Wednesday night. In France, Ms. Paradis has been a pop star since she was 14, when her single Joe le Taxi was a No. 1 hit in 1987, and where she won the Victoires de la Musique award, the equivalent of a Grammy, for album of the year with her 2007 album Divinidylle (Barclay). Outside Europe, she is better known as an actress and model, but she has begun a world tour with her band, coinciding with the American release of her compilation Best Of (Decca).

title: Space for Spices, Gadgets and Guests
description: AT his house in New Rochelle, Reginald Johnson cooked and baked in his dream kitchen, where he used a 60-inch-wide Wolf range to make delicacies like butternut squash ravioli and rosemary-olive-oil cake.

description: In the wake of the financial crisis, politicians, regulators and others slammed Wall Street for handing out supersize pay packages, saying they encouraged excessive risk-taking.

description: New Yorks flamencophiles are deprived of their annual Flamenco Festival this year, thanks to financial cutbacks in Spain. (The hope is to continue it biennially instead.) In its place, however, is a weeklong season of the filmmaker Carlos Sauras Flamenco Hoy (Flamenco Today) at City Center.

description: The Op-Ed columnist Nicholas D. Kristof talked with the family of a physician who was beaten by police after he tried to help injured protesters.

title: Disappearing People, Leaving a Lot of Clothes Behind
description: The something wicked that comes creeping like night in Vanishing on 7th Street, turning down the sun and seemingly sucking people right out of their homes, offices, cars and clothes, arrives without warning. One minute moviegoers are yukking it up at a multiplex in this generally nifty little horror flick, and the next minute theyve disappeared, their emptied-out clothes a spooky reminder of their existence, one that brings to mind the silhouetted shadows left behind after the bombs decimated Hiroshima and Nagasaki.

title: Tooth-and-Claw Life of a Dedicated Single Mother
description: One of the most urgent and certainly among the most beautifully shot documentaries to hit the big screen in recent memory, The Last Lions isnt just another cute and fuzzy encounter session with a different species. Its a pulse-quickening, tear-duct milking and outrageously dramatized story about the threats  wildfires, chomping teeth, stampeding hooves and, worst of all, unseen humans  that face a female lion trying to protect her cubs. Here, single motherhood doesnt mean juggling family, work and PTA meetings: it means parking the tots in the bushes and then trying to take down a water buffalo the size of a jeep.

title: Perfect, With Childbearing Hips
description: SEVERAL years ago I went to the California Cryobanks Web site to buy sperm. I was single and a lesbian and wanted to have a baby. Id always wanted a family and dreamed of creating one with a partner, but Id proved to be a love loser. When it didnt work out with anybody, including my most recent ex (after six years of couples counseling, meditation, acupuncture, hypnosis), I gave up.

title: A Strong Debut for Criminal Spinoff
description: Although a two-hour Hollywood week episode of Foxs American Idol topped the ratings on Wednesday, CBSs new series Criminal Minds: Suspect Behavior, with Janeane Garofalo and Forest Whitaker, delivered a strong debut at 10 p.m. According to Nielsens estimates 12.9 million viewers tuned in to the new procedural spinoff, slightly more than the original Criminal Minds (12.8 million) at 9. The new show outperformed ABCs Off the Map (4.3 million) and NBCs Law & Order: SVU (7.3 million). Fox led over all with Idol from 8 to 10 (22.8 million), CBS was second and saw below-average ratings for its season premiere of Survivor: Redemption Island (11.2 million). ABC placed a distant third and NBC was fourth.

title: Me, My Doppelgnger and a Dunk in the River
description: Liam Neesons latter-day renaissance as an unlikely action star should give hope to performers and viewers of a certain age (i.e., over 40) everywhere. While that irrepressible exhibitionist Helen Mirren, born in 1945, continues to inspire legions of AARP members, one discarded garment at a time, Mr. Neeson, a comparative pup born in 1952, is doing much the same, one hard-swinging fist after another.

title: Kickboxing Express and Other 30-Minute Workouts
description: UNTIL recently, I was convinced that a worthwhile workout meant at least an hour. But my trainer challenged me to consider 20- to 30-minute programs that she promised would push me just as hard as our 60 minutes together. When these high-intensity sessions of jumping rope and other powerful movements became even more strenuous than my longer routines, I was a convert.

title: Time Inc. Chief Executive Jack Griffin Out
description: The chief executive of Time Inc., Jack Griffin, is leaving the company after less than six months on the job  forced out over what company executives said was a widespread sense that his management style was brusque and did not fit the corporate culture there.

title: Joyce Carol Oatess Widows Lament
description: Writing up a storm, eh, Joyce? Shortly after the sudden death of Joyce Carol Oatess husband, Raymond Smith, in February 2008, an acquaintance put that familiar question to her. A closer friend was sure that words were tumbling forth, too. Knowing how you write, the friend said in a condolence note, you may already be completing the first of many novels that will help you explore what youve been experiencing. Oates felt herself shaking with cold, with a kind of choked fury. The Wonder Woman of American Letters, as she learned an exhibitor of her vast array of books had christened her, could not compose even a thank-you note. Yes its true that I used to be a writer  a writer with a very mixed reputation  controversial is the kindest term, she imagined trying to explain at a somewhat calmer moment. But now  I am not a writer now. I am not anything now. Legally I am a widow  that is the box I must check. But beyond that  I am not sure that I exist.

title: Stories of Love and Grief
description: When we speak of literary taste, we may imagine we refer to preferences regarding subject matter, genre, form and the varieties of narrative prowess. But much of what taste in reading boils down to is less conducive to objective analysis, less neatly parceled into scholarly-sounding brackets. Simply, its the extent to which we take pleasure in the company of the author  or rather, a facsimile thereof, a phantom version composed of and subsisting on words alone.

Fielding familiar classroom stereotypes  the bully, the science geek, the strutting alien female in the skintight cat suit  this turgid schedule filler is only marginally more fun than a weeks worth of detention.

So here he is, all the way from St. Petersburg, Russia, the man who put the madcap in madness. Put your hands together for the stand-up stylings of Aksentii Poprishchin.

title: The Chaperone: Wrestling With Laughs
description: Its too bad that Paul Levesque is so, well, large. Mr. Levesque  a professional wrestler whose ring name is Triple H  is a perfectly tolerable actor, as he shows in The Chaperone, a lightweight comedy aimed, presumably, at tweeners and fans of World Wrestling Entertainment, whose film division generated this project. But the guys so outsize that were never likely to see him as anything other than a thug or a gentle giant.

title: Among Egypts Missing, Tales of Torture and Prison
description: CAIRO  Ramadan Aboul Hassan left his house one night about three weeks ago to join a neighborhood watch group with two friends and did not return. The next time their relatives saw the three men they were emerging Wednesday night from a maximum security prison, 400 miles from home, run by Egypts military. Some family members said they bore signs of torture, though others denied it.

description: Loveless is an aimless film about an aimless fellow, but its not without its charms. It may be without a point, but hey, you cant have everything in a no-budget film like this.

description: Vivian Berger and Michael Finkelstein are the sole occupants of the 29th floor at Ariel East on Broadway and 100th Street. They have a 360-degree view from their four-bedroom apartment, and have added built-in shelves for their thousands of books.

title: Been There, Done That, and Now Going to This
description: THE theater critics of The New York Times are not the only ones willing to opine on spring theater highlights. We also polled a random assortment of Tony Award winners and nominees from last season to find out what they are most excited about seeing in the coming months. Here are some of their answers; for more go to nytimes.com/theater. STEVEN McELROY

title: On Long Island, Palin Opens Up and Plays Coy
description: WOODBURY, N.Y.  Sarah Palin did not visit Iowa or New Hampshire on Thursday, and she did not drop by South Carolina or Nevada. But inside a country club ballroom here, as she logged another stop as a paid speaker, she said she could not wait much longer to decide her future.

title: Joe Frazier, Who Managed Mets in Turbulent Time, Is Dead at 88
description: Joe Frazier, the manager of the Mets in the turbulent period between the tenures of Yogi Berra and Joe Torre, died Tuesday in Broken Arrow, Okla. He was 88 and a longtime Broken Arrow resident.

title: Comic Advice: Be Wary on Broadway
description: THE news that Kathy Griffin Wants a Tony!, as her Broadway-bound comedy show is titled, means even more crowding on Broadway this spring. Its hard to remember a season in which more comedians and comic actors decided to give the stage a try, sometimes in roles that arent quite laugh-a-minute. Heres a guide to the new arrivals, with advice from one who got there first: the stand-up comedian Colin Quinn, whose solo show Long Story Short opened on Broadway in November and plays through March 5.

description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla.  Kurt Busch declared himself the favorite for Sundays Daytona 500, and it was hard to argue after he won the first of two 150-mile qualifying races Thursday at Daytona International Speedway.

description: We Are What We Are, Jorge Michel Graus macabre fable of urban survival, follows the disintegration of a pod of people eaters when its diseased patriarch expires in a shopping mall.

title: Cost Overruns Found in Technology for Placement of High School Students
description: For the last several years, the citys Department of Education has boasted about its record of placing students in the high schools of their choice, thanks to a new computerized process. But if the ends were successful, the means were anything but, according to the city comptroller.

title: Zynga Nears Deal Valuing It at Close to $10 Billion

description: OSAKA, Japan  Japan will cut short this years annual whale hunt in the Antarctic Ocean after obstruction by an environmental group largely prevented its ships from killing whales, the government said on Friday.

title: Now & Later Explores Sex and Politics
description: Essentially a two-person play liberally sprinkled with gleaming, groovy, graphic sex, Now & Later exudes an amiably accessible vibe that softens the edges of its freewheeling explicitness.

title: Willie Sutton Wept
description: There are three things you need to know about the current budget debate. First, its essentially fraudulent. Second, most people posing as deficit hawks are faking it. Third, while President Obama hasnt fully avoided the fraudulence, hes less bad than his opponents  and he deserves much more credit for fiscal responsibility than hes getting.

title: In Puerto Rico, Protests End Short Peace at University
description: SAN JUAN, P.R.  Months of unrest at the University of Puerto Rico seemed to be reaching a finale over the last 10 days. Scores of students were arrested or injured by riot police officers. Faculty and staff members held a two-day walkout. The president of the university resigned Friday, the police who had occupied campus were withdrawn Monday and an interim president arrived Tuesday.

Alexander McQueen used the technology for his dramatic Platos Atlantis show in October 2009, and in his final collection of medieval-inspired jacquards before his death a year ago. And during New York Fashion Week, many designers, including Narciso Rodriguez and Joseph Altuzarra, used computerized prints.

Cuomo introduced legislation on Thursday to create an independent commission to redraw the boundaries for Congressional and state legislative districts, promising to end the longstanding Albany practice of protecting incumbent lawmakers through creatively drawn districts.

description: Given the ferment in certain corners of the world, the Manhattan headquarters of the Committee to Protect Journalists seemed surprisingly quiet on Thursday morning. As is often the case, appearances were deceiving.

title: There Wont Be Blood
description: The tree of liberty, goes the Thomas Jefferson maxim, must be refreshed from time to time with the blood of patriots and tyrants. The quote has become a favorite of Tea Party supporters, cited at rallies of pistol-packing partisans.

title: Players and N.F.L. Accept Mediation
description: In an attempt to jump-start negotiations that stalled a week ago, representatives for N.F.L. owners and the leagues players planned to engage in seven consecutive days of talks with a federal mediator beginning Friday.

title: A Breast-Feeding Plan Mixes Partisan Reactions
description: Perhaps it was inevitable that when Michelle Obama proposed something, Michele Bachmann would be the one to criticize her.

title: Population Tipping Point in Texas, as Hispanics Get Closer to Parity With Whites
description: HOUSTON  A phenomenal surge in Hispanics has fueled the population growth in Texas, which gained more people over the last decade than any other state, according to United States Census Bureau figures released on Thursday.

title: Gov. Walkers Pretext
description: In a year when governors across the country are competing to show whos toughest, no matter what the consequences, Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin stands out as the first to bring his State Capitol to a halt.

title: After Shooting, Merchant Is Hero of Arthur Avenue
description: On Arthur Avenue, a group of men piled out of Pasquales Rigoletto restaurant onto the sidewalk to pay their respects to a sudden local hero.

title: Photo Replay: Feb. 17
description: The day in sports, including cricket, skiing, and pitchers and catchers.

title: Looks Like Banks Lose on Risk Plea
description: When the mortgage securitization market collapsed amid a flood of defaults and foreclosures  many of them on loans that should not have been made  the cry arose for lenders to have skin in the game. To properly align incentives, the argument went, those who make loans must suffer if the loan goes bad.

title: Allen Stanford, Indicted Financier, Sues Authorities
description: R. Allen Stanford, the indicted Texas financier, has filed a lawsuit accusing prosecutors, Federal Bureau of Investigation agents and the Securities and Exchange Commission of abusive law enforcement.

title: Now Bahrain
description: King Hamad bin Isa al-Khalifa of Bahrain is the latest autocrat to choose brutality, rather than reform, to try to silence his peoples demands for a more just government. His actions are unconscionable and miss the lessons of Egypt and Tunisia where violence only fed popular anger. Hosni Mubarak and Zine el-Abidine Ben Ali are now gone.

title: Live From a Favorite TV Show: Items Branded With It
description: PRODUCTS bearing the likenesses of television stars  clothing, jewelry, lunch boxes, magnets, cookie jars, even bubble gum  have been popular as long as, well, television. Now, shelves are also filling up with merchandise bearing the names of the channels and networks on which the stars appear.

title: The Thomas Issue
description: When the Supreme Court hears arguments next week, it will mark the fifth anniversary of Justice Clarence Thomass silence during oral argument  unless he chooses to re-enter the give-and-take. We hope he will.

title: As Online Communications Stymie Wiretaps, Lawmakers Debate Solutions
description: WASHINGTON  Leading Democrats on the House Judiciary Committee on Thursday reacted skeptically to the idea of overhauling surveillance laws to make it easier to wiretap people who communicate online rather than by telephone, a major priority for the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: Dispute Over Cancer Tied to Implants
description: When talking to patients about a rare type of cancer linked to breast implants, plastic surgeons should call it a condition and avoid using the words cancer, tumor, disease or malignancy, the president of the American Society of Plastic Surgeons advised members during an online seminar on Feb. 3.

title: Daisy, Daisy
description: The most charming moments from Watson, the I.B.M. computer that clobbered two brilliant human champions on Jeopardy! were when Watson wasnt certain or failed. Those moments did not come often, but virtual humanity seemed most at hand when they did. Then his/her/its wagers on the answers would turn cautious and Watson even flashed question marks of self-doubt, as if to acknowledge the lack of a brow to furrow.

title: Tomorrow Never Comes
description: Jonathan Alter wrote a book about Barack Obamas first year in office called The Promise. Thats a great title because it works on so many levels. For example, over the past four years, Obamas career has been marked by a constant promise: He has continually said he is on the verge of doing something serious abut the national debt.

title: Administration Seeks Clarity From Judge on Health Ruling
description: The Obama administration asked a federal judge on Thursday to clarify whether his recent ruling against the new health care law was meant to block its implementation pending appeals.

title: IPad Service Draws Scrutiny
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Apples new subscription service for iPad and iPhone applications, which has drawn complaints from some publishers, has also drawn the attention of federal antitrust regulators, according to a person with direct knowledge of the matter.

title: House Spending Impasse Raises Risk of Shutdown
description: WASHINGTON  The House speaker, John A. Boehner of Ohio, said Thursday that Republicans would not agree to a short-term extension of the spending measure now financing the federal government without additional cuts, sharply raising the stakes in a war of wills with Democrats that officials say could lead to a government shutdown early next month.

title: Egyptians Say Military Discourages an Open Economy
description: CAIRO  The Egyptian military defends the country, but it also runs day care centers and beach resorts. Its divisions make television sets, jeeps, washing machines, wooden furniture and olive oil, as well as bottled water under a brand reportedly named after a generals daughter, Safi.

title: New York Police Plan to Quit Bank Robbery Task Force
description: The New York Police Department has informed the Federal Bureau of Investigation that it plans to pull all six of its detectives from a joint task force that investigates armed bank robberies, according to law enforcement officials with knowledge of the plan.

title: Planned Parenthood Financing Is Caught in Budget Feud
description: Almost unnoticed in the wars over the federal budget has been a pitched battle over money for Planned Parenthood, which provides contraception, medical services and abortions at 800 clinics around the country.

title: Hastily Composed
description: Montgomery, Ala., Feb. 18, 1861

title: At a Food Co-op, a Discordant Thought: Nannies Covering Shifts
description: The Park Slope Food Coop, in Brooklyn, is known for its rules: organic and nonorganic products must not touch; long vegetables must be displayed lying parallel to the aisles.

title: Penalty for New York City Principals Who Save
description: Sari Latto, the principal of P.S. 41 in Bayside, Queens, is thinking of buying some new lunchroom tables and extra paper for her classrooms. Joseph Lisa, the principal of Intermediate School 61 in Corona, would not mind new curtains in the auditorium or extra laptop computers for his 2,200 students.

title: Lottery Numbers
China Assails New U.S. Policy on Internet Freedom
description: BEIJING  The Chinese Foreign Ministry on Thursday criticized  a new Obama administration policy on Internet freedom, saying it was an attempt to meddle in the internal affairs of other countries.

title: Santanas Return Is Still Months Away
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Johan Santana has been throwing a baseball for almost two weeks, but the next time he throws a pitch in a major league game could be more than four months from now, perhaps sometime close to the All-Star break.

title: Madagascar: Ex-President to Return
description: The deposed president Marc Ravalomanana, left, living in exile since March 2009, announced Thursday that he would return to his island nation on Saturday even though the current government threatens to jail him. Speaking to reporters in Johannesburg, he repeatedly sidestepped questions about his possible arrest and the risk that his presence could incite civil war. I will bring peaceful dialogue, he insisted. Mr. Ravalomanana, twice elected Madagascars president, was ousted by a military-backed coup and then convicted in absentia on murder charges resulting from the killing of protesters by the presidential guard.

title: Suit Suggests Political Party Knew of Fraud
description: The Independence Party may have helped a Republican political consultant cover up a scheme to steal more than $1 million from Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg during his 2009 re-election bid, the Manhattan district attorneys office alleged in court filings released on Thursday.

title: Friday: Handmade Things
description: FRIDAYS PUZZLE  So many good entries, so little time.

title: Plenty of Fish, One Web Site
description: 12:46 p.m. | Updated There may be plenty of fish in the sea, as the saying goes, but when it comes to dating Web sites that are integrated into music video clips, there appears to be only one.

title: The Young Girl Pulls the Strings in This Relationship
description: Only a performer of monumental presence can withstand the theatrical typhoon that is Mandy Patinkin. So hats off to the frail-looking, child-size marionette who walks away with Compulsion, the straight-line bio-drama by Rinne Groff, starring Mr. Patinkin at gale force.

title: In a Field of Reason, Lawyers Woo Luck Too
description: Day after too many days, the defense lawyer Murray Richman went to the same restaurant for lunch, ordering the same meal as he had the day before: a Mayan sun salad with a sauted filet of salmon.

title: Scorecard | Proenza Schouler Wins!
description: On the penultimate day of New York fashion week, Americas stealth luxury master Michael Kors was in a reflective mood as he rang in the big 3-0, and other designers too took the opportunity to brush up on their fashion history. Oscar de la Renta looked back to his own 60s archives for a glamorous collection for Park Avenue princesses that was OTT, even by ODLR standards. Meanwhile, Scorecard knows critics felt the Proenza Schouler mavericks showed true grit with their pixelated Navajo prints. Thats how the West Village was won.

description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.

description: James Warren is a columnist for the Chicago News Cooperative.

title: Lawyer Turns From Jon Burge to Another Form of Injustice
description: Over 13 years, Joey Mogul has gained a reputation as being aggressive. A Chicago lawyer, she has focused attention on the plight of inmates who said the Chicago police tortured them into confessions.

title: For Notre Dames Hansbrough, Competitiveness Is a Family Trait
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind.  Every Sunday after church, on the Hansbroughs backyard basketball court in Poplar Bluff, Mo., three brothers would play the age-old game of 21. The scene conjures up both Rockwell and Darwin  little Ben Hansbrough, the youngest, learned to survive despite a weekly diet of blocked shots and sharp elbows.

title: After Stagnant 12 Months, N.B.A. Faces Its Own Labor Countdown
description: Before they can celebrate Derrick Roses ascendance, Kevin Durants dominance or Blake Griffins hang time, the N.B.A.s brightest minds and brightest players will gather in a hotel conference room and beg one another not to ruin it all.

description: The remaining games are starting to dwindle, and teams on the playoff bubble, like the Rangers and the Los Angeles Kings, are playing increasingly desperate hockey.

description: Curtis Mitchell, a fourth-generation contractor, was once in the business of building things. His company constructed some of San Franciscos most familiar public-works projects, including the Fourth Street Bridge near AT&T Park and most of the Third Street light-rail project.

title: Two Pitching Stars From the Past Hope for a Future in Pinstripes
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Freddy Garcia dipped into his memory bank the other morning, his mind drifting to a Seattle special of an afternoon, cool and overcast, during the 2001 playoffs, when he was the 25-year-old ace of the Mariners. Garcia recalled how Bartolo Colon pumped fastball after fastball past his Seattle teammates to secure the division series opener for the Cleveland Indians.

title: In Napa, Where the Downturn Is Measured Glass by Glass
description: Scott James is a columnist for The Bay Citizen.

title: State Keeps Pressing for Waiver to Change Medicaid, but Success Is Unlikely
description: Just a few months ago, Gov. Rick Perry led a group of Texas lawmakers who were threatening to drop out of Medicaid, the state-federal health care program for the poor. A state analysis showing that Texas would lose billions of dollars in financing put an end to talk of opting out.

title: Small Brewers Want to Tap Into a Little of the Action
description: If you want to sample Scott Metzgers Old Bat Rastard brew, you will have to travel to San Antonio, sit down at his pub, Freetail Brewing Company, and order a frothy glass from the tap or ask for a half-gallon growler to go.

description: Ross Ramsey, the managing editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column.

description: Eadweard Muybridge might have been born and raised in England, but at heart he belongs to the Bay Area.

title: Commission Is Set to Vote on Research of Taser Use
description: The San Francisco Police Department may be one step closer to getting Tasers.

title: China: Deal With Russia Denied
description: The Chinese Foreign Ministry on Thursday denied a report that Chinese and Russian companies had agreed to start a joint venture in islands that are disputed by Russia and Japan. Kyodo News, a Japanese news agency, had reported that the companies intended to farm sea cucumbers, a delicacy among Chinese, on one of four islands near the northeast coast of Hokkaido, Japan. Russia has reportedly invited enterprises from other countries to invest in businesses there, but so far there has been no third-party investment. The issue regarding the four northern islands is a bilateral issue between Russia and Japan, and we hope the two sides will properly handle the issue through talks, said Ma Zhaoxu, a Foreign Ministry spokesman, according to official Chinese news reports.

title: Tucson Firefighter Refused to Respond
description: PHOENIX  A Tucson firefighter refused to respond to the Jan. 8 shooting rampage that wounded Representative Gabrielle Giffords because of political differences with his crew, delaying his units arrival at the scene, according to internal department records.

title: Chinas Soft Prohibition
description: Officially, Chen Guangcheng, one of the Chinas most high-profile human rights defenders, is a free man. Unofficially, he has become a prisoner in his own home.

title: For Hockey, a Landscape That Now Includes Palm Trees
description: For some American hockey players at the highest level, memories of childhood are filled with idyllic days on frozen ponds and outdoor rinks.

title: Chinas Intimidation of Dissidents Said to Persist After Prison
description: DONGSHIGU, China  Chen Guangcheng is officially a free man, but it is hard to imagine a life more constrained. One of the countrys most prominent rights defenders, Mr. Chen is confined to his home 24 hours a day by security agents and hired peasant men armed with sticks, bricks and walkie-talkies. Visitors who try to see him are physically repulsed and sometimes beaten. Blinding floodlights illuminate his stone farmhouse at night.

description: BUSINESS

title: Len Lesser, Uncle Leo on Seinfeld, Dies at 88
description: Len Lesser, a character actor for more than half a century whose hawklike profile and Noo Yawk accent finally gained him popular recognition when he played Jerry Seinfelds annoying Uncle Leo on Seinfeld, died on Wednesday in Burbank Calif. He was 88.

title: John Strauss, Composer of Car 54 Theme, Dies at 90

title: Va-Va-Voom Goes the Soprano
description: LONDON  An opera about Anna Nicole Smith: the American sex symbol, Playboy Playmate, hapless model, laughable actress and fortune-hunting wife of a billionaire nearly 63 years her senior? Commissioned by, no less, the Royal Opera House, Covent Garden? When the plans were announced, it sounded like a dubious idea, a tawdry way for a major opera house to look hip.

title: Squashing the Ivies
description: One day in 1996, Trinity Colleges new president, Evan Dobelle, called the mens squash coach into his office. Dobelle was an unconventional hire. He didnt complete his bachelors degree until he was 39, working in politics  mayor of Pittsfield, Mass., aide to President Carter, treasurer of the Democratic National Committee  then running first one, then another community college. But Trinity was a troubled institution, and the trustees werent looking for another tweedy scholar. Enrollment was down even as the liberal-arts school was accepting 65 percent of all applicants  a striking contrast to its rivals Amherst and Williams, which typically admit fewer than 20 percent of their applicant pools. The biggest problem was Trinitys immediate surroundings, the crime-ridden, blighted neighborhood of Frog Hollow in Hartford. So Dobelle started an ambitious $225 million public-private urban-renewal project to improve the area  including the construction of three schools and a performing-arts center  without pushing its residents out. Then he turned to the colleges sports programs, wondering if there might not be a quicker way to improve Trinitys brand.

title: The Many Faces of Ugandas Elections
description: When Todd Heisler, a staff photographer for The Times, arrived in Kampala, Uganda, on Monday to cover the countrys elections, he didnt have to look far to find the candidates.

description: reprove \ri-prv\ verb

title: Internet Use in Bahrain Restricted, Data Shows
description: As protests have erupted in Bahrain over the last several days, the government has severely restricted the access of its citizens to the Internet, new data from an organization that monitors Internet traffic strongly suggests.

title: U.S. Tries to Head Off Vote Against Israeli Settlements
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration was trying Thursday evening to head off an imminent vote in the United Nations Security Council that would declare Israels settlement construction in the West Bank illegal, but would not declare publicly whether it was prepared to veto the resolution.

title: Argentina: U.S. Intended to Respect Argentine Law
description: The United States responded Thursday to the seizure by Argentina last week of American military equipment, saying it had approached a planned joint police-training program with a clear commitment to respect applicable Argentine law. The diplomatic rift escalated Wednesday when Argentinas cabinet chief, Anibal Fernandez, demanded an apology from the United States for what he called insults against his countrys foreign minister. Argentine officials had accused the United States of illegally trying to bring in guns, spying equipment and drugs under the guise of a training program for Argentine federal police. Mr. Fernandez suggested Wednesday that the equipment might be destroyed in accordance with Argentine customs regulations.

title: A Big Absence: No Reggie Miller on the Halls List
description: When the Naismith Memorial Basketball Hall of Fame announces its finalists for the class of 2011 on Friday, one name will be conspicuous in its absence: that of Reggie Miller, the former Indiana Pacers sharpshooter, who is in his first year of eligibility.

title: Security Forces in Bahrain Open Fire on Protesters
description: MANAMA, Bahrain  At exactly 5:18 p.m. Friday, the pro-democracy demonstrators, mostly young men, came to a fork in the road. Turn right, and they would head to a hospital that has cared for protesters. Turn left, and into Pearl Square, the symbolic center of the nation, where the army was waiting.

title: Clashes in Libya Worsen as Army Crushes Dissent
description: CAIRO  Thousands gathered Friday for a third day of violent demonstrations in Benghazi, Libyas second-largest city, in an unprecedented challenge to the mercurial 41-year reign of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi. Human rights groups said 24 people had been killed across the North African country, though activists say the count may be far higher.

title: Battle Lines Harden Across the Mideast as Rulers Dig In
description: Security forces and government supporters attacked protesters on Friday  using tear gas, batons, shotguns and grenades  in pitched street battles in Libya, Bahrain and Yemen.

title: The Big Chill: Huawei Imbroglio Puts Countries at Odds
description: A move by the United States to block the Chinese company Huawei Technologies from buying 3Leaf Systems shows that sometimes an acquisition is more than just an acquisition. This one is part of a wider standoff between Washington and Beijing that may have a chilling effect on cross-border deals.

title: Test Yourself | History, Feb. 18, 2011
description: Test your knowledge of history with todays question about two major events in astronomical history.

title: Uganda Carries Out Its Elections in Largely Peaceful Fashion
description: KAMPALA, Uganda  The ballot looked like a rebus puzzle, with pictures of a bicycle, a boom box, a key, a soccer ball, a yellow rose, a giraffe, a hoe  all colorful symbols for Ugandas various political parties. Moses Kibwami, a carpenter and the father of 12, stood there in his swamp boots on Friday morning, cast a quick look over them and then stamped his thumb onto the paper.

title: What Are Your Favorite Games?
description: The Toy Fair is in full swing in New York City, a big event in which manufacturers unveil new and soon-to-be-released toys and games. Do you play games now? Did you play when you were younger? What are some of your favorites?

description: 12:09 p.m. | Updated  to enable comments, correcting a technical problem.

title: James Franco, Artist, Surfaces in Berlin
description: It might seem like the actor James Franco is everywhere these days. He is a co-host  and a nominee  at this years Academy Awards. He may soon appear on Broadway opposite Nicole Kidman. Hes a partner at a secret bar in Los Angeles. And his artwork  yes, hes also an artist  is currently appearing at two Berlin galleries.

title: China Upholds Conviction of American Geologist
description: BEIJING  In a case that has prompted a number of appeals from the White House, a Chinese court on Friday upheld the conviction of an American oil geologist sentenced to eight years in prison on charges of industrial espionage.

title: Responding to Readers on Staying Connected Overseas
description: Thanks for all of the useful comments to my recent post on staying connected overseas  with special thanks to the several of you who took time from your international travels to write in. (Many people wrote directly to me instead of posting.)

title: How Bad Could Upshaw Have Been?
description: Look, Gene Upshaw was a friend of mine, but he was no labor leader, and he wasnt going to be one if he lived to be 3,000. He just wasnt. Unfortunately, the players have done this time and again. They have looked for leadership among ex-players like Upshaw and never into the regular trade-union movement.  Marvin Miller, the former head of the baseball players union, to Terence Moore in an article Wednesday in FanHouse.

title: Yemen Protesters Face Off for 8th Day
description: SANA, Yemen  Pro-government demonstrators armed with sticks ran down rivals calling for the ouster of President Ali Abdullah Saleh on Friday in the capital, breaking up the show of dissent as the countrys turmoil went into an eighth day.

title: Tesla Co-Founder Sizes Up President Obamas E.V. Pledge
description: In his State of the Union address last month, President Obama renewed his campaign pledge to put one million plug-in hybrid and electric vehicles into service in America by 2015. Tesla Motors has contributed about 1,500 cars to the bottom line, but Marc Tarpenning, the companys co-founder, says he believes the presidents promise could be half-baked.

title: Complaint Box | The Running of the Dogs
description: I dont mind admitting that I can be afraid of dogs  can be, rather than am, because it depends on their size and bark. But theres a reason the New York City Department of Parks and Recreation requires that dogs in parks be leashed between 9 a.m. and 9 p.m., except in dog runs, and theres a reason it regulates their behavior even in designated off-leash areas before and after those hours. Dogs are welcome at urban parks, but the parks are primarily for people, and while the vast majority of dogs are domesticated, acts of aggression by roaming dogs are, unfortunately, not uncommon.

title: Actually Its 787 Words
description: But its nice that Atrios likes todays column  especially because getting it down to length (4830 characters including spaces  word counts are unreliable) was a real struggle; this one really wanted to be about 25% longer.

title: Is Fashion Week Smoking?
description: As I reported in Thursdays Times, many residents of the neighborhood around Lincoln Center are less than thrilled with what Fashion Week has wrought: the noise and smell of diesel generators powering the tents for the runway shows.

title: Mervyn King Greenspans Himself
description: Ed Balls is right: Mervyn King, governor of the Bank of England, has stepped way over the line by turning into a cheerleader for the current governments policies. Hes wrong on the economics  front-loaded spending cuts are the wrong policy for a still-depressed economy  but thats not the key point; rather, the point is that if youre going to have an independent central bank, the people running that bank have to be careful to stay above the political fray.

description: On a Facebook page, the former Jets quarterback Ray Lucas is sharing the agony of trying to kick a painkiller addiction.

description: The mining giant Anglo American said Friday that it had agreed with the French cement maker Lafarge to combine their British building materials divisions in a joint venture.

description: President Obama and his political rivals in Washington have jumped into the epic battle in Wisconsin between organized labor and the states newly elected Republican governor over the rights and benefits of state workers.

title: The Billion Price Index
description: Some commenters have been claiming that the MIT Billion Price Index is telling a very different story from the official Consumer Price Index. So I guess its worth pointing out that it really matches pretty well.

title: This Weekends Top Soccer Matchups
description: Saturday

title: Ask the Carpetbagger
description: Borrowing on our grand tradition of gambits when we run out of things to write about, the Bagger would now like to go the crowd-sourcing route. What would you, dear readers, like to know about? One commenter has written asking for an interview with an Oscar-nominated costume designer; were working on it! What else do you have lingering questions about (that our film critic colleagues A.O. Scott and Manohla Dargis, cant answer)? As we wrote last year (look, were too drained to even produce new copy!), the Bagger is open to any and all reasonable queries and will gladly use the power of having The New York Times as a last name to get your questions answered. Leave them in the comments below or e-mail us at carpetbagger@nytimes.com.

title: Morning Buzz | Bloombergs Good News
description: The warmest day of the year so far, with the temperature reaching 63 degrees, but cloudy skies. Dont pack your coats yet, though; winter weather is on its way back. Clouds and wind to continue through the weekend.

title: Swede Spot
description: Our love for all things Swedish knows no bounds. Would that we could have a Little Stockholm right here in New York, a neighborhood whered snap up our favorite Scandanavian duds (and meatballs). So imagine our excitement when we found out that the Swedish label Our Legacy has built a temporary corner shop at Odin that will be open throughout spring. Its the largest selection of Our Legacy wares outside of Sweden, including a sizable pick from their latest collection, Observations. A one-stop spot for an entire wardrobe, the store sells eminently wearable pieces  go-anywhere tees, soft plaid Oxfords, lightly structured blazers, no-fuss pants  designed to be layered and assembled into an outfit as easily as an Ikea bookcase.

title: New Radiohead Album Arrives Early
description: Radiohead has released its new album a day earlier than expected. On Monday the band said that the album, The King of Limbs, would be available for download on Saturday  for fixed prices, unlike the widely noted name-your-own-price experiment of its last record. But on Friday morning Radiohead said in a statement that with everything ready on their website, the band decided to bring forward the release rather than wait until the previously announced date. A video for the first single, Lotus Flower, is also available and can be seen above.

title: Feb. 18: Updates on Middle East Protests
description: On Friday, The Lede continues to follow protest movements in Bahrain, Libya, Yemen, Iran, Iraq and Egypt. Updates below mix alerts on breaking news with reports from bloggers and journalists on the ground. A stream of Twitter messages on the protests is in this blogs right column.

title: Friday Reading: Retraining Your Spouse
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: Why Does College Cost So Much?
description: Robert B. Archibald and David H. Feldman are economists at the College of William & Mary, a public university in Virginia, and the authors of Why Does College Cost So Much? If you want the brief version, you could look at an op-ed article by the two economists for Inside Higher Ed or a summary of the book compiled by the University of Washington. The professors also talked about the book in this short video.

title: DuPont Extends $5.7 Billion Offer for Danisco
description: Daniscos headquarters in Copenhagen.

title: VIDEO: Republicans Accuse Liberals of Hateful Rhetoric in Wisconsin
description: The Republican Party of Wisconsin has produced a striking web video highlighting the angry rhetoric coming from the pro-union protesters in Madison.

title: Pawlenty Scores Keynote at Tea Party Summit
description: Tim Pawlenty, the former governor of Minnesota, has scored a 2012 coup of sorts: He will be the keynote speaker at the first Tea Party Policy Summit in Arizona this month.

title: A Month of Catherine Deneuve at Brooklyn Academy
description: 10:22 a.m. | Updated

title: Home Connections
description: Deploying with the military used to mean losing touch with family and friends. But with advances in technology, troops in combat zones can now communicate with home nearly 24/7.

title: Forecast-Beating Profits Sustain a Market Rally
description: Stocks advanced Friday, giving the Standard & Poors 500-stock index its third consecutive weekly rally, as higher-than-estimated corporate earnings overshadowed the Chinese central banks attempts to control inflation.

title: Ba-Gl
description: Portmanteau in South Korea for those who are baby-faced and glamorous. (Ba-Gl is pronounced bagel.)

title: Passport to Beauty
description: As plastic surgery has exploded, niche markets have sprouted among New York's immigrant groups.

title: Case Study | Mull This
description: Ive never had a particularly great rapport with mulled wine, that staple of ski slopes and Christmas markets throughout Northern Europe. In theory it should be a tremendously restorative, literally heartwarming (one tries to avoid the reference to Gemtlichkeit) tonic from the alpine quiver, carried to table preferably by a St. Bernard. In reality, however, I couldnt count how many frankly off-putting mulled wines Ive choked down slopeside over the years: harsh reds gussied up with a load of sugar and overwhelming spices to cover their unpalatable edge, then cooked, which only intensifies the jangle. Nein, danke.

title: Ethnic Differences Emerge in Plastic Surgery
description: At a plastic surgery clinic in Upper Manhattan that caters to Dominicans, one of the most popular procedures is an operation to lift womens buttocks, because  as the doctor explains  they all like the curve.

title: BYD Is the First Ripple in a Potential Chinese Wave
description: GLENDALE, Calif.

title: A Health Insurance Insider Offers Words of Advice
description: WENDELL POTTER is a 20-year health insurance veteran who served in top public relations jobs at such firms as Cigna and Humana. Now a senior analyst at the Center for Public Integrity, Mr. Potter has written Deadly Spin, a tell-all about practices of the health insurance industry. The book chronicles insurers attempts to influence legislators, policy makers and the public, as well as his own change of heart about his work.

title: Obamas Dinner in the Valley
description: Pete Souza/European Pressphoto Agency President Obama with Mark Zuckerberg of Facebook at the home of John Doerr in Woodside, Calif.

title: After Dizzying Debut, a Blue Jays Catcher Is Ready for More
description: DUNEDIN, Fla.

title: BYD F3DM
description: The BYD F3DM is bland enough to completely escape the notice of fellow drivers.

title: Egyptians in America Ponder a Return
description: LOS ANGELES  This week, Khaled Abou El Fadl has greeted each fellow Egyptian he sees with one word: Mabrook, or congratulations.

title: Photos of the Moment | Calvin Klein
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#323", 592, 440, true, chameleonData);

title: Cocktails Where the Stars Once Lounged
description: Where Valentino once ate cafeteria food, film buffs can now dine on lobster Thermidor.

title: Where Are the Chinese Cars?
description: CHINESE goods, from textiles to tools to toys, have been flooding into America for years. But despite their repeated promises, Chinese automakers havent begun to make a dent in the car market in the United States.

title: New Wrinkle in Hybrid Cars
description: WITH the electrification of the automobile gaining momentum each day, a dizzying variety of hybrid, plug-in hybrid and pure electric drive systems are heading to market in coming years.

title: Pets Help Sell Manhattan Apartments
description: JON LIGHTMAN and Judy Batalion never learned the name of the sociable beige cat in attendance when they checked out a seventh-floor loft in north Chelsea last fall. But the couple fell for him hard.

title: Local, Organic Milk: Nice Idea, but Try Making a Profit
description: EDMUNDS, Me.  Perched on the rocky coast of far eastern Maine, the farm owned by Aaron Bell and Carly DelSignore is stunning, both in its views of Cobscook Bay and in the distance that the milk they sell must travel to get on the shelves.

title: Rear-Suspension Problem Prompts Recall of 44,000 Cadillac CTS Models
description: General Motors is recalling about 44,000 Cadillac CTS models from 2009-10 after deciding a rear-suspension problem could cause the driver to lose control.

title: What Were Reading
description: Wallet Pop: Controversy erupts when the Center for Science in the Public Interest says that a caramel coloring found in sodas might cause cancer.  Jeff Gordinier

title: Nascars Changes Spice Up Spectating
description: THE Daytona 500 is to be run for the 53rd time on Sunday, and the 10th time since Dale Earnhardt was killed in a final-lap accident on Feb. 18, 2001, stunning even those who hardly knew what a stock car was.

title: A Red Scare
description: Whoa! That is definitely not poison oak, Dr. Walter Larsen blurted as he entered the exam room in his Portland, Ore., office. The patient smiled ruefully. I told you, she said to the doctor. The 56-year-old woman had seen Larsen that Tuesday, two days earlier. Then she was concerned; now she was scared. She looked down at her hands and arms. Her fair skin was nearly hidden by vicious-looking streaks of red. And its everywhere. She lowered the office gown to reveal scarlet lines crisscrossing up her arms, across her neck, down her back, chest and abdomen. Larsen leaned in close to get a better look at the patients red-streaked skin. He didnt know what this rash was, but it sure had become a lot uglier in just a couple of days.

title: Tel Aviv Broadcast
description: Its just after midnight on Saturday, and Ive been watching images from the protests in Egypt for hours. The TV is on mute, but the raging faces of Cairo are deafening. I dont want my son to wake up, and so I turn off the TV and sit down at my computer. My soccer team, Maccabi Petah Tikva, played Ashdod earlier today, and I surf over to Israels largest news portal to check the score. On the home page, above the headline reporting Petah Tikvas solid 3-1 victory, the following item appears: Palestinian killed in Samaria yesterday. Watch video footage.

title: This Aint Weird Al
description: The novelty song used to be popular, but it has never, ever been cool. Whether it was Allan Sherman making his 1963 hit Hello Mudduh! Hello Fadduh! or Weird Al Yankovic parodying Michael Jackson with Eat It in 1984, the comedian who made singalong spoofs was like the hip stand-up comics embarrassing country cousin. There were exceptions, of course, like the cerebral, political Tom Lehrer  but lets just say that, in general, Lenny Bruce and George Carlin did not sing. The novelty song was an outlet for nerds, morning-show shock jocks and the kind of guys who put the word weird in front of their names. This might help explain why the era of the novelty song seemed to end right around the time that hip-hop came of age: the greatness of Weird Als Straight Outta Lynwood notwithstanding, the average funny-song singer was not cut out to spoof N.W.A.

title: Hollywood Property Values
description: The Social Network poses this question: Did Facebooks founder Mark Zuckerberg steal the idea for the site from Harvard classmates? My row at a Writers Guild screening of The Social Network posed this one: Isnt it a little rich to examine that issue in a Hollywood movie, the product of an industry often portrayed as a snake pit, where one snake is apt to swipe the work of another? Isnt it even richer now that the movie has garnered eight Oscar nominations?

title: Magic and Loss
description: It has been more than 20 years since Tim Berners-Lee first proposed the World Wide Web as a shared system of hypertext that would give almost anyone access to the resources of the Internet. Nearly two billion people now surf the Web. They join up around the world from cellphones, fancy tablets, slender laptops and bulky desktops.

title: Exit Interview
description: You resigned as the No. 2 at WikiLeaks in September, and you write in your new book, Inside WikiLeaks: My Time With Julian Assange at the Worlds Most Dangerous Website, that you might resort to violence if you saw WikiLeakss founder, Julian Assange, in person again. Of all the awful things you describe him doing, what was the most hurtful?  He said he would destroy me, and he would hunt me down and kill me if I would endanger a source, although I never gave him reason to suspect I would. He also threatened to have me locked up.

title: Celebrating Its Pony-Car Success, Camaro Goes Topless
description: TESTED Chevrolet Camaro convertible.

title: Vegetable Hash for an Easy Dinner
description: Often families serve meat hash dishes as a way to reinvent leftovers. But in this weeks Recipes for Health, Martha Rose Shulman creates five new hash recipes loaded with vegetables and flavor, inspired by the beef hashes she remembers from her childhood.

title: SXSW Says It Is Disappointed by Absence of Female Comedians
description: Whether or not you agree that comedy is a male-dominated field, it is hardly an industry with a male-to-female ratio of 30-to-1. Yet that was the gender breakdown on the initial lineup of performers announced for SXSW Comedy, a long-running component of the annual South by Southwest festival in Austin. Of the 31 comedians in this years lineup, including notable funnymen like Michael Ian Black, Thomas Lennon, Donald Glover and John Oliver, only one  Tig Notaro  is a woman.

title: A Home for Two Households
description: THE journey that brought Vivian Berger and Michael Finkelstein to their spectacular aerie on the Upper West Side started more than a decade ago, with what might or might not have been a date.

title: A Blog for the Sixth Borough
description: ON THE SCREEN Blogs that cover niche topics usually appeal to niche audiences. In this city, where there are more bloggers per square mile than perhaps anywhere else in the world, highly specialized blogs create zealously exclusive communities around topics as diverse as cupcakes (Cupcakes Take the Cake) and fixed-gear bicycle freestyling (Prolly Is Not Probably).

title: G20 Leaders Voice Worry on Trade
description: PARIS  With the worlds economies moving at two different speeds, fast-growing developing countries are luring money at a pace that, if left unchecked, could set the stage for future problems, the Federal Reserve chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, said Friday.

title: Chevrolet Camaro Convertible
description: The new convertible is a welcome addition to the Camaro line.

title: A Promising Space-to-Price Ratio
description: WHEN Xian Edwards began house-hunting over a year ago, he was looking for something not easy to come by in New York City: space, and lots of it.

title: Living In | Williamsbridge, the Bronx
description: A north Bronx neighborhood  not to be confused with Williamsburg, Brooklyn  is dominated by single- to three-family homes, few of them more than 50 or 60 years old.

title: Backstage Beauty | Post-Shows Glow
description: During fashion week, top skin specialists are called in to bring a slight calm to the chaos backstage. This time around, for example, Nude Skincare celebrated its second season working with Victoria Bartlett at VPL; Sunday Riley revived the faces of Jason Wus models; Skyn Icelands stress squad went backstage at Elise Overland; and Vermonts Tata Harper was responsible for the glowing skin at Porter Grey and Bodkin. For a similar post-Fashion Week luster, consider the places and products listed below  on or off the runway, we all need a little pick-me-up right about now.

title: Pizza With No Sauce, but With Plenty of Flavor
description: When making pizza at home, Ive taken to dividing the dough in half and making two smaller pies with different toppings, one with tomato and one without. Usually, the one without is just drizzled with olive oil and sprinkled with coarse salt and an herb like rosemary. It comes out cracker-crisp in the middle, with great big bubbles and a nice rim of puffier crust at the perimeter. It tastes like focaccia; because of its crispness, however, it eats like pizza. My wife, Jackie, and I generally wolf it down in the kitchen while waiting upon the tomato/mozzarella/whatever pizza, which takes longer to bake.

title: A Backstage Oscars Pass From ABC
description: LOS ANGELES ABC, working feverishly to improve the digital components of this years Oscar telecast, unveiled a backstage pass app on Friday for iPad, iPhone and iPod touch users. Ho-hum, you say, another app. Were worn out with app mania too, but this one is notable partly because it is designed to be used while you are also watching the show.

title: Wisconsin Bill in Limbo as G.O.P. Seeks Quorum
description: MADISON, Wis.  The fight over a bill to slash collective bargaining for Wisconsins public workers came to a standstill on Friday, as Democratic state senators refused to appear at the Capitol, members of the State Assembly delayed a vote until next week and thousands of protesters, their numbers still growing, marched, screamed, sang and sat.

title: An Organic Milk Experiment in Maine
description: Struggling dairy farmers in Maine are trying a new tactic to become profitable.

title: House Set to Approve Cuts; Time Short to Stop Shutdown
description: WASHINGTON  House Republicans on Friday marched confidently toward approving the largest spending cuts in modern history, setting the stage for a standoff with Senate Democrats and the White House that each side has warned could lead to a shutdown of the federal government early next month.

title: Government Crackdown in Bahrain
description: Mourners buried those killed in violent clashes between antigovernment protesters and security forces, as the government hardened its stance against the demonstrations.

title: Parents Seeking Danger
description: After the 60 Minutes correspondent Lara Logan was brutally attacked in Cairo, one Web site asked today whether she was a bad mother for being on the scene in the first place.

title: Further Reading on Genetic Engineering and Food
description: I could probably read about G.E. for the rest of my life and still not grasp the full picture, but I sure know more than I did a couple of weeks ago. Here are some of the most interesting articles I read in researching this weeks column.

title: Winter, Fading
Rookies Strong Season Makes Islanders Look Smart
description: UNIONDALE, N.Y.  Michael Grabner, a speedy right wing for the Islanders, has done so well lately, scoring almost at will for a team on a roll, that he does not want to talk much about the most difficult three months of his brief N.H.L. career.

title: Geometry On Your Arm
description: ThreeASFOUR  the science-obsessed label designed by Adi Gil, Gabriel Asfour and Angela Donhouser is synonymous with geometric bags. It all started when Adi dreamt of the bag, says Asfour, referring to the labels kidney-shaped bag. Adds Donhouser, The kidney reflects our fascination with human anatomy. To celebrate its new e-commerce site, which goes live tomorrow, threeASFOUR is issuing the bag in two styles  a metal chain link version ($666) in black or pale gold snakeskin leather, and a split cell variety ($555) in bone or black canvas or leather. They join its perennially popular circle bag ($555). Available at planetofstyle.com.

title: Week in Pictures, Feb. 18
description: Photographs from the past week in New York City and the region.

title: Once on This Island
description: Who could love a rat? And what could possess a man to sail to an uninhabited island, in defiance of law, and throw out vitamin K pellets as an antidote to a government-sponsored rat-poisoning program? Therapists and law-enforcement officers might come up blank on that one, but no motive is beyond the grasp of an imaginative fiction writer. In his new novel, When the Killings Done, T. Coraghessan Boyle proves his mettle by grafting a page from the strange-crime annals into a life-and-death story of evolution, shipwrecks and dominion over the earth.

title: Deal With the Devil
description: In the decades since her death in 1979, Elizabeth Bishop has been recognized as an American original, as much ours and not ours as Whitman, Dickinson and that transplanted Yankee Robert Frost. A readers appetite for the lives of beloved poets can be hard to satisfy. Their mortgages are subject to scholarly study, their medical records sold in shadowy alleys, their childhood friends dunned to offer up nuggets of gossip. We would read their shopping lists if we could  such things make them more human, and therefore slightly inhuman, since how is it possible that the authors of Leaves of Grass or Because I Could Not Stop for Death or North of Boston could have needed new stockings, and hair oil, and cornflakes?

title: New Visual Books
description: Images from books reviewed in Steven Hellers column.

title: Irreverence You Can Almost Touch
description: I recently subscribed to a well-known magazine that offers an interactive digital edition for my iPad. I was utterly disappointed. As a magazine geek for many decades, I looked forward to complaining about how nothing is better than turning real pages, smelling real ink and caressing real paper. But sadly, I have finally come to recognize that after all that turning, smelling and caressing, what remains are piles of old magazines collecting dust. The new digital version may seem less substantial, but it doesnt have those annoying loose subscription cards or peel-and-sniff perfume ads that induce headaches (and depressing sensory memories). Whats more, I dont have to tie up digital magazines for disposal on recycling day. So I canceled all but one print subscription, and now I get my periodical enjoyment from an iPad. Which is actually why I am pleased to see new books devoted to printed magazines. Just in case the end of print comes tomorrow, well never forget what we had.

title: Up Front: Walter Isaacson
description: In his distinguished career, Walter Isaacson has been the chairman and chief executive of CNN and the editor of Time magazine. He is now the president and chief executive of the Aspen Institute.

title: Wise Guy
description: The problem with writing a biography of Socrates, as Bettany Hughes merrily admits, is that hes a doughnut subject: a rich and tasty topic with a big hole right in the middle where the main character should be. Despite his fame and his insistence on an examined life, Socrates never wrote anything, and our knowledge of him comes mainly from three contemporaries  his devoted pupils Plato and Xenophon, and the parodist Aristophanes  each of whom had his own agenda. He produced no great answers, only great questions, and the most enduring image we have of his life is his leaving of it, as the title of this book suggests.

title: Misery Loves Company
description: In a survey of unhappy families, youd be hard pressed to find one quite so spectacularly savage as the Goodyews of Kent. In Louise Deans darkly comic new novel, The Old Romantic, Nick Goodyew, an English solicitor specializing in divorce, hasnt seen his father, Ken, in 15 years, his mother, Pearl, in over 20  since Nick more or less broke up the family by revealing his fathers infidelities, then escaped to the loftier world of Cambridge. When Ken gets back in touch after years of silence, its largely to heap abuse on his son  Oy! Bigead! . . . Youre nothing! Youre a stuck-up, jumped-up . . . embarrassment  before admitting that hell be requiring Nicks services in divorcing his second wife, a squat, tittering woman whose banal chatter Ken likens to a dripping tap.

title: Sandalista!
description: Mocking ones younger self is a middle-age rite of passage. The jaded grown-up derides as nave the idealistic or altruistic impulses of youth. (Silly us: we once had convictions!) Underlying this sneering condescension, of course, is grief. Well never be that tender, certain or passionate about anything again. Life is half over, the glass half emptied. We slouch toward death.

title: Frontiers End
description: We Americans love to uproot ourselves and head out for unfamiliar territories. Our reasons, if sometimes murky, are also manifold: a fear of whats brewing at home or the ache for an ideal that virgin land might help realize. We want riches. We thrill at jumping into the uncertain void. West of Here, Jonathan Evisons broad-spectrum new novel, plays host, gleefully and mischievously, to all of the above. More than a dozen central characters willfully flip their lives upside down and inside out, eyes on the horizon.

title: Unkind and Unnecessary
description: To the Editor:

title: Market Values
description: To the Editor:

title: Paperback Row
description: UNION ATLANTIC,  by Adam Haslett (Anchor, $15.) Set chiefly in Boston and New York in 2001-2, this timely first novel meditates on Wall Street corruption and class warfare through its protagonist, Doug Fanning, one of the brains behind a rotten banking conglomerate.

title: Bruno Littlemores Lineage
description: To the Editor:

title: Inside the List
description: BATTLE ROYALE: As secretary of defense, Donald Rumsfeld was a strong advocate for the so-called Revolution in Military Affairs, a strategy that relies on high-tech combat systems and smaller, more nimble forces. When it comes to book-selling, however, hes something of an old fogey. While his Known and Unknown may be No. 1 on the hardcover nonfiction list, its a modest No. 10 on the mother of all mash-up lists shown in the graphic on Page 24  which combines fiction and nonfiction, print and e-books  in part because of comparatively weak e-book sales.

title: Bogarts Lonely Place
description: To the Editor:

title: Editors Choice
description: J. D. SALINGER: A Life,  by Kenneth Slawenski (Random House, $27.) The great achievement of Slawenskis reverent biography, coming just a year after Salingers death, is its evocation of the horror of his experiences in World War II.

title: Read the Book Instead
description: To the Editor:

title: Weekend Competition: Get Web Soon
description: This weekend, co-vocabularists are invited to design greeting card slogans fit for the times in which we live.

title: Study of Breast Biopsies Finds Surgery Used Too Extensively
description: Too many women with abnormal mammograms or other breast problems are undergoing surgical biopsies when they should be having needle biopsies, which are safer, less invasive and cheaper, new research shows.

title: Reviewing the BYD F3DM
description: In Sundays Automobiles section, Brad Berman reviews the F3DM, a plug-in hybrid from the Chinese automaker BYD. Mr. Berman finds the F3DM to be technologically impressive, but notes that it offers few of the frills and creature comforts that American drivers customarily expect. He writes:

title: Reviewing the Camaro Convertible
description: Jerry Garrett reviews the Chevrolet Camaro convertible in this Sundays Automobiles section, finding it to be a big improvement on past models. The wet-dishrag sensation of previous Camaro convertibles has been replaced, Mr. Garrett writes, by a more controlled ride with tighter tolerances. He goes on:

title: Making a Fashion Statement, With or Without Clothes
description: RENAZZO DI CENTO, Italy  To the untrained eye, the clusters of synthetic body parts scattered on the floor of a vast warehouse in Italys heartland looked very much like  well, like clusters of synthetic body parts.

title: McDyess Decides to Put Off Retirement
description: San Antonio Spurs forward Antonio McDyess thought this could be the last season of his N.B.A. career.

title: Letters: A Prescription for Fear
description: Virginia Heffernans opinion piece offered at best a misleading and unsubstantiated characterization of WebMD. WebMD has earned the trust of millions of consumers by providing objective and relevant health information that is written by a staff of professional journalists and board-certified physicians. Our award-winning content undergoes a rigorous medical-review process to ensure that it is credible and accurate. We always make a clear distinction between our own content and that of our advertisers. Heffernan asserts that MayoClinic.com is somehow more credible because it is owned by a nonprofit clinic, when in fact, as Heffernan acknowledges, it operates a commercial site that accepts advertising just as WebMD does. We would have also expected The Times to disclose its ownership of the advertising-supported health site on About.com, which competes with WebMD.

title: Letters: Shaken
description: Emily Bazelons article illustrates the need to reform a system in which expert medical witnesses who may have conflicts of interest argue complex cases to a lay jury. These expert witnesses are paid lucratively, can legally opine on anything outside their field and rarely face repercussions for incorrect testimony. To remove conflict of interest, the courts should seek interpretation of M.R.I.s and other test results from multiple independent court-employed neuroradiologists who dont have knowledge of or involvement with the case.

title: Look of the Moment | Blake Lively
description: The Look: Military might. With a coat like that, who needs an evening dress?

title: Four Questions on How to Cut Tuition
description: 7:42 p.m. | Updated See below for a comment Mr. McCardell submitted this evening to The Choice further explaining this sentence from one of his answers below: It costs us about $75,000 to educate one student for one year.

title: Nasdaq and ICE Consider NYSE Euronext Bid
description: 8:24 p.m. | Updated

title: Gilt Groupe Chief Considering I.P.O. in 2012
description: Now that Nordstrom has swooped in to buy a flash sales site, HauteLook, for $180 million in stock, the market is waiting for the Web sites larger rival, Gilt Groupe, to make a move.

title: Oscar Picks, Courtesy of the Man Behind Ron Swanson
description: Hey, have you noticed our spiffy new interactive Oscar ballot, winking suggestively at you over on the right side of the screen? Go ahead, fill it out! In the lead-up to the big day, the Bagger has asked some well-known folks to join you in picking the most Oscar-worthy films and performances, and well be talking to some of them about their choices. First up: Nick Offerman, best known for playing the lushly mustachioed, world-weary boss on Parks and Recreation  one of the Baggers favorites  where he occasionally stars opposite his wife, Megan Mullally.

title: The Art of the Mannequin
description: A family company provides upscale mannequins to fashion houses, department stores and museums alike.

title: A Pair of Vintage Lancias Find a Savior
description: Not long after Jaan Hjorth, a Lancia mechanic in Berkeley, Calif., was profiled in November by The New York Times, he received a phone call.

title: Top 10 Composers: A Young Reader Who Responded Is Now on Video
description: We hope you didnt miss the videos of our chief music critic, Anthony Tommasini, playing the piano to demonstrate some of the musical ideas he applied to his effort to assemble a list of the 10 greatest composers. Were also happy to remind you of one of the more striking responses, from an 8-year-old pianist with his own firm ideas about the Top 10. Now the lad, Lucas Amory, has a video too. Can he spell p-r-e-c-o-c-i-o-u-s?

title: TimesCast | February 18, 2011
description: Michael Slackman reports from Manama, moments after an attack on protesters by security forces; and a week after Mubaraks fall, huge crowds gather in Cairos Tahrir Square to celebrate.

title: Twitter Patter | @SandraBernhard
description: Tweeting Since April 2009Followers 57, 545Twitter Bio Actress, author, personality, singer

title: Fishing Online for Cable Viewers
description: SHORT STORIES

title: An Arthur Worthy of the Modern Ages
description: FORGET everything you thought you knew about Camelot  the hulking round table, the wizened Merlin, the Lerner and Loewe book and score. This Camelot, the latest historical epic from Starz, skews young and sexy with a Harry Potter and Twilight alumnus (Jamie Campbell Bower, as King Arthur), a Bond girl (Eva Green, as Morgan) and an MTV Movie Award winner for best kiss (Joseph Fiennes, as Merlin).

title: Smash the Windows, Bang the Cowbell
description: The Psychic Paramount

title: With Whaling Ships Under Attack, Japan Will Recall Fleet
description: TOKYO  Japan will cut short this years annual whale hunt in the Antarctic Ocean after obstruction by an environmental group largely prevented its ships from killing whales, the government said Friday.

title: Russian Finance Minister Says Political Change Is Needed
description: MOSCOW  Russias powerful finance minister, Aleksei L. Kudrin, said in a speech on Friday that economic advantages in Russia were too often granted based on relationships with government officials, and warned that economic reforms would not be possible without political change.

title: The Big Short Meets the Maestro
description: Thanks  for the bubble?

title: Childhood: Falls From Cribs Injure Dozens a Day
description: A crib should be a safe place to leave an infant, but every day dozens of babies are injured in falls from cribs, according to what may be the first study focusing on nonfatal crib-related injuries in children younger than 2.

title: The Medium Size Is the Message
description: Models arent generally known for their word play. But Modelinia.coms cool new T-shirts are emblazoned with model-related catchphrases that riff on well-known idioms and logos. Now you can Facebook like Karlie Kloss or proclaim that Nobody does it better than Abbey Lee on your shirt.

title: Boxing Here, but Focusing on Egypt
description: As Ahmed Samir stood in a ring in the Flatiron district throwing punches the other day, his mind was on another fight  for the future of his homeland, and for his right to return there.

title: A Revived George Mason Has Major Ambitions
description: FAIRFAX, Va.  Five years removed from its improbable Final Four appearance, George Mason embraces the past while choosing not to be defined by it. Enlarged magazine covers chronicling the Patriots run still hang in Coach Jim Larranagas office, and at home games this season fans received bobblehead dolls depicting the 2005-6 teams starting five.

title: Leyland Not Concerned About Cabrera
description: The inevitable questions about Miguel Cabreras recent D.W.I. arrest hit Tigers Manager Jim Leyland on Friday, and he was not overly concerned about his first baseman in his responses.

title: A Sales Record for Lady Gaga
description: Lady Gagas new single, Born This Way, released Feb. 11, has already scored a sales milestone: it is the fastest-selling song in iTunes history, with more than 1 million downloads around the world in five days.

title: Penthouse Skin Care
description: After 11 years of tending to the skin of A-listers like Kate Winslet, Brad Pitt and Lara Stone in her downtown atelier, Tracie Martyn has moved to a sprawling penthouse in the Flatiron district. Designed by Benjamin Noriega-Ortiz (who counts the Mondrian SoHo among his projects), the airy space is filled with his signature flourishes, including a cloudlike feather chandelier and Swarovski crystal-studded walls. Clients can buy the facialists all-natural products, including her latest, Resculpting Body Serum with mushroom extract; 101 Fifth Avenue (East 17th Street), (212) 206-9333; traciemartyn.com.

title: Senator Bingaman of New Mexico Will Retire
description: 6:12 p.m. | Updated Jeff Bingaman, a Democratic senator from New Mexico, will retire at the end of his term in 2012, adding to the growing list of open seats the party will have to defend next year.

title: Sara Katz and Douglas Mercer
description: EVERYTHING about Douglas Mercer, 38, is intense, from what he reads (Shakespeare) to where he travels (Rwanda, India, Nicaragua). He is passionate about experimental theater, scuba diving, Buddhism and Boston sports teams.
