In his teens, he liked the Grateful Dead so much that his mother, Carol Ann Mercer, drove him to concerts the way other moms drive their kids to soccer games.

title: Wheelies: Dearborn-on-Volga Edition
description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

title: Attacks Across Afghanistan Leave Over a Dozen Dead
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Attacks in four parts of the country left at least 18 people dead on Friday, including four NATO service members, four Afghan police officers and 10 civilians, signaling the tenaciousness of the insurgency even through the winter.

title: Midwinter Ritual: When Good Actor Meets Bad Movie
description: LATE winter is traditionally a time to celebrate great acting, as the most distinguished performances of the previous year parade before us on their long march to the Oscars. At the moment, accordingly, those of us with deadlines and airtime to fill are busy trumpeting the artistry of Colin Firth and Annette Bening, Natalie Portman and Christian Bale. But meanwhile, in the real world of day-to-day moviegoing, there are screens and seats to be filled, and genre movies  horror, action, romantic comedy, kiddie adventure  flood the multiplexes, forgoing the Academys consideration and hoping for a bit of yours. Many of these movies take part in another, less-heralded seasonal ritual: the spectacle of great actors appearing in bad movies.

title: Egyptian Archeological Sites Were Looted, Antiquities Minister Says
description: Important archeological sites in Egypt were looted during the antigovernment protests, Egypts antiquities minister, Zahi Hawass, wrote on his blog on Thursday. The announcement contradicted earlier statements by Mr. Hawass that Egypts archeological sites were safe. Mr. Hawass wrote that tombs at Saqqara and Abusir and storage buildings at Saqqara and at Cairo University, among other sites, had been broken into. He added that he had formed a committee to determine and report on what objects were missing.

title: Many Americans See Economy Improving, but Not for Them
description: AMERICANS are becoming more optimistic about the prospects for the economy, but are still concerned about their own financial situation.

title: Off Screen, a Long-Running Romance
description: WHEN Zack Snyder and Deborah Johnson married on Sept. 25, 2004, he had just finished directing his first feature film, a remake of Dawn of the Dead, and she was producing television commercials.

title: Weekend Fare
description: Talks and panel discussions are scheduled for Friday and Saturday at the International Association of Culinary Professionals conference. The events cover topics like the New York restaurant scene, food blogging and the farm-to-table movement. Receptions, lunches and dinners are also scheduled. Tickets are $149 for the conference, and a schedule of events is available from theculinarytrust.org.

title: Turkey Jails 3 Journalists in Coup Investigation
description: ISTANBUL  Three journalists from a Web site critical of the government were jailed and charged on Friday as part of an investigation into accusations that the military plotted to overthrow Turkeys pro-Islamic government in 2003. The moves came as Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan sharply criticized the new American ambassador here for his comments on the case.

title: Videophiles | Doug Aitkens Patterns & Repetition: Jack White
description: There are certain things that creative people share in common, and lately a chat with the artist Doug Aitken seems to be one of them. Aitkens 2006 book, Broken Screen, featured interviews with 26 artists, including Robert Altman and Rem Koolhaas. Now, with his latest video project, Patterns & Repetition, the artist sits down with a new cast in an attempt to put the pieces of the creative puzzle back together again. Each week, The Moment will feature a different segment: Mike Kelley talking about the Motor City; Jacques Herzog on instinct and architecture; Jack White (above) imagining Michelangelo as a modern-day blogger. But dont be fooled by the coffee mugs and the California sunshine. Aitken doesnt do anything casually. The subtext of the conversations is nothing less than the future of art itself.

title: Violence Erupts at Jordan Protest
description: AMMAN, Jordan  A protest turned violent here in the Jordanian capital on Friday as government supporters clashed with demonstrators calling for political change, injuring several, witnesses said.

title: Valle de Bravo, an Upscale Refuge Near Mexico City
description: A BAND of tubas, trumpets and saxophones played as a lone, wide-grinning inebriate swayed to the wailing horns. There were balloons, popcorn stands and roasted-peanut vendors. Children on scooters whipped through the crowd, chased by a scrawny, yapping mutt. Teenage girls danced among themselves while young men sipped micheladas  beer spiked with lime, salt and chili  from one-liter Styrofoam cups. The smell of cotton candy and churros was everywhere.

title: Flemish Comfort Food in French Flanders
description: ON a Friday night at Estaminet T Rijsel, a restaurant in Lille, France, just 30 minutes from the Belgian border, my dining companion and I sampled a trio of dishes: waterzooi, carbonnade and potje vleesch. In France, the bones of history end up in the stock pot, so reading a menu can tell you a lot about where you are. This menu was telling me that I was in Flanders  more specifically, French Flanders.

title: Store Review: La Chocolaterie de Jacques Genin, in Paris
description: When Jacques Genin opened his chocolaterie of the same name in late 2008, it was a star turn for one of the great supporting actors on the French culinary stage.

title: Hotel Review: Fairmont Pacific Rim in Vancouver
description: THE BASICS

title: An Olympic Village in Vancouver Is Reborn
description: DURING the Olympic Games in Vancouver last February, about 3,000 athletes and officials spent their downtime holed up in the Olympic Village. Filling eight city blocks, with 25 residential high-rises and mixed-use buildings, the $1.1 billion pop-up neighborhood was built on a desolate stretch of industrial land along the citys waterfront. After the athletes left, the sprawling complex  nearly 1,100 units in total  was reinvented as Vancouvers newest residential district. That transformation has, in turn, accelerated the emergence of the area around the complex as a destination unto itself.

title: In New Hampshire, Can Bretton Woods Get Gnarly?
description: FOR years, the problem facing the Bretton Woods ski resort has been entirely its own making: It is too perfect. Perfectly groomed. Perfectly contoured with rough edges softened. Perfectly positioned, shielded from wind and blessed with sun and snow. Perfectly tranquil, neither hurried nor crowded.

title: Letter: Mexican Food in Las Vegas
description: To the Editor: I thoroughly enjoyed Matt Grosss Lost in Las Vegas (Feb. 6). I was especially delighted to see that his first stop was at my favorite Las Vegas restaurant, the divey Mexican joint El Sombrero. My husband and I first discovered this little gem many years ago when we asked a cab driver to recommend a good, off-the-Strip Mexican restaurant favored by the locals. Since then, we never fail to stop at El Sombrero whenever were in the neighborhood. Karen Douglas

title: Letters: New Zealand Adventurers
description: To the Editor: We truly enjoyed Extreme New Zealand (Jan. 30). During our trip there, six or seven years ago, we were staying at the Novotel Queensland, and as I was looking out of the window, I saw a fellow and his guide come paragliding down toward the lake. I immediately called the concierge and asked if she could arrange for me to try it the following morning. My wife overheard and asked to join me.

title: In Washington, D.C., Columbia Heights Hip Strip
description: A cluster of independent businesses has revitalized a once-desolate stretch of 11th Street, where big box stores and chain restaurants give way to indie rock dance parties and guerrilla theater performances.

title: An Upscale Refuge Near Mexico City
description: Valle de Bravo, a lakeside community of 57,000 nestled in pine-covered hills, is just two hours west of Mexico City.

title: Speaking French, Cooking Flemish
description: Locals in this sliver of Flanders that lies in France still love to eat traditional Flemish meals.

title: A Grande Dame Gets Gnarly
description: Once known as Medicare Mountain, Bretton Woods has become a favorite winter destination.

title: In a Seating Chart, Silicon Valleys Pecking Order
description: In Silicon Valley, its all about who you know  and who you are sitting next to.

title: Hoping Mediation Makes Breaking Up Easier
description: After the passage of no-fault divorce in New York State last year made splitting up a bit easier and cheaper, court officials in Nassau County are taking another step that they hope will make things even easier. They are encouraging mediation.

title: Echoes of Another Time and Place
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I.

title: Best in Shows
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#276", 592, 480, true, chameleonData);

title: How Families Avoid Scandal, When Any Slip Can Go Viral
description: TWO types of privacy violations scare people with wealth and a reputation to protect: the isolated annoyances and the breaches that go viral. How to prevent the privacy violations from happening or, if that fails, handling the fallout was the focus of a timely and provocative discussion on Tuesday.

title: Finras Deputy Enforcement Chief to Depart
description: James S. Shorris, the No. 2 cop at the Financial Industry Regulatory Authority, Wall Streets self-policing organization, is leaving to pursue a job in the private sector.

title: F.E.C. Rules on Politicians Memoirs
description: The use of personal memoirs by politicians to grab headlines has become a common occurrence. Now, its officially legit as well.

title: Deficit Discussions: Understanding Obamas Federal Budget Proposal
description: On Monday, President Obama released his proposed federal budget, which would cut the deficit by a projected $1.1 trillion over 10 years. Meanwhile, Republican lawmakers have indicated that the budget proposal they will unveil in April will include much deeper spending cuts than the presidents.

title: Cathy Horyn on New York Fashion Week
description: This season, designers extended the creative boundaries with their fabric research and development.

title: Movies for Grown-Ups Find an Audience
description: Weve wondered how ticket sales affect Oscar campaigning all season long; films certainly get a boost from a nomination, perhaps even more so than a victory. The Los Angeles Times takes a close look at what could be either an anomaly or a harbinger in this years crop of best picture nominees: even if they dont take home a little gold man, most are poised to be box office champs.

title: App Smart Extra: Translating Signs
description: Mobile translators can help you squeeze through a conversation with someone who speaks another language, as this weeks App Smart column points out. But what about situations where you just want to know whats on the menu or how to read a set of signs?

title: Fashion Week Parties, Night 8
description: Fashion Week winds down with a party for Naeem Khan.

title: Flash Crash Panel Lays Out Several Steps to Diminish Volatility in the Market
description: A committee set up in response to the flash crash of the stock market last May said on Friday that regulators had done much to address the blow to investor confidence but had not yet done enough. It also set out additional steps, including tightening controls on the growing number of computerized high-frequency and algorithmic traders.

title: A Bubble in Private Internet Companies?
description: Zynga, the company behind many of the Webs most viral games, is close to a deal that would value it at nearly $10 billion and is considering an initial public offering as soon as the first quarter of 2012. Valuations of Facebook and Groupon are similarly stratospheric. Bill Gurley of Benchmark Capital weighs in on whether there is a bubble in private Internet companies in this CNBC video.

title: 'Boeing 737' by the Low Anthem
description: The premiere of the video for "Boeing 737," from the Low Anthem's new album, "Smart Flesh" (Nonesuch).

title: He May Be No. 2, but Kaymer Is Still a Secret
description: Martin Kaymer? How did he get to be the second-ranked golfer in the world so fast? Unless you are a bleary-eyed watcher of the Golf Channel or a student of the Challenge Tour, the European equivalent of the Nationwide, you could be forgiven for thinking that Kaymer, a 26-year-old German, had been sprung on the world like a top-secret piece of engineering developed by some Bavarian aerospace Gesellschaft.

title: Carmelo Anthony Trade Talks Get Their Second Wind
description: LOS ANGELES  Carmelo Anthony is dominating the N.B.A.s All-Star weekend, without making a single move on the court.

title: Arts & Leisure Preview: Good Actors in Bad Movies, The Book of Mormon and More
description: Wisdom, insights and observations from this weekends Arts & Leisure section.

title: Chic in Review | Jennifer Lopez, Fashion Victim
description: All the fashion news of the week thats fit to reprint.

title: Cellphones Become the Worlds Eyes and Ears on Protests
description: For some of the protesters facing Bahrains heavily armed security forces in and around Pearl Square in Manama, the most powerful weapon against shotguns and tear gas has been the tiny camera inside their cellphones.

title: Time Inc.: The Anatomy of a Fiasco
description: Like most bad news, the departure of Jack Griffin  the chief executive of Time Inc. for less than six months  dropped at the end of the day, leaving the publishing community scratching its head and wondering how things had gone so wrong. No one, including Mr. Griffin, saw this one coming. He was at a board meeting of Next Issue Media until 4 p.m. on Thursday, and another executive at the meeting said it was clear that Mr. Griffin did not know he was about to be fired from the worlds largest magazine publisher.

title: How Will Republicans Take Advantage of Bingamans Retirement?
description: New Mexicos Jeff Bingaman announced his retirement Friday, making him the fourth member of the Senate Democratic caucus to have done so since the start of the year.

title: Buzz Tracker
description: Is Goldman Really to Blame? Some bloggers take issue with the view that Goldman Sachs was responsible for the 2008 collapse of the American International Group. For me, it is difficult to see any malpractice from Goldman here. Goldman acted to protect itself, as it had every right to do. If A.I.G. did not want to have to accept Goldmans valuations, it could have negotiated a different valuation procedure for the trades. Instead it left itself open to massive liquidity risk by agreeing to the collateral arrangements that it did. A.I.G. never considered the consequences were the underlyings to its trades to become illiquid, nor where it would find the collateral were the trades to go against them. For me that is by far the worst of the behavior seen here. Deus Ex Macchiato

title: Neighborhood Joint | Knitty City
description: A colorful Upper West Side yarn shop offers both knitting supplies and instruction.

title: Scientists Call for New Sources of Critical Elements
description: WASHINGTON  Technologies for green or renewable-energy devices like batteries, solar cells and advanced electric motors are dependent on critical metals and other elements that are threatened by major shortages, two influential American scientific groups said in a report Friday.

title: Worldly Actor Finds Method in a Monastery
description: ON Friday, around the time New York moviegoers arrive for an afternoon showing of the French film Of Gods and Men, last years grand prize winner at Cannes, the star, Lambert Wilson, should also be making his way to a theater. But not for a movie. In Paris it will be Csar night, Frances Oscar night, and Mr. Wilson is nominated for his performance as the leader of a tiny Trappist monastery in strife-torn Algeria.

title: Auschwitz Shifts From Memorializing to Teaching
description: OSWIECIM, Poland  For nearly 60 years, Auschwitz has told its own story, shaped in the aftermath of the Second World War. It now unfolds, unadorned and mostly unexplained, in displays of hair, shoes and other remains of the dead. Past the notorious, mocking gateway, into the brick ranks of the former barracks of the Polish army camp that the Nazis seized and converted into prisons and death chambers, visitors bear witness via this exhibition.

title: Rabbi Is Sentenced in Plot to Shake Down SAC Capital
description: John Marshall Mantel for The New York TimesRabbi Milton Balkany arrives at federal court in Manhattan for sentencing.

title: U.S. Blocks Security Council Censure of Israeli Settlements
description: UNITED NATIONS  The Obama administration vetoed a United Nations Security Council resolution on Friday condemning Israeli settlement building in occupied territory as illegal, choosing not to alienate Israel and risking the anger of Arabs.

title: Growing Older Isnt the Same as Growing Up
description: THERE are parties, and then theres the Party, that one shimmering night that presents the chance to cut loose, kiss the prom queen and reveal ones true self. And always its the last chance: before graduation, before leaving home, before everybody grows up.

title: Mom for President
description: Across the country in recent days, women with political clout have been arguing about the rights and needs of mothers.

title: Italian Passion, Hollywood Hooey
description: SENSO

title: The Digital Lives of Babies
description: MY wife was about to go into the operating room for a scheduled C-section a few months ago when a nurse asked me an urgent question: Where is your camera?

title: A Composer Is Dead, but Smiles Survive
description: John Strauss, composer of the theme song to Car 54, Where Are You? has died. Rather than a moment of silence, we propose 31 seconds of indelible catchiness, a whirlwind tour of the crime-and-mayhem news cycle of New York City circa 1961 (Khrushchevs due at Idlewild!) and a peek inside an old-school r.m.p., all available above via the miracle of YouTube.

title: Pictures of the Day: Uganda and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Uganda, Egypt, Bahrain and Yemen.

title: Whodunit Most Musical by a Musician Most Literary
description: WESLEY STACES new book, Charles Jessold, Considered as a Murderer, is both a murder mystery and a novel about classical music, with a character who sometimes assumes another identity. Mr. Stace, an enthusiastic, donnish Englishman with an honors degree in English literature from Jesus College, Cambridge, and a head stuffed full of historical trivia, is an expert on both double lives and music. Improbably, he is also John Wesley Harding, an Elvis Costello-like singer-songwriter and folk rocker who has released more than a dozen records and is cool enough to have enlisted most of the Decemberists as the backup band on a forthcoming album.

title: House Republicans Push Through Budget Amendments
description: As the House marched steadily on Friday toward approving the largest spending cuts in modern history, Republicans easily pushed through amendments to deny government financing for Planned Parenthood, to block money for carrying out the big health care overhaul and to bar the Obama administration from regulating certain greenhouse gases that contribute to global warming.

title: Been There, Done That, and Now Going to This
description: THE New York Timess theater critics are not the only ones willing to opine on spring theater highlights. We also polled a random assortment of Tony award winners and nominees from last season to find out what they are most excited about seeing in the coming months. Here are some of their answers. Though The Book of Mormon, the irreverent new musical created by Matt Stone and Trey Parker, the guys behind South Park, is looking like a popular choice among theater people (and others, presumably) the rest of the assortment below is as eclectic as our group of panelists. STEVEN McELROY

title: A Presidential Vote in Uganda
description: In stark contrast to the recent upheavals in northern Africa and the Middle East, governmental change in Uganda on Friday took on a decidedly different feel.

title: HCA Seeks to Price I.P.O. at Up to $30 a Share
description: John Russell/Associated PressHCA headquarters in Nashville.

title: Realism on Defense Spending
description: One thing Im hearing and reading from liberal sources is the argument that we can find big savings by ending the war in Afghanistan, and more generally by cutting bloated defense spending. So, a few words on that issue.

title: Morning T Video | Andy Cohen
description: In the latest installment of our video interview series, Andy Cohen, the Bravo executive and host of Watch What Happens Live, talks to Horacio Silva about how the Real Housewives franchise has hogged the fashion dialogue, Ramona Singers pinot grigio, Allison Duboiss e-cigarette and the one-woman, mononymic powerhouse that is Zoila!

title: The Week in Pictures for Feb. 18
description: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include ice fishing, a bonsai festival and fashion week.

title: Green Roof Collapses in Illinois
description: Green roofs have become increasingly popular in the United States as a way to beautify and insulate buildings and reduce heat pollution in urban areas, but last week one drew attention for a far different reason: it collapsed.

title: Cairo in the Midwest?
description: As a native Wisconsinite, I cant tell you how often Ive heard the old saw that Badger State politics mirrors its geography: to the right of Minnesota and above Illinois. Well, the first part was proven last November, when Republicans achieved a near-stranglehold on state politics, while the latter is contradicted by the fact that this week all 14 Democrats from the State Senate fled to a hotel across the border in the Land of Lincoln.

title: A Well-Lighted Media Blackout
description: KANYE WEST spent New York Fashion Week under a self-imposed cone of silence, refusing to talk to the news media. Yet somehow, he became a spectacle: his every move was chronicled by a cloud of bloggers, Twitter users, fashion reporters and paparazzi. Heres how he spent the week, starting on Feb. 10.

title: Morning T: Andy Cohen
description: Andy Cohen, executive in charge of dysfunction at Bravo TV, talks to Horacio Silva about the housewives and their many ancillary products.

title: The Mystery of Obamas Dinner with Tech Executives
description: For technology spectators, a dinner on Thursday evening with President Obama and a dozen Silicon Valley executive seemslike a scene straightout of an Agatha Christie novel: a pile of questions and very few answers surrounding the dinner and its guests.

title: Have Your Cake and Eat It Too
description: In my previous reader response, I mentioned the puzzling proverb You cant have your cake and eat it too. Matthew Parry writes: Id always found have your cake and eat it too perplexing, too, until it was pointed out the reversed construction makes sense: You cant eat your cake and have it too. Of course, everyone thinks Im misquoting when I say this now!

title: Pratfalls From Haydn, Swing From Marsalis
description: Taken at face value, the program that the New York Philharmonic presented on Wednesday evening in Avery Fisher Hall was a curious clutch of disparate works. Still, there was symmetry to the arrangement: two saxophone showcases played with an estimable soloist, Branford Marsalis, both also heard during a Philharmonic concert in Central Park last summer, flanked here by pieces that repurposed viable music from forgotten stage dramas.

title: Pictures of the Day: Uganda and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Uganda, Egypt, Bahrain and Yemen.

title: A Contender Elbows In
description: WEST HOLLYWOOD, Calif.

title: Chilean Priest Found Guilty of Abusing Minors
description: SO PAULO, Brazil  After an internal investigation, the Vatican found the Rev. Fernando Karadima guilty of sexually abusing minors in Chile and ordered him to retire to a life of prayer and penitence, the archbishop of Santiago said Friday.

title: New York Fashion Week | Plenty of Plaid
description: Mens-wear-inspired womens wear isnt anything revolutionary. From Diane Keaton in Annie Hall wearing Ralph Lauren to Cate Blanchett channeling Katharine Hepburn in The Aviator, dressing like the boys doesnt have to mean androgyny. This fall plaids are designers latest nod to mens wear  and were not talking suits. Thakoons tribal-inspired cobalt blue and cherry red checkered 18th-century red puffer jacket would be foreign to Gaelic Scots. Similarly, Rag & Bone used a mixed color palette, but also paired neo-traditional houndstooth kilts with tough biker jackets. Some were more direct: Theyskens Theory delivered plaids exactly how you want and expect them, a little oversized and unbuttoned, as if you threw on your boyfriends. Conservative looks did resurface, however  patterns woven in maroon, brown and yellow made an appearance at Chris Benz as a simple long smock dress and Altuzarra-fitted trousers. Thankfully, this is one of those brilliant trends that you always have somewhere buried in your closet. Happy hunting.

title: 4 Yanks, 2 Games, 1 Midfield
description: Its no great secret that the United States national team lacks the position-by-position depth of the worlds top soccer nations.

title: SoHo Gallery? Black, of Course.
description: Vladimir Restoin Roitfeld, 26, is an art dealer and curator. His most recent endeavor, with his partner, Andy Valmorbida, is the recently opened exhibition of the Los Angeles-based street artist Retna at a gallery space in SoHo. Mr. Restoin Roitfeld, born and raised in Paris, is surrounded by a holy trinity of fashion-savvy women: his mother, the recently departed French Vogue editor Carine Roitfeld; his girlfriend, the LUomo Vogue fashion editor Giovanna Battaglia; and his sister, Julia Restoin Roitfeld, an art director and a model. CHLOE MALLE

title: Idol Rolls Again
description: American Idol cut its field of contestants down to 60 on Thursday as Part 3 of the reality shows Hollywood Week remained unstoppable in the ratings, attracting 21.9 million viewers at 8 p.m., according to Nielsens estimates. Fox placed first for the night over all despite drawing more modest ratings at 9 for Bones (9.9 million). Opposite Idol at 8, CBS fared best, earning 12.5 million for its half-hour sitcom The Big Bang Theory and 9.8 million at 8:30 for $#*! My Dad Says. CBS also led the 9 and 10 p.m. time slots with CSI (13.3 million), featuring Justin Bieber as a guest star, and The Mentalist (14.9 million), finishing in second place for the night over all. ABC was third with Wipeout at 8 (6.2 million) followed by Greys Anatomy (10.2 million) and Private Practice (6.9 million), while NBC ranked a distant fourth as usual with its three-hour comedy block.

title: Footnote
description: The soprano Anna Netrebko is ill and has pulled out of Saturdays matinee performance of Don Pasquale, the Metropolitan Opera said. Rachelle Durkin will sing the role of Norina in her place.

title: Nuanced Comfort Music That Channels Kate Smith
description: Musical moments at sporting events can be memorable  Whitney Houstons Star-Spangled Banner, Janet Jacksons wardrobe malfunction  but the singing doesnt usually affect the outcome.

title: Mullin May Join  Olympic Teammates in Hall of Fame
description: With Chris Mullin being named a finalist for the Basketball Hall of Fame, the Dream Team from the 1992 Olympics moved one step closer to perfection.

title: Facebook, Android, China and More at Mobile Conference
description: BARCELONA, Spain  This week, tens of thousands of mobile technology executives, entrepreneurs and enthusiasts descended on this beautiful city to watch demonstrations of new software, get a close look at the latest phones and tablets and stop at a tapas bar or two.

title: Celebrations in Tahrir Square
description: A week after Mubarak's fall, crowds gather to celebrate.

title: Eyewitness in Bahrain
description: Michael Slackman reports from Manama, moments after an attack on protesters by security forces.

title: Perry Moore, Author of Book About Gay Superhero, Dies at 39
description: Perry Moore, an executive producer of the fantasy movie series The Chronicles of Narnia and the author of Hero, a book about a gay superhero, died on Thursday after being found unconscious in his Greenwich Village apartment. He was 39.

title: Obama to Visit Latin America in March
description: President Obama will make his promised trip to Latin America from March 19 to 23, visiting four cities in three countries, the White House said on Friday.

title: About Those Fabrics
description: THE final day of Fashion Week felt a bit like a dash for the last plane out of Lisbon, if you know what I mean. Everyone wore very tight expressions. The journalists heading to London were already in the transit lounge. Still, the days shows held some delights: Ralph Laurens beautifully rendered Deco glamour and subplot of a Chinese retail assault; LWren Scotts Gauguin colors and a pitch, from both Ms. Scott and Francisco Costa of Calvin Klein, for short hemlines. Skirt lengths have generally been below the knees or to the ankles.

title: Vietnam, and Make It Snappy
description: I DIDNT come up with a banh mi recipe under the illusion that I could improve the classic Vietnamese sandwich.

title: Shortcut Banh Mi With Pickled Carrots and Daikon
description: Time: 45 minutes

title: Radiohead Surprises With Early Release
description: This time, Radiohead went for an ambush.

title: Speedy Evolution, Indeed
description: Talk about a quick learner: in just 50 years, a fish has evolved a resistance to toxic chemicals polluting its Hudson River home, a new study finds.

title: F.D.A. Chief Backs Fees for Generic Drug Reviews
description: Dr. Margaret Hamburg, commissioner of the Food and Drug Administration, called on Friday for a new process to allow makers of generic drugs to pay user fees to the F.D.A. to speed up approval of the low-cost drugs.

title: 25 Years of Hyundai in America
description: Hyundais offerings have evolved from the bargain-basement Excel to the luxury-class Equus.

title: They Shoot Movies, Dont They? The Camera as Star
description: LOS ANGELES  At Paramount Pictures these days, a lot of movies are less about the star than the camera  and the way its been keeping an eye on the rest of us.

title: Start Spreading the News
description: Albany to New York City, Feb. 19, 1861

title: Chasing a Police Scanner
description: Ride with Metro reporter Corey Kilgannon as he chases a police scanner in New York City.

title: Swiss Locate Funds Linked to Mubarak
description: Investigators have discovered tens of millions of dollars in Swiss bank accounts belonging to the ousted Egyptian president Hosni Mubarak, his family or five prominent associates, officials in Switzerland announced Friday. The officials said the accounts had been frozen, but declined to break down who controlled the vast sums.

title: Damage Control in a Viral World
description: In this weekends Wealth Matters column, Paul Sullivan writes about the ways in which the affluent try to protect their familys reputation.

title: MSNBC Hosts Settle In After Olbermann
description: MSNBC has certainly felt the impact of the departure of its most successful host, Keith Olbermann, last month, though the network has not suffered anything that could be called a collapse.

title: Cleaning Up Tahrir Square
description: Demonstrators tried to bring the square back to normal after Hosni Mubarak's resignation.

title: A Long Weekend, and a Long List of News
description: As we head into the long Presidents Day weekend, I am leaving you with brief updates on a number of the weeks events.

title: Hyundais Swift Growth Lifts Alabamas Economy
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala.  Few people in this city 800 miles south of Detroit cared much about the auto industry until Hyundai announced it would build cars here nine years ago.

title: One Giant Family
description: Since new school versus old school is one of the plot-generators (as opposed to ideas) floating around in the amiable, schlocky family comedy Big Mommas: Like Father, Like Son, it seems fair to point out that of all the cross-dressing comedies of recent decades, none has channeled Some Like It Hot quite so thoroughly.

title: Unrest in Tunisia, Fueled by Facebook
description: Social media sites help stoke deep unrest in Tunisia.

title: Anna Nicole
description: The opera based on the life of Anna Nicole Smith opened to raves in London.

title: Map of Key Locations in Manama, Bahrain
description: At least seven people had died in clashes between protesters and security forces in Bahrain before Fridays violence.

title: Former Liverpool Chairman Will Sue Hicks for Defamation
description: The takeover of Liverpool F.C. may be complete, but the key players in the drama continue to squabble.

title: A Black Widow Tale
description: Vishal Bhardwajs Shakespeare adaptations, Maqbool (Macbeth, 2004) and Omkara (Othello, 2006), remain high points of recent Hindi cinema. Serious and seriously entertaining, they married Shakespeare to contemporary Indian reality as artfully as they wedded a heightened realism to Bollywood showmanship.

title: Events on Long Island
description: Film

title: Father of 5 Browns Pleads Guilty to Abusing Daughters
description: The father of the 5 Browns, a high-profile performing quintet of classical pianists, has pleaded guilty to sexually abusing his daughters when they were under 14. The father, Keith S. Brown, 55, entered his plea on Thursday in Fourth Judicial District Court in Provo, Utah. In an agreement with prosecutors, Mr. Brown pleaded guilty to a first-degree felony count of sodomy and two second-degree felony counts of sexual abuse of a child. He faces a sentence of 10 years to life in prison at sentencing on March 31.

title: Events in Westchester
description: Comedy

title: The Looks That Lingered
description: THE tufted vinyl columns at Marc Jacobss show on Monday night were lighted in bordello red. Looks like a boudoir moment, the editor seated next to me offered sagely. On Wednesday morning, the young blogger sprinting alongside me to Michael Kors assured me with equal conviction that we would be having a Halston moment.

title: Trend Report: New York Fashion Week Fall 2011
description: The story line that ultimately emerged on the runways was pure Americana.

title: BBC Charts New Course for its U.S. Newscast
description: Tapping into what it sees as a need for impartial international news on cable, the BBC said Friday that it would aggressively seek distribution in the United States for BBC World News, its 24-hour news channel.

title: Events in Connecticut
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in Connecticut this week. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com, or by mail to the Connecticut Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

title: Events in New Jersey
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405; or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: A Winter Markets Bounty
description: Good news for shoppers who miss the festive atmosphere of the summer  farmers market in Chappaqua. Its still festive but now wintering indoors, cozy in the parish hall of the Church of St. Mary the Virgin.

title: Iberian Specialties Reach a New Elevation
description: THERE was no way around it: After relishing smoky-sweet chourio flambed over Portuguese brandy and sipping tourmaline-pink cava at Bellota, on the 42nd floor of the Ritz-Carlton Westchester, we literally had to come back to earth. But with six inches of slush in the streets below, who could blame us for wanting to linger just a little longer?

title: William Daley Made $8.7 Million from JPMorgan Last Year
description: The White Houses new chief of staff, William M. Daley, is rich  so much so that his recent earnings from JPMorgan Chase appear to give even Jamie Dimons pay package a run for the money.

title: Finances Could Sink Seaport Museum
description: For more than a decade the Seaport Museum New York has struggled to stay afloat. But it has never looked closer to going under.

title: Soups of the World
description: The daily rotation of five to eight soups at the NY Soup Exchange in Garden City has an international flair. On a recent day, hot and spicy Caribbean crab bisque shared the menu with teriyaki chicken and rice stew.

title: Notes, Melodies and, Here, Politics
description: I have something to say, the talk-show host Glenn Beck once said, and his words, set to music by Matt Marks, made an unlikely keynote to powerFUL, a program of politically charged music performed on Thursday evening as part of the Tune-In Music Festival at the Park Avenue Armory.

title: A Japanese Menu With Ideas of Its Own
description: ONSEN SUSHI may look like other Japanese storefront restaurants, but the four-month-old Oakdale newcomer is far from ordinary. Though the dcor is spare and cool, the welcome is warm. From behind the sushi bar, Jason Chen shouts a cheery hello to patrons as they arrive and banters with them throughout the meal, asking how they like his creations.

title: Alone With Thoughts and an Audience
description: Body Madness is a great name for the latest in Danspace Projects series of platforms  a thematic grouping of performances, usually organized by an invited artist. They have mostly been a raging success, creating intriguing links between artists and works you might never have considered in the same context. The first part of Body Madness  put together by the director of Danspace, Judy Hussie-Taylor  is called Absurdity and Wit, and previous shows featured vogueing and aerobics in explorations of genre that were as entertaining as they were thought-provoking.

title: The Sushi-Go-Round
description: Umi Sushi and Tapas, which opened in August, is one of the newest Japanese restaurants in Connecticut. Along with sushi rolls and nigiri pieces, it offers diners something different: dishes delivered via a conveyor belt.

title: Game in the Major or in No-Trump?
description: One of the most enjoyable events in the Greater New York Bridge Association calendar is the Betty Kaplan Teams. This was played last Saturday and won by John Boyer of Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y.; David Moss and Andrew Rosenthal of New York City; and Robert Stayman of New Rochelle, N.Y.

title: Tiny Kitchen Produces Wide Array of Delights
description: UPON entering Farmers Table in New Canaan, I found it hard to believe that so many different foods could emerge from such small quarters. Six starters, three soups, seven entrees and three desserts are all made on the premises for dinner, along with good, textured bread kneaded at the counter and baked in the minuscule kitchen. The fact that almost everything I tasted was delicious added to my incredulity.

title: Defying Sexual Mores in Conservative Georgia
description: TBILISI, Georgia

title: A Phone Plan With Music Built In
description: Prepaid phones are often a great deal, offering voice and data at a low price and without tying you to a two-year contract. But the stripped-down handsets often limit the apps and services.

title: Tip of the Week: Making the Web Plain
description: Some Web pages are crowded with so many graphical elements that it can be hard to locate the text you went there to read in the first place. The latest version of Apples Safari browser might help clear things up, however. When visiting an overly busy page, check the browsers address bar to see if a small gray Reader button is visible. If so, click the button to get an uncluttered version of the page that is free of everything except the text and accompanying photographs.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, Feb. 18
description: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

title: Why Does College Cost So Much?
description: In a week in which there was much talk in higher education circles about the full cost of tuition, The Timess Economix blog has an interview with the authors of a book titled Why Does College Cost So Much?

title: Imagination, Covered in Icing
description: GIVEN the popularity of the TLC reality show Cake Boss and its star, Buddy Valastro, owner of Carlos Bakery in Hoboken, one could be forgiven for assuming that Carlos, and only Carlos, bakes cakes replicating everything from human torsos to golf bags.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, Feb. 18
description: More Photographs

title: A Homecoming for Bighorn Sheep in Colorado
description: SEDALIA, Colo.  The mechanics were simple. A trailer latch popped, a gate swung open and three wild bighorn sheep  two females, presumably pregnant, and a year-old lamb, definitely frisky  trotted up the rocky slope of Thunder Butte under a pale afternoon sun.

title: Podcast: Growth, the Deficit and the Elliott Wave
description: How rapidly will the economy grow this year? The Federal Reserve has become somewhat more upbeat about the prospects for growth, and we feature its new appraisal on this weeks Weekend Business podcast.

title: Misery Most Proud, in Two Acts
description: The Subject Was Roses, a three-character play, is one of those small, relatively quiet dramas in which nothing much happens except that everything changes. Frank D. Gilroys Pulitzer Prize-winning 1964 drama about a young mans viewing his troubled parents through fresh eyes is receiving a muted production at the George Street Playhouse in New Brunswick.

title: A Place on the Right for a Few Godless Conservatives
description: As a child, Razib Khan spent several weeks studying in a Bangladeshi madrasa. Heather Mac Donald once studied literary deconstructionism and clerked for a left-wing judge. In neither case did the education take. They are atheist conservatives  Mr. Khan an apostate to his familys Islamic faith, Ms. Mac Donald to her left-wing education.

title: In Bahrain, the Bullets Fly
description: MANAMA, Bahrain

title: Scorecard | Calvin Klein Collection Wins!
description: On the eighth and final day of a New York fashion week that turned out to be all about fashioning modern Americana, Scorecard knows critics werent quite sure what to make of the erstwhile master of prairie-luxe Ralph Laurens rather literal love letter to the screen siren glamour of a Limehouse Blues-era Anna May Wong. Meanwhile over at Calvin Klein, Francisco Costa infused his minimalist chic with a new sporty vibe. That was deemed a stylistic home run.

title: A Bush Rule on Providers of Abortions Is Revised
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration on Friday rescinded most of a 2008 rule that granted sweeping protections to health care providers who opposed abortion, sterilization and other medical procedures on religious or moral grounds.

title: Sublime Notions From a Species That Likes to Doodle
description: Is there anyone who hasnt enjoyed making an abstract drawing  an elaborate classroom doodle, a Spirograph masterpiece, a tic-tac-toe game? Marking up a blank piece of paper, even in these pixel-fixated times, seems an inherently human activity. But the stunning new exhibition of abstract  or mostly abstract  drawings at the Katonah Museum of Art reveals the elements of the sublime in this sometimes mundane pursuit.

title: Long Floor Fight Over Spending Cuts Gets Personal
description: WASHINGTON  It was billed as a battle over numbers, but the marathon floor fight in the House this week was more a drama over core political beliefs, with long-simmering resentments, partisan grandstanding and startling personal revelations sprinkled throughout the script.

title: All-Star Weekend Turns Into Bidding War for Anthony
description: LOS ANGELES  The season-long spectacle involving Carmelo Anthonys future is nearing a resolution, with the Nets and the Knicks making competing proposals to acquire the discontented All-Star from the Denver Nuggets.

title: In a Range of Styles, an Improvisational Ethos
description: HOLED up in the Village Vanguard as a snowstorm raged last month, the pianist Jacky Terrasson was whipping up a storm of his own  attacking the keyboard, strumming and striking the instruments strings, and swinging and swaying atop his stool to an improbable mix of tunes like Michael Jacksons Beat It and Duke Ellingtons Caravan.

title: Approaching Abstraction, but Not Quite Getting There
description: The title of the current exhibition at the Nassau County Museum of Art, Milton Avery and the End of Modernism, on view through May 8, signals that it is an ambitious show. The end of modernism? Thats a huge subject, particularly in an art world where categories like modernism, postmodernism and the contemporary are still  and will probably never stop  being sorted out.

title: Finding Eternal Youth (in Song, Anyway)
description: ASK the two-time Tony Award-winning actress Christine Ebersole to describe the cabaret show she will perform on March 4 at the Mayo Center for the Performing Arts in Morristown, and the answer comes out in themes.

title: City to Toughen Auditing of School Test Scores
description: New York City school officials said Friday that they would introduce a new, rigorous system of auditing the test scores, grading practices and graduation rates of the public high schools, appearing to acknowledge rising concerns that some schools might be manipulating the statistics they are judged by.

title: On the Street | Skirting
description: Many guests attending designers shows for next fall wore a transparent curtain-skirt, while some designers runway visions showed a marked drop  to mid and lower calf.

title: HCA Expected to Seek $30 a Share in Public Offering
description: HCA, the hospital operator that was acquired by buyout firms in 2006, is seeking to price its initial public offering at as much as $30 a share when it begins its presentation to investors next week, people briefed on the matter said Friday. HCA has set a preliminary price of $27 to $30 for the stock sale, which is expected to be one of the biggest by a private equity-owned company in years. HCA was acquired in 2006 by a group led by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, Bain Capital and Merrill Lynchs private equity arm. The company is one of the largest for-profit hospital operators in the United States, running 162 hospitals and 104 more surgery centers in the United States and Britain.

title: Art School Runs Afoul of Facebooks Nudity Police
description: The New York Academy of Art, a graduate university that has been teaching figurative art since 1982, is not the kind of institution you would expect to get into trouble for mischief on Facebook. Yet the school recently received a stern warning from the site: You uploaded a photo that violates our Terms of Use, and this photo has been removed. The message went on to explain the kinds of things that Facebook does not allow: photos that attack a person or group, that depict drug use or contain violence or nudity.

title: Intel Plans New Chip Plant in Arizona
description: The Intel Corporation announced plans on Friday to build a $5 billion microprocessor plant in Arizona and hire 4,000 employees in the United States this year. The workers will focus on product development, research and design, the chief executive, Paul S. Otellini, said. Mr. Otellini disclosed the plans for the plant during a visit by President Obama to an Intel plant near Portland, Ore. The new plant will be located at the companys existing site in Chandler, Ariz.

title: Up-and-Comer Finds the Top
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla.  The tears flowed freely a year ago for Jamie McMurray, a driver with a redemption story that played out on Nascars grandest stage.

title: Find the Taxes That Do Double Duty
description: THE nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office projects a cumulative federal deficit of nearly $3.8 trillion over the next four years. So the $100 billion in annual spending cuts advocated by House Republicans will have a negligible impact on that total.

title: Rodman In and Miller Out as Hall Finalists Are Named
description: LOS ANGELES  The basketball Hall of Fame announced 12 finalists for enshrinement in 2011 on Friday.

title: Boldface Names With Guns
description: Among those licensed to own handguns in New York City are City Council members, actors, business moguls, lawyers and judges.

title: What Makes Community Health Care Work?
description: In response to Tuesdays column about two programs in India that train relatively uneducated women as their villages health workers, readers provided an avalanche of information about other community health worker programs around the world. Gregory Ortiz from London (95) wrote about Operation ASHA, which has semi-literate counselors treating tuberculosis in slums in India and Cambodia. In thefield from Alaska (109) wrote about para-dentists in rural Alaska. Marianne Loewe (121) from Santa Ana, Calif., commented on her organization, Concern America, which works with health promoters in Colombia and Central America.

title: A Watershed Moment for Public-Sector Unions
description: In the half century since Wisconsin became the first state to give its public workers the right to bargain collectively, government employee unions have mushroomed in size and power  so much so that they now account for more than half of the nations union members.

title: Holding Out Hope for a Missing Son
description: Here is living room furniture with the memories locked in, waiting for release:

title: Plan for Indian Casino in the Catskills Is Rejected
description: The federal government rejected a proposal on Friday to build an Indian casino in the Catskills, nullifying a deal reached in the waning days of the Paterson administration to settle a land claim by a tribe based in Wisconsin.

title: Healing a Wounded Credit Score
description: Millions of consumers have fallen out of favor with the credit scoring gods.

title: For Autistic Children, a Schools Coffee Shop Imparts Skills While Raising Money
description: EDISON, N.J.  The coffee shop at Woodrow Wilson Middle School is serious about service with a smile. When Edward Lin, a seventh grader, stared silently at his feet the other day instead of greeting a customer, his teacher prodded him.

title: Shareholders Offer a Spate of Climate and Environmental Resolutions
description: After a year marked by Congressional paralysis on issues like global warming and renewable energy, and after a parade of energy-related disasters  including the huge oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico  social investment groups are signaling their displeasure with a suite of shareholder resolutions.

title: Wisconsin Leads Way as Workers Fight State Cuts
description: The unrest in Wisconsin this week over Gov. Scott Walkers plan to cut the bargaining rights and benefits of public workers is spreading to other states.

title: The Rich, the Famous, the Armed
description: MEN and women. Democrats and Republicans. Doctors, lawyers, merchants and moguls. A remarkable, if relatively small, cross-section of New Yorkers legally own handguns, according to public records obtained by The New York Times.

title: Resolution Requested in Bonds Case
description: The federal judge presiding over Barry Bondss perjury case asked the sides on Friday to find a way to resolve the case before the trial next month. In a hearing in San Francisco, prosecutors told United States District Court Judge Susan Illston that they would discuss the option of a plea agreement with Bondss lawyers. But Bondss lead lawyer, Allen Ruby, said he expected the case to go to trial.

title: Lottery Numbers
U.S. Offered Rosy View Before Bahrain Crackdown
description: WASHINGTON  At a town-hall-style meeting in Bahrain two months ago, Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton got a pointed question from a member of Bahrains Parliament: was the United States letting Bahrain, a Persian Gulf ally, off the hook for a string of arrests of lawyers and human rights activists?

title: N.F.L. and Union Quiet on Meeting
description: Small groups from the N.F.L. and the players union met with a federal mediator in Washington on Friday in the first in a planned series of meetings in an effort to achieve a breakthrough in the stalled negotiations over a new collective bargaining agreement.

title: It Ended in a Suitcase
description: THE 17-second video, assembled from security cameras in Harlem, showed what seemed to be an ordinary man, in a cap and a leather jacket, walking down the street with an ordinary suitcase. Neither, however, was ordinary, the authorities said. The man, they claimed, was a murderer; the suitcase held the body of a woman he had killed.

title: After Long Exile, Sunni Cleric Takes Role in Egypt
description: CAIRO  Sheik Yusuf al-Qaradawi, an influential Sunni cleric who is banned from the United States and Britain for supporting violence against Israel and American forces in Iraq, delivered his first public sermon here in 50 years on Friday, emerging as a powerful voice in the struggle to shape what kind of Egyptian state emerges from the uprising that toppled Hosni Mubarak.

title: William Webbs World
description: William Webb was a typical Southerner. He was born in Georgia in the late 1840s, but like hundreds of thousands of Americans he rode the expansion of cotton westward, carried as a teenager first to Mississippi and then to Kentucky. Webb spent long days at work outdoors: driving wagons, hoeing cotton, harvesting tobacco. When he needed to raise cash, he sold homemade treats at camp meetings, those lengthy religious revivals popular among antebellum Americans. Webb started with ginger cakes, but when he realized that the Christians were not averse to something stronger, so he quickly switched to whiskey. It paid the best, Webb later admitted in a narrative he wrote years later.

title: As Mediator in Mets Case, Mario Cuomo Has Practice
description: Mario M. Cuomo, the former New York governor, has made a career of brokering solutions to tense standoffs, including housing crises, budget battles and a prison inmate takeover.

title: Message to Egypt From Qaedas No. 2
description: WASHINGTON  Al Qaedas Egyptian-born second in command, Ayman al-Zawahri, attacked secular rule in Egypt in an audio lecture released Friday, but the message appeared to have been recorded before President Hosni Mubarak stepped down last week.

title: The Lure of a Price Tag That Says Zero
description: When Stop N Swap, the rolling caravan of other peoples junk, pulled up at the St. George Library on Staten Island one recent Saturday, the citys latest initiative to remodel consumer habits was a modest, even slightly depressing affair: a few scraggly pieces of clothing hanging on a sparse rack and someone elses housewares.

title: Amid a Sea of Upheaval, Algeria Is Still
description: ALGIERS  Even as North African neighbors have smoldered, the oil-producing giant Algeria has kept a sullen calm in the wake of a stifled protest march here last week, with the regional upheaval, for now, not catching on.

title: Sanctions Placed on Afghan Exchange
description: WASHINGTON  The Treasury Department imposed sanctions on Friday against one of the largest money exchange houses in Afghanistan, along with 15 of its executives, on charges that it used billions of dollars transferred in and out of the country to help hide proceeds from illegal drug sales.

title: The Goal: Dont Go to Manhattan
description: Kathryn S. Wylde, 64, president of the Partnership for New York City, the citys premier business association, works days that start early and often stretch into the night. Once a month she takes a break and flies to Puerto Rico, where she spends five or six days  including one Sunday  with her husband, Wilfredo Lugo, 65, who lives full time at the couples home in Quebradillas, on the northwest coast. On most Sundays, she catches up on e-mail and makes plans for the week ahead from her co-op in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, which she shares with her cats  officially two, the limit her co-op allows.

title: Nets Themselves the Biggest Obstacle to Luring Anthony
description: LOS ANGELES

title: Corrections
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Keeping Titles, and Targets, in Sight
description: SYDNEY SHAEFER honed her bow-and-arrow skills not in summer camp but by hunting small game in the Black Hills of South Dakota.

title: A Suspect in a Killing Spree Is Indicted in Four Murders
description: The man accused of a violent 28-hour rampage through Brooklyn and Manhattan last week was indicted Friday on murder charges.

title: Holiday Schedule for Washingtons Birthday
description: NEW YORK

title: Preservationists Focus on a Little Brick House
description: Cooper Square was an unnamed but thriving business district about 1825 when a descendant of Peter Stuyvesant, Nicholas William Stuyvesant, built what is now one of the oldest remaining Federal-style houses on the Bowery.

title: Former Interim Coach Reflects on Experience
description: When Wyoming Coach Heath Schroyer was dismissed last week and replaced on an interim basis by Fred Langley, Jared Grasso could relate.

title: Illinois: Radical Group Member Denied Parole
description: Oscar Lopez Rivera, who has been in prison for almost 30 years for seditious conspiracy for his role in the Puerto Rican nationalist group the F.A.L.N., was denied parole Friday.

title: Saturday: Like a Message in a Bottle
description: SATURDAYS PUZZLE  Tim Croce is back with his third themeless puzzle, and he hits us with 10 10-letter entries that didnt seem too tough for a Saturday. With the possible exception of 1 Across, they were all eminently gettable, many are unique and I thought they were all interesting. In general, I found that I tussled more with some of the shorter entries than I did with the longer ones. How did you do?

title: Savoring Indian Cuisine, and Dealing With the Heat
description: When Rajesh Bhardwaj, who co-founded the Cafe Spice chain in 1997, decided to open a new Indian restaurant, he had something very different in mind from the typical hole in the wall a diner might find on East Sixth Street or in Jackson Heights, Queens. With hand-hewn stone walls, an antique wood palace gate and a long reflecting pool leading to a soaring dining room, Junoon, on 24th Street west of Fifth Avenue, offers high-toned food that spans Indias many regions and cooking techniques, formal service and an extensive wine list  with prices to match. Open since December, the restaurant has attracted affluent Indian immigrants like Salman Rushdie, guests from the Wyndham Garden hotel down the block and, on Tuesday evening, two friends chatting about work.

title: Unrest Around the Region
description: LIBYA There were violent demonstrations in Benghazi, Libyas second-largest city, for a third day. Human rights groups said 24 people had been killed across the country, although activists say the count could be much higher.

title: When Parents Are Pushed to the Limit
description: To the Editor:

title: Comfort With Riviera Course Carries Couples to Lead
description: LOS ANGELES  Fred Couples is 51 and can no longer practice. His back is so creaky that he cannot hit iron shots during his truncated pre-round warm-ups for fear he will tweak a disk and bring on spasms. As for post-round work, he just laughs and says he cannot recall the last time he did any.

title: The Cause of Democracy
description: To the Editor:

title: Beltran in Center? The Mets Will See
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Carlos Beltran played in only 64 games last year, and during much of that time he looked nothing like the superstar player he had been for most of his career. But in the last month of the season, and especially the final 14 games, the old Beltran reappeared, giving hope to the possibility that he could again become the Mets best all-around player.

title: Afghan Womens Shelters
description: To the Editor:

title: France: Commentator Convicted for Inciting Racial Bias
description: A French court on Friday convicted the prominent commentator ric Zemmour on charges of provocation to racial discrimination for televised comments in which he suggested that a majority of criminals in France were black and Arab, and said that employers have the right to deny employment to those ethnic groups. Mr. Zemmour was ordered to pay over $14,000 in legal fees and damages to the five rights groups that were the plaintiffs in the case, and also received suspended fines totaling $2,700. The commentator had gone beyond the permitted bounds of the right to freedom of speech, the court wrote in its decision, adding that Mr. Zemmour had a particular responsibility to respect those limits as a professional of the media and of expression. Mr. Zemmours lawyer, Olivier Pardo, said his client had not yet decided if he would appeal the decision.

title: Church Sex Abuse Scandal
description: To the Editor:

title: Vatican: Warning on Ticket Sales
description: The Vatican issued a rare statement on Friday warning people not to be fooled by agencies and Web sites selling tickets for the beatification of Pope John Paul II. It said no tickets were required for the ceremonies, in particular for the beatification Mass, which Pope Benedict XVI is expected to celebrate on May 1. Millions of visitors are expected in Rome for festivities surrounding the beatification of John Paul, which places him one step closer to sainthood. After the Mass on May 1, John Pauls tomb will be moved from beneath St. Peters Basilica to its interior, where his remains will be on view.

title: Less Crime, Fewer Prisons
description: To the Editor:

title: Primed to Pick Up Where Pettitte Left Off
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Each of the 51 pitches Andy Pettitte threw for the Class AA Trenton Thunder last Sept. 9 was dutifully tracked by Manny Banuelos, a teenager sitting a few rows behind home plate who grew up in Mexico admiring the man on the mound, the modern-day patron saint of Yankee left-handers. That night Banuelos charted Pettittes velocity and his location, his selection and his movement, and afterward he had an epiphany.

title: Apollos $48.9 Million Man
description: Apollo Global Management filed the seventh amendment to its filing with securities regulators late on Friday as its prepared for its long-awaited public listing on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Ligetys Victory Helps U.S. Break Through
description: Ted Ligety came into last years Winter Olympics a medal favorite, especially given his status as a defending Olympic champion. Four members of the United States team combined to win a record eight medals in Vancouver, but Ligety did not reach the award podium.

title: Three Days at the Pearl Roundabout
description: Manama, Bahrain

title: Burke Shows Kaberle Respect While Maximizing His Trade Value
description: In trading Tomas Kaberle to Boston for a prospect, a first-round pick and a conditional pick on Friday, Toronto General Manager Brian Burke pulled off a rarity in the business of hockey transactions: he gotboth aspects of a complicated deal right.

title: Sacred Cows, Angry Birds
description: The House of Representatives has been cutting like crazy! Down with Planned Parenthood and PBS! We cant afford to worry about mercury contamination! Safety nets are too expensive!

title: Empire at the End of Decadence
description: Its time for us to stop lying to ourselves about this country.

title: Democrats Propose Temporary Budget Extension
description: With a debate over government spending raging on the House floor, Democrats late Friday night proposed a temporary extension of the stopgap measure now financing the government that would maintain expenditures generally at 2010 levels through March 31 and avert a federal shutdown.

title: Bloggingheads: Trains to Nowhere?
description: Bill Scher, left, of the Campaign for America's Future and Kristen Soltis of the Winston Group debate high-speed rail.

title: Devils Top Rangers for 6th Win in Row
description: NEWARK  The roaring crowd at the Prudential Center might have begun to believe that the Devils could continue their improbable run at a playoff berth. But for Coach Jacques Lemaire, it is much too soon for such talk.

title: Resilient Bond Between Sports and the Military
description: When Rep. Betty McCollum, Democrat of Minnesota, decided to take on Nascar last month, she did not know until midfight what she was getting into. All she knew was that everyone was being asked to make deep budget cuts and sacrifices and the Department of Defense said that it had no fat to cut.

title: How Foreclosure and Bankruptcy Damage Your Credit Score
description: In this weekends Your Money column, Tara Siegel Bernard explains what happens to your credit score when you pay multiple bills late, your home goes into foreclosure or you file for personal bankruptcy. She also gives readers a blueprint for repairing your credit report and credit score once the worst has happened.

title: Low Point of Season Was Turning Point
description: It was not until St. Johns worst loss of the season that Coach Steve Lavin realized what could become of the team he inherited.

title: Dave Duerson, Safety Who Made Pro Bowl 4 Times, Is Dead at 50
description: Dave Duerson, a four-time Pro Bowl safety who won Super Bowls with the Chicago Bears and the Giants, died on Thursday. He was 50.

title: Teufel Is Sued Over Madoff Tie
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Tim Teufel, the Mets Class AAA manager in Buffalo, has long been known to have been an investor in Bernard L. Madoffs multibillion-dollar Ponzi scheme. Now Teufel, like his Mets employers, is being sued by the trustee for the victims of Madoffs fraud, who says Teufel profited from the crime.

title: Teenage Wastelands
description: Vampires live forever, but vampire novels, even ones as popular as the Twilight series, eventually molder just like everything else, so publishers of young-adult fiction and the moviemakers who find inspiration from them have already moved on from fantasy about the undead to science fiction. A harbinger of whats to come is I Am Number Four, based on the novel of the same title, which just opened in theaters. I Am Number Four, sold to DreamWorks even before it found a publisher, is ostensibly the work of one Pittacus Lore, an extraterrestrial. Its really by James Frey, the author of the factually challenged memoir A Million Little Pieces, and Jobie Hughes, a minion hired as part of Freys latest project: Full Fathom Five, a literary sweatshop modeled on Damien Hirsts art factory and designed to churn out Y.A. material for books, movies and TV.

title: Medicaid and New Yorks Budget
description: New York State spent more than $20 billion on Medicaid this fiscal year  or nearly a quarter of the total operating budget. With the state confronting a projected $10 billion deficit for next year, Gov. Andrew Cuomo has little choice but to cut back the program. The challenge will be to do that in a way that causes the least possible harm to some of the states most vulnerable citizens.

title: The Virtual Attic
description: Last week, I moved to a new laptop. Because the new laptop is so fast and so baronially spacious, I went probing among the files to see if I could create a little more free space just for the fun of it. It was a nostalgic experience.

title: Criminal Inquiry of Countrywide Chief Has Ended
description: Feb. 20 | Updated The New York Timess Gretchen Morgenson has more on federal prosecutors dropping their case against Angelo R. Mozilo.

title: Long Arms Reach for the Rim
description: JUBA, Sudan  His first two attempts sprung off the back of the rim, the ball careening through the air, the crowd sighing loudly. Mangistu Deng, 16, dribbled back to halfcourt, pounding the ball for his final dunk of the night.

title: Photo Replay: Feb. 18
description: Pictures from the day in sports: winter sports, an opening day, and a foggy day for fishing.

title: House Votes to Continue Army Sponsorships in Nascar
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla.  The House voted 281-148 on Friday to defeat an amendment to a larger government financing bill offered by Rep. Betty McCollum, Democrat of Minnesota, that would have ended the Armys spending on Nascar racing.

title: Somali Pirates Hijack Yacht With Americans Aboard
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  It is becoming a familiar tale of the Somali seas: A retired couple sets out for the trip of a lifetime, sailing around the world in a relatively small yacht, blogging all the way, sharing adventures of meeting people, seeing exotic locales and experiencing the thrill of being totally free.

title: As House Votes to Cut $60 Billion, Standoff Looms
description: WASHINGTON  The House vote Saturday to slash more than $60 billion from the federal budget shows how powerfully the anti-spending fervor of the fall elections is driving the new Republican majoritys efforts to shrink government. It puts the two parties on a path to a succession of showdowns over the deficit and the nations growing debt.

title: Dave Duerson, a Member of the Magical 1985 Bears
description: Andy Barall writes about pro football history for The Fifth Down. Dave Duerson died on Thursday at age 50. Dave Duerson was an important contributor to one of the most interesting and colorful defenses in N.F.L. history: the mid-80s Chicago Bears. It was also one of the greatest. At its peak, in 1985, that defense wouldnt just stop opponents, it would frequently intimidate and embarrass them. In his famous 46 defense, Buddy Ryan created a new role for the strong safety and Duerson fit the bill perfectly.

title: The Weekend Word: Clocks Ticking
description: From Todays Times:Forging ahead amid speculation about a government shutdown, House Republicans pushed to approve the largest spending cuts in recent history Friday. Time is running out before the governments current funding plan expires, leaving just two weeks for Congress to come to an agreement  one week of which will be spent in recess. And The Timess David M. Herszenhorn reports even a temporary agreement might be too difficult to reach in time.

title: Protesters Take Bahrain Square as Forces Leave
description: MANAMA, Bahrain  Thousands of jubilant protesters surged back into the symbolic heart of Bahrain on Saturday as the government withdrew its security forces, calling for calm after days of violent crackdowns.

title: A Less Virtual Keypad for the iPhone
description: When people complain about the iPhone, one of the loudest complaints is the phones lack of a physical keypad. For many, no physical keys is a deal-breaker, driving consumers to a BlackBerry or Android phone instead.

title: The Murdoch in Waiting
description: LONDON

title: Feb. 19: Updates on Middle East Protests
description: On Saturday, The Lede continues to follow protest movements in Bahrain, Libya, Yemen, Iran, Iraq and Egypt. Updates below mix alerts on breaking news with reports from bloggers and journalists on the ground. A stream of Twitter messages on the protests is in this blogs right column.

title: Bad Central Bankers
description: Via Yves Smith, the Guardian has picked up on my remarks about Mervyn Kings politicization.

title: Thank You, Boeing
description: For providing such a clear illustration of the forces driving the theory of the firm.

title: Wisconsin
description: Yes, Im on it. Getting all my facts in a row before I comment.

title: Laugh Lines
description: JAY LENO

title: Fighting Words
description: The BBC asked the British novelist Martin Amis whether he would ever write a childrens book. His answer tipped a few teacups in the nursery.

title: Prime Number
description: 10: The number of milliseconds it took the I.B.M. computer Watson to buzz in when confident of its response during a game of Jeopardy! Watsons competition, the former champions Ken Jennings and Brad Rutter, usually looked like Old West fighters who couldnt quite draw their guns out of their holsters fast enough. Ten milliseconds, or a centisecond, is one-hundredth of a second. By the way, thats much faster than the blink of an eye.

title: Delirious Joy in Bahrain
description: BAHRAIN  Theres delirious joy in the center of Bahrain right now. People power has prevailed, at least temporarily, over a regime that repeatedly used deadly force to try to crush a democracy movement. Pro-democracy protesters have retaken the Pearl Roundabout  the local version of Tahrir Square  from the government. On a spot where blood was shed several days ago there are now vast throngs kissing the earth, chanting slogans, cheering, honking and celebrating. People handed me flowers and the most common quotation I heard was: Its unbelievable!

title: Dolphins to Boats: Put a Cork in It
description: Noise has increased a hundredfold in many parts of the ocean over the last 50 years, according to National Geographic, a result of dramatic growth in shipping and other human activities. The problem is getting steadily worse for another reason. Seawater is absorbing less sound as carbon dioxide from fossil-fuel burning seeps into the ocean and acidifies it. For many of these animals its as if they live in cities, Brandon Southall, a marine scientist, says of the din. The noise has led to changes in foraging, calling and migration patterns among many species of whales and dolphins.

title: Uganda President Takes Big Lead in Re-Election Bid
description: KAMPALA, Uganda  President Yoweri Museveni appeared to take a commanding early lead on Saturday in the presidential election here, capturing nearly 69 percent of the vote, with about 77 percent of polling sites reporting, a government Web site showed.

title: Fashion in 1943
description: With World War II in full throttle, the federal government imposed regulations restricting the use of wool, silk, leather and nylon in clothing. Designers thus faced the challenge of doing more with less. How did they respond? With astounding ingenuity, The Timess Virginia Pope reported at the time. For designers, Ms. Pope reported, the limitations imposed were an asset rather than a hindrance. They evolved a new silhouette  one that will go down in fashion history as the duration silhouette. It is sleek, slim, functional, expressive of active American womanhood.

title: Kathleen Mortimer, Rich and Adventurous, Dies at 93
description: Her grandfather ran a railroad, and her father was an ambassador, a governor and a cabinet secretary. She married the grandson of an oil baron at her familys 25,000-acre estate.

title: Variety: And Sometimes My Diagramless
description: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE  Confused by the title? You wont be, once you solve.

title: Asking for a Lot, Perhaps Too Much, from St. Louis
description: Ever since Albert Pujolss self-imposed deadline for a new contract with the St. Louis Cardinals passed Wednesday without a deal, speculation has been rampant about whether he will re-sign, how much he could command as a free agent and whether he will be worth it. He is reportedly seeking $300 million over 10 years, and his employers are believed to have offered less than $200 million  a gap that is bigger than the entire value of all but a handful of contracts in history.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: As G20 Leaders Set Deal, Geithner Criticizes China
description: PARIS  Treasury Secretary Timothy F. Geithner took direct aim at China on Saturday at a meeting of the worlds most powerful economies, saying that its currency was still substantially undervalued and that recent steps taken by Beijing to adjust its value were too small.

title: Case on Mortgage Official Is Said to Be Dropped
description: Federal prosecutors in Los Angeles have dropped their criminal investigation into Angelo R. Mozilo, the former chief executive of Countrywide Financial, once the nations largest mortgage lender, according to a person with direct knowledge of the investigation.

title: Cycle of Suppression Rises in Libya and Elsewhere
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Libyan security forces moved against protesters Saturday in Benghazi, the countrys second-largest city and the epicenter of the most serious challenge to four decades of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafis rule, opposition leaders and residents said. The death toll rose to at least 104 people, most of them in Benghazi, Human Rights Watch reported.

title: Promising Female Player Stows Her Passport
description: Christen Press said she was exactly where she wanted to be, except that she probably is not.

title: Writing Danger in Ever-Larger Letters
description: THE stock market has been thrilling lately. Thanks to the marvel of the mobile Internet, Ive been able to check my account balances throughout the day, just for the pleasure of watching them rise  which is probably a sign that somethings wrong.

title: A Chance to Keep Up With New Technology (for a Price)
description: DONT get left behind, Best Buy advised us in a commercial during the Super Bowl.

title: Unrest Encircles Saudis, Stoking Sense of Unease
description: WASHINGTON  As pro-democracy uprisings spread across the Middle East, the rulers of Saudi Arabia  the regions great bulwark of religious and political conservatism  are feeling increasingly isolated and concerned that the United States may no longer be a reliable backer, officials and diplomats say.

title: Bahrain Protesters Retake Pearl Square
description: Protesters were jubilant as security forces withdrew and the people retook Pearl Square Saturday morning.

title: Yankees Will Miss Dr. Pettitte
description: TAMPA, Fla.

title: Sarah Ashfaq and Joshua Lantos
description: Sarah Ashfaq, a daughter of Ishrat S. Ashfaq and Muhammad Ashfaq of New Hyde Park, N.Y., is to be married Sunday afternoon in Glen Cove, N.Y., to Dr. Joshua Elliot Lantos, a son of Phyllis Lantos and Dr. George Lantos of Scarsdale, N.Y. Adnan A. Zulfiqar, the Muslim spiritual adviser at the University of Pennsylvania, is to lead the ceremony at the Glen Cove Mansion, an event space.

title: Anna York and Alejandro De La Cruz
description: Anna Ritland York and Alejandro Miguel De La Cruz were married on Monday in Norwalk, Calif. Sara C. Keating, a deputy commissioner of civil marriages who was sworn in for Valentines Day, officiated at a Los Angeles County Clerks office.

title: Life-Changing Accident, but an Unchanging Goal
description: Last year, Chad Jones was on the verge of fulfilling a lifelong dream. A two-sport athlete at Louisiana State, he was about to play in the N.F.L.

title: Michelle Oliver and Andrew Fisher
description: Michelle Aviva Oliver and Andrew Allan Fisher were married Saturday at the United Methodist Church in Morristown, N.J., by the Rev. Neill Tolboom, the churchs pastor.

title: Katherine Lehman, Benjamin Trumbull
description: Katherine Eberle Lehman and Benjamin Davis Trumbull were married Saturday at Prospect Plantation Chapel in Ocho Rios, Jamaica. The Rev. Wesley C.
