Boynes, a minister who was ordained by the Christ for the Nations Institute, a three-year Christian Bible institute in Dallas, performed a nondenominational ceremony.

title: Kathryn Slattery, Matthew Longo
description: Kathryn Elizabeth Slattery, the daughter of Kathryn B. Slattery and Thomas E. Slattery of New Canaan, Conn., was married Saturday to Matthew Thomas Longo, a son of Maureen Kelly Longo and Dr. William A. Longo of Middletown, Conn. The Rev. Richard J. Gemza performed the ceremony at St. Mary Church in Greenwich, Conn., where he is the parochial vicar.

title: Kelley Morrell, David Stolzar
description: Kelley Elizabeth Morrell and David Scott Stolzar were married Saturday at the Hay-Adams hotel in Washington. Larissa Chernock, a friend of the bride, officiated with the assistance of Christopher M. Mancuso, a friend of the bridegroom. Both became Universal Life ministers for the occasion.

title: Miranda Litt, Will Saunders
description: Miranda Beth Litt and Will Franklin Saunders are to be married Sunday at the Union League club in Philadelphia. Rabbi Shimon L. Berris is to officiate, with the Rev. James Harris, a United Methodist minister, taking part in the ceremony.

title: Lauren Clancy, Frederick Kammler
description: Lauren Cecily Clancy and Frederick Karl Kammler were married Saturday at the Coral Sands Hotel on Harbour Island in the Bahamas. Stephanie Rahming, the senior deputy administrator for the North Eleuthera district, officiated.

title: Lauren Berrol, Jeremy Soffin
description: Lauren Jennifer Berrol, the daughter of Jacki Berrol and Jerry J. Berrol of Syosset, N.Y., is to be married Sunday evening to Jeremy Seth Soffin, a son of Sandra Soffin and Rabbi Joel E. Soffin of Manhattan. The bridegrooms father is to officiate at the Angel Orensanz Foundation for the Arts in Manhattan.

title: Lydia Fenet, Christopher Delaney
description: Lydia Wickliffe Fenet and Christopher Barrett Delaney were married Saturday afternoon at Christ Church Cathedral in New Orleans. The Very Rev. J. Mark Holland, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Colleen Lang, Eduardo Crosa
description: Colleen Margaret Lang and Eduardo Luis Crosa were married Saturday at Holy Name of Jesus church in Brooklyn. The Rev. James K. Cunningham, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Sarah Slobodien, Edward-Isaac Dovere
description: Sarah Margalit Slobodien and Edward-Isaac Robert Dovere were married Saturday evening at the Academy of Music in Philadelphia. Rabbi Steven Lindemann officiated.

title: Evelyn Solis, Frank Pipitone
description: Evelyn Paz Solis and Frank Paul Pipitone were married Saturday at Brecknock Hall, a historic home in Greenport, N.Y. The Rev. Marie April Gismondi, a minister of the Church of Ancient Ways, officiated.

title: Elizabeth Githens, Douglass Coyle
description: Elizabeth Mildred Githens and Douglass Hamilton Coyle are to be married Sunday evening at the Central Park Boathouse in New York. Cantor Dorothy Goldberg is to officiate.

title: Leslie Klein, Ken Nahshon
description: Leslie Faith Klein, a daughter of Marcia Klein and Martin Klein of Lake Grove, N.Y., was married Saturday evening to Ken Nahshon, the son of Edna Nahshon and Gad Nahshon of New York. Rabbi Henry Glazer officiated at Battery Gardens, an event space in New York.

title: On Mondays, Look Forward to Coming In
description: This interview with Laura Ching, co-founder and chief merchandising officer of TinyPrints.com, an online card and stationery company, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

title: A Swarm of Wasps, if Not Investors
description: THE white paper by the Georgia scientists Glen C. Rains and W. Joe Lewis has a technical-sounding title that masks the exciting news within. A Project to Bring Innovative New Technology Into the Market Place for Detecting Agents of Harm in Agriculture, Security, and Human Health/Safety Arenas, it says blandly.

title: Independent Scholars: A Nomadic Lot
description: IN 1992, I quit my teaching job at the University of Arkansas, put everything into storage, cashed in my life savings  a stupendous $10,000  and moved to Rome to begin the first phase of research for a project that has become my lifes work. My money ran out nine months later, but by then the project had begun to take on a life of its own, and I had become an independent scholar.

title: The Family-Business Test
description: MY father, Tino, started our family business, an electronic assembly and manufacturing company, in 1991 because he was tired of all the reorganizations and layoffs at high-tech companies where he worked. Hes Hispanic and a Vietnam veteran and always wanted to be an entrepreneur. The layoffs pushed him to do it.

title: Attackers Wearing Army Uniforms Make Deadly Assault on Bank in Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  As Afghan soldiers and police officers lined up on Saturday to get their monthly salaries at a bank in downtown Jalalabad, they became targets for seven heavily armed attackers in Army uniforms who had joined them, Afghan officials said.

title: Two Cosmetics Giants, Flaws and All
description: THERE is a wonderful anecdote about the great Helena Rubinstein in Ugly Beauty: Helena Rubinstein, LOral and the Blemished History of Looking Good (HarperCollins). One morning in 1964, not long before her death at the (approximate) age of 92, three armed robbers disguised as flower deliverymen gained entrance to her Park Avenue apartment, where she was in bed, eating breakfast.

title: Can Both Sides Win?
description: To the Editor:

title: Doing Just Fine, Thanks
description: To the Editor:

title: How a Whistle-Blower Conquered Countrywide
description: WHAT does it take to hold your powerful bosses accountable if they try to bully you out the door?

title: Not the Driver, but the Driving Force
description: Chad Knaus was sitting in his small, meticulous office one day last month, preparing for the Nascar Sprint Cup season and pondering the absurd.

title: Recipe for Coke? One More to Add to the File
description: ATLANTA    Over the years, the public radio show This American Life has done some ambitious work. It was the first media outlet in the country to broadcast lengthy interviews with Guantnamo Bay prisoners. It sent reporters to Iraq for a month. And it exposed the misdeeds of a hedge fund.

title: The Tigers Are Supporting Their Star Through Another Setback
description: LAKELAND, Fla.  The Detroit Tigers held their first full-squad workout of spring training on Saturday, but their best player was not here. First baseman Miguel Cabrera is home in South Florida, awaiting a doctors evaluation after his arrest on suspicion of drunken driving.

title: Bronx Man Is Linked to Two Rapes a Decade Apart
description: The authorities have linked a 39-year-old Bronx man who they believe raped a woman in the Bronx in November with another rape in the Bronx in 2000.

title: Boom Time to Bankruptcy
description: Over eight years, the federal government paid at least $20 million for counterterrorism video technology that documents and interviews suggest to be a hoax.

title: Hiding Details of Dubious Deal, U.S. Invokes National Security
description: WASHINGTON  For eight years, government officials turned to Dennis Montgomery, a California computer programmer, for eye-popping technology that he said could catch terrorists. Now, federal officials want nothing to do with him and are going to extraordinary lengths to ensure that his dealings with Washington stay secret.

title: A Season of Giving Motivates Donors in Greater Numbers
description: The 99th New York Times Neediest Cases Fund campaign began Nov. 7 and ended Jan. 30. Daily articles in the newspaper and online offered a window into the lives of New Yorkers coping with poverty and spotlighted how the fund helped ease some of their struggles.

title: Ernie Tyler, the Ironman of Umpire Attendants, Dies at 86
description: In the sports world, showing up for work every day is so valued that consecutive-game streaks are hallowed in the record books. Lou Gehrig, the Yankees first baseman known as the Iron Horse, for example, played in 2,130 straight games, a record that seemed unassailable until Cal Ripken, the Baltimore Orioles infielder, broke it; his streak reached 2,632 games.

title: Can You Frisk a Hard Drive?
description: If you stand with the Customs and Border Protection officers who staff the passport booths at Dulles airport near the nations capital, their task seems daunting. As a huge crowd of weary travelers shuffle along in serpentine lines, inspectors make quick decisions by asking a few questions (often across language barriers) and watching computer displays that dont go much beyond name, date of birth and codes for a previous customs problem or an outstanding arrest warrant.

title: Protests Continue to Surge
description: Thousands of jubilant Bahrainis returned on Saturday to Manamas Pearl Square, the focal point of bloody anti-regime demonstrations, after police and troops withdrew in an apparent conciliatory move.

title: Twilight of the Teen Idol
description: The Beliebers were out in force last weekend. You could see them in Justin Bieber: Never Say Never, the rushed-to-market movie  as much documentary about fandom as concert film  that had opening-weekend ticket sales of more than $30 million. On screen, Mr. Biebers fans were everywhere, a screaming and devoted army, more emotive and compelling than the object of their affection. In the audience of the movie theater where I saw the film, they were also screaming and devoted, gasping when Mr. Bieber was seen shirtless and cooing when his baby pictures were shown.

title: For Wisconsin Governor, Battle Was Long Coming
description: MADISON, Wis.  Just last fall, people here were waving campaign signs. But the blocks around the State Capitol have been filled for the past week with protesters brandishing signs with a different message  demanding a recall of Gov. Scott Walker, calling him a bully and likening him to Scrooge, Hosni Mubarak, even Hitler.

title: More on Defense
description: A few followup points to my earlier note:

title: So Much on the Line for Miguel Cabrera
description: LAKELAND, Fla.  The Detroit Tigers held their first full-squad workout of spring training on Saturday, but Miguel Cabrera was home in South Florida. He is awaiting a doctors evaluation after his arrest Wednesday on suspicion of drunken driving.

title: Monopoly, Milton Friedmans Way
description: When Hasbro showed a new version of Monopoly last week at the Toy Fair, people were aghast that an infrared tower in the center of the board would squawk instructions, track players money and make sure that everyone abided by the rules.

title: The Legacy of 18 Days in Tahrir Square
description: CAIRO  Tahrir means liberation in Arabic, but until three weeks ago, Tahrir Squares name hardly fitted it. Egyptians would drive around it, stuck in their cars, incessantly honking their horns, to get past a congested downtown traffic circle before veering off in different directions.

title: Par 140? Twitter Hits the PGA Tour
description: LOS ANGELES  The generational contrast between the not-so-tech-savvy 36-hole leader of the Northern Trust Open and the PGA Tours use of social networking last week is evidence of golfs ability to span decades and gracefully embrace change.

title: Reporting While Female
description: Last winter, I reported on a religious festival in Pakistan, attended by thousands of worshipers. There were no women, at least that I could see. As I waded through the crowds, I held my breath, looking behind me every few seconds, warding off gropers, pushing them away with my hands.

title: Anthony Draws the Line With Nets
description: LOS ANGELES  Carmelo Anthony is informing those close to him that he will not sign a contract extension if he is traded to the Nets, according to a person aware of Anthonys preference.

title: When Armies Decide
description: WASHINGTON  There comes a moment in the life of almost every repressive regime when leaders  and the military forces that have long kept them in power  must make a choice from which there is usually no turning back: Change or start shooting.

title: Dueling Protests in a Capital as Nothing Much Gets Done
description: MADISON, Wis.  In a capital city overrun for much of the past week by union supporters, state employees and students  all objecting to the Republican governors plan to cut collective bargaining rights and benefits for public workers  a new element was introduced on Saturday: opposition to the opposition.

title: Jilted in the U.S., a Site Finds Love in India
description: IN 2008, three young guys in Manhattan started Ignighter.com, a dating Web site focused on twentysomethings. They sought to set themselves apart by enabling members to set up group dates: One member, serving as a point person, could arrange a date  a movie, say, or a picnic in Central Park  with a group of other people and thereby take some of the awkward edge off of typical dates.

title: Why We Need Women in War Zones
description: THOUSANDS of men blocked the road, surrounding the S.U.V. of the chief justice of Pakistan, a national hero for standing up to military rule. As a correspondent for The Chicago Tribune, I knew I couldnt just watch from behind a car window. I had to get out there.

title: Levine Misses Don Pasquale Matinee
description: James Levine, the music director of the Metropolitan Opera, withdrew from a matinee performance of Don Pasquale on Saturday because of illness, the house said.

title: Pediatrician Facing Claims of Sex Abuse Dies at Home
description: Dr. Melvin D. Levine, 71, a pediatrician and a leader in the field of learning disabilities, died in North Carolina a day after a sexual abuse and malpractice suit was filed against him in Boston.

title: Democracy Welcomed, but Risk Remains
description: The Op-Ed columnist Nicholas D. Kristof on the withdrawal of security forces from Pearl Square and Bahrain's democratic future.

title: Generation Hot Meets Generation Coal
description: [Feb. 21, 1:59 p.m. | Updated  Mark Hertsgaard has posted a piece defending his push against climate cranks, including an apology for his errant description of his relationship with Politico.]

title: Sunday: Gift From Above
description: SUNDAYS PUZZLE  Im going to start by saying that its very difficult for me, as a writer and a constructor, to resist making a joke or pun where one so clearly needs to be made. Theres one here today, based on Liz Gorskis puzzle, but Im going to be disciplined and professional. I want you to know upfront that Im going to try to get through this post without making this joke, because you are all very smart and it will most likely give away the theme. So Im going to keep my mouth shut.

title: The Weeks Business News in Pictures
description: Photos from the news and features this past week in the business world.

title: Nevada Seeks to Cut Funds for Treating Gambling Addiction
description: Gordie Greco was hooked on gambling almost from the first time he shot dice at age 16. And for 35 years, gambling was his life: he worked in the industry and made his own bets on sports and horses.

title: Along the Columbia, Concerns for Salmon and Energy Production
description: STARBUCK, Wash.  The governor of Montana invited himself to Washington State not long ago to explain to people who live along the Columbia River why they should help Montana export its coal across the Pacific Ocean to China.

title: Detroit Symphony Cancels Season as Musicians Strike
description: The management of the debt-burdened Detroit Symphony Orchestra canceled the rest of its season on Saturday, after executives and the players failed to resolve a strike that has lasted four and a half months.

title: Lincoln Center
description: New York City, Feb. 20, 1861

title: Madagascar Bars Entry to President Ousted in 09
description: JOHANNESBURG  Madagascars ousted president, Marc Ravalomanana, was prevented from boarding a commercial flight here on Saturday, stymieing his attempt to return home after two years in exile.

title: Oil Flows, but High Prices Jangle Nerves
description: PARIS  The turmoil in North Africa and the Middle East has helped drive oil prices up to more than $102 a barrel for an important benchmark crude, Brent, although so far there have been no significant disruptions in production or supply, according to experts at the International Energy Agency here.

title: A Monopoly on Cheating
description: I HATE cheats. They cut the line and snatch the bargain. They sweet-talk the customer service rep into bending the rules. They count cards and win the raffle with some sneaky ticket placement. They are the 100th caller every time. They trick you on mileage or square footage and bribe their way up the organ transplant list. They pump and dump their stocks, their families, their friends. They get ahead and they win. We lose. Then they explain ever so condescendingly that its not a zero-sum game.

title: Russian Trial to Bare a Face of Nationalism
description: MOSCOW  It once seemed as if Nikita Tikhonov was positioning himself to join this countrys political elite: he attended the prestigious Moscow State University, founded a right-wing political magazine called The Russian Way and worked as a campaign aide for a parliamentary candidate.

title: The G.O.P.s Post-Tucson Traumatic Stress Disorder
description: SIX weeks after that horrific day in Tucson, America has half-forgotten its violent debate over the power of violent speech to incite violence. Its Gabrielle Giffordss own power of speech that rightly concerns us now. But all those arguments over political language did leave a discernible legacy. In the aftermath of President Obamas Tucson sermon, civility has had a mini-restoration in Washington. And some of the most combative national figures in our politics have been losing altitude ever since, much as they did after Bill Clintons oratorical response to the inferno of Oklahoma City.

title: Winds Topple National Christmas Tree
description: WASHINGTON  High winds whipped through the metropolitan Washington area on Saturday, downing power lines, fueling brush fires and even toppling the National Christmas Tree.

description: John Drew believes, quaintly, that we are our brothers keeper.

title: At Garden, a Last-Second Layup Drops, and Pitt Is the Latest to Fall
description: St. Johns has burnished its N.C.A.A. tournament rsum by making a habit of upsetting top-10 teams at Madison Square Garden. Now, with the Red Storm seemingly assured a bid, it is most likely playing for style points and seeding.

description: Defense Secretary Robert Gates understands that the country cannot keep issuing blank checks to the Pentagon and that the Pentagon needs to spend more rationally and efficiently.

description: Washington

title: Texas Tech Beats No. 1 Baylor, 56-45
description: LUBBOCK, Tex.  Another blow was delivered that will be felt throughout womens basketball when Baylor and Texas Tech met on Saturday. Unlike when the squads played here a year ago, no blood flowed, only tears as the unranked Lady Raiders stopped the top-ranked Lady Bears 21-game winning streak with a 56-45 victory.

description: To the Editor:

title: Fat Monkeys
description: Scientists are using monkeys, primarily rhesus macaques, to study the twin epidemics of obesity and diabetes. The animals eat high-fat diets and lead sedentary lives. As one researcher says, We are trying to induce the couch potato style.

title: Todays Lab Rats of Obesity: Furry Couch Potatoes
description: HILLSBORO, Ore.  Like many these days, Shiva sits around too much, eating rich, fatty foods and sipping sugary drinks. He has the pot belly to prove it, one that nearly touches the floor  when hes on all fours, that is.

title: Chicago Candidates Skirt Financial Crisis
description: When voters go to the polls Tuesday to pick Chicagos first new mayor since the 1980s, they can reflect on a lively campaign that featured topics ranging from education and crime to whether one of the mayoral hopefuls had smoked crack.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Feb. 20
description: The House of Representatives burned the midnight oil last week, passing a continuing resolution with more than $60 billion in spending cuts shortly after 4:30 a.m. Saturday. With two weeks to hammer out an agreement in Congress and sidestep a government shutdown, the budget joins the Middle East uprisings as the dominant topics on the Sunday talk shows.

title: Patrick Makes Progress, and Stewart Prevails
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla.  Danica Patrick led a lap at Daytona International Speedway on Saturday, a sign of progress that Patrick, Nascars next great marketing hope, is getting up to speed in racing stock cars for a living. But there was no storybook ending for Patrick or her boss, Dale Earnhardt Jr., in the lower-level Drive4Copd 300 Nationwide Series race.

title: The Tricky Terrain of Education Finances
description: Ross Ramsey, the managing editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column.

title: Algeria Mostly Calm, but Dissent Is Present
description: The type of violence that has plagued other Middle Eastern countries has only erupted a few times lately in Algeria, where an older, oil-rich generation holds sway and younger protesters have been kept under control so far.

title: Crawley Town Is Out of F.A. Cup, and So Is Chelsea
description: Crawley Town, which stands a mere 93 places below Manchester United on the English soccer ladder, held its own with the Premier League leaders at Old Trafford before falling, 1-0, in the fifth round of the F.A. Cup on Saturday. Crawley was joined on the exit ramp by Chelsea, which lost to Tim Howard and Everton on penalties. Read more here and click the headline above to comment.

title: Power Failures Thrust Deregulation Into Public Glare
description: For the Texas power industry, this has been a time of soul-searching angst. Three weeks ago, dozens of the states power generators failed in frigid weather, causing the worst blackouts in years and prompting multiple investigations. State lawmakers are demanding to know what went wrong.

title: Corrections
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: The Unemployed Need Not Apply
description: The Federal Reserve is projecting unemployment to continue at or near 9 percent for the rest of the year. That is 13.9 million Americans out of work. Here is more grim news: Barriers to employment for jobless workers may be even higher than previously thought.

title: This Just In ...
description: President Obama is not a foreigner. He is not secretly a Muslim. Those are the facts, but they do not seem to matter in many quadrants of the Republican Party.

title: Italys Trials
description: Italian governments are rarely known for efficiency. But even the countrys most pressing problems are being ignored since a court ruled last week that Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi must stand trial on charges of prostitution with an under-age girl and abusing his office to cover it up.

title: Lawmakers May Come to Charter Schools Aid
description: It took seven years for Houston-based Harmony Public Schools, the states largest charter network and one of its best academically, to secure a bank bond in 2007 to buy and remodel buildings on its 33 campuses. Since then, it has obtained two additional bonds  the most recent for $90 million issued last year  to continue its expansion.

title: The Justices and Political Activity
description: To the Editor:

title: Pats Pick: The Best New Restaurant in Texas Right Now
description: The best new restaurant

title: Amid All-Star Din, Relative Quiet From Anthony
description: LOS ANGELES

title: Woodlawn Memorial Park
description: The remains of one of San Franciscos most celebrated characters, Joshua Abraham Norton, are buried on a green slope at Woodlawn Memorial Park in the town of Colma, south of San Francisco. Admirers of that lovable 19th-century eccentric gather there annually to celebrate his birthday. HANK PELLISSIER

title: As Chorus Swells, Griffin Leaps Car to Win Contest
description: LOS ANGELES  Blake Griffin spent the first part of his rookie season dangerously jumping over, through and around people in providing a montage of YouTube clips of himself assaulting rims. In the All-Star weekends slam-dunk contest  an event that seemed tailor-made for Griffin  he tried the same, only a car stood as his obstacle.

title: Vows: Mia & Andrew
description: After Mia Oliver accompanied Andrew Fisher to pickup a dog from a shelter, their bond was strengthened.

title: Baddeley and His Closest Pursuers All Feel Win Is a Long Time Coming
description: LOS ANGELES  It has been a long time between PGA Tour victories for the top four players on the leader board going into the final round of the Northern Trust Open, and the difference on Sunday may just come down to which of them has the longest memory.

title: Mets Dickey Is Writing a Self-Portrait, Warts and All
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  About five years ago, around the time that R. A. Dickey decided to dig his fingernails into a baseball full time and cross a boundary into the eccentric, lonely world of a knuckleball pitcher, he also began to get a grip on his life as a husband, father, friend and son.

title: Santi Santamara, Catalan Chef, Dies at 53
description: MADRID  Santi Santamara, a chef and restaurant owner who helped raise the international profile of Spanish cuisine but invited controversy by criticizing avant-garde chefs and their techniques, including the use of chemical emulsifiers, died on Wednesday in Singapore. He was 53.

title: For One Teenage Champion, Moscow Is a Charmed City
description: Le Quang Liem startled the chess world last year when he won the top section of the prestigious Aeroflot Open in Moscow. He was 18 and had just entered the top 100.

title: Protests and Counterprotests in Wisconsin
description: As protesters objecting to the Republican governors plan to cut collective bargaining rights and benefits for public workers rallied at the state Capitol, supporters of the bill also gathered.

title: A Candidate for Mayor? Lee Says He Isnt One
description: With eight months left until the November election, the semiofficial list of candidates for mayor of San Francisco looks something like this: a city attorney, a state senator, three former supervisors, the tax assessor and a Silicon Valley businesswoman.

title: At the Free University, in a Store Basement, the Tuition Price Is Right
description: The newest university to open its doors in San Francisco has no official curriculum, no accredited course work, no grades and no paid teachers.

title: Gifted Programs Go on Block as Schools Must Do With Less
description: When she was just 3, Teela Huff understood how to add numbers. By third grade, she was tutoring her peers.

title: A Quest to Add Sophistication to Beers Appeal
description: Like soaring architecture, wily crooks and hard-hitting sports, a good beer is something Chicagoans love. Ray Daniels has gone one further: He wants to know exactly what makes a good beer good and use that knowledge to improve the beer-drinking experience.

title: In Farewell, a Blueprint for Running Chicago
description: James Warren writes a column for the Chicago News Cooperative.

title: Teixeira Tries New Approach After Down Year
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Routines are normally standard fare for Mark Teixeira, the son of a former Navy pilot, but not after last season. Instead of playing golf or riding a bike during that first, dark month of the off-season, he rehabilitated his torn hamstring. Instead of easing into his hitting program, he accelerated it, even buying a pitching machine to use as he pleased. Instead of spending a free half-hour in the weight room, he would take swings left-handed, searching for the consistency that eluded him in 2010.

title: Before Suicide, Duerson Said He Wanted Brain Study
description: Before he shot himself fatally in the chest Thursday, the former Chicago Bears defensive back Dave Duerson sent family members text messages requesting that his brain tissue be examined for the same damage recently found in other retired players, two people aware of the messages said Saturday night.

title: Outdoor Classics Spawn Border Brouhaha
description: The N.H.L.s second Heritage Classic will be played Sunday at McMahon Stadium in Calgary, a revival of the leagues first regular-season outdoor game from eight years ago designed to feature two Canadian teams. The first game matched the Montreal Canadiens against the host Edmonton Oilers. Montreal will once again provide the opposition, this time for the Flames.

title: Biding Time in Atlanta
description: Michael Gearon Jr., part of the Atlanta Thrashers ownership group, said last Wednesday that there was a sense of urgency over the long-futile search for new investors in the club, which according to court documents has lost more than $130 million since 2005.

title: Basketball Grows With Peace in South Sudan
description: As violence has declined, young people in southern Sudan are rekindling an interest in basketball. Some Sudanese are among the tallest people in the world.

title: Photo Replay: Feb. 19
description: Pictures of the day in sports: injuries, hopes and celebrations.

title: Fire at 6-Story Building in Brooklyn
description: 11:20 a.m. | Updated A 62-year-old retired guidance counselor was killed and hundreds of residents were displaced Saturday night when a five-alarm blaze ripped through a six-story residential building in Brooklyn.

title: Progress of Negotiations Is Hidden in Semantics
description: LOS ANGELES  In the vaguest of terms, and in the loosest semantics, the N.B.A. and its players union inched toward each other this weekend in their stalled collective bargaining talks. Even that slim bit of progress is subject to some debate.

title: Koufax, a Madoff Investor, Offers Support to Wilpon
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  There was a full roster of Bernard L. Madoff investors at Mets camp Saturday, with Sandy Koufax, Fred Wilpon and Tim Teufel all on hand. On Thursday, Wilpon addressed the situation surrounding his investments in Madoffs multibillion-dollar Ponzi scheme, and on Saturday, Teufel and Koufax took their turns.

title: Rolls-Royce Goes Electric for Geneva Auto Show
description: The Rolls-Royce Phantoms prodigious V-12 engine, capable of compelling nearly three tons of iron, leather and exotic hardwoods from a standstill to 60 miles per hour in under six ticks of a Piaget watch, has new competition, and it comes with a plug port.

title: Deficits Reshape the Debate as Republicans Jockey for 2012
description: WASHINGTON  Gov. Mitch Daniels of Indiana described the nations fiscal condition in dark terms more often reserved for a terror threat, declaring, We face an enemy lethal to liberty and even more implacable than those America has defeated before.

title: Lottery Numbers
In a Town Built Upon Patronage, a Test of Egypts New Order
description: BAGOUR, Egypt  In a town he represented in Parliament for 46 years, Kamal al-Shazli left his mark. There is the Kamal al-Shazli School on Kamal al-Shazli Street, around the corner from the Kamal al-Shazli Mosque, which is a little ways from the cafe where Mr. Shazli held court when he was the only man in town who got things done.

title: 3 Rangers on Their American Youth Hockey Memories
description: To mark Hockey Day in America, we asked three U.S.-born Rangers for their memories of growing up playing the great winter game. Brandon Dubinsky, from Anchorage, Alaska, talked about the outdoor rinks associated with every school in town. Michael Sauer, from Sartell, Minn., remembered the town fire department coming by to help make kids backyard rinks. Ryan McDonagh, from the Twin Cities suburb of Arden Hills, spoke about the second-hand Zamboni that anyone could use to resurface the park rink.

title: A Night of Greek Drama
description: Ah, a lovely Greek evening. The lights in the harbor. The scent of grilling meat. The choking smoke of a thousand flares.

title: In Amsterdam, a Look at Picassos Paris Days
description: Pablo Picasso spent time painting in Paris between 1900 and 1907, a period when he grew from a struggling Spanish artist to a leader of the French avant-garde. Today, paintings from those years are among the most sought after Picassos on the market. Through May 29, the Van Gogh Museum is hosting Picasso in Paris, a collection of 70 pieces from that era.

title: Qaddafis Son Warns of Civil War as Libyan Protests Widen
description: CAIRO  A five-day-old uprising in Libya took control of its second-largest city of Benghazi and spread for the first time to the capital of Tripoli late on Sunday as the heir-apparent son of its strongman, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, warned Libyans in a televised speech that their oil-rich country would fall into civil war and even renewed Western colonization if they threw off his fathers 40-year-long rule.

title: Dave Duerson, and Making Football Safer
description: Its too early to say whether Dave Duersons suicide was tied to head injuries he sustained in football. But brain impairment was something that concerned him in his final months:

title: How Far Will a Revolution Reach?
description: Residents of the town of Bagour in the Nile Delta celebrated the fall of a powerful state leader and his party, even as many freely acknowledge reaping their rewards.

title: Columbia Coach Has Archers on Target
description: Since taking over as head coach in 2005, Coach Derek Davis has the female archery team at Columbia University winning national championships and conquering the mental side of shooting.

title: Victory, Martyrs and Mourning
description: CAIRO  The days of our revolution were given various and expressive names. Jan. 28 was the Friday of Rage; Feb. 2, the Day of the Camels, when we were attacked by N.D.P. thugs riding horses and camels; and of course Departure Friday, when we, well, gently nudged the president to pack up and leave.

title: Where Hockey Is Growing, State by State
description: USA Hockey has been keeping track of player registration on a state-by-state basis since the 1998-99 season, enabling us to get a snapshot of where the game is growing  and shrinking  in the United States. So, on this Hockey Day in America, we present those statistics.

title: President of Uganda Coasts Into a Fourth Term
description: KAMPALA, Uganda  President Yoweri Museveni of Uganda was re-elected to a fourth term in a presidential election on Friday, the countrys electoral commission announced Sunday.

title: Cano Wont Seek Contract Extension From Yankees
description: TAMPA, Fla.  The lone television in the Yankees clubhouse was tuned Sunday morning to the MLB Network, which was showing a program that ranked the best second basemen in baseball. As No. 1 appeared on the screen, he also walked out of the food room. Robinson Cano took his physical exam early Sunday after mixing up the teams reporting dates, drawing some playful ribbing from Derek Jeter and Alex Rodriguez.

title: A Wallet Lost 40 Years Ago Now Is Found
The Maya Archaeologists at Ceibal
description: Takeshi Inomata, a professor of anthropology at the University of Arizona, writes from Guatemala, where he and Daniela Triadan are excavating the Maya site of Ceibal, Guatemala.

title: Top 10 Composers? Been There, Done That. What About Poets?
description: Attentive ArtsBeat readers must have noticed by now that we cant resist any excuse to mention our recent Top 10 Composers project. Here we go again.

title: Chinese Government Responds to Call for Protests
description: BEIJING  Skittish domestic security officials responded with a mass show of force across China on Sunday after anonymous calls for protesters to stage a Chinese Jasmine Revolution went out over social media and microblogging outlets.

title: Iran Squelches Protest Attempt in Capital
description: Antigovernment protesters gathered throughout parts of Iran on Sunday, most concentrated in the capital Tehran, to mark the deaths of two men killed during demonstrations last Monday. The government mounted a stultifying security presence in the capital, with the police making arrests and using tear gas to try to prevent the unrest from escalating.

title: Peacekeepers In Somalia Hit Trenches Of Rebels
description: MOGADISHU, Somalia  At least 20 people were killed and dozens wounded in heavy fighting in Somalias capital over the weekend, as African Union forces attacked an extensive underground fortification system of trenches and tunnels used by Islamist insurgents.

title: Photos of the Moment | Central St. Martins
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#304", 592, 490, true, chameleonData);

title: Next Question for Tunisia: The Role of Islam in Politics
description: TUNIS  The Tunisian revolution that overthrew decades of authoritarian rule has entered a delicate new phase in recent days over the role of Islam in politics. Tensions mounted here last week when military helicopters and security forces were called in to carry out an unusual mission: protecting the citys brothels from a mob of zealots.

title: Mark Rylance: Shape Shifter
description: Ben Brantley narrates a look at the career of the actor Mark Rylance, who is coming to Broadway this spring in the play "Jerusalem."

title: Amid Standoff, Opposition Seeks Dissolution of Bahraini Government
description: MANAMA, Bahrain  Teachers, lawyers and engineers marched into Pearl Square on Sunday, joining an emboldened opposition whose political leaders demanded that the king dissolve the government and fire his uncle, who has held the post of prime minister for 40 years, before they agree to enter into talks.

title: Weighing Reggie Millers Hall of Fame Credentials
description: The final ballot for the Naismith Memorial Basketball Hall of Fame was announced on Friday, but one notable omission has generated more buzz in N.B.A. circles than any of those actually in contention for the honor. As Jonathan Abrams reported in The Times, the Indiana Pacers guard and Knicks nemesis Reggie Miller will not be among the finalists for the Hall this season.

title: Knicks Claim a Unified Front-Office Front
description: LOS ANGELES  The Knicks dogged pursuit of Carmelo Anthony is exposing philosophical rifts in the organization and stoking concerns about who is running the basketball operation.

title: Marking Daviss Confederate Inauguration
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala.  One hundred and fifty years and one day later, the South did it again.

title: Another Stop on a Long, Improbable Journey
description: PHILADELPHIA  There are times, at the Penn Museum here, when you are almost hesitant to breathe. And it has nothing to do with the recent flurry of events in which Chinese officials suddenly forbid the display of the remarkable objects in the exhibition Secrets of the Silk Road, ultimately relenting and allowing them to be shown for just a short time. These doings (about which more later) are scarcely blinks in the history of these objects.

title: Myanmar Hardens Stance on Opposition
description: BANGKOK  The military rulers of Myanmar appear to be taking a harder line toward the pro-democracy leader Daw Aung San Suu Kyi and her party three months after her release from house arrest, focusing on the oppositions support for continued punitive sanctions against the government.

title: Excerpt: 'Armida'
description: Renee Fleming in a scene from Mary Zimmerman's production of "Armida" at the Metropolitan Opera. (Video courtesy of the Met)

title: Rumsfeld Implies That Obama Apologizes for U.S.
description: Former Defense Secretary Donald Rumsfeld reiterated a common conservative criticism of President Obama on Sunday, implying that the president is embarrassed by the United States.

title: First-Place Flyers Extend Rangers Slump
description: The Rangers are falling fast, and their once-bright season is becoming increasingly troubled as the homestretch approaches.

title: 40-Year Reunion
description: A former New York Times employee receives his lost wallet, found some 40 years later. Inside, he finds photos and documents from his past.

title: A Little Off the Top
description: The Op-Ed columnist Nicholas D. Kristof has time to get a haircut during a day of relative peace in Manama, Bahrain, and reflect on what a democracy there could look like.

title: Whats the Better Fit? The 4-4 vs. the 5-3
description: The last paragraph of Saturdays column generated a few queries. When is a 4-4 fit better than a 5-3, and vice versa?

title: A Frayed Familys Tenuous Bonds
description: Given how often playwriting substitutes for therapy or supplements it, few subjects are explored as frequently in contemporary American drama as the corrosive bonds of family.

title: The Siren Song of the Bath Toy
description: On Jan. 10, 1992, a container ship traveling south of the Aleutians, in the region once quaintly known as the Graveyard of the Pacific, en route from Hong Kong to Tacoma, Wash., took a steep roll and lost part of its cargo. The incident had near-mythical repercussions. Among the lost merchandise were 7,200 packs of bathtub toys. Each four-piece set included a blue turtle, a green frog, a red beaver and a yellow duck. This came to be erroneously understood as the story of 29,000 rubber duckies set adrift and washing up all over the globe.

title: Species Seekers and Spies
description: Theres a scene early in the 2002 film Die Another Day, where James Bond poses as an ornithologist in Havana, with binoculars in hand and a book, Birds of the West Indies, tucked under one arm. Oh, Im just here for the birds, he ventures, when the fetching heroine, Jinx Johnson, played by Halle Berry, makes her notably unfeathered entrance.

title: Santas Number and Grouchos Face
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: SoHo Theater Is Reborn in the West Village
description: The recently deceased Ohio Theater in SoHo will not have to wait long for a resurrection. SoHo Think Tank, the company that ran the Ohio, an Off Off Broadway theater at 66 Wooster Street, for almost 20 years, will have a new home at the Archive Building at 154 Christopher Street in the West Village beginning this fall. The original Wooster Street building was sold in 2008, and the company was forced to leave two years later after failing to renegotiate the rent with the new landlord. Since then the Think Tank has been operating under the banner Ohio Interrupted at the 3 Legged-Dog theater in Lower Manhattan. It will produce its annual Ice Factory festival there this summer before moving in September to the new 73-seat theater, where it will reopen under a subsidized 10-year lease and a new name, Ohio West. To be back in our own space within a year of leaving Wooster Street, and to be in the West Village, no less, is just unbelievable, said the companys artistic director, Robert Lyons, above. The new building is owned by Rockrose Development, which designated the theater for nonprofit use at below market rates as part of an agreement made with the city during the commercial development of the building in 1988.

title: The Thriller Unknown Tops the Box Office
description: Liam Neesons stolen-identity thriller Unknown was a surprise No. 1 at North American theaters over the weekend, gunning past I Am Number Four, a science-fiction entry that represented the reconfigured debut of Steven Spielbergs DreamWorks Studios. Made for about $30 million, Unknown (Dark Castle/Warner Brothers) sold an estimated $21.8 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles box office statistics. I Am Number Four, which received negative reviews, cost at least $50 million to make and was predicted by some analysts to lead the weekend box office derby, sold about $19.5 million for second place. It was the first film that DreamWorks has released since refinancing itself and breaking ties with Paramount Pictures in favor of a distribution relationship with Walt Disney Studios. Gnomeo & Juliet (Disney) was a strong third with $19.4 million, bringing the two-week total for the 3-D animated comedy to about $50.4 million. The Adam Sandler-Jennifer Aniston comedy Just Go With It (Sony Pictures Entertainment) placed fourth in its second weekend, selling an estimated $18.2 million for a new total of $60.8 million. Big Mommas: Like Father, Like Son, a comedy from 20th Century Fox and New Regency starring Martin Lawrence in fat-suit drag, rounded out the top five with about $17 million.

title: Aretha Franklin to Return
description: It seems that the Grammy Awards get well tribute to the singer Aretha Franklin, above, last week may have worked. Ms. Franklin, 68, who was forced to cancel numerous concerts late last year because of an undisclosed illness, has announced plans to perform at the Seneca Niagara Casino & Hotel in Buffalo on May 28, BBC News reported. It will be her first performance since she had surgery to treat a medical condition in December. In January Ms. Franklin said that the condition had been resolved, and last week she appeared at the Grammys via video to thank her well wishers.

title: 3-D Great Gatsby to Film in Australia
description: Sydneys first live-action 3-D film wont feature fantastical woodland creatures, superheroes or even aliens. Instead, the lost and lonely souls of The Great Gatsby will do the honors. Baz Luhrmanns adaptation of F. Scott Fitzgeralds novel will begin filming at Fox Studios there in August, according to The Hollywood Reporter. The film is set in New York and will star Leonardo DiCaprio as Jay Gatsby; Carey Mulligan (An Education) is expected to play the role of Daisy Buchanan, the article said. Kristina Keneally, the New South Wales premier, said the movie was a big win for the state and Australia, which was thought to be losing international filmmaking due to the strong Aussie dollar. The production is expected to boost the economy by around $200 million, though the incentives used to lure the producers, Warner Brothers and Bazmark Films, remained confidential.

title: Rocker From the Heartland, Aging Brashly
description: At Radio City Music Hall on Friday night John Mellencamp joshed about what it would be like to meet his younger self: a brash kid whod condescendingly say, Hey, Classic Hits, whats happening? He went on proudly to assert his age, 59, as a lead-in to what he announced as a song for my generation. It was Dont Need This Body, a blunt, death-haunted stomp that began, This getting older, it aint for cowards.

title: O, Unsmiling Villainess!
description: LONDON  John Berry, the innovative artistic director of the English National Opera, is not alone among his colleagues in thinking that directors from fields other than opera should be brought in to shake up and enliven the art form. A tempting idea, but it does not always work out, as a performance of Donizettis Lucrezia Borgia on Friday night here at the English National Opera demonstrated.

title: Shes Young, Restless and a Bit Dreamy
description: Its the unrest inside me, and I think Ill go mad, sang the beautiful young woman in the red dress at the Oak Room of the Algonquin Hotel on Wednesday evening. Those words, imparted in a near whisper tinged with an otherworldly vibrato, come from I Wish It So, a gorgeous, little-known Irish-flavored ballad by Marc Blitzstein from his 1959 show, Juno. And what is the narrators wish? A vague I still dont know.

title: In Budget Wars, Tough Talk Hasnt Often Led to Political Victory
description: Is it really different this time?

title: Rene Fleming Returns to Rossinis Tale of a Sorceress and Her Crusader
description: In Rossinis operas coloratura is character. When critics mention singer Xs trills, Ys roulades and Zs runs, they are not just being nitpicky. Qualities like joy and anger are expressed here entirely through those purely vocal means. The emotions are in the notes.

title: Feet on the Furniture, and Other Playful Moves
description: Its interesting how much effect context has on perceptions of a show. For the last few years Bill Young and Colleen Thomas have offered the LIT series, informal presentations of their own and other peoples work in their SoHo loft. On Friday night Mr. Young and Ms. Thomas opened the 92nd Street Y Harkness Dance Festival by creating a rough approximation of that setting in the Ys Buttenwieser Hall. The audience was placed in an L around the stage space, with some people at small cafe tables and others on couches or chairs. A D.J. was spinning music as people arrived, and a cash bar was doing steady business.

title: Monday: Like a Wave
description: MONDAYS PUZZLE  In todays puzzle, you cant possibly get lost. And on a Monday, thats not necessarily a bad thing.

title: Drama Revived by the Kindness of Strangeness
description: The Wooster Group was just getting started in 1977 when Tennessee Williamss once-glorious career was fading. That was the year his Vieux Carr opened, and quickly closed, on Broadway, the year in which he wrote: No one is more acutely aware than I that I am widely regarded as the ghost of a writer.

title: In Poland, at Mercy of Weirdos
description: A Couple of Poor, Polish-Speaking Romanians may wear its shambolic nature on its sleeve, and it could stand to shed at least a third of its nearly two-hour running time. But in this blistering picaresque by an acclaimed young Polish novelist, Dorota Maslowska, having its New York premiere at the Abrons Arts Center under the auspices of the Polish Cultural Institute in New York and East River Commedia, she tempers her grotty verve with a tenderness that helps steer its lead performers through any number of stylistic hairpin turns.

title: 30 Seconds With Bill Buckner
description: Bill Buckner had 2,715 hits during his major league career, but he is best remembered for a defensive miscue almost 25 years ago. As the Boston Red Sox first baseman, he allowed a slow ground ball by Mookie Wilson to squirt between his legs to give the Mets a victory in Game 6 of the 1986 World Series.

title: The Foot Comes Down
description: New York City to Philadelphia, Feb. 21, 1861

title: Secrets of the Silk Road
description: Images from the exhibition at the Penn Museum in Philadelphia.

title: Merkels Party Is Defeated in Election in Hamburg
description: BERLIN  Chancellor Angela Merkels Christian Democratic Union party suffered a major defeat on Sunday in an election in Hamburg, with preliminary results showing that the opposition Social Democrats had made big gains and would form the next government there.

title: Music in Review
description: JEREMY DENK

title: Portrait of Spy Agency Leaves Much in Shadow
description: LONDON  The mysterious oil painting entitled Waiting in the Hotel Room sold for a relatively modest $28,200 last week on the opening night of an exhibition in the upscale Mayfair district of London, where softly lighted galleries staffed by velvet-voiced staff members sell artworks that can fetch millions.

title: Chuck Allen, Who Championed Surfing and Snowboarding, Dies at 74
description: Chuck Allen, who helped found two nonprofit organizations that worked to bring respect and legitimacy to surfing and snowboarding, died on Feb. 14 in Redlands, Calif. He was 74 and lived in Yucaipa.

title: Economic Reports for the Week
description: ECONOMIC REPORTS Scheduled for this week are the Standard & Poors/Case-Shiller home price indexes for December, and the fourth quarter and consumer confidence for February (Tuesday); existing home sales for January (Wednesday); durable goods orders and new-home sales for January and initial jobless claims (Thursday); and gross domestic product for the fourth quarter and the Thomson Reuters-University of Michigan consumer sentiment index for February (Friday).

title: Mets Have Reassuring Words for Luis Castillo
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  During their initial meeting in the managers office Saturday, Luis Castillo and his new manager, Terry Collins, discussed Castillos painful 2010 season, including the best ways to get past it and be productive, providing he is still on the Mets when the season starts.

title: Ollie Matson, an All-Purpose Football Star, Is Dead at 80
description: Ollie Matson, who was a star in the National Football League for 14 years but whose college football career was hindered by racism, died Saturday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 80.

title: Jeter Adjusts His Swing, but Not His Mind-Set
description: TAMPA, Fla.

title: Fears of Chaos Temper Calls for Change in Morocco
description: CASABLANCA, Morocco  For Morocco, a kingdom on the western edge of North Africa, the calls for change sweeping the region are muted by a fear of chaos, a prevalent security apparatus and genuine respect for the king, Mohammed VI. Since he took the throne in 1999, the king, who is only 47, has done much to soften the harsh and often brutal rule of his father, Hassan II.

title: Treading Water Isnt Enough for the Knicks
description: Ive been down so long

title: N.F.L. Players Shaken by Duersons Suicide Message
description: When the former football player Andre Waters shot himself in the head in late 2006, the few recoverable pieces of brain tissue, which later showed the same degenerative disease previously associated only with boxers, made the health risks of football a national conversation.

title: Rising Property Taxes Overwhelm Many Who Are Living on the Edge
description: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomos campaign to cap property taxes has angered school and municipal officials who say that limiting local tax revenue will make it impossible for them to cover rising expenses and will result in drastic cuts in services.

title: NATO Airstrike Is Said to Kill Afghan Civilians
description: JALALABAD, Afghanistan  NATO airstrikes killed at least 35 people in a remote mountainous area of eastern Afghanistan last week in an attack that NATO officers say was a successful mission against Taliban insurgents, but that Afghan officials have condemned as causing mass civilian casualties.

title: Greeces Efforts to Limit Tax Evasion Have Little Success
description: ATHENS  The agents from the Financial and Economic Crime Unit slipped in on a holiday evening recently, taking some of the tall seats at the crowded bar in the Three Little Pigs Cafe here.

title: In Surprise Ending, Trevor Bayne Captures Daytona 500
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla.  With a record number of lead changes, leaders and cautions from wrecks that took out some of the biggest names in Nascar, it was only appropriate that a most unpredictable Daytona 500 ended with a most unexpected driver celebrating in victory lane.

title: Protesters in Wisconsin Say They Are Staying Put
description: MADISON, Wis.  Union leaders urged Wisconsin teachers to return to work at schools that are open on Monday, but large protests were expected to continue at the Capitol against a plan to cut collective bargaining rights and benefits to state workers.

title: Book Lovers Fear Dim Future for Notes in the Margins
description: CHICAGO  Locked in a climate-controlled vault at the Newberry Library here, a volume titled The Pen and the Book can be studied only under the watch of security cameras.

title: A Tale of Two Presidents
Ally of New Haven Police for 17 Years, Now a Target
description: NEW HAVEN

title: Cuomo Seeks to Curb Aid to Schools Sharing Tasks
description: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo has called on New Yorks hodgepodge of small and large school districts to operate more efficiently by consolidating and sharing services.

title: Supreme Court to Hear Material Witness Case
description: GRAND TERRACE, Calif.  When the director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, Robert S. Mueller III, gave Congress a progress report in early 2003on the agencys success in identifying and dismantling terrorist networks, his first example was the capture of Khalid Shaikh Mohammed, the mastermind of the Sept. 11 attacks. His second was the arrest of Abdullah al-Kidd.

title: Dolans Hand Is Seen in Pursuit of Anthony
description: LOS ANGELES

title: U.S. Gravely Concerned Over Violence in Libya
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration on Sunday condemned Libyas use of lethal force against peaceful demonstrators, pointing to what it said were multiple credible reports that hundreds of people had been killed and injured in several days of unrest.

title: Bryant Briefly Draws All-Star Focus Off Anthony
description: LOS ANGELES  Carmelo Anthony wandered from meeting to meeting and owner to owner this weekend looking for resolution to his season-long drama. On a neutral court, in a generic jersey for a ceremonial game, he was not a Nugget, Knick or Net, but simply an All-Star with a ticking deadline that will determine his future employer.

title: Dream Act Advocate Turns Failure Into Hope
description: HARRISONBURG, Va.  Isabel Castillo was counting on the Dream Act, and when the Dream Act was defeated in December, it upended her dreams.

title: A Catchers Search for a Team Leads to the Yankees
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Every winter, Gustavo Molina and his wife, Carla, seem to have the same conversation. She asks him which team he will play for. He tells her he doesnt know. She asks why he switches teams every season. He tells her that its his job.

title: Wisconsin Puts Obama Between Competing Desires
description: WASHINGTON  The battle in Wisconsin over public employee unions has left President Obama facing a tricky balance between showing solidarity with longtime political supporters and projecting a message in favor of deep spending cuts to reduce the debt.

title: Nationals Racing Presidents Tryouts No Laughing Matter
description: WASHINGTON  The urgent phone call came just about halfway through the mascot tryouts for the Washington Nationals. A concerned member of the Nationals entertainment staff gave his colleagues the horrible news.

title: Night Helicopter Rescue Lifts 2 West Point Cadets Off Ledge
description: HIGHLAND FALLS, N.Y.  In a daring nighttime run, amid conditions that left no room for error, a New York City police helicopter hoisted two shivering West Point cadets early Sunday morning off an 18-inch-wide ledge on Storm King Mountain, where they had been stranded for more than eight hours.

title: Revived George Mason Has Major Ambitions
description: FAIRFAX, Va.  Five years removed from its improbable Final Four appearance, George Mason embraces the past while choosing not to be defined by it. Enlarged magazine covers chronicling the Patriots 2006 run still hang in Coach Jim Larranagas office, and at home games this season, fans received bobblehead dolls depicting that teams starting five.

title: Blogs Wane as the Young Drift to Sites Like Twitter
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Like any aspiring filmmaker, Michael McDonald, a high school senior, used a blog to show off his videos. But discouraged by how few people bothered to visit, he instead started posting his clips on Facebook, where his friends were sure to see and comment on his editing skills.

title: At Newsweek, a Humble and Frugal Tina Brown
description: There will be no celebrity-studded gala with fireworks over New York Harbor this time. No brash predictions of upending the magazine business.

title: Baddeley Holds Off Singh at Riviera, Where Generation Gap Is 2 Shots
description: LOS ANGELES  After four years of searching, and 95 tournaments without a victory, Aaron Baddeley finally put it all together again on Sunday. On a chilly, bright day at Riviera Country Club, Baddeley won the Northern Trust Open with a rebuilt swing and some newfound resolve.

title: After iPads Head Start, Rival Tablets Are Poised to Flood Offices
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The billboards promoting the iPad have a simple message: The tablet is a device for leisure, to be held on ones lap while lounging on a couch in casual clothes, to watch a film or read a magazine.

title: Unrest Around the Region
description: LIBYA The son of the Libyan leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, warned that continued antigovernment protests could lead to a civil war. The uprising spread to the capital, Tripoli, while protesters in the eastern city of Benghazi took over the city.

title: Brooklyn Woman Dies as Blaze Displaces 100
description: A retired guidance counselor was killed and more than 100 residents were forced to flee into the chill of a winter night when a wind-whipped fire raced through a seven-story apartment building in Flatbush, Brooklyn, on Saturday evening.

title: 100 Years Later, the Roll of the Dead in a Factory Fire Is Complete
description: In the Cemetery of the Evergreens on the border of Brooklyn and Queens, there is a haunting stone monument to the garment workers who died in the Triangle shirtwaist factory fire of 1911 but were never identified. It contains the bas-relief figure of a kneeling woman, her head bowed, seemingly mourning not only the deaths, but also the fact that those buried below were so badly charred that relatives could not recognize them.

title: European Airports Balk at Easing Ban on Liquids
description: PARIS  With barely two months remaining before the European Union is scheduled to partially lift a nearly five-year ban on liquids in air passenger hand luggage, airports across the region are balking at the approaching deadline, arguing that current liquid-explosive detection technology is still too unreliable.

title: In Records, Portraits of Lives Cut Short
description: Within half a year of identifying Maria Giuseppa Lauletti, one of the six unidentified victims of the Triangle shirtwaist factory fire of 1911, Michael Hirsch, an amateur genealogist, had put names to the five other unknowns, with the identity of the last one, Fannie Rosen, emerging last summer. In every case, he found decaying records from charitable or government agencies whose details allowed him to paint portraits of six truncated lives.

title: Woman Dies During Night on Sidewalk Near Church
description: A woman found dead on an East Village sidewalk Sunday morning was known to several people in Tompkins Square Park only by a first name, Grace. She was a regular in and around the park, they added, and often slept outside.

title: Louganis Is Back on Board
description: FULLERTON, Calif.  The Olympic-size outdoor pool at Fullerton College on a recent afternoon was an aquatics diorama, with a beginners swim class sharing space with a group of seasoned competitors churning out laps. At the far end, in the deep water, three divers practiced their springboard takeoffs.

title: In Prime-Time TV, Networks Losing the War for 10 P.M.
description: For the past several years, many broadcast network executives have looked at the ratings for their 10 p.m. shows and lamented that it has become impossible to build a true, breakout hit at that hour anymore.

description: The Times welcomes comments and suggestions, or complaints about errors that warrant correction. description: Digital subscriptions, a grail for the mainstream media that often seemed more like a mirage, took on some firm if not altogether friendly dimensions last week.

description: A view of the day in sports, with an unexpected victory at the Daytona 500 and a predictable throng at the N.H.L. Heritage Classic.

title: TV Industry Taps Social Media to Keep Viewers Attention
description: By the time the first ballot is opened at the Academy Awards next Sunday, millions of people will be chatting about the awards show on the Internet. And ABC will be ready.

title: The Short Shelf Life of a Serie A Coach
description: Unable to right his foundering ship, Claudio Ranieri resigned as Romas coach on Sunday after the team blew a three-goal lead in a 4-3 loss to Genoa in Serie A. His decision capped a lightning-fast journey from optimism to resignation. Lets recap, in his own words.

title: Rebranding Mount Vernon
description: MOUNT VERNON, George Washingtons bucolic estate in Northern Virginia, has been an American shrine since his death in 1799. But after the Civil War, when its historic restoration began, the image of the first president began to be outshone by that of the 16th, Abraham Lincoln.

description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: U.S. Sets 21st-Century Goal: Building a Better Patent Office
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama, who emphasizes American innovation, says modernizing the federal Patent and Trademark Office is crucial to winning the future. So at a time when a quarter of patent applications come from California, and many of those from Silicon Valley, the patent office is opening its first satellite office  in Detroit.

description: Washington

title: Pakistans Nuclear Folly
description: With the Middle East roiling, the alarming news about Pakistans nuclear weapons buildup has gotten far too little attention. The Times recently reported that American intelligence agencies believe Pakistan has between 95 and more than 110 deployed nuclear weapons, up from the mid-to-high 70s just two years ago.

title: Wisconsin Power Play

title: Recommended Reading for Republicans
description: The administration last week released a sweeping report recommending many useful steps for conserving, even expanding, Americas open spaces and making them more accessible to the American people. It is the sort of document destined to gather dust on bureaucratic shelves unless someone pays attention and follows up.

title: A Good Investment in Tough Times
description: About 2.5 million residents of New York State, trapped at the margins of the economy, lack the basic skills that come with a high school education. To help these people  and strengthen the economy  the state must work with the cities to expand access to the relatively inexpensive programs that prepare people for the General Educational Development Test, which provides the equivalent of a high school diploma and gives low-skilled workers a leg up in the job market.

title: Watching Protesters Risk It All
description: Manama, Bahrain

title: Keeping Up With the Christies
description: There is no sound economic justification for the decision by Gov. Rick Scott of Florida to reject $2.4 billion in federal financing for the vital Tampa-to-Orlando high-speed rail project. Political pandering to his Tea Party supporters is the only explanation we can come up with.

title: With Takeover Bids, No Is Often the Most Profitable Reply
New Jersey TV Station Is Accused of Failing Its Audience
description: WWOR-TV is the subject of an unusual investigation by the Federal Communications Commission, which is looking into charges that the stations owner, the News Corporation, misrepresented the stations number of employees and amount of programming. The investigation is gaining attention in part because WWOR is a rarity: it is effectively the only big commercial station licensed to the state of New Jersey.

title: A Steady Decline in the Number of Restaurants
description: The total number of restaurants in the United States dropped nearly one percent from fall 2009 to fall 2010, according to the NPD Group, a market research firm. That is the latest decline in a decade in which the number of American restaurants has fallen steadily by roughly half a percentage point each year.

title: Egyptians Were Unplugged, and Uncowed
description: FOR a segment of the young people of Egypt, the date to remember is not when Egyptians first took to the streets to shake off the 30-year rule of Hosni Mubarak.

title: Edmund de Unger, Islamic Art Collector, Is Dead at 92
description: Edmund de Unger, whose childhood fascination with Oriental rugs and The Arabian Nights led him to amass one of the worlds largest and most important collections of Islamic art, died on Jan. 25 at his home in Ham, Surrey, England. He was 92.

title: Roy Gussow, Abstract Sculptor, Dies at 92
description: Roy Gussow, an abstract sculptor whose polished stainless-steel works with swooping contours gleam in public squares and corporate spaces, died on Feb. 11 in Queens. He was 92 and had lived and worked in Long Island City, Queens, for nearly half a century.

description: BRUSSELS  At the annual World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, the hottest ticket in recent years has invariably been an invitation to Googles lavish private party, and 2011 was no exception.

description: It was an opportunity that Fred Wilpon and Saul Katz, the owners of the Mets, extended only to select people: the chance to invest with their old friend Bernard L. Madoff.

Their agenda echoes in its ambition what President Obama and Democrats tried after winning office in their own electoral wave in 2008.

description: KABUL, Afghanistan  A suicide bomber wearing a vest with explosives blew himself up Monday, killing 31 people, as residents lined up for identification cards at a census office in northern Afghanistan, Afghan security officials said.

description: CAIRO  The faltering government of the Libyan strongman, Col. description: BAGHDAD  A suicide bomber on Monday detonated a truck packed with explosives outside a police headquarters just north of Samarra, killing 12 officers and wounding 20 others, a local official and a law enforcement official said.

description: Room A in the National Gallery of Art is one of the best and most unusual places to appreciate art in London. And judging by the light traffic during a recent visit, the room is also one of the citys better-kept secrets.

title: BP to Pay $7.2 Billion for Stake in Oil Fields in India
description: MUMBAI, India  The British oil giant BP said on Monday that it would pay $7.2 billion to buy into Indias fast-growing oil and gas industry. It is BPs second big deal in two months, as it seeks to rebuild after last years Gulf of Mexico oil spill.

title: Editors Pick Social Network, Adding Some Oscar Intrigue
description: With less than a week to go, the pace of tea-leaf-reading  and stirring  is approaching Daytona levels. On Saturday the American Cinema Editors guild, considered a good harbinger of the best picture Oscar, announced its winners (known as the Eddies), and it was enough to cause  if were going to keep going with this metaphor  a tempest in a teapot. The big prize went to Angus Wall and Kirk Baxter for The Social Network over The Kings Speech (and over Black Swan, The Fighter and Inception). In the comedy/musical category, Alice in Wonderland bested The Kids Are All Right and several other non-Oscar contenders, and Exit Through the Gift Shop won for documentary  an illustration of how well-liked it is as a film. Meanwhile pundits pounced on a victory for anything other than the projected favorite, The Kings Speech.

title: BP to Buy Stake in Reliances Oil and Gas Fields for $7.2 Billion
description: BP said on Monday that it would pay $7.2 billion to buy into Indias fast-growing oil and natural gas business, the companys second big deal in two months, according to The New York Times.

title: Artifacts | Laurie Simmonss Love Doll

Others have pets. The more adventurous, perhaps, opt for a love doll  a life-size latex sex partner who never cheats, has just the right look and is always ready to play.

title: Hoot-Smalley
description: David Warsh has a good essay, inspired by recent work of Doug Irwins, about how the notion that the Smoot-Hawley tariff caused the Great Depression  a notion unsupported by either theory or evidence  nonetheless became conventional wisdom.

title: Revisiting the Value of Elite Colleges
description: A decade ago, two economists  Stacy Dale and Alan Krueger  published a research paper arguing that elite colleges did not seem to give most graduates an earnings boost. As you might expect, the paper received a ton of attention. Ms. Dale and Mr. Krueger have just finished a new version of the study  with vastly more and better data, covering people into their 40s and 50s, as well as looking at a set of more recent college graduates  and the new version comes to the same conclusion.

title: British Chip Maker CSR Acquires U.S. Firm for $679 Million
description: CSR, a British chip maker, agreed on Monday to buy the Zoran Corporation, a maker of technology for digital photography and video, for about $679 million in stock.

title: Best Political Quotes of the Holiday Weekend
description: Did you miss some of the political chatter over the holiday weekend? Dont worry. The Caucus has gathered the best weekend quotes for you.

title: Got a Great Idea? Tell Everyone!
description: Youve heard of high-tech start-ups being in stealth mode, meaning theyre not telling anyone what theyre up to yet. It has a glamorous aura to it, conjuring up images of a brilliant project in the works that will soon be sprung upon the world, disrupting established players and leaving everyone scrambling to catch up. All smart companies with really great innovations keep those ideas hidden away until theyre ready to release them, lest competitors steal them. Look at Apple, which has perfected the art of secretiveness, to enormous profit. You can tell people about your great idea  but only if they sign one of those nondisclosure agreements you keep in your briefcase at all times. No exceptions!

description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: Sudans President, in Power Since 1989, Wont Run Again, Spokesman Says
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  President Omar Hassan al-Bashir of Sudan, who has been in power for more than 20 years and faces international charges of genocide, will not run for office again after his current term ends in four years, a Sudanese government spokesman said Monday.

title: For Braves Catcher, Quiet Excellence in the Family Business
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  Proximity is important for Howie McCann. He lives in Duluth, Ga., six miles from his son Brians home. He lives 28 miles from Turner Field, where Brian is the catcher for the Atlanta Braves. Most nights, he arrives in time to wave hello while Brian warms up the pitcher in the bullpen.

title: If There Were an Oscar for Title Sequences
description: Are there enough categories in the Academy Awards race? Not according to Alice Rawsthorn, design columnist for The International Herald Tribune. She proposes an Oscar for the opening and closing credits and offers her own nominees for the most creative, or effective, of this movie season. Typography is important but not always paramount. Her standard is one set by Saul Bass, who worked on Hitchcock, Kubrick and Scorsese films among many others: Do the credits set the mood for the movie to come? As he said in a 1966 interview with Film Quarterly, I saw the title as a way of conditioning the audience, so that when the film actually began, viewers would have an emotional resonance with it.

title: Egypts Leaders Signal Commitment to Civilian Rule
description: CAIRO  The military and civilian leadership controlling Egypt in the wake of a popular revolution took several high-profile steps on Monday to reassure Egyptians that it shared their fervor for change and to signal to foreign leaders that the move to full civilian rule would be rapid.

title: To Sell an Apartment, No Detail Is Too Small
description: On a recent Thursday morning, Jamella Swift, a Citi Habitats broker, was trying to anticipate every detail that would prevent a buyer from purchasing the two-bedroom condo she was selling in Bedford-Stuyvesant. She put a full-size bed in the bedroom so buyers wouldnt think the room was too small. She dragged in a Lucite coffee table to create the illusion of a larger living space and set up three floor lamps to supplement the recessed lighting. Ms. Swift hoped that the $5,000 she had spent would help her land $395,000 to $425,000 for the apartment.

title: Wisconsin G.O.P. Plans to Work Without Democrats
