title: Dirty Energy Dwarfs Clean in China and India
description: Many experts agree that for the world to rein in rising greenhouse gas emissions, the galloping economies of China and India would have to figure out how to base their future economic expansion on technologies and fuels that are cleaner than the fossil fuels the United States and Europe used in their own industrial revolutions long ago.

title: Put Away the White Rice
description: Many years ago, after I decided to stop eating meat (I am not a strict vegetarian now, though thats the way I usually eat), I walked down the street to look over whole grains at my local health food store in Austin, Tex. There wasnt much of a selection; still, it was all new to me, and I bought some of the grains sold in bulk bins: brown rice, millet, kasha and wheat berries.

title: Of Heart and Guts
description: Q. Is it better for digestion to sleep on the left side and better for the heart to sleep on the right?

title: Silver Lining
description: When it comes to makeup, the runway often resembles a glamorous laboratory, where mad scientists (a k a makeup artists) cook up otherworldly or exaggerated looks that work well in photos but rarely make it to real life. The molten silver eye at Pradas spring show seemed exactly that  a hothouse exotic that wouldnt survive outside a fashion show. Not so, according to Pat McGrath, who created the look and also employed silver at Valentino and Galliano. Metallics are unique, modern and chic, she says. But most of all, they are completely wearable on every skin tone. For an evening out, she suggests using Laura Merciers intense Foiled Eye Color in V.I.P. Silver on the lid, keeping the color centered, rather than extending up to the brow, and following with black liquid liner and mascara. For day, try Covergirl Smoky ShadowBlast in Silver Sky from the lash line to the browbone, and finish with two coats of mascara. Romy Soleimani, who created the liquid mercury look for this story, recommends a sheer wash of Make Up For Ever Aqua Cream No. 3 all over the lid and in the crease, followed by mascara. Fill in your brow, do a beautiful pale pink lip, and you have a delicate version of the look, she says.

title: Braves Look Behind the Plate and See a Leader
description: When the Atlanta Braves took their prospects to Turner Field for an orientation camp in January, Brian McCann was one of the veterans to speak. McCann lives nearby  he is a Georgia boy, born and raised  and the way he connected with the kids struck Eddie Perez.

title: Home Internet May Get Even Faster in South Korea
description: SEOUL, South Korea  South Korea already claims the worlds fastest Internet connections  the fastest globally by far  but that is hardly good enough for the government here.

title: Bahrain Withdraws From Opening Race of Formula One Season
description: On Monday, the Informational Affairs Authority for the Kingdom of Bahrain posted the following message on Twitter: .bbpBox{background:url(http://a2.twimg.com/profile_background_images/207330950/IAA_logo.jpg) #C0DEED;padding:20px;}

title: Bahrain Cancels Grand Prix Amid Political Unrest
description: The organizers of the Bahrain Grand Prix announced Monday that the Formula One race next month had been canceled because of the political unrest in the country.

title: A Preacher Raises His Voice in Egypt
description: The Times's Stephen Farrell visits Mahdi Mohammed, a Muslim preacher he met during the protests in Tahrir Square.

title: When Alzheimers Waited Outside the Oval Office
description: WASHINGTON  Ron Reagans new memoir, My Father at 100, has touched off sensational headlines with its suggestion that President Ronald Reagan might have begun showing hints of Alzheimers disease while still in the White House.

title: One More Job Lost in the Recession: The Mayors
description: CENTRAL FALLS, R.I.  These are trying times for the people of Central Falls, a city so close to fiscal collapse that the state seized control of City Hall last summer. Taxes have risen nearly 20 percent to help solve the immediate crisis, unions have agreed to givebacks and the city of 19,000  all 1.29 square miles of it  seems tinged with defeat.

title: Friends Without a Personal Touch
description: Teenagers who send and receive six to eight thousand texts a month and spend hours a day on Facebook. Mourners who send text messages during a memorial service because they cant go an hour without using their BlackBerries. Children who see an authentic Galapagos tortoise at the American Museum of Natural History and cant understand why the museum didnt use a robot tortoise instead. High school students who wonder how much they should tilt their Facebook profiles toward what their friends will think is cool, or what college admissions boards might prize.

title: Scorecard | Mulberry Wins!
description: Scorecard, here, checking in with your weekend recap of all thats new in London fashion. In a word: heritage. For even before Christopher Bailey brought Burberry back form springs biker trench dark side with a catwalk extravaganza live streamed to jumbotrons at Picadilly Circus, with a whistle and click the creative director of an It Brit bag brand made a triumphant homecoming from across the pond, sending out a full lineup of sixties-inspired Mr. Foxy looks.Fantastic, Ms. Hill.

title: It Gets Better, the Public Service Announcement
description: The It Gets Better Project, an online video campaign to cheer up gay teenagers who have been victims of bullies, has joined with the stars of the new Broadway musical Priscilla Queen of the Desert to produce the projects first public service announcement, which will begin airing on Tuesday on the CBS affiliate in the New York region.

title: Glow From a Victory Did Not Last for Long
description: LINDEN, N.J.  Kelly Kulicks 2002 Nissan Pathfinder, with 163,000 miles and a worn-out radio that was recently replaced, was making a strange sound. Kulick was nervous that it would not bring her home the day after last weeks Brad Paisley concert in Hershey, Pa.

title: BMW Officially Announces BMW i Brand
description: On Monday at its corporate headquarters in Munich, BMW announced details of its coming sub-brand, BMW i.

title: 'Priscilla' PSA for It Gets Better
description: The spot, part of the It Gets Better Project, features stars of the new musical "Priscilla Queen of the Desert."

title: Egypt Reopens Museums and Historical Sites
description: Egypt has reopened many of its museums and historical sites, which were hit by sporadic looting during the uprising that led to President Hosni Mubaraks ouster, Reuters reported.

title: Modigliamania
description: With Modigliani: A Life (Knopf, $35), Meryle Secrest rehabilitates the famously dashing Italian, once thought to be a minor painter and something of a brute. The meticulously sourced book coincides with a flurry of art market activity, suggesting that 91 years after his death, Modigliani may be having a moment.

title: Addiction: A First in Sub-Saharan Africa: Methadone Maintenance Program
description: With the help of the American government, the first methadone maintenance program in sub-Saharan Africa opened this month in a hospital in Dar es Salaam, Tanzania.

title: Faking Happiness May Lead to Blues
description: In the song Smile, the crooner Nat King Cole famously advised that we smile through heartbreak. But now research suggests that faking happiness may just make things worse.

title: In Yemen, Leader Says Hell Talk, but Not Quit
description: SANA, Yemen  President Ali Abdullah Saleh, looking shaken at a news conference here on Monday, said he would not give in to the demands of protesters who have sought his ouster during 10 days of sustained demonstrations around Yemen.

title: Travel With the Boss: The Pluses and the Pitfalls
description: Traveling with the boss offers an array of both professional opportunities and minefields.

title: BMW to Create Sub-Brand for Battery-Powered Cars
description: FRANKFURT  BMW, the German luxury car builder, said on Monday that it would create a sub-brand known as BMW i to market a line of battery-powered cars starting in 2013, and gave the most complete picture yet of how the vehicles made of carbon fiber and aluminum would look.

title: Barbour Visits With State Leaders in Iowa
description: On Monday, Gov. Haley Barbour of Mississippi visited Iowa, which will hold the nations first presidential contest in less than a year.

title: Q.& A. With Eric Cantona
description: At first, even second glance, Eric Cantona, 44, looks as if he could be minutes away from shedding his stylish street clothes and stepping back onto the soccer field without embarrassing himself. An enigmatic Frenchman, Cantona starred for Manchester United in the 1990s, retired at age 30 and left it all behind for a budding film career. He is back in the game for the first time in 14 years. Cantona has been named the director of soccer operations for the reborn New York Cosmos, a team that really is not a team  yet  but that hopes to become the 20th entry in Major League Soccer, perhaps as soon as the 2013 season. Cantona spoke with Jack Bell of The Times (who, as he took notes using an iPad and wireless keyboard, heard Cantona say that he felt strange, like Im talking to the police at the station) about his days at Old Trafford, his exploits on the silver screen and his expectations with the Cosmos.

title: Libyas U.N. Diplomats Break With Qaddafi
description: Members of Libyas mission to the United Nations renounced Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi on Monday, calling him a genocidal war criminal responsible for mass shootings of demonstrators protesting against his four decades in power. They called upon him to resign.

title: Found Baggage Earns an Airline Clerk a Much Nicer Bag
description: BACK in 2001, when I was 21, I started my own apparel line.

title: A Dazzling Show Inside a Laser, but a Vacuum of Light Outside
description: In an elegant melding of theoretical and experimental physics, scientists at Yale University have taken the basic function of a laser and flipped it around  producing a device that absorbs, rather than emits, a beam of light.

title: Consider the Dray Horse (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: All Heart (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Europe Focuses on Flow of Migrants
description: BRUSSELS  Two days of meetings of European Union ministers meant to address broad themes of change in the Middle East were dominated by short-term issues, particularly the possibility of increased migration from North Africa if regional unrest grows.

title: Energy Savings for All (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: The Wages of Bullying (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Spain Identifies Risk of Problem Loans in Savings Banks
description: MADRID  Spains central bank on Monday classified 46 percent of the exposure that the countrys savings banks had to the construction and real estate sectors as problematic.

title: Maersk Line Orders 10 Container Ships With Option to Buy More
description: Betting on a continued rebound in global trade, Maersk Line said on Monday that it had agreed to buy up to 30 of the largest container ships ever built from Daewoo Shipbuilding and Marine Engineering of South Korea, in a deal that could be worth $5.7 billion.

title: Q.&A.: Low-Budget Passport Photos
description: Q.

title: Arrests in Zimbabwe for Seeing Videos
description: JOHANNESBURG  Dozens of students, trade unionists and political activists who gathered to watch Al Jazeera and BBC news reports on the uprisings that brought down autocrats in Tunisia and Egypt have been arrested on suspicion of plotting to oust President Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe.

title: When the Doctors Wife Has Cancer
description: As a medical student 20 years ago, I learned all about anatomy, physiology and pharmacology. My professors also taught me, implicitly, how to put on the white doctor coat as a shield against human vulnerability. With the coat on, you could get right up close to frailty, even touch it, and it wouldnt be able to reach out and pull you in.

title: For Liszts 200th, a Youthful Tribute
description: Many 19th-century composers endured poverty, illness and artistic struggle, their achievements fully recognized only posthumously. Franz Liszt followed the opposite trajectory: he lived a glamorous life, rich in material and artistic success, but his reputation suffered in posterity.

title: American Songbooks Afro-Cuban Connection
description: Ral Esparzas driving force is a daredevil spirit of defiance. Bring on the challenge, and he will leap into the breach.

title: For Pepsi, a Business Decision With Social Benefit
description: SAN GABRIEL, Mexico  In the past, farmers would make the dangerous trek north from this tiny town hidden in the rugged folds of the Jalisco mountain range to the United States, hoping to earn enough money doing odd jobs to cover debts incurred while cultivating the small plots of land that have been in their families for generations.

title: Blagojevich Trying to Keep Recordings Out of Court
description: CHICAGO  Rod R. Blagojevich, the ousted governor of Illinois, is trying to stop federal prosecutors from playing wiretap recordings during his retrial on corruption charges this spring.

title: In Budget Bill, a Dispute Over Border Security
description: Preparing for the fight next week in Congress over federal spending legislation, Democratic leaders in the Senate said they will not support a bill with $60 billion in budget cuts that passed the Republican-led House on Saturday because it reduces funding for border security.

title: Studying Aging, and Fearing Budget Cuts
description: Dr. Richard J. Hodes presides over the nations prime source of grants for studies of aging at a worrisome time for researchers. Just when the cohort of elderly Americans is surging, many scientists fear that government budget cuts may hamper a broad array of research efforts on Alzheimers and other diseases of aging  not to mention the eye-catching recent progress on reversing age-related decline in genetically altered mice.

title: The Threatening Scent of Fertile Women
description: The 21-year-old woman was carefully trained not to flirt with anyone who came into the laboratory over the course of several months. She kept eye contact and conversation to a minimum. She never used makeup or perfume, kept her hair in a simple ponytail, and always wore jeans and a plain T-shirt.

title: The Surreal Life of Aron Ralston
description: With all the attention being paid to James culturally omnipresent Franco - being everywhere all the time kind of makes you a go-to target, especially for people looking for go-to targets - its almost easy to forget that Mr. Franco is getting Oscar attention not just for manic multitasking but for playing a real person: the hiker Aron Ralston, whose true story inspired 127 Hours.

title: Opposition to Infrastructure Spending: The Origins
description: Im currently reading Daniel Walker Howes What Hath God Wrought, and theres an interesting discussion of the debate over internal improvements. Some southerners were opposed, for an interesting reason. Heres Nathaniel Macon of North Carolina, in 1818:

title: Blockbuster Receives $290 Million Initial Takeover Bid
description: Blockbuster, the bankrupt video rental company, said on Monday that it had agreed to sell itself to a group of creditors for about $290 million as a way to jump-start an auction process that could yield a higher bid.

title: Critics' Picks: 'Donnie Brasco'
description: A. O. Scott discusses themes of loyalty and betrayal in Mike Newell's 1997 film.

title: Bay Says Hell Gladly Give Up No. 44, but
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Under the right circumstances, Jason Bay wants to give up his No. 44 jersey. Bay, who has worn the number since he was traded from the Pirates to the Red Sox at the trading deadline in 2008, said he is hoping to give the number to Jason Isringhausen if Isringhausen makes the team.

title: Colorado Faces a Fight Over Naturopathy
description: DENVER  For more than a decade, Mark Cooper has had a bustling naturopathy practice in Colorado Springs, treating everything from chronic headaches to digestive problems to insomnia.

title: Cutting Hair and Cracking Wise, All While the Radio Plays
description: You know this place, even if you dont know the language. Its the wacky small business where little business gets done but where an eclectic group of people gather to crack wise and occasionally say something pithy, and it has been a staple of American sitcoms over the years: a general store, a diner, a neighborhood bar, a taxi garage, a barbershop.

title: Spider-Man Producers Hire Help; More Delays Possible
description: The producers of the Broadway musical Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark have brought on a veteran musical supervisor and conductor, Paul Bogaev, as a consultant to help improve the performance, vocal and orchestration arrangements, and sound quality of the songs and numbers, a production spokesman, Rick Miramontez, confirmed on Monday.

title: Civilizations End, but Does Happiness?
description: Watching Heaven on Earth at La MaMa is a bit like sitting on a bus, with strangers conversations drifting in and out of your consciousness. Pieces may catch your attention, but you dont expect narrative coherence. In any case, too many other things compete for your focus: the passing scenery, your iPod, the newspaper in your lap.

title: Rasmussen Poll on Wisconsin Dispute May Be Biased
description: Weve noted before that the automated polling firm Rasmussen Reports has had problems with bias in a statistical sense: in the election last fall, its polls overestimated the standing of Republican candidates by roughly 4 percentage points on average.

title: Spotify Raises Investments at $1 Billion Valuation
description: Spotify, the online music service, has raised new financing from investors including Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers at a valuation of more than $1 billion, a person briefed on the matter told DealBook on Monday.

title: Mining Memories to Preserve the Past
description: Her memory is creaky, Dwania Kyles insisted, and most of the photographs that help unlock it are stored in her computer. But recently, sitting in a warren of rooms in Harlem as the light outside faded, she had a rush of recollections about her family and the night that the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. did not come to dinner.

title: Turning It Outside-In at Armory
description: The prospect of a major New York premiere, with all its attendant notice, is something most composers might dream of longingly. But when John Luther Adams was approached with the notion of having his Inuksuit performed as the final event of the Tune-In Music Festival at the Park Avenue Armory, he resisted, he said on Sunday afternoon in a conversation before the concert there.

title: Miami, Another Battlefront in the War Against Wrinkles
description: Inevitably, one day your toddler will ask: Mommy, is there really any difference between one Housewife and the next? I mean, dont they even all go to the same plastic surgeon? You will feel the instinct to respond counterintuitively. Absolutely, Sophie, you will say. The Real Housewives franchise is an exercise in anthropology. It seeks to explore the different ways wealthy women live in different parts of the country. I mean, honey, youre probably not going to find an emotionally volatile, discount-upholstery-fabrics heiress like Jill Zarin in Atlanta.

title: A Guitarist Adds Depth With Some Extra Strings
description: Just after a group of Dowland lute works that opened his recital at the Frick Collection on Sunday afternoon, the Swedish guitarist Goran Sollscher told the audience that he was particularly fond of slow music. The Dowland set, which had the doleful Lachrimae Pavan as its centerpiece, suggested as much, as did the work that followed his remarks, Sylvius Leopold Weisss Tombeau sur la Mort de M. Comte de Logy. Indeed, relaxed tempos became a unifying theme. Mr. Sollscher opened the second half with a work by Arvo Prt, whom he described, accurately, as the master of slowness. And as his only encore, he played a Bach sarabande.

title: BHP to Pay Chesapeake $4.75 Billion for Shale Gas Assets
description: BHP Billiton said on Monday afternoon that it would buy Chesapeake Energys shale-based natural gas assets in northern Arkansas for $4.75 billion.

title: Celebrating 50 Years Worth of Promising Talent
description: Success in any artistic field depends largely on talent and hard work, but also on the luck of recognition.

title: Critics Choice: New CDs
description: GIL SCOTT-HERON AND JAMIE XX

title: Union Bonds in Wisconsin Begin to Fray
description: JANESVILLE, Wis.  Rich Hahn worked at the General Motors plant here until it closed about two years ago. He moved to Detroit to take another G.M. job while his wife and children stayed here, but then the automaker cut more jobs. So Mr. Hahn, 50, found himself back in Janesville, collecting unemployment for a time, and watching as the citys industrial base seemed to crumble away.

title: Video of Libyan Diplomats Denouncing Qaddafi
description: As my colleague Colin Moynihan reports, on Monday in New York members of Libyas mission to the United Nations denounced Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi for his bloody response to protests and called on him to resign.

title: Adam Driver On Stage
description: A look at some of the actors past performances.

title: No Combat Duty but Plenty of Curtain Calls
description: The moment that persuaded Adam Driver to pursue an acting career didnt come when he was cast as the Leading Player in a college production of Pippin, or even when he was accepted to Juilliard. It happened one thankfully windy afternoon as a cloud of deadly white phosphorus  a high-powered chemical that can burn through cars  inched its way toward him and a group of fellow Marines during a mishap in a California training exercise.

title: Child-Product Makers Seek to Soften New Rules
description: Emboldened by a Republican majority in the House of Representatives, manufacturers of toys and other childrens products are making a last-ditch effort to quash new safety regulations that they say are unfair or too onerous.

title: Shakespeare, Pirate: An Internet Tale
description: To the Editor:

title: Reporters Notebook: In Afghanistan, Glimpses of the Soviet Try
description: This is the view from the American outpost at Band-e Sardeh, in Ghazni Province. To the left is a large Soviet-built reservoir. Its pale green surface, at least near the dam beneath the road, is now frozen. The dam was built by the Soviet Union in the 1960s, during the Kremlins long and frustrating period of Moscow-Kabul engagement. The American outpost today lies within the confines of what was once a much larger Soviet Army position astride a significant Kremlin public-works investment. Last fall, before air and water temperatures plummeted with the onset of the Afghan winter, the American soldiers here swam in the lake, no doubt just like their Soviet predecessors did.

title: For Air Passengers, Future Doesnt Look Rosy
description: I HAD reason to contemplate elementary physics last week when a fellow passenger, whom I shall sarcastically call Tiny, hauled himself into the middle seat beside me on a Southwest Airlines flight from Washington to Denver.

title: Word Games Anytime, No Travel Tiles Required
description: If the inventor of Scrabble were alive today, he would be amazed by the way millions of people are playing his word game now: on tiny screens, wherever they happen to be, against players who can be halfway across the country, or the world.

title: Hank Steinbrenner Picks on the Captain
description: When I left Tampa for some snow shoveling back home on Sunday night, there was nothing left to ask Derek Jeter. He had spoken for about 20 minutes that morning in his first gathering of the season with the news media. It went smoothly.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 4,429 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war and 1,464 who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

title: Bloggingheads: Abortion War
description: Sarah Posner, left, of Religion Dispatches and David Weigel of Slate debate the G.O.P.'s fight against abortion.

title: Resisting Trujillo While Staying Stylish
description: I had never heard of the Mirabal sisters before I saw En el Tiempo de las Mariposas, Repertorio Espaols version of their tragic story. But the actresses playing them look smashing (and very much like the real Mirabals) in their stylishly feminine 1940s and 50s dresses and little hats.

title: Dynegys Top Executives to Resign in Wake of Failed Deals
description: Dynegy, the embattled power company, said late on Monday that its top management team, including its chief executive, planned to resign after the company failed in its second attempt to sell itself.

title: Gattuso Gets Four-Game Ban
description: A.C. Milan midfielder Gennaro Gattuso was suspended for four European games by UEFAs disciplinary committee on Monday for his actions in last weeks Round of 16 game against Tottenham.

title: Wades Busy Weekend Gives Him Time to Relax
description: LOS ANGELES  Dwyane Wade knows that children sometimes ask more serious questions than reporters.

title: A Founding Fathers Books Turn Up
description: A literary detective story that began 18 months ago and was advanced through a chance reading of an 1880 edition of The Harvard Register has led researchers from the Jefferson Library at Monticello to a trove of books that were among the last ones that Thomas Jefferson, the nations most bibliophilic president, collected and read in the decade before he died.

title: A Risky Trip Leads to Stardom and Sanctuary
description: A Honduran teenager gained fame as the star of a documentary film that showed the dangers faced by children who ride across Mexico atop freight trains to cross illegally to the United States. But the boy, Kevin Casasola, rode the trains again, and now he has been granted asylum in the United States, his lawyer said on Monday.

title: Japanese Stock Market Is Getting New Respect
description: TOKYO  Japans government finances are on the verge of collapse, and its economy has floundered for two decades.

title: B. N. Nathanson, 84, Dies; Changed Sides on Abortion
description: Dr. Bernard N. Nathanson, a campaigner for abortion rights who, after experiencing a change of heart in the 1970s became a prominent opponent of abortion and the on-screen narrator of the anti-abortion film The Silent Scream, died on Monday at his home in Manhattan. He was 84.

title: A School Topples Hurdles to Learning
description: ALBERTSON, N.Y.  It is lunchtime in the cafeteria of the Henry Viscardi School in Nassau County, and two eighth graders are doing what boys their age do best: batting insults back and forth.

title: Exposs on Oil Spill in Gulf, Afghanistan and Steroids Win Polk Awards
description: Investigative reports that exposed the devastating environmental and economic impact of the oil spill last year in the Gulf of Mexico and leadership failings in Americas military mission in Afghanistan were among the winners of 13 George Polk Awards for 2010 announced on Monday by Long Island University.

title: All or Nothing
description: Philadelphia, Feb. 22, 1861

title: Win at Daytona Energizes a Venerated Nascar Brand
description: DAYTONA BEACH, Fla.  Nascar itself could not have scripted an ending to this years Daytona 500 that would have put the Wood Brothers in victory lane on Sunday at Daytona International Speedway. That was nearly impossible for a team that was once a standard-bearer in Nascar but had fallen behind the competition years ago.

title: Keeping a Watchful Eye on a Part of the Bronx
description: Maybe it was the sudden screech of the buss brakes or the orange flash of its hazard lights. But something caught Sidney Floress attention on a recent Friday night. Something was not right. Mr. Flores quickly made a U-turn and came to a stop behind the bus on East Fordham Road in the Bronx.

title: Ibrahim Dabbashi's Press Conference
description: On Feb. 21, Libya's ambassador to the United Nations gave a press conference to announce that mission staffers are calling upon Muammar el-Qaddafi to leave Libya.

title: A Scholastic Refuge for Severely Disabled Children
description: The Henry Viscardi School on Long Island caters to a variety of children, including those who cannot hear, see or turn the pages of a textbook.

title: A Famous Babys First Word? Hint: Its Not Mama
description: IN a dictionary of brand names, you can find Clicquot Club beverages, pronounced KLEE-ko; De Cecco pasta, pronounced, roughly, Day CHECK-o; and Chicos, the retailer of womens clothing, pronounced CHEE-kos.

title: Political Unrest in North Africa and the Middle East
description: In the wake of the overthrow of the leaders of Tunisia and Egypt, here is a look at challenges facing other countries across the region.

title: In This City, Its a Long Climb to the Top
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The long war here has had a lot of ups and downs, but that has not been the case with the countrys elevators  at least until recently.

title: Whose Day? Well, at Least Its Not Whos
description: On Monday, Radio Shack offered special prices for Presidents Day. Office Depot had discounts, too, in honor of Presidents Day. Not to be left out, Macys advertised sales of its own to celebrate Presidents Day.

title: Hank Steinbrenner on Revenue Sharing
The War for (George) Washington
description: Charleston, S.C., Feb. 22, 1861

title: Banner Year for Skiing, and for Search Parties
description: KILLINGTON, Vt.  With near-record snowfalls leaving several feet of fluffy powder, ski resorts on the East Coast have had no trouble attracting skiers and snowboarders this season. The problem has been keeping them on the mountain.

title: As Talks Continue, Jets Tell Staff to Expect Furloughs
description: Negotiators for N.F.L. owners and the players union met for the fourth consecutive day in the presence of a federal mediator Monday, just 11 days before the collective bargaining agreement is set to expire. While nobody is discussing what is being said behind closed doors in Washington, the sides have spent more than 25 hours together, by far their most consistent negotiating time toward a new deal.

title: With Mideast Unrest, Foreign Investment Is Again Interrupted
description: With the global markets on the mend last fall, a private equity consortium moved to sell its 93 percent stake in the Egyptian drug maker Amoun Pharmaceutical.

title: Billionaire Brothers Money Plays Role in Wisconsin Dispute
description: WASHINGTON  Among the thousands of demonstrators who jammed the Wisconsin State Capitol grounds this weekend was a well-financed advocate from Washington who was there to voice praise for cutting state spending by slashing union benefits and bargaining rights.

title: As Chicago Votes, Many Say the Question About Emanuel Isnt If, but When
description: CHICAGO  As Chicagoans headed to the polls on Tuesday, the water-cooler debates here have focused less on whether Rahm Emanuel, the former White House chief of staff, would become mayor of this city, than on when.

title: Shhh, and Not Because the Fauna Are Sleeping
description: MUIR WOODS NATIONAL MONUMENT, Calif.  At times, deep within this vaulted chamber of redwoods, it is almost quiet enough to hear a banana slug slither by. For the National Park Service, that stillness is as vital a component of the site as the trees green needles, or the sudden darting rays of sunlight.

title: For Christie, Ailing Economy at Home May Test His Allure
description: In a year as governor of New Jersey, Chris Christie has captivated conservatives across the nation, with an in-your-face frankness and nonstop aggressiveness that few have seen from a chief executive.

title: N.F.L. Labor Dispute Plays Out on Twitter
description: A few hours after N.F.L. owners filed a complaint against the players union last week alleging that it was not bargaining in good faith, Houston Texans right tackle Eric Winston took to his keyboard to react.

title: Collinss Pep Talk Makes an Impression on the Mets
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Sometimes the simple, blunt honesty of a child is enough to shatter the niceties of adult discourse and drive home an important message. And it was a 7-year-old Mets fan whose pointed question to Manager Terry Collins during the off-season framed one of the themes of Collinss speech to the team on Monday.

title: Long-Term Care Needs Changes, Officials Say
description: WASHINGTON  One of Senator Edward M. Kennedys legacies in the new health care law, intended to allow the chronically ill and people with disabilities to continue living in their homes, is too costly to survive without major changes, Obama administration officials now say.

title: For a Bond Formed Over Mohair, Its Not So Odd
description: WASHINGTON  One lawmaker is a brash New Yorker whose tempestuous speeches on the House floor are a thing of YouTube wonder. The other is the fun-guy-in-your-physics-class type who prefers to cut up on Fox News. One has an F from the National Rifle Association, the other likes to tote his Glock as he walks the streets of his Utah district. Their voting records have almost zero overlap.

title: F.D.I.C. Is Said to Weigh Suing Leaders of Washington Mutual
description: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation has sent letters to several former executives of Washington Mutual warning that it was considering taking legal action tied to their role in the collapse of the savings bank, according to a person with knowledge of the matter.

title: Dim View of U.S. Posture Toward Bahraini Shiites Is Described
description: MANAMA, Bahrain  The United States military undermined efforts to improve relations with Bahrains Shiite majority and understated abuses by the Sunni royal family, according to one present and one former American government adviser and a Bahraini human rights advocate.

title: Carmelo Anthony Headed to the Knicks
description: A Knicks revival that began last July and took hold in the fall is about to receive another significant infusion of star power. Carmelo Anthony is bound for New York.

title: What Did Watson the Computer Do?
description: Last week brought the story of a fourth grader who was suspended from school for having placed a kick me please post-it on the backside of a classmate. The punishment, The New York Post reported, was delivered by the school principal who said in a note to the boys parents, This incident is in violation of the Discipline Code and is classified as infraction A37  engaging in bullying behavior.

title: The Dirty Energy Party
description: President Obama has decided that the failure of last years comprehensive climate bill does not have to mean the death of climate policy. Instead of imposing a mandatory cap and stiff price on carbon emissions, as the bill would have done, the president is offering a more modest approach involving sharply targeted and well-financed research into breakthrough technologies, cleaner fuels and more efficient cars and trucks.

title: F.D.I.C. May Sue Former Washington Mutual Executives
description: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation has sent letters to former leaders of the failed lender, and agency officials have discussed seeking damages of up to $1 billion, The New York Times reports. Read more

title: Mr. Bloombergs Not-So-Bad Budget
description: When Mayor Michael Bloomberg presented his new budget for New York City, he rightly took credit for keeping the city fiscally fit through the worst recession in decades. His $65.6 billion budget for the next fiscal year was less painful than expected. Now he needs to make sure that an improved economy  and improved tax revenues  helps those who need help the most.

title: Advocate for Women in Baseball Finally Gets to Be One
description: GOODYEAR, Ariz.  Justine Siegal felt a chill of excitement when she saw her dark blue Cleveland Indians jersey. She changed in the umpires locker room and emerged with a confident gait, her blond pigtails shining in the Arizona morning sun. Siegal, 36, smiled as she prepared for her debut Monday, her 13-year-old daughter, Jasmine, following close by her side.

title: Lucking Out Inside the Beltway
description: The House Republican majority made a big show last week of pursuing its campaign promise to slash the federal budget. Far less obvious was the discreet dinner break for campaign fund-raising taken by 13 freshmen Republicans on the Armed Services Committee. The yearling defense appropriators went to solicit re-election help from the defense industry.

title: What Quincy Can Teach New York City
description: The drama of urban snow removal has preoccupied this newspaper for 150 years. In 1910, The Times wrote about no-show contractors failing to get men and wagons onto the streets after a storm that buried New York City and snarled the Long Island Rail Road. In 2010, we  and pretty much everyone in the city  criticized a no-show mayor who left town before a storm that buried the city and snarled the Long Island Rail Road.

title: Strong Earthquake Shakes New Zealand
description: A large earthquake struck Christchurch, New Zealand, on Tuesday, according to the United States Geological Survey, causing buildings to collapse and burying vehicles under debris. Prime Minister John Key said at least 65 people had been killed.

title: A Families-First Approach to Foster Care
description: Its difficult to change systems even when they are widely acknowledged to be broken. Thats the situation facing the nations foster care system. According to the governments most recent estimate, there were roughly 424,000 young people in foster care as of Sept. 30, 2009. Each year, about 30,000 of them turn 18 (or 21 in some states) and age out of foster care. What happens to them?

title: Lottery Numbers
Make Everybody Hurt
description: Over the past few weeks weve begun to see the new contours of American politics. The budget cutters have taken control of the agenda, while governments defenders are waging tactical retreats. Given the scope of the fiscal problems, it could be like this for the next 10 or 20 years.

title: Timing a Glencore I.P.O.
Protests Continue in Wisconsin
description: Union members and supporters in Wisconsin protested Governor Scott Walkers bid to reduce the bargaining power of unions at the capital for a seventh straight day.

title: At Grave Risk
description: Buried deep beneath the stories about executive bonuses, the stock market surge and the economys agonizingly slow road to recovery is the all-but-silent suffering of the many millions of Americans who, economically, are going down for the count.

title: Rodriguez, With Leaner Physique and Healed Hip, Has Renewed Focus
description: TAMPA, Fla.  One of Alex Rodriguezs boyhood heroes, Cal Ripken, was on his mind Monday. Asked how much longer he expected to play third base, Rodriguez cited Ripken as someone who flouted the perception that aging players should automatically assume diminished roles.

title: Ethics Reform in Albany
description: To the Editor:

title: Seoul Hotel Break-In Has Makings of a Spy Novel
description: SEOUL, South Korea  Police officials are investigating a mysterious break-in at the five-star Lotte Hotel, an odd bit of cloak and dagger in Room 1961 whose storyline includes bumbling spies caught red-handed, negotiations for a supersonic jet fighter, a stolen laptop and a conveniently timed meeting with the president of South Korea.

title: Childrens Homework
description: To the Editor:

title: Banker Said to Be Held in Offshore Inquiry
description: A senior private banker at Credit Suisse has been arrested in the United States in connection with a federal investigation into the Swiss banks work with questionable offshore accounts, two people briefed on the matter said on Monday.

title: Midlevel Taliban Admit to a Rift With Top Leaders
description: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan  Recent defeats and general weariness after nine years of war are creating fissures between the Talibans top leadership based in Pakistan and midlevel field commanders, who have borne the brunt of the fighting and are reluctant to return to some battle zones, Taliban members said in interviews.

title: Corrections
description: NATIONAL

title: Germany Says Iran Meeting Necessary to Free Journalists
description: BERLIN  Chancellor Angela Merkels office on Monday addressed criticism of her foreign ministers decision to meet the Iranian president over the weekend, saying that it was the price to pay for the release of two German journalists and that it did not change Germanys criticisms of the Iranian government.

title: Best All-Star Game Ratings Since 03
description: The N.B.A. All-Star Game on Sunday attracted an average of 9.1 million viewers on TNT, up 33 percent from 6.9 million last year, according to Nielsen. It was the leagues most watched All-Star Game since 2003, when Michael Jordan made his final appearance.

title: Knicks Set to Acquire Anthony
description: Carmelo Anthony is nearly a Knick.

title: Ahead of Day of Rage, Iraqis Have Mixed Demands
description: BAGHDAD  It is a date being discussed in Iraqs tea shops, on television and in the streets with varying shades of hope, fear and cynicism.

title: Error Delayed Fire Dept. in Fatal Brooklyn Blaze
description: Firefighters were briefly delayed in putting out a fire in Flatbush, Brooklyn, on Saturday night because an engine that had been sent to the blaze was already at another emergency, attending to a police officer who had accidentally shot himself in the leg, the Fire Department said Monday. The fire eventually took the life of a 64-year-old woman living on the top floor.

title: Malcolm X Daughter Accused of Theft
description: One of Malcolm Xs daughters is being held in North Carolina on an arrest warrant from Queens, stemming from an accusation that she stole from the widow of one of her fathers bodyguards, the authorities said Monday.

title: Girardi Impressed by Brackmans Evolution
description: TAMPA, Fla.  The Yankees system is one of the best in baseball, and its strengths are not hard to discern. Of their top 30 prospects according to Baseball America, only 10 are position players. Jesus Montero, the touted 21-year-old catcher, is almost ready, and the Yankees hope that someday he will catch Andrew Brackman.

title: New Yorks Little Italy, Littler by the Year
description: In 1950, nearly half of the more than 10,000 New Yorkers living in the heart of Little Italy identified as Italian-American. The narrow streets teemed with children and resonated with melodic exchanges in Italian among the one in five residents born in Italy and their second- and third-generation neighbors.

title: Photo Replay: Feb. 21
description: A view of the day in sports, from raucous soccer fans to a prickly situation on the golf course.

title: Washington Theater to Bring Back Oklahoma!
description: Will Arena Stages revival of Oklahoma! make it to Broadway? In an unusual move, the Arena, a Washington theater, announced on Tuesday that it will resume performances of Oklahoma! on July 8 at its in-the-round Fichandler Stage, more than six months after the critical hit closed in December. The reprise is scheduled to run through Oct. 9.

title: Word of the Day | lustrous
description: lustrous \ls-trs\ adjective

title: Location and Timing Contribute to Losses in New Zealand Earthquake
description: Intensity maps from the United States Geological Survey help show why the earthquake that struck Christchurch, New Zealand, on Tuesday (local time), while substantially weaker than the temblor that struck nearby in September, appears to have been far more damaging and deadly, according to local news accounts. Timing clearly played a role, as well, with the latest quake striking at 12:51 p.m. local time on a work day. [12:57 a.m. | Updated  The latest reports indicate that scores of people were killed.]

title: Bold Move Puts Pressure on Anthony
description: The Knicks made the right decision.

title: Rescuers Work to Find Survivors of a Powerful New Zealand Earthquake
description: CHRISTCHURCH, New Zealand  Rescue workers spent a cold, rainy night pulling survivors from the wreckage caused by a powerful earthquake that struck Christchurch, New Zealands second largest city, early Tuesday afternoon, killing at least 75 people.

title: George Bugliarello, Visionary Engineer, Dies at 83
description: George Bugliarello, who as president of Polytechnic Institute of New York spearheaded the creation of MetroTech, a 16-acre research park that spurred development in Downtown Brooklyn, died on Friday in Roslyn, N.Y. He was 83.

title: Is This Apartheid in Bahrain?
description: A few scattered thoughts about Bahrain, on a day on which huge protests are unfolding.

title: Free Trove of Music Scores on Web Hits Sensitive Copyright Note
description: Humanitys musical treasures  Beethoven piano sonatas, Schubert songs, Mozart symphonies and the like  come to life in performance. But they truly survive as black marks on a page, otherwise known as scores. Now a Web site founded five years ago by a conservatory student, then 19 years old, has made a vast expanse of this repertory available, free.

title: News Quiz | February 22, 2011
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: Qaddafis Grip on the Capital Tightens as Revolt Grows
description: TOBRUK, Libya  Vowing to track down and kill protesters house by house, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi of Libya tightened his grip on the capital, Tripoli, on Tuesday, but the eastern half of the country was slipping beyond his control.

title: Israel Silent as Iranian Ships Transit Suez Canal
description: JERUSALEM  Israeli leaders maintained a tense silence on Tuesday over reports that two Iranian Navy ships had passed through the Suez Canal and entered the Mediterranean en route to Syria, a move described by officials here as a provocation.

title: Zurich Financial Buys Majority Stake in Santander Insurance Unit
description: The Zurich Financial Services Group said on Tuesday that it would pay $1.67 billion to Banco Santander of Spain for a majority stake in its Latin American insurance operations.

title: What Does Mercy Look Like?
description: Mercy is commonly defined as compassion, forgiveness, kindness or an act of piety. But photographs of prisoners reaching through bars, a wrestler being contorted by masked men and an infant dressed for burial are among the many interpretations of the word in the book The Mercy Project/Inochi, created and curated by James Whitlow Delano.

title: Return of the Champions League: Week II
description: Chelsea has not died is probably not the greatest of rallying cries, but it might be all Carlo Ancelotti and his team have left. After tumbling to fifth in the Premier League and falling out of the F.A. Cup, Chelsea travels to F.C. Copenhagen for a Champions League game on Tuesday hoping to salvage a season gone suddenly, horribly wrong.

title: Do You Write in Your Books?
description: The rise of e-books means the decline of marginalia  readers written commentary in the margins of their books  much to the dismay of many book lovers, librarians and historians. Do you write in your books? Do you enjoy reading what others have written in the margins of old books?

description: A moment of levity during this time of labor talks .

title: An Electronic Music Celebration in Amsterdam
description: Amsterdam thumps to an electronic beat as the 5 Days Off festival presents D.J.s and live bands exploring all areas of electronic music, from March 2 to 6. Now in its 11th year, the festival (31-20-799-7271; www.5daysoff.nl) features the genres superstars alongside emerging artists and local favorites.

description: Edward L. Glaeser is an economics professor at Harvard and the author of Triumph of the City.

title: Searching for a Place In a Better World
description: Susanne Biers In a Better World goes into Sundays Academy Awards as the favorite to capture the Oscar for best foreign-language film, if only because it won the Golden Globe in that category last month. The film, which is mainly in Danish, is a thoughtful and complex movie, set in a quiet village in Denmark and in a refugee camp in an African country riven by civil war. A compassionate but flawed Danish doctor serves, in Ms. Biers words, as the character who bridges those two worlds.

description: A century ago, a glance at Ellis Islands handwritten ledgers would have offered a sense of the diverse crowds pouring into New York.

title: London Fashion Week | Love, Gradually
description: Monday was a packed day of shows. Riding on the heels of a successful spring collection, Peter Pilotto and Christopher De Vos of Peter Pilotto showed their signature long cutout dresses in black and white patterns. There was a sexy white sheath with a peekaboo slash from the neckline down toward the torso. Multicolored cardigans, lots of layers, and skirts over pants (a trend here) over thick blue tights made for a warm and wearable collection.

title: A Green Makeover for Planters Nutmobile
description: The Nutmobile, the peanut-shaped traveling ambassador for the Planters brand, is going green. Its newest iteration runs on biodiesel and has a wind turbine, solar panels, LED interior lighting, recycled parts and wood floors reclaimed from a 19th century Pennsylvania barn. It will make its public debut at the Global Green Oscars preparty in Los Angeles on Wednesday.

title: Google Faces New Antitrust Charges in Europe
description: BRUSSELS  Google faced new accusations on Tuesday that it was blocking a smaller European search service by restricting the use of its powerful system for attracting advertisers.

description: The economics of the N.B.A. dictate that there are only two ways to build an elite team:

title: Protests in Bahrain Become Test of Wills
description: MANAMA, Bahrain  More than 100,000 demonstrators packed central Pearl Square here on Tuesday in what organizers called the largest pro-democracy demonstration this tiny Persian Gulf nation had ever seen, as the monarchy struggled to hold on to its monopoly on power.

title: BP Moves to Shed Some British Assets
description: BP, in the midst of a spurt of global deal-making, announced of Tuesday that it wanted to sell its interests in some British oil and natural gas fields.

title: Pirates Brutally End Yachting Dream
description: LOS ANGELES  Jean and Scott Adam shared a dream through 15 years of marriage: to retire, build a boat and sail the world. And that is precisely what they did, heading out in 2004 from Marina Del Rey, Calif., on a custom-built 58-foot yacht for a permanent vacation that brought them to exotic islands and remote coastlines: Fiji, Micronesia, China, Phuket.

title: Name That Tune, if Its a New York TV Theme
description: The  death last week of John Strauss, composer of the theme song to Car 54, Where Are You? put the tune in heavy rotation on the playlist in our brains all weekend. And it got us thinking: What are some other super-catchy New York television themes? Here, again by the miracle of YouTube, is the theme from The 4:30 Movie, which ran for many years on Channel 7. Movies were either divided in half, with lots of commercials, to stretch across two hour-and-a-half slots on successive afternoons, or cut to ribbons to fit into one. And there were themes: Planet of the Apes Week, Our Man Flint Week (remember that?), etc.

title: Home Prices Slid in December in Most U.S. Cities, Index Shows
description: Real estate prices slid in just about every part of the country in December, pushing a housing market that once seemed to be rebounding nearly back to its lowest level since the crash began.

title: Ruling Party In Japan Suspends Kingmaker
description: TOKYO  Japans governing party suspended its scandal-tainted political kingmaker on Tuesday as Prime Minister Naoto Kan struggled to restore his flagging popularity ahead of a crucial budget battle.

title: N.H.L. Gets Boost With a Nearly $400 Million Beer Deal
description: The N.H.L. often boasts about improving business measures like higher TV ratings, increased use of its Web site and the success of the annual Winter Classic.

With good humor, Derek Jeter responded Tuesday morning to comments by Hank Steinbrenner, who took an indirect shot at Jeter by saying Monday that some players were too busy building mansions and not concentrating on winning after their 2010 bid for a title repeat ended in the American League Championship Series.

description: REDMOND, Wash.  Behind Kinect, the computer game device that recognizes gestures and voice commands, lies a far larger agenda for Microsoft.

title: If You Go to Bretton Woods
description: Full-day lift tickets at the Bretton Woods ski area (brettonwoods.com) are $37 to $76, with discounts for staying at one of the resorts lodging properties. The price for a three-and-a-half-hour canopy tour, a series of treetop zip lines, is $99 to $110. A shorter racing zip line is $15 a ride. Reservations are suggested: (603) 278-4947.

title: U.S. Sales At Wal-Mart Show Decline
description: As the Christmas season approached, Wal-Mart Stores said it was fixing the problems in its United States division. It hired new executives, added merchandise that it had cut, and fought with Target and other competitors to provide the lowest prices over the holidays.

description: Justine Siegal throws batting practice for the Cleveland Indians, becoming the first woman to pitch to a major league team.

title: Fill-In: Blogging and Young People
What Were Reading: SoHo Development
The Problem With Public Relations
description: Six months before Southfork Kitchen opened, a local public relations director pitched me, telling me what he would do, how he would do it and how much it would cost: $4,500 a month for the busy months of the year and maybe half that for the other half. I wondered which six months needed more P.R.  the long lonely winters or the hot and heavy summers? The Hamptons is an archipelago of 20 key resort towns where even the worst restaurants seem crowded in the summer.

title: Last-Minute Push by Chicago Mayoral Candidates
description: CHICAGO  As the candidates made last-minute appeals for votes at train stations and in diners, Chicago voters began streaming to the polls on Tuesday morning to pick their first new mayor in 22 years.

title: Are We Buying High All Over Again?
description: Carl Richards is a certified financial planner in Park City, Utah. His sketches are archived here on the Bucks blog and on his personal Web site, BehaviorGap.com.

title: Judith P. Sulzberger, Physician and Times Family Member, Dies at 87
description: Dr. Judith P. Sulzberger, a physician whose philanthropy led to the creation of a center for genome studies in her name at Columbia Universitys College of Physicians and Surgeons, and a member of the family that controls The New York Times, died on Monday at her home in Manhattan. She was 87.

title: Lifting the Veil on the Practice of Billing Patients Who Sue
description: New York State has long had a policy of countersuing patients who demand compensation for being injured in state psychiatric hospitals. The Office of Mental Health immediately bills them for the time they spend in the hospital, often stopping the case cold and making it nearly impossible for the patient to attract or keep a lawyer, a practice we explored in this article in December.

title: Return of the (Other) Champions League
description: Hey Columbus Crew and Real Salt Lake, welcome to the post-preseason, you are both playing Tuesday night in a meaningful regional tournament more than three weeks before the start of the 2011 Major League Soccer season, though it is certainly not Arsenal-Barcelona, Real Madrid-Lyon, Inter-Bayern Munich in the Europes, if not the worlds, premier club competition.

title: AOL Founder Named to Presidents Jobs Council
description: President Obama named Steve Case, the AOL founder, to the new White House Council on Jobs and Competitiveness.

title: Issues of Adjustment Loom for Knicks
description: After months of insufferable rumor after insufferable rumor, Carmelo Anthony is finally set to be a Knick. But Anthony is not the only likely inbound Nugget; Chauncey Billups will take over the outgoing Raymond Feltons job as starting point guard, and three role players  Shelden Williams, Anthony Carter and Renaldo Balkman  could help fill in minutes at the bottom of Coach Mike DAntonis rotation. This is obviously a substantial deal for New York, as DAntoni will have to integrate two major contributors on the fly while also dealing with the losses of Felton, Danilo Gallinari, Wilson Chandler and Timofey Mozgov. Thats a substantial portion of the Knicks lineup that is headed to Denver, and trading away so many foundational players makes the process of incorporating Anthony, Billups, et al., even more difficult.
