title: Stanford Joins Madoff at North Carolina Prison
description: Bernard L. Madoff, meet your new neighbor: R. Allen Stanford, the jailed Texas financier. The two men are now at the same prison.

title: Thune Passes on 2012 Presidential Run
description: Senator John Thune, Republican of South Dakota, has decided not to run for president in 2012, according to a statement on his Facebook page.

title: SoLoMo
description: Portmanteau term for the meeting of Social, Local and Mobile media.

title: Accounts and People of Note in the Ad Industry
description: Chris Adams and Margaret Keene, a creative team, are joining the Torrance, Calif., office of Saatchi & Saatchi, part of the Publicis Groupe, as executive creative directors, overseeing the output of the 74 members of the creative department. They are assuming duties that had been handled by Mike McKay, who left to become executive creative director at the San Francisco office of BBDO Worldwide, part of the Omnicom Group. The team had been group creative directors, working on brands like Nissan and Pedigree, at the Playa del Rey, Calif., office of TBWA/Chiat/Day, part of the TBWA Worldwide unit of Omnicom. The Torrance office of Saatchi & Saatchi creates campaigns for Toyota Motor Sales USA.

title: HCA Confirms I.P.O. Price of Up to $30 a Share
description: HCA Holdings, the large hospital operator, confirmed that it had set a preliminary price range for its initial public offering of $27 to $30 a share.

title: NBC to Broadcast All Three Triple Crown Races
description: The NBC Sports group will broadcast all three legs of horse racings Triple Crown, unifying the spring races on one network for the first time since 2005.

title: Q&A: Day Trips From Sarajevo
description: My husband and I will be in Sarajevo this June. Do you know of any travel agencies in that city that can arrange day trips to places like Mostar and other sites in Bosnia and Herzegovina?

title: Authors of Palin Tell-All Book Accuse Rival Author of Leak
description: The authors of a tell-all book about Sarah Palin said that Joe McGinniss, the author of a rival book on Ms. Palin, leaked an early copy of their manuscript last week and had sabotaged their ability to sell it.

title: Directors Cut of Never Say Never Will Get Deeper in the Bieber Subculture
description: They grow up so quickly these days. Two weeks after the opening of Justin Bieber: Never Say Never, a 3-D concert documentary about that 16-year-old, Canada-preferring, floppy-hair-cutting, Grammy-almost-winning pop phenomenon, an extended version of that film will be released into theaters.

title: A Scrappy Youth and His Fists Must Fend for Themselves
description: On a warm night in July 1986, the writer Andre Dubus pulled over on a stretch of Massachusetts highway to help a young couple, a brother and sister, in a disabled car. Within a few minutes, a distracted driver ran into the three of them at nearly 60 miles an hour.

title: Optimistic, to a Point, About the Knicks Big Trade
description: Michael Powell, a business reporter for The Times, occasionally sends City Room dispatches about his beloved, bemoaned Knicks. Here are his thoughts on the Carmelo Anthony acquisition.

title: Playing a Sad Song for Joy: Mark Seliger
description: Mark Seligers collection of nudes, portraits and landscapes is just about the handsomest book of photographs to be published in a while. Every detail of Listen, from the quality of the binding and endpapers to the selection and reproduction of the platinum-plated prints, is a book-lovers treat. Mr. Seliger is such a believer. And he has put together a book, with Rizzoli, that sharpens the senses for the silent and seemingly insignificant. He is well known for his portraits of actors and musicians and his fashion work for magazines, among them Vanity Fair and Italian Vogue. Listen displays a natural feeling for things that hover between ordinary and monumental, sad and self-renewing. You can catch his show of photographs from Listen at the Steven Kasher Gallery in Chelsea; it closes on Saturday. Heres an excerpt from our recent conversation.

title: Facebook Poaches Googles Top Executive in Latin America
description: The fight for talent between Google and Facebook  or more precisely, the flow of Google employees to Facebook  is not just a Silicon Valley affair.

title: Southern Comfort Combines Tradition With New Technology
description: A liqueur brand born in New Orleans in 1874 is turning to some modern-day technologies to engage more effectively with contemporary consumers.

title: The Oscar Prognosticators Weigh In
description: Its like a more glamorous tax day: the Oscar ballots are due today, by 5 p.m. in the offices of PricewaterhouseCoopers in Los Angeles. (And the hard deadline matters; like recalcitrant high school seniors working on their college apps, every year there are some stragglers who wait until the last minute and must hand-deliver.) For the rest of the week, in their famously undisclosed location, the accountants will tabulate and retabulate. Which leaves the rest of us free to speculate and hypothesize.

title: Cracking the Genetic Code of Brown Tides
description: In the first genetic sequencing ever of a harmful algal bloom species, researchers said Tuesday that they had cracked the genome of the micro-organism responsible for the Eastern Seaboards notorious brown tides.

title: Celebrity Skin
description: Weve decided to spill the beans on one of Hollywoods best-kept secrets. (After all, why should tabloids have all the fun?) Her name is Joanna Czech, and her facials make the A-list sparkle.

title: Should Doctors Stop Patients From Driving?
description: In my many years of reporting about the elderly, I found little that caused doctors more angst than confronting a patient and family about driving. When is it time for someone with physical or cognitive problems to give up the car keys? Who makes that decision? And how can it safely and compassionately be enforced?

title: When Unsecured Creditors Are Unequal
description: Europeans have discovered, in plans for future bank recapitalizations, that all unsecured creditors are not created equal. This has long been the reality in the United States, although some found it politically convenient to pretend this was a new development, created solely for the automotive cases.

title: A Long, Deep View of the U.S. Budget
description: I thought the Obama White House had brought something useful to the budget debate with its visual depiction of United States spending  which revealed the profound growth in politically untouchable programs and the almost invisible dimensions of programs on education, research, innovation, development assistance and the like.

title: Trailer: 'Vieux Carr'
description: Excerpts from a rehearsal of the Wooster Group's production of the Tennessee Williams play. (Video courtesy of the Wooster Group; camera by Zbigniew Bzymek)

title: Striking PCB Levels Found at a New York School
description: The federal Environmental Protection Agency has found the highest levels of leaking PCBs to date in its inspections of New York City schools, at Public School 45 in Bushwick, Brooklyn.

title: German Defense Minister Defies Calls to Quit Over Plagiarism
description: BERLIN  Defying calls by the opposition for his resignation, the German defense minister, Karl-Theodor zu Guttenberg, said Tuesday that he would hold on to his job despite his admission that he had submitted a faulty dissertation for his doctoral degree.

title: Governors Ball Music Festival Is Planned
description: Add to the already crowded list of summer music festivals a new one destined for Governors Island, just off the southern tip of Manhattan. The inaugural Governors Ball Music Festival is scheduled to take place on the island, where Ronald Reagan once met with Mikhail Gorbachev, on June 18. It will offer a stylistically mixed bill, with a variety of indie rock, electronica, dance and hip-hop acts booked to perform. Headlining acts include Girl Talk; Pretty Lights; and Big Boi, of Outkast. Tickets are scheduled to go on sale on Thursday.

title: Highway in India Offers Solution to Land Fights
description: JIKARPUR, India  When the state of Uttar Pradesh announced plans to confiscate farmland for a toll road to the Taj Mahal, a grimly predictable plotline ensued. Protesting farmers, angry over low compensation, blocked road work. Frustration boiled into fatal clashes with the police. Then opposition politicians arrived to pillory the state government and pose for photos with farmers.

title: Indiana Treasurer to Challenge Lugar in 2012
description: Richard Mourdock, the state treasurer of Indiana, announced on Tuesday that he would challenge Senator Richard G. Lugar in the states Republican primary next year, one of several anticipated Tea Party challenges to incumbent Republican senators in 2012.

title: This Weeks Health Industry News
description: The effort by Congressional Republicans to undo the health care law and to cut the federal budget will shift out of Washington this week as members of Congress are in their home districts on a break.

title: Justices Reject Suit Faulting a Vaccine
description: WASHINGTON  People injured by vaccines that they say were improperly designed must rely solely on a compensation system created by a 1986 law and may not sue vaccine manufacturers, the Supreme Court ruled on Tuesday.

title: Its Wabbit Season
description: Whimsy is a word that runs rampant in the description of childrens literature, but Il Sung Nas picture books certainly merit the label. Snow Rabbit, Spring Rabbit is the latest of Nas deceptively simple storybooks (A Book of Sleep, Brrrr: A Book of Winter), where a straightforward tale of nature or nighttime is elevated by distinctive illustration into a somewhat more enchanted realm than that of mere snowfall and frozen dirt.

title: Christie Declares New Normal in Budget Proposal
description: TRENTON  A pugnacious and boastful Gov. Chris Christie proposed a no-growth budget for New Jersey on Tuesday, saying he had inspired a legion of copycat governors from Albany to Sacramento and was not about to let up in his efforts to shift money from public workers to property-tax payers and businesses that create jobs.

title: Anthony Is Only a Piece of the Puzzle
description: We all want to jump to conclusions, declare the Knicks acquisition of Carmelo Anthony to be the greatest deal in the history of the franchise since Dave DeBusschere. Or the worst case of destructive ownership interference since James L. Dolan tried to rehire Isiah Thomas (which, granted, was only last summer, but Dolan does seem to raise the bar on recidivism).

title: Reid Assigns Chief of Staff to Negotiate Spending Deal
description: 2:33 p.m. | Updated The Senate majority leader, Harry Reid of Nevada, called on Tuesday for a 30-day stop-gap spending bill to prevent a shutdown of the federal government early next month.

title: Teachers Union TV Ad Attacks Cuomos Budget Cuts
description: ALBANY  New Yorks teachers have taken to the airwaves.

title: Another Top Time Inc. Executive Departs
description: A top executive at Time Inc. announced on Tuesday that hewas leaving the company to return to his old job. It was the first sign of high-level fallout from the abrupt firing last week of Jack Griffin aschief executive.

title: The Too Big to Fail Quandary
description: Too big to fail, meet the regulatory bureaucracy.

title: For the S.E.C., Problems of Time and Money
description: The budget battle in Washington may constrain funding for the Securities and Exchange Commission as it tries to implement new rules required by the Dodd-Frank Act while dealing with a growing number of whistle-blower complaints and complex insider trading cases. A recent federal court decision in Texas in an options backdating case highlights the danger posed by a possible freeze or even cutbacks in the S.E.C.s budget if it results in slowing down investigations of possible securities fraud.

title: Robin Wagner, Set Designer for Producers, Dreamgirls, Gets Excellence Award
description: The veteran Broadway set designer Robin Wagner, whose early use of large-scale automated scenery in musicals like On the Twentieth Century and Dreamgirls has now become standard in American theater, will receive the industrys Robert L.B. Tobin Award for sustained excellence in theatrical design at a ceremony that will honor several colleagues as well. The Theater Development Fund, the not-for-profit group that runs TKTS and administer the awards, announced the recipients in a statement on Tuesday.

title: Oil Soars as Libyan Furor Shakes Markets
description: HOUSTON  The political turmoil sweeping the Arab world drove oil prices sharply higher and stocks much lower on Tuesday despite efforts by Saudi Arabia to calm turbulent markets.

title: Obama Meets Small-Business Owners
description: President Obama called for increased spending on education and transportation in order to help increase American competitiveness on Tuesday, as the White House continued to position itself as business-friendly and prepared to wrestle with Republicans over the budget deficit.

title: Critics Picks Video: Donnie Brasco
description: In this weeks Critics Picks video, A. O. Scott looks back at Mike Newells 1997 crime drama with Johnny Depp and Al Pacino, Donnie Brasco. Based on a true story, the film follows Joe Pistone, an undercover F.B.I. agent who is charged with the task of infiltrating the Bonanno crime family in the 1970s.

title: Big Love Watch: Anything Is Possible
description: As the final season of Big Love closes out, things are really feeling anarchic. Do you get the sense that anything could happen? That Barb could become a lesbian Mormon minister?

title: Apple Said to Showcase New iPad on March 2
description: If you are thinking of buying an iPad, you may want to hold off a bit.

title: Ristretto | Young Barista
description: Espresso Incognito, the coffee bar Callum Hale Thomson set up in Five Hundred Dollars, an art gallery on Vyner Street in East London, is only open the first and second Thursdays of each month from 6 to 9 p.m. and by special appointment. The hours are limited with good reason: Hale Thomson is just 15 years old, and still in school.

title: The Declining Payoff From Black Colleges
description: I mentioned in a recent post that students who choose to attend a historically black college instead of a more selective college may be hurting their future earnings prospects. Theres more evidence for this finding than I knew. A 2007 study, by Roland Fryer and Michael Greenstone, came to a similar conclusion.

title: The High Line, Manhattan, 2:34 P.M.
On Our Radar: Frog Deformities Tied to Pharmaceuticals and Plastics
description: Deformities in frogs in the northeastern United States are far more common in suburban and urban areas, not in and around farmlands, a Yale ecologists research shows. The findings upend the conventional wisdom that agricultural pesticides are largely responsible for the abnormalities. Rather, the combination of many household chemicals, including pharmaceuticals and plastics that mimic hormones, appear to be the root cause. [Yale Environment 360]

title: The Basics: Understanding the Upheaval in the Middle East
description: Overview | Where in the Arab world have protests sprung up? Why? What is happening? Who is involved? When, why and how did these movements begin, and how have the various governments responded to citizen protests? In this lesson, students find out basic information about the upheaval that has spread across the Arab world so that they can understand the background and the events and continue to follow the events as informed news consumers.

title: Distressed T-Shirts for Distressed Mets Fans
description: In the past half-century, Mets fans have plenty of reasons to cry, including Marv Throneberry, Tom Seavers departure and the teams epic collapse in 2007. To survive, many fans have learned to laugh about the teams foibles.

title: Will Britains Royal Wedding Pay the Bills?
description: LONDON  Royal weddings can generally be counted on to produce plenty of pomp and circumstance, not to mention  later on, of course  a possible future king or queen. In Britain, the approaching wedding of Prince William, second in line to the throne, to Kate Middleton, his longtime girlfriend, comes with a whole new set of expectations.

title: Geneva Auto Show: Nissan Esflow Concept
description: More than 140 product debuts are planned for the Geneva auto show, which opens to the press on Tuesday, March 1. Before the gates open, Wheels is highlighting the Geneva standouts that have already broken cover online. Be sure to check back next Tuesday for news and photos from the convention floor.

title: A Debate Over Leveraged Buyouts
description: Do management-led buyouts like the deals for J.Crew and Del Monte Foods shortchange shareholders? A lawyer involved in the lawsuit over the Del Monte deal discusses the issue. Plus, a breakdown of the HCA I.P.O. in this CNBC video.

title: Barroom Dirges of the Working Class
description: Imagine it as the lost Cheers episode by Tennessee Williams: Misanthropic Lilith wipes the smug smile off Sams face in a bleak fantasy that banishes his lovable regulars and turns his establishment into a watering hole for blue-collar depressives  a bar where nobody wants to know your name.

title: After 25 Years Sitting Down, Larry King Will Do Stand Up
description: Larry King the one-man interviewing machine is now Larry King the one-man showman.

title: TimesCast | February 22, 2011
description: Chaos grows in Libya as Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi holds on to power; in Bahrain, more than 100,000 antigovernment protesters take to the streets.

title: Songorrheic
description: The prolific production of (often not very good) songs.Writing for prefixmag, Dan Nishimoto spotlighted the term songorrheic:

title: An Oscar Peek Behind the Scenes
description: The Academy is really taking its new mandate to be more open and revealing than ever before seriously. In a new promo, Anne Hathaway, who is co-hosting the evening with James Franco, is shown practicing her Teleprompter lines, and today the group announced that even average movie fans will have a spot on the red carpet  via questions they submit on Twitter or Facebook, of course.

title: Pictures of the Day: Bahrain and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Bahrain, New Zealand, Yemen and Libya.

title: Chicago Voters Voice Concerns About Budget and Corruption
description: CHICAGO  As voters headed to the polls here on Tuesday to pick a new mayor, the citys budget crisis and corruption were among the issues on peoples minds.

title: Leaked: Original Songs of a Beatle Imitator
description: Whatever happened to feeling good? the singer asks. Was it a dream?

title: A Suicide, a Last Request, a Familys Questions
description: SUNNY ISLES BEACH, Fla.  The words came up on Alicia Duersons cellphone as blithely as text messages typically do, but this one was different: her former husband, the former Chicago Bears star Dave Duerson, asked her to donate his brain for research.

title: I.S.S. Weighs In Against J.Crew Deal
description: 5:15 p.m. | Updated with J. Crew comment

title: Racism Comes to Dinner and Everything Is Flamb
description: The ways in which politics can shape or shatter relationships and divide generations have informed a number of recent plays, among them Lisa Krons In the Wake and Amy Herzogs After the Revolution. But in A Perfect Future, by David Hay, those considerations are just wallpaper.

title: Pictures of the Day: Bahrain and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Bahrain, New Zealand, Yemen and Libya.

title: E.C.B. Criticizes Countries for Dragging Feet on Spending
description: The European Central Bank criticized political leaders Tuesday on the grounds of moving too timidly against countries whose excessive spending and borrowing had endangered the stability of the euro.

title: Buzz Tracker
description: Life After Lehman What is Erin Callan, the former chief financial officer of Lehman Brothers, been up to these days? Well, were not sure, but thanks to John Carney, we now know what her house in the Long Island community of East Hampton, N.Y., looks like. Net Net

title: Folk Art Museum to Show Self-Taught Black Artists in Venice
description: The American Folk Art Museum, which is facing serious financial problems, is nonetheless embarking an ambitious project: an exhibition of African-American self-taught and graffiti artists to take place in Venice during the Biennale there. The exhibition will open June 1 at the Fondaco dei Tedeschi, a building owned by the Benetton Group that may ultimately become a Rem Koolhaas-designed retail and exhibition space. Benetton is offering the building to the museum for free, as well as providing advertising and art materials and holding the opening-night party. The museums director, Maria Ann Conelli, said that the budget for the one-month exhibition was between $300,000 and $400,000 and that the museum was reaching out to foundations and corporations for financing. Since January, the museum has been unable to make payments on the roughly $30 million it owes against its building on West 53rd Street. Last summer, it entered into a forbearance agreement with the company that insured its debt, ACA Financial Guaranty. That agreement expires on June 30. According to the most recent available financial statements, in the fiscal year that ended June 30, 2010, the museum ran a deficit from unrestricted activities of $3.6 million. Ms. Conelli said that the museum had a balanced budget for this year.

title: Rangers and Capitals Closer to Playing Openers in Russia
description: Negotiations to send the Rangers and the Washington Capitals to Russia to begin the 2011-12 season are near a conclusion, with a decision expected within two weeks, officials of the Russian Kontinental Hockey League said Tuesday.

title: Workers Sickened at Apple Supplier in China
description: SUZHOU, China  Last week, when Apple released its annual review of labor conditions at its global suppliers, one startling revelation stood out: 137 workers at a factory here had been seriously injured by a toxic chemical used in making the signature slick glass screens of the iPhone.

title: How to Roast a Whole Fish
description: Melissa Clark demonstrates how to roast a flavorful whole fish in a home oven.

title: Cellphone Use Tied to Changes in Brain Activity
description: Researchers from the National Institutes of Health have found that less than an hour of cellphone use can speed up brain activity in the area closest to the phone antenna, raising new questions about the health effects of low levels of radiation emitted from cellphones.

title: The Other Ann Taylor
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#69", 592, 440, true, chameleonData);

title: Introducing Childrens Book Reviews Online
description: Beginning today, the Book Review will post an online-only review of a new picture book each week, supplementing  but not replacing  our regular coverage of picture books in the print edition.

title: Townie
description: Visits with Pop

title: Finding Low-Budget Amazon, and an Island Paradise
description: Heres an agenda that you cant pull off just anywhere:

title: The Lion Roars Loudest At the Box Office After 13 Years on Broadway
description: The long-running musical The Lion King is the first show to hit No. 1 in Broadways weekly box office grosses so late in the life of its run, earning $1,534,779 last week to edge out its closest competitors, Wicked and Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark. One likely factor was Disney Theatrical Productions decision to shift the shows usual Tuesday evening performance to Monday evening, Feb. 14, to capitalize on date nights for Valentines Day.

title: A Boy and a Building Help Shape Each Other
description: The Empire State Building doesnt loom as large in the public imagination as it did generations ago. In this century it has ceded its place to the twin towers, with all their tragic symbolism. But during the Empire States construction, in 1930-31, it represented rising hope and progress at a time when so much seemed crushed and fallen.

title: The Insider | Michael Hauptman
description: A former photo assistant of Richard Burbridge, Michael Hauptman has been taking pictures and living in New York City for the past five years. This week Hauptman, whose photographs have appeared in T and the Japanese cult magazine Untitled, releases his first book, Notes on, Something Like Life Should Be. Published by the Williamsburg, Brooklyn-based AndPress, its a personal portrait of Hauptmans relationships over the years. The Moment caught up with Hauptman to ask him about his peccadilloes and his favorite haunts in his adopted city.

title: Shining Light on Some Russian Rarities
description: I know you are absolutely sincere, and I think a great deal of your judgment, Tchaikovsky once wrote to his friend Sergei Taneyev. But I also fear it.

title: Oscar Picks, From the Voice of Trixie from Toy Story
description: For the second installment of our celebrity Oscar ballot and questionnaire, were allowing a little bias. Kristen Schaal, best known as the ardent fan Mel on the HBO series Flight of the Conchords and as a correspondent on The Daily Show With Jon Stewart, voices Trixie the triceratops in Toy Story 3, an Oscar nominee this year. She also stars as Louise in the new animated series Bobs Burgers on Fox, and is the author, with Rich Blomquist, a Daily Show writer who also happens to be her boyfriend, of The Sexy Book of Sex Sex. Ms. Schaal, who is not (we repeat, not an Academy member), is also a longtime pal of the Baggers. We spoke to her about her Oscar choices in an interview conducted in the most informal way possible, over Instant Message.

title: Historic African American Murals to Be Restored
description: A set of important murals depicting events in African-American history will be restored and sent on tour for the first time through a collaboration of Talladega College in Alabama, which owns the murals, and the High Museum of Art in Atlanta. In 1938 Talladega, one of the countrys oldest all-black colleges, commissioned Hale Aspacio Woodruff, an African-American artist who had studied with Diego Rivera, to create the murals for the lobby of its new library. Comprising six canvases, the murals depict events like the uprising on the slave ship La Amistad, scenes from the Underground Railroad and the founding of the college. At the High, the murals will be cleaned and restretched, Philip Verre, the museums chief operating officer, said in a phone interview. They will go on view in an exhibition opening in Atlanta on June 2, 2012, and will travel later to the Indianapolis Museum of Art. Woodruff, who taught art at New York University for more than 20 years, died in 1980. He had a retrospective at the Studio Museum in Harlem in 1979 and an exhibition at the High Museum, focused on his paintings in Atlanta, in 2004.

title: Bloomberg Criticizes Proposed Cut to Planned Parenthood
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg joined other elected officials, as well as the president of Planned Parenthood, Cecile Richards, on a conference call Tuesday to condemn provisions pending in Congress that would cut hundreds of millions of dollars out of Planned Parenthoods budget, calling them detrimental to poor women and politically motivated.

title: Eight Hours of Songs, and Uncounted Influences
description: Contemporary classical music has been fragmenting into ever greater eclecticism, as demonstrated by the repertory performed at the Music of Now marathon at Symphony Space on Monday. Works by 21 living composers born between 1925 and 1985 were showcased during the event, which began at 4 p.m. and lasted until midnight.

title: Italian Energy Company Suspends Gas Pipeline to Libya
description: ROME  Concerns rose about Italys natural gas supplies on Tuesday, after the countrys main energy company, ENI, said it had suspended supplies through its Greenstream pipeline, which runs from Libya to Sicily and supplies 10 percent of Italys natural gas.

title: Nuts
For 3-D Viewers, Robots in Disguise
description: Have you ever wanted to take home the glasses that theater ushers hand out to view 3-D movies? Yeah, me neither. Theyre not fashion-forward and dont have any practical use outside of a darkened movie theater. Theyre really something only a child could appreciate.

title: Q&A: Editing Video Preview Frames
description: Q.

title: Amazon Couples Movie Streaming With Shipping
description: Movie-watching has gotten so confusing. My wife says, Lets watch a movie, and I say, Sure, satellite, Netflix, Xbox Live, Sonys PlayStation Network or how bout the old-fashioned DVD, or the Blu-ray player?

title: Judge Rules Against Online TV Service
description: A federal judge ruled Tuesday that Ivi TV, an ambitious online video start-up, must stop rebroadcasting signals of local television stations on the Internet, dealing a major setback to the company.

title: Chaos Grows in Libya
description: Reporter Neil MacFarquhar reports from Cairo on the bloody protests in Libya.

title: Peaceful Protests in Bahrain
description: Michael Slackman reports from Manama, Bahrain, where on Tuesday, more than 100,000 protesters -- one fifth of the nation's citizens -- held a peaceful protest.

title: Reviewing Ai Fiori
Ai Fiori
description: HERE at long last is a winning new defense of fine dining: Ai Fiori, in the Setai Fifth Avenue hotel, just below Midtown. The chef and restaurateur Michael White opened the place late last year, with Chris Jaeckle in the kitchen and Ahmass Fakahany down at the bank. It is an emphatic rejoinder to the trend toward farmhouse tables, rustic food and shouting that has so dominated the dining scene in Manhattan at least since the start of the recession.

title: Photo Replay: Feb. 22
description: A view of the day in sports, including the cricket World Cup in India and basketball, above and below the rim.

title: The Site Makes the Man
description: Gentlemen, get out your plastic and get ready to spend till you bend: Mr. Porter, the male counterpoint to Net-a-Porter, the high-end fashion e-tailer, is finally live after more than a little hype over the past few months. Aimed at men who want to purchase clothes, accessories and other dapper goods online, Mr. Porter is a stand-alone destination, not an add-on to its sister site. We started from scratch, said Natalie Massenet, the founder of Net-a-Porter. We didnt want to simply include a mens tab on Net-a-Porter. Massenet hired the former British Esquire editor Jeremy Langmead and a team of experienced mens-wear editors to tailor the editorial content (style advice, guides and portfolios of non-models like the poet Nick Laird, above) for an audience that is generally held to be more interested in connoisseurship than in passing fads. Not surprisingly, the site will carry classic establishment brands like Ralph Lauren and Dunhill as well as harder-to-find heritage labels like Lock & Co. and Swayne Adeney Brigg. Its handsome black and white packaging will ship to 170 countries, proving that for stylish men, even e-commerce is all about the details.

title: Turning a Rearview Mirror on Kevin Roche
description: NEW HAVEN  Few figures better illustrate the divide between how architects see the world and how the general public does than Kevin Roche.

title: I.M.F. Reviews Praised Libya, Egypt and Other Nations
description: Less than two weeks ago, the International Monetary Funds executive board, its highest authority, assessed a North African countrys economy and commended its government for its ambitious reform agenda. The I.M.F. also welcomed its strong macroeconomic performance and the progress on enhancing the role of the private sector, and encouraged the authorities to continue on that promising path.

title: Vieux Carr
description: Images from the Wooster Groups production of Tennessee Williamss play.

title: Your Ideal Doughnut
description: This week, Pete Wells tours the expanding universe of doughnut shops in New York City, including the new Doughnut Plant location at the Chelsea Hotel, the Brindle Room in the East Village and two bakeries in Brooklyn, Dough in Bedford-Stuyvesant (whose chocolate variety with cacao nibs is pictured here) and the stalwart Peter Pan Donut & Pastry Shop in Greenpoint.

title: A Slip of the Tongue Could Lead to Terror
description: Anyone who regularly sees American premieres of new foreign-language plays knows how easy it is to get lost in translation. Even as solid a craftswoman as Yasmina Reza can sound off-key in a different language, which makes the accomplishment of the Play Company so impressive.

title: A New York City Doughnut Tour
description: A look at three of the citys doughnut greats: Dough, Peter Pan Donut & Pastry Shop and the Doughnut Plant.

title: A Flowering of the Doughnut Arts
description: IN The Donut Chef, a childrens book by Bob Staake, two bakers on one block compete by dreaming up increasingly outlandish pastries: Their donuts were such crazy things! Some were square and some were starry. Some looked just like calamari. Soon the townspeople cant remember when doughnuts were round and covered with glaze.

title: All Over London, Love Hurts
description: LONDON

title: Former Congressman to Join Morgan Stanley
description: Harold Ford Jr., the former congressman and Merrill Lynch banker, is joining Morgan Stanley.

title: Long After Giving His Money Away, a Donor Takes the Pledge
description: The Shy Philanthropist is most decidedly going public.

title: Wine in Two Words
description: IM not one to go overboard in describing the myriad aromas and flavors in a glass of wine. In fact, most of the gaudy descriptions found in tasting notes will not help a whit to understand the character of a bottle of wine or to anticipate the experience of drinking it.

title: Many Methods to Collaborative Madness
description: IT began, as actors stories often do, with a guru. Her name was Stella Burden, a k a the other Stella. Ms. Burden created a risky suite of training exercises called the Approach, attracted a fervent band of followers and abandoned them nine years into rehearsals for a high-concept production of A Streetcar Named Desire, to be performed without Stanley, Blanche, Stella or Mitch.

title: Summing Up Wine in Two Words
description: At some point in their professional lives, engineers, astrophysicists and reporters will be privileged to hear some workplace elder preach the virtues of simplicity. But wine writers? Seemingly, we are encouraged to make things as complicated as possible.

title: Dump Black History Month?
description: John McWhorter, left, of The New Republic and Glenn Loury of Brown University discuss the relevance of Black History Month.

title: The Rangpur, a Lime in Name Only
description: The Rangpur lime, said to have originated in the Indian subcontinent, has nothing to do with limes. Its bright orange, about the size of a clementine and a cross between a lemon and mandarin, making it easily peeled and segmented. The juice is extremely sour, like a lemons, but with a deeply floral, honeysuckle aroma. The leaves are scented like kaffir lime and can be used in cooking. A commercial crop, from California, will be available until spring.

title: Dining Calendar
description: Weekend Wine Expo

title: Off the Menu
description: Opening

title: Fresh Goat Milk, Dead Wood and Dubious Neighbors
description: WHEN Heidi Kooy bought her two Nigerian dwarf goats last year, she was flush with fantasies of fresh raw milk and homemade cheese, yogurt and ice cream.

title: In Indianapolis, the World Comes to Eat
description: Indianapolis

title: Glazed Beef-and-Scallion Rolls
description: Adapted from Takashi Inoue, Takashi restaurant, Manhattan

title: Stellina, a Sunny Cafe With Gelato and More
description: Emma Hearst, left, and Sarah Krathen, who own the Italian restaurant Sorella on the Lower East Side, are turning the adjacent storefront into a bright little cafe and retail sweet shop called Stellina. All whitewash and pale marble, its set to open on Sunday.

title: Chutney and Ketchup Creations
description: A native of Atlanta, Drake Page was familiar with his familys sweet Southern-style chutneys. He also lived in London, where chutney comes with the cheese in a pub. Now his DP Chutney Collective (a one-man band so far) produces a rotating line of more than a dozen chutneys and ketchups. The aromatic curried peach, top, and the musky sweet tomato with black mustard seeds, bottom, are the most popular. He said that about 75 percent of his ingredients come from local farms. Hes nailed the Raj look on the labels, inspired by the classic tins of Sun Brand Madras curry powder.

title: Shaved Steak, a Favorite With Many Names
description: YOU turn up the flame under a sizzling pan and sear steak for just a minute or two, barely cooking it before you sit down. The beef is remarkably tender. You are eating:

title: Spring for Fall | Marni Clutch
description: Dont say we didnt warn you. The bold patterns and prints that cropped up in the pre-fall collections have materialized into a full-blown trend for fall. From the pastoral landscape prints at Rodarte to the techno Navajo patterns at Proenza Schouler (with checks and florals and tartans from the likes of Thakoon, Suno, Gregory Parkinson and Preen in between), there is no blending in with the crowd. Of course, anyone who would like to try her hand with the trend right away can grab this tribal-inspired clutch ($735, center) from the Marni spring collection. Just the thing to carry you clear through to September.

title: Designers Art Collection Is a Passionate Triple Mix
description: Fashion designers are some of the most original collectors, as the art world was reminded when works owned by Yves Saint Laurent and Pierre Berg hit the block in Paris in a sale organized by Christies a couple of years ago. And the designer need not be a European couturier; Mannerism and Modernism: The Kasper Collection of Drawings and Photographs, at the Morgan Library & Museum, celebrates the unusual collection assembled by Herbert Kasper, the American designer whose garments were sold at Lord & Taylor and other department stores from the 1950s through the 80s.

title: Why Budget Cuts Dont Bring Prosperity
description: Washington

title: Bank Closings Tilt Toward Poor Areas
description: Until it closed its doors in December, the Ohio Savings Bank branch on North Moreland Boulevard was a neighborhood anchor in Cleveland, midway between the mansions of Shaker Heights and the ramshackle bungalows of the citys east side. Now it sits boarded up, a victim not only of Clevelands economic troubles but also of a broader trend of bank branch closings that is falling more heavily on low- and moderate-income neighborhoods across the country.

title: Private Hiring and Government Layoffs
description: In my column this week, I mention that government employment and private sector employment have both fallen during the last two years. Over just the last year, private employment has risen  though more slowly than the population has been growing  while government employment has continued falling. These numbers make clear that a surge of government hiring cant be the economys problem right now  because there has been no surge.

title: Under the Radar Amid Wide Labor Strife
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.

title: Pasta Handkerchiefs With Chunky Pesto
description: Mark Bittman makes easy fazzoletti  rectangular pasta  that is as traditional as anything else, and as delicious.

title: Hand-Pulled Chinese Noodles
description: Huacan Chen of the restaurant Hung Ry in NoLIta spins out endless skeins of la mian, smooth, springy hand-stretched noodles, using nothing but a countertop and his hands.

title: Zucchini Souffl
description: Mark Bittman makes a savory mock souffle, filled with shortcuts that make this dish far less intimidating.

title: Cardamom-Scented Oatmeal Pancakes
description: Mark Bittman uses oatmeal and whole wheat flour to update the classic pancake.

title: How to Stir-Fry Noodles
description: Grace Young, the author of several books on Chinese cooking, demonstrates how to stir-fry longevity noodles for Chinese New Year.

title: Governments Try to Remove Citizens From Libya
description: ROME  Governments around the world scrambled Tuesday to evacuate their citizens from an increasingly chaotic Libya, chartering military and civilian planes and, in the case of Britain and Turkey, mobilizing military ships.

title: Jeter Puts Thorny Situation to Rest
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Derek Jeter fielded the first question Tuesday morning with a smile, a laugh and a headshake, and he left the Yankees clubhouse more than three hours later wearing the same amused look.

title: N.C.A.A. Bars Calhoun for 3 Big East Games Next Season
description: The N.C.A.A. suspended UConn Coach Jim Calhoun for three Big East conference games next season for seriously violating its recruiting rules. One of his recruits, Nate Miles, received $6,000 in improper benefits from an agent who was also a Huskies booster.

title: Wall St. Often Slow to Disclose Brokers Sins
description: Driving his black Mercedes-Benz over the Fourth of July weekend, a Morgan Stanley Smith Barney broker, Martin Joel Erzinger, hit a cyclist, leaving the rider seriously injured on the side of the road.

title: Lehman Sale to Barclays Was Proper, Judge Rules
description: Barclays Capitals purchase of a large portion of Lehman Brothers, only days after the American investment bank filed for bankruptcy in September 2008, was acceptable, the judge overseeing Lehmans Chapter 11 case ruled on Tuesday evening.

title: Court Weighs the Power of Congress
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court heard arguments on Tuesday in a case that touched on the most pressing constitutional question of the day: just how much power does Congress have to regulate matters ordinarily left up to the states? The fate of President Obamas health care law will turn on how that question is answered.

title: Messages From Libya
description: Ed Ou and Scott Nelson, photographers on assignment for The New York Times, crossed into Libya from Egypt on Tuesday, with a Times reporter, Kareem Fahim. About five hours after they arrived, Kerri MacDonald interviewed Mr. Ou through an instant messaging service. His responses, somewhat condensed, are reproduced as they came in, line by line.

title: A New Volley From Boehner in Spending Dispute
description: WASHINGTON  As the strategic jockeying in a fight over federal spending kicked into high gear, the Republican House speaker, John A. Boehner, said on Tuesday that it was up to the White House and the Democrats who control the Senate to agree to at least some Republican-backed cuts to help reach a short-term deal and avoid a government shutdown early next month.

title: Kevin Roches Architecture
description: Images from Kevin Roche: Architecture as Environment, an exhibition at the Yale School of Architecture.

title: Dynegy Problems Suggest Broader Investor Unease
description: Shareholders of Dynegy have prompted the highly unusual resignations of its top management as well as an impending exit of its board.

title: A Campaign to Introduce Keds to a New Generation
description: DRIVERS who see a 32-foot shoebox rolling down the highway over the next few weeks should not be alarmed. The large white box is part of a new national marketing campaign for the sneaker company Keds.

title: Year After a Scandal, Woods Will Test His Progress at the Site of a Triumph
description: MARANA, Ariz.  The first clue was the view. Pounding golf balls off the pristine turf on the range at the Ritz-Carlton Golf Club at Dove Mountain Tuesday was one great ball striker after another: Robert Allenby of Australia, Rory McIlroy from Northern Ireland, the Colombian Camilo Villegas, the teenage sensation Ryo Ishikawa of Japan and, way on the far end, in a form-fitting golf shirt and wraparound shades, Tiger Woods.

title: High Stakes: The Battle for Wisconsin
description: To the Editor:

title: In Vancouver, a New Effort to Sell Olympic Condos
description: VANCOUVER, British Columbia  On a typical weekend Larry W. Campbell flies into this city from Ottawa, where he is a Liberal Party senator representing British Columbia, then spends the night at his 600-square-foot condominium at the Olympic Village.

title: Cantona Looks to Revive the Storied Cosmos Name
description: At first, even second, glance, Eric Cantona, 44, looks as if he could be minutes away from shedding his stylish street clothes and stepping back onto the soccer field without embarrassing himself. Cantona, the enigmatic Frenchman who starred for Manchester United in the 1990s, retired at age 30 and left it all behind for a budding film career, is back in the game for the first time in 14 years.

title: A U.S. Immigrant Program
description: To the Editor:

title: How to Make Oatmeal . . . Wrong
description: Theres a feeling of inevitability in writing about McDonalds latest offering, their bowl full of wholesome  also known as oatmeal. The leading fast-food multinational, with sales over $16.5 billion a year (just under the G.D.P. of Afghanistan), represents a great deal of what is wrong with American food today. From a marketing perspective, they can do almost nothing wrong; from a nutritional perspective, they can do almost nothing right, as the oatmeal fiasco demonstrates.

title: The Price of Colonoscopy
description: To the Editor:

title: An Afghan Bank: The View From Kabul
description: To the Editor:

title: Call on Anthony Trade Was His to Make, Walsh Says
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  The uncomfortable moments come and go, but Donnie Walsh disarms them with the same emotional distance and wry humor.

title: A Royal Boon to the Economy
description: At a time of economic gloom, businesses and Britains government are hoping that the wedding of Prince William to Kate Middleton on April 29 will give the economy a lift.

title: WikiLeaks Cables Detail Qaddafi Familys Exploits
description: WASHINGTON  After New Years Day 2009, Western media reported that Seif al-Islam el-Qaddafi, a son of the Libyan leader Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, had paid Mariah Carey $1 million to sing just four songs at a bash on the Caribbean island of St. Barts.

title: Knicks Go for Greatness With Anthony
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Carmelo Anthony wanted the Knicks, and the Knicks wanted Carmelo Anthony, but the trade that finally united them was so much more complicated than mutual attraction.

title: As Bostons Economy Grows, Demand for Rental Units Outpaces Condo Market
description: BOSTON  Investments in multifamily rentals have been one of the few hot spots in a sputtering economy, and nowhere is that more evident than in the Boston area, where a high-tech economy is enjoying comparatively strong job growth.

title: Nepals Stalled Revolution
description: Kathmandu

title: At St. Brigids, a Life Lost, Though Not Unknown
description: Many of the oldest saints are legends that lasted, frail flesh made into sturdy word. The Catholic church that stands at Avenue B and Seventh Street in Manhattan rose in 1848, the work of immigrants fleeing famine in Ireland. They reached into the past to call it St. Brigids, after a woman of the fifth century who was said to have been the first abbess of Ireland, a figure whose powers included running the church, healing the dying, and pardoning people as they trudged toward execution. She also was believed to have started a school of art whose students created the Book of Kildare, an illuminated manuscript of transcendent beauty.

title: As N.F.L. Talks Go On, Union Adjusts Its Schedule
description: The N.F.L. and its players union met for nearly eight hours Tuesday, the fifth of seven scheduled days of negotiations with a federal mediator.

title: Scorecard | Pringle of Scotland Wins!
description: Its been said that the sun never sets on the British Empire  or at least not on the Burberry Prorsum live stream. But Scorecard knows the jurys still out on whether all of Christopher Baileys nostalgic archive digging on the third day of London fashion week was his labels own. Before a more intimate audience that included the brand ambassador Tilda Swinton, meanwhile, the creative director of another heritage house that has 41 years on Burberrys 155, Clare Waight Keller, enlisted the help of Central Saint Martins students to rethink Pringle of Scotlands iconic knits. Thats one way to create from past and present a new warp and weft.

title: U.S. Condemns Libyan Tumult but Makes No Threats
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration on Tuesday reiterated its condemnation of bloody clashes between protesters and those loyal to the Libyan leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, but it stopped short of threatening concrete measures, like sanctions or a no-flight zone above Tripoli.

title: Anarchist Ties Seen in 08 Bombing of Texas Governors Mansion
description: HOUSTON  It has been two and a half years since an arsonist tossed a firebomb into the governors mansion in Austin and slipped into the night, but the Texas Rangers say they are finally closing in on the person responsible.

title: Midshipman, Then Pacifist: Rare Victory to Leave Navy
description: NEW LONDON, Conn.  The question that changed Michael Izbickis life appeared on a psychological exam he took not long after graduating in 2008 near the top of his class at the United States Naval Academy: If given the order, would he launch a missile carrying a nuclear warhead?

title: Finally, Turkey Looks East
description: London

title: Clashes Over Yemens Government Leave 2 Protesters Dead
description: SANA, Yemen  Two young men were shot dead by government supporters on Tuesday night during a protest in front of Sana University, medical workers said. They are the first deaths in clashes between pro- and antigovernment demonstrators in Sana in the nearly two weeks since students began calling for the ouster of President Ali Abdullah Saleh.

title: Dont Ask, Dont Tell Remains in Effect Months After Passage of Law to End It
description: In December, Congress voted to end the 17-year old dont ask, dont tell policy that prohibited military service by anyone who was openly gay or bisexual. President Obama applauded the vote, which he had long urged, and signed the bill on Dec. 22.

title: Emanuel Triumphs in Chicago Mayoral Race
description: CHICAGO  Rahm Emanuel, a former congressman who worked for two presidents, was elected mayor of Chicago on Tuesday, marking a new path for a city that has, for 22 years, been led by a singular, powerful force, Richard M. Daley.

title: Judge Orders City to Release Reports on Shots Fired by Police at Civilians Since 1997
description: A Manhattan judge has moved to shine more light on New York Police Department shootings, ruling that departmental reports generated whenever an officer fired at a civilian in the last 13 years be turned over to the New York Civil Liberties Union.

title: Bidders Want More Than a Slice of Mets
description: The Mets and their advisers are still weeks from narrowing the list of potential buyers of the 25 percent of the team they originally hoped to sell. But already, a variety of proposals are surfacing that suggest that investors want more than the Mets are offering.

title: Like a Thief in the Night
description: Just two years ago, President-elect Barack Obama staged the final leg of his pre-inaugural journey by boarding a train in Baltimore for a very public rally at the Amtrak station, followed by a leisurely rail journey to Washington, where the media and a large and exuberant crowd welcomed the future president and his wife. Preceding as it did Mr. Obamas new birth of freedom inauguration, billed as a tribute to his hero, Abraham Lincoln, there was little doubt that the carefully crafted trip from Baltimore was meant as a symbolic prelude. Lincoln, too, had traveled from Baltimore to Washington on the final sprint of his own so-called journey to greatness.

title: Union Leader Minces No Words When Labor Issues Are at Stake
description: MADISON, Wis.  As executive director of the main union of Wisconsin state employees, Marty Beil is at the vortex of the hurricane here  and that makes some union members gulp.

title: If Not Now, When?
description: Whats unfolding in the Arab world today is the mother of all wake-up calls. And what the voice on the other end of the line is telling us is clear as a bell:

title: Street Stops by the Police Hit a New High
description: New York City police officers last year stopped more people on the streets  to question, and sometimes frisk  than in any year since the Police Department began recording the number.

title: Black Swan Lakeside
description: CHICAGO

title: Wednesday: Celebrity Guest Solver Josh Radnor
description: WEDNESDAYS PUZZLE  If you happen to be on Facebook, you know that you can express your approval of just about anything with the click of the LIKE button.

title: The Boarders Put the Polish on Eccentric
description: Last seen in sober work attire, with his nose buried in a book for about six hours, the protean actor Scott Shepherd appears in far more garish guises in the Wooster Groups restless but surprisingly reverent production of Vieux Carr, a little-seen Tennessee Williams play in which the writer exhumes a macabre assortment of lonely ghosts from his youthful, desperate days in New Orleans in the late 1930s.

title: Lottery Numbers
Germany: Defense Chief Refuses to Quit
description: Defying calls by the opposition for his resignation, the German defense minister, Karl-Theodor zu Guttenberg, left, said Tuesday that he would not quit despite his admission that he had lost sight of the sources in one or two places in his doctoral dissertation. Opposition political parties and some academics had accused him of plagiarizing sections of his dissertation for his Ph.D., conferred by the University of Bayreuth in 2007. He said he would give up the title of doctor.

title: A Call to Deny Communion to Cuomo
description: ALBANY  A consultant to the Vaticans highest court is calling for Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo to be denied holy communion because he lives with his girlfriend without being married to her.

title: Corrections
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Edward Zigo, a Detective in the Son of Sam Case, Dies at 84
description: Edward Zigo, a seasoned New York detective who helped arrest David Berkowitz for the so-called Son of Sam serial murders, which terrorized New York in the mid-1970s, died Saturday at his home in Lynbrook, on Long Island. He was 84.

title: Spreading Anti-Union Agenda
description: Like a wind-whipped brush fire, the mass union protests that began in Madison, Wis., last week have spread to the capitals of Ohio and Indiana where Republican lawmakers also are trying to cripple the bargaining power of unions  and ultimately realize a cherished partisan dream of eradicating them. In each case, Republican talk of balancing budgets is cover for the real purpose of gutting the political force of middle-class state workers, who are steady supporters of Democrats and pose a threat to a growing conservative agenda.

title: France: Diplomats Take Sarkozy to Task
description: An anonymous group of former and current French diplomats said Tuesday that President Nicolas Sarkozys approach to foreign policy was plagued by amateurism, impulsiveness and a preoccupation with media attention. The criticisms, in an opinion article in the influential newspaper Le Monde, followed a string of diplomatic embarrassments for France, many involving Tunisia. Contrary to the announcements trumpeted for the past three years, Europe is powerless, Africa escapes us, the Mediterranean wont talk to us, China has kept us down and Washington is ignoring us! the authors said, adding that Mr. Sarkozy was quick to blame career diplomats for the disappointments of policies decided at the presidency of the Republic without taking into account the analyses of our embassies.

title: Libyas Butcher
description: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi of Libya vowed on Tuesday that he would fight on to the last drop of my blood and die a martyr. We have no doubt that what he really meant is that he will butcher and martyr his own people in his desperation to hold on to power. He must be condemned and punished by the international community.

title: Pledge? What Pledge?
description: Before last years elections, when New Yorks legislators were terrified of losing their jobs, a majority signed a pledge to pass a set of much-needed reforms, starting with a plan to end the gerrymandering of political districts. Now all 32 Republicans in the State Senate and a few Democrats in the Assembly have decided that they have more important things to do. That sort of cynical postelection amnesia is an insult to voters.

title: The Fire That Changed Everything
description: In The Timess grim, vivid account on March 26, 1911  the day after the Triangle shirtwaist factory fire  these words appear: The victims who are now lying at the Morgue waiting for some one to identify them by a tooth or the remains of a burned shoe were mostly girls from 16 to 23 years of age. There were 146 victims in all, 129 of them women.

title: Role in Anthony Deal? Thomas Isnt Saying
description: MIAMI  Isiah Thomas leaned against the scorers table in an empty arena Tuesday and exhorted his players as they ran wind sprints. Wearing khaki shorts and a dark polo shirt bearing the logo of the Florida International University Panthers, he gathered his players at midcourt and spoke briefly about their most pressing issue  their next game at Western Kentucky.

title: Cuomo Adviser Takes Pay From Health Industry
description: When Andrew M. Cuomo married Kerry Kennedy in 1990, Jeffrey A. Sachs served as an usher. When Mr. Cuomos daughter Michaela was born, he asked Mr. Sachs to be her godfather. When his marriage fell apart years later, Mr. Cuomo stayed in Mr. Sachss triplex near the United Nations.

title: Pakistan Case Tests Laws on Diplomatic Immunity
description: WASHINGTON  An American C.I.A. contractor is accused of killing two men at a crowded intersection in Pakistan. Can Pakistani officials lawfully prosecute him for murder?

title: Haitis Scars, and Its Soul, Find Healing on Walls
description: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti  Colorful and sad, beautiful but cracked, the three remaining murals of the Episcopal Trinity Cathedral received the soft afternoon sun after last years earthquake only because the rest of the church had collapsed.

title: Towns Slip From Qaddafis Control
description: A growing number of towns in Libyas east have in effect declared their independence from Col. Muammar el-Qaddafis rule and set up informal opposition governments.

title: A Third Judge Validates Health Care Overhaul Law
description: A third federal judge upheld the constitutionality of the Obama health care law on Tuesday, reinforcing the divide in the lower courts as the case moves toward its first hearings on the appellate level.

title: Unrest Throughout Northern Africa and the Middle East
description: LIBYA A defiant Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi vowed to fight until the last drop of my blood as a bloody crackdown enabled him to tighten his grip on the capital, Tripoli. But in the east, the opposition appears to have consolidated its hold over a string of cities across nearly half of Libyas coast.

title: A Climate Skeptic With a Bully Pulpit in Virginia Finds an Ear in Congress
description: RICHMOND, Va.  For nearly a year, Kenneth T. Cuccinelli II, Virginias crusading Republican attorney general, has waged a one-man war on the theory of man-made global warming.

title: Nuggets Were Prepared for Trade They Didnt Want to Make
description: DENVER  Josh Kroenke and Carmelo Anthony faced each other in a college game nearly eight years ago. Anthony was the splendid freshman for Syracuse, the eventual national-title winner. Kroenke played for Missouri as its captain and an all-academic performer. Anthony scored 16 points and grabbed the win.

title: Queen of the Mommy Bloggers
description: O.K., then, I say, almost begging at this point, almost to the point of tears, is there anyone I can talk to who might see what Ive been through and understand? And heres where I say: Do you know what Twitter is? Because I have over a million followers on Twitter. If I say something about my terrible experience on Twitter, do you think someone will help me? And she says in the most condescending tone and hiss ever uttered: Yes, I know what Twitter is. And no, that will not matter.  AUG. 28, 2009, Dooce.com

title: Phys Ed: Should Children Run Marathons?
description: With temperatures warming and the snows of 2011 finally dissolving into oatmeal slush, many people are feeling an insistent urge to get outside and run, perhaps even to start training for a spring marathon or other distance race. But for some of us, particularly those with young families, this laudatory goal can pose a problem. Should we take our kids with us? Can and should children, at any age, be runners?

title: In Portugal With the Emergency Brake On
description: Midfielder Yael Averbuch, a Montclair, N.J., native by way of the University of North Carolina, will be contributing to the Goal blog in the runup to the third season of Womens Professional Soccer and as the United States womens national team prepares to play in the Algarve Cup and the FIFA Womens World Cup in Germany later this year.

title: Word of the Day | trigger
description: trigger \tri-gr\ noun/verb

title: Queens of the Mom-Blog Kingdom
description: I have an article in the New York Times Magazine this weekend about moms who blog  and who make a lot of money doing it.

title: James McLure Dies at 59; Wrote Garrulous Plays
description: James McLure, a playwright whose Southern roots were reflected in the loquacious, mostly comic (but not necessarily Southern) characters he created in plays like Lone Star, Pvt. Wars and Wild Oats, died Thursday in Marina del Rey, Calif. He was 59.

title: Mourning and Marching in Bahrain
description: As Shiites mourned those who had been killed in earlier protests, more than 100,000 marchers to Pearl Square called for political harmony.

title: News Quiz | February 23, 2011
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: Rescuers Press Search for New Zealand Earthquake Survivors
description: CHRISTCHURCH, New Zealand  Hopes of finding more survivors of the devastating earthquake here waned Thursday as the search-and-rescue operation entered its third day, with many foreigners among those missing.

title: Protests Spread to Indiana and Ohio
description: After weeks of upheaval in Wisconsin, people in Indiana and Ohio marched on Capitol buildings to express grievances with their governments.

title: Test Yourself | Math, Feb. 23, 2011
description: Test your math skills with todays question, created by Kari Kokka at Math for America from the article On the Worlds Largest Cruise Ship, the Sea Is an Afterthought.

title: Protests in Wisconsin and Ohio
description: Note: To help students understand this complex topic, we have drawn questions from three articles, one about the Ohio protests and two about the protests in Wisconsin. We have linked each question to the resource in which the answer can be found.

title: Qaddafi Massing Forces in Tripoli as Rebellion Spreads
description: BAIDA, Libya  As rebellion crept closer to the capital and defections of military officers multiplied, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi called on thousands of mercenaries and irregular security forces on Wednesday to defend his bastion in Tripoli, in what residents said was a desperate and dangerous turn in the week-old uprising.

title: Have You Ever Lost (or Found) Something Valuable?
description: A City Room blog post tells the story of a former New York Times employee who recently received his lost wallet, found some 40 years later. Inside, he found photos and documents from his past. What have you ever lost of real sentimental or monetary value? Did you get it back? Have you ever found something that seemed valuable and tried to return it? What happened?
