description: Todays word, in association with the terrific Oxford English Dictionary, is

title: Music and Motion, at Times Overwhelming
description: From Jennifer Frasers perspective, New York is a city of classical and modern dance, bright lights, fast cars and street musicians; a carnival of movement and motion, a haven for self-expression.

title: Commerzbank Says 2010 Results Put It on Path to Repay Bailout
description: Commerzbank on Wednesday reported a 1.4 billion euro operating profit for last year, beating expectations and putting it on a path to repay a significant part of the 18.2 billion euro government bailout it received in the crisis.

title: Economics and Democracy in Egypt
description: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago.

title: A Secret Berlin Cabaret for the 21st Century
description: A compact man in a buttoned-up, collared shirt was standing outside a faded but grand turn-of-the-century building in a neighborhood in West Berlin, looking rather confused. Suddenly, he was buzzed in and told to take an ancient elevator to the fourth floor. A mysterious blonde woman with a Mona Lisa smile and a glass of Champagne in her hand greeted him at the door of an expansive Berlin-style apartment. Welcome to Salon K, she said as she led him into a large room with wood parquet floors and impossibly high ceilings. It was bare except for pillows and futon-style seating around the edges and an arrangement of candles that glowed in the center.

title: The Early Word: Mr. Mayor
description: From Todays Times:

title: Remembering Ollie Matson, Hall of Fame Running Back
description: Andy Barall writes about pro football history for The Fifth Down. Ollie Matson died on Saturday at age 80.

title: An Amelia Island Pilgrimage for 1965 Mercedes Popemobile
description: The Amelia Island vintage car show and auction weekend, held annually on the northern Florida island, will receive an unlikely dignitary when the pomp begins on March 11.

title: Under the Gowanus Canal, Flushing Out the Stench
You Should Open a Store!
description: That is what everyone is telling Joanne Tarzian. And for good reason. In 1997, she joined her sister who was running her fathers neighborhood kitchenware store in New York. Over the next 11 years, she bought out her sister and transformed the store into a modern mecca for both gourmet and aspiring cooks. She ultimately sold the store and moved to Chicago to pursue a new opportunity working for a housewares manufacturer. She was ready to move on from the grueling hours and responsibilities that come with owning a store.

title: Trial Shows Cystic Fibrosis Drug Helped Ease Breathing
description: The gene responsible for cystic fibrosis was discovered in 1989. Now, 22 years later, a drug that tries to compensate for the genetic defect might be nearing the market.

title: Italy Says Death Toll in Libya Is Likely Over 1,000
description: ROME  Italys foreign minister, Franco Frattini, said Wednesday that estimates of more than 1,000 Libyan civilians killed in clashes with security forces and government supporters appear to be true.

title: Hybrids vs. Nonhybrids: The 5-Year Equation
description: A car buyer who lays out an extra $6,200 extra to buy the hybrid version of the Lexus RX will get the money back in gas savings within five years, according to Consumer Reports magazine, but only if gasoline averages $8.77 a gallon. Otherwise, the nonhybrid RX 350 is a better buy than the Hybrid 450h, the magazine says. The hybrid gets 26 miles per gallon, and the nonhybrid, 21, in the magazines calculation.

title: Morning Buzz | Cuomo Adviser Is Also a Paid Consultant
description: Sunny, with temperatures heading up to 43 degrees Wednesday.

title: Morning Take-Out
description: MERGERS & ACQUISITIONS

title: Rio Tinto Gets $340 Million Bid for Talc Unit
description: Rio Tinto said on Wednesday that Imerys had made a binding $340 million offer to buy its talc division.

title: K.K.R. Posts Fourth-Quarter Earnings of $697 Million
description: 6:29 p.m. | Updated

title: Now Screening | Gucci
description: The Fall 2011 collection from Gucci at Milan Fashion Week.

title: Chicago, City in Transition, Picks a Big Personality
description: CHICAGO  In the eyes of some, Rahm Emanuels victory in this citys mayoral race marks the end to a minor political skirmish but the start of far larger chaos.

title: Joseph H. Flom, Pioneering Lawyer in Mergers and Acquisitions, Dies at 87
description: Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & FlomJoseph H. Flom

title: Duncan Energy Receives $2.4 Billion Offer
description: Enterprise Products Partners announced on Wednesday that it had offered $2.4 billion for Duncan Energy Partners in an all-unit deal.

title: Decoding the Wisconsin Polls
description: Some people have expressed confusion about the various polls that are now out over the dispute in Wisconsin, but I dont think theyre all that difficult to unravel.

title: U.S. Accuses Four Bankers Connected to Credit Suisse of Helping Americans Evade Taxes
description: Credit Suisse, the big Swiss bank, on Wednesday came under heightened scrutiny of authorities in the United States and Germany over its sale of private banking services that enable tax evasion.

title: Feb. 23: Updates on the Uprising in Libya
description: On Wednesday, The Lede is following the uprising in Libya and protest movements in Bahrain, Egypt, Yemen, Morocco and Iran. Updates below mix alerts on breaking news with reports from bloggers and journalists on the ground. A stream of Twitter messages from the region is in this blogs right column.

title: Oil Prices Rise and Wall Street Stocks Drift Lower
description: Turmoil in the Middle East and North Africa continued to send stocks lower and oil prices up on Wednesday as crude operations were disrupted in Libya.

title: Bahrain King in Saudi Arabia to Discuss Unrest
description: MANAMA, Bahrain  A day after one of the largest pro-democracy demonstrations this tiny Persian Gulf nation had ever seen, its king was in Saudi Arabia, a close ally and neighbor, to discuss the unrest engulfing the region.

title: Red Bulls Live, Online
description: The Red Bulls of M.L.S. will provide a live stream of Wednesdays matches against Chicago in Florida on their official Web site.

title: Business Group Tied to U.S. Wades Into Nicaraguas Politics
description: WASHINGTON  As president of the American Chamber of Commerce of Nicaragua, Rger Arteaga Cano routinely dealt with business issues and trade practices affecting members like ExxonMobil or Citigroup. But he also led an unusual campaign: organizing secret meetings with opposition party leaders in an effort to oust President Daniel Ortega in an election this year.

title: PEN World Voices Festival Announces Lineup
description: A lecture by the Nigerian author and Nobel Prize winner Wole Soyinka, readings by Wallace Shawn and Malcolm Gladwell, a debate on the prison industry and an evening on the topic of sex led by Edmund White are among the offerings at this years PEN World Voices Festival of International Literature, which will take place from April 25 to May 1 in New York. Other events in the festival, which is put on by the PEN American Center, include a discussion of cultural and political conditions in China featuring the New Yorker contributor Jianying Zha; a night with the storytelling group the Moth, on the theme of Whats Gone Wrong; a celebration of poetry, curated by Laurie Anderson and featuring Antony and the Johnsons; and a game of telephone in which a Tibetan lama will pass along sutras down a list of 200 festival attendees, ending with Salman Rushdie, who will Tweet the result. The festival, which is being organized by the former Hungarian Cultural Center director Laszlo Jakab Orsos, will be based out of the Standard Hotel, with events taking place at the New York Public Library, Cooper Union, the 92nd Street Y and elsewhere. Mr. Whites sex event, which, according to a news release, will feature celebrated members of the fashion and music worlds, will take place in the Standards rooftop bar, Le Bain (French for the bath).

title: By a Point, Caltech Ends 26-Year Conference Skid
description: The California Institute of Technology mens basketball team won a conference game Tuesday night for the first time since 1985, breaking a losing streak believed to have stretched to 310 games.

title: The Bagger Rounds Up a Costume Designer
description: Its time for the fun party game that is Ask the Bagger. In todays installment, we speak with an Oscar-nominated costume designer at the request of a commenter, perdita.

title: Some Joint | QuaDror
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#948", 592, 440, true, chameleonData);

title: A Knick Is Traded, and Italians Are Desolate
description: A tiny round table for two, tucked into a corner of the Via Della Pace restaurant on East Seventh Street, was missing its usual occupant. But Danilo Gallinari could not stop in for a last bite of Gorgonzola gnocchi or veal scaloppine on Tuesday because he was already on his way out of town, sent packing after two and a half seasons by the Knicks in a trade for the heralded Carmelo Anthony.

title: Coming of Age With a Quick Wit and a Sharp Eye
description: Although The Adults is quite a good novel, it is easily underestimated. On the surface this is the coming-of-age story of a disaffected girl in wealthy, leafy Connecticut, and please, please try not to start yawning. The book is better than its title. Its sweep is larger than might be expected, its fine-tuning more precise. And the girl, Emily Vidal, is a lot more interesting than the sum of her spoiled suburban parts.

title: Wednesday Reading: More Legal Wrangling Over Health Care Law
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: Emanuel Celebrates Decisive Mayoral Victory
description: CHICAGO  Rahm Emanuel, the mayor-elect of Chicago, stood at a train station on the South Side on Wednesday morning, offering hugs and high-fives to residents a day after his decisive victory in a city where a generation of voters has only ever known a different mayor, Richard M. Daley.

title: When a Vacation Package Can Save You Money (and When It Cant)
description: ONLINE travel agencies have long promoted vacation packages as a means to big savings: Book flight + hotel, save up to $450 is the lure on Expedia.coms homepage, while Orbitz.com promises a savings of up to $465. Travelocity.com raises the bid with its claim that users can save as much as $525 on some packages.

title: Signs of a Turnaround for the Banking Industry
description: After three dismal years, the American banking industry regained its footing in 2010, according to a regulatory assessment released on Wednesday.

title: Geneva Auto Show: Renault Captur Concept
description: More than 140 product debuts are planned for the Geneva auto show, which opens to the press on Tuesday, March 1. Before the gates open, Wheels is highlighting the Geneva standouts that have already broken cover online. Be sure to check back next Tuesday for news and photos from the convention floor.

title: A Park Rediscovers Its Soundscape
description: As I write on the 15th floor of a San Francisco office tower, not one but two jackhammers are pulsating somewhere outside, in a syncopated tattoo that echoes off nearby buildings. That quintessential urban noise, along with car alarms and sirens, are a reminder of how necessary it is for parks to provide respite not just from urban landscapes but urban soundscapes as well.

title: What Were Reading
description: An aggregation of links by the reporters and editors of Diners Journal.

title: Standoffs, Protests and a Prank Call
description: MADISON, Wis.  An increasingly heated national debate about the rights of union workers was stuck in a standoff Wednesday as Democratic lawmakers here and in Indiana stayed away from their Capitols to frustrate Republican efforts to vote on legislation that would undercut collective bargaining and the ability to organize.

title: Hybrids vs. Nonhybrids: The 5-Year Equation
description: From our colleagues at Green:

title: Why the Lehman Case Was Special
description: The hopes of distressed debt investors everywhere were dashed as Judge James M. Peck rejected most  indeed almost all  of the claims by the Lehman Brothers estate, which contended that Barclays had received an unwarranted windfall when it bought Lehmans broker-dealer assets at the height of the financial crisis.

title: Q&A: Taking Digital Notes
description: Q.

title: Shilpa Ray | Good Time Girl
description: Photograph by Cameron Krone. Fashion editor: Vanessa Traina. Fashion assistant: Claudia Codron. Hair by Enrico Mariotti at See Management. Makeup by Beau M. Nelson at The Wall Group/Beaut Cosmetics.Tao Comme des Garons skirt, $960. Call (212) 604-9200. Acne jeans, $230. Go to acnestudios.com. The Elder Statesman hat, $400. Go to barneys.com. Chanel necklace, $2,450. Call (800) 550-0005. Manolo Blahnik shoes, $575. Call (212) 582-3007.

title: Lost Property, Found Humanity
description: The story of Rudolph R. Restas reunion with his lost wallet after 40 years has bounced happily around the world. The idea that a lost object of extraordinary value might be returned by some good-hearted soul resonated with many people. Among them was our colleague Tony Cenicola, who shot the video and took the pictures of Mr. Resta.

title: Ex-Knicks Are Eager to Strut Their Stuff
description: DENVER  There is always another side to a trade. For the four former Knicks  Raymond Felton, Danilo Gallinari, Wilson Chandler and Timofey Mozgov  it came in the shadows of the elation and expectations of the Knicks acquisition of Carmelo Anthony, and also at their expense.

title: Banh Mi, the Outtakes
description: In this weeks banh mi article, I talk about several of the variations I tried in my quest for the quickest sandwich I could make at home. Before settling on ground pork, I took a little detour out of the porcine kingdom to see what would happen. Here are my notes:

title: United States and Other Nations Step Up Libyan Evacuations
description: Whether by plane or bus, ferry or foot, tens of thousands of foreign citizens  including hundreds of Americans  were scrambling to find a way out of Libya on Wednesday as forces loyal to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi fought to maintain control of a shrinking portion of the oil-rich country.

title: Oscar Picks, Courtesy of Univisions El Gordo
description: Viewers of Univision, the Spanish-language network, know Ral de Molina, a veteran journalist, as El Gordo. With Lili Estefan, the Cuban-born Mr. de Molina is a host of El Gordo y la Flaca, a wildly popular daily talk show on Univision that has made him a well-known personality in the Spanish-speaking world. Mr. de Molina is also a contributor to The Huffington Post, where he writes about food and health, and an inveterate world traveler (even though he was almost mauled by lions while on safari last year). He filled out our Oscar ballot, and when the Bagger spoke with him from his home in Miami, he wasted no time in sharing his picks.

title: Geneva Auto Show: Porsche Panamera S Hybrid
description: More than 140 product debuts are planned for the Geneva auto show, which opens to the press on Tuesday, March 1. Before the gates open, Wheels is highlighting the Geneva standouts that have already broken cover online. Be sure to check back next Tuesday for news and photos from the convention floor.

title: Did You Say Helmut Newton?
description: Before I pop over to Versace to have coffee with Donatella, let me dash off a few words about the Gucci show. It will only take a few moments, so comprehensibly 70s were Frida Gianninis fur-covered shoulders, tie-at-the-neck blouses and chic gaucho trousers in flannel or suede with boots or platforms. The palette was all violet, wine, rust, emerald green, teal and a bit of cherry. Ms. Giannini also offered those lady-ish full-sleeved dresses with tiny belts that figure so prominently in memories and archives of the 70s, along with fedoras and feathers. Her press notes referred to Helmut Newton and Bob Richardsons fashion photographs of Anjelica Huston, his girlfriend at the time, who practically lives on every designers mood board. The silhouette is certainly one for the ages  Marc Jacobs made a pass for spring  but it hardly lifts the old skirts.

title: Basketball Economics
description: Kevin Clark has a fascinating piece in todays Wall Street Journal comparing pro basketball in this country with pro soccer in England:

title: Dodd-Frank Requires Tsunami of Rules
description: The Deal Professor, Steven M. Davidoff, speaks to Margaret E. Tahyar, a partner at Davis Polk & Wardwell, about what regulatory agencies must do to put the Dodd-Frank Act, which overhauls financial regulation, into effect. How can regulators decide which organizations are actually too big to fail?

title: Further Reading on Alternatives to McDonalds Oatmeal
description: So what on earth is there to do with oatmeal if you dont buy it from McDonalds? Read up:

title: New Earnest Cast Members Named for Broadway
description: To lose one parent, Lady Bracknell declares in The Importance of Being Earnest, may be regarded as a misfortune and to lose both looks like carelessness. But the loss of three performers from Roundabout Theater Companys Broadway revival of that Oscar Wilde comedy is an inevitability. Though it was recently announced that Earnest would extend its run at the American Airlines Theater through July 3, the cast members Dana Ivey (who plays Miss Prism), Paxton Whitehead (Rev. Canon Chasuble) and Sara Topham (Gwendolen Fairfax) are set to depart after the March 20 performance.

title: City to Replace School Lighting Tainted by PCBs
description: The Bloomberg administration announced on Wednesday that the city would replace light fixtures containing the toxic chemicals known as PCBs in nearly 800 city school buildings over the next 10 years, after months of pressure from federal officials and worried parents.

title: A Normal Family
description: What is a family? Statistically, it is no longer a mother, a father and their biological children living together under one roof (and certainly not with Dad going off to work and Mom staying home). Although perception and acceptance often lag behind reality, there is evidence that a new definition of family  while far from universally accepted  is emerging.

title: Best Movie Query? You Win
description: THIS is the first of what will be a monthly question-and-answer column that will run on Sundays in The New York Times and also, in longer form, at nytimes.com/movies. The focus of this round of questions is the Oscars, which are being given out Sunday. For future columns, we would like to hear from you about whatever movie-related subject piques your curiosity: individual films, industry trends, historical trivia. Write to us at askthefilmcritics@nytimes.com.

title: Billboard Opposing Abortion Stirs Debate
description: A billboard that an anti-abortion group erected last Friday in SoHo, a half-mile from a Planned Parenthood center, claiming that the most dangerous place for an African-American is in the womb, quickly stirred discussion and controversy.

title: Searching for Survivors After New Zealand Quake
description: Rescuers at a collapsed building in central Christchurch on Wednesday. The city remained silent and dark a day after an earthquake killed scores of people.

title: Deep Into the Big Pit and Beyond
description: Takeshi Inomata, a professor of anthropology at the University of Arizona, writes from Guatemala, where he and Daniela Triadan are excavating the Maya site of Ceibal, Guatemala.

title: Nets to Acquire Deron Williams From Jazz
description: A superstar arms race has broken out on both sides of the Hudson River.

title: Normal Heart Revival a Late Addition to Broadway (and Tony) Calendar
description: Every spring brings one or two late entries to the Broadway season, opening just under the wire to qualify for the Tony Awards. This year it will be The Normal Heart, Larry Kramers landmark play about love, AIDS and New York in the 1980s, which will begin preview performances at the Golden Theater on April 19 and open on April 27, a spokesman for the production said on Wednesday. (To qualify for this years Tonys, shows must open by April 28.)

title: The Ups and Downs of A.D.H.D.
description: Is there an upside to A.D.H.D.? Are certain careers more suited to the person with attention deficits than others? How does someone with A.D.H.D. deal with the daily ups and downs of the disorder? These are among the questions recently posed by readers of the Consults blog. Here, Dr. Russell Barkley, clinical professor of psychiatry at the Medical University of South Carolina, responds.

title: Republican Governors Split on Collective Bargaining
description: Scott Walker, the Republican governor of Wisconsin, shows no signs of backing down as public workers continue to protest his efforts to restrict collective-bargaining rights in the state.

title: Net Effect
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#494", 592, 490, false, chameleonData);

title: Apple Announces an iPad-Related Event
description: Apple on Wednesday sent the news media an official invitation to an event that is expected to showcase the next iPad.

title: London Fashion Week | Its a Wrap!
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#673", 592, 490, true, chameleonData);

title: Democrats Target Republican House Members for Budget-Cut Vote
description: 3:08 p.m. | Updated Democrats are targeting 50 Republican House members with a new round of automated phone calls, Web videos and mass e-mails into their districts that seek to link the lawmakers to unpopular cuts included in their partys budget proposals, Democratic officials told The Caucus.

title: Collective Bargaining Rights and Higher Education
description: While much of the focus of the protests in Wisconsin and other states that are trying to outlaw collective bargaining has focused on how it will affect public schools, the online publication Inside Higher Ed is reporting that college faculty members are also at risk of losing their bargaining rights.

title: Top S.E.C. Lawyer Sued by Madoff Trustee
description: The top lawyer at the Securities and Exchange Commission has been sued by the trustee seeking to recover money for victims of Bernard L. Madoffs Ponzi scheme.

title: In Shift, U.S. Says Marriage Act Blocks Gay Rights
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama, in a striking legal and political shift, has determined that the Defense of Marriage Act  the 1996 law that bars federal recognition of same-sex marriages  is unconstitutional, and has directed the Justice Department to stop defending the law in court, the administration said Wednesday.

title: Budget Wars or Culture Wars?
description: Gail Collins: David, you wrote a very evenhanded column about the situation in Wisconsin that I admired. Unfortunately, when it comes to budgetary issues I have wandered off to the land of the insanely angry.

title: Glenn Beck Does The Times Deficit Puzzle
description: Glenn Beck spent several minutes filling out our deficit puzzle on the air last week. The segment starts around 22:00.

title: Madison Has Been a National Stage Before
description: The conflict in Madison, Wis., pitting crowds of unionized state employees (and their supporters) against allies of Gov. Scott Walker (and Tea Party members), took much of America, and many of our political leaders, by surprise. But while Madison may deserve its reputation as a liberal college town, a backdrop for Lorrie Moores fiction and home to The Progressive magazine  not to mention the annual Great Midwest Marijuana Harvest Festival  the city also has a long history of ideological conflict.

title: Are Irrational Designs Ideas Strong Enough to Bootstrap?
description: Last week, we published a case study that discussed the challenges facing Irrational Design, a technology start-up that is determined to bootstrap. Its co-founders, Jared Cosulich and Adam Abrons, say they believe they will be freer to take risks and experiment without pressure from investors seeking a quick return. But operating on a shoestring has meant releasing imperfect products  a dating Web site, an application that serves as an online suggestion box for businesses, and a goal-sharing message board.

title: Building Buzz for a Small, Australian Film
description: In doing the Q&A thing with readers, its pretty hard to avoid the Yes, Virginia, there is a style of reply (Yes, Virginia, there is a Weinstein), but rest assured, the Bagger is trying. A lot of folks have written us asking about the Academy members viewing habits.

title: U.S. U-17 Team Qualifies for World Cup
description: 8:46 a.m. | Updated The United States will play host Jamaica, while Canada faces Panama, in the regional U-17 semifinals on Friday. Games are available as live streams at Concacaf.com (registration required).

title: When M.&A. Hurts
description: In the heat of the deal, it is hard to remember that mergers and acquisitions are a risky business. This is particularly true when management is seeking a defensive deal, one born out of desperation to save the company or otherwise fight off an activist investor. It is not a deal born to further the companys expansion but rather in response to its own distress.

title: Homes for $440,000
description: A three-bedroom house in Austin, Tex., a three-bedroom house in Sarasota, Fla., and a two-bedroom condo in a Chicago townhouse.

title: An Unexpected Compliment From Albanys Corner Office
description: ALBANY  School superintendents are used to having relatively thankless jobs. So after completing successful negotiations for a wage freeze with labor officials in his school district in central New York, Christopher R. Brown was content with a celebratory lunch with his father at a local hamburger establishment last Friday.

title: Wild and Woolly | The Pringle Archive Project
description: Though London Fashion Weeks endearingly creative reputation rests on its relentless embrace of the new, Pringle of Scotlands collaboration with the M.F.A. students at Central St. Martins, which was unveiled earlier this week, looks to the past. The 196-year-old cashmere purveyor  its often credited with inventing the twin set  threw open its archives in Hawick, Scotland, last summer to the design schools students, who first catalogued them, then mined them for inspiration. The result is a woolly mashup that mixes 1950s argyles with a postmodern sensibility  in other words, perfect for falls emerging grunge-meets-prim trend.

title: Unintended Air-Bag Deployments Lead to Recall of 144,000 Ford F-150s
description: Ford is recalling about 144,000 F-150 pickups from the 2005-6 model years because the drivers side air bag might deploy without the vehicle being in a crash, a Ford spokesman said Wednesday. The number represents a small fraction of the total F-150s that the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration was initially concerned about.

title: Ticket Resellers Prepare for Anthonys Debut
description: Carmelo Anthonys potential debut Wednesday night at Madison Square Garden against the Milwaukee Bucks has made some Knicks fans very happy, but left others looking in their wallets for more money.

title: Finlit
description: Portmanteau for Financial Literacy.

title: Where and How to Guard Your Laptop
description: My laptop was recently stolen by a cab driver who was dropping me off at an airport. But airports arent the only place where consumers should make sure to carefully guard their portable computers.

title: Feeding the Nurses
description: I joke that nurses will do anything for food. Good food, bad food, healthy food, junk food  were not particular. Patients must understand that too, because they constantly bring us food.

title: Alberta Ferretti: The Beat Goes On
description: The Milan fall shows are just revving up and Alberta Ferretti also likes teal. How will we feel by Friday if this becomes a trend? Ms. Ferrettis collection this evening had a slight Mod haze (short lengths, tunic dresses, stand-away collars) with baroque touches (best that I could make out) and over-the-knee velvet boots. All very pretty, but while you dont expect Ms. Ferretti to light the fashion path, you do hope for more signs of research into new materials that would help push her brand forward.

title: An Apartment in Central Berlin
description: A two-bedroom apartment in a 1900s Art Nouveau building is on the market for 289,000 euros, or $400,000.

title: Man Accused in Fraud Scheme Wants to See Son Compete
description: Mark Mazer may have been in the headlines recently because he is accused of being the architect of an $80 million scheme to siphon money from the Bloomberg administrations CityTime project to automate payroll for all city workers. But he is also the parent of an accomplished gymnast.

title: General Is Cleared of Sex Accusations
description: WASHINGTON  The Marine Corps officer who has been called President Obamas favorite general  and one considered a leading candidate for chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff  was investigated and cleared of accusations that he had a sexual relationship with a subordinate, according to documents released Wednesday.

title: Spring Visas Delay Boys of Summer
description: Felix Hernandez is one of baseballs best young pitchers, but when he arrives at the United States Embassy in Caracas, Venezuela, before the start of spring training each year, he has to walk through a metal detector and submit to being fingerprinted  like every other applicant for a visa to work in this country.

title: For Berra and Guidry, It Happens Every Spring
description: TAMPA, Fla.  With all the yearly changes made by the Yankees, Yogi Berras arrival at their spring training base adds a timeless quality to baseballs most historic franchise.

title: Nets Trump Knicks With Deron Williams Deal
description: It did not take long for the Knicks to be upstaged by their soon-to-be Brooklyn neighbors. As was first reported by Al Iannazzone of The Record of Woodland Park, N.J., the Nets have agreed to a deal that will send Derrick Favors, Devin Harris, New Jerseys 2011 first-round pick and a protected 2012 first-round pick (via Golden State) to Utah for the All-Star point guard Deron Williams.

title: With Abarth, Fiat Hopes to Avoid Cute Curse in America
description: When Laura Soave, the head of Fiat North America, visited New York last week, she recalled her prior professional experience at Volkswagen to illustrate a keen branding point. Fiat is determined not to let its 500 subcompact be pigeonholed as merely a cute car  a fate, she suggested, that befell the New Beetle while she was at VW.

title: Pictures of the Day: New Zealand and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from New Zealand, Tunisia and Afghanistan.

title: The Critics Answer Your Oscar Questions
description: In the first installment of what will be a monthly fixture, Manohla Dargis and A.O. Scott, the co-chief film critics of The New York Times, answer reader questions about the Oscars. For future columns, they would like to hear from you about whatever movie-related subject piques your curiosity: individual films, industry trends, historical trivia. Write to them at askthefilmcritics@nytimes.com.

title: Paul McCartney Collaborates With City Ballet
description: In an unexpected intersection of celebrity pop music and ballet, that most refined of the performing arts, Paul McCartney has written a major orchestral work for New York City Ballet.

title: Calls for a Jasmine Revolution in China Persist
description: BEIJING  A small but stubborn protest movement is continuing calls for demonstrations despite a campaign of arrests and censorship that underscores Chinas concern over unrest and revolts in authoritarian countries in the Middle East and North Africa.

title: Fringe Artist
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#69", 592, 490, true, chameleonData);

title: Goldmans $70 Million Investment in AppSense
description: Goldman Sachs next big Silicon Valley move after Facebook is a $70 million investment in AppSense, a company providing user-personalization technology. User virtualization allows user-specific information to be accessed independent of a desktop.

title: Supreme Court Allows Lawsuit Over Rear Seat Belts
description: WASHINGTON  The family of a woman killed in a head-on collision may sue the maker of the minivan she was riding in for failing to install lap-and-shoulder belts, the Supreme Court unanimously ruled on Wednesday.

title: Man Held in Stabbing Spree Is Indicted in Manhattan
description: The Ukrainian man accused of carrying out a 28-hour rampage that killed four people has been indicted in Manhattan on attempted murder and assault charges, prosecutors said on Wednesday.

title: The Little People Pay Taxes
description: Leona Helmsleys legacy lives on in the building that bears her name.

title: Upheaval Jolts Israel and Raises New Worry
description: CASABLANCA, Morocco  The old certainties of the Middle East have been upended, and Israel finds many of its most reliable partners buffeted or blown away by popular agitation from below. Egypt was long one of Israels most important allies, and ties were quietly close to Tunisia. With demonstrations for change also in Jordan, Bahrain and Morocco, Israel finds itself floundering.

title: New Face for Economic Council
description: President Obama will nominate a Justice Department official to his Council of Economic Advisers, the White House press secretary, Jay Carney, said Tuesday.

title: Photos of the Moment | Gucci
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#12", 592, 440, true, chameleonData);

title: Agent Provocateur, Selling Kink on Madison Avenue
description: I ONCE worked on a play with a dominatrix, who explained a troublesome producer with the smiling dismissal: Oh, dont worry about him. Hes such a John.

title: Hey, Mr. Critic!
description: The mailman came this week with questions about restaurant grief and birthday wishes, about escaping the kids for a weekend of meals, about eating linguine with clam sauce and celebrating marriage. I endeavored to answer as best I could. You may add your own thoughts in the comments below. And, as ever, you may send restaurant questions to me at dinejournal@nytimes.com.

title: Wall Street Remembers Joseph Flom
description: The death of Joseph H. Flom, who built Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom into a global legal powerhouse, represents the passing of a giant in deal-making.

title: Geneva Auto Show: Mini Rocketman Concept
description: The Mini Rocketman concept, which will be introduced at the Geneva auto show next week, is largely about space exploration.

title: New Street Food Rules in Vancouver Emphasize Health and Diversity
description: In Vancouver, street food is an emerging mini-industry. But new vendors who want to sell hot dogs and cheese steak sandwiches may need to switch to healthier options. A controversial city council decision made last month requires vendors seeking licenses to conform to a range of new rules, which emphasize healthier fare; organic, local and fair-trade foods; and an increased diversity of options.

title: A New Sandwich Shop for Cobble Hill
description: The Van Horn Sandwich Shop, which combines Southern fried fare with an industrial chic aesthetic, opened recently in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn. Jacob Van Horn, an architect who grew up in Chapel Hill, N.C., but has spent the last four years living in Brooklyn, conceived of the restaurant last year after getting laid off from Skidmore, Owings & Merrill, an architectural and engineering firm. He hired the chef Rick Hauchman (of Robertas Pizza in Bushwick and The Commodore), a friend and fellow North Carolinian, to run the kitchen, and spent about four months hunting for the right space. In July, he found it at 231 Court Street, falling in love with its unobstructed view down leafy Baltic Street.

title: Ken Cuccinelli v. Climate Skeptics
description: As I wrote in Wednesdays Times, for nearly a year, Virginias attorney general, Kenneth T. Cuccinelli II, has tried to force the University of Virginia to turn over the files of Michael Mann, a climatologist, as part of a broader crusade against the scientific basis of man-made global warming.

title: Fewer Broken Windows, and a Decline in Crime
description: Score one for the broken-windows theory, that largely hypothetical correlation between vandalism and crime. Overall crime in the New York metropolitan area has declined in the past six years. So has the number of broken windows.

title: The Insiders on Their Oscar Hosting Dynamic
description: That Oscars countdown clock over to the right keeps ticking away, and now news about the telecast is coming fast and furious. So far, the producers, Bruce Cohen and Don Mischer, have revealed that to serve their concept of touring Hollywood and Oscar history, they are abandoning most of the movie montages and using an ever-shifting virtual reality set.

title: In Deal With Netflix, New Revenue for CBS
description: CBS is likely to earn about $200 million over the next two years under the deal it reached with Netflix this week to stream TV shows from the networks library, an analyst estimated on Wednesday.

title: Milan Fashion Week | I Spy With My Little Occhio
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#858", 592, 440, true, chameleonData);

title: Taking Notes, and Saving as Digital Text
description: Q. I am a psychiatrist and would like to handwrite my notes and then have a program convert them into text that I can save to my computer. The Livescribe pen does not fill the bill, but I hear the Apple iPad has an application called Note Taker HD. I have not been able to try the app, but would it work for what I want? What about a Lenovo tablet?

title: The Big Jacket on Campus
description: VARSITY jackets are having a moment, evidently. In the fall collections shown in New York last week, variations of them appeared in the collections of Thom Browne, Phillip Lim, Patrik Ervell, Wayne Lee, Rag & Bone, Peter Som and Calvin Klein.

title: House Hunting in ... Berlin
description: A 1,227-SQUARE-FOOT APARTMENT WITH TWO BEDROOMS AND ONE AND A HALF BATHS

title: What You Get for .... $440,000
description: AUSTIN, TEX.

title: New Violence as Strongman of Ivory Coast Fights Ouster
description: DAKAR, Senegal  The muscular efforts by the Ivory Coast strongman Laurent Gbagbo to remain in office after losing an election appeared to be intensifying this week, with assaults by his troops on a neighborhood of Abidjan, the countrys commercial capital, and deaths among soldiers and civilians in several other districts of the city.

title: At Risk? Investigating Dams
description: Overview  | What are dams and how do they work? What are some of the issues surrounding the construction and maintenance of dams? In this lesson, students explore the kinds of dams used in waterways around the world. They explore dam design, investigate the history of dams and investigate how dams affect wildlife and communities.

title: Walker Receives Prank Call From Koch Impersonator
description: MADISON, Wis.  A prank caller posing as a prominent conservative donor succeeded in getting Gov. Scott Walker on the phone to talk about his budget repair bill, a lengthy conversation that contained some of his most unguarded comments to date about the standoff with public employees.

title: Buzz Tracker
description: The Irritated Hedge Fund King The governments long-running investigation into insider trading has ensnared a number of former SAC Capital employees. Matthew Goldstein and Svea Herbst-Bayliss of Reuters report that Steven Cohen, the founder of SAC, is personally irritated by the governments focus on him and his fund. Still, it hasnt hurt business: They report that SAC has attracted $2 billion in new money from investors over the last two years. Reuters

title: In Guayaquil, Some Old-School Survey Work
description: Lekelia D. Jenkins, a postdoctoral researcher at the University of Washington, writes from Ecuador, where she is studying factors in the cross-cultural adoption of marine conservation technologies like turtle excluder devices and circle hooks. She co-leads this project with Patrick Christie, who is an environmental sociologist and Associate Professor at the University of Washington.

title: Solar Energy Faces Tests On Greenness
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Just weeks after regulators approved the last of nine multibillion-dollar solar thermal power plants to be built in the Southern California desert, a storm of lawsuits and the resurgence of an older solar technology are clouding the future of the nascent industry.

title: TimesCast | February 23, 2011
description: Rebels move closer to Tripoli; American officials avoid condemning Colonel Qaddafi by name; Italy's long and complicated relationship with Libya.

title: Tattoos as Makeup? Read the Fine Print
description: AURI REYNOSO, a hairstylist in Englewood, N.J., says she wanted to roll out of bed looking beautiful. So three years ago, she asked Melany Whitney, a certified permanent-cosmetics professional based in New York, New Jersey and Florida, to tattoo eyeliner and defined brows onto her face.

title: Higher-Paying Jobs Lost, but Lower-Paying Jobs Gained
description: While the countrys recessionary job losses skewed to middle- and higher-paying jobs, its job gains since then have skewed to lower-paying jobs.

title: Patchogue, N.Y., 11:26 A.M.
Jeter Gets a Shave, Over and Over Again
description: Derek Jeters carefully manicured image is getting a makeover. On a billboard in SoHo, heappears with virtual stubble one day, has his face lathered with Gillette shave cream the next day and appears clean shaven a third day. The three-day cycle will be repeated until March 6.

title: Beauty & Essex
description: FOR the last two decades, Lower East Side night life has largely revolved around dive bars with live music, worn-out pool tables and cheap drinks. title: Bieber Dominates Billboard Chart
description: Justin Bieber, Lady Gaga, Mumford & Sons and Lady Antebellum all got big Grammy lifts  the typical boost in record sales after the awards show. But who had the biggest lift depends on how you look at the numbers. Mr. Bieber, who did not win any awards but who had a prominent performing slot at the ceremony, dominates this weeks Billboard album chart. Never Say Never: The Remixes (Island), the soundtrack to his new 3-D concert film, opened at No. 1 with 161,000 copies sold. But just as impressive, he has three other albums in the Top 40: My World 2.0 is No. 8, My Worlds Acoustic is No. 18, and My World, the mini-album that was his debut, is No. 31. Billboard said Mr. Bieber was the first artist to pull off that feat since Garth Brooks in 1993. The British alt-folk band Mumford & Sons and Lady Antebellum, the country-pop trio that went home with the most Grammy awards (five, including record and song of the year), also had good runs on the album chart. Mumford & Sons Sigh No More (Glassnote) holds at No. 2 this week. Its rise to No. 2 from No. 11 last week was largely based on impulse buys made during the Grammys telecast, on which the group performed with Bob Dylan, with 133,000 sales, a 169 percent increase from the week before. Lady Antebellums Need You Now (Capitol Nashville) is No. 4, with 85,000 sales, a 205 percent gain. (No. 3 this week goes to Vol. 37 of the series Now Thats What I Call Music!, which sold 95,000.) In terms of digital downloads, however, Lady Gaga and Cee Lo Green came out way ahead. Born This Way, which Lady Gaga performed at the awards, sold 509,000 copies in its first full week on sale, bringing its total sales in the United States  in just 10 days  to 957,000. And sales of Cee Los ____ You jumped 178 percent, to 412,000.

title: Enigmatic Choreographer Tells an Enigmatic Tale
description: The choreographer Paul Taylor  one of the few living artists who have made classics by which our age should be remembered  is a puzzle, and means to be. He makes works whose rhythms answer that of their music, except sometimes they carry on regardless. He makes dances that are primarily about dancing, except that in many of them he seems preoccupied by more specific subject matter. His pieces are addressed to the audience in a way that speaks of entertainment (bright, harsh or both) and yet frequently they do things that will make audiences think, We should be entertained by that? His companys repertory has become so large  his latest is listed as Opus No. 133  that each year brings a major revival of at least one important work that hasnt been seen in decades. It contains many other pieces that get revived only fleetingly before being returned to cold storage for several more seasons.

Mr. Mehta, 25 when he first led the orchestra, became its music director in 1969. In 1981 his appointment was extended for life.

title: Moviegoing Leaps, Except in North America
description: International moviegoing soared in 2010, but the North American market started to show more signs of trouble, according to an annual survey released on Wednesday by the Motion Picture Association of America. Total box office receipts for all films released around the world climbed to $31.8 billion, an 8 percent increase over 2009. But overseas ticket sales contributed all of the increase, as sales in North America were flat for a second year, at $10.6 billion, despite a boom in sales of higher-priced 3-D tickets. The Chinese box office market is just going gangbusters, said Bob Pisano, president and interim chief executive of the movie association. The association does not report overseas attendance figures; admissions in North America fell 5 percent, to 1.34 billion. In a development that Mr. Pisano called not so encouraging the number of North American admissions per capita fell to 4.1, the lowest level since 1993, from 4.3 in 2009. Mr. Pisano said he was unsure of the reason, but added, Weve got to get more Americans and Canadians back to the movie theaters.

A juice virgin, that is. Sure, Id toyed with the idea of trying one of Organic Avenues prettily packaged potions at Fashion Week last season. (They were conveniently available to the thin and wanting-to-be-thinner at Lincoln Centers Alice Tully Hall.) But about the closest Id gotten to fresh juice up to that point was the O.J. in a good mimosa. As for raw food, well, I thought that meant those cute precut, packaged carrot and celery sticks you get from the corner deli.

The question was whether a core section of the Voting Rights Act of 1965, as renewed by Congress in 2006 for another 25 years, was constitutional. A majority opinion by Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr. strongly suggested that it wasnt.

title: Out of Work, Out of Time
description: Since losing my job Ive struggled with countless questions for which I have no suitable response: Is it healthy for my family to subsist on a diet entirely of packaged ramen, canned beans and grocery-store samples, and if so, must it be certified organic? Does baby really need a new pair of shoes? If Im so smart how come Im so broke? The worst question, though, and the one most likely to induce paroxysms of guilt, irritation and half-joking existential despair, is one that seems so simple to answer, but has proven the most vexing: if Im not working, why dont I have more time? Shouldnt a jobless fellow like myself be free to relax, clean house, run errands for my fiance Tomoko and, most important, spend time with my children, J.P., 4-years-old, and Ellie, the baby?

title: Woods and Poulter Stumble Late in Match Play
description: MARANA, Ariz.  For Tiger Woods, the desert far to the right of the first fairway at the Ritz-Carlton Golf Club at Dove Mountain looked like a circle of hell. His ball barely visible amid a tangled web of leafless branches and gnarled cactus, Woods was in an inescapable trap, moments after giving himself hope of surviving another setback.

title: Is Mississippi the New New Hampshire?
description: Gallup has tabulated approval ratings for President Obama over the course of its extensive polling in 2010 and there are a couple of surprises. For instance, Mr. Obamas approval rating was 47.1 percent in Mississippi last year  several percentage points higher than it was in New Hampshire (41.3 percent).

title: U.S. Presses Tobacco Firms to Admit to Falsehoods About Light Cigarettes and Nicotine Addiction
description: A federal judge on Wednesday unsealed a government proposal that outlines what it wants tobacco companies to say in national advertising and on cigarette packages  that they lied to the American public about so-called light cigarettes and the addictiveness of nicotine.

title: Libya's Northern Neighbor
description: Across the Mediterranean from Libya lies Italy, and a long and complicated relationship.

description: American officials avoid condemning Colonel Qaddafi directly

title: Owners and Union Continue Negotiations
description: With the expiration of their collective bargaining agreement little more than a week away, representatives of the N.F.L.s owners and the players union continued negotiations for a sixth consecutive day in Washington. There is one more day in the seven days of scheduled talks with a federal mediator, George Cohen.

title: How the West Was Won
description: Histories of mid-19th century America tend to separate its two most important threads: a war over slavery engulfs the East, while mineral rushes transform the West. But while these developments are geographically distinct, they could not be more interdependent. At its heart, the political crisis that led to the Civil War was fought over the extension of slavery into the West, and it was the subsequent implosion of the Union that enabled the Northern, Republican-controlled Congress to create these western territories.

title: The Fight for Libya
description: In Libya, rebels move closer to the capital Tripoli, as Colonel Qaddafi digs in.

title: Concerns for Boeing Grow as a Tanker Decision Nears
description: As the Air Force tries to end its long and often embarrassing effort to buy new aerial fueling tankers, Boeings supporters are questioning the fairness of the bidding, while its European rival seems confident it will win the $35 billion contract.

Rebels Hope for Qaddafis Fall but Remain Fearful
description: SHAHHAT, Libya  Opponents of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi held a former state radio station in this town on Wednesday, which they had renamed Free Libya and clearly intended to keep.

Cuomo, violated state law by failing to register as a lobbyist and called on Mr. Sachs to disclose the clients of his private consulting business.

description: Russell W. Peterson, who helped develop Dacron as a DuPont research scientist before becoming a champion of environmentalism as governor of Delaware, a White House adviser and president of the National Audubon Society, died Monday at his home in Wilmington, Del. He was 94.

title: Port Chester to Appeal U.S. Voting-Rights Ruling Aimed at Helping Latinos
description: It seemed as if Port Chester, N.Y., was finally about to end a bitter chapter in its history  after four years of voting-rights litigation against the federal government, more than $1.2 million in legal fees, the creation of a new voting system and the election of the municipalitys first Latino to its board of trustees.

title: Life on the Run for Democrats in Union Fights
description: CHICAGO  By now, Jon Erpenbach, one of 14 Democratic state senators on the run from Wisconsin, has switched hotels in this city three times, a necessity, he says, as word kept slipping out about where he was staying.

title: Thursday: Ducks for Cover
description: THURSDAYS PUZZLE  You cant see it, but Im fully armed today in anticipation of the lively commentary that will follow this puzzle. Thats right. I have an ASP and I know how to use it, so please behave yourselves. Just because we have the sort of theme we have today is no reason to be juvenile. Its no reason to snicker. I promise you, I maintained my well-known sense of decorum at all times while solving this puzzle. Mostly.

title: Raised Brows as Christie Dons Mantle of Trailblazer
description: Gov. Chris Christie is a prolific denier that he is interested in running for president in 2012, but this week he billed himself as a different kind of national leader. When other states close budget deficits and curb rising costs, he said in unveiling his budget plan on Tuesday, they are reading from the New Jersey playbook.

title: Charles Epstein, Leading Medical Geneticist Injured by Unabomber, Dies at 77
description: Dr. Charles J. Epstein, a prominent medical geneticist who in 1993 was seriously injured in an attack by the Unabomber but was later able to continue his research on Down syndrome and other genetic conditions, died on Feb. 15 at his home in Tiburon, Calif. He was 77.

title: Georgia: Prison Guards Charged in Beating
description: Seven prison guards were arrested Monday on charges of beating an inmate so badly that he sustained brain injuries and was partly paralyzed. The inmate, Terrance B. Dean, 29, in prison for armed robbery, was assaulted by the guards in December after an argument, according to a recent investigation by the Georgia Bureau of Investigation. The arrests follow a period of strife for Georgias corrections department. In December, inmates in at least four prisons refused to work until their living conditions improved. Mr. Deans beating was not related to the strike, but it was uncovered during the states investigation of the strike, said his lawyer, Mario Williams.

title: Texas: Dallas Mayor Resigns Amid Talk of Senate Run
description: Mayor Tom Leppert of Dallas announced at a City Council meeting Wednesday that he would resign this week. Mr. Leppert has been mentioned in Republican circles for weeks as a possible candidate to replace Senator Kay Bailey Hutchison, who announced last month she would leave the Senate after 19 years in office. Mr. Leppert told Council members that he would make an announcement in a few days about his future. Lt. Gov. David Dewhurst, also a Republican, has said he is considering running for Senator Hutchisons seat. The mayor pro tem, Dwaine Caraway, will become interim mayor after Mr. Leppert finishes his last day on Friday.

title: State Proposal Would Limit Annual Medicaid Rise
description: ALBANY  The State Health Department on Thursday will propose a cap on yearly increases in Medicaid financing that will require across-the-board spending cuts by health care providers.

title: Dwayne McDuffie, Comic-Book Writer, Dies at 49
description: Dwayne McDuffie, a comic-book writer known for diversifying the pantheon of superheroes, creating popular black characters in print and on television, died in Burbank, Calif., on Monday, the day after his 49th birthday.

title: How Quickly They Forget
description: Following the recall of millions of toys from China because of lead paint and other hazards, Congress got its act together in 2008 and passed the Consumer Product Safety Improvement Act. Bipartisan majorities rallied around the idea that the government should ensure that products  whether theyre made abroad or here  wont sicken or maim American consumers or their children.

title: A First Look at the Nintendo 3DS
description: In stores March 27, the Nintendo 3DS ($250) is a pocket-size game system that Nintendo says will reshape the portable gaming landscape by offering glasses-free 3-D viewing. But will enough people part with $250 for the experience?

title: Treasurys Restructuring Chief to Depart
description: James E. Millstein, the Treasury Department official overseeing the governments role in reorganizing the American International Group, is stepping down this week, an administration official said on Wednesday.

title: Unnecessarily Invasive
description: A warning to all women whose mammograms show an abnormality: If your surgeon says you need a surgical biopsy to determine if you have cancer, be sure to get a second opinion. The odds are good that you should get a needle biopsy. That is safer, less invasive, and cheaper.

title: Trustee Gets Time to Fine-Tune Suit
description: The beleaguered owners of the Mets face the possibility of an amended lawsuit by March 18 from the trustee for the victims of Bernard L. Madoffs multibillion-dollar Ponzi scheme.

title: New Rules for New Technology
description: The proposal from the Federal Communications Commission to stop subsidizing rural phone lines and start subsidizing rural broadband connections is long overdue. Right now an estimated 14 million to 28 million Americans have no way of getting access to the Internet.

It started with an electrifying introduction of Anthony, settled into a series of approving chants and ended with a satisfying win that will stoke the lofty expectations.

title: Letter: The Irish Affliction
description: It took courage for the abbot of Glenstal Abbey to address child sexual abuse in the Irish Catholic Church in Russell Shortos article. I agree with him that severe sexual repression most likely led to the masochistic sexual culture graphically described in the Ryan and Murphy Reports. For the Roman Catholic Church in Ireland and elsewhere, however, the real systemic culprit remains deeply woven into the fabric of the institution. Power that only plays at accountability while continuing to practice control will spawn yet-to-be-imagined forms of abuse. This is far from over.

title: Supercolossal Street Art
description: In a Paris suburb in October 2005, two teenagers of African descent were running away from the police and tried to hide inside a power substation. They were electrocuted instantly. The violence that broke out in protest of police harassment soon spread to neighboring communities and eventually to housing projects across the whole of France. When the media came to document the events in Clichy-sous-Bois, they were met with an additional, unexpected kind of confrontation: behind one of the countless cars in flames was a black-and-white photograph that was pasted onto the side of an apartment building some time before and took up its entire width. From its center, surrounded by a group of boys striking aggressive poses, a black man several times larger than life stared out, pointing with what appeared at first to be a shotgun. On closer inspection, it was a video camera. Get out, he seemed to be saying, were recording this too, and well tell the story the way we see it.

title: How Chris Christie Did His Homework
description: Like a stand-up comedian working out-of-the-way clubs, Chris Christie travels the townships and boroughs of New Jersey, places like Hackettstown and Raritan and Scotch Plains, sharpening his riffs about the states public employees, whom he largely blames for plunging New Jersey into a fiscal death spiral. In one well-worn routine, for instance, the governor reminds his audiences that, until he passed a recent law that changed the system, most teachers in the state didnt pay a dime for their health care coverage, the cost of which was borne by taxpayers.

title: Israel Strikes Gaza After Rocket Attack on Israeli City
description: A rocket fired from Gaza on Wednesday struck the southern Israeli city of Beersheba for the first time in two years, damaging one house but causing no physical injury, the Israeli police said. Israel carried out an airstrike soon after that in northern Gaza against what the military said was a rocket-firing squad.

title: Mexico: Suspect Detained in Shooting of U.S. Agent
description: The Mexican Army said Wednesday that it had detained a man suspected in the shooting death of a United States Immigration and Customs Enforcement agent and the wounding of another on a Mexican highway last week. The detained man was identified as Julin Zapata Espinosa, known as El Pioln, a leader of the Zetas gang in San Luis Potos. The agents were ambushed and fired on as they drove from San Luis Potos State to Mexico City. The motive was not clear but speculation has focused on a possible carjacking.

title: Rumsfeld Gets to Know Jon Stewart
description: Former Secretary of Defense Donald H. Rumsfeld took a seat in unsympathetic territory on Wednesday to promote his memoir, Known and Unknown, sitting for an interview on The Daily Show with Jon Stewart, a harsh and early critic of President George W. Bush and the war in Iraq.

title: Zimbabwe: TV Viewers Charged With Treason
description: Zimbabwean authorities on Wednesday charged a total of 45 students, trade unionists and activists with treason, accusing them of watching news videos of the uprising in Egypt and plotting to topple Zimbabwes autocratic president, Robert Mugabe, 87, who has been in power since 1980. If convicted, they face sentences of life in prison or death. Human rights lawyers say the accused are innocent and were merely engaged in an academic discussion about events in Egypt.

title: London Court Grants Swedish Request to Extradite Assange
description: LONDON  Julian Assange, the WikiLeaks founder, must be extradited to Sweden to face accusations of sexual abuse, a British court ordered Thursday. Mr. Assange immediately said he would appeal the decision.

title: An Appetizing Proposition: Anthony Hopkins Takes His Music on Tour
description: With some tours, you wonder what songs will appear on the set list; for this one, we wonder what theyll serve at the concession stands. Anthony Hopkins, who has variously cooked up the liver of a census taker and the brain matter of Ray Liotta in his onscreen capacity as Dr. Hannibal Lecter, plans to take on more digestible material in a series of concerts featuring his own musical compositions. BBC News reported that Mr. Hopkins will participate in the City of Birmingham Symphony Orchestras summer tour of Britain, on which the orchestra will perform the original scores he created for his films August and Slipstream, as well as a new work by the actor. The orchestra, conducted by Michael Seal, will also play selections from the scores of Mr. Hopkinss best-known films, including The Remains of the Day and The Silence of the Lambs, and Mr. Hopkins will discuss his music and creative process (and who knows, maybe even favorite recipes) with Tommy Pearson, a producer of the concerts. There was no immediate announcement if the concert series might come to the United States or if Mr. Hopkins might take a brief detour to the Bahamas to have an old friend for dinner.

title: Aware of His Changing Role, Jones Is Ready to Help Yankees
description: TAMPA, Fla.  Any proper highlight montage of Andruw Joness career would begin with video from the opening game of the 1996 World Series and go on to show a dizzying assortment of gravity-defying catches and majestic home runs. Jones, for all of it, would be wearing an Atlanta Braves uniform. His last game with the Braves was in 2007. For the sake of accuracy, Jones has since played for the Los Angeles Dodgers, the Texas Rangers and the Chicago White Sox, adjusting every season to the industrys changing perception of him. A prodigy at 19, a star at 25 and a backup at 31.

title: Sabathia Says Weight Loss Improved His Stamina
description: TAMPA, Fla.  C. C. Sabathia was not expecting a miraculous difference Thursday morning when he faced hitters for the first time this spring, no extra velocity or sharper break or improved command now that he is pitching at 290 pounds. After throwing about 30 pitches, Sabathia did notice an increase in stamina, and that counts as progress.

title: Fox News Chief, Roger Ailes, Urged Employee to Lie, Records Show
description: It was an incendiary allegation  and a mystery of great intrigue in the media world: After the publishing powerhouse Judith Regan was fired by HarperCollins in 2006, she claimed that a senior executive at its parent company, News Corporation, had encouraged her to lie two years earlier to federal investigators who were vetting Bernard B. Kerik for the job of homeland security secretary.

title: Prime Minister Urges Iraqis to Call Off Nationwide Protests
description: BAGHDAD  Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki on Thursday urged Iraqis not to take part in nationwide demonstrations scheduled for Friday, saying he had evidence that insurgents were trying to use the protests to create unrest.

title: Remembrance of Flavors Past
description: When Gabrielle Hamilton was a child, growing up in Pennsylvania, her family gave an annual party that was legendary in its small town  a spring lamb roast for almost 200 people, who came from as far away as New York City: former ballet dancer friends of her mothers and artist friends of her fathers, along with local friends and neighbors, who all gathered in the meadow behind their house to feast on lamb and asparagus vinaigrette and shortcake. In preparation Gabrielle and her sister and brothers would fill dozens of brown paper lunch bags with sand and candles and set them along the streams edge under the weeping willows to light everyones way, and juice up glow-in-the-dark Frisbees in the car headlights, so they could send those glowing greenish discs arcing through the jet black night.

title: A Cheat Sheet for the Foreign-Language Oscar Race
description: Handicapping the competition for the Oscar for best foreign-language film is a bit more complex than for some of the other categories, since theres no telling how many people are going to vote, what motivates those who do, or even who they are. To qualify to vote, an academy member must see all five nominated films, and many  or most  Oscar voters simply cant be bothered with a category considered so marginal or esoteric. Thats not the case with categories like best film or best actor and actress.

title: James Earl Jones Elected for Broadway Revival of Gore Vidals The Best Man
description: When his time behind the wheel at Driving Miss Daisy comes to an end, James Earl Jones need not resort to reciting Justin Bieber lyrics for fun and profit (unless he wants to), as his next term of office on Broadway has been decided: Mr. Jones, a Tony Award winner for Fences and The Great White Hope, will next portray a former United States president in the revival of Gore Vidals The Best Man, a political play scheduled for spring of next year. Press representatives for the revival said on Thursday that Mr. Jones will play Arthur Hockstader, a Truman-esque chief executive deciding between endorsing the potential presidential nominees William Russell and Joe Cantwell. When The Best Man was first presented on Broadway in 1960 (and made into a film in 1964), Russell was perceived as an analogue for Adlai Stevenson and Cantwell as an amalgam of John F. Kennedy and Richard M. Nixon; a 2000 Broadway revival, starring Charles Durning as Hockstader, Spalding Gray as Russell and Chris Noth as Cantwell, seemed to have its eye on the real-life contest between Al Gore and George W. Bush. Michael Wilson (The Orphans Home Cycle) will direct the 2012 production, though its producers have not yet announced their nominees to play Russell and Cantwell.

title: The Third Arm Illusion
description: Researchers test whether one can fear for the safety of a fake third arm.

title: Putting People Back to Work
description: I mentioned on Wednesday that World War II was the stimulus program that finally ended the Depression. My colleague Alan Schwarz  he of concussion-expose fame  said that the mention reminded him of one of his high school teachers, Werner Feig, who used to tell students that the Depression was ended by the Full Employment Act of Dec. 7, 1941. (Mr. Feig evidently made a big impression: Aaron Sorkin, another former student, wove him into a West Wing episode.)

An increasingly heated national debate about the rights of union workers was stuck in a standoff on Thursday as Democratic lawmakers here and in Indiana stayed away from their Capitols to frustrate Republican efforts to vote on legislation that would undercut collective bargaining and the ability to organize.

title: Californias Tax Aversion Complicates Budget
description: OAKLAND, Calif.  For nearly two months, Gov. Jerry Brown has been immersed in a furious effort to win the support of the Legislature for his proposal to close a $26.6 billion budget gap with spending cuts and by asking voters to approve $12 billion in taxes in a special election this June.

title: Should Suns Adjust to Vince Carters Game?
description: Life in the N.B.A. is a constant stream of adjustments. Even the leagues most influential stars are rarely left to their own devices; the dynamics of the game demand that each player make concessions at every step of the way  to their teammates, to their coach, to the system their team employs  in order to reach the closest approximation of their potential as a part of a collective.

title: Deeper Peril for Coral Reefs
description: Coastal development, overfishing and climate change are creating a perfect storm for the worlds coral reefs, nearly three-quarters of which are now at risk of serious degradation, a top federal environmental official warned this week at the unveiling of a comprehensive new report.

title: Citadel Plans to Cut E*Trade Stake
description: Shares of online brokerage firm E*trade plummeted nearly 5 percent Thursday, following the disclosure that its largest shareholder, the hedge fund Citadel Investment Group, plans to sell 24 million shares in the company.

description: WASHINGTON  A 20-year-old Saudi college student who was arrested Wednesday night on bomb charges in Texas wrote in his journal that he sought a student visa three years ago so he could carry out terrorist attacks inside the United States, according to an F.B.I. document released Thursday.

University of Washington Huskies. In college, Mr. Robinson starred as a 6-foot-5 guard on a team with James Edwards, the 7-foot center who later guided two Detroit Pistons teams to world championships.

title: Enlisting Prison Labor to Close Budget Gaps
description: JAY, Fla.  Before he went to jail, Danny Ivey had barely seen a backyard garden.

title: Its (Gasp!) Alive, Not to Mention Peeved
description: LONDON  Bet youve never seen baby pictures like these. In the thrilling first moments of the National Theater production of Frankenstein, directed with rough magic by Danny Boyle, a newborn tumbles hard from the womb and straight into the struggle that is life. Oh, the muscle-clenching pain of it, as this still inchoate being tries out its lungs, its limbs, its voice. When it takes its first wobbling steps, its an act of exultation, and we want to roar with it.

title: 36 Hours in Mammoth Lakes, Calif.
description: FOR over half a century, Angelinos have flocked to this secluded corner of Californias Sierra Nevada mountains. Its easy to see why. Despite the 8,000-foot altitude, Mammoth Lakes sprawl of splashy condos and strip malls has a distinct Los Angeles feel. But the surrounding frozen lakes and granite peaks, immortalized by the photographer Ansel Adams, are decidedly un-Los Angeles, and can hold their own with any landscape in Colorado or Canada. And with expanded daily flights from the San Francisco Bay area and Los Angeles, not to mention a flurry of new aprs-ski offerings, Mammoth is hoping to draw skiers from beyond the Golden State.

title: An Impressive Lineage for Animated Gruffalo
description: Fans of Helena Bonham Carter who fear she may not win the Oscar for her supporting role in The Kings Speech (out-advertised by Melissa Leo or underdogged by Hailee Steinfeld) will be happy to know that Ms. Bonham Carter has a second chance to bring home an Oscar this year, albeit indirectly.

title: Thieves Arrested in Egypt Trying to Break Apart Ancient Statue
description: Two thieves were arrested last week trying to break apart an important 20-foot-tall statue of the pharaoh Ramses II embedded in a quarry in the southern city of Aswan, Egypts antiquities minister, Zahi Hawass, said in a phone interview. Mr. Hawass said that the thieves wrongly believed that the statue was hollow and had gold hidden inside it. They were caught by guards at the site, he said, comparing the thieves to the people who looted the Egyptian Museum on Jan. 28. Those looters were also looking for gold, according to Mr. Hawass, and for a fictitious substance called red mercury that is believed by ignorant people to have been used in mummification and to have magical properties.

title: Brewer Isnt Answer for Knicks Need for Wing Depth
description: In their deal to acquire Carmelo Anthony, the Knicks opted to consolidate. Danilo Gallinari and Wilson Chandler are solid players, but rather than have those two good scorers in their rotation, the Knicks cashed in on their trade value to net one terrific scoring talent. Neither Gallinari nor Chandler can touch Anthony when it comes to shot creation or scoring volume, but the cost for the upgrade in first-unit production is the teams depth. Both former Knicks played over 34 minutes a night, which means that in addition to Anthony, New York will have at least one more new regular filling in minutes on the wing.

Eight days later, Citigroup told shareholders its controls were fine. Jonathan Weil wants to know what happened and who knew what when. Bloomberg

title: Founding President of Seaport Museum Calls for Resignations
description: 3:54 p.m. | Updated The founding president of the Seaport Museum New York, which in recent weeks lost a third of its trustees and furloughed half its staff, has called for the resignation of the museums current president, Mary Pelzer, and its chairman, Frank J. Sciame. In a letter to Ms. Pelzer that he shared with The New York Times, the former president, Peter Stanford, said that the museum needed new leadership to survive. He wrote that Ms. Pelzers and Mr. Sciames credibility had been damaged by concealment of its financial problems, and that the overall direction of the Seaport Museum has been neglectful of its principal physical asset, its historic ships. Mr. Sciame, a real estate developer, has lent the museum $3 million in the last year to cover operating expenses. Mr. Sciame and Ms. Pelzer are extremely surprised and deeply disappointed by these inaccurate comments, said Adam Pockriss of Rubenstein Communications and a spokesman for the museum. Neither Ms. Pelzer nor Mr. Sciame returned phone calls.

title: Can the Economy Recover Without Housing?
description: You sometimes hear the claim that the economy cannot recover before the housing market recovers. I think thats wrong. Just because real estate led the economy into the recession does not mean it must lead the economy out. Other sectors can accomplish that. Its more likely that the economy will need to recover  with unemployment falling and income rising  first and then housing will begin a very slow recovery.

title: Putin Questions Europes Foreign and Energy Policies
description: BRUSSELS  Prime Minister Vladimir V. Putin of Russia warned European officials on Thursday that uprisings in North Africa and the Middle East could produce governments hostile to the West, and he criticized the European Unions energy policy.

title: The Critics Tackle Some More Oscar Questions
description: Manohla Dargis and A.O. Scott, the co-chief film critics of The New York Times, are answering Oscar-related questions this week, as they kick off what will be a monthly fixture in print and online. For future columns, they would like to hear from you about whatever movie-related subject piques your curiosity: individual films, industry trends, historical trivia. Write to them at askthefilmcritics@nytimes.com.

title: Shifting Battlefronts Cut a Long Gash Across Somalia
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  Fierce fighting broke out across Somalia on Thursday along several different fronts, as African Union peacekeepers, Somali government soldiers, allied militias and Ethiopian troops opened a multipronged offensive against radical Islamist insurgents.

title: Questions and Intrigue After Recall of Ford F-150
description: Fords recall on Wednesday of 135,000 F-150 pickup trucks, conducted because the drivers air bag may inadvertently deploy, could be seen as a laudable act of corporate responsibility. But for the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, which has called for 10 times as many vehicles to be recalled, it is a rebuff and a challenge.

Citing the Yankees condensed spring schedule, Joe Girardi said Thursday that there was not enough time for a team building outing before the exhibition season begins Saturday against Philadelphia.

title: Theater Talkback: When Shakespeares Comedies Draw Tears
description: At first I thought maybe it was just jet lag. But no, I said to myself, this always happens at exactly this point. And then I realized I wasnt the only one who was doing it in my row at the Cottesloe Theater in London  crying, that is, in involuntary sheets of tears, over what was meant to be the happiest moment of the evening.
