description: While the exhibitions at the Brooklyn Museum have recently been aimed at capturing younger and hipper audiences, its latest renovation project looks like a step back in time, to an era when museums were grand palaces of culture.

title: Fix It and They Will Come
description: On Friday morning, the Hamilton Project will release a few new proposals for helping fiscally struggling state and local governments keep their roads, bridges and other infrastructure in decent shape. One of the proposals fits a theme Ive been writing about recently: making government programs less wasteful.

title: GMO Poll Results (and More)
description: Clearly this is something Ill be writing about for years to come; emotions are high and many pro-GMO people are industry boosters in disguise. Nothing wrong with that, I suppose, but fake impartiality is obnoxious. There were two pieces in Forbes about my column. The more reasonable one categorized me as a foodie elite  presumably not because I sometimes eat well but because I refuse to acknowledge that genetically engineered foods will save the world, which they will not (you might read this terrific piece by Christopher Cook in The Christian Science Monitor, about Monsantos business and its threat to food safety, and then remember that not all new developments are progressive) and a luddite (which is ridiculous, unless believing that not every bit of technology is world-saving makes you a luddite).

title: Issa Issues More Subpoenas, Increasing Tension on Oversight Committee
description: 4:38 p.m. | Updated Tension between the top two lawmakers on the House Oversight and Government Reform committee escalated Thursday, after Representative Darrell Issa, the chairman, demonstrated once again that he wont hesitate on his own to issue subpoenas compelling federal agencies or private companies to cooperate with his growing list of investigations.

title: TimesCast | February 24, 2011
description: As antigovernment forces claim victory in Benghazi, clashes break out around the Libyan capital of Tripoli; and journalists struggle to get the story out to the world.

title: Along Came Yet Another Spider: Get Ready for a Third Spider-Man Musical
description: Among the things youll soon be able to find on every street corner in Manhattan: a Chase bank; a fresh fruit stand; a Duane Reade; and a theater presenting a musical based on Spider-Man. To an embarrassment of riches that already includes Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark (which opens  maybe  at Broadways Foxwoods Theater on March 15) and The Spidey Project: With Great Power Comes Great Responsibility (which comes to the Peoples Improv Theater on March 14), you can now add Spidermann, which will arrive at the Tank on W. 45th Street in Manhattan for three performances beginning March 13, possibly in an attempt to capitalize on the outsize publicity generated by one of the two aforementioned projects.

title: Where Its Still Legal to Exhale
description: AN aficin for cigars  penchant lacks the necessary passion, while fondness is at least three shades too tame  is a difficult itch to scratch in Bloombergian New York, which, aside from its high property taxes and low trans fats, is almost entirely smoke-free. There arent many Cubans to be found, even at the high-end joints in Midtown, which leaves the connoisseur with the alternative of second-fiddle Dominicans. If you are going to buy such things, you might as well go to the source.

title: New York Public Library, 11:14 A.M.
description: Keri Russell reads to children at the New York Public Library in Manhattan as part of an annual Read Across America program, honoring the birthday of Dr. Seuss.

title: Anthony Boosts Ratings for MSG Network
description: Carmelo Anthonys first game with the Knicks on Wednesday night generated a 6.75 rating (or 507,285 local TV households) on the MSG Network, the best performance for one of the teams regular-season games in 16 years on the channel. In that game, which had a 6.78 rating, Michael Jordan scored 55 points in his return to the Madison Square Garden after his first retirement.

title: Recruits for Police in Sudan Are Abused
description: JUBA, Sudan  The medic said patients started coming in by the dozens, and never stopped.

title: Mets Want Tejada to Concentrate on Shortstop
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  If all goes well for the Mets this spring, Ruben Tejada will be the starting shortstop at Class AAA Buffalo. If it doesnt, Tejada might just be the Mets starting second baseman on opening day.

title: Solar Projects Pit Green Against Green
description: As I wrote in Thursdays Times, the fate of several multibillion-dollar solar thermal power plants to be built the Southern California desert is in question as conservationists and other groups sue to stop the projects largely on environmental grounds.

title: Authorship or Translation? Notes Toward Redefining Creativity
description: Drawn From Photography, at the Drawing Center in SoHo, is all about the vulnerability of movements, some aesthetic, others political. Its a narrow slice of drawing today, encompassing a mere 13 artists, but it feels right for our moment of global trepidation.

description: The revolt is setting off debates about how the region will be affected.

description: GENEVA  The 2011 Geneva auto show steps into the batters box on March 1. The on-deck circle, however, is looking uncharacteristically crowded.

title: From City Folk, Toe-Tapping Country Sounds
description: ON a recent Saturday night, in a desolate corner of Red Hook, Brooklyn, a crowd gathered at Sunnys, a family-owned bar thats been soothing homesick sailors for well over a century. Outside, icy winds sliced across New York Harbor; inside, visitors clutched mugs of hot spiced cider, squeezing onto the handmade wooden benches flanking the back room. A man wandered in holding a guitar.

title: Big Deal | Courtney Love Rents in the Village
description: Like a lot of other things in the life of Courtney Love  a musician, an actress and the wife of the late Kurt Cobain her house hunt, a relentless and dramatic search for a West Village town house, took on an epic nature.

title: A Fund-Raiser Grown Wild
description: The word fund-raiser evokes an image of endless speeches, bland evening gowns and even blander buffets, but Edible Schoolyards yearly benefit should veer a little more toward the wild side. With three fabulous hostesses (the food artist Jennifer Rubell, the fashion buyer Julie Gilhart and the 303 gallerist Lisa Spellman) and a storied downtown locale (the Odeon), the event promises to be more Studio 54 than Cipriani Ballroom. Its the kind of fund-raiser that I would love to attend, a fund-raiser that is not boring says Rubell, just back from the opening of her Engagement show at the Stephen Friedman gallery in London. My favorite women in the city will be there, including Lynn Wagenknecht  the restaurants owner  who came up with the idea.

title: On Our Radar: Palins Predator-Control Policies Persist
description: Aggressive predator-control policies instituted during the tenure of Sarah Palin, the former governor, remain in place in Alaska and continue to stir controversy there. The baiting, snaring and killing of black and grizzly bears, and the gassing of wolf puppies in their dens with carbon monoxide, were both pushed for by hunting groups and authorized by Ms. Palin before her 2009 resignation. Conservation and wildlife groups call the tactics cruel and overzealous. [High Country News]

description: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey takes a lightning round of questions from The Caucus's Michael D. Shear.

description: RAMALLAH, West Bank  Young Palestinians watching the revolutions in Egypt, Tunisia and elsewhere in the region have no shortage of their own protest-worthy causes.

title: Andrea Mohins Jump Shot
description: Certain performances and rituals  on the stage or the playing field, in religious shrines or halls of government  have moments so emblematic that they are definitive. No matter how many times theyve been captured before, a photographer must not miss them, even if they summon a sinking sense of dj dj dj vu.

title: The Midlife Thing, the Nightmare Thing
description: THE bassist and bandleader Mike Watt, who once played in the great Southern California punk band the Minutemen and now spends half his life on the road with five different groups, turned 53 in December. He feels all right about it. Its not a totally lame place to be, he said last week by telephone from his home in San Pedro, Calif. My knee hurts, but I do have experiences I didnt have as a younger man.

title: Renaissance Painting as Punk Mirror
description: The bassist and bandleader Mike Watt describes how The Garden of Earthly Delights, by Hieronymus Bosch, inspired his new album.

description: An expedition to the mountains of the Solomon Islands sought to understand how new species evolve.

title: Amtrak Now Stops at a YouTube Channel
description: Amtrak started a YouTube channel this month to offer travelers a new way to get information about the rail line. The channel will feature videos about safety, security and other travel tips, information about the Trails & Rails program (done in conjunction with the National Park Service), high-speed rail initiatives and expansion plans for its Wi-Fi service. Personal stories of passengers who share their travel experiences will also be highlighted.

title: Using Solar Power to Extract Oil
description: A California company has begun using solar power to squeeze oil out of an old oil field, flooding the underground rock with steam that comes from the suns heat instead of from burning natural gas.

title: 4 Rules to Win Your Oscar Pool
description: Nate Silver is providing awards-season insight for Carpetbagger leading up to the 83rd Academy Awards on Feb. 27. Mr. Silver is the author of The Timess FiveThirtyEight blog, which is devoted to the analysis of statistics and data in politics and other areas.

title: Discovery, Bound for Space Station, Leaves Earth One Last Time
description: KENNEDY SPACE CENTER, Fla.  With seconds to spare after a last-minute glitch, the repaired shuttle Discovery, grounded since November because of vexing fuel tank cracks, rocketed into orbit Thursday on its 39th and final flight, setting off for the International Space Station to deliver supplies, equipment and a final American storage module.

description: In a surprise twist to a long-running saga, the Air Force said on Thursday that it would award a $35 billion contract for aerial fueling tankers to Boeing rather than to a European company that builds Airbus planes.

title: Mathieu Palombino to Open a Diner on Bowery
description: With two Motorino pizzerias under his belt, Mathieu Palombino is about to head in a different direction. He and his partners plan to open Bowery Diner in the late spring, in what had been a restaurant supply store at 241 Bowery (Stanton Street). Modeled after what Mr. Palombino calls a mid-century American diner, with a counter and booths, it will serve coffee, doughnuts and other breakfast dishes in the morning, then segue into sandwiches and other dishes at lunch.

title: A Promising Rookie Gives Houston and M.L.S. the Royal Treatment
description: Kofi Sarkodie is probably the first player in the history of Major League Soccer who comes from a royal family. Not the so-called soccer royalty. Real Ashanti royalty. Queens and kings, and princesses and princes.

title: The Self-Invented Artist
description: WASHINGTON  Paul Gauguin was a dreadful man who made some beautiful art. Thats the present take on him. In his craving for fame and fulfillment he dumped his family, bullied his friends, ripped off ideas and lied about his past. His book Noa Noa, which he advertised as an account of his life in Tahiti, was largely fantasy, mostly plagiarized. If he published it today, Oprah would be demanding an apology.

They all involve greenhouse gases other than carbon dioxide, along with black carbon  the sooty emanations from diesel engines and guttering cooking fires that both heat and kill.

description: Jazz

title: Bill Requiring the University of Iowa to Relinquish Pollocks Mural Is Dropped
description: State legislation that would have forced the University of Iowa to sell Mural  an 8-by-20-foot painting by Jackson Pollock valued at more than $100 million  to raise money for the school has been dropped, The Des Moines Register reported. State Representative Scott Raecker introduced the bill this month as a way to create an endowment to pay for as many as 1,000 full student scholarships a year, but the proposal drew widespread criticism. David Miles, the president of the Board of Regents, State of Iowa, described the bill as a profoundly bad idea, one that was examined by the board in 2008 and determined to be not in the best interests of the University of Iowa or the state. Mr. Raecker told the student newspaper The Daily Iowan that he still believed the painting should be sold but said that the issue had become so polarized that reaching consensus is unlikely. Im a firm believer in the legislative process, he added, and further discussion of the sale of the Pollock painting will not be moved forward in the legislature this year.

title: Just Looking Changes Her Tune
description: WITH little cash for a down payment, Siobhan Briley was not serious about buying.

title: A.I.G. Posts $2.2 Billion Loss as Stock Sale Draws Nearer
description: The insurer American International Group reported a $2.2 billion adjusted loss for its fourth quarter on Thursday, as it prepares to sell a big portion of the governments stake in the company that was gained as part of a huge taxpayer-financed bailout.

title: F.H.A. to Raise Insurance Premiums
description: FEDERAL Housing Administration mortgages, the government-insured loans that have surged in popularity in recent years, will be getting slightly more expensive this spring.

title: Man-Child in the Promised Land, for a Whole (Pant! Pant!) Week
description: The bodily fluids that Peter and Bobby Farrelly let fly and sometimes squirt in their movies, along with the assaults visited on their hapless male characters and those mens various body parts, might suggest that these filmmaking brothers are stuck in a developmental quagmire. They dont just like to play around in human messes, those both ickily literal and situational; they also revel in them. Yet while all this foul play can make you blanch, these excesses are affirmations of the humanity that comes with the yuks. Their characters poop, therefore they are  or at least the guys are.

description: Classical

title: Speaking at Arms Length With Music
description: TO woo her, I needed a music box. I conceived this idea the night I met her. Id gone alone to an open-mike night. I was 22 and new to the city. I wasnt at this open mike to launch a career as a ukulele-player, but to meet new friends. I got along best with other musicians.

title: The Caucus Podcast: Egypt vs. Libya
description: Click to Listen

title: Fin-de-Sicle Hothouse, Plush and Neurotic
description: Theres no modernism like Viennese modernism, that amazingly fraught, conflicted efflorescence of art and thought that flared up around the turn of the 20th century. As the Austro-Hungarian Empire sank into paralysis in the decades before World War I, Freud discovered the unconscious lurking, unsurprisingly, behind the citys repressive social codes. Otto Wagner and Adolf Loos designed buildings that rejected the historicist wedding-cake facades of the Ringstrasse. Arnold Schoenberg pursued atonal music in the perfumed wake of the Viennese waltz; and Gustav Klimt painted beautiful women surrounded by mosaic patterns straight out of Byzantium.

title: Dance Listings for Feb. 25-March 3
description: Dance

title: Huckabee Is Out Hawking His Book, and Maybe His Candidacy
description: Mike Huckabee, the former governor of Arkansas, is out hawking his new book, Twelve Things We Really Need from Washington (and a Trillion That We Dont!). As a former presidential candidate whose book tour includes an eyebrow-raising number of stops in early nominating states  six in Iowa and five in South Carolina  he had a thing or two to say about the current state of politics.

title: Fox Finds Right Tune Wednesday
description: The remaining contestants on American Idol performed songs from the Beatles catalog on Wednesday as the judges named 5 of the top 24 to advance. The Fox reality competition easily dominated the nights ratings over all. According to Nielsens estimates, an average of 22.6 million viewers tuned in to the episode from 8 to 10 p.m. CBSs Criminal Minds, with its 13.4 million viewers at 9, came closest to matching the audience for Idol, as CBS claimed second place, earning solid results the rest of the night for Survivor: Redemption Island at 8 (11.2 million) and Criminal Minds: Suspect Behavior at 10 (9.9 million). ABC ranked third with its comedy lineup from 8 to 10, including Modern Family (13.3 million) and Mr. Sunshine (6.5 million) in the 9 p.m. hour. NBC finished fourth with Minute to Win It from 8 to 10 (4.1 million), followed by Law & Order: SVU at 10 (8 million).

title: Artifacts | Terence Kohs Tink Tank
description: As a designer-label ascetic who boasts a white, monkey-fur coat and white-on-white suits, Terence Koh has no trouble getting attention. But it isnt just his monochromatic taste that turns heads. The ceremony, elegance and debauchery of his sculpture and performance work, which can involve white chocolate, potato starch, white sugar, blinding white light and bodily fluids, also draws crowds. For his current show at Mary Boones Chelsea gallery, however, visitors are leaving him pretty well alone.

title: Keeping Score: Big Trades Dont Come With Guarantees
description: Justin Kubatko is the creator of Basketball-Reference.com, an online basketball encyclopedia. He is also a statistical consultant for the Portland Trail Blazers.

title: Diners Questions on the Reviewers Plate
description: The mail came this week with questions about restaurant grief, birthday wishes and more. As ever, you may send restaurant questions to me at dinejournal@nytimes.com.

title: La La Vazquez, the Wife of Carmelo Anthony, Gets VH1 Show
description: La La Vazquez, the wife of the NBA star  Carmelo Anthony, wont just be busy setting up house when the couple moves to New York. She has landed a reality series on VH1, La Las Full Court Life, which will chronicle the couples move from Denver. On Monday Mr. Anthony was traded by the Denver Nuggets to the New York Knicks. The 10-episode, half-hour series, which is scheduled to premiere in August, will show Ms. Vazquez, an actress and television personality, as she copes with the demands of career and home in New York. It is a follow-up to La Las Full Court Wedding, a series about the couples wedding broadcast last year on VH1. Viewers connect with La La because despite the fairy tale wedding and NBA star husband, she is a real, down to earth, hardworking woman who stays true to herself, said Jeff Olde, executive vice president for original programming and production at VH1.

title: A For-Sale Sign With Brains
description: IN 1996, when J. Philip Faranda started out in real estate, he never left home without a beeper, a day planner in a three-ring binder on the passenger seat of the car and a street atlas on the back seat. Those items and a fax machine in his home office, as well as a voice-mail account with the telephone company, he said, made me a big shot.

title: DreamWorks Animation and Imax Report Higher Profits
description: Two small but important Hollywood companies, DreamWorks Animation and Imax, reported greatly improved quarterly financial results on Thursday.

title: Drink Up, Pay Up
description: Ive been on two dates with this girl. We get along great and have a blast together. Problem is, I end up buying all the drinks. She doesnt even pretend to offer, even after I hint. This doesnt seem right, especially in the age of $14 Belgian beers. My friends tell me shes a mooch and I should ditch her. Or should I just keep paying?

title: The Inside Story on Outsiderness
description: A STARTLING sight will soon be hanging in midair in the Madison Avenue window of the Whitney Museum of American Art, just a few blocks from Ralph Lauren, Prada and Gucci: a 22-foot-long neon sign spelling out the words negro sunshine.

title: A Low Tide for Home Sales in the Shoreline Market
description: FOR the shoreline real estate market, by unvarying tradition, spring arrives early. Sometime in mid-January, in all four coastal counties  Monmouth, Ocean, Atlantic and Cape May  the number of listings begins to swell and rises in small waves, usually reaching a peak by early April.

title: Bed-and-Breakfast Inns Being Sold as Vacation Homes
description: ELEVEN years ago Jeanne and Lou Genovese bought two and a half acres on a quiet lane in the middle of North Fork wine country in Cutchogue. They designed a 4,340-square-foot house with six bedrooms, five and a half baths, and a broad front porch, planning for it to double as a bed-and-breakfast.

title: Libyans Call for Qaddafi to Step Down
description: Foreign mercenaries and Libyan militiamen loyal to the embattled leader tried to roll back the uprising that has advanced closer to his stronghold in Tripoli, attacking two nearby cities in battles that killed at least 15 people.

title: Embracing the Ambiguity of Mahlers Seventh
description: Mahlers Seventh Symphony, composed during the summers of 1904 and 1905, is generally considered the most problematic and baffling of his works in the form. The piece may be the least programmed and the last that most conductors learn, often simply because they have set out to perform the complete Mahler symphony cycle.

title: Anti-Abortion Billboard is Removed
description: Updated Feb. 25, 1:19 p.m. |The outdoor advertising company that put up a controversial billboard sponsored by a group opposing abortion decided to remove it on Thursday because employees in the Mexican restaurant below the sign were harassed by people angered by the billboards message, the company said.

title: Blockbusters Fall and Netflixs Rise, in Pictures
description: Blockbuster announced this week that it had accepted a preliminary bid to sell itself  for $290 million, as part of a plan to more quickly exit bankruptcy. The chain also plans to shutter 609 stores.

title: Journalists Face Big Challenges in Libya
A Pharaonic Smackdown as Envisioned by Handel
description: Once again, an Egyptian oppressor has fallen on dark times. In Handels grand oratorio Israel in Egypt, it is the God of the Israelites who wreaks vengeance on the enslaving pharaoh, with no need of Facebook or Twitter. But recent events added a certain immediacy to Handels vivid recounting of the biblical plagues visited on Egypt, when the Musica Sacra Chorus and Orchestra, directed by Kent Tritle, performed the work at Carnegie Hall on Wednesday evening.

description: Is the Big East really about to get 11 of its 16 teams into the N.C.A.A. mens basketball tournament?

title: Floating Through Fog, and Yet Structured
description: Beach House played Webster Hall on Tuesday night with the three musicians faces in shadows and their bodies silhouetted against pyramids of white fabric. Smoke-machine smoke was in the air; a few songs into the set, starry lights began to shine behind the band. Beach Houses music is at home in the dusk and haze. Victoria Legrand sings about dissolving boundaries  between lovers, between past and present, between memories and desires  with her voice floating on the sustained chords of her keyboard and the reverb of Alex Scallys guitar.

title: 4 Rules to Win Your Oscar Pool
description: Two years ago, I tried to predict the Oscar winners by crunching data from the last 30 years of awards history. The project was a mixed success. But Ive dusted off the database and aimed to simplify it  boiling it down to a few core factors that have been especially reliable predictors in the past. Here, then, over at the Carpetbagger, are the rules-of-thumb for predicting the Oscars. Read more.

title: Weekend Miser
description: The bad news? Natalie Portman is bringing her fit fianc to the Academy Awards on Sunday night instead of you. The good news? At its Oscars viewing party, Side Bar is offering two-for-one drinks in which to drown your sorrows. The broadcast starts at 8 p.m., as do the drink specials, but those who R.S.V.P. to Emily@yourpartyplanning.com should arrive early to get a free drink. You can fill out an Oscar ballot for a chance to win two movie tickets and more drinks. (Sunday, 7 p.m.; 120 East 15th Street, at Irving Place, Manhattan; 212-677-2900, sidebarny.com.)

title: Runner Warms to Williamsburg
description: I DONT generally make New Years resolutions. Life is complicated and abundant enough with opportunities for disappointment. And I tend to be on the quiet side, so I dont like making announcements, even if theyre only in my mind.

title: Slim Pickings For Climate Science Critics in Inspector General Report
description: Senator James M. Inhofe, the Oklahoma Republican and the dean of congressional naysayers on the need for action on climate and energy, appeared to come up empty-handed today.

title: Serious? Snarky? Oscar Courts a Social Medium
description: In one of the latest promotions for the Oscar telecast on Sunday, the hosts, James Franco and Anne Hathaway, do something almost unheard of: they spoof the self-seriousness of the whole endeavor.

title: Where Its Still Legal to Exhale
description: An aficin for cigars  penchant lacks the necessary passion, while fondness is at least three shades too tame  is a difficult itch to scratch in Bloombergian New York, which, aside from its high property taxes and low trans fats, is almost entirely smoke free. There arent many Cubans to be found, even at the high-end joints in Midtown, which leaves the connoisseur with the alternative of second-fiddle Dominicans. If you are going to buy such things, you might as well go to the source.

title: Battle-Honed Commander Unleashes Pirates
description: CONVEYING with any accuracy the goings-on at a recent rehearsal of Treasure Island would come most naturally to a comic-book artist or perhaps a writer for the old Batman TV show. Swords and oars and barrels and fists oooff and shhkrit into one another, a seemingly endless barrage of chaos until B. H. Barry, the theaters pre-eminent fight director for some 50 years, dived in for a quick correction. Would-be pirates in sweatpants stood attentively, a thwup morphed into a thwap, and the mayhem began again.

title: House Tour: Pound Ridge, N.Y.

title: Scorecard | Gucci Wins!

If youre looking to Anjelica Huston for inspiration this Milan fashion week,Scorecard knows Frida Giannini took the early lead on the first day with a 90th anniversary collection that married the molto luxe Gucci brand DNA with her own 70s thing. Fiat accompli.

title: The Next Impasse
description: In the nine years since the first American troops landed in Afghanistan, a new kind of religion has sprung up, one that promises success for the Americans even as the war they have been fighting has veered dangerously close to defeat. Follow the religions tenets, give yourself over to it and the new faith will reward you with riches and fruits.

title: Chilean Miners, in Israel, Count Blessings Amid Media Glare
description: JERUSALEM  With revolts toppling governments across the Middle East and peace talks between Israelis and Palestinians suspended, 25 of the Chilean miners rescued after more than two months underground toured the holy sites of the Old City of Jerusalem on Thursday.

title: The Carpetbaggers 2011 Oscar Predictions
description: Melena Ryzik, aka the Carpetbagger, has spent three months following the news and nonsense of Hollywoods awards season. Now she uses all that knowledge to predict who will emerge victorious on Sunday night and why.

title: Coastal Carolina Struggles on Way to Tournament
description: CONWAY, S.C.  Coastal Carolina University has a bandbox gym that holds 999 fans, a remote location near Myrtle Beach and a funky nickname, the Chanticleers  the requisite trappings of a mens basketball darling. On the court, Coastal Carolina had the nations longest winning streak  22 games  and almost reached the top 25 this season.

title: When a Show Goes Down, a Poster Goes Up: Will Spider-Man Join Moose Murders?
description: By now, you probably know that Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark risks becoming to Broadway musicals what the Titanic was to ocean voyages. If things keep going the way they have, with previews constantly extended, Wal-Mart might open in New York before this $65 million show does.

title: Hoping to Lead Bank, Italian Faces Hurdles
description: ROME  He is a familiar face at the European Central Bank. Many economists think he should be the next person to run it.

title: China: Uighur Groups Criticize Death Sentences
description: Uighur advocacy groups have criticized the recent death sentences of four men who are all apparently ethnic Uighurs. The men were reportedly sentenced for three separate incidents of violence last year. They are Turhun Turdi, Abdulla Tunyaz, Ahunniyaz Nur, and Abdukerim Abdurahman. The report of the sentencing first appeared on Wednesday in Xinjiang Daily, an official newspaper published out of Urumqi, the capital of Xinjiang, a vast region in western China where Uighurs, the largest ethnic group there, chafe against policies set by the ethnic Han, who rule China.

title: Production of Two and Half Men Halted After Sheen Assails Creator
description: 11:33 p.m. | Updated  CBS and the television production studio Warner Brothers have decided to shut down production of the hit comedy Two and a Half Men, the companies said Thursday, after the shows star, Charlie Sheen, attacked the creator of the show, Chuck Lorre, in two incendiary interviews.

title: Bye-Bye, Happiness; Life Is a Trap
description: Frazer Bradshaws eerie, melancholy film Everything Strange and New captures a sensation that can suddenly overtake you: that everyday life is as weird as any piece of science fiction. If there are no aliens or spaceships to be seen, the strangeness consists of jolts of information and confusion that seem to arrive from out of the blue.

title: Motorola Xoom
description: David Pogue reviews a new tablet called Motorola Xoom, which is $800.

title: Leader of Teachers Union Urges Dismissal Overhaul
description: Responding to criticism that tenure gives even poor teachers a job for life, Randi Weingarten, the president of the American Federation of Teachers, announced a plan Thursday to overhaul how teachers are evaluated and dismissed.

title: Drilling for an Oil Crisis
description: Amherst, Mass.

title: Mediator in N.F.L. Talks Cites Strong Differences
description: INDIANAPOLIS  The federal mediator working with N.F.L. team owners and the players union said Thursday that very strong differences remain on the all-important core issues that separate the parties.

title: Three to a Bed, but No Funny Stuff
description: Heartbeats, a fluffy romantic souffl, is introduced by an epigraph from the French poet Alfred de Musset: The only truth is love beyond reason. Well, I suppose if youre as young and as besotted with cinematic dreams as Xavier Dolan, the 21-year-old Qubcois who wrote, directed and edited this film, and also served as its art director and costume designer, that slogan makes a crazy kind of sense.

title: Q.&A. With the Director of 'Inside Job'
description: DealBook's Andrew Ross Sorkin interviews Charles H. Ferguson, the director of the documentary 'Inside Job', about Wall Street's reaction to the film and his own views on the financial crisis.

title: Drug Raids Across U.S. Net Hundreds of Suspects
description: WASHINGTON  A little more than a week after an American law enforcement agent was shot to death by gunmen suspected of being drug traffickers in Mexico, federal authorities struck back Thursday with raids across the United States that rounded up more than 450 people believed to have ties to criminal organizations south of the border.

title: Suit Accuses F.B.I. of Spying at Mosques in California
description: At the Islamic Center of Irvine, some members look at each new person who walks into the Los Angeles-area mosque with suspicion. They worry that their conversations are being recorded or that law enforcement officers are watching, simply because they are Muslim.

title: After Expos, Filmmaker Sees Little Change on Wall Street
description: Will Wall Street win over Hollywood?

title: A Good Man: A Sideline in the Sex Industry
description: Theres nothing fancy about A Good Man, Safina Uberois rough-hewn profile of Chris Rohrlach, an Australian farmer with a sideline in the sex industry. But Ms. Uberois straight-shooting style is a perfect match for her salt-of-the-earth subject, a hard-working husband and father with more on his plate than most.

title: The Man Who Wont Be King
description: Dating Mark Zuckerberg, a few years before he guided a computer conceit into the most successful American company of this century, was like dating a Stairmaster.

title: In Cuba, Cigar Lovers Are a Lifeline
description: HAVANA  Simon Chase, a British sage of the cigar world, stood in an elegant hotel salon here on Wednesday before a select group of aficionados, scrutinizing a box of 1970s cigars for evidence of their proclaimed vintage.

title: Harvard and Princeton Restore Early Admission
description: Harvard and Princeton each announced Thursday that they would revive their early-admission programs, allowing high school seniors who apply by next Nov. 15 to get a decision by Dec. 15 without having to promise to attend the college if admitted.

title: Annotating Books
description: To the Editor:

title: Its Early, but Isringhausen Impresses Collins
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Jason Isringhausen continues to impress the Mets decision-makers, and if he keeps throwing the ball the way he has so far in camp, he has a strong chance to return to the Mets 12 years after he was traded away.

title: New Kidney Transplant Policy Would Favor Younger Patients
description: Younger patients would be more likely than older ones to get the best kidneys under a proposal being considered by the nations organ transplant network.

title: New York Medicaid Panel Backs Cuts
description: ALBANY  In an unexpected vote, a committee appointed by Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo to cut billions in health care spending approved on Thursday an annual spending cap and across-the-board reductions for all Medicaid providers.

title: Celtics Break Up Their Fantastic 5
description: When the Celtics lost to the Orlando Magic two seasons ago in the Eastern Conference semifinals, their coach, Doc Rivers, took comfort in a convenient yet accurate statement: no team had beaten Boston in the playoffs when its starting five  Rajon Rondo, Ray Allen, Paul Pierce, Kevin Garnett and Kendrick Perkins  was healthy. Garnett missed that series with a knee injury. The previous year, the Celtics won their 17th N.B.A. title.

title: The Redemption of a Racist
description: Responses to religious films are bound to be personal, so at the risk of sounding patronizing, Ill say that my main reaction to The Grace Card was one of pleasant surprise at its competence. Not because of its provenance in the filmmaking arm of a suburban Memphis Christian church, but because the director, David Evans, is an optometrist whose previous arts experience involved producing the churchs annual Easter passion plays.

title: Sanford C. Sigoloff, Corporate Turnaround Expert, Dies at 80
description: Sanford C. Sigoloff, a corporate turnaround expert who called himself the Skillful Scalpel as he sought to preserve the value in failing companies, died on Saturday at his home in Brentwood, Calif. He was 80.

title: Shared Sacrifice: A Sliding Scale?
description: To the Editor:

title: Nevada: Move to Curb Horse Population
description: Birth control for wild horses could soon expand. The federal Bureau of Land Management, which oversees about 36,000 wild horses on public lands  half of them in Nevada  said Thursday that it would quadruple the number of mares getting fertility treatment under a test with the National Academy of Sciences. The agency also plans to reduce numbers of animals removed from the herds, bolster tourism and create new avenues for people who want to adopt.

title: Journalists Tiptoe Inside Forbidding Libya
description: Despite threats by the embattled Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, journalists are finding ways to report and broadcast from parts of Libya, one of the least hospitable places in the world for news organizations.

title: Now in Brooklyn, Homegrown Tobacco: Local, Rebellious and Tax Free
description: The cigarettes Audrey Silk used to smoke  Parliament Lights  are made at a factory in Richmond, Va. The cigarettes she smokes these days are made and grown in Brooklyn, at her house.

title: Like Old Times
description: Lodged firmly in the You go granny! genre alongside wrinkled fluffery like Calendar Girls and the execrable Boynton Beach Club, The Over the Hill Band at least offers truth in advertising. Following three Belgian septuagenarians as they attempt to resurrect their singing group from half a century earlier, this drippy dramedy embraces every inappropriate-oldster clich with depressing calculation.

title: Trade Center Transit Hubs Cost Now Over $3.4 Billion
description: Four years ago, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey said a $3.4 billion price tag for its new transportation hub at the World Trade Center site would be simply unacceptable.

description: This article is by Motoko Rich, Catherine Rampell and David Streitfeld.

title: Shortstop of Future or Sooner at Second
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  If all goes well for the Mets this spring, Ruben Tejada will be the starting shortstop at Class AAA Buffalo. If it does not, Tejada might just be the Mets starting second baseman on opening day.

description: COLUMBUS, Ohio  When protesters descended this week to oppose a bill that would weaken collective bargaining for public workers, Elaine, a cashier at a Dollar Store in a crazy quilt of strip malls in southern Columbus, had little sympathy.

description: MARANA, Ariz.  When Ben Crane made quick work of Rory McIlroy on Thursday in the second round of the W.G.C.-Accenture Match Play Championship, eliminating him, 8 and 7, it was more than just a stunning upset.

title: Mideast Turmoil Is First Test for New G.M.
description: The Middle East is giving General Motors its first big test since it left the junkyard. As shares of G.M. hover at their November initial public offering price, investors are not forgetting what happened when oil prices surged last time around. When crude prices in the United States reached $100 a barrel in 2008  a level they returned to this week  G.M.s profit center in trucks and sport utility vehicles took a big hit.

title: Gay Marriage Seems to Wane as Conservative Issue
description: WASHINGTON  President Obamas decision to abandon his legal support for the Defense of Marriage Act has generated only mild rebukes from the Republicans hoping to succeed him in 2012, evidence of a shifting political climate in which social issues are being crowded out by economic concerns.

title: Scientists Are Cleared of Misuse of Data
description: An inquiry by a federal watchdog agency found no evidence that scientists at the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration manipulated climate data to buttress the evidence in support of global warming, officials said on Thursday.

description: Alexandria, Va., Feb. 25, 1861

title: Shock Doctrine, U.S.A.
description: Heres a thought: maybe Madison, Wis., isnt Cairo after all. Maybe its Baghdad  specifically, Baghdad in 2003, when the Bush administration put Iraq under the rule of officials chosen for loyalty and political reliability rather than experience and competence.

title: Cabbys Good Deed Makes Him a Hero Back Home
description: As public relations jobs go, selling a positive image of Sierra Leone has to be among the most challenging. Amid endemic corruption and widespread poverty, the small West African nation has struggled to recover from a decade of civil war that left tens of thousands dead and displaced millions  not exactly making it a place where investors are scrambling to park their money.

title: Stopping Qaddafi
description: Unless some way is found to stop him, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi of Libya will slaughter hundreds or even thousands of his own people in his desperation to hang on to power.

title: U.S. Trying to Pick Winners in New Mideast
description: WASHINGTON  As the Obama administration grapples with a cascade of uprisings in the Middle East, it has come to a stark recognition: the regions monarchs are likely to survive; its presidents are more likely to fall.

title: Population Off Sharply in St. Louis and Birmingham
description: ST. LOUIS  They call this the Gateway to the West, but for the past six decades that gateway has more resembled an exit, as this city, once the nations fourth largest, has lost roughly half a million people.

title: The Food Crisis
description: Food prices are soaring to record levels, threatening many developing countries with mass hunger and political instability. Finance ministers of the Group of 20 leading economies discussed the problem at a meeting in Paris last week, but for all of their expressed concern, most are already breaking their promises to help.

title: Menendez Gears Up for 2012 Senate Race, With Christie Looming as a Factor
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Robert Menendez of New Jersey spent the past two years as chairman of the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee, trying to help Senate colleagues around the country retain their seats.

title: Gov. Cuomos Friend
description: Gov. Andrew Cuomo of New York has promised zero tolerance of ethical lapses. His close ties with Jeffrey Sachs, a longtime friend and health care adviser, are raising questions about that commitment.

title: Stolen History
description: Last month, the National Archives banned an amateur historian who did what should have been unthinkable: He doctored the date on a valuable Lincoln document. Now the archives has found that it has a more widespread problem, with underhanded scholars and sneak thieves making off with American treasures to sell on the black market to history buffs.

title: In Anthony Trade, Dont Forget About M.V.P.
description: Greenburgh, N.Y.

title: Court Hears of Earlier Bid by L.I. Man to Die
description: An admitted hustler and drug addict, Melvin Fleming was panhandling for quarters in front of an East Harlem bodega in July 2009 when he got an unusually generous donation of $5.

title: In the Cradle of Libyas Uprising, the Rebels Learn to Govern Themselves
description: BENGHAZI, Libya  The rebels here said they caught a spy in the court building, the nerve center of the uprising, recording insurgent plans on a cellphone camera. The response was swift. Prosecutors interrogated the man on Thursday, and the rebels said they planned to detain him, for now.

title: Friday: Retro Style
description: FRIDAYS PUZZLE  Henry Hook has a reputation as the mad genius of puzzles, and rightly so. His wit and delightfully twisted themes are applauded by beginners and veteran solvers alike. Todays puzzle is not the most difficult Friday grid Ive ever solved, and the majority of clues are fairly straightforward compared with other Hook puzzles, but thats all right. Mr. Hooks personality shines through, and even on a themeless Friday, he manages to squeeze in a groaner of a mini-theme and some brilliant cluing.

title: Delias Puts Itself  Up for Sale
description: Delaney Parker wearing a dress from Delias last spring.

title: Love Thy Neighbor? Yeah, Right
description: Spend a few minutes  or even a few hours  wandering the halls of your average New York apartment building, and you are not likely to see much more eye-popping action than the collecting of newspapers, the wrangling of children into chunky strollers and the delicate dance of polite avoidance that most locals consider all that is required of neighborly intimacy.

title: Players Union Attempts to Keep TV Money From N.F.L.
description: MINNEAPOLIS  A week before the N.F.L.s collective bargaining agreement expires, a federal judge heard arguments Thursday on the players unions request to bar the league from using $4 billion in television revenue to finance its operations in the event of a lockout.

title: In Twist, Off Broadway Looms Larger for Hits
description: Any television executive knows that the big money is in reruns: Hit shows like Seinfeld and Star Trek keep raking it in long after the writers penned their last scripts. Now a group of theater producers is putting a twist on that business model, taking long-running Broadway hits and moving them Off Broadway to test if they can live on in rerun mode, where costs are lower and the profit potential is significant.

title: Afghan Officials Say Jailed Convert Is Free
description: Under international pressure, government officials in Kabul, Afghanistan, say they have freed an Afghan man who had been jailed since May and faced the prospect of the death penalty for converting from Islam to Christianity.

title: Nets Unveil New Cornerstone With Hopes of Keeping Him in Place
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  There were balloons to celebrate the arrival of Deron Williams in New Jersey on Thursday, and two giant photographs of him on either side of the dais that was being used for the welcoming news conference at the Nets practice facility.

title: Knicks Will Keep Looking for Help in the Frontcourt
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  On a frenetic final trading day in the N.B.A., the Knicks roster remained static. It had been jumbled enough for one week.

title: The Rebellion in Libya: A View From Italy
description: To the Editor:

title: GTT
description: Our quirky, discerning picks for

title: Nonteachers School Pay Under Scrutiny
description: Beaumont Independent School District is the 64th largest in Texas. It is also the home of the states highest-paid public school administrator. Superintendent Carrol A. Thomas takes home $ $346,778 annually  a fact that could soon put an uncomfortable spotlight on the community.

title: Unlikely Alderman Is Helped by an Unlikely Ally
description: James Warren is a columnist for the Chicago News Cooperative.

title: Some Baseball Stories Cant Be Told in Numbers
description: Jim Edmondss recent retirement announcement didnt draw much notice in Chicago, even though that unfailingly stylish center fielder was a Cub in 2008. Wrigleyville never took to him. The 19 home runs that Edmonds hit and the fielding gems he contributed to a division winner could not undo the damage he caused the Cubs over eight years of distinguished service to Tony La Russas hated Cardinals.

title: New Zealand Earthquakes Toll Continues to Mount
description: CHRISTCHURCH, New Zealand  Rescue crews on Friday pulled more bodies from the charred wreckage of a five-story office building that collapsed and caught fire during the earthquake on Tuesday, as officials warned residents to brace for a death toll that could eventually exceed 200.

title: Runoffs for Aldermen Pose First Test for Emanuel in Dealings With Council
description: After winning the mayoral election with a highly polished campaign that seemed more like a run for governor or president, Rahm Emanuel immediately turned his focus to the bare-knuckle, parochial world of Chicago ward politics.

title: Tumult Around the Region
description: LIBYA Rebels repelled a concerted assault by forces loyal to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi on cities close to Tripoli as Libyas patchwork of protests evolved into an increasingly well-armed revolutionary movement.

title: Rescuing 4 Children, but Struggling for Assistance
description: Last October, Theresa Coleman received a call from a child-welfare investigator. Four young children, distant family members, had been discovered in a Georgia motel room filled with drugs, alcohol, a half-loaf of bread, a half-jar of peanut butter and a dwindling supply of baby formula.

title: A Public Schools Coffers Require a Private Boost
description: Scott James is a columnist for The Bay Citizen.

title: 3 Musical Experimenters Forge Indie Success in Area
description: In todays fractured music industry, the definition of success has changed: cultivating devoted niche audiences means more than major label contracts. In the independent-minded Bay Area  where musicians have had difficulty finding financial rewards  some musicians are thriving in this do-it-yourself environment.

title: Pockets of Abundance in Distressed Areas
description: Walk down Post Street near Union Square in San Francisco  past the famed Gumps department store, the Prada boutique, De Beers and Saks Fifth Avenue  and you will probably think the area is economically vibrant.

title: Stars Align Better This Session for an Expansion of Gambling
description: Ross Ramsey, the managing editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column.

title: As Mental Health Cuts Mount, Psychiatric Cases Fill Jails
description: Dressed in an orange Harris County Jail-issued jumpsuit, Sterling Shepherd sat at a metal picnic table and described what got him into this situation  again.

title: Poynter Institute Faculty to Act as Ombudsmen for ESPN
description: After having three ombudsmen offer regular critiques of its journalistic content, ESPNs work will be scrutinized for the next 18 months by a faculty panel from the Poynter Institute.

title: Edwin Kilbourne, Flu Vaccine Expert, Dies at 90
description: Dr. Edwin D. Kilbourne, a medical researcher who figured out how to outwit fast-evolving flu germs, developing a new vaccine each year by intermingling genes of different disease strains, died Monday in Branford, Conn. He was 90.

title: Google Tweaks Algorithm to Push Down Low-Quality Sites
description: Updated  See our more complete article about this change.

title: Letters: Shaken
description: In the atmosphere of a possible murder inquiry (Emily Bazelon, Feb. 6), it may be almost impossible to establish the unvarnished truth. Even so, as noted in my 1971 report, Infantile Subdural Haematoma and Its Relationship to Whiplash Injuries, because shaking was regarded as an acceptable form of correction in the north of England (where I practiced), the police were only involved when there were other injuries. Forty years on, our standards are higher: I have watched with fascination how medical opinion has changed from denial to admission that infant abuse could and did happen there. As the lawyers say, Cases are decided not on the truth but on the evidence. With no fear of prosecution, my patients caregivers had no motive to lie. I stand by the conclusions of my 1971 paper  that there are occasions when violent shaking can cause severe or even fatal brain damage.

title: Word of the Day | effervescent
description: effervescent \e-fr-ve snt\ adjective

description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

description: Test your knowledge of history with todays question about a key event in boxing history.

title: All Cried Out, Lucia Cedes Emotion to Men
description: Deep in Act II of Donizettis opera Lucia di Lammermoor, the desperate and doomed title character, deserted by everyone she has trusted and about to be married against her will, cries out that even the ability to weep has left her. My own tears have abandoned me, she pathetically laments.

title: The Smell of Money
description: Tom Ford likes his ladies (and gents) to show more than a little skin, so its no surprise that he decided to expand his beauty franchise with the Neroli Portofino Collection, a sexy-smelling line of bath and body products that are meant to evoke the fragrant orange groves and jet-set lan of the Italian Mediterranean. (The leisurely scent of money, in other words.) Intended to be unisex  the ad campaign, shot by Ford, depicts a boy and girl getting down and dirty in the shower  the collection contains a moisturizer, shower gel, body oil (shown here; $70), body scrub and soap, and will be available April 1 at Bergdorf Goodman.

title: Look of the Moment | Samantha Cameron
description: The look: Tory Glory  favoring emerging talent, this ensemble gives new meaning to the words Rule Britannia!

title: Obama Changes Course on Marriage Law
description: WHO announced that the Obama administration intended to stop legally defending the Defense of Marriage Act?

title: Daily Lexeme: Jog-Trot
description: Todays word, in association with the excellent Oxford English Dictionary, is

title: When People Power Won the Philippines
description: As popular revolts rapidly depose or threaten one autocrat after the next, there could scarcely be a better time for Revolution Revisited, an exhibition of the work of Kim Komenich. But the timing of his show is not directly related to the convulsions in the Arab world. Instead, it is intended to mark the 25th anniversary of the people power revolt in the Philippines that brought an end to the regime of President Ferdinand E. Marcos and swept Corazon C. Aquino into power.

title: Korea Exchange Imposes Record Fine on Deutsche Unit
description: Korea Exchange said Friday that it had decided to impose a record fine of 1 billion won on the local subsidiary of Deutsche Bank for breaching the rules of the bourse during an enormous stock sell-off last November.

title: Demonstrations Turn Violent in Iraq
description: BAGHDAD  Iraqs day of rage on Friday ended with nearly 20 protesters killed in clashes with security forces. Dozens more were wounded, and several local government offices lay smoldering and ransacked.

title: Hundreds of Thousands Protest Across Mideast
description: CAIRO  Hundreds of thousands of protesters turned out in cities across the Middle East on Friday to protest the unaccountability of their leaders and express solidarity with the uprising in Libya that Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi is trying to suppress with force.

title: Would You Mind if Your Parents Blogged About You?
description: A Sunday Magazine article considers the mommy blogger phenomenon, focusing on the popular  and profitable  blog Dooce. What do you think about parents blogging about their family life? How would you feel if one of your parents were blogging about you?

title: American Idol': The Top 24
description: Stop crying, J.Lo: Chris Medina already has a single out in stores, months before anyone in this seasons Top 24 will.

title: American Ferry From Libya Arrives in Malta
description: VALLETTA, Malta  After a two-day wait in the Tripoli harbor followed by a rough eight-hour crossing, more than 300 evacuees from Libya landed here on Friday night on a high-speed ferry chartered by the United States government.

title: The Merits of For-Profit Colleges
description: Judith Scott-Clayton is an assistant professor at Teachers College, Columbia University.

title: Baroque Fun at Pragues Carnevale
description: The romance and mystery of a masked ball, Baroque soires, frolicking in the streets  it must be Carnival time in Prague. Carnevale Praha, 12 heady days of glam and mystique, begins on Feb. 25. Two fancy dress balls, a mask parade, Baroque music concerts, a childrens party and a food festival are just a few of the activities designed to liven up the gray winter of the city.

title: The Early Word: Balancing Acts
description: From Todays Times:

title: Julius Thomas, the Latest Basketball Tight End
description: Cecil Lammey, a senior staff writer for Footballguys.com and the NFL Insider for the Front Range Sports Network, is in Indianapolis for the scouting combine. You can follow him on Twitter @theaudible

title: Qaddafi Forces Violently Quell Capital Protest
description: TRIPOLI, Libya  Mercenaries and army forces put down an attempt by protesters on Friday to break Col. Muammar el-Qaddafis hold on this capital city, opening fire on crowds who had taken to the streets after prayers to mount their first major challenge to the governments crackdown, witnesses said.

title: Everyones an Athlete in Tokyo Marathon
description: OSAKA, Japan  Not long ago, to run a marathon in Japan all you had to do was sign up, show up and run your heart out. But nowadays, the greatest obstacle would-be marathoners face is no longer the course itself, but rather getting the chance to set foot on it.

title: The Future Tense
description: Eureka! That was the cry of the New York Times executive editor A. M. Rosenthal in early 1979, when he hit upon an idea for a new column to run in the front of the magazine. Rosenthal tapped William Safire, then a Pulitzer Prize-winning political columnist for The Times, to create a column exploring the vagaries of the English language. As Safire later recalled, Rosenthal figured the series could be sustained for a year, maybe.

title: Can Owning a Business Ever Be a Passive Investment?
description: One of the best things about my business is the variety of phone calls I get. My husband and I frequently look at each other at the office and say, I wonder whos going to call today. It could be a business owner we met three years ago who is ready to talk about selling, or perhaps a referral from an interesting or unexpected source. There is, however, one particular type of phone call that Ive come to dread  the ones from buyers who say they are looking for a business to buy as a passive investment.

title: China Telecom Giant, Thwarted in U.S. Deals, Seeks Inquiry to Clear Name
description: SHANGHAI  In a highly unusual move, Huawei Technologies, one of the most successful companies in China, has asked the United States to formally investigate its background in the hopes of clearing the companys path to expand and make deals in United States.

title: Answering Questions About Island Species
description: Chris Filardi of the American Museum of Natural History studied evolution and conservation in the Solomon Islands.

title: Ireland Winding Down 2 Banks With Deposit Shift
description: Ireland took a major step Thursday to bring the curtain down on two of its most troubled banks  Anglo Irish Bank and Irish Nationwide Building Society  by transferring 12.2 billion euros in deposits to two larger institutions.

title: Complaint Box | Lights! Camera! Leave?
description: Invasion of the Film Crews

title: Geneva Auto Show: BMW Vision ConnectedDrive Concept
description: More than 140 product debuts are planned for the Geneva auto show, which opens to the press on Tuesday. Before the gates open, Wheels is highlighting the Geneva standouts that have already broken cover online. Be sure to check back next Tuesday for news and photos from the convention floor.

title: Tough Cookies
description: We know that Sarah Palin hunts animals on reality TV and cheers her daughter on Dancing With the Stars  but do we know that both conservative and liberal scholars rate Nancy Pelosi as one of the most successful speakers of the House in United States history?

title: PCB Removal, With Zero Upfront
description: As I reported in Thursdays paper, New York City is allocating $708 million for an energy retrofit program in public schools over the next 10 years that is mostly spurred by the need to replace light fixtures containing the toxic chemicals known as PCBs. For some months, the cost issue was a major factor delaying this weeks decision to replace the lighting at nearly 800 schools.

title: Suzanne Somers, Cancer Expert
description: This week, Dateline on NBC devoted an entire hour on Sunday evening to allow the actress Suzanne Somers to express her rather unconventional beliefs about cancer.

title: Lots of Talk, but Still No 2012 Republican Candidates
description: Its been nearly four months since the day after the 2010 midterm elections  otherwise known as the unofficial start of the 2012 presidential campaign  but still, not one Republican candidate.

title: Friday Reading: Growing Your Own Tax-Free Cigarettes
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: Mitch Daniels Memories
description: These days, Mitch Daniels is being held up as an icon of fiscal responsibility. There are a lot of reasons to question his actual stewardship in Indiana; but what I cant forget is his key role in the squandering of the fiscal surplus Bush inherited. It wasnt just that he supported the Bush tax cuts; the excuses he made for that irresponsibility were stunningly fraudulent.

title: Rapes Are Again Reported in Eastern Congo
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  More than 40 people, including men, women and children, have been raped in the past two weeks in eastern Congo in roughly the same area as a series of rapes earlier this year, United Nations officials said on Friday.

title: Morning Take-Out
description: MERGERS & ACQUISITIONS

title: Small Is Beautiful
description: Dean Baker points us to Feyrer and Sacerdote, who use cross-state variation in stimulus spending per capita to estimate the employment effects of the stimulus. They find a clear positive effect: states that got more money per person did better on jobs. And as Baker points out, the national effects must have been larger, since some money spent in New Jersey presumably creates jobs in New York and vice versa.

title: A 19th-Century Cake, Guest Starring Caraway
description: My wife and I were in London recently, and on our way to an excellent exhibition at the Whitechapel Gallery, we stopped for coffee and a snack at St. John Bread and Wine. Options included a seed cake, something I had only seen referenced in 19th-century novels. The St. John version was so simple and delicious that I decided to try making it at home. (The recipe can be found in the St. Johns cookbook, Beyond Nose to Tail: More Omnivorous Recipes for the Adventurous Cook by Fergus Henderson and Justin Piers Gellatly, or on The Guardians Web site.

title: Model-Morphosis | Siri Tollerod at D&G
description: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of Milan Fashion Week. Here, the model Siri Tollerod before (left) and after (right) transforms, with makeup by Pat McGrath and hair by Sam McKnight. (Drag the orange bar left to reveal the full transformation.)

title: U.S. 4th-Quarter Growth Figure Is Lowered, Dimming Hopes for Jobs
description: Amid fears of an oil shock and a further slide in housing comes news that Americas economic recovery is weaker than previously thought.

title: Good Inflation, Bad Inflation
description: And another economistic piece: FTAlphaville reports that some people believe that surging commodity prices might be good for Japan, because they will make deflation go away.

title: Chinese Activists Continue Calls for Protests
description: BEIJING  Calls for China to emulate the Jasmine Revolution sweeping the Middle East and North Africa continue to reverberate in the countrys blogosphere, causing another popular Web site to be blocked temporarily and ensnaring the American ambassador, Jon M. Huntsman Jr.

title: A Netscape Founder Increases His Bet on Mobile
description: While top social Web companies like Facebook and Groupon are dominating the headlines, investor Marc Andreessen is increasing his bet on mobile.

title: Jury Nullification Advocate Is Indicted
description: Julian P. Heicklen sat silent and unresponsive as his bail hearing began one day recently in federal court in Manhattan; his eyes were closed, his head slumped forward.

title: Saudi Student to Be Arraigned in Bomb Plot
description: LUBBOCK, Tex.  A 20-year-old Saudi student appeared in federal court here on Friday, charged with trying to make bombs to be used in attacks on American targets, while federal agents sifted through electronic correspondence, telephone records and other material to see if there was evidence of a wider conspiracy.

title: Milan Fashion Week | Escaping La Moda
description: There are plenty of reasons to venture off Milans fashion week treadmill. For starters, dozens of outstanding museums dot the city, including the new Museo del Novecento (Palazzo dellArengario), which opened in December. The collection of mainly Italian painting and sculpture  like Pirandello and Morandi  occupies the Palazzo dellArengario, which was gutted to make room for a giant white spiral ramp that feeds into linear white gallery spaces. Attached is the instant hot-spot, Ristorante Giacomo allArengario. If you can get a table, I applaud you.

title: Pssst! Corolla, You Have a Stalker
description: IVE long thought that General Motors shaky public image could be traced to car rental lots. Thats where unsuspecting travelers and their Disney-loving children were introduced to G.M.s weakest models: its small cars. These were the companys crummy diet crackers, helping to keep its corporate fuel economy average below federal limits.

title: In Film, Stuttering Symptoms Reflect Current Research
description: In the Oscar-nominated movie The Kings Speech, King George VI begins stuttering at 4 and struggles with it throughout his life. But he rarely talks like the stereotypical stutterer, Porky Pig, rapidly repeating letter sounds; usually the king has trouble getting sounds out from the get-go, blocked by sputtering pauses.

title: The Lady Is a Champ: Eliza Dushku Goes a Few Rounds With Fight Night Champion
description: On television series like Buffy and Dollhouse, Eliza Dushku was perfectly comfortable holding her own against tough guys, and maybe throwing a punch or two when the situation required it. So her next role is a bit of a departure, and not only because she isnt called upon to swing her fists. In the boxing video game Fight Night Champion, which EA Sports will release for the Xbox 360 and PlayStation3 consoles on Tuesday, Ms. Dushku plays the daughter of an unscrupulous fight promoter, and finds herself drawn into an intrigue involving her father and an up-and-coming boxer (played by the actor and athlete LaMonica Garrett). The story, which is told in movie-style sequences that unfold between the games playable boxing matches, is written by Will Rokos, an Academy Award-nominated writer and producer of Monsters Ball, and represents the latest effort to bridge the worlds of gaming and cinema. These sequences (which were created using 3-D motion-capture technology) also allowed Ms. Dushku to play a character who was very much herself and yet as unearthly as anything seen on a Joss Whedon show.

title: College Costs Arent the Main Problem
description: 3:46 p.m. | Updated to correct list of defunct companies.

title: How to Throw Punches Without Getting Hurt
description: THE explosive and angst-ridden writhing, jerking and lunging that Steven Hoggett choreographed for the musical American Idiot is hardly typical of Broadway dancing, and to some theatergoers (including, apparently, the Tony voters last season) the approach was not necessarily impressive. Still, the merit of the movement there and in most shows is ultimately a matter of taste. Sometimes, though, the choreography in a show can be just plain incorrect.

title: Air Forces Shifting Rules Helped Boeing
description: When a European company offered a larger tanker than Boeing for a lower price in 2008, the Air Force grabbed what seemed like a bargain.

title: Prodigy Ages Into a Merely Young Conductor
description: LONDON

title: Feb. 27  Mar. 5
description: Dance

title: 2011 Chevrolet Cruze
description: The Cruze offers a solid and composed feel, but leaves a somewhat generic impression.

title: If You Want 40 M.P.G., Youll Shift for Yourself
description: FOR the last few years, if you wanted a car that went more than 40 miles on a gallon of fuel, you had few choices behind hybrids and small diesels. Among purely gasoline-powered models, only the Smart Fortwo  a doorstop-size two-seater  carried a federal highway mileage rating above 40 m.p.g.

title: Feb. 25: Updates on Libyas Revolt and Mideast Protests
description: On Friday, The Lede is following the uprising in Libya and protests in Egypt, Yemen, Bahrain, Iraq and the West Bank. Updates below mix alerts on breaking news with reports from bloggers and journalists on the ground. A stream of Twitter messages from the region is in this blogs right column.

title: A Figure of Speech
description: Your film, The Kids Are All Right, is nominated for four Academy Awards, including Best Picture and Best Original Screenplay for you and Stuart Blumberg. So what are you going to wear?  Were in between some really couture dress and some sexy kind of 70s-era Bianca Jagger type tux that a designer friend of mine is making. I was complaining to the stylist whom Im working with, and I said  God, I feel like Im ramping up for my gay wedding, all this wondering what to wear.

title: Living Singles
description: Long-form journalism is the only homegrown American literary form. Im talking about the kind of journalism that, in an effort by writers to conceal how radically theyre blurring the fact-fiction line, is innocently labeled narrative nonfiction in journalism schools and M.F.A. programs. Narrative nonfiction typically conforms to the artfully narrow standards of American fact checking (another indigenous art) while enjoying what Dwight Macdonald once called the atmospheric license of fiction. Some of the most beautiful and illuminating writing in all of American English is narrative nonfiction.

title: Nice Girls
description: My daughter Kate loves horses, her violin and, above all else, her friends. She also happens to have been born with dwarfism, a condition that makes her smaller than other kids. She will always be smaller. Kates fine with that. She doesnt give it much thought, really. But Ive become increasingly full of dread that her generation of mean girls will eventually stop accepting her for who she is, seize upon her obvious difference and just destroy her.

title: Goodbye
description: I loved this job, especially the interaction with the readers. I admired the moral seriousness of their questions and the astuteness of their criticism  often fierce, occasionally discourteous, never sufficiently threatening to report to the police. But close. And thats fine. Ethics is a subject about which honorable people may differ. I was less sanguine about readers who disparaged not my argument but my character or my shoes or my nose, attacks that generally concluded, You should be ashamed. I blame the anonymity of e-mail. And underprescribed medication.

title: A Small Compromise in Californias Water Wars
description: Like an early spring bud poking out of a thicket, a compromise emerged on Thursday in one of the intertwined legal battles that pit Californias major agricultural and urban water users against federal scientists and environmentalists. For the moment, both sides agree on how to protect the endangered delta smelt while managing water deliveries through the West Coasts largest and most degraded estuary, the delta where the Sacramento and San Joaquin rivers meet.

title: Deciphering M.P.G.: The Meaning of 35.5
description: FOR all the talk of the indignities meted out by this cold, wet winter, there are few indications that anyone is actually doing something about the weather.

title: Fact-Free Science
description: President Obama has made scientific innovation the cornerstone of his plans for winning the future, requesting in his recent budget proposal large financing increases for scientific research and education and, in particular, sustained attention to developing alternative energy sources and technologies. This is our generations Sputnik moment, he declared in his State of the Union address last month.

title: One More Way to Tell A Guzzler From a Sipper
description: WHAT is the best way to measure how efficiently a car turns fuel into distance? It seems a vital question, but like food, music and the cultural importance of Jerry Lewis, the answer varies all over the world.

title: Letter: The Ethicist
description: Randy Cohen is much too mild in his criticism of the medical students who are posting photos of patients with comical conditions. Besides being sadly lacking in empathy, these people are putting their medical schools at risk of federal intervention, including censure and fines, for their violation of federal regulations regarding patient privacy. Expulsion might seem harsh to some but would certainly send the message that respect for patients is the cornerstone of all medical care.

title: Letter: Consumed
description: Enjoying collections as digital presentations without the clutter of stuff: this was the ultimate essay from Rob Walker. In light of all the recent economic upheaval, the arrangement and enjoyment of a variety of items we use everyday, virtual or not, seems like a refreshing approach. If we can have virtual friends and relationships, why not virtual possessions, all neatly stored in a small notebook computer on our desk (or lap). Ah, technology!

title: Letters: A Separate Peace
description: My unequivocal response to Bernard Avishais most illuminating article is the Hebrew: halvai  may it be. According to records of negotiations conducted between the former prime minister of Israel, Ehud Olmert, and the president of the Palestinian Authority, Mahmoud Abbas, more than anyone knew or imagined was accomplished vis--vis the most prolonged, seemingly intractable Palestinian-Israeli conflict, and although a great deal is still left to iron out, it proves that if there is a genuine will on both sides, it can be done and, as the author maintains, now is the time.

title: Franco and Hathaway Continue the Big Tease
description: LOS ANGELES The Bagger was busy compiling our Oscar predictions yesterday, and amazingly, the Internet did not stop without us. Anne Hathaway and James Franco continued to dole out clips that tease at what they will be doing when they host the show  heres Ms. Hathaway performing an awkward mash-up of Dont Cry for Me, Argentina and Rump-Shaker and the two of them in a hazy Grease montage, Mr. Franco also started a Twitter back-and-forth with Cher when he posted a clip of himself (badly) singing You Havent Seen the Last of Me, her song from Burlesque, which he said was cut from the telecast. (If its true, this is a blessing.) For her part, Cher wrote that she would miss singing at the Oscars.

title: Shrinking Government
description: One big reason the economy is struggling: the shrinking of state and local government.

title: The Super Comes Out of the Basement
description: GREGORY CAPIZZI is a successful New Yorker. He lives in a luxury condominium in the financial district, has a degree in mechanical engineering from the University of Hartford and drives a Mercedes.

title: John Galliano Suspended from Dior
description: John Galliano, the chief designer at Christian Dior since 1996, has been suspended from his duties at the fashion house after he was arrested for allegedly assaulting a woman and making anti-Semitic remarks at an outdoor Paris caf last night.

title: So Many Cars, So Little Time
description: GENEVA

title: Wisconsin Bill Advances, Then Stalls
description: MADISON, Wis.  The State Assembly approved a bill Friday to limit the collective bargaining rights for most public workers, but the measure stalled because Senate Democrats remained out of the state as part of an effort to derail the legislation.

title: Kennedy International Airport, 6:28 A.M.
description: Gregg Breinberg, the choral director at Public School 22 on Staten Island, chaperoned his students on a trip to Los Angeles, where they will perform at the Academy Awards ceremony on Sunday.

title: What Were Reading
description: An aggregation of links by the reporters and editors of Diners Journal.

title: In the Society of Dead Masons
description: WHEN late-winter temperatures break 32, the Park Avenue railroad viaduct calls to mind a weeping statue of a saint, teardrops of meltwater dripping from the battered stone along the massive walls, which extend from 98th to 111th Street. And the strange series of letters and symbols running all the way along the 1875 structure is just as otherworldly  as mysterious as messages from another planet.

title: U.S. Imposes Sanctions on Libya in Wake of Crackdown
description: WASHINGTON  The United States closed its embassy in Tripoli on Friday and imposed unilateral sanctions against Libya, including the freezing of billions in government assets, as the Obama administration made its most aggressive move against Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi since his security forces opened fire on protesters.

title: New Developments Rolling Out Fitness-Based Amenities
description: AS the citys real estate market continues to thaw, fitness-based amenities are once again being used to draw buyers to new condominium developments. But this time around, the clang of weight machines and the whirr of treadmills are giving way to the thumps of basketballs and the grunts of climbers on indoor walls.

title: Habitats | Brooklyn Heights
description: Catherine Fitzsimons, a landscape designer, lives in a cozy duplex in Brooklyn Heights.

title: Diors John Galliano Suspended for Alleged Comments
description: Christian Dior said this afternoon that it had suspended the designer John Galliano pending an investigation into anti-Semitic remarks he allegedly made on Thursday night in Paris.

title: Scorecard Update | Prada
description: Designer: Miuccia PradaDate and Location: Thursday, Feb. 24, Via Fogazzaro, 36Photos: slide show | video

title: The Almost Landless Gardener
description: THE cobblestone part of Joralemon Street is among the loveliest stretches of Brooklyn Heights. Come spring, and well into the fall, the front gardens of the brownstones that line the street will be lush with greenery, and the window boxes will explode with flowers. But even on this beautiful strip, the low-slung red brick building just off Hicks Street stands out.

title: Path to B.Y.U. Stardom Began in Upstate New York
description: PROVO, Utah  From the straight-to-YouTube 3-pointers to an endless reel of highlight shows to knockoff T-shirts, Jimmer Mania has spread across the country. But it is hard to pinpoint the moment when Brigham Youngs Jimmer Fredette transformed from basketball star to national sensation, from fan favorite to cult hero, from boy next door to phenomenon.

title: Smaller Government Can Be a Drag (on Growth)
description: My colleagues Motoko Rich and David Streitfeld and I had an article today focusing on how rising oil prices are threatening Americas fragile economic recovery. But we could just have easily written another 1,000 words on the perils shrinking governments now present to the economy.

title: Southern Pride, of a Kind
description: WHEN Jennifer Aziz told her father she was thinking of buying an apartment on East 29th Street near Park Avenue South, he was worried. As Ms. Aziz recalls it, his concern went beyond the standard fatherly protectiveness. As a rug dealer, he had owned a store decades ago in the commercial district south of Midtown Manhattan, which he remembered as it had been then: drably commercial, dead at night and a little seedy.

title: ABC Promotes Nightline Producer to Good Morning America
