description: ABC News wants to go aggressively after the long dominance of NBCs Today show in the mornings.

title: The Flakes That Never Managed to Fall
description: SAN FRANCISCO  With a Pacific storm coinciding with a blast of cold Canadian air over their fair city, residents here spent much of Friday in giddy anticipation of a long-absent guest: snow.

title: Engine Stalling Prompts Investigation of Toyota Highlander Hybrid
description: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration has begun investigating inverter failures on the hybrid systems of nearly 44,000 Toyota Highlander S.U.V.s from the 2006 model year. The agency said it had received 32 complaints of engine stalling, but no reports of accidents.

title: When Statistics Dont Tell the Whole Story
description: In a recent article from the Chicago News Cooperative, Dan McGrath writes about Jim Edmonds as an example of a player where statistics fail to tell a complete story of a player. Edmonds, known for his dazzling catches that helped him win eight gold gloves, retired from baseball last week after 17 seasons. McGrath writes:

title: London Theater Journal: Punished by Fame
description: LONDON  Fame kills. Or at the very least, it would appear, it destroys your health, your love life, your family and your sanity. The wages of celebrity are being assessed all over this city in productions that should give weighty pause to those who would be stars.

title: Photos of the Moment | Etro
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#986", 592, 440, true, chameleonData);

title: Rough Boys
description: One Saturday night in the mid-70s, I stood on the deck of a shabby duplex watching my teenage boyfriend  a character who could have walked out of the pages of Andre Dubus IIIs powerful new memoir, Townie  beat another boy senseless in the parking lot below. Under the yellowish dusk-to-dawn lights, I could see my boyfriends blond sideburns, denim jacket and dingo boots, and I could see him punch the boy in the stomach until he crumpled to the ground, then kick him over and over until his nose and lips were split and bleeding. In Townie, which details Dubuss 1970s coming-of-age in the poor mill towns of Massachusetts, there are none of the usual signifiers of todays 70s Nostalgia Industrial Complex, no peace-sign key chains or smiley-face T-shirts, none of the goofy stoners and ditsy girls in tube tops that American television viewers have become accustomed to on That 70s Show. Instead, Dubus writes about the apartments where his older sister buys drugs, two rows of three-story buildings surrounded by packed dirt worn smooth, a Dumpster in back always filled with dirty diapers, used condoms and pizza boxes. He writes about an early manifestation of Fight Club culture at his school, where, whenever there is a fight, boys and girls rush to one spot like they were being pulled there by the air itself. . . . Kids were yelling: Kill him! Kill him!

title: Up Front: Darcey Steinke
description: Darcey Steinke opens her review of Townie, Andre Dubus IIIs memoir of street violence, remembering a beating her long-ago boyfriend delivered to another boy.

title: New Senators Goals May Be Shaped by Their Styles
description: WASHINGTON  After another quiet appearance on the Senate floor, Senator Marco Rubio, the heralded freshman Republican from Florida, quickly made his way back to his office, avoiding eye contact with a phalanx of reporters in the Capitol basement.

title: Alexei Kovalev Returns to Pittsburgh
description: Alexei Kovalev has returned to Pittsburgh in a trade that brought happiness to fans of the Penguins and the Ottawa Senators.

title: Tip of the Week: Customizing iTunes Playlists
description: Want to sort your iTunes music collection in different ways, like by file size, year of release or equalizer setting? If the iTunes song-list window only shows you basic information like time, artist and album name, you can customize your criteria by adding fields with the Options box.

title: The Selby | Juice Press
description: Its not even a year old, but the Juice Press in the East Village of Manhattan has gained a cult following among celebrities. Marcus Antebi, one of the owners, delivers a raw-food diet of salads, entrees, juices and smoothies, guaranteed to sluice the most stopped-up systems. Slide Show | Related Article: Spring Cleaning, by Sandra Ballentine

title: This Weekends Top Soccer Matchups
description: Saturday

title: A.I.G. Chief on First Earnings Call: It Was O.K.
description: Robert H. Benmosche, the chief executive of the American International Group, is known for being blunt.

title: Arts Czars
description: Solomon VOLKOV loves his czars. And in Romanov Riches he pays homage to them as patrons of the arts and apostles of power, sweeping the reader across 300 years of Russian history from the accession of Czar Mikhail in 1613 to the violent collapse of the imperial world in 1917. On this whirlwind tour, Volkov visits many of the major landmarks and personalities: the archpriest Avvakum Petrov, Lermontov and Gogol; Herzen, Tolstoy and the Womens Issue; Tchaikovsky and homosexuality; Dostoyevsky, Mussorgsky and Lenin. Volkovs focus is on power: every artist has his czar.

title: Goldmans Ruzika to Retire
description: Richard Ruzika, the influential Goldman Sachs executive who runs the firms special situations group, is retiring from the Wall Street bank, according to a memo sent last week to employees.

title: And the Award for Best Dictator Goes To
description: .entry-content table th { font-size: 10px!important;}.entry-content table td { padding: 5px 3px 5px 0px!important;}.entry-content table td.xl36,.entry-content table td.xl41 {text-align: center!important;}.entry-content table td.xl58 {text-align: center!important;font-weight: bold;}table.nate-details tr th {text-align: center!important;}table.nate-details tr.weightings td {font-style: italic!important;}

title: Shades of White
description: Racial passing is one of Americas deeply hidden traditions, a largely unacknowledged and unstudied aspect of national life. Historically, African-Americans with identifiably dark skin have had only two choices when confronting racial discrimination and oppression: either they could try to ease their burden through accommodation, making the best of a bad situation, or they could engage in protest and active resistance. The situation was often quite different, however, for light-skinned African-Americans of mixed parentage. For them, there was a tempting third option of trying to pass as white.

title: Defining a Family
description: Over on The New York Timess The Learning Network blog, students are weighing in on the question How Do You Define Family?, a response to our discussion here on Motherlode about normal families earlier this week.

title: Big Deal | Pinchas Zukerman Buys West Side Condo
description: Pinchas Zukerman, who is considered one of the worlds greatest violinists, has definite opinions about investing. He likes to buy musical instruments and real estate.

title: Graphic Books Best Sellers: When Lightning Strikes
description: This may very well be the year of the Flash. The resurrected hero hits the hardcover list at No. 2 with The Dastardly Death of the Rogues, the first collected edition of his new ongoing series. The scarlet speedster will also be at the center of Flashpoint, the next event storyline from DC Comics. The hardcover edition, and the upcoming Flashpoint series, are both written by Geoff Johns, who pushed Green Lantern to new heights and garnered critical acclaim for Blackest Night, DCs last major event.

title: Consumers Hold On to Products Longer
description: Throw away the cellphone after two years? Not so fast. Ditch the flat-panel TV for an even thinner model? Maybe next year. Replace the blouse with the hole? Darn it!

title: The Critics on All-Time Classics and Foreign Films
description: Manohla Dargis and A.O. Scott, the co-chief film critics of The New York Times, are answering Oscar-related questions this week, as they kick off what will be a monthly fixture in print and online. (Previous installments can be found here and here.) For future columns, they would like to hear from you about whatever movie-related subject piques your curiosity: individual films, industry trends, historical trivia. Write to them at askthefilmcritics@nytimes.com.

title: What Were Reading: 25 Guys to Avoid on Wall Street
Paths of Glory
description: An indelible scene from the life of Alexander the Great finds the prodigious warrior-king  just 25 years old in 330 B.C.  and his conquering army on a stretch of R&R at Persepolis, one of Persias great capitals, now marked out for plunder. During a drunken revel characteristic of the rough Macedonian court, an Athenian woman named Thais, the mistress of one of the high officers present, made a startling suggestion. It would be a fine thing, she said, if with her own hands and with Alexander looking on, she set fire to the palace built by King Xerxes, who a century and a half earlier had reduced her home city to ashes, that it might be recorded to posterity that the women who followed Alexander had taken a severer revenge on the Persians for the sufferings and affronts of Greece, than all the famed commanders had been able to do by sea or land.

title: Battlefields of New York
description: To the Editor:

title: Only One Right Answer
description: To the Editor:

title: Bobby Fischers Endgame
description: To the Editor:

title: Inside the Lists
description: To the Editor:

title: The Wanderer
description: I dont believe in coming clean, Bruce Chatwin once told Paul Theroux, who had suggested that Chatwins travel writing could benefit from more detail about how he got from one place to the next. During his brief literary career, readers usually sensed that Chatwin was hiding as much about himself as he displayed. Half the story appeared to reside in the white spaces between bejewelled little sections of narrative.

title: Growing Up Fast
description: Alison Espachs first novel opens, brightly and winningly, at a cocktail party in Fairfield, Conn., on a steamy summer evening in the early 1990s, in a garden crowded with tiger lilies. Emily Vidals father, Victor, an investment banker, is celebrating his 50th birthday. Most visible, among the hundreds of guests: Victors angry and acerbic wife, Gloria, and Victors mistress, Mrs. Resnick, who lives next door with her reclusive husband. Also a birthday cake, meant to resemble Victor, that looks alarmingly like Bill Clinton.

title: Stormy Weather
description: Like Eddie (Rochester) Anderson in Cabin in the Sky, the 1943 movie-musical parable of temptation, most Americans seem constitutionally predisposed to choose Lena Horne over Ethel Waters  that is, to prefer a model of classical beauty, sex appeal, excitement and youth to a symbol of matronly stolidity, virtue and middle-age languor. Anderson comes around to Waters, of course, when a team of celestial Simon Cowells repackages her to show that the old lady still has loads of talent, vigor and carnality in reserve. Nearly 70 years later, American culture has grown so absorbed with beauty and youthfulness that the films vindication of ability over appearance, depth and experience over novelty and thrills, seems even more wishfully fantastical than it was in 1943. Meanwhile, the movies top-billed star, Ethel Waters, has been nearly forgotten by all but enthusiasts of music and movie history.

title: Suddenly Susan
description: When the author shacked up with Susan Sontags son, and his brainy mom, in 1976, three was not company.

title: One Designers Love: Vintage Trailers
description: LOLITA, light of my life, fire of my loins.

title: Becoming Ottoman
description: The promising opening chapters of Michael David Lukass first novel, The Oracle of Stamboul, have many of the appealing features of a fairy tale. A girl of unusual gifts is born in fulfillment of a prophecy, and after her mother dies giving birth, she is raised by a loving but weak-willed father and an oppressive stepmother, while a mysterious flock of birds follows her wherever she goes. But the girl, Eleonora Cohen, is also a Jew born into a specific historical context  the Ottoman Empire in the late-19th century  and on the day of her birth in 1877, her hometown, the Romanian port of Constanta on the Black Sea, is sacked by the Russian cavalry. This juxtaposition of fable and brute history tells us right from the start that were in the realm of magic realism, and the storys tension, or lack thereof, between magic and realism is an indication of both the ambition and the shortcomings of this ultimately frustrating novel.

title: These Crowded Streets
description: The very first words in Open City, an indelible debut novel by Teju Cole, imply an inevitability, connecting the narrators past with his present task, that of explaining his place in the world: And so, his narrator, Julius, says, when I began to go on evening walks last fall, I found Morningside Heights an easy place from which to set out into the city.

title: Inky Depths
description: Portland, Ore., is wet from the start of The Night Season. A storm has soaked the city for weeks. Gulls line the roads, blown inland from the sea. The Willamette River surges with debris. Rain cascades from rooftops and clogs the basement drains of the Multnomah County morgue. This Portland is much like the one in Chelsea Cains previous novels, but darker, blurred around the edges and sunk under a cloud cover that threatens to engulf it completely.

title: The Company He Keeps
description: Ask not what John Wells can do for your country. Seriously, dont ask. Even if you found this former C.I.A. operative in a chatty mood, his answers might leave you feeling uneasy. Hes the sort of guy who borrows civilians cars with all the hesitation of a teenage shoplifter, wholl club the skull of a useful drug dealer whos already comfortably trussed in the back of an Econoline. When a beefy thug on a pier in Cyprus dismisses him with an ostentatious yawn, Wells quickly takes him to task, dumping him into Zygi's oily harbor. And these are just the tales he could actually tell. The ones he couldnt  now those are scary.

title: With or Without You
description: One of literatures most seductive questions was asked by the Hungarian novelist Sandor Marai in Embers, his exquisite novel of friendship and betrayal, published in Budapest in 1942, but not translated into English until 2001, 12 years after his death. Do you want it to be the way it used to be? a woman asks a man. Yes, he responds.Exactly the same. The way it was last time. This exchange occurs not between lovers but between a 91-year-old servant and the 75-year-old general she nursed as a baby, in whose household she has remained. The general wants her to set up the dining room just as it looked at his lifes most critical juncture, 41 years earlier, when the closest, most sacred friendship of his youth came to an end.

title: White Light
description: In the first pages of The Illumination, Kevin Brockmeiers elegantly written new novel, a lonely character named Carol Ann Page receives a spite package from her ex-husband. The box is covered in tape, the kind fretted with hundreds of white threads, and as Carol Ann attempts to cut through it, she slips and nearly lops off her thumb. Hours later, she wakes from reattachment surgery to find her sutures blazing with a bright white light.

title: Mosh Pit Diplomacy
description: The would-be foreign policy prodigy Parag Khanna made a splash with his first book, The Second World, in 2008, by announcing with great fanfare  including a lengthy adaptation in The New York Times Magazine  what everyone already knew: that the international order was changing. The book was Khannas version of the fall of the West and the rise of the rest. Having described this grave new world, Khanna now wants to tell us how to run it. The result is another easy, breezy book that dispenses platitudes as though they were original insights and in the process fails to examine their actual significance.

title: Untamable Tongue
description: Does anyone at all understand anything about a story that is not their own? asks Kadir, one of the primary characters in Jonas Hassen Khemiris Montecore: The Silence of the Tiger. Its an apt question in any novel, but particularly so in this one, which is told in two voices, a generation and the distance (literal, social, linguistic) from Tunisia to Sweden separating them. Khemiri offers familiar if not simple emotional territory, a story about a son and his estranged father  complicated by questions of culture and language, racism and violence, metafiction and postmodernity, formal conceit and constraint.

title: It Gets Worse
description: Susan Jacoby has long made it her project to uncover ill-formed, cynical junk thought and administer a cold dose of reason and logic against it. But Jacoby is no Mr. Spock. Her rationalism is delivered in an angry barrage peppered with enthusiastically snide asides. In previous books, including The Age of American Unreason and Freethinkers, her targets have been right-leaning religionists, social Darwinists, and the paucity of reason in a generation that stares too much at glowing screens and too little at learned books. In her latest jeremiad, Never Say Die, she fights to slay the conspiracies of ignorance and greed that she believes conceal a single, and indeed irrefutable, truth: extreme old age can be nasty, brutish and long.

title: Behind Every King
description: Woman was never born to rule. Medieval man never doubted that simple proposition. Neither did the 15th- and 16th-century men whose deplorably low opinion of uppity women helps provide Helen Castor, an accomplished and elegant historian, with a framework for her third book.

title: Womens Team Gives North Dakota a New Reason to Cheer
description: GRAND FORKS, N.D.  Leveraging another teams history as a recruiting tool instead of your own requires just the right touch. For Brian Idalski, coach of the suddenly successful North Dakota womens hockey team, it also involves a little show and tell.

title: Steak-Eaters
description: Name given to a group of red-blooded Academy Awards voters who generally favour epic movies.

title: A Mother-in-Law With Hands-On Experience
description: ACQUIRING a mother-in-law later in life is different from acquiring one at 22.

title: What an N.H.L. Trade Call Might Sound Like
description: Have you ever wondered whats involved in reporting a trade to the N.H.L. head office? Many fans have heard about the league trade calls that must be completed before any deal is official. You may even have imagined what those calls could be like, with harried general mangers making impassioned pleas into their phones until league executives agree to give their stamp of approval.

title: Daniels Sorts Out Trade and Injury Treatment
description: The former Celtics swingman Marquis Daniels is finding life to be a bumpy ride these days. He was traded by the Celtics to the Kings for cash and a 2017 second-round draft pick before the deadline. More pressing, Daniels needs to figure out the best way to overcome his bruised spinal cord.

title: Protests Draw Hundreds of Thousands Across Middle East
description: Demonstrations in Libya and Iraq were met with violence, while those in Bahrain, Yemen, Jordan and Egypt were mostly peaceful.

title: Inside the List
description: BLOOD SIMPLE: By day, Deborah Harkness is a highly regarded historian of 17th-century science and proprietor of the award-winning blog Good Wine Under $20. By night, shes a crazed vampire compiling tasting notes on the blood of graduate students  or so her first novel, A Discovery of Witches, might lead you to believe. The story of an American academic who finds a magic book (and some Chteau dYquem-soaked hot paranormal romance) in the stacks of Oxfords Bodleian Library, Discovery notches its second week at No. 2 on the hardcover fiction list. Thats an impressive showing for a writer whose previous book, The Jewel House: Elizabethan London and the Scientific Revolution, had an initial print run in the mid-four figures.

title: Lipstick on Her Collar? Men Say, O.K.
description: THE GIST A man minds less when a woman cheats on him with another woman than with another man.

title: The Real Housewife of Paris
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#528", 592, 490, true, chameleonData);

title: Tahrir Square, Egypts Newest Tourist Draw
description: LAST October, on my final day in Cairo after a yearlong stay, I walked across the Kasr el-Nil Bridge toward Tahrir Square, stopping for a moment to take in the view. Though the Nile was, as always, a lovely sight, it was still hard to ignore the broken glass and cigarette butts beneath my feet, and the tired, worn faces of the young Egyptians standing near me.

title: Overshadowed, an Ex-Models Gruesome Death
description: Every elevator should be so clean.

title: Safety: Wound Care May Matter More Than Antibiotics
description: Preventing infection in a wound may depend less on choosing the right antibiotic than on simply keeping it clean.

title: How to Appear in the World Series (Without Actually Playing)
description: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz. - Im a baseball nerd, always have been, with a special fixation on postseason statistics. I love how a postseason series lasts only a few games, but it gets its own line in your statistical profile, forever.

title: Haila Stoddard, Actress and Theatrical Producer, Dies at 97
description: Haila Stoddard, an actress who had a long career on the stage and on television and who as a producer brought the works of Nol Coward, James Thurber and Harold Pinter to Broadway, died Monday at her home in Weston, Conn. She was 97.

title: Editors Choice
description: A WIDOWS STORY: A Memoir,  by Joyce Carol Oates (Ecco/HarperCollins, $27.99.) The prolific author has assembled a book more painfully self-revelatory that anything Oates the fiction writer or critic has ever dared to produce.

title: Paperback Row
description: THE MYTH OF THE RATIONAL MARKET: A History of Risk, Reward, and Delusion on Wall Street,  by Justin Fox (Harper Business, $16.99.) Instead of emphasizing the errors and abuses of bankers in the 2008 financial crisis, Fox, a former business and economics columnist for Time magazine, zeroes in on the academics whose efficient-market theories enabled those abuses.

title: Troubled Spirit
description: Andrew Taylor has written almost every kind of genre fiction, from village mysteries to psychological thrillers. But his mandarin style and eccentric imagination seem best suited to the historical crime novel. An Unpardonable Crime was a cunning facsimile of a 19th-century Gothic melodrama. Bleeding Heart Square caught the swoony sensationalism of a 1930s womens romance. Now THE ANATOMY OF GHOSTS (Hyperion, $24.99) pitches us into dynamic but rowdy 18th-century England, when superstition still held a grip on rational minds despite the advent of the Enlightenment.

title: Bent Spines
description: A year ago, an injury left me unable to sit. For months, I could choose only between standing and lying on my back. In the past, sick days had bought me time to read, novels anesthetizing every ill. But now, with no lap to rest a book on, books became unwieldy. Tables were too high when I lay down, too low when I stood up. Flat on the floor, I tired of propping a paperback above my head. Pacing the room, I craved an extra hand: one to hold the book, another to turn its pages, a third to underline.

title: An App That Reminds You to Unplug
description: Introducing the last smartphone app you will ever need. Well, more like the last app you will use for at least 25 hours.

title: Canadian Rescue Plane Leaves Tripoli Empty
description: OTTAWA  An evacuation flight chartered by the government of Canada made it into Tripoli, the Libyan capital, on Friday morning, but after its crew was unable to find any Canadians at the chaotic airport, the airplane left empty.

title: Having a Baby: Stress Doesnt Hamper Fertility Treatment, Researchers Conclude
description: Women taking fertility treatments can relax, researchers say: Despite the common wisdom, being worried or tense does not affect ones chances of becoming pregnant.

title: James Levine Cancels Another Performance
description: Dogged by a virus and his back ailment, James Levine has yet again canceled a performance. The Boston Symphony Orchestra, where Mr. Levine is music director, said he was withdrawing from Fridays concert. Sean Newhouse, an assistant conductor, will take his place in leading Mahlers Symphony No. 9 at Symphony Hall in Boston. Mr. Levine is also music director of the Metropolitan Opera. He has canceled three performances with the Met since Jan. 24, although his absences had not been blamed on back problems. Mr. Levine had major spine surgery in April. The Boston Symphony on Friday said he was experiencing ill effects from a recent procedure addressing his ongoing back issues, further complicated by a viral infection.

title: Leora Klein and Emmanuel Werthenschlag
description: THE NOVELS of Philip Roth often focus on duality  between tradition and change, conformity and transgression, privilege and the quest to attain it.

title: Stony Brook, With Assist From Canada, Lands on the Map for Lacrosse
description: STONY BROOK, N.Y.  As the final minute wound down last May, Kevin Crowley was part of the sea of Stony Brook red, a desperate wave pushing for the tying goal on its home turf against Virginia. A ticket to the N.C.A.A. mens lacrosse semifinals hung on the outcome.

title: White House Names First Openly Gay Social Secretary
description: After both a historic (see Desiree Rogers, the first African-American social secretary) and shaky start (see Ms. Rogers, whose first state dinner would best be remembered as Salahi-gate), the White House made history yet again when it announced Friday that Jeremy Bernard will be the new social secretary. Mr. Bernard will be the first openly gay person to hold that position.

title: VIDEO: Christie Sits Down for Lightning Round
description: Chris Christie sat down with The Caucus Wednesday morning for an interview, and at the end we subjected him to the Lightning Round, 60 seconds of short questions with short responses.

title: In Battle Over State Payrolls, Data Show a Mixed Picture
description: The janitors who buff floors and empty wastebaskets for the State of California earn a median wage of a little over $31,000 a year, which is 45 percent more than janitors in the private sector earn there. Georgias janitors, by contrast, earn less than $21,000, about 6 percent below their private sector counterparts.

title: Carter Hancock, Claiborne Johnston
description: Caroline Carter Hancock and Francis Claiborne Johnston III were married Saturday evening at St. Pauls Episcopal Church in Richmond, Va. The Rev. Gary Durward Jones, an Episcopal priest, officiated, with the Rev. Dr. Dennis Marion Campbell, a United Methodist minister, taking part.

title: David Knudson and William Hohengarten
description: David Mark Knudson and William Mark Hohengarten were married Saturday evening at the Long View Gallery in Washington. Nancy Hohengarten, a judge of the County Court of Travis County, Tex., and Mr. Hohengartens sister-in-law, officiated. Mr. Knudsons father, the Rev. John O. Knudson, a retired Lutheran minister, took part in the ceremony.

title: Kristi Remington, Brian Benczkowski
description: Kristi Louise Remington and Brian Allen Benczkowski were married on Saturday afternoon at St. Patricks Catholic Church in Washington. Msgr. Salvatore A. Criscuolo, the churchs pastor, performed the ceremony.

title: Jessica Cohen and Andrew Weber
description: Jessica Lynn Cohen and Andrew Jacob Weber are to be married Sunday afternoon at Stage 6 at Steiner Studios in the Brooklyn Navy Yard. Rabbi Leonard A. Schoolman is to officiate.

title: Kimberly Togman, Geoffrey Aguirre
description: Kimberly Joan Togman and Dr. Geoffrey Karl Aguirre were married Friday in a Quaker-style self-uniting ceremony at Le Bec-Fin, the Philadelphia restaurant.

title: Heather Dominguez and Robert Rahilly
description: Heather Dominguez and Robert Gerard Rahilly were married Saturday at the Cathedral of St. Mary in Miami. Ian Taylor, a Roman Catholic deacon, performed the ceremony.

title: Eileen Hartigan, Eric Barendse
description: Eileen Frances Hartigan, a daughter of Anne Magilligan Hartigan and Maurice Henry Hartigan II of Pound Ridge, N.Y., was married Saturday to Eric Leonardus Barendse, the son of Karen E. Barendse and Jan J. Barendse of Schuyler, N.Y. The Rev. Bernard E. Gaudreau, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at Our Lady of the Snows Church in Waitsfield, Vt.

title: Deborah Schoeneman, Joshua Groban
description: Deborah Schoeneman and Joshua Paul Groban were married Saturday evening at the Colony Palms Hotel in Palm Springs, Calif. Judge Carol Isackson, of Superior Court in San Diego and the bridegrooms aunt, officiated.

title: Kerry Willoughby and David Barry
description: Kerry Kelly Willoughby and David John Barry were married Saturday in Beaver Creek, Colo. Msgr. Robert J. Kinkel, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at Chapel at Beaver Creek.

title: Juliana Duffy and Gene Magee
description: Juliana Alix Duffy and Dr. Gene Aloysius Magee were married Saturday evening at the Hotel Monaco in Washington. Andrew Touchette, a friend of the couple who was ordained by World Christianship Ministries for the occasion, officiated.

title: Cervellis Tutor for the Day? Yogi Berra
description: TAMPA, Fla.  The final batting practice session of the morning Friday had just ended, sending pitchers and catchers, coaches and club officials, into the dugout to get ready for the days light workout. Two people lingered on the grass, about halfway up the first-base line: Francisco Cervelli and Yogi Berra. Berra talked. Cervelli listened, nodding.

title: A Tipping Point for Oil Prices
description: With speculation calming, at least for the moment, oil prices are no longer soaring higher and higher every day. But prices are at a tipping point.

title: The (Ex) Voice of the Village
description: WAYNE BARRETT wants to say nice things about people. He wants to, but he finds it so hard.

title: CNN Reformats Parker Spitzer Without Kathleen Parker
description: 8:54 | Updated | CNN is reformatting Parker Spitzer as an ensemble program with Eliot Spitzer  and without Kathleen Parker, who has been his co-host for the last four months.

title: Team Evil
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#657", 592, 490, true, chameleonData);

title: The Missing Guest at Oscars Party
description: THE Academy Awards ceremony on Feb. 27 will be the first one in years at which the veteran publicist Ronni Chasen wont be expertly shepherding a client down the red carpet.

title: Geneva Auto Show: Morgan 3 Wheeler
description: GENEVA  While most attendees at the Geneva auto show, which opens here on Tuesday for the first of two press preview days, will be hoping to glimpse the future, the Morgan Motor Company will be gazing 100 years into its past.

title: Excuse Me, but Can There Be More Civility in the Court?
description: How far does a thank you, please, sir or maam go?

title: A Year at War: The Afghan Partners
description: A Year at War

title: Reviewing the Chevy Cruze
description: In Sundays Automobiles section, Lawrence Ulrich evaluates the 2011 Chevrolet Cruze, a new compact car from General Motors. With the Cruze, the company is taking aim at the rival Toyota Corolla, even calling out the Toyota by name in advertising. Mr. Ulrich finds the Cruze to be a step forward for G.M., which struggled in the past to sell small cars to American buyers. He writes:

title: To Catch a Thief (or a Murderer)
description: WHEN a convicted murderer or child predator or armed robber escapes from a maximum-security prison, two United States marshals, Charlie DuChamp (Laz Alonso) and Ray Zancanelli (Domenick Lombardozzi), try to track him down. And who better to help them catch a convict than a convict  or three?

title: Heaven, Hell, Brothers and an Impala
description: IF you are neither 15 years old nor the sort of person for whom the term fan fiction has an ounce of resonance, then chances are that Supernatural is not in your DVR queue or even in your frame of reference. The series, now in its sixth season on the CW network, remains an invisibly pervasive cultural phenomenon: enormously popular and yet unknown even to many of those of us who take pride in dabbling in the literature and television of young adults. Supernatural is one of CWs most watched series, this year attracting an average of 700,000 more viewers each week than Gossip Girl, even as none of its stars feature regularly in the pages of Us Weekly.

title: Pianists, Yes, but a Jazz Singer and Deep Metal, Too
description: BRAD MEHLDAU is a jazz pianist enamored of many kinds of music, as his recent albums make clear. Live in Marciac, his new album and concert film on Nonesuch (two CDs, one DVD), chronicles a recent solo piano concert, with his originals brushing up against songs by Radiohead, Nirvana and the Beatles. His previous Nonesuch album, Highway Rider, was a jazz-rock-classical hybrid that featured his writing for a string orchestra. Mr. Mehldau spoke with Nate Chinen a few days before performing with the Swedish mezzo-soprano Anne Sofie von Otter at Carnegie Hall, where he currently holds the Richard and Barbara Debs Composers Chair.

title: Boy Meets Girl. And Angels Conspire.
description: LOS ANGELES

title: Warning Against Wars Like Iraq and Afghanistan
description: WEST POINT, N.Y.  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates bluntly told an audience of West Point cadets on Friday that it would be unwise for the United States to ever fight another war like Iraq or Afghanistan, and that the chances of carrying out a change of government in that fashion again were slim.

title: Whos Best for Your Car, Dealer or Independent?
description: WHEN we moved back to the United States about 11 years ago, we bought a Saturn, which I faithfully took to the nearby dealer for every service checkup. Once it was out of warranty, I gradually shifted to an independent mechanic who was more convenient and seemed cheaper.

title: Does the Southwest Face a Mega-Drought?
description: Rising global temperatures resulting from emissions of human origin could tip the southwestern United States into a period of prolonged extreme drought seen before only in distant geological history, a new study suggests.

title: In the Fountain of Youth, Hopes for the Derby
description: BOYNTON BEACH, Fla.  There is no doubt that the center of the current thoroughbred universe resides here in Barn 11 of the Palm Meadows training center. It is the home of Uncle Mo, the undefeated 2-year-old champion and early Kentucky Derby favorite.

title: Lorin Stein, the Paris Reviews New Party Boy
description: DO you mind the smell of smoke? asked Lorin Stein, the whippet-thin editor of The Paris Review, on a recent Wednesday night in his tidy art-filled loft of an office, quite possibly one of the last workplaces in Manhattan where indoor smoking is considered acceptable.

title: Where the Deer and the Chameleon Play
description: AFTER directing the blockbuster 2003 adventure film Pirates of the Caribbean: The Curse of the Black Pearl and two hit sequels, Dead Mans Chest and At Worlds End, there was only one movie that Gore Verbinski wanted to make next: an animated feature about a talking chameleon who thinks hes a western hero. Why? Were still not entirely sure we understand, but thats the story behind Rango, which stars Johnny Depp as the voice of the titular lizard, who is liberated from his terrarium and finds himself in a ramshackle frontier town, populated by desert critters (whose voices are provided by Isla Fisher, Ned Beatty, Bill Nighy and many more).

title: The Week in Pictures, Feb. 25
description: A look back at the weeks events in New York City and the region.

title: How I Met Your City, the Real One
description: FOR the past few years the actor Josh Radnor has been trafficking in two very different New Yorks. The one he works in more often is located in Los Angeles. Thats where Mr. Radnor films How I Met Your Mother, the CBS sitcom about five friends in Manhattan  or at least studio-set version of the city: clean sidewalks, perfect outfits and brownstones for everybody.

title: Serendipity Is No Algorithm on College Dating Site
description: JEAN MEYER, a business student at Columbia University and a founder of Datemyschool.com, an online matchmaking service, believes modern ambition is the death of love.

title: Letter to My Sons College
description: I have been traveling this week, visiting colleges with my younger son, who is a high school junior. Weve been through this process before at our house, and I know how tense things are in homes of seniors right now, as they wait for answers over the next few weeks that will decide where they spend the next four years.

title: Yemeni City Feeds Unrests Roots
description: TAIZ, Yemen  Tens of thousands of demonstrators massed in pivotal Yemeni cities on Friday, holding their largest demonstrations against President Ali Abdullah Saleh since the wave of anti-authoritarian unrest began sweeping across North Africa and the Middle East.

title: Of Budgets and Bargaining: Putting the Union Protests Into Context
description: On Feb. 16, thousands of protesters, including many teachers, flooded the Wisconsin Capitol building to confront Gov. Scott Walker. School was canceled because of teacher absenteeism, and many Democratic state legislators also avoided work and purposely missed a voting deadline to send a message about their sentiments.

title: Jim Carrey as the Id Unleashed a Bit Before Its Time
description: WHEN The Cable Guy appeared in the summer of 1996, it seemed exactly the wrong movie for its star, Jim Carrey, and its director, Ben Stiller.

title: Weekend Competition: Thou Shalt Not
description: This weekend, co-vocabularists are invited to submit proposals for an eleventh commandment.

title: Sarkozy Is Criticized on a Visit to Turkey
description: ISTANBUL  President Nicolas Sarkozy of France made a six-hour visit to Turkey on Friday, and was greeted with criticism on Europes so-far limited reaction to the Libyan crackdown as well as Mr. Sarkozys own reluctance to bring Turkey into the European Union.

title: Troy Jackson, Street Basketball Star, Is Dead at 38
description: Troy Jackson, one of the best-known stars of street basketball  a showy style of play that gained global attention when its games were shown on ESPN  died Sunday in Los Angeles. He was 38 and lived in Dix Hills, N.Y.

title: Weekend Fare
description: The New York Wine Expo kicks off the weekend beginning Friday at 6 p.m. at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center, 655 West 34th Street (Eleventh Avenue). More than 760 wines from 190 wineries around the world will be available for tasting. A host of speakers will be on hand to give seminars, too. Fridays grand tasting is $90; Saturdays is $100 and runs from 2 to 6 p.m.

title: Changing of the Avant-Garde
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#146", 592, 490, true, chameleonData);

title: Tracking Down and Collecting Unclaimed Life Insurance
description: THE most basic purpose of having a life insurance policy is to provide some assistance for loved ones when you die. Wealthier people sometimes use life insurance for estate planning, while most people expect the policies on which they have paid premiums for decades to help their heirs get by  or at the least cover funeral expenses.

title: A New Credential for Home Care Aides
description: When the Direct Care Alliance first offered the test that would lead to becoming a credentialed personal care and support professional, Maria Frank, a 60-year-old home care aide in Nazareth, Pa., signed up.

title: Oscar Night Preview
description: David Carr and A. O. Scott discuss The New York Times's live Oscar night coverage.

title: Oscar Night Guide (Gold Statues Included)
description: The brave new world of two-screen Oscar watching is upon us, and its spreading. On the big night, visit oscars.nytimes.com/dashboard on your iPad, laptop, mobile phone or device of your choosing for wall-to-wall coverage, starting with live photos and interviews from the red carpet at 5 p.m. ET, tweets from the styles editor Stuart Emmrich (@StuartEmmrichNY), followed by live video analysis by our fashion experts, Eric Wilson and Simone Oliver.

title: The Contribution Scam
description: David Cay Johnston has a terrific piece up about the nonsense of comparing government workers to private-sector counterparts by claiming that the government pays for more of their benefits. As he says,

title: The Night Shift | Rinko Kikuchi
description: If you want to dress up, then prepare to strip down. The feisty actress and freshly minted New Yorker Rinko Kikuchi works the seasons new minimalism. More

title: What if: Standing in Line for Climate Aid
description: Lisa Friedman of Climatewire has an excellent story on The Times Web site digging in on an issue Ive touched on periodically here  the prospect of intensifying fights over whatever money might flow someday to poor countries exposed to risks thought to be amplified by human-driven global warming.

title: Candles in Religious Rite Ignited Fatal Fire, Officials Say
description: A fatal five-alarm fire that roared through a building in Flatbush, Brooklyn, on Saturday was ignited by candles arrayed around a bed that was intended to be part of a voodoo ceremony, Fire Department officials said on Friday.

title: Overlooked Gems of the Trade Deadline
description: The trade deadline has passed. Two stars have changed conferences, a contender shook up its starting lineup, and 21 teams participated in the N.B.A.s trade bonanza leading up to Thursdays 3 p.m. cut-off. Its a new league out there, and the flurry of roster changes have altered the present and future of numerous franchises.

title: TimesCast | February 25, 2011
description: Clashes erupt in the Libyan capital of Tripoli; a naval base in Benghazi is under opposition control; the legislative standoff in Madison, Wis.; and why networks love live TV events like the Oscars.

title: Arts & Leisure Preview: Glenn Ligon, Mike Watt, Gore Verbinski and More
description: Wisdom, insights and observations from this weekends Arts & Leisure section.

title: Yankees Shut Down Brackman With Groin Tightness
description: TAMPA, Fla. - The right-hander Andrew Brackman, whose profile has soared after an impressive two weeks, became the first injury casualty of camp Friday when the Yankees shut him down because of discomfort in his groin. Manager Joe Girardi described the injury as very small, but it is still a setback for a prospect trying to work his way into the mix for a back-end rotation spot.

title: Whos Paid More? Experts Can Disagree
description: The question of whether state workers are overpaid has been much studied over the years and remains contentious.

title: Photographing a Revolution
description: Scott Nelson, taking pictures for The Times of the rapidly changing events in Libya, was moved by the rebels and protesters, who would look you in the eye, and from the bottom of their hearts, express a gratitude and respect for journalism, and its power to reflect their experience and their struggle.

title: The Last Red Carpet
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif.

title: Tax Breaks to Take Before They Go
description: Part of what lies at the heart of the heated debate in state capitals and Washington over the last couple of weeks is a legitimate concern about a pretty simple question: have governments made too many promises about what they should provide without collecting enough money to fulfill them all?

title: Galleon Whistle-Blower Agrees to Testify
description: A former employee of the Galleon Group has agreed to testify on behalf of federal prosecutors as they pursue a case against the hedge fund firms founder, Raj Rajaratnam, according to a person familiar with the case.

title: Making Sure Life Insurance Doesnt Go To Waste
description: Life insurance is meant to help the ones you love when you die. Yet hundreds of millions of dollars in life insurance goes unclaimed each year for a simple reason: the beneficiaries have no idea it ever existed.

title: In Germany, Cherundolos Hannover Surprises
description: By most yardsticks, Steve Cherundolos 32nd birthday last Saturday was pretty darn good.

title: Lower Manhattan, 1:21 P.M.
description: Winds and heavy rains hit New York City today, and a piece of public art drew an appreciative crowd near the corner of Broadway and Liberty Street.

title: Pakistan Demands Data on C.I.A. Contractors
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Pakistans chief spy agency has demanded an accounting by the Central Intelligence Agency of all its contractors working in Pakistan, a fallout from the arrest last month of an American involved in surveillance of militant groups, a senior Pakistani intelligence official said Friday.

title: Dusty Packards, a Graham, Dodge and Ford Among Scottys Castle Treasures
description: In Death Valley National Park, about 200 miles from the unrestored Bugattis at the Mullin Automotive Museum in Oxnard, Calif., sits an indigenous group of hard-bitten vehicles that holds its own special allure.

title: Hurt in Panama? Government Covers You
description: Whether you have health insurance at home or not, if you visit Panama youll get free coverage for 30 days under a program that the country began last month.

title: Pictures of the Day: Libya and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Libya, Egypt, Iraq and Mexico.

title: Lets Assure Free Passage From Libya
description: CAIRO  Ive been on the phone today again with people in the Tripoli area in Libya, and I had an inquiry that goes to the heart of the need for NATO, the United States and Europe to move more forcefully. Several Libyan navy ships were ordered to bombard the city of Benghazi, which has been liberated by rebels. The ships officers dont want to do that and dont like Qaddafi, and theyre also fearful that if they attack Benghazi theyll be attacked right back by shore batteries. They would like to make a run for Malta and defect, but they fear that the Libyan air force is watching them and will bomb them if they head in that direction. And the commanding officers also arent entirely sure who on board is trustworthy and who isnt. Theyre in a bind.

title: What Do All of Your Tax Breaks Add Up To?
description: In this weekends Your Money column, I take a look at all of the tax breaks that I gladly take advantage of that dont come with income caps.

title: Video: Troy Jackson
description: Troy "Escalade" Jackson, a street basketball player, died in his sleep on February 20, 2011.

title: A Snowmobile Trip and a Hot Springs Dip, All in One Day
description: SHUFFLING from one bare foot to the other, I wriggled into my swimsuit, ready to plunge into the pool at a remote, off-the-grid bathhouse. Outside, steam wafted from the surface, and bathers squealed with delight as they eased into a pool fed by a 112-degree natural spring coming off the rocks of a limestone cliff. The day  with uninterrupted blue sky and abundant sunshine beaming down on us  was unseasonably warm: It was 20 degrees.

title: Hotel Review: Aloft Harlem, in New York City
description: THE BASICS

title: Kayaking Lake Tahoe in Winter
description: BUMPING along a freshly plowed road in Lake Tahoe, Calif., I felt oddly unburdened. No skis were locked on top of my car, no clunky boots rattled in the trunk. After more than a decade of ski trips to the region, I kept feeling as if I were missing something. Sure, it was sunny, but also a biting 17 degrees  and I was going kayaking.

title: In Pittsburgh, Trading Pirogi for Farm-to-Table Fare
description: PITTSBURGH has long had an appetite for hearty Old World fare introduced by Eastern European immigrants: pirogi, cabbage rolls, kielbasa. Tourists still flock to Primanti Brothers, a landmark restaurant famous for its outsized meat-and-cheese sandwiches stuffed with French fries and coleslaw. Recently, however, Pittsburghs value-driven food and restaurant culture has been undergoing a transformation, with a new emphasis on whats fresh and local.

title: Luxury Camping in the Oman Desert
description: THE paved road abruptly ended just past the town of Al Mudairab, at the edge of the Empty Quarter in eastern Oman. Stepping out of my Nissan 4-by-4 at the point where a sand track began, I stared at a vista of coffee-colored dunes and flyblown Bedouin encampments that stretched toward the horizon.

title: Restaurant Review: Burgermeester in Amsterdam
description: The walls of all three branches of this Amsterdam mini-chain are lined with portraits of cows. In the black-and-white photographs, some lie in repose with their ilk. Others stand solo. One stares directly at the camera, looking unperturbed by the flies on its face. Said Justus de Nijs, one of Burgermeesters three owners, with characteristic Dutch candor: Here are the cows. Have a nice burger.

title: The French Alps Sans Skis
description: JUST in front of me, a skier jumped from a helicopter and sped down the treacherous slope, zigzagging wildly as he dodged boulders and soared over moguls. Then, suddenly, catastrophe struck. Unable to see an approaching cliff, he shot off its edge into a free fall.

title: Kayaking on Lake Tahoe
description: In the dead of winter, trading skis for a kayak, on Tahoe, a lake that never freezes over.

title: Luxury Shops in Buenos Aires
description: New York has Madison Avenue, Rome has the Via Condotti and Buenos Aires has Recoleta  a shopping district thats similarly luxurious, but much more affordable.

title: Dunes and Silence: A Tent Resort on Oman
description: A Bedouin-style resort in the Sharqiya Sands desert, where guests can experience its tranquility and splendor.

title: French Alps
description: You dont need a lift ticket to soak up the food, history, night life and general fabulousness of the French Alps during ski season for nonskiers.

title: Oscar Picks, Courtesy of Wendy Williams
description: LOS ANGELES How you doin? As part of our continuing celebrity Oscar ballot coverage, the Bagger spoke with Wendy Williams, the outspoken radio star-turned-TV talk show host. In addition to The Wendy Williams Show, which is broadcast every weekday, Ms. Williams will next host the game show Love Triangle, in which she will help real-life daters sort out their romantic entanglements. It will have its premiere in April on GSN, the game show network.

title: Buzz Tracker
description: Retail C.D.S.? The Chicago Board of Options Exchange will soon begin trading credit event binary options. In essence these will be like credit default swaps, accessible to everyone, which will have a $1,000 payoff per contract in the event of a bankruptcy before contract expiration..What this will do is to revolutionize the shorting aspect of trading, as there will be no borrowing need to express a bearish outlook on a company, and no possibility for State Street, BoNY or your favorite repo desk to pull your borrow from underneath your feet thus forcing a short squeeze. In essence, this will be a marginable equity product trading as a credit derivative. Zero Hedge

title: Now Online | T Womens Fashion Spring 2011
description: The Spring Fashion issue highlights the seasons most notable, wearable and desirable trends  from pajamas to wear all day (Early Birds, photographed by Collier Schorr) to a new sensually minimal take on evening (The Night Shift, shot by Terry Richardson). The women who appear throughout the issue, on the other hand, defy such easy categorization. Take our cover star, Salma Hayek  she is an actress, a mother and an undeniable firebrand. Then there is Alexa Chung: It-girl, designer, TV personality and, as Jacob Brown discovered, former captain of Team Evil. Add to that list the actress Rinko Kikuchi, the artist Rachel Feinstein, and the musicians Lykke Li and Shilpa Ray. Last but definitely not least, the issue celebrates the Tough Cookies of Congress: Barbara Lee, Barbara Boxer and Nancy Pelosi, women whose no-nonsense brand of politics makes us all look good. See all stories from this issue >>

title: Libyan City of Benghazi Firmly Under Opposition Control
description: Tens of thousands of people gathered in Benghazi for Friday Prayer outside of the courthouse where protests that set off the rebellion began more than a week ago.

title: Pictures of the Day: Libya and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Libya, Egypt, Iraq and Mexico.

title: Baseball Gave $25 Million Lifeline to Mets
description: Major League Baseball provided $25 million to the owners of the Mets as they struggled to deal with a cash shortfall last fall and a looming lawsuit seeking hundreds of millions of dollars for victims of Bernard L. Madoffs vast Ponzi scheme, according to two people briefed on the arrangement.

title: Internet Fraud Declined in 2010
description: Were criminals hurt by the recession, too?

title: New-World Tale Steeped in Old-World Tradition
description: Precisely why Gian Carlo Menottis operas have vanished so thoroughly from American stages during recent decades is a bit of a mystery. That this once-popular Italian-American composer rejected progressive trends in favor of time-tested formulas proved by Puccini, Mascagni and other Italians at the start of the 20th century seems to work against him now.

title: Childs Remains Reveal Ice Age Burial Practices
description: Archaeologists have discovered the remains of a child cremated in central Alaska about 11,500 years ago. They are the earliest known human remains from the North American Subarctic and Arctic region.

title: Nonfiction Mainstays
description: Weekly rank of the four hardcover nonfiction titles that have been in the top 35 spots the most often over the past year.

title: The Week in Pictures for Feb. 25
description: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include a bridal sale, a tunnel under the Gowanus Canal and a school for disabled children.

title: Dior Suspends Top Designer After Report of Altercation
description: PARIS  The fashion house Christian Dior said on Friday that it had suspended its design director, John Galliano, after he was accused of making an anti-Semitic slur during a drunken tussle at a Paris bar.

title: Off the Field, a Woman Tames Brazils Soccer Fans
description: RIO DE JANEIRO

title: Medtronic Bypasses a Hospital Group Buyer
description: Medtronic could save more than $40 million a year through its decision to cancel five group-purchasing contracts worth $2 billion and to negotiate prices directly with hospitals instead, Bernstein Research said in an investor note on Friday.

title: Photos of the Moment | Versace
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#396", 592, 440, true, chameleonData);

title: Protesters in Bahrain Demand More Changes
description: MANAMA, Bahrain  In by far the largest protest yet here, tens of thousands of demonstrators packed the citys streets on Friday and closed a stretch of highway as they demanded that their king dissolve the government and agree to a transition to a true constitutional monarchy.

title: The Mayor Steals the Show at Oscar-Week Party
description: LOS ANGELES After arriving here late Wednesday night, the Bagger made it out to a few of the vaunted Oscar week parties on Thursday night. In local parlance the events are known as a thing  as in, are you going to the Tom Ford thing? The Ed Ruscha thing? The IFC thing? The Soho House thing(s)? And as with any party circuit, a majority of the evenings conversations revolve around which thing youre going to after the thing that youre at, because clearly, theres always got to be a better thing.

title: Libya's Defectors
description: In Benghazi, a small naval base is now controlled by the opposition.

title: Better Card Placement Thanks to the Bidding
description: The dreadful earthquake in Christchurch, New Zealand, earlier this week nearly had a ghastly effect on bridge. The president of the World Bridge Federation, Gianarrigo Rona, and his wife, Cippi, were in the city visiting a longtime member of the W.B.F. Executive Committee, John Wignall, and his wife, Adele.

title: Newborn Mices Hearts Can Heal Themselves
description: An adult zebra fish can regenerate a damaged heart with no scar formation. This remarkable phenomenon has been seen in other fish and amphibians as well, but never before in a mammal.

title: Oscar's Appeal for Networks
description: A.O. Scott and David Carr discuss why in the internet age, networks love live TV events like this Sunday's Oscars.

title: In Dispute Against Starbucks, Court Dismisses Krafts Claim
description: Kraft Foods lost on Friday an appeals court ruling that upholds a decision allowing the Starbucks Corporation to end a deal under which Kraft distributes Starbucks coffee to grocery stores.

title: Versace: New Baroque
description: Donatella Versace was back in the family palazzo tonight, on a baroque carpeted runway, with members of Duran Duran in the front row, but the collection didnt vibrate with that extra feeling. Still, this was a solid showing of sharp tailoring, with belted coats streaked with gold buttons, and imaginative use of the baroque motifs that her brother Gianni loved to extravagance. Ms. Versace wisely turned the detail into abstract swirls set into coats and mini sheaths, sometimes interpreted with a coiling bit of colored python on a knee-length black or white sheath.

title: Kings Speech Producers Await Seats at Table
description: WEST HOLLYWOOD, Calif.  The fancier people at the Chateau Marmont on Thursday evening were lined up outside, having their photos snapped at the entrance to a pre-Oscar affair sponsored by Vanity Fair and Fox Searchlight Pictures.

title: Software To Make Photos Artfully Worse
description: If your photos dont look as crummy as youd like, there is new software that will wreck them for you.

title: Why Networks Love the Oscars
Chic in Review | Kate vs. Kate
description: All the fashion news of the week thats fit to reprint.

title: On the Ground in Libya
description: Scott Nelson and Ed Ou photographers on assignment for The New York Times, crossed into Libya from Egypt on Tuesday, with a Times reporter, Kareem Fahim. Along with the staff photographer Tyler Hicks they have been reporting from eastern Libya. On Friday morning, James Estrin interviewed Mr. Nelson by e-mail.

title: At Danspace, Physicality Gets a New Dimension
description: When Yvonne Meier greets the audience with a seemingly innocent line  Welcome to Body Madness  it doesnt hurt to take her seriously. What happened to me probably wont happen to you, but its best to be on your guard.

title: Idol Tops Ratings Again
description: American Idol filled out the rest of its slate of 24 semifinalists on Thursday as the latest two-hour installment of the singing competition topped the ratings with 21.6 million viewers, according to Nielsens estimates, up nearly 20 percent versus the comparable night a year ago. Fox easily led the night ahead of its network competitors, while CBS placed second, aided by solid results for CSI at 9 (12.5 million) and The Mentalist at 10 (14.7 million). At 8 and 8:30, CBS broadcast The Big Bang Theory (12.5 million) and Rules of Engagement (9.6 million). In third place, ABC posted modest ratings for Wipeout (7.1 million), Greys Anatomy (9.1 million) and Private Practice (6.7 million). NBC was fourth with low ratings for its comedy line-up, earning its most viewers at 9 for The Office (6.2 million).

title: Republicans Propose Budget Stopgap, Reducing Risk of a Federal Shutdown
description: WASHINGTON  The prospect of an imminent federal government shutdown diminished Friday as House Republicans proposed a carefully calibrated stopgap measure that Democrats said could be acceptable.

title: Oscar Party Recipes
description: Finger food sweet and savory and cocktails for a festive night.

title: The Night Season
description: Chapter One

title: From Sleeping Bag to Starbucks
description: The comedian Mike Birbiglia, 32, who transformed his self-destructive sleep disorder into Sleepwalk With Me, a one-man Off Broadway show, in 2008, is returning to the stage next month in My Girlfriends Boyfriend at the Barrow Street Theater. Mr. Birbiglia lives on the Upper West Side with his wife, Jen Stein, a writer, and their elderly cat, Ivan. He is a late riser on Sundays. ROBIN FINN

title: Sunday Routine | Mike Birbiglia
description: Mike Birbiglia, a comedian and sleepwalker, is the author of a book and one-man show about the disorder.

title: Never Say Die
description: Preface

title: Bloody Attempts to Escape From Fate
description: When an Asian serial-killer movie is deemed to be so violent that it severely damages human dignity  and is effectively banned from public exhibition until cuts are made  large segments of the international cinblogosphere get very excited.

title: With Island Spice, and Years of Seasoning, Old is New Again
description: The Jolly Boys returned to New York City for their first public show here in decades like a Model T with a new CD player in the dashboard. At Hiro Ballroom on Thursday night, they had material few people would expect from a band that was started in the 1950s to play a style that was already decades old. The Jolly Boys have been entertaining people in Port Antonio, Jamaica, since then, often as a hotels house band, with a shifting lineup; Albert Minott, 72, recently stepped forward as lead singer.

title: A Qaddafi Son, Italian Soccer and the Power of Money
description: Over the years, one of the charges against the murderous regime of Colonel Muammar el-Qaddafi was that state funds were being used to further the footballing career of his third-oldest son, Al Saadi. He was once thought to run the Libyan Football Federation. It is hard to know if Libyan football will survive revolution and civil war, but it is worth telling the story, again, of Saadis surreal, so-called career in Italian football.

title: Abstract Expressionism in Aural Mixed Media
description: In 1971, the Rothko Chapel, a meditation space and museum supported by the art patrons and philanthropists Dominique and John de Menil, opened in Houston. Missing from the ceremony was Mark Rothko, the artist who had painted a series of 14 large canvases for the chapel. The year before the opening, Rothko, who had been experiencing severe depression, took his own life.

title: Open City
description: ONE

title: In the End, Its All About the Party
description: Music and dance come so close together in the great flamenco performances that some of the happiest moments occur in the finales, when musicians sometimes dance too. Although this is done for the public, thats not how it feels. The atmosphere suggests an offstage celebration, with dancers and musicians encouraging and teasing one another in the greatest high spirits. We in the audience feel weve been allowed to witness family fun and games.

title: App Smart Extra: More Weather Apps
description: As I pointed out in a recent App Smart column, all-purpose weather apps fall far short when it comes to offering weather alerts. But thankfully the march of mobile software only moves forward  at least for iPhone and Android users.

title: Recreating a Bill of the Obscure and the Familiar
description: The Dutch violinist Janine Jansen is making efficient use of her stay in New York. Mainly, she is in town as a guest of the New York Philharmonic, with which she played Brittens Violin Concerto at Avery Fisher Hall on Thursday evening. She is also giving a recital at Le Poisson Rouge on Monday, between her last two Philharmonic appearances.

title: Scorecard | Fendi Wins!
description: Tangerine. Azure blue. Cravats of striped fox and fitch. Nope, Scorecard isnt talking about Chiquita Prada. In his 46th year collaborating with the fur and leather goods house of Fendi, Kaiser Karl went and got all Dadaist and conceptual. Sorry, Miuccia, critics didnt all feel your game of dress-up in mammas closet was the most bananas showing in town.

title: Oscars Watchdog Monitors Foul Play in Stores, Online and on Red Carpet
description: It was as ominous a moment as any in the history of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences. A federal judge had ruled that its gold Oscar statuette was not protected by copyright.

title: The New Police Siren: Youll Feel It Coming
description: Joe Bader tried setting the two tones of his invention four notes apart on the musical scale, but the result sounded like music, not a siren. Same thing when he played around with a five-note interval. But when he set the two tones apart by two octaves and gave the siren a test run outside the Florida Highway Patrol headquarters in Tallahassee, the effect was so attention-grabbing that people came streaming out of the building to see what the strange sound, with its unfamiliar vibrations, could possibly be.

title: Wages by State
description: How state workers salaries compare to those in the private sector in all 50 states.

title: Chronicle of a Changing City
description: HASH FIFTY FIVE, a snazzy new hookah lounge upstairs from the new restaurant Fifty Five, has a Midnight at the Oasis theme, with lots of mirrors, black drapery, glam art and low sofas of white leather.

title: Adventures in an Urban Wilderness
description: BEN RYDER HOWE says he was raised to avoid using the personal pronoun I when writing. Moreover, he rarely wrote about New York. Fortunately for readers, he overcame both disinclinations in his first book, My Korean Deli: Risking It All for a Convenience Store (Henry Holt, $25). Its a charming, present-tense, only-in-New York chronicle of the agonies and ecstasies of immigrant entrepreneurship (and of being in business with your mother-in-law, whom Mr. Howe describes as the Mike Tyson of Korean grandmothers).

title: Map of the Rebellion in Libya, Day by Day
description: Interactive map of the rebellion in Libya, day by day. (Note: This map is no longer being updated daily.)

title: On a Mission, but Not From God
description: There are those who insist that no great work of cinematic art will ever be presented in 3-D. The most persuasive among them  Roger Ebert, for example  offer learned arguments grounded in science and aesthetics. None of that really has anything to do with Drive Angry, which at least in its 3-D version makes a loud, incoherent but oddly compelling case for the enhancing effects of stereoscopic projection on certain treasured objects of the cinematic gaze, like classic Detroit muscle cars, womens breasts and Nicolas Cage.

title: Milan Shows How It All Makes Sense
description: MILAN

title: Bridging Cultures Onstage
description: WHEN Eva Bornstein became executive director of the Lehman Center for the Performing Arts in 2005, its headliners had included Zubin Mehta and the New York Philharmonic, Marcel Marceau and Victor Borge. But as their appeal dwindled in a changing Bronx neighborhood, so did audiences. To bolster the theaters fortunes, Ms. Bornstein, a Polish migr, set out to explore the area  as she had done in Toronto, Pennsylvania and New Jersey when she ran theaters there.

title: Iran Reports a Major Setback at a Nuclear Power Plant
description: Iran told atomic inspectors this week that it had run into a serious problem at a newly completed nuclear reactor that was supposed to start feeding electricity into the national grid this month, raising questions about whether the trouble was sabotage, a startup problem, or possibly the beginning of the projects end.

title: Whos Afraid of the Brothers Koch?
description: Two brothers steeped in wealth and power, visionaries to some, yet widely feared by others as overseers of a vast conspiracy, steeped in paranoia, that threatens to change the very fabric of society. I speak, of course, of Reggie and Ronnie Kray, the odd, mod gangster siblings of Swinging London. Who did you think I meant? Dinsdale and Doug Piranha?

title: When Berra Speaks, a Yankees Catcher Listens
description: The Yankees final batting practice session of the morning Friday had just ended, sending pitchers and catchers, coaches and club officials into the dugout to get ready for the days light workout in Tampa, Fla. Two people lingered on the grass, about halfway up the first-base line: catcher Francisco Cervelli and Yogi Berra. Berra talked. Cervelli listened, nodding.

title: Bush Cancels Speech Because of Assange Appearance
description: President George W. Bush canceled a speaking engagement Friday because the group that invited him, the Young Presidents Organization, also asked Julian Assange, the founder of WikiLeaks, to take the conference stage.

title: Jeffrey Tambor Withdraws from La Cage aux Folles
description: Is there a title to one of Jeffrey Tambors previous projects that might apply here? On Friday night, the producers of the Broadway revival of La Cage aux Folles said that Mr. Tambor, a star of the television comedies Arrested Development and The Larry Sanders Show, had withdrawn from the production following Thursdays performance and after having started in the musical just over a week ago.

title: Events in Westchester
description: Comedy

title: Reads and Reactions
description: This is the inaugural edition of a new feature well be running to highlight reactions from around the web (positive, negative, indifferent and otherwise) to posts here at FiveThirtyEight. Well also pick out some articles that take quantitative, data-rich approaches to subjects that we care about. If you spot either of these things out there in the online ether, pass the link along. These roundups will run bi-weekly on Fridays or Saturdays.

title: A Filmmaker Returns to a Lucky Theater
description: WHEN the filmmaker Jeff Lipsky grew up in Plainview, N.Y., there were literally eight movie theaters in spitting distance of my house, he said recently. Now there are none.

title: Afghan Officials Say Jailed Christian Convert Is Free
description: Under international pressure, government officials in Kabul say they have freed an Afghan man who had been jailed since May and faced the prospect of the death penalty for converting from Islam to Christianity.

title: Events in Connecticut
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in Connecticut this week. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com, or by mail to the Connecticut Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

title: Events on Long Island
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Nassau and Suffolk Counties this week. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com, or by mail to Long Island Weekly, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

title: Voodoo Candles Ignited Deadly Fire, Officials Say
description: A fatal five-alarm fire that roared through a building in Flatbush, Brooklyn, last Saturday was ignited by candles arrayed around a bed for a voodoo ceremony, Fire Department officials said Friday.

title: 3 Banks Warn of Big Penalties in Mortgage Inquiries
description: Several big banks warned investors on Friday that they could face sizable financial penalties as a result of state and federal investigations into abusive mortgage practices.

title: A Star Turn for Stuttering, On-Screen and in Research
description: In the Oscar-nominated movie The Kings Speech, King George VI begins stuttering at age 4 and struggles with it throughout his life. But he rarely talks like the stereotypical stutterer, Porky Pig, rapidly repeating letter sounds; usually the king has trouble getting sounds out from the get-go, blocked by sputtering pauses.

title: Centennial Celebration for a Special Collection
description: KATHERINE ANNE PAUL, curator of the Newark Museums Arts of Asia collection, says that when she travels the world researching Tibetan art, I see more about the Newark Museum than any other institution.

title: Frederick Douglasss Irish Liberty
description: Frederick Douglass drew on many influences during his life as an orator, journalist and anti-slavery activist. Few, however, are more unlikely than the man he met in 1845, during a two-year lecture tour of Ireland, Scotland and England: Daniel OConnell.

title: Graying Audience Returns to Movies
description: LOS ANGELES  Hollywood and older Americans have never had much use for each other. The 50-plus crowd doesnt go to opening weekends or buy popcorn; a youth-obsessed Hollywood has happily ignored them.

title: A Heap of Crosses for a Nun to Bear
description: From the beginning of Amy Hartmans Mercy and the Firefly, the playwright goes for shock value. A 15-year-old girl in a parochial-school uniform turns her prayer into a rap number, and when she asks God, Youve got to kill?/Is this your will? she throws in a familiar  but in this context, still jolting  obscenity.

title: Kayte Walsh, Kelsey Grammer
description: Kayte Walsh and Kelsey Grammer were married Friday on the stage of the Longacre Theater on Broadway, where Mr. Grammer until recently was one of the stars of La Cage aux Folles. Terry Lavell, who plays Mercedes in the show, officiated.

title: Events in New Jersey
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405; or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Killings Jolt a Family in Mexico
description: MEXICO CITY  When Josefina Reyes Salazar was murdered in the border state of Chihuahua last year, not long after she accused the military of playing a role in the killing of her son, protests brought attention to the familys plight.

title: Two Directions for the Prices of Natural Gas and Oil
description: CRUDE oil prices have risen this year, and this week they briefly touched $100 a barrel for the first time since 2008.

title: Egyptian Military Cracks Down on New Protest
description: CAIRO  Tens of thousands of protesters returned Friday to Tahrir Square, the site of demonstrations that led to the ouster of President Hosni Mubarak two weeks ago, to keep up the pressure on Egypts military-led transitional government.

title: Abuse Suspects, Your Calls Are Taped. Speak Up.
description: The men charged with beating, stabbing or burning their wives or girlfriends have plenty to say. Lately, their words have been used against them in New York courts as never before.

title: Deadline for N.F.L. Talks Could Be Extended
description: INDIANAPOLIS  The leader of the N.F.L. players union told agents Friday that no progress had been made on any of the big issues at the center of the games labor dispute. The bleak outlook throws into question whether a new collective bargaining agreement can be reached without a work stoppage  the leagues first in more than two decades  that could threaten at least the start of the 2011 season.

title: Niger: 3 Hostages From French Mine Are Released
description: Al Qaedas North African affiliate has released three hostages abducted in September from a French-run mine in Niger, the French presidency said Friday. Niger authorities brought the three to Niamey, the capital, on Thursday, a security official said. The hostages, a Frenchwoman and men from Madagascar and Togo, and four Frenchmen were abducted from a uranium mine operated by the French nuclear giant Areva. It was not reported whether a ransom had been paid to Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb, which claimed responsibility for the kidnappings. The other four hostages remain in captivity.

title: Mubarak, Terrorism and Their Tie
description: The blind sheik in charge of blowing up New York City had invited reporters to interview him one evening in 1993, so 57 of us stood in his bare living room. The floor shuddered every time another person or camera crew squeezed in. Then, for more than half an hour, the sheik, Omar Abdel Rahman, spoke at a dead sprint, in Arabic. The translators panted. From the sound of things, they apparently were able to render only about one phrase in English for every three he spoke in Arabic.

title: Biggest Fish Face Little Risk of Being Caught
description: So much for Angelo Mozilo taking the fall for the financial crisis.

title: How Do You Open for a Mind-Reading Horse?
description: Do you, or someone else out there, have any idea what became of Ed Steib?

title: A Neighborhoods Steeples Are Set to Disappear Quietly
description: Frederick Irving William Lundy was many things to Sheepshead Bay.

title: U.S. Gathered Personal Data on Times Reporter in Case Against Ex-C.I.A. Agent
description: WASHINGTON  Federal law enforcement officials, trying to uncover the sources of a New York Times reporter, James Risen, obtained extensive records about his phone calls, finances and travel history, according to a court brief filed late Thursday.

title: Thousands Rally for Reform in Jordan
description: AMMAN, Jordan  Thousands of people demonstrated peacefully for political reform in Amman, the capital, and in other Jordanian towns on Friday, with opposition forces drawing the largest crowds since the weekly Friday protests began eight weeks ago. The opposition also expanded its demands.

title: The Man at the Center of a Dispute at the Dakota
description: It was not that long ago that Alphonse Fletcher Jr.s fifth-floor apartment at the Dakota on the Upper West Side was a salon for wealthy and famous guests who traded ideas and chatter at his popular parties. Mr. Fletcher, an accomplished financier, opened his home to fellow Harvard alumni for fund-raising events, and to fellow black notables like Anna Deavere Smith and Anita Hill, two of more than three dozen people who have been given the honor of being Fletcher Fellows, each one receiving a $50,000 stipend from him.

title: The Return of the Conquering, Gnarly Heroes
description: Scottsdale, Ariz.

title: Bank of America Settles Countrywide Financial Case
description: Countrywide Financials multibillion-dollar tab for Bank of America just got even steeper.

title: David T. Kearns, Champion of Education Reform, Dies at 80
description: David T. Kearns, a former chief executive at the Xerox Corporation and a champion of education reform who served as deputy secretary of education under the first President George Bush, died Friday at a hospice near his winter home in Vero Beach, Fla. He was 80.

title: Pediatrician in Abuse Case Killed Himself
description: Dr. Melvin D. Levine, a nationally known pediatrician who was found dead last week, died of a self-inflicted gunshot wound, a medical examiner said on Friday.

title: Seeking to Weed Out Drivel, Google Adjusts Search Engine
description: In a tacit admission that Web publishers are flooding its search engine with low-quality pages, Google has revised its methods to improve the usefulness of its results.

title: Mayor Tries to Reassure Providence Teachers as Furor Grows Over Firing Notices
