description: BOSTON  A day after the school board in Providence, R.I., voted to send termination notices to all of the citys 1,926 teachers, Mayor Angel Taveras sought to calm the uproar by saying that an overwhelming majority would not, in fact, lose their jobs.

title: Lottery Numbers
Amid Cuomos Medicaid Cuts, Health Care Workers Union Shapes a Victory
description: In Wisconsin, public workers face a nearly unprecedented rollback of collective-bargaining rights. In New Jersey, teachers and their unions find themselves the target of open ridicule from Gov. Chris Christie, who is seeking major increases in how much the states public employees pay for their pensions and health care. And in Connecticut, state workers are being pressured to accept a wage freeze, more furlough days and a higher retirement age.

title: Match Play Could Be Battle of Snow and Long Ball
description: MARANA, Ariz.  There is no arguing that the W.G.C.-Accenture Match Play Championship lost some of its youth and appeal on Friday when the 17-year-old Italian Matteo Manassero and the stylish 22-year-old Rickie Fowler were eliminated.

title: The Worlds Wonders, in an Ecologists Eyes
description: Amagansett, N.Y.

title: A Network of Support
description: In my column this week I examined the work of an organization called Youth Villages, which offers intensive in-home services to help children in the foster care system return to their families, or extended families, wherever it is possible to do so safely. My point was to highlight the fact that this approach, which is vastly underutilized and underfunded, is proving to be superior to the current practices in the child welfare system. Its now common for youth to remain in foster care or residential treatment for years. When they age out of these systems, many are unable to live successfully as adults.

title: Election Defeat Predicted for Irelands Ruling Party
description: DUBLIN  If there were people walking around during the national election on Friday who were passionate supporters of the ruling party, Fianna Fail, they were doing an excellent job of keeping it secret.

title: Sheen Tantrum Likely to Cost in the Millions
description: Charlie Sheens latest antics may leave CBS and Warner Brothers with a quarter-billion-dollar headache.

title: Jupiters El Sol
description: The seaside town of Jupiter, Fla., has lots of immigrant day laborers, which makes it scarcely different from hundreds of towns across the country. Men started showing up on street corners there a few years ago, taking manual jobs in construction, landscaping and carpentry. It was  in the boom years, anyway  a good match of labor demand and supply.

title: Absorbing the Pain
description: Philadelphia

title: Presidential Primary Book Club
description: One of a journalists most important duties is to seek out information in places the readers wouldnt go themselves, like following troops into combat or covering charter revision commission hearings. In that spirit, I have been reading all the books written by likely candidates for the Republican presidential nomination.

title: Preserving Wilderness
description: To the Editor:

title: Mideast Reform?
description: To the Editor:

title: Helping the Casualties of the Economy
description: To the Editor:

title: 3 to 2 for Health Care Reform
description: Enormous attention has been focused on rulings by two federal district judges who found the new health care reform law unconstitutional. Less attention has been paid to rulings by three judges who upheld the laws constitutionality.

title: Delivering Moral Support in a Steady Stream of Pizzas
description: MADISON, Wis.  Someday the ruckus here might be remembered as the Pizza-Powered Peoples Uprising.

title: An Alchemy of Color and Craft
description: We all know that any given painting or sculpture can tell many stories. But so can groupings in a museum show. And at The Chemistry of Color: The Sorgenti Collection of Contemporary African-American Art, the story possibilities abound.

title: The War on Women
description: Republicans in the House of Representatives are mounting an assault on womens health and freedom that would deny millions of women access to affordable contraception and life-saving cancer screenings and cut nutritional support for millions of newborn babies in struggling families. And this is just the beginning.

title: Look at the Science
description: Every winter, some of Yellowstone National Parks more than 3,000 bison wander out of the park seeking better grazing. When they do, they are either shot, hazed back into the park or corralled for possible slaughter, all in accordance with a plan developed by the Interior and Agriculture Departments and the State of Montana. It is time to change that plan, which was based on bad science and has now been rendered obsolete by new regulations from the U.S.D.A.

title: Paying for Old Age
description: LIFE expectancy at birth for Americans is about 78. But many Americans will die well before then, while others, like Eunice Sanborn, who died in Texas last month, will live to be 114.

title: Illegal Immigrants
description: To the Editor:

title: Correction
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Indianas 3-Year-Old Agitator
description: INDIANAPOLIS  The littlest protester cannot count past 10 and gets his alphabet mixed up. But in the midst of civic strife, Sheadon ODay, a 3-year-old agitator, has mastered one thing that really matters inside the Statehouse here: screaming Save Daddys job! With that and his blond hair and blue eyes, one could say that he stole the show, even from the large men in hard hats yelling into their megaphones.

title: Lorillard and Reynolds Sue F.D.A.
description: Two major tobacco companies filed a lawsuit against the Food and Drug Administration on Friday, contending that three members of an advisory committee had conflicts of interest that would taint any recommendations by the panel to the agency.

title: Wisconsin Assembly Passes Anti-Union Bill as Senate Democrats Stay Away
description: MADISON, Wis.  Over shouts of protest from Democrats, the Republican-controlled Wisconsin State Assembly passed a bill in the early morning hours Friday that would strip state employees of most of their collective bargaining rights. But there was no sign that a stalemate over the proposal would end, as Democrats in the Senate remained out of the state after fleeing to prevent their own vote on the proposal.

title: Gay Male Secretary for the White House
description: WASHINGTON  The White House made history Friday by announcing the appointment of Jeremy Bernard as the first male, and openly gay, social secretary.

title: Seeking Lynching Stories as Accounts of Faith
description: DALLAS  With a broken bone in one foot and gout in the other, Shirley Johnson limped across her living room toward the front door. The visitor waiting there one recent afternoon, the Rev. Angela D. Sims, hoped that at age 74, Mrs. Johnsons memory was in sturdier shape.

title: On the Street | The Business Look
description: The mens wear being worn in New York is sending early signals that the era of dressing down is over.

title: Bloggingheads: 'Social Network' Divide
description: David Edelstein, left, of New York Magazine and film director Alex Gibney debate the meaning of "The Social Network."

title: Christian Lambertsen, Inventor of Scuba Precursor, Dies at 93
description: When American commandos slipped into the sea off the coast of Burma in the last months of World War II and swam underwater to attach explosives to Japanese vessels, Capt. Christian J. Lambertsen often led them. After all, he had trained them to dive and had invented the breathing device that allowed them to stay below the waves.

title: Canada: Conservatives Charged With Finance Violations
description: Two Conservative members of the Senate, including Prime Minister Stephen Harpers former campaign manager, and two former Conservative party officials were charged with several violations of campaign finance laws, Elections Canada announced Friday. The agency said the Conservatives exceeded campaign spending limits by $1.3 million in the 2006 election. According to the agency, the party improperly channeled spending for national campaign advertising through the budgets of local candidates. Fred DeLorey, a spokesman for the party, said it followed all financing rules. We did nothing wrong, he said.

title: Disney Calling? A Band Takes Off
description: FAIRFIELD, Conn.

title: An Interview With Gabrielecorto Moltedo
description: The designer expands his seven-year-old Corto Moltedo brand with a new standalone store in Milan, an e-commerce Web site and a new line of bags.

title: Saturday: Opening for Firing
description: SATURDAYS PUZZLE  At one time, Bob Peoples was a fairly prolific end-of-week constructor, yet we havent seen a puzzle with his byline since 2007 (Across Lite, Solution).

title: Herbs Sit Down to Tea
description: Some of New York Citys best chefs, including Jean-Georges Vongerichten, Gray Kunz and Lidia Bastianich, have long depended on Honey Locust Farm House in Newburgh for its organic herbs.

title: Where Portions Are Big and Protein Abounds
description: MAKE no mistake: a meal at Benjamin Steakhouse requires muscular eating. Portions are large; protein abounds. And prices can give pause. Nonetheless, if a visit to Benjamin on a recent weekday evening is any indication, the appeal of the New York-style steakhouse persists  the handsome dining room was filled, mostly with suits hatching deals and, we assume, charging expense accounts.

title: Reyes, Healthy Again, Reclaims Crown as the Fastest Met
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  For the first time in two years, Jose Reyes has his winged shoes, and with no restrictions or limitations, he is showing his burning speed once again.

title: The G.O.P.s Abandoned Babies
description: Republicans need to figure out where they stand on childrens welfare. They cant be pro-life when the child is in the womb but indifferent when its in the world. Allow me to illustrate just how schizophrenic their position has become through the prism of premature babies.

title: Life and Death in the North of Mexico
description: To the Editor:

title: Made for Meals
description: The portfolio of wines made by Shinn Estate Vineyards is pointedly food-friendly.

title: A Steakhouse Sticks With the Classics
description: THE sign outside the venerable old house in Great River spells out Strip Steak in letters large enough to halt any passing carnivore. I was attracted by the words in small print: George Martins. This newcomer, which opened early last month, is one of six restaurants in the well-regarded George Martin Group. The other five, including the original George Martin in Rockville Centre, are in Nassau County.

title: Sip, Munch and Cheer
description: On weekends in Hoboken, jersey-clad fans file into the citys many bars to root for their sports teams. These days, they have one more to choose from, with the opening in November of an outpost of the Village Pourhouse, the sports bar minichain based in Manhattan. The bar serves more than 100 beers, along with wings, nachos, burgers and other food popular on game days.

title: A Robust Menu With Global Cuisine
description: IF the restaurant Coco-La, with its exuberant interiors and playful format, embodied the effervescent economy of central New Jersey before the recession, then The Maestro 206, which opened in its place in August in Hillsborough, personifies the new frugality.

title: Chaos in Libya
description: A roundup of the events across the country from France 24 and the International Herald Tribune.

title: Warm Slabs of Meat on Cold Winter Nights
description: I HOPE they have a defibrillator in this restaurant, a member of my party quipped cheerfully as he launched into a large lobster pot pie. Sure, the pie was decadent: the meat from a one-and-a-half-pound lobster was blanketed with lobster cream sauce and topped with a flaky disk of buttery pastry. But if the lobster put him over the top, it was only because he started the meal with a sensational appetizer of roasted marrow with foie gras mousse.

title: Tacos and More, With a Twist
description: There are only three types of tacos on the blackboard menu at Husk New American Tacos in Collinsville, but this informal eatery lives up to its New American label by putting a fresh spin on them  and on a number of other south-of-the-border favorites.

title: Tumult Around the Region
description: LIBYA Mercenary and army forces put down an attempt by protesters to break Col. Muammar el-Qaddafis hold on Tripoli, the capital, opening fire on crowds who had taken to the streets after prayers to mount their first major challenge to the governments crackdown, witnesses said.

title: Knicks Euphoria Is Thrown for a Loss
description: CLEVELAND  The first test was a rousing success. Carmelo Anthony made a triumphant Knicks debut Wednesday at Madison Square Garden. But playbooks take time to learn, and simply suiting up superstars does not guarantee victories.

title: Best Visit to New York by a Former King?
description: GUY PEARCE, the actor who played King Edward VIII in The Kings Speech, is not among the nominees for an Academy Award at Sunday nights ceremony. But Mr. Pearces character  who abdicated the throne to his brother (King George VI, played by Colin Firth, a favorite for Best Actor) in order to marry a double divorcee  captivated audiences during a visit to tenements on the East Side of New York in 1941.

title: High School Indoor Record Set in 600 Meters
description: Strymar Livingston, a 17-year-old junior at Christopher Columbus High in the Bronx, posted a national indoor high school record in the boys 600 meters, finishing in 1 minute 17.64 seconds at the Public Schools Athletic League title meet at the New Balance Track and Field Center. The previous mark was 1:17.90, set by Shaquan Brown in 2005.

title: Legislative Standoff
description: In Wisconsin, Republican Governor Scott Walker's bill to limit the collective bargaining rights for most public workers has created a legislative showdown.

title: Sports Replay: Feb. 25, 2011
description: A look at the day in sports, from uncomfortable positions on the tennis court and the golf course, to angry coaches and a newfangled gizmo.

title: Podcast: Economic Turbulence, and a Call for Fed Action
description: The United States economy cant seem to catch a break. On Friday, the federal government revised its calculation of fourth-quarter growth to 2.8 percent from 3.2 percent. In the Weekend Business podcast, Catherine Rampell explains why: the turmoil in the Middle East has sent oil prices soaring. Investors fear that the unrest will spread to other countries, further disrupting production. In the United States, major cutbacks by state and local governments and threats of federal cutbacks are throwing more workers into the unemployment pool. Taken together, the uncertainty means businesses are unlikely to invest, let alone hire more workers.

title: Loss to Spurs Gives Williams Crash Course in Nets Routine
description: SAN ANTONIO  Even as Fridays game against San Antonio slipped away, Nets point guard Deron Williams decided to have a little fun with his new teammates.

title: Larger-Than-Life Dallas Is Barely Growing
description: Big D may need a new nickname.

title: Bermans Agenda Leads Charge From the Right
description: Sitting in his Texas Capitol office, surrounded by pictures of his storied 22-year military career, the seven-term, 75-year-old Representative Leo Berman said in his distinctive New York accent, Im very unusual for a legislator.

title: Austin Filmmaker Scores Sight Unseen at Sundance
description: Minutes before the world premiere of his second feature, Take Shelter, at last months Sundance Film Festival, Jeff Nichols stood alone just beyond the red carpet at the Eccles Center, the festivals largest site. The Austin-based writer-director had a look of cheerful amusement on his handsome face, almost like a boy taking in the sights at the circus.

title: Republicans Must Walk Fine Line on Immigration
description: Ross Ramsey, the managing editor at The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column.

title: Snow Falls on San Francisco After a 35-Year Wait
description: SAN FRANCISCO  As a Pacific storm coincided with a blast of cold Canadian air over their fair city, residents here saw snow late Friday, a long-absent visitor for a city accustomed to fog, sweater-weather and other nearly bone-chilling accoutrements.

title: On Our Radar: Spain Lowers Speed Limit as Oil Price Spikes
description: Spain will lower its national speed limit, reduce the cost of rail fares and raise the minimum percentage of biofuels blended into gasoline, all in a bid to reduce oil dependence in the face of spiking crude prices, the countrys deputy prime minister says. Driven by Middle East turmoil, the benchmark price for Brent crude oil in Europe settled at over $112 a barrel on Friday. [Reuters]

title: Irelands Governing Party Ousted in Historic Loss
description: LONDON  Ireland ousted its discredited government on Saturday, electing new leaders who pledged to restore faith in the country after the trauma of a calamitous economic collapse.

title: The Weekend Word: Breathing Room?
description: From Todays Times:

title: Following U.S. Sanctions, U.N. Security Council to Meet on Libya
description: WASHINGTON  One day after the United States closed its embassy in Tripoli and imposed unilateral sanctions against Libya, the United Nations Security Council prepared to meet in New York on Saturday to consider imposing international sanctions, including an arms embargo and an asset freeze and travel ban against Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, his relatives and key members of his government.

title: The Effects of Union Membership on Democratic Voting
description: How important are labor unions to the Democratic Party?

title: Classic Ad: A Cavalcade of Stars for Chevy
description: When it comes to classic car ads, you can never have too much star power.

title: New N.F.L. Standard for Assessing Players Suspected of Having Concussions
description: The N.F.L. released new guidelines on Friday for handling players who are suspected of having been concussed. The league wants one set of sideline tests for all 32 team doctors and trainers before a player is sent back to the field. The complete news release from the league is below.

title: Bombing Damages Iraqs Largest Oil Refinery
description: BAGHDAD  Iraqs largest oil refinery, in Baiji, was crippled by a predawn attack on Saturday in which gunmen stormed the vast complex, killed one engineer and set off several bombs.

title: Suddenly, a Rise in Piracys Price
description: At some point, Thomas Jefferson realized, you just cant do business with pirates any more.

title: Flirt in a Skirt
description: Is it her voice, her smile or the way she wears her impressive spring blouse that turns prim into fabulous? In this shoot, the fashion editor David Vandewal and the photographer Walter Pfeiffer conspire to make grown-up looks that dont take themselves too seriously. More

title: Feb. 26: Updates on Libyas Revolt and Mideast Protests
description: On Saturday, The Lede is following the uprising in Libya and protests in Egypt, Yemen, Bahrain, Iraq and the West Bank. Updates below mix alerts on breaking news with reports from bloggers and journalists on the ground. A stream of Twitter messages from the region is in this blogs right column.

title: Iceland-Ireland Again
description: Via the Irish Economy, I see that there have been two articles in the Irish Times comparing Iceland and Ireland, and concluding that Iceland did no better. The articles arent bad  but need to be read with caution. Specifically, Id make four counter-arguments:

title: Mail Call for E.T.
description: I tend to subscribe to the rare earth hypothesis propounded by Peter Ward and Donald Brownlee, but, hey, you never know. In that spirit, Marc Roberts, the British eco-cartoonist, has been doing a series on alien encounters thats worth a look:

title: A Clarification On Public Workers
description: I see that a number of commenters failed to click on my link in this post. Um, its true that the Times article did not include data on benefits as opposed to wages. But other studies have  notably the big EPI study (pdf). The Times results match what those studies say about wages  and those studies find that the lack of evidence for overpayment remains once you take benefits into account.

title: Joel McHale on Low Standards and Hosting Gigs
description: LOS ANGELES You know, if a weekend with one awards show is good, then a weekend with two award shows must be better, right?

title: In Libya Capital, Long Bread Lines and Barricades
description: TRIPOLI, Libya  A bold play by Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi to prove that he was firmly in control of Libya appeared to backfire Saturday, as foreign journalists he invited to the capital discovered blocks of the city in open defiance of his authority.

title: Urban Forager | Growing a Salad in Winter
description: Instead of throwing down weedkiller, why not dig up dandelions for next winters food?

title: Model-Morphosis | Melissa Tammerijn for Etro
description: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of Milan Fashion Week. Here, the model Melissa Tammerijn before (left) and after (right) transforms, with makeup by Charlotte Tilbury for M.A.C. and hair by Eugene Souleiman for Wella. (Drag the orange bar left to reveal the full transformation.)

title: As Berkshire Improves, Buffett Sings Praises of U.S.
description: Warren E. Buffett does not put a title on his annual letter. But if he did, this years dispatch might be headlined God Bless the U.S.A.

title: Polanski Basks in Applause at Csar Awards
description: PARIS Roman Polanski, the 77-year-old director whose film The Ghost Writer was snubbed by the Oscars, won a measure of solace on Friday when the French cultural elite showered the thriller with four Csars. The honors (Frances version of the Academy Awards) included a best directing nod for Mr. Polanski, who was vigorously supported by French film and political celebrities when he was arrested in September 2009 on a more than 30-year-old sex crime warrant from the United States and jailed and detained in Switzerland until he successfully fended off extradition last July.

title: Maluca Mala | La Crazy Bad
description: Two years ago, Nathalie Yepez  a 29-year-old first generation New Yorker who was born to Dominican parents in the Bronx and grew up in Washington Heights and the East Village  moved back to her mothers house, quit her bartending and waitressing jobs to pursue music full time, and reinvented herself as the singer Maluca Mala. I thought to myself, Enough is enough! she recalls. Im miserable sitting at home writing music and just talking about it. Mala, who not surprisingly identifies as a hood hipster, performs a mix of what she calls ghetto-techno, Latin-dance, hip-hop, rave music. Its a decadent mix that has not gone unnoticed  especially by Lady Gaga, whose beer-cans-as-rollers look in the video for Telephone appears to have been inspired by Malas headgear in her video for El Tigeraso.

title: Key Tribal Chief Wants Yemen Leader to Quit
description: SANA, Yemen  One of Yemens most prominent tribal sheiks resigned from the ruling party on Saturday and called for President Ali Abdullah Saleh to step down, posing one of the most significant challenges yet to the Yemeni leader, an American ally who has struggled for more than two weeks to quell a popular revolt.

title: Suicide Attack Continues Afghan Trend
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  A playing field in a remote area of northwest Afghanistan where a crowd had gathered was the most recent target for a suicide bomber who detonated himself on Saturday, in the seventh suicide attack in Afghanistan in less than a month.

title: Variety: A Winner of a Cryptic
description: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE  Some days you conquer the puzzle, and some days, as they say, the puzzle conquers you. Although it was immensely enjoyable, I narrowly escaped with my life on this one, and I think its because 1) this is only the second cryptic Ive ever done, and 2) Since the only other cryptic Ive solved was by Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon, I feel like Im more on their wavelength.

title: How Budget Battles Go Without the Earmarks
description: WASHINGTON  The fact that Congress remains a spending disagreement or two away from shutting down the government no doubt strikes some as remarkable. But there is another extraordinary aspect to the fiscal clash unfolding on Capitol Hill: earmarks have disappeared from the budgetary landscape.

title: In Africa, Lessons on Passion and Perspective for Kershaw
description: PHOENIX  The Los Angeles left-hander Clayton Kershaw held the audience in his sway from the first pitch. A world removed from the grandeur of Dodger Stadium, the barefoot children stood in awe as they watched Kershaws curveball spin and dip.

title: How Buffetts Most Recent Big Deals Have Done
description: Berkshire Hathaway is, perhaps more than anything else, a giant deal machine, and Warren E. Buffett signaled in his latest investor letter that hes eager to make another big acquisition.

title: Held Hostage Off Somalia
description: A tally of vessels and their passengers and crew believed held by Somali bandits as of last week. All in all, 51 vessels and at least 819 people are believed to be held hostage.

title: In-Line Hockey: Still Rolling, but Not on a Roll
description: OLD BETHPAGE, N.Y.  Jonathan Mosenson has traveled the globe playing hockey on in-line skates. He is 24 and has competed in Italy, Germany, Argentina and Taiwan. He has won gold medals at world championships, receives free equipment from sponsors and is tested for performance-enhancing drugs. He wears a suit to the arena.

title: The Weeks Business News in Pictures
description: Photographs from news and features in business over the past week.

title: Everyones Talking About It (but Jeter)
description: TAMPA, Fla.  If Derek Jeter owns the largest home in Hillsborough County, then he probably has the most garbage, right?

title: Waiting Seven Years for Two Answers
description: WHEN Zella Mae Green of Georgia filed for bankruptcy to save her home from foreclosure in 2004, she and her lawyer wanted to know two things: Did she actually owe any back payments on her mortgage? And, if so, to whom?

title: Scorecard | Versace Wins!
description: When sexy is the root of the compound modifiers  supremely sexy, Versace-sexy  used most in the reviews, then you know Scorecard is really in Milan. On the third day of shows, which saw Dubai-based financial backers bring Gianfranco Ferr back from the brink, Rossella Jardini dialed Moschinos surreal provocation way back. Donatella Versace, meanwhile, went for a somewhat discreet vision of Gianni-baroque, proving the old adage to make new friends, but keep the old.

title: Want Clarity? Learn to Play Devils Advocate
description: This interview with Richard D. Fain, chairman and C.E.O. of Royal Caribbean Cruises, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

title: Genius Loves Company in N.B.A. Balance of Power
description: Contrary to growing sentiment, the recent migration of players to large N.B.A. markets to form cabals of superstar power is no more likely to wreck professional basketball than it is to ensure multiple championships for the teams that LeBron James and Carmelo Anthony decided to take their talents to.

title: A Corporate Sleuth Tries the Credit Rating Field
description: FEW people ever penetrate the dark side of money, but Jules Kroll is one of them.

title: Carrots, Sticks and Digital Health Records
description: THE United States is embarking this year on a grand experiment in the government-driven adoption of technology  ambitious, costly and potentially far-reaching in impact. The goal is to improve health care and to reduce its long-term expense by moving the doctors and hospitals from ink and paper into the computer age  through a shift to digital patient records.

title: Tosses and Turns of Yankees-Phillies
description: Tampa, Fla.

title: Set Against Black, Jil Sander Strikes a Nerve
description: Bumping into an old friend today, I heard him lament that fashion shows had become events  geared to the demands of social media and branding strategies  and had lost their charm. This is not an overnight change, but it feels that way. Designers are doing what they have to do, and not want they want to do, he said. And many collections this season seem overly influenced by films and fashion of the 60s and 70s. The other night, while searching for a Bob Richardson photograph of Donna Mitchell, I found one of Jill Kennington wearing a beige-pink shag fur coat virtually identical to the one Miuccia Prada showed. Oh, well, I thought. But this habit gives everything a kind of movie-still quality, even when there may not be a direct reference.

title: Moonlighting Within Microsoft, in Pursuit of New Apps
description: IF you have a smartphone, you probably have apps on it to check the news, play games, help with shopping or further a hobby like travel or bird-watching. But chances are that you dont yet have Bubblegum  a new app that lets you instantly dress up cellphone photos, tinting them in sepia or adding neon blue highlights, for instance, and then share the results on Facebook.

title: The Lands Autocracy Wont Quit
description: MOSCOW  Let the Middle East and North Africa be buffeted by populist discontent over repressive governments. Here in Lenins former territory, across the expanse of the old Soviet Union, rulers with iron fists still have the upper hand.

title: Letters: The Goals of New Taxes
description: The Goals of New Taxes

title: The Debate Thats Muting the Feds Response
description: MONETARY policy makers at the Federal Reserve have long been classified as hawks or doves. The distinction is appealing in its simplicity. Hawks care deeply about inflation, while doves are willing to risk inflation to reduce unemployment.

title: Suddenly, Emerging Markets Look Complicated Again
description: LATE last year, when demand for emerging-market stocks reached new heights, investors viewed the threat of global inflation as yet another reason to keep betting on them.

title: Buffett Finds a Friend, Sometimes, in the Fed
description: Warren E. Buffett is widely regarded as one of the savviest investors on the planet. But it was during the financial crisis that he struck one of his most lucrative deals: a $5 billion investment in Goldman Sachs that has paid out more than $1 billion in dividends so far.

title: But Who Will Grade the Grader?
description: IN this episode of the Haggler, a sobering look at the Better Business Bureau.

description: LOS ANGELES

title: Your Rsum, for All to See
description: YOU think you have a serviceable rsum. Maybe you have worked with a professional rsum writer, or at least have had someone read it over and give you feedback. But you still havent gotten a new job. Should you start a Web site, solely for job hunting, that features your rsum?

title: From Software to Satellites
description: I WAS born in Dayton, Ohio, the second of six children  five boys and one girl. My father, John, was a manager for a hydraulic lift truck business, and my mother, Geraldine, was a semi-professional dancer who later was a secretary in the Dayton police department and in the local county sheriffs office.

title: Canada Looks Past Boycott and Forward to Cyprus Cup
description: Tensions between Canadas womens national team and the Canadian Soccer Association have eased according to a published report that says the team has lifted its boycott threat.

title: Can Scientists Learn from Science Journalists?
description: Maggie Koerth-Baker, science editor of BoingBoing.net, gave a really good talk at the University of Wisconsin aiming to encourage scientists to communicate effectively with other human beings. A starting point: listening. Another: Start a blog.

title: Spider-Man Producers Mulling Another Delay for Opening Night
description: The producers of Broadways Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark are considering delaying the musicals opening night for a sixth time, people familiar with the deliberations say, to make more changes to the show in hopes of improving its worldwide commercial prospects after theater critics savaged it this month.

title: James Francos Oscar Prep, Captured by James Franco
description: LOS ANGELES Does it surprise anyone to learn that James Franco has had two guys filming every moment of his Oscar rehearsals?

title: The Fish Whose Bite Is as Fierce as Its Name
description: SEATTLE  The trucks delivering produce to Pike Place Market were still being unloaded when Dave McCoy, the owner of Emerald Water Anglers, picked me up at my hotel for a day of fishing. Soon we were driving south on Interstate 5. After a quick stop for coffee, we headed west across the Tacoma Narrows Bridge and then down a twisting country road. Coming around a bend, we saw the snow-covered Olympic Mountains jutting forth, resembling jagged dollops of meringue.

title: Why We Write About Grief
description: Grieving has always been a public as well as private act, and lately, it seems, people are increasingly writing memoirs about it.

description: MADISON, Wis.  Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin and other officials who are pushing to eliminate or weaken collective bargaining by government employees say their goal is to save millions of dollars and increase governments flexibility to run its operations.

description: WASHINGTON  The duty of the Justice Department is to defend statutes that have been passed by Congress, unless there is some very compelling reason not to, Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. said during his 2009 confirmation hearings.

title: Japans Arimura Leads Webb at HSBC
description: Japans Chie Arimura shot a one-under 71 for a one-stroke lead over Karrie Webb of Australia after the third round of the HSBC Womens Champions in Singapore on Saturday.

title: Fighting Words
description: Younger patients would be more likely than older ones to get the best kidneys under a plan being considered by the nations organ transplant network. The proposal would replace the current system  first come, first served with one that would provide better matches between life expectancies of patients and the functional life of donated kidneys.

description: JAY LENO

title: Back Then: 1964
description: Muhammad Ali, then known as Cassius Clay, upset the heavily favored Sonny Liston on Feb. 25 to win the heavyweight title. The Timess Robert Lipsyte was at the fight in Miami Beach:

title: Prime Number
description: 310: The number of basketball games Caltech lost in a row in the Southern California Intercollegiate Athletic Conference. The losing streak, which began in 1985, ended last week when the Beavers defeated Occidental at home 46-45 in the final game of the season. Not a record to write home about, but there is this: Thirty-one Caltech faculty or alumni have won 32 Nobel Prizes. (The chemist Linus Pauling won two: chemistry and peace.) Go Beavers!

title: Torre Selected by Selig as a Top Lieutenant
description: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz.  When Joe Torre retired from managing last September, he said, he did not expect his next job to be as intense as the one he has chosen. But Torre said Saturday that he was looking forward to life as a top lieutenant of Commissioner Bud Selig.

title: Baseballs New Top Cop: Joe Torre
description: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz.  When Joe Torre retired from managing last September, he said, he did not expect his next job to be as intense as the one he has chosen. But Torre said Saturday that he was looking forward to life as a top lieutenant of Commissioner Bud Selig.

title: Officer Denies Efforts to Sway Lawmakers
description: WASHINGTON  The spokesman for a three-star general accused of instructing troops to carry out psychological operations to sway visiting members of Congress said Saturday that the general was innocent of any wrongdoing.

title: As Embassies Close, People Flee Libya
description: An effort by Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi to prove that he was firmly in control of Libya appeared to backfire as foreign journalists he invited to the capital discovered blocks of the city in open revolt.

title: Swedes Begin to Question Liberal Migration Tenets
description: MALMO, Sweden  Nick Nilsson, 46, decided to vote for Swedens far-right party last fall because of a growing sense that his country had gone too far in letting so many immigrants settle here.

title: The Budget Fight Continues
description: In defense of their bill to slash federal spending by $61 billion over the next seven months, House Republicans claim they are trying to make the economy grow and create jobs. In truth, such deep and sudden cuts could derail the recovery, without ever addressing the real sources of budget deficits  mainly explosive health care costs and incessant high-end tax cuts.

title: Angry Arizona, Again
description: Many states are doing urgent business: jobs, the economy, broken budgets. Arizonas legislators are trying to give government new powers to strip away individual rights, to extend immigration enforcement into schools, public housing, hospitals and doctors offices.

title: Trashing the Lessons of Watergate
description: House Republicans, pandering to the new corporate money trough legitimized by the Supreme Court, have voted to kill off public financing for presidential elections. Unless the Senate Democratic majority acts forcefully, the death of the public alternative  first adopted in the wake of the Watergate scandal  could be sealed in the rounds of budget negotiations to come.

title: Joe Flom
description: Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom may be the worlds most influential corporate law firm. Now usually called Skadden, it is known by the family name of a long-gone partner and not by that of Joseph Flom, who built the firm into a global powerhouse by democratizing the elite practice of corporate law.

title: Rallies for Labor, in Wisconsin and Beyond
description: MADISON, Wis.  With booming chants of This will not stand! at least 70,000 demonstrators flooded the square around the Wisconsin Capitol on Saturday in what the authorities here called the largest protest yet in nearly two weeks of demonstrations.

title: Sunday: V-2
description: SUNDAYS PUZZLE  Do you play by the rules? Everyone has rules they have to live by in their everyday life, and puzzle constructors are no different. Rotational symmetry, maximum number of words and black squares, no words with fewer than three letters, yada yada yada.

title: Why Wouldnt the Tea Party Shut It Down?
description: NO one remembers anything in America, especially in Washington, so the history of the Great Government Shutdown of 1995 is being rewritten with impunity by Republicans flirting with a Great Government Shutdown of 2011. The bottom line of the revisionist spin is this: that 2011 is no 1995. Should the unthinkable occur on some coming budget D-Day  or perhaps when the deadline to raise the federal debt ceiling arrives this spring  the G.O.P. is cocksure that it can pin the debacle on the Democrats.

title: North Koreans Struggle, and Party Keeps Its Grip
description: SEOUL, South Korea  As military and political tensions persist on the Korean Peninsula, North Korea is trudging through another winter of shortages, bitter cold, not much food and precious little fuel.

title: Unfit for Democracy?
description: CAIRO

title: Learning From Buchanan
description: By mid-January 1861 a sleepless President James Buchanan contemplated the remaining seven weeks of his presidency. Above all, he hoped to avoid the outbreak of civil war. He had come to Washington as a northern Democrat who, through training, background and conviction, believed himself well positioned to solve the sectional crisis.

title: Have You Driven a Smartphone Lately?
description: DETROIT

title: How the Arabs Turned Shame Into Liberty
description: PERHAPS this Arab Revolution of 2011 had a scent for the geography of grief and cruelty. It erupted in Tunisia, made its way eastward to Egypt, Yemen and Bahrain, then doubled back to Libya. In Tunisia and Egypt political freedom seems to have prevailed, with relative ease, amid popular joy. Back in Libya, the counterrevolution made its stand, and a despot bereft of mercy declared war against his own people.

title: After a Record Haul in Maine, Try the Lobster Mac and Cheese
description: KENNEBUNKPORT, Me.  The dozens of traps that Ron Francoeur pulled from frigid waters here on Thursday held only about 30 lobsters, but maybe it did not matter. Last years statewide lobster haul  93 million pounds, up from 81 million in 2009  was the largest on record. And Mr. Francoeur allowed that he had shared in the bounty.

title: Taliban Bet on Fear Over Brawn as Tactic
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  This year the spring offensive by the Taliban and other insurgent groups has a new and terrifying face: the insurgents are using suicide bombers who create high casualties to sow terror and are planning an assassination campaign as well, Afghan and American military analysts say.
