description: Charleston, S.C.

title: On the Stump, Gingrich Puts Focus on Faith
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio  Newt Gingrich needs no introduction to most Republican audiences. It is the reintroduction that is the challenge.

title: A Spectacle of Muscle, Somewhat Muted
description: INDIANAPOLIS  Rule 1 of the N.F.L. scouting combine: dont talk about anything.

title: Utah Regroups
description: The Utah Jazz had an eventful February, losing its longtime coach, Jerry Sloan, to retirement and trading the superstar point guard Deron Williams to the Nets. With all the disarray, it was easy to not notice that as of Friday, the team was still eighth in the Western Conference, meaning if the season ended the Jazz would qualify for the playoffs.

title: Security Council Calls for War Crimes Inquiry in Libya
description: The United Nations Security Council voted unanimously on Saturday night to impose sanctions on Libyas leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, and his inner circle of advisers, and called for an international war crimes investigation into widespread and systemic attacks against Libyan citizens who have protested against the government over the last two weeks.

title: What We Learned in the Statehouse
description: With Americas governors gathering in Washington this weekend to discuss their ailing state budgets and other common problems, the Op-Ed editors asked four departing state leaders to single out difficulties their successors face  and to provide guidance on how to conquer them.

title: Theres No Business Like Show Business
description: Santa Fe, N.M.

title: As the Knicks Rearrange, They Focus on the Kinks
description: MIAMI  The Knicks hope is that pairing Carmelo Anthony with Amare Stoudemire will create a high-scoring union that will result in parades and confetti on Broadway. The reality, at least for now, arrived on a snowy night in Cleveland. A superstar again watched the final ticks from the bench as confusion rather than cohesion marked a deflating loss.

title: Bundesliga Gets Fourth Spot in Champions League
description: The German Bundesliga will have four places in the UEFA Champions League starting with the 2012-13 tournament. Its gain will come at the expense of Italys Serie A, which will have its allotment cut to three based on UEFAs five-year rankings of the leagues performances in Europe.

title: Q. and A. With Ivan Lendl
description: With his punishing topspin ground strokes, Lendl won eight Grand Slam singles titles, reached the final of at least one Grand Slam tournament for 11 straight years (Sampras is the only other man to do that), advanced to 19 Grand Slam finals (only Roger Federer has played in more), and was ranked No. 1 for 270 weeks (only Sampras and Federer have surpassed him). He is also familiar with the Garden: during the 13 years that the Masters Tournament was held there, Lendl reached a record nine straight finals, losing four times (including twice to McEnroe) but winning five (beating McEnroe once).

title: Q. and A. With Jim Courier
description: Jim Courier is a former No. 1 tennis player who won 23 Tour singles titles, including two French Opens and two Australian Opens, before he retired in 2000. Last October, Courier, 40, was named the captain of the United States Davis Cup team. The first round of the competition begins Friday, with the United States facing Chile in Santiago. JOE BRESCIA

title: Focus on Schools and Jobs
description: Nashville

title: Soldat Quiets Doubters in Fountain of Youth
description: HALLANDALE, Fla.  With every powerful stride that Soldat took in the stretch of the 65th running of the Fountain of Youth, the trainer Kiaran McLaughlin felt whatever doubts he had about his colt being pounded away. When the year began, McLaughlin wondered if Soldat was really a Kentucky Derby horse or if he was just hoping that he was.

title: Sabres Job of No. 1 Fan Is Taken
description: It is the dream of every sports fan to own his or her favorite team. For Terry Pegula, that dream has come true. Pegula, a Buffalo Sabres fan who had season tickets for 18 years, then became a billionaire in the energy business, completed his purchase of the team from Tom Golisano last week.

title: Movement at Combine, but Not at the Table
description: INDIANAPOLIS  The N.F.L. players union plans to decertify before the collective bargaining agreement expires at midnight March 4, unless a labor agreement can be agreed to in negotiations this week.

title: Match Play Comes Down to Two Golfers Who Rarely Blink
description: MARANA, Ariz.  It took four days of sorting through upsets, routs and skintight matches, but when it all shook out on Saturday at Dove Mountain, the two best players in the W.G.C.-Accenture Match Play Championship were in the finals.

title: Familiarity Breeds a Change in Routine
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  The Mets play 36 spring training games this year, and 22 of them are against three of their four National League East rivals, including five of the last six games of the spring. Because of that, Manager Terry Collins said he would have his starting pitchers throw their last starts against minor league competition to prevent the Atlanta Braves, the Washington Nationals and the Florida Marlins from getting too familiar with the pitchers they will face in the regular season.

title: Immigrant Communities of Sweden
description: Once seemingly immune to anti-immigrant sentiment, Sweden faces a growing sense that it allowed too many foreigners in.

title: Mets May Yearn for Another Pipeline
description: The cash shortfall that required the Mets to seek an emergency loan from Major League Baseball was not the first financial squeeze the team faced last year. And with spring training under way and players collecting paychecks again, it may not be the last.

title: Sweden's Immigrant Identity
description: One out of four Swedes are immigrants or have a parent with an immigrant background.

title: Bahrain Opposition Leader Returns From Exile
description: MANAMA, Bahrain  The leader of a banned opposition party returned from exile on Saturday and exhorted a crowd of tens of thousands of antigovernment protesters to continue demonstrating until they achieved a successful revolution.

title: Brigham Young Shows Off Its Supporting Cast
description: SAN DIEGO  Occasionally, the Heartbreakers steal the show from Tom Petty, Derek Fisher swipes the playoff spotlight from Kobe Bryant and the little-known Cheers barfly Paul zings a better one-liner than Norm or Cliff.

title: Villanova Is Merely Another Milestone for St. Johns
description: PHILADELPHIA  It has become commonplace this season for St. Johns to hear that it has just accomplished something for the first time since some long ago year.

title: Your Comments on my Arab Democracy Column
description: My Sunday column notes that there is a fair amount of anxiety about what a democratic revolution will mean in the Arab world, and specifically about whether the Arab world (and other less developed parts of the world) are ready for democracy. I find this entire debate patronizing, especially after witnessing the incredible courage of democracy activists in recent weeks. Sure, there are plenty of rough spots ahead but if people are dying for democracy, who are we to say that theyre not ready for it? Read the column and post your thoughts.

title: Corrections
description: METROPOLITAN

title: Tea Party Group Issues Warning to the G.O.P.
description: PHOENIX  While heaping scorn on President Obama and the Democrats for overspending, more than 2,000 members of the Tea Party Patriots gathered here for a national conference also had strong words on Saturday for Congressional Republicans and vowed to vote them out of office next year if they did not move aggressively to cut the budget.

title: Corporate Giants Received TIF Money, Records Show
description: During the mayoral campaign, Chicagoans heard a great deal about tax increment financing, including frequent criticism that the program, Mayor Richard M. Daleys favorite economic development tool, gave big tax breaks to downtown businesses and left neighborhoods short.

title: Emanuel Has a Tough Row to Hoe, but Far From an Impossible One
description: James Warren writes a column for the Chicago News Cooperative.

title: In Libyan Port, Stranded Migrants Watch Hope Depart
description: BENGHAZI, Libya  American and British citizens have been evacuating for days. The Chinese workers were on their way, and the Bosnians stood ready with their bags on the shore. But from the milky windows of stifling rooms in a makeshift camp, the migrant workers from other, poorer countries, stranded by war and, in some cases, forsaken by their employers, watched cruise ships  and salvation  depart.

title: A Port in a Storm
description: In Benghazi, migrant workers have gathered to wait for their way out of Libya.

title: How a Past Political Star Became an Also-Ran
description: JeNest Murry was not going to allow her teenage niece, Raven, to sit out the mayoral election. Right after work on Tuesday, Ms. Murray drove Raven to the polls. To stay home, Ms. Murry said, would have betrayed the past and the future.

title: Doctors Clear Kiwanuka
description: The Giants announced Saturday that defensive end Mathias Kiwanuka had been cleared by doctors to return to football activities after his 2010 season was cut short by a herniated disk in his neck. Kiwanuka was the Giants most versatile defensive lineman and had four sacks in his first three games, but the injury forced him onto injured reserve.

title: Vows: Jessica & Andrew
description: Jessica and Andrew fell in love exploring New York City together. Their relationship culminated in a quintessential New York moment with tourists applauding them as he proposed on a muggy summer day.

title: Wrist-Wrestling Statue
description: Bronze biceps are bulging at the intersection of East Washington Street and Petaluma Boulevard in downtown Petaluma. The statue commemorates Bill Soberanes, who founded the towns World Wristwrestling Championships.

title: Vintage Jet Crashes in Hudson Valley
description: Feb. 27, 2011, 7:28 p.m. | Updated A Cold War-era plane with a dragons face painted on its nose fell out of the sky on Saturday afternoon and crashed into the icy Hudson River in upstate New York.

title: Salt River Fields, the New Spring Sensation
description: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz.  Bud Selig is a 76-year-old from Milwaukee, so his frame of reference for any ballpark is County Stadium, the spartan former home of the Braves and the Brewers that did not even have an office for the visiting manager. Compare that with Salt River Fields at Talking Stick, the new spring home of the Diamondbacks and the Rockies, and its no wonder Selig gushed.

title: Governors Look for Means to Cope With Budgets
description: WASHINGTON  Democratic governors warned Saturday that federal budget cuts could crimp a fragile economic recovery, and governors of both major parties asked the Obama administration to give them more flexibility in running education and health care programs so that they could cope.

title: Lottery Numbers
Americas Cup Vanguards Begin Their Preparations
description: The worlds fastest yacht, which is too tall to sail under the Golden Gate Bridge, is scheduled to arrive in San Francisco on a freighter this week. The boat will be off-loaded in crated pieces and stored at Pier 80.

title: In Mayoral Race, Yee Makes Name for Himself as a Loner and a Workhorse
description: It is a peculiar ritual, as regular as the lunar calendar itself: During the Chinese New Year Parade held in San Francisco every year, Rose Pak, the Chinatown power broker who organizes the festival, paces the reviewing stand at the end of the parade route with a microphone in hand, joshing with elected officials that she likes  and haranguing those she does not  as they roll past in sparkling convertibles.

title: On Stage and Afterward, Spotlight on Apple in China
description: Mike Daiseys The Agony and the Ecstasy of Steve Jobs, a provocative monologue that challenges Apple Computer over labor conditions in the factories in China where the iPhone and other devices are produced, ends a successful run at Berkeley Repertory Theater today.

title: Zimbabwe Orphans Get Chicago Support
description: When Elizabeth Mhangami was 15, she helped administer polio vaccinations to children in rural Zimbabwe. The villages were not far from her hometown, Bulawayo, but today Ms. Mhangami can see that the short journey altered her perception.

title: Team Championship Rewards the Whimsical and the Skilled
description: Amateur team championships are held every year over the Presidents Day weekend in four cities, and they are the most popular tournaments of the year.

title: Jay Landesman, Beat Writer and Editor, Dies at 91
description: Jay Landesman, a writer and editor whose journal Neurotica analyzed the anxieties of postwar America and whose Broadway musical, The Nervous Set, has been called the first (and only) Beat musical, died on Feb. 20 at his home in London. He was 91.

title: First Game of the Spring Doesnt Change the Subject
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Manager Terry Collins took the first lineup card out to home plate, hot dogs were cooking on the grill, the sun was shining brightly and a couple of vultures were spotted circling overhead.

title: Colon and Chamberlain Open in Right Direction
description: TAMPA, Fla.  The company line is that individual results in exhibition games matter far, far less than the process of preparation, especially on lazy Saturdays in February when the regulars spend a few innings in the field, log a couple of at-bats and escape into the sunshine. Still, judgments are formed, opinions are developed and, as Manager Joe Girardi said, That doesnt mean that you cant open someones eyes now.

title: Spider-Man May Be Postponed Again
description: The producers of Broadways Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark are considering delaying the musicals opening night for a sixth time, people familiar with the deliberations say, to make more changes to the show in hopes of improving its worldwide commercial prospects after theater critics savaged it this month.

title: Sports Replay: Feb. 26
description: A look at the day in sports, from the basketball court to the baseball diamond.

title: Keeping the Lure of Street Crime on the Ropes
description: After budget cuts eliminated many school athletic programs in Toledo, Ohio, private boxing gyms have emerged to help offset the temptations of street life for the citys youth.

title: Caught in the Heat of Baghdads Protests
description: It was not a normal Friday in Baghdad.

title: Pro-Labor Rallies Around the Nation
description: Demonstrators gathered in cities around the country to show support for unions and Wisconsins workers.

title: The Vacuum After Qaddafi
description: CAIRO  Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi sounded a resonant warning, exhorting his dwindling supporters toward civil war.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu, Feb. 27
description: As protests for and against budget cutbacks continue in Wisconsin, state budgets are stealing the spotlight on the Sunday talk shows.

title: Reviving Carnival in Istanbul
description: Even in Istanbul, a city touted as a cultural mosaic, the sight of a few hundred costumed revelers parading through the streets in a pre-Lenten bash will certainly attract some attention.

title: Call for Protests in China Draws More Police than Protesters
description: BEIJING  A call for protests on Sunday in more than 20 Chinese cities resulted in a tiny turnout but an enormous law enforcement presence that led to police clashes with foreign journalists in Beijing.

title: Shes Got Props
description: While the young fashion editor Robbie Spencer is an old hand at mens wear (hes the senior mens wear editor at Dazed & Confused), he is equally interested in dressing women. Mens wear is instinctive, he says. But womens wear is a more exciting challenge, with much more variety and diversity. By diversity, in this case, he means two-tone furs and jewels that look like bugs.

title: Rebels in Libya Gain Power and Defectors
description: ZAWIYAH, Libya  The Libyan rebels challenging Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi demonstrated their increasing military coordination and firepower on Sunday, as defecting officers in the east took steps to establish a unified command while their followers in this rebel-held city, just outside the leaders stronghold in the capital, displayed tanks, Kalashnikovs and antiaircraft guns.

title: The Speech Writer Speaks
description: LOS ANGELES When the news came on Friday that the Oscar front-runner, The Kings Speech, would be re-cut in order to earn a PG-13 rating (its currently rated R, for some language), it didnt necessarily sit well with some of the people behind the film.

title: Model-Morphosis | Andreea Diaconu for Emporio Armani
description: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of Milan Fashion Week. Here, the model Andreea Diaconu before (left) and after (right) transforms, with makeup by Linda Castello. and hair by Oribe. (Drag the orange bar left to reveal the full transformation.)

title: The Last Days for a Music Store Where Vinyl Has Respect
description: Joe Long has tried closing his legendary Brooklyn music shop, Birdels Records, before.

title: Trends | The Mono Suit
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#24", 592, 490, true, chameleonData);

title: Cam Newton in His Words, Subject to Interpretation
description: Cam Newtons news conference at the scouting combine on Saturday was subject to interpretation  a Rorschach test for the news media. Was he too rehearsed? Was he sincere? This video gives you a chance to judge for yourself.

title: Now Screening | Marni
description: The fall 2011 collection from Marni at Milan Fashion Week.

title: T Trends | The Pleated Skirt
description: Not since "Lolita" has a schoolgirl staple looked this hot.

title: T Trends | Monochromatic Suits
description: T's fashion editor, Sara Moonves, explains how to rock a monochromatic suit.

title: A Defense of Acting on Ephemeral Sources of Heat
description: [1:01 p.m. | Updated  At the end of the post Ive added a very useful reaction from Ken Caldeira of the Carnegie Institution and Stanford University.]

title: Photos of the Moment | Marni
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#752", 592, 440, true, chameleonData);

title: Harvey Has It Both Ways
description: LOS ANGELES Harvey Weinstein, just how confident are you of The Kings Speechs chances going into today?

title: Qaddafi YouTube Spoof by Israeli Gets Arab Fans
description: JERUSALEM  A YouTube clip mocking Col. Muammar el-Qaddafis megalomania is fast becoming a popular token of the Libya uprising across the Middle East. And in an added affront to Colonel Qaddafi, it was created by an Israeli living in Tel Aviv.

title: Yanks Abroad: 10 Updates
description: Carlos Bocanegra

title: Tunisian Premier, Vestige of the Old Government, Resigns
description: MANAMA, Bahrain  Tunisias prime minister, a holdover from the government that was toppled last month, resigned Sunday after a weekend of violent protests that left five people dead in the capital, Tunis.

title: Mr. Brainwash Embraces Oscar Week
description: LOS ANGELES Among the biggest potential surprises at this years Oscars is the appearance of Banksy, nominated as director of Exit Through the Gift Shop. Hes staged an unconventional campaign, sometimes poking fun at the proceedings, but he is planning to attend the ceremony. Whether well recognize him or not is another matter.

title: A Prize The Last Airbender May Not Desire
description: LOS ANGELES In the lead-up to the Oscars, there are two awards shows where The Kings Speech was not a favorite: the Razzies and the Spirit Awards.

title: Abuse Often Follows Afghans to America
description: When she arrived in New York from Afghanistan last year to join her husband, an Afghan-American she had married in Kabul, Nadia K. was thrilled at the prospect of a new American life.

title: The Kings Speech Wins Big at the Oscars
description: Oscars Night

title: Now Screening | Dolce & Gabbana
description: The fall 2011 collection from Dolce & Gabbana at Milan Fashion Week.

title: King Lear Inspires a Riff on the Endurance of Time
description: There comes a point in Storm Still when even the most patient theatergoer will stop forgiving its faults. That point occurs when a man, naked except for a Tarzan-like loincloth, is spanked repeatedly by another character, then bent over a chair and sodomized with a walking stick  a stick that is thrown to the floor and picked up in the mouth of an actor portraying a dog.

title: Afghan Team Says NATO Killed Civilians in Strikes
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Afghan investigators said Sunday that they were convinced that NATO forces killed 65 civilians in airstrikes in eastern Afghanistan this month, a charge that, if true, would be one of the worst civilian casualty episodes of the war.

title: Israeli Panel Finds No Crime in 2002 Assassination
description: JERUSALEM  Nearly nine years after an Israeli assassination of a Hamas leader in Gaza killed at least 13 civilians and led to widespread international condemnation, a government-appointed panel of inquiry concluded Sunday that the operation was flawed but that the consequences did not stem from disregard or indifference to human lives.

title: Photos of the Moment | Missoni
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#916", 592, 440, true, chameleonData);

title: Trade Winds Off Ice, Crucial Loss on It
description: As the Rangers vie to make the playoffs, the franchises front office has been working to bolster the teams roster. The twin goals have been to retain future assets while emboldening the current teams postseason aspirations.

title: Scorecard | Jil Sander Wins!
description: The Laws of Fashion are funny things. Raf Simons took minimalism to the max via couture volumesat Jil Sander last season, and on the fourth day of the current shows Milans other master of chic sobriety, Bottega Venetas Tomas Maier, went curvilinear  yet Scorecard knows critics couldnt agree on whether his sixties-inspired silhouettes were mired in stasis or moved on. The designer for the house that Jil built, meanwhile, pared down his billowing volumes to tops and added sleek ski pants, proving to be an unstoppable force.

title: Duke Snider, a Prince of New Yorks Golden Age of Baseball, Dies at 84
description: Duke Snider, the Hall of Fame center fielder renowned for his home run drives and superb defensive play in the Brooklyn Dodgers glory years, died Sunday in Escondido, Calif. He was 84.

title: Prostate Guideline Causes Many Needless Biopsies, Study Says
description: Current guidelines for the early detection of prostate cancer recommend a biopsy for men whose P.S.A. rises rapidly, no matter what the initial level. But a new study says that the practice does not help patients find aggressive cancers and results in many unnecessary biopsies.

title: A Chat With Oscars Australian Cinderella
description: LOS ANGELES Oscar loves a Cinderella story, and this year one of the best has belonged to Jacki Weaver. A veteran Australian stage actress, Ms. Weaver hadnt been in a movie in a dozen years and was unknown in the U.S. until she starred in Animal Kingdom, the Australian indie crime drama from a first-time filmmaker that earned her a best supporting actress nomination. She has been a petite charmer on the circuit all season long. We spoke to her at a party for Sony Pictures Classics, the films distributor, on Saturday, and she revealed a bit of country pride. Its the first time an Australian has been nominated in an Australian film since Shine,' she said. Her Australian-designed gown had arrived only hours before, and it, too, was a Cinderella moment. It takes about six able-bodied people to lift me into my frock, she said. Im going to have to lean on my husband walking up the red carpet. As a first-time nominee, Ms. Weaver had no problem admitting that she really, really wanted to win, and sharing details of her acceptance speech strategy.

title: The Kings Speech Tops Oscars 2011
description: Oscars Night

title: A Reading of Schubert, Both Fiery and Fresh
description: The opening performances of Lincoln Centers Tully Scope festival at Alice Tully Hall were high-profile new-music programs, but the idea behind this nonthematic series is that it should touch on the breadth of New Yorks musical life. There will be a lot more new music, and early music as well. But on Saturday evening the festival set its sights on the 19th-century Viennese mainstream, presenting a Schubert recital by the pianist Emanuel Ax.

title: Young Players From England Secure a Trophy
description: We must continue to encourage junior bridge if the game is to survive, and in Britain, the Peggy Bayer Trophy for players under 20 and the Junior Camrose for those under 25 do just that. England, Northern Ireland, the Republic of Ireland, Scotland and Wales are eligible to send teams to compete in the two events, which this year concluded on Feb. 20.

title: Model-Morphosis | Dempsey Stewart for Marni
description: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of Milan Fashion Week. Here, the model Dempsey Stewart before (left) and after (right) transforms, with makeup by Tom Pecheux. and hair by Paul Hanlon. (Drag the orange bar left to reveal the full transformation.)

title: How Species Save Our Lives
description: When adding up the benefits from three centuries of species discoveries, Im tempted to start, and also stop, with Sir Hans Sloane. A London physician and naturalist in the 18th century, he collected everything from insects to elephant tusks. And like a lot of naturalists, he was ridiculed for it, notably by his friend Horace Walpole, who scoffed at Sloanes fondness for sharks with one ear, and spiders as big as geese! Sloanes collections would in time give rise to the British Museum, the British Library, and the Natural History Museum, London. Not a bad legacy for one lifetime. But it pales beside the result of a collecting trip to Jamaica, on which Sloane also invented milk chocolate.

title: Libyan Rebels Reinforce Boundaries in Zawiya
description: In Zawiya, a city 30 miles west of Tripoli, hundreds of people rejoiced in a central square on Sunday, while opposition leaders in Benghazi started to form a provisional government.

title: Raising a Milkshake to the Bride and Groom
description: HONG KONG  As classical Muzak blasted from a loudspeaker, Kelvin Kwong got down on one knee and declared his love for his fiance, Ashley Tse, in front of a rowdy media scrum. Their engagement party on Valentines Day was the inaugural event of a new and aggressively promoted nuptial service at McDonalds restaurants in Hong Kong, the first in the world to offer McWeddings.

title: Recalling a Revered Singer in Harlem
description: The mezzo-soprano Betty Allen was part of a generation of pioneering black female vocal artists who emerged triumphantly in the 1950s and 60s, a select group of greats including Leontyne Price, Shirley Verrett and Grace Bumbry. If Ms. Allen never achieved the status or the public renown of her sister singers, she was a distinguished performer who combined a rich voice with musical integrity and scrupulous diction; a devotee of American music; and a favorite of composers as varied as Virgil Thomson, Ned Rorem and Leonard Bernstein. As a conductor Bernstein recruited her often to sing with the New York Philharmonic. Yet she may have had her greatest influence as an educator who taught for decades at the Manhattan School of Music and directed the Harlem School of the Arts during 13 high-growth years, becoming its president emeritus in 1993.

title: Mahlers Third, Whimsy-Free Version
description: Unlike most of the audience, to judge from the clamorous ovation afterward, this lover of Mahlers Third Symphony found precious little to love in the grim, overcontrolled performance of the work by Valery Gergiev and the London Symphony Orchestra at Avery Fisher Hall on Friday evening.

title: Varied Music Legacies Find Much in Common
description: A New Orleans second-line beat, shaken and tapped on tambourines, started CubaNOLA: More Than the Spanish Tinge, the concert by Arturo OFarrill and the Afro Latin Jazz Orchestra on Saturday night at Symphony Space. Then a cowbell joined in, tilting the rhythm toward Cuba. It was the prologue to a concert devoted to musical kinships: between Cuba and New Orleans, and between generations.

title: In Milan, a Movie Obsession and a 1960s Tilt
description: I hope to be watching the Oscars tonight, at least the red carpet. It starts around 1 a.m. here. Meanwhile, Milans obsession with the movies this season persists. The music for Missoni this afternoon came from True Romance and Natural Born Killers, and the chaotic, pastel clothes brought to mind Juliette Lewis, though not specifically her character in the Oliver Stone film. The mood was girlish innocence verging to girlish wreck, with long silk-print and knit dresses, impressively fat cardigans, and maxi coats in multi-hued python. The colors seem to flood from a girls bedroom, or the bathrooms of a 1960s subdivision: baby yellow, mint green, pink, and violet. Angela Missoni threw them together, sometimes causing one to cringe (example: a crinkly violet knit pants outfit with a sick twinkle of Lurex). It was strong and little perverse, thanks to the pastel upchuck. The accessories also pointed to bad movie girls: floppy knit caps and adorable motorcycle boots in a collage of python and colors.

title: A First Wife Can Be So Stolid and Clueless and Plain and Pregnant
description: The strikingly attractive cover of The Paris Wife depicts a glamorous, poised-looking woman perched in a Paris cafe. She wears a belted, tailored dress reminiscent of the late 1940s or early 1950s. Her face cannot be seen, but her posture radiates confidence and freedom. The picture is interesting because it has absolutely nothing to do with the book it is selling.

title: Rich Talent and Promising Voices Well Rewarded
description: You are all so attractive, Im really sorry Im too old for you, Nora London said with a laugh before announcing the winners of the 40th George London Foundation Awards Competition, named for her husband, the renowned American bass-baritone who died in 1985.

title: Interpreting Several Phases of a Singular Creator
description: Schubert was the only composer represented in the program that the Takacs Quartet offered at the 92nd Street Y on Saturday night, but in no sense was there too much of a muchness about the affair. Midway through a three-concert series devoted almost entirely to Schuberts music  a previous program included a new piece inspired by a Schubert work  this consistently invigorating, satisfying ensemble offered three distinct views of a singular creator.

title: Monday: Kawasaki Competitor
description: MONDAYS PUZZLE  Help, Im surrounded by baby talk! And I thought I was out of that stage, parenthetically speaking. Or, speaking as a parent. Whatever.

title: For One Young Muslim the Path to Faith Is Rocky
description: Mooz-Lum, a drama by Qasim Basir about wrestling with faith  here its Islam  manages to avoid many pitfalls common to similar movies. What could have been a morality tale told through rigid contrasts proposes instead a series of diffuse challenges to its young black hero, not all of them from outside his religion.

title: Veterans With Quartets, Stretching Out in Sound
description: Lee Konitz and Ahmad Jamal, in their 80s now and radically stubborn survivors of most of jazzs history, each came with a quartet. But in both cases the rooms acoustics became the fifth member of the band. Saturday nights double bill at Rose Theater  the second night of a weekend stand at Jazz at Lincoln Center  was a study in sound: soft and loud, natural and amplified, furry and sharpened, as delivered and as echoed.

title: The World Spins (Bicycle Wheels, Too)
description: With a title like And All the Question Marks Started to Sing, there is much room for the imagination, and thats a fine thing. Performed by the Norwegian art collective Verdensteatret on Friday night at Dance Theater Workshop, this production continued the groups magical explorations into hybrid forms in which performance, installation, animation and sound unite for the good of art.

title: Skip the Sundae? Christie Is on the First Ladys Side
description: In the dessert wars, at least, Chris Christie and Mike Huckabee side with Michelle Obama, not Sarah Palin.

title: Paul Taylor Offers a Vision of the World Through Mirrors and Illusions
description: Paul Taylor is a major choreographer whose season at City Center has begun in a thoroughly minor way. There is no more dramatically imaginative choreographer today, and yet sometimes that imagination looks feeble. There is no choreographer who puts more remarkable dreamscapes onstage, and yet some of his dreams are trite.

title: Two Remembrances of One Deadly Day in 1911
description: ooo

title: The Truth About Pensions
description: Dean Baker has a deeply enlightening analysis of state pension shortfalls (pdf), containing a lot of stuff I didnt know. The basic moral is that the official story these days  of years and years of huge giveaways to unions, resulting in gigantic, unpayable debts  is just wrong: to a very large extent, the pension shortfall has emerged just since 2007, thanks to the financial crisis, and even then its not nearly as big relative to future state incomes as widely imagined. Heres a key figure:

title: Relocating Drama From Ice to Stage
description: Unlike baseball and golf, say, the sport of hockey has not inspired a particularly illustrious body of literature. There are only a handful of decent hockey novels, chief among them King Leary, by the Canadian writer Paul Quarrington, and Amazons, by one Cleo Birdwell, supposedly the first woman to play in the National Hockey League. Amazons is actually by Don DeLillo, but for years now he has disowned the 1980 pseudonymous work, which may indicate something of hockeys status among American literati, at least. By far the best book about hockey is still The Game, a memoir by the Hall of Fame goalie Ken Dryden that was published almost 30 years ago.

title: Two Winners, Two Potential Shows
description: It was perhaps Oprah Winfreys most personal giveaway to date. Ms. Winfrey announced on Friday that she would give television programs to Zach Anner and Kristina Kuzmic-Crocco, the finalists on Your Own Show, a televised competition that promised a program for the winner. The truth is that both of you really deserve to have your own show, Ms. Winfrey said on Fridays finale on OWN, her new cable channel. Mr. Anners win was notable because he had been vaulted into the competition by an Internet campaign by fans. Mr. Anner, who has cerebral palsy, said he wanted to host a travel show called Rollin Around the World With Zach Anner, a cheeky reference to his wheelchair. Ms. Kuzmic-Crocco wanted to host a cooking show. Development of both will begin soon, the channel said.

title: Oman Joins Protest Wave, and 2 Die in Clashes with Police
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Oman, the normally quiet sultanate along the southeastern coast of the Arabian Peninsula, joined the wave of two-month-old political protests shaking the Arab world on Sunday, as hundreds of demonstrators clashed with the riot police in the northeast port city of Sohar. Omans state news agency, ONA, said two protesters were killed.

title: A Gift for Art Institute
description: The Art Institute of Chicago has received a $10 million gift from the Jaharis Family Foundation to renovate and expand galleries devoted to Greek, Roman and Byzantine art, as well as to support acquisitions and special exhibitions of that art. The museum described it as the largest gift it had ever received in support of the arts of the ancient Mediterranean and Byzantine worlds. Michael and Mary Jaharis, who run the foundation along with their two children, are active in Greek-American cultural activities, and Mrs. Jaharis is a life trustee of the Art Institute, as well as an honorary trustee of the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York.

title: U.S. and Allies Weigh Libya No-Fly Zone
description: WASHINGTON  Obama administration officials held talks on Sunday with European and other allied governments as they readied plans for the possible imposition of a no-fly zone over Libya to prevent further killings of civilians by forces loyal to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi.

title: Fela! Heading to Nigeria
description: When Broadway musicals go on tour, Lagos, Nigeria, is not usually on the itinerary. But Fela!, the musical based on the life of the Nigerian performer and activist Fela Anikulapo Kuti, which ran for 14 months on Broadway and recently ended a three-month engagement in London, is headed next for Lagos, the hometown of its title character, who died in 1997. The lead producer, Stephen Hendel, said last month that he was in discussions to take the show to Lagos, and now there is a firm date. The production will run April 20 to 25 at the New Expo Center in the Eko Hotel. It will feature the original Broadway cast, including Sahr Ngaujah, above, as Fela and Lillias White as his mother, Funmilayo.

title: Gnomeo & Juliet Is Tops at Box Office
description: It was a bad weekend for bodily-function comedy. Hall Pass, the latest from Bobby and Peter Farrelly, was expected by movie analysts to top the North American box office with about $20 million in sales. But it fizzled in second place. Instead, the animated Gnomeo & Juliet (Walt Disney Pictures) (the lovers, above) rose to No. 1 in its third weekend with an estimated $14.2 million, bringing its total to about $75 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles box-office statistics. Hall Pass, starring Owen Wilson and Jason Sudeikis and filmed at a cost of about $35 million by New Line Cinema, sold $13.4 million, becoming the latest in a string of disappointments from the Farrelly brothers. The Liam Neeson thriller Unknown (Warner Brothers) sold an estimated $12.4 million for a two-week total of $42.8 million. Adam Sandlers Just Go With It (Sony Pictures Entertainment) was fourth with about $11.1 million, lifting its three-week total to $79.4 million. I Am Number Four, a teenage science-fiction thriller from DreamWorks Studios, rounded out the top five with about $11 million for a two-week total of $37.7 million.

title: French Awards Favor Polanski Film
description: Roman Polanski, whose film The Ghost Writer was snubbed by the Oscars, won a measure of solace on Friday when the French cultural elite showered that thriller with four Csars. The honors, Frances version of the Academy Awards, included a best directing nod for Mr. Polanski, who was vigorously supported by French celebrities when he was arrested in 2009 in connection with a 1977 sex charge in the United States and detained in Switzerland until he fended off extradition in July. I finished this film while in jail, so I would like to thank all the people who helped me and supported me until the very end, Mr. Polanski said in his speech, referring to his work completing the film while under house arrest. He also shared the Csar for best adapted screenplay with Robert Harris, while the film also captured awards for best editing and best score. But it was defeated for best picture by Of Gods and Men, about French Cistercian Trappist monks slain by Algerian fundamentalists. (That film was spurned by the Oscars in its foreign-language category.) Quentin Tarantino was also celebrated, receiving an honorary career award and a standing ovation.

title: Bringing Responsible Oversight to the Gas Drilling Boom

A portion of the proceeds from the performance will benefit the nonprofit Lifebeat, which helps educate young people about H.I.V.-AIDS prevention. ... Playwrights Horizons has announced complete casting for the premiere of David Greenspans Go Back to Where You Are, which begins previews on March 24. Mr. Greenspan, as previously announced, will star as a chorus boy from ancient Greece who, after 2,000 years in Purgatory, is sent back to earth, where he finds himself with a vacationing family in the Hamptons. title: The Anthropocene
description: The edges of historical eras tend to be fuzzy. It would be nice to think that someone awoke in Florence, Italy, one day in the late 1300s  perhaps as spring started and said, Today the Renaissance begins! We can be sure no one did, if only because historians discern such eras only in retrospect. The same is true of geological epochs. Humans existed when the Pleistocene ended and the Holocene began, 11,500 years ago. The geologic time scale, which defines geological periods, began to take its modern form only in the 19th century.

title: Developments in the Region
description: LIBYA Defecting Libyan military officers in the eastern part of the country took steps to establish a unified command, while rebels in several cities close to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafis stronghold in Tripoli continued to repulse repeated attempts by the government to retake them. Rebels also began making plans to tap revenue from the vast Libyan oil resources now under their control  estimated by some oil company officials to be about 80 percent of the countrys total. The Qaddafi government implicitly acknowledged for the first time that it feared elements of its military falling into rebel hands, as Colonel Qaddafis son Seif said in a television interview that the Libyan government had bombed its own ammunitions depots in the east. NATO allies discussed steps that included a possible no-fly zone over Libya.

title: Despite It All, a Night Worth Spending Time With
description: My vantage point for the Oscars was a newsroom set for Web television commentary, from which I watched broadcast television. So not the most visibility, but here is what I saw. The Oscars did the job, but then again, they had an awful lot of good movies to work with. At least eight of the movies were worthy of best picture in one way or another, and there were enough twists and turns to keep the show interesting. Cant say the same about the hosts, who were really a host, namely Anne Hathaway. She gamely soldiered along while James Franco did, um, what exactly? Mr. Franco tweeted about doing the Oscars, made movies about doing the Oscars, gave many interviews about being a host, but when it came time to do the actual Oscars, he entered the witness protection program. Perhaps we should draw some satisfaction from the fact that this time around, it was the man who had the job of standing there and looking pretty. But his frozen smile, punched-out gaze, made you wonder while he was there in the first place.

title: Tradition Emerges Victorious

The best picture win for The Kings Speech, and the corresponding win for Tom Hooper as best director over The Social Network and David Fincher, will be fussed over by critics and bloggers as a return to the Academys staid tastes. It could equally be called a win for Harvey Weinsteins aggressive campaigning  an unusually superstitious Mr. Weinstein pulled out every stop short of calling in the Queen to promote his comeback film; oh wait, he did get her seal of approval, along with Rupert Murdochs. title: A Mixed Bag of a Cultural Mash-Up
description: LOS ANGELES  So how did the Academy Awards do as a cultural mash-up? Not so hot. Though the hosts, James Franco and Anne Hathaway, joked about being the hip Oscars from the start of the show and then acted on it  Mr. Franco unleashed a torrent of backstage Twitter posts, and Ms. Hathaway mentioned drinking games  their performance drew decidedly mixed reviews, especially when compared with the riffing of the 94-year-old Kirk Douglas. The Auto-Tune the News segment was a bit of a head-scratcher. And the use of the fifth-grade choir from Staten Islands P.S. 22, a YouTube sensation known for its renditions of pop and indie songs, was denuded by singing Somewhere Over the Rainbow as the credits rolled. Dont get us wrong, it was still cute (and the shot of Melissa Leo singing along was sweet, especially after she dropped an obscenity in her remarks accepting her Supporting Actress Oscar). But it could have been much sharper. What did you think?

title: Frank Buckles, Last World War I Doughboy, Is Dead at 110
description: Frank Buckles, who drove an Army ambulance in France in 1918 and came to symbolize a generation of embattled young Americans as the last of the World War I doughboys, died on Sunday at his home in Charles Town, W.Va. He was 110.

title: Charlie Sheen Says Hell Sue CBS
description: In dueling interviews on network morning shows, Charlie Sheen told NBC News that he intended to sue CBS for stopping production on his hit comedy Two and a Half Men, and he took a drug test that ABC News revealed, which showed there were no drugs in his body for at least the last 72 hours.

title: So Long to Another of the Boys of Summer
description: With the death of Duke Snider on Sunday at age 84, the roster of living Dodgers from the Boys of Summer era and Brooklyns only World Series champion team continued to shrink.

title: Fabulous Dead People | Pauline Trigre
description: If Pauline Trigres only legacy were her grooming  the thin, perfectly drawn mouth; the magnificently shaped brows; the sculptured hair whooshed behind one ear  it would be quite enough. For brittle, Gallic chic she will always be the gold standard. You can still encounter the look in Paris if you know where to look (side streets in the far reaches of the 17th Arrondissement), but in New York the rigor, the discipline and the polish died when Pauline did, at age 93 in 2002.

title: Feb. 28: Updates on Libyas Revolt and Mideast Protests
description: On Monday, The Lede is following the uprising in Libya and protest movements across North Africa and the Middle East. Updates below mix alerts on breaking news with reports from bloggers and journalists on the ground. A stream of Twitter messages from the region is in this blogs right column.

title: An Aid Worker Writes: How Sustainability Works (or Doesnt) in Afghanistan
description: In Panjsher Province, just north of Kabul, on the riverbank tucked far below the steep green slopes of the surrounding mountains, is a micro-hydro power (MHP) station with the capacity to electrify two nearby villages of more than 2,000 families. But it has sat dysfunctional since it was built 10 years ago. The villagers once solicited the assistance of the Panjsheri mujahideen commander, Ahmad Shah Massoud, but to no avail. (The tomb of Mr. Massoud, who was killed in September 2001, lies just around the bend from the plant.)

title: The Rails Derby 10
description: A look at the contenders for the Kentucky Derby, listed in order of preference by Joe Drape. As Drape wrote in his column kicking off the Triple Crown season, Uncle Mo has done little wrong and merits the leading spot. You can follow Drape on Twitter.

title: Shares End the Month With Gains, Helped by Buffetts Comments
description: Stocks advanced on Monday as benchmark indexes notched a third straight monthly gain, helped by improving economic data and news of Warren E. Buffetts plans for more acquisitions.

title: Hutchison Plans $5.8 Billion Ports Offering
description: Hutchison Whampoa, the Hong Kong-based conglomerate controlled by the billionaire Li Ka-shing, said Monday that it would seek to raise $5.8 billion in a spin-off of its ports unit.

title: Abercrombie Not Yet Ready to Be an Ohio Player
description: Abercrombie & Fitch on Monday postponed a special meeting for shareholders over its proposal to move its reincorporation to Ohio from Delaware.

title: Monday Reading: Purchasing Travel Packages Online
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: Talk of a Faux Pas at a Weary Governors Ball
description: LOS ANGELES  Was it the lack of suspense at the Oscar ceremonies or just plain awards-season exhaustion that hung over the Governors Ball Sunday night? Perhaps a ho-humness that a British entry won best picture? Maybe the dark blue lighting was responsible for the low-key vibe. It was palpable, whatever it was.

title: Congressional Week Ahead: Budget Battles
description: Though for the moment, House Republicans and Senate Democrats have stepped back from the brink of a government shutdown, Congress must still pass a continuing resolution and send it to President Obama this week if the government is to continue operating after Friday.

title: U.N. Unveils Tool for Tracking Progress of Climate Talks
description: Well always have Cancn. Online, at least.

title: Now Screening | Giorgio Armani
description: The fall 2011 collection from Giorgio Armani at Milan Fashion Week.

title: Vain Glorious | No More Waity Katie by Butter
description: What: No More Waity Katie nail lacquer.

title: Obama Backs Easing State Health Law Mandates
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama, who has stood by his landmark health care law through court attacks and legislative efforts to repeal it, told the nations governors on Monday that he was willing to amend the measure to give states the ability to opt out of its most controversial requirements right from the start, including the mandate that most people buy insurance.

title: Thou Shalt Not Use Archaic Pronouns
description: This weekend, co-vocabularists have generously proposed eleventh commandments.

title: What Were Reading
description: An aggregation of links by the reporters and editors of Diners Journal.

title: Protests in Oman Spread From Port City to Capital
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Demonstrators blocked roads and held rallies on Monday in Oman, a normally quiet oil-rich country along the southeastern coast of the Arabian Peninsula, as three-day protests calling for political reforms and better living conditions spread to Muscat, the capital.

title: Model-Morphosis | Sara Blomqvist for Missoni
description: The photographer Greg Kessler captures the transformations of New York Fashion Week. Here, the model Sara Blomqvist before (left) and after (right) transforms, with makeup by Lucia Peroni for M.A.C. and hair by Eugene Souleiman for Wella. (Drag the orange bar left to reveal the full transformation.)

title: Experience, Not Winning, Matters for Derby Hopeful
description: HALLANDALE, Fla.  You dont see many old-school prep races these days, the kind in which a trainer takes a talented horse to a race and doesnt really care if he wins. The trainer is looking for seasoning and fitness.

title: Is Thunderbolt Really a Thunderbolt?
description: A big hat tip to Farhad Manjoo of Slate, who first raised doubts about the value of Thunderbolt in this post. My two cents are below.

title: The Limits of Laws as a Conservation Tool
description: Peter Gleick, a water and energy analyst and founder of the Pacific Institute, has postedan impassioned critique of discussions in California on whether it will be necessary to let some imperiled species go extinct as part of broader efforts to manage human and ecological systems there. Heres the opening section:

title: Hearsts Manilla Aims to Handle Household Bills
description: There are many ways to manage your finances online, but many of them handle only the paying of run-of-the-mill bills. A site starting in beta-test mode on Monday, called Manilla, is aiming for something broader.

title: Photos of the Moment | Giorgio Armani
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#704", 592, 440, true, chameleonData);

title: E.V.s Are Here, but Can Utilities Handle the Load?
description: Electric cars are starting to roll out across the United States, and early predictions suggest they will cluster in certain ZIP codes where there is a mixture of affluence, early-adopter enthusiasm and environmental awareness. California, perhaps not surprisingly, is at the epicenter.

title: Dr. Richard Daines, Former Health Commissioner, Dies at 60
description: Dr. Richard F. Daines, the former state health commissioner who presided over hospital downsizing, the fight against swine flu and an unsuccessful attempt to enact a soda tax, died Saturday at his family farm in Dutchess County.

title: Violence Reigns With No Apologies
description: Its tough to take yourself seriously when youre writing about video games with names like Bulletstorm and Killzone 3. Thats probably a good thing. Plenty of other titles provide ample grist for discussion of weighty topics like the place of video games in the artistic firmament and the evolving modalities of personal entertainment.

title: A Tax Strategy for 529 College Savings Accounts
description: In last weekends Your Money column, I wrote about all the tax breaks that disproportionately benefit the upper middle class and how many of them were likely to come under the microscope soon.

title: Talkin Baseball and the Knicks
description: There is a whiff of the past in the air today, particularly in New York, where whiffs of things in the air are not usually pleasant. Mixed with mourning over the death of Duke Snider are warm, rekindled memories of a team called the Brooklyn Dodgers. And mixed with analysis of the Knicks victory over the Heat Sunday is a flashback to a time when New York boasted a relevant, exciting N.B.A. team.

title: Tax Break Raises Consumers Income, but Spending Still Falls
description: In December Congress voted to temporarily slash payroll taxes, in an effort to give consumers more pocket money to go out and stimulate the economy. So far the tax break has indeed put more money in consumers wallets, but early evidence indicates that it hasnt yet been enough to increase spending.

title: Investors Are Drawn Anew to Digital Music
description: Since it emerged in the 1990s, digital music has been hugely popular with fans, but for online music companies and their investors it has almost never been profitable.

title: St. Joe to Replace Four Directors With Berkowitz Nominees
description: The St. Joe Company said on Monday that it had struck an accord with its biggest shareholder, Fairholme Capitals Bruce Berkowitz, and would add his four board nominees as new directors.

title: French Aid Bolsters Libyan Revolt
description: PARIS  France is moving quickly to side with the forces trying to overthrow the Libyan leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, sending planes on Monday with aid and doctors to eastern Libya.

title: For a Late-Blooming Billy Elliot, Audition Is Crucial to Admission
description: Los Angeles, along with New York, is popularly seen as the prototypical make-it-or-break-it town for actors, where young thespians go to pursue their dreams  at the risk of a long-term career in waiting tables.

title: Space Tourism May Mean One Giant Leap for Researchers
description: If all goes as planned, within a couple of years, tourists will be rocketing into space aboard a Virgin Galactic space plane  paying $200,000 for about four minutes of weightlessness  before coming back down for a landing on a New Mexico runway.

title: The Claim: Side Stitches? Change Your Posture
description: THE FACTS

title: Now Screening | Giorgio Armani
description: The fall 2011 collection of Giorgio Armani at Milan Fashion Week.

title: Big Love Watch: So Many Questions, So Little Time
description: We are now really down to the wire. Next Sunday HBO will broadcast one of the last episodes of Big Love, and the most recent installment on the walk-up to the finale ended with the very real possibility that Bill Henrickson would find himself in the slammer.

title: Egypt Prosecutor Sharpens Case Against Mubarak
description: CAIRO  Egypts public prosecutor on Monday froze the domestic assets of former President Hosni Mubarak and his immediate family and barred them from leaving the country, answering the public clamor that the deposed first family account for suspected ill-gotten gains.

title: Oscars Mom
description: Show of hands  how many of you repeated, or tweeted, or felt a stab of guilt at Tom Hoopers acceptance speech for Best Director last night? How many of you called your mother?

title: Lower Manhattan, 8:09 A.M.
description: Barry Greenberg, a teacher, addresses reporters at a news conference in front of Public School 126 on Catherine Street in Lower Manhattan, as Michael Mulgrew, president of the United Federation of Teachers, right, watches. The news conference was called in response to the citys release on Sunday of a list estimating the number of teachers each school could lose to layoffs if seniority rules are not changed and more state money is not forthcoming.

title: A Celebrity Force Field at the Vanity Fair Party
description: LOS ANGELES  The Governors Ball may have been sleepy, but the other must-stop Oscars afterparty, thrown by Vanity Fair at the Sunset Towers, had wind-up energy. At its height it felt like a starry sea where everyone from Hollywood and the worlds it touches  which is all of them  bobbed in to do a lap.

title: Pension Funds Strained, States Look at 401(k) Plans
description: Lawmakers and governors in many states, faced with huge shortfalls in employee pension funds, are turning to a strategy that a lot of private companies adopted years ago: moving workers away from guaranteed pension plans and toward 401(k)-type retirement savings plans.

title: Early Oscar Ratings Suggest Slightly Fewer Viewers Than Last Year
description: The Oscars appear to have dodged a bullet. In a difficult year for the ABC telecast  two youthful and untested hosts and a group of top races with heavy favorites  early ratings from 56 markets were down only a smidge from last year. Among adults 18 to 49 in these markets, the 83rd Academy Awards posted a 14.5 rating, down from 14.8 last year, according to Nielsen. ABC wont have national ratings, which will include information about millions of viewers, until about 3 p.m. Eastern time on Monday.

title: Salon.com Merger Talks Collapse
description: 8:20 p.m. | Updated

title: Five Grains for Exotic Home Meals
description: In the latest Recipes for Health, Martha Rose Shulman explores the exciting offering of grains now available to home cooks.

title: This Weeks Health Industry News
description: The week begins with a meeting of some of the nations for-profit hospitals, talking public policy and business in the nations capital. The Federation of American Hospitals, which represents investor-owned or for-profit hospitals, is holding its annual conference this week.

title: Q. and A. With Stuart Elliott
description: Q: (Reader)

description: Our friends at DealBook have all the details:

title: Macys Wants to Be a Spring Break Star
description: The department store known for wholesome fare like Miracle on 34th Street and its annual Thanksgiving Day parade is getting frisky in a test campaign aimed at students.

title: Accounts and People of Note in the Ad Industry
description: Matt Bonin joined the Playa del Rey, Calif., office of TBWA/Chiat/Day in a new post, executive director for integration. He had been executive producer at Tool of North America, Santa Monica, Calif. TBWA/Chiat/Day is part of the TBWA Worldwide division of the Omnicom Group.

title: Preventing Side Stitches
description: As every runner knows, a painful side stitch can quickly ruin a workout. In todays Really? column, Anahad OConnor explores recent research that suggests side stitches are related to poor running posture.

title: Taking a Crack at Social Media
description: Its no secret that many small-business owners struggle with social media. Beyond leaving the occasional post on Facebook or Twitter, theres lots of confusion about how its supposed to work. Heres a nice example of how a small company creatively and efficiently built some brand buzz.

title: Anant Pai, 81, Is Dead; Comics Told Indian Children Their Countrys Stories
description: MUMBAI, India  Anant Pai, the creator of a popular comic book series that taught several generations of Indian children the countrys history and mythology, died here on Thursday. He was 81.

title: Heaven Help Us: Douglas Carter Beane Joins Sister Act Creative Team
description: Sometimes even those with a direct line to the Almighty need a little assistance here on earth. That includes the creative team of Sister Act, the coming Broadway musical adapted from the 1992 Whoopi Goldberg comedy, which said on Monday that Douglas Carter Beane would join its roster to provide additional material to the shows book.
