description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#960", 592, 440, true, chameleonData);

title: Putting Bankers In Spotlight At Oscars
description: Charles H. Ferguson, director of the Academy Award-winning documentary 'Inside Job', used his acceptance speech to decry the lack of punishment for bank executives after the financial crisis.

title: Supreme Court Halts Mayors Push for Hybrid Taxis
description: The Bloomberg administration has banned cars from Broadway, prohibited smoking in public parks, and cracked down on fats and salts in restaurants.

title: Immunity Gone, Contractor in Iraq Sentenced to Prison
description: BAGHDAD  A British contractor who admitted to murdering two other foreign contractors was sentenced by an Iraqi court on Monday to 20 years in prison, the first sentence imposed on a Westerner here since Saddam Hussein was overthrown in 2003.

title: Suze Rotolo, Muse and Girlfriend to Bob Dylan, Dies at 67
description: Suze Rotolo, who entered into a romantic relationship with Bob Dylan in the early 1960s as his career was just getting started and, in one of the signature images of the decades, walked with him arm-in-arm on the cover of his groundbreaking second album, The Freewheelin Bob Dylan, died on Thursday at her home in Manhattan. She was 67.

title: What Were Reading: Madoff Tapes
Rarest of the Rare: Javan Rhinos
description: .The World Wildlife Fund and Indonesian park officials have released video of Javan rhinoceroses obtained from camera traps in Ujung Kulon National Park, which is thought to be the last refuge of the critically endangered species. The video clips show young calves and a mother, implying the species, which once ranged through much of Southeast Asia but is now down to a few dozen individuals, is hanging in there.

title: Beltran Moves to Right Field; Pagan to Play Center
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  After 13 years and 1,563 games as one of baseballs premier center fielders, Carlos Beltran will now become a right fielder.

title: Not Enough Bureaucrats
description: Theres a new article in the Washington Monthly making the point that we need federal bureaucrats to manage spending, including spending on private contractors, and that understaffing the government  which were doing already, and will do more of if the right gets its way  actually increases the deficit. I agree. And with perfect timing, we have a new report finding that tens of billions have been wasted on undersupervised contractors in Iraq and Afghanistan.

title: Honda Repeats, Ford Surges and Mercedes Tumbles in 2011 Consumer Reports Study
description: Japanese automakers continue to make the best vehicles in the world, according to Consumer Reports in the magazines annual Automaker Report Card feature, but Ford is gaining.

title: Experiment on 2001 Space Shuttle Flight
description: Joshua Colwell's experiment in 2001 aboard the space shuttle attempted to understand how dust grains in the early solar system stuck together through low-speed collisions.

title: Preschool Wardrobe Wars
description: When my son was in preschool he refused to wear pants. No, he didnt go naked, but even when there was snow on the ground, he insisted on wearing shorts. I fought daily battles for awhile, until I realized that my real objection was not to the shorts themselves, but rather to the nasty looks I was getting from the other mothers. So he wore shorts every day. For years.

title: When 9/11 Memorial Opens, What About the Tour Buses?
description: Five million visitors a year are expected to pour into Lower Manhattan after the National September 11 Memorial and Museum opens later this year, a powerful symbol of the neighborhoods newfound vitality in the decade since the attacks.

title: Inflation Theorists
description: Christy Romer has a piece framing the inflation debate in terms of empiricists versus theorists. Id say shes being too nice.

title: When Dementia Drains the Pocketbook
description: Wendy Miller first became alarmed when her mother began complaining during their phone conversations. Im spending so much money, she fretted. I cant figure out why I dont have any money. This was a departure: Ms. Millers mother, always responsible about her finances, never liked talking about them. Ms. Miller wondered what was going on.

title: Pirates Hijack Vessel Carrying 7 Danes, Including 3 Children
description: Pirates in the Arabian Sea hijacked a yacht carrying seven Danish citizens, including three children, the Danish government said Monday, in the first reported attack on a small pleasure vessel since four Americans were killed by their pirate captors last week.

title: Fewer Voters From Union Households in 2010
description: Voters from union households are fresh off an election in which their turnout nationally was down significantly from previous years, and since they tend to favor Democratic candidates, that perhaps partly explains why Republican lawmakers in several states have singled out public-sector unions as a way to reduce budget deficits.

title: Glencore Moves Closer to I.P.O.
description: Glencore, the worlds largest commodities trader, is reaching out to analysts and investors as it readies for a potential initial public offering in London, said two people with knowledge of the matter.

title: Asset Manager Sues Over The Big Short
description: Michael Lewis, author of The Big Short

title: Baronoff to Lead Merrills M.&A. Team Again
description: Bank of America Merrill Lynch will again hand the reins of its mergers and acquisitions group to Steven Baronoff as the teams current head, Jeffrey Kaplan, will leave to join the hedge fund Appaloosa Management, the firm said in an internal memorandum obtained by DealBook.

title: In France, Michelin Dims Its Galaxy of Three-Star Restaurants
description: Michel Tramas Aubergade in Puymirol, in southwest France, lost one of its three stars in Michelins 2011 guide to France, and five other restaurants joined the galaxy of two-star recipients.

title: Sheen Talks Rehab, Money and Instant Coffee
description: Since production of Two and a Half Men was suspended last week, the shows star, Charlie Sheen, has been averaging one interview each day.

title: A Conquering Climax to a Tribute to Mahler
description: Avery Fisher Hall can be hard on an orchestra. Lush sound sometimes turns arid in the big box, and even the loudest, most dramatic moments can feel flat. The tough part isnt exactly filling the space but rather making the sound seem to live.

title: Excerpt: London Symphony Orchestra
description: An excerpt from the Adagio movement from Mahler's Symphony No. 10, led by Valery Gergiev, at Avery Fisher Hall on Sunday.

title: Exclusive First Look | YSL Manifesto
description: Its that time of the year again  when Stefano Pilati, the creative director of YSL, takes his vision to the streets. For the eighth season in a row, YSL is distributing its Manifesto publication on the streets of Paris, New York, London, Milan, Tokyo, Hong Kong and, for the first time, Los Angeles.

title: Where Lawyers Earn the Most
description: Silicon Valley has the highest paid lawyers in America, earning an average annual wage of $192,020.

title: Oscar Spotlight Puts Wall Street Under Harsh Light
description: Charles H. Ferguson, director of the Academy Award-winning documentary Inside Job, used his Oscars acceptance speech to decry the lack of justice in the aftermath of the financial crisis. In an interview with DealBook editor Andrew Ross Sorkin before Sundays ceremony, Mr. Ferguson expands on the regulatory shortcomings.

title: Climate Change Takes Toll on the Lodgepole Pine
description: Rising temperatures, drought and the spread of destructive insect pests will shrink the North American range of the lodgepole pine nearly 10 percent by 2020, a new study finds.

title: A Proposal to Reconstruct a Destroyed Afghan Buddha
description: German scientists said on Friday that it might be possible to reconstruct the smaller of the two Bamiyan Buddhas destroyed in Afghanistan by the Taliban in 2001, Agence France Presse reported.

title: The Perfect Futility of Basketball Analytics
description: Those in the world of basketball analytics are tasked with the impossible: to convert a complex game of interrelated and inextricable factors into simple measures of player and team performance. Theres no question that the efforts to develop those measures have intensified in the last few years, but despite every advance toward the coveted one-number metric - a single rating that can accurately describe a players impact on the floor or a teams relative standing - basketballs answer to sabermetrics comes with limitations and caveats. No stat in basketball is perfect, regardless of the complexity of its formulation.

title: U.S. Freezes a Record $30 Billion in Libyan Assets
description: WASHINGTON  The United States has blocked $30 billion in Libyan government assets since President Obama announced his executive order late Friday night imposing unilateral sanctions against Colonel Muammar el-Qaddafi and his family, the Treasury Department said Monday. It is the largest amount of foreign assets ever seized in an American sanctions action.

title: The 5-Second Rule
description: Q. You know the five-second rule for dropped food? Is it really safe if you pick it up in time?

title: Mobile App Revenue to Reach $38 Billion by 2015, Report Predicts
description: It may be hard to remember, but when the Apple iPhone had its debut in early 2007 there were only a few apps available for the device  no Angry Birds, Doodle Jump or Netflix.

title: Flexisexuals
description: Straight women who experiment with their (bi)sexuality.

title: Geneva Auto Show: Volkswagen Bulli Concept
description: GENEVA  Is Volkswagen trying to Bulli disgruntled fans of the brand into a rapprochement? Here, on the eve of press previews, it rather looks like it.

title: Where Call Reception Fades for Pilot Whales
description: Pilot whales are highly social creatures that communicate extensively with one another through tonal calls.

title: Auto Executives Brace for Oil Price Increases
description: GENEVA  The chief executives of BMW and PSA Peugeot Citron warned Monday that the auto industry would have to prepare itself for permanently higher fuel prices and said they would work together to develop new hybrid propulsion systems.

title: Burnett Checks On Golson After Beaning
description: TAMPA, Fla.  A. J. Burnett made sure to stop by outfielder Greg Golsons locker in the Yankees clubhouse Monday morning to check on him after a scary moment Sunday, when Burnett beaned him in batting practice.

title: Life, Liberty and the Pursuit of Vaccines
description: Recently I found myself on the outskirts of an antivaccine rally in my hometown, listening to a succession of ill-informed diatribes with a mixture of dismay and fascination.

title: 18 Stethoscopes, 1 Heart Murmur and Many Missed Connections
description: BOSTON  One by one, the medical students bent down to listen to my heart.

title: Out of Albany, Ravitch Is Writing Memoir
description: Richard Ravitch, the former lieutenant governor, has finally escaped Albany, with its never-ending budget messes and grinding dysfunction. But he hasnt stopped thinking about it.

title: Lasers Rise as Threat to Retinas
description: So far, the reports have been scattered and anecdotal. But eye doctors around the world are warning that recent cases of teenagers who suffered eye damage while playing with high-powered green laser pointers are likely to be just the first of many.

title: Parasitic Disease: Guinea Worm Takes a Step Closer to Eradication, Jimmy Carter Says
description: The guinea worm is a spaghetti-thin parasite that has proved notoriously hard to eradicate around the world. Now former President Jimmy Carter, who has led a 25-year campaign against guinea worm disease, is reporting progress in the effort to make it only the second human disease to be eradicated, after smallpox.

title: Natalie Portman, Oscar Winner, Was Also a Precocious Scientist
description: The Intel Science Talent Search is considered the nations most elite and demanding high school research competition, attracting the crme de la milk-fats-encased-in-a-phospholipid-and-protein-membrane of aspiring young scientists. Victors and near-victors in the 69-year-old contest have gone on to win seven Nobel Prizes in physics or chemistry, two Fields Medals in mathematics, a half-dozen National Medals in science and technology, a long string of MacArthur Foundation genius grants  and now, an Academy Award for best actress in a leading role.

title: For Tendon Pain, Think Beyond the Needle
description: Two time-honored remedies for injured tendons seem to be falling on their faces in well-designed clinical trials.

title: In Store | Impulse Buying at Macys
description: As the head fashion honcho at Macys, Molly Langenstein is charged with creating an exciting experience for a new generation of shoppers, which translates into trendy lines, hot designer collaborations and a hip new private label. View interactive >>

title: In Wisconsin, Flinging Blame and Citing Deadlines
description: MADISON, Wis.  Time may or may not be running out to make some crucial decisions in the Wisconsin fight over labor unions and budgets. But the blame game is definitely coming to a boil.

title: Opposition in Yemen Supports Protesters
description: SANA, Yemen  Yemens political opposition rejected an invitation from President Ali Abdullah Saleh to form a national unity government and instead threw its support for the first time behind street protests calling for an immediate end to his authoritarian rule.

title: 12 Ways to Use The Times to Develop Math Literacy
description: Math may not be the first thing that comes to mind when you think about using The New York Times for teaching and learning, but the newspaper lends itself to math just as naturally as it does to other subjects. Here are a dozen engaging ways to use The Times any day to foster mathematical understanding and skills. And if you have other ideas, please share them using the comment box below.

title: Three Follow-Up Thoughts (and One Recipe)
description: MSNBC is doing a poll about whether GMO foods should be labeled. Regardless of the origins of that idea (possibly here?), Im glad its happening. Go vote.

title: U.S. Readies Military Options on Libya
description: WASHINGTON  The United States began moving warships toward Libya and froze $30 billion in the countrys assets on Monday as the administration declared all options on the table in its diplomatic, economic and military campaign to drive Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi from power.

title: Whole Grain Goodness, Straight From the Oven
description: The muffins available in most coffee shops and cafes are like oversize, unfrosted cupcakes: too sweet and too big. But muffins dont have to be cloying  a bit of natural sweetener is all thats required to make them taste like a treat. And they dont have to be calorie-laden confections.

title: Commercial Real Estate Breathes Life Into a Moribund Market
description: A crucial part of the securitization market  the Wall Street credit machine that helped set off the financial crisis  is kicking back into gear.

title: Small Airports, Left Behind
description: Residents of some of Americas smaller cities may face a tough choice in the future: pay increasingly high fares to board a plane close to home or drive farther to a bigger airport with lower ticket prices.

title: Lord, Make Us Thrifty, but Not Yet
description: Following up on my earlier post on the fall in American consumer spending: The flip side of the declining spending numbers is that the personal savings rate increased in January. Households had a saving rate of 5.8 percent (measured as the share of disposable income not spent), up from 5.4 percent in December.

title: TimesCast | February 28, 2011
description: Airstrikes in eastern Libya; world leaders pressure Colonel Qaddafi to resign; the cost of speaking out against him.

title: Lawyers Attack Part of Medicaid Panels Plan
description: The members of Gov. Andrew M. Cuomos Medicaid task force were full of praise last week for the deal on Medicaid cuts they presented to Mr. Cuomo.

title: Jury Can Hear Dying Mans Words, Justices Say
description: WASHINGTON  A mortally wounded mans identification of his assailant may be repeated by police officers in court, the Supreme Court ruled on Monday.

title: Get in Line | The Chlo Billie Bag
description: The call for clean lines and bold colors was broadcast loud and clear last week in Milan. If the new Prada collection is any indication, Mondrianesque geometry and mod color blocking are certain to have a place in every womans wardrobe come fall.

title: Buzz Tracker
description: Madoff, the Jailhouse Tapes The convicted fraudster Bernard L. Madoff, in an interview with New York magazine, talks about his Ponzi scheme. At times, he seems remorseful, even asking his therapist: Am I a sociopath? New York

title: Radio for the YouTube Era?
description: The Internet has inspired people to create and share media to an unprecedented degree, through the prose of blogs, Twitters 140-character haikus, cellphone photography and the short-form videos of YouTube.

title: From Charlie Chaplin to Wheres Charley?
description: Rob McClure, an actor who just played Charlie Chaplin in a world premiere musical but has comparatively few New York credits, has snagged the title role in Wheres Charley?  the part that won a Tony Award for Ray Bolger  in the final production in the 2010-11 Encores! season of underappreciated musicals.

title: Fighting to Stay in the Game
description: TROIS-RIVIRES, Quebec  In a dimly lighted corridor of the dingy, old arena, Donald Brashear, an N.H.L. enforcer for 16 years, said he was playing in the rough-and-tumble Ligue Nord-Amricaine de Hockey because he still loved the game. And though this Quebec league is widely regarded as the worlds toughest, Brashear said he was not in it to fight, but to play hockey the way I did when I started  making passes, scoring goals.

title: In Quebec, Love for a Tough League
description: Despite the wildness, the antique rinks and the modest skill level, the Ligue Nord-Amricaine de Hockey has drawn a surprising number of former N.H.L. players.

title: Maternal Link to Alzheimers Makes a Gain
description: Alzheimers disease is more common in people whose mothers had the illness than in those whose fathers had it  and the evidence can be found in the brains of people who are still healthy.

title: Dinosaur-Hunting Hobbyist Makes Fresh Tracks for Paleontology
description: Last week, Mike Taylor identified a new dinosaur called Brontomerus mcintoshi, a sauropod with uncommonly large, powerful thighs.

title: In London, U.S. Art Enjoys Diplomatic Showcase
description: LONDON  Winfield House, which has been home to American ambassadors here since 1954, is a stately neo-Georgian mansion nestled in 12  acres in the northwest corner of Regents Park. Originally built for Barbara Hutton, the Woolworth heiress, in the 1930s, it was sold to the United States government for $1 shortly after World War II. Its imposing facade has not always been appreciated by the British; in 1937, when it was still under construction, the venerable British journal The Architectural Review described the redbrick structure as pinkly glowing like an open sore.

title: The Emotions That Get Lost in Budget Discussions
description: Carl Richards is a certified financial planner in Park City, Utah. His sketches are archived here on the Bucks blog and on his personal Web site, BehaviorGap.com.

title: Migrants in Israel Face Uncertainty, Despite Oscar
description: TEL AVIV  The children in the kindergarten class were taking their new celebrity status in stride on Monday, singing a Hebrew song about patience hours after a movie about their school, Bialik-Rogozin in south Tel Aviv, won the Academy Award for best short documentary in Los Angeles.

title: Optimistic Heart Patients Live Longer
description: Heart patients who were optimistic about their treatment and recovery were more likely to be alive after 15 years than patients with similar disease but lower expectations, new research shows.

title: At an Eerie Crossroads in Tripoli
description: Moises Saman is photographing in Libya on assignment for The New York Times. James Estrin spoke with him on Sunday. Their conversation has been edited and condensed.

title: Earthly Delights | The Slug and the Squirrel Terrariums
description: When Sara Moonves, Ts fashion editor, received a terrarium as a holiday gift, the entire office was smitten. This bijou oasis provided a moment of tranquility in the midst of the daily style department chaos. Incredibly low-maintenance (they only need to be watered once), terrariums are just the thing for urbanites like us who are strapped for space and yearning for a patch of greenery. Further inspired by Nocturne of the Limax maximus, the artist and landscape designer Paula Hayess recent installation of cast acrylic and hand-blown glass containers filled with tropical plants at the Museum of Modern Art, we wanted to know where we could get a mini-garden all our own.

title: Oil Drilling to Resume in the Gulfs Deep Waters
description: WASHINGTON  The Interior Department said Monday that it had approved the first new deepwater drilling permit in the Gulf of Mexico since the BP explosion and spill last spring, a milestone after a period of intense uncertainty for industry and a wholesale remaking of the nations system of offshore oil and gas regulation.

title: Netanyahu Warns on Settlements
description: JERUSALEM  Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu berated leaders of his conservative-leaning Likud Party on Monday after they pressed him for more settlement construction, telling them that Israel was under international pressure and operating in a complex new reality in the Middle East.

title: Numberplay: Lacing It Up
description: In todays puzzles, we have fun tying shoelaces. Most of you have probably spent a significant chunk of time carrying out this mundane activity, maybe a few months of your entire life when its all added up. Perhaps its even more if you wear lace boots. Done right, shoelaces add to the elegance of footwear. Not done right, they can trip you up or deprive you of an Olympic medal, as might have happened to the notorious ice-skater Tonya Harding in 1994. Nowadays, shoemakers use newfangled ways to make shoes secure, such as velcro fasteners or new space-age materials that need no fasteners at all. To us puzzle lovers, shoelaces provide a wealth of combinatorial delights. So I thought it was worth getting this puzzle out before shoelaces disappear entirely.

title: A New Service for Video Chatting on Facebook
description: For those who wish there were yet another way to connect with friends on computer screens, a new start-up called SocialEyes now offers video chatting through Facebook.

title: A War of Letters
description: 2:27 p.m. | Updated The Times published a followup story today on Duane R. Clarridges private spy network, reporting that the Federal Bureau of Investigation has been tapping the network for information about the killing of 10 medical aid workers in northern Afghanistan.

title: Behind the Scene: 'Timon of Athens'
description: Richard Thomas talks about and performs an excerpt from Shakespeare's drama, now at the Public Theater.

title: Photo Replay: Feb. 28
description: A look at the day in sports, including disappointment and delight at the Nordic world ski championships in Oslo.

title: Winter at City Ballet
description: Looking back at the winter season at New York City Ballet.

title: Holiday Bandit Crosses Hudson to Rob New Jersey Bank
description: The so-called Holiday Bandit, thought to have robbed seven banks in New York over the last three months, has struck again, according to the F.B.I. But this time he picked a target in New Jersey.

title: A Season of Many Singers in Jazz at Lincoln Center
description: As was the case last year, singers look to be an especially high priority among the bookings in Jazz at Lincoln Centers coming season. On Tuesday, the organization announced the new seasons schedule, which runs from this September through June 2012.

title: Finding the Subtle Humor and Whimsy in Haydn
description: The Argentine pianist Ingrid Fliter, in an interview about her recital at the 92nd Street Y on Sunday afternoon, described Haydns humor as an essential part of his music and an aspect she always tries to emphasize.

title: Treasury Names Buyout Executive to Ally Board
description: The Treasury Department said on Monday that it had named John D. Durrett as a director for Ally Financial, the former lending arm of General Motors, which received a taxpayer-financed bailout during the financial crisis.

title: Zimbabwe Activists May Have Been Tortured, Official Says
description: JOHANNESBURG  The United Nations torture investigator confirmed Monday that he had written the government of Zimbabwe to express concern about allegations that state security agents had assaulted the 45 activists who, after watching reports of the uprisings in Egypt and Tunisia, were recently detained and charged with treason.

title: Curtain Down, Heads Up: Readers Advice for Spider-Man
description: When word came out that the producers of Broadways Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark were considering delaying the musicals opening night for a sixth time, readers weighed in with constructive, urgent and humorous advice for the producers. Readers also had some feedback on an article about long-running Broadway shows moving to Off Broadway for extended runs. Following are excerpts of readers comments on these articles culled from this blog and The Timess theater coverage on Facebook and Twitter. Spider-Man Delayed Again?

title: Adding Ratings Injury to Critical Insult
description: LOS ANGELES One of the worst Oscar telecasts in history.Dead. In. The. Water.

title: Random House Adopts New Model for Selling E-Books
description: Beginning Tuesday, Random House will join other major book publishers in selling its e-books using the so-called agency model, setting its own prices for e-books while the retailer takes a commission.

title: Cantor Says House Will Defend Marriage Act
description: 6:00 p.m. | Updated With Republicans upset at the Obama administrations abandonment of the Defense of Marriage Act, Representative Eric Cantor, the Virginia Republican and majority leader, said on Monday that House Republicans would decide by the end of the week how to take action to make certain the law is defended against legal challenges.

title: In Milan, Pato Puts on a Show
description: On a day of few European games, A.C. Milans Alexandre Pato made the northern Italian night his own.

title: Russians Say Damaged Cooling Pump Is Cause of Delay in Starting Iranian Reactor
description: Russia on Monday explained why fuel is being removed from a nuclear reactor in Iran, delaying plans to start up the giant plant this month. The Russian account, the first official rationale, came after experts last week offered theories of the failure ranging from a startup glitch to foul play.

title: Go Easy on Yourself, a New Wave of Research Urges
description: Do you treat yourself as well as you treat your friends and family?

title: Critics Choice: New CDs
description: ADELE

title: China Issues Warning on Climate and Growth
description: BEIJING  Chinas environment minister on Monday issued an unusually stark warning about the effects of unbridled development on the countrys air, water and soil, saying the nations current path could stifle long-term economic growth and feed social instability.

title: Younger Audience Still Eludes the Oscars
description: LOS ANGELES  The Oscars tripped in their transition to a hipper, younger, media-mad future, attracting 12 percent fewer viewers than last year in the important 18-to-49 age bracket.

title: At City Ballet This Winter, You Could Sometimes See the Music
description: Though ballet is no better than other forms of dancing, its capacity for large-scale legibility have singular theatrical potency. Its shapes and lines beam far into space. When those geometries meet music, their union occurs not only in the bodies of the dancers: the music seems to animate the air around them. Paradoxically it is often felt more keenly by those in the uppermost rows of the theater than by those seated near the conductor. Ballet can turn music into physics; the connection of time and space becomes full of mysterious significance.

title: Critics' Picks: 'The Red Shoes'
description: A. O. Scott looks back at Michael Powell and Emeric Pressburger's film about artistic obsession.

title: Call It a Reversible Coma, Not Sleep
description: Dr. Emery Neal Brown, 54, is a professor of anesthesiology at Harvard Medical School, a professor of computational neuroscience at M.I.T. and a practicing physician, seeing patients at Massachusetts General Hospital. Between all that, he heads a laboratory seeking to unravel one of medicine’s big questions: how anesthesia works.

title: Famous, With Foot in Mouth
description: Charlie Sheen has an addiction.

title: Koch Plans to Make Redistricting Personal
description: ALBANY  Last year, Edward I. Koch placed automated telephone calls to voters on behalf of scores of candidates who signed his pledge to support redrawing Congressional and legislative districts in an independent, nonpartisan manner.

title: Video Raises Questions for Designer
description: PARIS  John Galliano, the chief designer for Christian Dior, faced fresh accusations on Monday of anti-Semitism after a video surfaced of Mr. Galliano appearing to deliver a tirade in a Paris bar.

title: With a Few Tweaks, Shaking Up History
description: The what if? genre of alternate history has attracted a disparate a crew of practitioners including Newt Gingrich (1945, written with William R. Forstchen), Philip Roth (The Plot Against America) and Philip K. Dick (The Man in the High Castle). Its yielded best sellers like Robert Harriss Fatherland and literary gems like Michael Chabons Yiddish Policemens Union. And its addressed staggering questions like: What if the Nazis won World War II? What if a group of time-traveling white supremacists from South Africa gave Robert E. Lees troops AK-47 assault rifles to help the Confederacy win the Civil War?

title: Few Winners Against the Oscars
description: Opposite ABCs coverage of the Academy Awards on Sunday night rival networks drew mostly meager audiences  even as the Oscars, according to Nielsens estimates, drew 37.6 million viewers, down from the 41.7 million who watched a year ago. CBS earned second place as it typically has on the night of the award show, garnering modest ratings early in prime time with 60 Minutes at 7 p.m. (8.4 million) and The Amazing Race at 8 (7.6 million). CBS broadcast a repeat of Undercover Boss at 9 (5.6 million) followed by CSI: Miami at 10 (8.2 million). Fox ranked third with reruns of its animated comedies, including an hourlong repeat of Family Guy at 9 (4.3 million). NBC was fourth with Dateline at 7 (4.7 million) and a three-hour marathon of Minute to Win It reruns, which averaged 2.9 million viewers.

title: Remapping Computer Circuitry to Avert Impending Bottlenecks
description: PALO ALTO, Calif.  Hewlett-Packard researchers have proposed a fundamental rethinking of the modern computer for the coming era of nanoelectronics  a marriage of memory and computing power that could drastically limit the energy used by computers.

title: N.Y. Classroom Scores 100 (That Is, 100% PCBs)
description: As the Bloomberg administration seeks to firm up its plans to replace light fixtures containing the toxic chemicals known as PCBs in nearly 800 city school buildings, federal officials said Monday that the latest school inspection revealed the highest levels of the toxic chemicals yet.

title: Judging Napa Cabernets Class of 2007
description: EVEN in Napa Valley, where only the rare vintage is spoken of in less than superlatives, 2007 was considered nearly perfect for cabernet sauvignon. Wine Spectator rated it 99 on its 100-point scale, while other commentators, perhaps exhibiting more caution, used words like splendid and extraordinary.

title: Pictures of the Day: Libya and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Libya, Oman, Bolivia and Ivory Coast

title: Asked and Answered | Manolo Blahnik
description: Tonight is the first performance of the new Broadway musical Priscilla Queen of the Desert. Just like the film that inspired it, the show is a whirlwind of over-the-top costumes, industrial-strength makeup and riotous musical numbers as Priscilla and the girls travel across Australia on a tour bus with a towering heel topper. But just in case you thought it couldnt get any more fabulous than the movie, Manolo Blahnik has designed a custom pair of stilettos for the show.

title: Pictures of the Day: Libya and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Libya, Oman, Bolivia and Ivory Coast.

title: Anne Hathaway at the Oscars
description: At the 83rd annual Academy Awards ceremony, the actress changed her outfit seven times, outdressing many of the starlets in attendance.

title: In China, Security Muffles Calls for Change
description: BEIJING  The call to action shot across mobile phones and Internet chat sites, urging people to converge on 13 Chinese cities to demand an end to corruption, inflation and the strictures of authoritarian rule. The Chinese people do not have the patience to wait any longer, said one message.

title: New York Times/CBS News Poll: Collective Bargaining
description: The complete results of a New York Times/CBS News poll on support for collective bargaining.

title: Majority in Poll Back Employees in Public Sector Unions
description: As labor battles erupt in state capitals around the nation, a majority of Americans say they oppose efforts to weaken the collective bargaining rights of public employee unions and are also against cutting the pay or benefits of public workers to reduce state budget deficits, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.

title: U.S. Plans for Trade Are Stalled
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama has made expanding exports a centerpiece of his plan for accelerating the economic recovery, but in recent weeks, his trade agenda has nearly ground to a halt amid partisan feuding.

description: To the Editor:

title: On a Plane, and Glad to Be Carrying Wine
description: THE whole frequent-flying experience makes me laugh. Its just that so many weird things happen, and since I fly so much, the weird things happen a lot.

title: In Maya Burials, Unsettling Clues
description: Daniela Triadan, an associate professor of anthropology at the University of Arizona, writes from Guatemala, where she and Takeshi Inomata are excavating the Maya site of Ceibal.

title: My Unhealthy Diet? It Got Me This Far
description: SOMETIMES I cant believe what my 82-year-old mother has been eating. Living now in a retirement home in Durham, N.C., she told me she recently had cherry cobbler for breakfast. Apparently shed had French toast stuffed with bananas and Nutella for lunch the day before, and after lunch had gone to dessert theater (You know, like dinner theater, but with desserts), where shed gobbled down a lot of cookies. So when they served cherry cobbler for dessert that night in the dining room,  I thought, I better take this back to my room and eat it tomorrow. For breakfast.

title: Health Care REIT to Buy Genesis Real Estate for $2.4 Billion
description: Health Care REIT said Monday that it had agreed to buy the real estate of Genesis HealthCare for $2.4 billion, in the second major health care real estate deal of the day.

title: Amuse-Bouche | Stoking the Appetite for Paris Fashion Week
description: Paris Fashion Week is less than 24 hours away, and although there is still Oscar buzz about Natalies win in Rodarte and Cates incredible Givenchy couture, the anticipation is building for the last leg of the fashion show marathon. Kickoff begins tomorrow with Hakaans second Paris show. Daria and Natalia walked the runway there last year, so expect the casting to set the bar high.

title: On Our Radar: Small Nuclear War Would Cool Globe, Scientists Say
description: Even a small nuclear war  one involving only 100 Hiroshima-sized bombs  would cause catastrophic global cooling, reduced rainfall and widespread damage to agriculture, a new report by federal scientists finds. Explosions from the bombs, representing just 0.03 percent of the global nuclear stockpile, would throw approximately five million tons of black carbon into the upper atmosphere, blocking sunlight and causing a plunge in temperature equivalent to a massive volcanic eruption. [National Geographic]

title: Americas (and the Worlds) Least Wanted
description: There are way too many official years, weeks, and days focused just on the environment, let alone all the other issues needing attention these days.

title: A 4G Network That Delivers 4G
description: Since marketers began to apply the term 4G to anything with a chip and a network, it has become hard to know what 4G really is. But heres a step toward restoring its meaning.

title: How the Poll Was Conducted
description: The latest New York Times/CBS News poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Feb. 24-27 with 984 adults throughout the United States.
